Microsoft acknowledged its engineers included a secret password in some of its Internet software that could be used to gain access to websites globally , the Wall Street Journal said Friday .
The article said the manager of Microsoft 's security-response center Steve Lipner " acknowledged the online-security risk " and said such a backdoor password is against the company 's policy .
The employees had not yet been identified .
There have been no reports that the alleged security flaw has been exploited , the article said .
The computer code , part of which was the comment that Netscape rivals " are weenies , " was discovered by two security experts .
Lipner said in the article that the software giant will warn the largest website providers in the U.S. directly about the flaw .
A Microsoft spokesman was not immediately available for comment .




Crypto-Convict Will n't Recant

Before Jim Bell went to prison , he suspected that most government officials were corrupt .
Three years behind bars later , the self-proclaimed Internet anarchist is sure of it .
After Bell , a cypherpunk who the United States government dubbed a techno-terrorist , is released Friday at 10 a.m. PDT , he plans to exact revenge on the system that imprisoned him .
" If they continue to work for the government , they deserve it .
My suggestion to these people is to quit now and hope for mercy , " the 41-year-old Washington state native said in a telephone interview this week from the medium-security federal penitentiary in Phoenix .
Bell pleaded guilty to tax evasion in 1997 .
The retribution he has in mind ?
Well , it 's decidedly not simple thuggery or wild-eyed ranting .
Before he was arrested , the MIT graduate even gave his scheme a catchy title : " Assassination Politics . "
It 's an unholy mix of encryption , anonymity , and digital cash to bring about the ultimate annihilation of all forms of government .
The system , which Bell spent years talking up online , uses digital cash and anonymity to predict and confirm assassinations .
Darkly brooding during his stints in solitary confinement , Bell has honed his idea to a knife-sharp edge , and seems to have shed any remaining scruples in the process .
" I once believed it 's too bad that there are a lot of people who work for government who are hard-working and honest people who will get hit and it 's a shame , " he says . "
by Assassination Politics
Well , I do n't believe that any more .
They are all either crooks or they tolerate crooks or they are aware of crooks among their numbers . "
That kind of fervid rhetoric comes close to crossing the line , says one former prosecutor . "
It 's an oblique threat , " says Mark Rasch , now a lawyer at Science Applications International Corporation . "
Depending on how immediate the threat is or how immediate the incitement is , it could violate federal law . "
And Assassination Politics ?
If Bell tries to set it up , will he end up back in Club Fed ? "
Now you 're getting closer to the line that says , ' I will pay you to kill a federal agent .
' Even though it 's indirect , it has the same effect , " Rasch says .
U.S. law punishes " any threat to injure the person of another " with a five-year prison sentence .
Robb London , the assistant United States Attorney for the Western District of Washington , did not immediately return phone calls .




Ericsson Wins Top Pirelli Prize

MILAN , Italy -- Ericsson Medialab of Sweden won Pirelli 's annual INTERNETional Award for multimedia works with Warriors of the Net , a movie about how the Internet works .
Ericsson was awarded the US$ 15,000 first prize for " their highly successful effort in explaining the functioning of the Internet by utilizing state-of-the-art multimedia tools : high-level screenplay , graphics , and original subject have made this work one of the most powerful examples of contemporary digital art , " according to Pirelli officials .
The movie shows a dark technological underworld where an information packet is launched by a personal mail-room and travels along the highways of a LAN .
On its way to the Net , the packet encounters routers , router switches , and firewalls .
" We started out by going through the basics about TCP/IP and how it works , " said Tomas Stephanson of Ericsson . "
I tried to get a grip on the elementary parts and how to visualize them in an effective manner . "
Martin Goldman of the United States won the second prize for Physics 2000 , a Web site illustrating an interactive journey through modern physics .
With lots of applets and animations , the site explores the secrets of the atomic world , and explains X-rays , microwave ovens , lasers , waves , and quantum mechanics .
Third prize went to Human Sexuality , an informative Web site on human sexuality , by Gisele Grinevicius Garbe of Brazil .
Another U.S. work -- Atomic Archive -- by A.J. Software & Multimedia won the prize for the CD-ROM section .
The CD-ROM explores the complex history surrounding the invention of the atomic bomb .
Instructions for submitting multimedia works such as movies , Websites , hypertexts , animations , sounds , for next year 's awards can be found on the PirelliAward .
The final deadline is September 30 , 2000 .




Huge Kid Porn Ring Busted

Editor 's note : This story was updated on April 18 , after its original publication on April 14 .
Underneath a monstrous heap of electronic kiddie porn , federal prosecutors have uncovered a suburban Texas couple , three foreign webmasters , and thousands of customers worldwide who left behind a trail of credit card charges totaling $ 1 million .
Federal prosecutors , who watched with glee as a grand jury handed down an 87-count indictment against the peddlers Thursday , say they 've never had such a big case .
U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of Texas Paul Coggins said the case is a major step forward in a high-stakes fight against the people who sexually abuse children and sell images of the abuse on the Web .
Catching the webmaster , he said , makes finding their victims a real possibility .
" Where these webmasters are establishing sites could well be where these scenes of sexual abuse take place , " Coggins said .
Prosecutors say the children in this case are 4-12 years old . "
These kids are being scarred for life somewhere , someone needs to be prosecuting . "
and
The indictment charges Fort Worth 's Thomas and Janice Reedy with operating a commercial kid porn ring from their home .
According to the Texas Secretary of State , the Reedys incorporated their company , called Landslide , Inc. , on Feb. 13 , 1997 .
Prosecutors say Landslide acted as the " gatekeeper " between one Russian and two Indonesian webmasters who supplied customers with pornographic images of children in exchange for US$ 29.95 per site .
Landslide supplied the password-protected access to the sites -- including childrenforcedtoporn.com , childrape.com , and childrenofgod.com -- and handled the credit card transactions .
Those charges left behind a handy trail of evidence for prosecutors , who say the Reedys made $ 1,111,266 in less than a year .
They kept a third of the profits and sent the rest to the foreign webmasters .
People close to the case said the size of the Reedys ' business was enormous .
" The extent of the kiddie porn business , the scope of the customers , they are spread across the states and across the globe , shocked me , " Coggins said .
and the fact that
Lead prosecutor Terri Moore agreed , calling the scope of the operation " absolutely frightening . "
" I 'm a seasoned prosecutor and I was appalled , I was floored , " she said .
Parry Aftab , director of anti-child pornography group Cyberangels , called Landslide a major commercial scheme , setting it apart from most child pornography on the Internet , which is not commercial .
" This is a very , very important case , " she said . "
For child pornography , this is as important as the World Trade Center bombing . "
Without commenting specifically on Landslide , Aftab said commercial rings are extremely dangerous and even deadly for the children who are targeted . "
They are particularly heinous , " she said . "
Many of them kill the children after they abuse them .
They use foreign children , from Eastern Europe and South America .
It is the kind of world you can n't imagine . "
The Reedys , who are being held in federal prison until a detention hearing next week , have been forced to take down their alleged kid porn , and most of the sites they once operated are now out of service .
But they 're still using the landslide.com site to assert their innocence .
" We have committed no illegal act , and are confident to be found innocent of any such charges , " the site reads .




From iBash to iBusted

Last October , Michael Fenne , founder and former chairman of Pixelon.com , presided over the most extravagant Net start-up bash in the short , self-indulgent history of decadent dot-com shindigs .
For the Las Vegas event , dubbed iBash ' 99 , Fenne rented out the MGM Grand ; hired a slew of top-drawer recording artists including Kiss , The Dixie Chicks , Sugar Ray , and Brian Setzer ; and , to cap it off , paid top-dollar for a reunion performance by The Who .
All of the performances were broadcast over the Net , ostensibly to showcase Pixelon 's Web video technology .
The total price tag : $ 12 million , a hefty chunk of the $ 35 million-worth of venture capital financing Fenne had rounded up for Pixelon .
Today , Michael Fenne is sitting in a jail cell in Wise County , Virginia .
There he 's known by his real name , David Stanley .
Until Wednesday , he also was known as one of Virginia 's most-wanted fugitives , a bogus stockbroker who skipped bail in the mid-1990s after he was convicted of swindling clients out of more than $ 1 million .
Stanley turned himself in Wednesday after Virginia police , alerted by a tipster , called Stanley 's San Bernardino , California , home to tell him the jig was up , authorities said Friday .
" We called him and said , ' Hey , we know you 're there , ' on April 11th , and he turned himself in the next night , " said Capt. Terry Bowes , assistant director of the Virginia State Police Bureau of Investigation .
Pixelon employees were shocked by the news .
" It all happened really quickly , " a spokeswoman said . "
There was really no warning . "
Fenne/Stanley had been replaced as Pixelon 's chairman last winter by disgruntled venture capitalists on the company 's board .
Pixelon 's corporate officers and board of directors were in an emergency meeting Friday and could not immediately be reached for comment .




Who 's Richer , Larry or Bill ?

A couple of years back , a book with the following title hit the bestseller 's list : The Difference Between God and Larry Ellison* .
* God Does n't Think He 's Larry Ellison
Tuesday , perhaps , or maybe Wednesday , it may be time to offer up a second descriptive question/answer string for Ellison , bad-boy billionaire chairman and CEO of database king Oracle : The Difference Between Bill Gates and Larry Ellison* .
* Larry Ellison Has More Money
Yup , that 's right .
Larry Ellison , the man who lands his private jet after-hours in San Jose and sues when the city tries to stop him , is poised to take the title of world 's richest man from his hated arch-rival in Redmond .
At the close of the market Monday , Ellison 's 690 million Oracle shares were worth $ 51.6 billion -- a mere $ 4.6 billion less than Gates ' $ 56.2 billion , 741 million-share , Microsoftian fortune .
both men have other assets , but we 're ignoring those for the sake of over-simplification
While $ 4.6 billion may seem like a hefty sum to mere mortals , consider this : A surge in Oracle 's shares on Monday piled nearly $ 8 billion onto Ellison 's mountain of wealth .
Bill Gates ' booty , by contrast , has dwindled by some $ 30 billion in the last three weeks , thanks in no small part to the antitrust assault Ellison helped orchestrate .
Gates declined comment on his shifting fortunes , and Ellison could not be reached .
If Larry does topple Bill , however , the world can expect a lot more old-fashioned , alpha-male , rich-guy behavior from its top financial dog .
While pasty-faced Bill tinkers with code , works 80-hour weeks -- and figures out a way to guide his company through the antitrust mess -- exquisitely tailored , libidinous Larry consummates email affairs , flits about the world on yachting adventures , and lands his $ 38 million private jet wherever and whenever he feels like it , thank you very much .
" There 's a side to him that -- well , let 's just say I understand why he 's been married three times , " said Elizabeth Ferrarini , a marketing consultant who claims to have had a personal relationship with Ellison .
" His attitude is , ' I 'll do what I want to do , and I do n't give a s**t about you .
I can buy anything and do anything -- I can s**t on the floor and hire someone to clean it up .
' "
Added David Vossbrink , spokesman for San Jose Mayor Ron Gonzales : " I know that Larry Ellison has a unique view of the rules and regulations at the airport , but nothing is quite as simple as it looks from the vantage of 30,000 feet , or $ 51 billion . "
But boy , do Oracle shareholders love him .
Since last May , Oracle 's stock has jumped 670 percent .




Investors ' IRS Bill Sharp as Tax

NEW YORK -- Goodbye wealth effect , hello tax collector .
At least that 's how it must seem to some investors whose active trading and stock profits left them flush with cash last year and with a big tax bill this year .
" People are shocked when they see the tax rate , " said James Weikart , head of Weikart Tax Associates .
Taxes on gains from securities held more than a year total no more than 20 percent .
But active investing , in which people eagerly locked in profits made over short periods of time , can generate gains on which the tax bill rises to 39.6 percent .
" Given the number of people who became very active traders in 1999 and the rapid appreciation of so many technology and Internet stocks , a lot of individual investors were shocked at the bill that has come due this week , " said James Capozzola , senior director of research at Individual Investor magazine and IndividualInvestor.com .
" I 've had tons of experience with people being overwhelmed with their capital gains , " said David Tysk , senior financial advisor at American Express in Minneapolis .
Tysk said those profits were generated not so much by day trading in the stock market , but by mutual funds " which last year kicked out an enormous amount of capital gains . "
Tysk said his clients ' tax liability for capital gains generated by mutual funds were higher in 1998 than in 1997 and higher in 1999 than in 1998 .
" People are finding that their quarterly estimates of taxes owed were n't big enough ; and if they were n't doing them at all , they have a big tax bill , " Tysk said .
The reactions , he said , are " shock . Panic .
And then , ' What do we do to come up with some money ?
' "
For many clients , the only way to raise enough money to pay the tax bill is to sell something , Tysk said .
But it 's not always that simple .
" In the last couple of weeks , I 've seen three or four people who 've been under tremendous stress because they owe taxes on money they made , but no longer have , because the market has gone down , " Weikart said . "
They have n't been under pressure to pay their taxes until now . "
But while some individual investors have had to sell stock holdings to pay capital gains taxes , equity market analysts said that selling had played little or no role in the stock market 's recent retreat .
" The pressure on the stock market commenced with Microsoft 's problems , increased margin calls throughout the market , and mounting worries about how many interest rate hikes lie ahead , " said Alan Ackerman , executive vice president at Fahnstock & Co. Inc. "
The confluence of those elements took a big bite out of optimism and caused the market to turn tail . "




The Icebergs Breaketh

WELLINGTON , New Zealand -- In 1956 , you had to be aboard the U.S.S. Glacier , then the U.S. Navy 's most powerful icebreaker , to see the massive hulk of an Antarctic iceberg .
In 2000 , you can keep tabs on one simply by checking out the latest satellite images on your computer .
In the past few weeks , four massive icebergs , including one that is among the biggest ever , have broken free in Antarctica . "
It 's a natural occurrence but on this scale it 's unusual , " says Dr. Dean Peterson , science strategy manager at the New Zealand Antarctic Institute .
The massive B15 iceberg , and the also-large B16 , B17 , and B18 , all are calved from the Ross Ice Shelf , formed by ice streams flowing off the Antarctic ice sheet .
The naming of icebergs is eminently practical : B15 is the 15th iceberg to be tracked from the " B " quadrant of Antarctica , which is 90 degrees west to 180 degrees .
Matthew Lazzara , a meteorologist at the University of Wisconsin 's Antarctic Meteorology Research Center , has been one of the iceberg 's monitors .
He tracks icebergs from pictures taken by polar orbiting satellites operated by the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration and the Defense Meteorological Satellite Program .
" When the satellite flies over McMurdo , the data 's available , " he said . "
I can get access to it within minutes of it flying over . "
He also mixes in pictures from geo-stationary satellites , which observe " the full disk " of Earth . "
We combine all of the satellites to make a composite , mosaic image over the Antarctic and Southern Ocean .
It is a specialty of the AMRC . "
Lazzara receives about 10 to 12 pictures every day , posting the best to the AMRC website . "
That was wonderful , to be able to get them out to the world , " he said .
But in fact , it 's not just tracking the icebergs that 's important . "
We do n't really care where it goes , unless it happens to block up a base , " says Dr. Harry Keys , a scientist at New Zealand 's Department of Conservation .
More crucially , the movement of the icebergs act as a guide to the tides and currents around Antarctica , which still are not well understood .
" In terms of global climate change , they are one of the drivers for moving heat around , " Keys said .
currents




Winning at the Inventing Game

Bob Olodort is the brains behind the amazing folding keyboard for Palm handhelds .
The full-size Palm Foldable keyboard , which magically folds up into a neat portable package , looks set to be a smash .
But for years Olodort struggled as an independent inventor .
In an interview with Wired News , Olodort describes how he got started in the inventing game .
He discusses how the keyboard allowed him to launch his own design company , Think Outside , and the amazing risk he took with an earlier model .
And Olodort hints at the work he is doing on much smaller designs for cell phones and the next generation of wireless handheld computers .
Wired News : Where did you get the idea for the folding keyboard ?
Bob Olodort : It was the realization six or seven years ago that computers would become commodities .
That they would be very small , very powerful and very low-cost .
But as a touch typist I realized the input technology would be sorely lacking .
So I started looking into all kinds of input technology .
I rejected pen-recognition and I rejected voice-recognition .
...
So I came back to the keyboard and I started working on all kinds of designs .
I realized it had to be very small and open up to full size .
So I started looking at things with no moving parts : virtual keyboards with light beams that look at your fingertips and other types of digitizers that could tell pressure .
None of these worked well because they all required new learning or unnatural movements .
WN : How much time did you spend on these early prototypes ?
Olodort : Years .
I worked on a number of things at once .
But I would say four years .
WN : And you built these things ?
Olodort : Yeah .
Some were thought projects .
Some were breadboard models .
Some were working electrical models .
WN : How many do you think you built ?
Olodort : Say 10 .
I looked at chordal keyboards that would be very small and had 10 keys or five keys that were like chords , like when you play the piano .
WN : Like a stenographers keyboard ?
Olodort : Kind of .
Again , they 're small but they require learning .
I rejected that .
The last thing I was hopeful about but I rejected was thin membrane keyboards which could be rolled up or folded up .
WN : With bubble-type keys ?
Olodort : Yeah .
There are a couple out there but they 're awful .
It 's like typing on your microwave oven .
You can n't type quickly .
WN : So you spent four years and you finally came back to this -- the traditional keyboard ?
Olodort : Yeah .
I finally came up with a design .
It was purely mechanical and it had 3 millimeter movement , just like the current design , and it was 100 percent full-size .
But it folded up on scissors linkages .
It was really magical .
Like an accordion , you pull it open and you close it .
WN : How many links did it have ?
Olodort : Hundreds .
I forget .
Maybe 600 .
WN : How big a package did it fold into ?
Olodort : Bigger than we have now .
The same footprint but maybe two or three times as thick .
The tricky part is that it has the same layout as a keyboard , which has staggered keys and some keys are bigger than others .
So it took a lot of cleverness to figure out .
And I hand-made it .
I had several schemes , but basically it measured resistance to establish which key is being pushed .




Balkan War in Domain Attacks ?

Domain-name hijackers are taking over hundreds of websites in a campaign that may be rooted in tensions among Balkan states , site owners and monitors say .
Individuals listing Serbian and Albanian postal addresses in recent weeks have exploited a weakness in registrar Network Solutions and appropriated names registered through the company , officials there said .
Domain takeovers enable the hijacker to control the server associated with a domain name , such as Viagra.com or Indianajones.com .
Hijackers can then reassign the domain name to another Web server , or to no server at all , scuttling all traffic intended to go to the site .
This latest round of mass hijackings could be random hacking or part of a fledgling Balkan info-war , but since online identities can be easily spoofed , it 's hard to know for sure .
Network Solutions spokeswoman Cheryl Regan confirmed that many domains had recently been " redirected " to a registrant listing an Albanian address , but refused to pinpoint the exact number of affected domains beyond " considerably less than 2,000 . "
WebDNS , a domain-name system-monitoring service based in England , reported Thursday that at least 50 domain names have been attacked since April 9 , including Adidas.com , Jamesbond.com , Mafia.com , France.com , Italy.com , Spain.com , Slovenia.com , Croatia.com , Sarajevo.com , Kosova.com , Washington.com , and Bosnia.com .
" We have been in contact with owners of some of the domain names affected and have found the companies were either not aware of the situation or had been alerted by the fact services were failing , " said WebDNS founder Alex Jeffreys . "
Many had been in touch with Network Solutions and were in the process of having the domain re-transferred . "
Among the victimized sites were those run by pro-democracy groups and other Web publications maintained by Serbian political opponents , such as Montenegro.com and Bosnia.com , both of which have since been returned to their owners .
Hijackers have targeted Internet domain names belonging to Montenegran pro-democracy activists and to news and information sites , said Montenegro.com owner Alex Obradovic , who runs Montenegro.com and related domains from Los Angeles to cover developments in Montenegro .
Obradovic is convinced the hijacking is the work of hackers conducting an electronic attack on Montenegro , Serbia 's smaller sister republic in the Yugoslav federation .
Using electronic tracing tools , he determined that the Internet service hosting the hijackers is based in the Serbian capital of Belgrade .
He says the possibility that hackers were dialing into the service 's account from outside Serbia is " unlikely . "
Network Solutions was able to return the domains to Obradovic before any changes were made , he said .
But other Balkan-related domains , including Slovenia.com and Croatia.com have been hijacked for weeks and remain so , he said .
Late Friday , the Slovenia.com domain carried the message : " KOSOVO IS SERBIA Site hacked BYGreb-a-Thor and ScsiMaster .
...
Be happy if we hacked your site because we hack ONLY the best sites on the Internet ! "
Obradovic suspects the hijackers are trying to undermine the spread of information in Montenegro as part of a propaganda war .
Network Solutions ' Regan would not comment on the possible info-war motive , nor confirm the likely geographical origins of the hijacking campaign . "
We can not address specifics of our active investigation of this domain-name attack , " she said .
Regan said many of the hijacked domains had since been returned to their original owners .
But a registry search early Friday showed that at least 50 domains still listed the hijackers ' phony contact name , justdoit@megapost.net .




Going Out of Dot Commission ?

PALO ALTO , California -- No company has an easy time swallowing a decline of 50 percent or more in its stock price , but when a company has no profits , limited cash , and uses its shares as a virtual currency to pay employees and fund expansion , such a drop can be crippling .
That was the situation facing many online retailers even before the overall market slumped last week .
Now , with their already depressed stock prices taking another beating , the long-expected shakeout seems to be imminent .
" They have to figure out a new way to fund their growth , " says Michael Murphy , president of Murphy Investment Management in Half Moon Bay , California . "
Most of these guys are n't profitable and the game 's over when you run out of cash . "
Much has been made of the distinction between leaders in the online retail sector , such as Amazon.com , and all the would-be Amazons that are not nearly so well established , or so well-funded .
But in many ways , all of these e-tailers , big and small , have been thrust into crisis mode .
Not a single publicly traded e-tailing company is profitable , and none of them appear to have enough cash to last until that unspecified time in the future when they will start to make money , Murphy said .
Online grocer Webvan , for instance , is one of the best-funded among them , with an enviable $ 540 million in cash .
But Webvan expects that money to last only through the end of the year , and says its operating losses will last somewhat longer .
If nine months-worth of cash on hand was once regarded as a healthy reserve , it no longer looks like that much , now that markets have soured on the e-tail sector and IPOs and secondary offerings are often being canceled .
As investors lose faith in e-tail businesses , it not only becomes harder for these companies to raise more money , but it poses the added challenge of how they can retain employees who are paid in large part with stock options .
" Obviously , the stock price decline is a concern , " says Mitch Hill , chief financial officer of the online superstore Buy.com .
The company , whose stock has lost more than half its value since its initial public offering two months ago , has seen some staff turnover in recent months , Hill says .




Hey , Babe , Want To Call ...
Chad ?

Editor 's note : This story was modified on April 28 to clarify the identities of the presidents of Alchemy Communications and Babenet .
Tore Loding wishes he never heard of adultbuffet.com .
That 's because a few weeks after a romp one night through that site 's adult offerings , the 24-year-old San Francisco State University journalism student got a $ 357 phone bill that made him consider swearing off pornographic websites .
Like an increasing number of scammed surfers , Loding , by clicking through an agreement attached to a movie he wanted to download , inadvertently took with it a piece of software that reset his modem and dialed a number in Chad , a country in central Africa .
The program , dirtymovies.exe , came with an agreement , which Loding clicked through without reading . "
I do n't know if I was drunk or whatever , I thought it was just some sort of privacy agreement , " he said .
Drunk or not , he 's still responsible for the charges , attributed to two mysterious 31-minute calls to Chad .
AT&T spokeswoman Lee Ann Kuster said the company has received a significant number of complaints about these kinds of charges , " enough to get our attention and put it on our radar screen , " she said .
AT&T even issued a customer warning last week about it .
But while the company feels its customers ' pain , it still wants to get paid .
" The bottom line is that customers are responsible for the calls made from their home .
The charges are sustained , " she said .
But $ 357 ?
" Why does an adult movie have to be downloaded from Chad ? "
Loding wants to know . "
It does n't make sense to me at all .
I think maybe it 's some deal with the phone company . "
He might be right .
The desolate , landlocked country , which has one of the lowest per capita incomes in the world , has a very primitive telecommunications system .
And it does n't make a lot of money from it .
So striking a deal with a U.S.-based Internet company , adult in nature or not , may not seem like such a bad idea .
A spokesman at the Embassy for the Republic of Chad in Washington said the country 's government had never heard of these telephone calls , and offered no further comment .
In fact , it was difficult to find out anything from anyone who might be involved or responsible .
A spokesman from Adultbuffet.com who would only identify himself as " Brad " said his company was not responsible for the charges Loding received , because the link he clicked on was owned by another site .
Adultbuffet , he said , is simply a collection of other adult sites .
Adultbuffet is registered to All World Creations , a company that filed for a license in Atlanta as a book dealer .
According to the county business office , the company is not operating with a license in Atlanta , and neither All World Creations nor Adultbuffet have filed papers with the Georgia Secretary of State .
On Wednesday , the page on the site that contains the movie Loding downloaded was registered to Abovenet , a San Jose , California-based bandwidth provider that said it provided services to Nonstopnet , a Walnut Creek , California , company .
Nonstopnet spokeswoman Johnette Stubbs said her company had nothing to do with Adultbuffet.com , and shifted the blame to Skyhosting.com , the company she says really hosts Adultbuffet.com . "
We have nothing to do with their site at all , " she said .
Skyhosting.com appears to be closely affiliated with Nonstopnet , according to information posted on its own website and filed with Network Solutions .
Minutes after denying a relationship , Stubbs called back to say she had just spoken with Skyhosting and " they are no longer hosting Adultbuffet . "
Lynn Macias , another Nonstopnet spokeswoman , said when the company learned of Skyhosting 's affiliation with Adultbuffet , it was dropped . "
I think that 's unbelievable that they were running that , " she said . "
We had no idea they were running that little scam , that 's not within our business model . "
By Thursday afternoon , the site had been picked up by Hitter Communications , an ISP in Hernando , Florida .
But a call to Andrew Cook , the registered contact at Hitter , revealed that he was no longer with the company .
Company officials said they would act immediately to discharge the site from their control .
Now the only company left that will admit to hosting the adult smorgasbord known as Adultbuffet is Flying Crocodile , a Seattle company that hosts 60,000 adult sites .




MS to Execs : ' We Want You '

SEATTLE -- Microsoft Corp. said Monday it is offering fatter stock option packages , more vacation time , and loftier titles to top executives as the software giant moves to staunch the flow of talent from its offices to startup companies .
Upping the ante against young Internet and technology firms that are luring programmers and managers with lucrative stock deals , Microsoft has sweetened its own stock option packages , said company spokeswoman Kimberely Kuresman .
While Kuresman declined to comment on the details of such packages , she said a story in Monday 's Wall Street Journal accurately portrayed the new rewards system .
A handful of high-level executives had been offered the chance to buy as many as 200,000 shares of Microsoft stock , and some options packages were at least five times bigger than normal , the newspaper said .
" Microsoft is committed to being competitive in offering packages that retain the best talent , " Kuresman said . "
Microsoft is constantly looking at ways to be competitive in the industry . "
Microsoft has been hit in recent months by several high-level departures , including its chief financial officer , who joined a Canadian fiber-optics company , and several executives from its Internet division , who started an investment firm to boost wireless technology .
In further moves to show its appreciation , Microsoft also recently promoted several dozen employees , bestowing on them the titles of vice-president or " distinguished engineer " -- a new title aimed at honoring technical wizards who do n't aspire to management jobs .
" It was created to recognize Microsoft 's top technical leaders ... who have made great contributions to Microsoft technology and who will continue to do so in the future , " Kuresman said .
The promotions occurred over the past few months , with several coming at the end of March , when Microsoft announced a reorganization to focus more on the Internet , Kuresman said .
Other perks include more vacation time to make it easier for executives to balance their work loads with family life , she said , adding that Microsoft has long offered things like discounts to Seattle-area events and attractions , and outings for children of employees .
" They understand that work is n't everthing for people , " she said . "
They 're also looking at adding to the work-life balance programs they offer employees . "
Shares in Microsoft rose 11/16 to 74-13/16 in active trading mid-afternoon on the Nasdaq .
MSFT
The company 's stock , which flew skyward in the 1990s and transformed thousands of employees into millionaires , has fallen from a year high of nearly 120 in February , battered by antitrust woes and recent bearish market sentiment .




The Cosmos Is Coming

Researchers at Microsoft are working on an ambitious Internet database that will make the data from massive surveys of the cosmos available to anyone with a Web browser .
The project is the first in a series of initiatives to bring to the public " virtual telescopes " that scientists are saying will herald perhaps the greatest revolution in the history of astronomy .
" It will totally change the way we do astronomy today , " said Alex Szalay , an astronomy professor at Johns Hopkins University .
When it comes online in six months to a year , Microsofts SkyServer will be the astronomical equivalent of the company 's popular TerraServer , which catalogs aerial images of the Earth and is one of the biggest databases on the Internet .
In the same way users of the TerraServer choose a region of the planet and drill down for pictures of the ground at ever greater resolution , users of the SkyServer will be able choose a region of the sky and probe deeper and deeper into space .
The data will come from several ongoing sky surveys , including the Sloan Digital Sky Survey , an automated survey of the cosmos that plans to catalog 200 million celestial objects over the next several years .
Some of these astronomy databases will be massive .
The Sloan survey is expected to generate 40 terabytes of data .
The Library of Congress , by contrast , is about 2 terabytes .
Microsoft is building the SkyServer from off-the-shelf PCs and software .
A prototype is already up and running .
But unlike the TerraServer , which is essentially a collection of unprocessed pictures , the SkyServer data will be somewhat " cooked " -- analyzed and catalogued -- allowing members of the public to do science with the data .
" This changes the equation for astronomy , " said Jim Gray , a senior researcher at Microsoft Research who is heading up the SkyServer project . "
Anyone will be able to look through one of the worlds best telescopes . "
But the Microsoft project is just the tip of the iceberg .
In the next few years , astronomers are hoping to use the Internet and the vast amounts of astronomical data that is streaming in from surveys like the Sloan to create " virtual telescopes " accessible to anyone with a PC and Net connection .




DNA Testing Furor in Wee Waa

SYDNEY , Australia -- A 44-year-old local laborer has been charged in connection with the rape of a 91-year-old woman in a small town , following a DNA testing program for most of the town 's 600 men .
The New Year 's Eve 1998 sexual attack on the woman shocked tiny Wee Waa in northern New South Wales .
As a result , most of the town 's 1,900 residents supported the DNA testing program .
Many saw it as a way to catch a perpetrator many feared still walked unpunished in their midst , casting a Twin Peaks-like pall over local life .
On Monday afternoon , the man walked into Wee Waa police station , asking to speak with detectives .
He was later charged in the case , and was being held without bail .
Police would n't confirm whether he had contributed a DNA sample during the testing program , saying that would have violated the program 's confidentiality .
" We were hoping we 'd get a breakthrough of this nature , " said John Gillett , regional police superintendent . "
The assistance and community support we got helped a lot . "
While the latest developments led to sighs of relief , many worry the DNA testing program sets an ugly precedent for future investigations in which personal privacy is forfeited under community pressure .
While most of the town 's men willingly came forward to give samples , holdouts were scorned .
Over time , civil libertarians worry such testing programs could shift the focus of police work toward presuming potential suspects guilty until cleared , rather than innocent until implicated .
For his part , Gillett says any curbs on forensic DNA technology are something the legal system must decide .
" We 're cutting new ground here , " he said . "
All of these issues and procedures will be tested in the courts . "
This week 's developments took place just as the local testing program was nearing completion , with only a few principled opponents and those recently out of town still to be tested .
The samples are being held in a government laboratory in Sydney , which had only just begun comparisons of the samples with those taken from the crime scene .
Now that someone 's been charged in the case , Gillett said the testing program will be suspended .
He took pains to stress that all samples and records will eventually be destroyed and donors notified in writing .
David Sweeney , a local attorney who from the start refused to give a sample , said that the case presents large societal issues .
" We need to work in the coming years to see how DNA technology can work toward -- rather than against -- society 's goal of avoiding witch hunts , " he said . "
There are plenty of ways for people to assist in police investigations without actively becoming a part of them . "
To Brett Collins , spokesman for Sydney-based community legal watchdog Justice Action , the case has opened a Pandora 's Box , with ripple effects hard to control .
" Before , we had one person traumatized , now we have 600 people who have had their bodies invaded , " Collins said . "
And there 's still the question of how that genetic material will be handled . "
He believes largely compliant Wee Waa represented a controlled environment for demonstrating DNA technology as the Australian federal government mulls legislation establishing a nationwide DNA database .
By having DNA testing either smoke out a perpetrator through a confession , or link him via laboratory tests , the effectiveness of the technology could be demonstrated to lawmakers , Collins believes .
He believes the case represents the thin end of the wedge for the use of DNA in forensics and , later , huge identity databases that will progressively strip the global citizenry of any anonymity .
Wee Waa is a small , agricultural town bordering populous New South Wales ' border with the northern Australian state of Queensland .
Wee Waa is part of a rural police jurisdiction covering roughly 26,000 square miles , with a population of about 30,000 .




Net CEOs : ' Shallow and Greedy '

The head of a major Internet consulting firm predicts that many dot-com companies will soon be exposed for what they really are : hollow , half-baked schemes without much hope for long-term success .
George Colony , CEO of Forrester Research , recently concluded a lengthy series of interviews with executives about how they expect the Internet to change their businesses over the next 10 years .
About a fifth of the CEO 's hailed from Internet companies , and Colony based his conclusions largely on interviews with them .
His findings were not pretty .
" Many of the dot-com CEOs lacked depth , experience , and common business sense , " he wrote in a letter on Forrester 's discussion site . "
There was a fanatical focus on valuation -- getting public and liquid -- while value -- what the customer eventually gets -- was a back-seat discussion . "
Colony drew a sharp distinction between CEOs of Net startups and leaders of more established companies .
Most Net executives , he said , seemed committed only for the short-term , unfazed by their highly fluid work force , and fixated on cliched and simplistic business models .
He also was n't too impressed by many of their businesses .
" These companies are not built to withstand competition , they 're not built to deliver sustained value , and they 're not built to last , " he wrote , offering this year 's Super Bowl as an example of the lack of foresight .
Internet companies spent record sums on 30-second spots that in most cases proved to be " a phenomenal waste of money . "
Colony had kind words for a few high-profile dot com executives , like Priceline founder Jay Walker , Amazon.com 's Jeff Bezos , and eBay CEO Meg Whitman .
Those few executives who possess a long-term vision and are willing to marshall the sales forces and put up the investments to back them will end up controlling most of the market .
Weaker players , in the meantime , will be forced to drop out .
The future , Colony said , will be one with fewer IPOs , less advertising , massive consolidation , and more stable prices .
In the meantime , many of those in-your-face upstarts will find themselves cowed into the shadow by those slow-moving , profitable " old economy " companies they once derided .
So where will all those 20-something Net millionaires end up ?
Colony issued the following prediction :
" The dot-com generation will get squeezed by more skilled baby-boom managers and aggressive Generation Y newcomers .
Former dot-com managers will end up working for their elders and their juniors , " he said .

Finally , the industrial-strength models from Symbol Technologies are rugged bar-code readers geared toward vertical markets .
In the landmark terminals main lobby , Microsoft employees in bright-yellow fleece vests gave demos of the new Pocket PCs to passersby .
Well , they tried to give demos , but most of the people dashing by the famous terminal clock did n't stop , perhaps attempting to avoid being any later for work .
Despite the public 's indifference to the event , the Microsofties spirit remained high .
" This is our demographic , the mobile professional , " said program manager Chad Whitney , who had been giving demos since 6:45 a.m.
Indeed , once the real morning crush was over , close to a dozen passersby gathered around Whitney and his fellow Pocket PCers .
But theyre not all the typical " mobile professionals , " Microsoft was trying to reach .
The onlookers included students , tourists , and the usual peculiar range of personalities youd expect at Grand Central at 11:00 on a weekday morning .
Ballmer and company spent a good portion of this mornings launch talking up the fun stuff you can do with Pocket PCs .
The presentation started out with a cartoon of the gregarious Ballmer grabbing a cab in New York .
Developed using ActiveSky technology and created by Atom Film , the cartoon is just one of about 25 pieces of video entertainment specifically created for the Pocket PC platform .
In fact , its the entertainment arena that many believe just might finally give Microsoft an edge over the industry-dominating Palm .
For example , you can read e-books on a Pocket PC using Microsofts new ClearType display technology , which quadruples text resolution on the screen .
And you can listen to books being read to you , thanks to Audible.coms integrated content .
Not surprisingly , Microsofts own Slate magazine will also be available in e-book format .
It was the e-book technology that sold Cliff Helsel -- currently a Palm user -- of WallStreetWise Software . "
Its a lot better than the last CE device I looked at , " he said , after checking out one of the units at the terminal . "
Palm has a ways to go to beat it . "
If youre not a reader or a short-movie buff , theres always music .
Both MP3 and Windows Media Player audio formats are supported on the Pocket PCs .
Gamers might enjoy the free Fun Pocket PC Expansion Pack , which includes a version of Pac-Man thats an exact duplicate of the popular 80s arcade game .
But Microsoft didnt forget the business uses for Pocket PC , including full compatibility with Outlook , page-fitting technology that lets Pocket Internet Explorer duplicate the look of Web pages as displayed on a PC screen , and partnerships with strictly business types like mySAP.com and TD Waterhouse .
Consultant Sunil Patel liked the e-book reader , but he was also intrigued by the business applications . "
Its got the features were looking for -- Outlook synchronization , maps &#91 ; Pocket Streets comes bundled with the devices&#93 ; , a color screen , " he said , adding that he planned to buy one immediately .
Quentin Solano , a jazz clarinetist , seemed tentative about the MP3 capabilities and worries over the need for music publishers to work out new ways to pay musicians .
But , he agreed that the technology is inevitable .
Pocket PCs and their ilk , he said " are the thing of the future .
Soon it will be like having a wristwatch . "




Parlez-Vous Online ?

Students who want to brush up on their Spanish verb tenses , patrons looking to impress the maitre d ' at a swanky French restaurant , and visitors to Germany who do n't want to sound like tourists can all get a little help on the Web .
But do n't expect to get that help immediately from the established language companies that have offered dictionaries , traveler 's phrase books , lesson plans , audio tapes , and even CD ROM language programs .
While most of the well-known language instruction firms said they are evaluating or already planning online offerings , there are currently a handful of new online-only players dominating the online language learning space .
These online-only sites are attempting to leverage the strengths of the Net , such as interactivity , constant availability , and audio , and text capabilities , to create comprehensive and immersive language learning programs .
Parlo aims to recreate that feeling of immersion into another country and culture -- as much as possible while parked in front of a computer .
It includes music , stories , and pictures from other countries , in addition to its vocabulary lists and listen-and-repeat features .
" It 's injecting some entertainment into the educational experience instead of making it a pain , " said co-founder Varun Bedi , who speaks five languages .
Beginner lessons at Parlo are free .
Students connect with other students and an instructor through chat rooms on the site .
The site currently offers English , Spanish , and French courses , and plans to add Italian and German by the end of the year .
LearnPlus also offers free trial language lessons , but does not feature the cultural immersion component included in Parlo .
Several other online-only language offerings are aimed at the casual traveler that simply wants to ask directions .
Most of the language-learning sites on the Web are beginning to gain momentum just as traditional players , such as The Learning Company , are facing hard times .
Its parent company -- toy giant Mattel -- recently announced plans to sell the seven-year-old foreign language instructional CD-ROM maker .
Even though it is up for sale , The Learning Company plans to launch online language instruction later this year .
The site is expected to include video -- a component not found in current language sites .
" provides a great way to improve language learning through personalization , " said Teri Clayton , vice president of marketing for Mattel Interactive . "
The Web
People from various sources . "
learn
With both CD ROMs and Web instruction , she said , " we can offer a lot . "
Well-known language instruction company Berlitz also sees huge potential in Web-based instruction .
However , the company is still in the early stages of deploying its offerings online .




Clinton Does Comdex

CHICAGO -- Here 's some free advice for companies hawking their products at trade shows : Before handing it to the leader of the free world , make sure it works .
When President Clinton was strolling through the gargantuan Comdex trade show on Tuesday afternoon , he took a few minutes to stop by Motorola 's wireless booth .
Motorola executive Janice Webb showed him Mya , a sexily packaged product that 's supposed to read the content of websites to you over any telephone .
The problem : Mya got a bad case of laryngitis , choking up halfway through the demo , and the panicked Motorola representative had to start over .
Motorola 's two-way message pager had similar problems .
Webb could n't send anything -- perhaps because the crush of Comdex-bound geeks had overloaded Chicago 's wireless network -- and ultimately gave up .
Clinton also stopped by storagepoint.com , where director of product development Lauren Brinner gave him an account on the system , which lets you store your files on the Internet so you can access them from anywhere .
username:clinton , password : buddy
Brinner suggested Clinton could store sensitive information on the system , but he laughed off the suggestion .
" We 've had enough problems , " Clinton said , referring to the ongoing scandal over thousands of misplaced email messages .
Clinton was in town during the final stop in a whirlwind " digital divide " tour , making him the first president to speak at Comdex .
Earlier in the trip , he ran into his own technological problems : The presidential limo ran out of gas when returning his daughter Chelsea to Stanford University after an event Sunday evening in San Francisco .
At Comdex , Clinton called on the tech-savvy audience to do more to help the less affluent .
" I came here today to ask you to ... devote more time and technology , more ideas an energy , to closing the digital divide , " Clinton said .
" This idea of closing the digital divide is good social policy .
It 's good personal ethics , " he said . "
But it 's also very , very important for our continued economic expansion as a nation . "
After the event , Clinton went to Maxim 's restaurant for a 58th birthday party for Mayor Daley .
" The only thing that I have lingering hard feelings about is that he 's four years older than me and looks younger , " Clinton said .
He was scheduled to return to the White House before traveling to Oklahoma City for a memorial service Wednesday .




Apple on a Roll

Apple Computer Wednesday reported a 47 percent rise in per share income , excluding a one-time gain , to handily beat Wall Street expectations citing strong sales of its Powerbook laptop and G4 high-end desktop computers .
Excluding an after-tax gain of $ 73 million , or 40 cents a share , from the sale of 1.5 million shares of ARM Holdings Plc. , Apple said its profits rose 72 percent to $ 160 million , and its per share profits rose 47 percent to 88 cents .
The Cupertino , California , computer maker said its net income rose to $ 233 million , or $ 1.28 a share , in its fiscal second quarter ended April 1 , up from $ 135 million , or 84 cents a share , a year earlier .
Revenue rose 27 percent to $ 1.94 billion from $ 1.53 billion , and gross margins rose 28.2 percent , up from 26.3 percent in the year-ago quarter .
Wall Street analysts had expected the company to post a profit of 81 cents a share , according to First Call/Thomson Financial .
Apple , which has seen its stock price soar in the last year , also declared a two-for-one stock split .
AAPL
Do n't Ask Jeeves About Profits : Online search engine Ask Jeeves , said Wednesday it had a first quarter loss despite sharply higher revenue .
ASKJ

Analysts at First Call/Thomson Financial had predicted a loss of 74 cents .
Revenue for the quarter was $ 17.8 million , compared with $ 1.5 million for the same period last year .
Cnet 's Earnings News : Cnet Networks Wednesday reported a first-quarter operating profit and said its sales more than doubled .
CNET
The Internet company , which runs an online service offering a broad range of technology content , said its pro forma net income was $ 1.5 million or two cents per share .
That figure , however , excluded a host of unusual items like goodwill amortization , merger costs , net losses on investment sales and stock-based compensation .
Including all those items , Cnet posted a net loss in the quarter of $ 19.5 million or 23 cents per share , compared with a profit last year of $ 20.4 million or 23 cents per share .
Total revenue grew to $ 45.4 million from $ 20.1 million .
During the quarter , Cnet acquired the online comparison shopping site mySimon in a $ 700 million stock deal , as part of its new strategy to expand its focus beyond technology .
Earthlink Loses Less Than Expected : EarthLink Network , the second-largest Internet service provider in the United States , Wednesday reported an unexpectedly smaller first-quarter loss from strong revenue and subscriber growth .
ELNK
Atlanta-based EarthLink , which recently completed a merger with MindSpring Enterprises , said it lost $ 50.9 million , or 43 cents a share , before acquisition and one-time merger expenses in the first quarter of 2000 .
Last year , EarthLink had a profit of $ 3.2 million , or 3 cents a share .
Analysts polled by First Call expected a loss of 49 cents in the just-concluded quarter .
Including special items , EarthLink posted a net loss of $ 111.8 million , or 95 cents a share , compared with a loss of $ 31.4 million , or 29 cents .
Revenue rose 69 percent to $ 219.7 million , up from $ 129.9 million .
Conexant Semiconductor Sales Up : Conexant Systems Wednesday beat consensus estimates , driven by strong demand for its communications chips in network and television equipment .
Conexant said pro forma net income for the fiscal second quarter ended March 31 was $ 47 million , or 21 cents per share , compared with $ 8.9 million , or 5 cents a share , in the year-ago period .
These results excluded merger-related charges .
Analysts had forecast an average of 19 cents per share , according to First Call/Thomson Financial .
In a statement , the company said strong demand for its semiconductor products in wireless and networking equipment was leading it to boost its outlook for earnings and revenue growth in the coming quarter and full fiscal year .
Revenue for the quarter jumped to $ 502 million , up 58 percent from the year-earlier quarter 's $ 317 million .
Revenue was down slightly from the seasonally stronger first quarter ended in December , but by far less than analysts expected .
