Valley : ' Cruzing ' to the Beach

SANTA CRUZ , California -- " Silicon Beach " may sound like a bad summer replacement show on Fox , but it pretty much sums up the way Silicon Valley spillover has transformed this oceanside community a half-hour south of San Jose .
There are other areas that also claim the Silicon Beach moniker -- South Florida , as well as various Southern California locales -- but Silicon Valley types have chosen to live in the mellow , hippified beach culture in and around Santa Cruz for as long as there has been a Silicon Valley .
What 's new is the influx of technology businesses , so people do not have to make the awful commute over the Santa Cruz Mountains .
Which , in turn , feeds the growing sense of a separate identity .
" It started out as spillover , but now I think it 's reached a critical mass where it has become it 's own scene , " said longtime Santa Cruz resident John Govsky , a senior editor at Cruzio.com .
" Santa Cruz is always ahead of the curve .
People have been willing to work here for $ 10,000 or $ 20,000 less than they could make over the hill .
Now they might not have to compromise , " he said .
Cruzio was the first ISP in the area and now offers tech writing courses at its website and Internet courses in its office .
Software developer Borland International , now called Inprise , has been located in Scotts Valley , just a few miles north of Santa Cruz , since 1983 .
When former Borland chairman and founder Philippe Kahn left the company in 1994 , he started StarFish Software in Santa Cruz , which was later bought by Motorola .
Two of Kahn 's other technology ventures , LightSurf and OpenGrid , are also located in Santa Cruz .
The Santa Cruz Technology Alliance offers a Who 's Who in Monterey Bay technology .
The group estimates that more than 450 tech companies are based in Santa Cruz County now , compared to less than 50 before 1990 and just 262 as recently as 1994 .
That was the year that Marge Cappo , president of educational software developer Learning in Motion , embarked on an international search for the best place to start her company .
She was living in New York at the time and wanted more than just easy access to board meetings .
" We were looking for a nice community , not too large , near the ocean and preferably near mountains , though I 'm not sure the Santa Cruz Mountains qualify as mountains , " she said .
" If people want to get away and take a walk to the ocean and think an idea through , they can .
We love it here . "
Learning in Motion has a modest 50 employees , but it 's only one of 150 computer-related businesses in Santa Cruz itself .
Nearly half of those have popped up in the last two years , according to the San Jose Mercury News .
Not so long ago , Santa Cruz residents would express their resentment of people in the neighboring Santa Clara Valley -- which includes a large chunk of Silicon Valley -- by spray-painting " Valley Go Home " on freeway overpasses .
But the 1989 Loma Prieta earthquake wreaked enough havoc in the area to make any kind of economic rebuilding welcome .
And now the Internet has made work-by-modem a widespread fact of life , so the economic links between the two areas can develop without clogging the only route to San Jose -- the windy , two-laned Highway 17 .
" One big change I 've noticed in the last year is I get a lot more calls from people looking to hire my students to work in the field of networking , " said Rick Graziani , who teaches computer science and networking at Cabrillo College .
The Santa Cruz Technology Alliance and the Santa Cruz Chamber of Commerce joined forces in February for a technology trade fair .
The event exceeded expectations , showcasing 95 local companies and attracting thousands of visitors .
There is also a growing acceptance in Silicon Valley that bright , creative people might choose to live on the beach and still be close enough to drive over the hill for a meeting on short notice .
Santa Cruz programmers used to be regarded in Silicon Valley as " goofballs ... doing their own thing , " Santa Cruz resident Brian Pierson , business development manager at Menlo Park-based Informix , told the Santa Cruz Sentinel recently .
But he said that 's changing , and fast .
But the changes are bringing problems , too .
Tech companies are finding there is less vacant office space near the coast , and some residents worry that overcrowding could upset Santa Cruz 's traditional easy-going , unhurried pace .
The venerable Santa Cruz Beach Boardwalk is still one of the main landmarks in town , and it has changed little over the decades .
About the only sign of the times a visitor encounters there is at an ice cream stand near the Giant Dipper roller-coaster , where the big sign advertises " Dippin ' Dots , " billed as the " Ice Cream of the Future . "
Still , the thriving new industry in town might not be quite as easy to ignore as misguided attempts to cash in on it .
" I think we 're kind of back where the Model T was when the automobile was invented , " said Graziani . "
I do n't think we 've begun to see how the Internet and computer technology is really going to affect all of our daily lives .
We have an opportunity to look toward the future and make it a positive change for everybody , including people from different economic and ethnic backgrounds . "




Analyst Rocks Microsoft Again

NEW YORK -- Goldman Sachs software industry analyst Rick Sherlund has Wall Street 's ear and Microsoft 's tail .
Sherlund , who has followed the Redmond , Washington-based software company since his brokerage helped take the company public in 1986 and is said to dine with Microsoft executives regularly , has a long history of making the stock rock .
In the latest such move , the boyish looking 44-year-old analyst lowered his recommendation on the stock and trimmed his financial outlook on Microsoft after the company last week cautioned investors to expect slower growth .
Sherlund 's comments , echoed by many on Wall Street , helped send the stock down nearly 16 percent to 67-1/4 on Monday , and triggered a broad sell-off in technology stocks .
The decline also came amid reports that that the U.S. Justice Department may be favoring breaking up the company as punishment for its illegal abuse of monopoly power .
" He 's viewed as the No. 1 software analyst , " said Chuck Hill , director of research for First Call/Thomson Financial . "
He calls them the way he sees them . "
Two weeks ago , his warning that Microsoft 's March quarter revenues would fall short of estimates triggered a 4 percent single-day decline in the company 's share price .
While some analysts are under pressure from the investment banking arms of their firms to tout the record of the companies they track , Sherlund has a reputation for independence despite his long ties to the company , Hill said .
Robert Burgoyne , technology strategist for Monument Funds Group , said while he sometimes disagrees with Sherlund 's views , there was no disputing the influence the analyst has on how investors judge the world 's leading software maker .
" You have to take that very seriously , " Burgoyne said . "
He has influenced many , many billions of dollars .
It takes a lot of guts to say that the thing is not as attractive . "




MS to DOJ : ' Put Up Your Dukes '

WASHINGTON -- The Justice Department is close to seeking a break-up of Microsoft Corp. for violating U.S. antitrust law , a source familiar with the case said Monday , prompting the company to vow a lengthy fight .
The government proposal would split the company in two , with one part making the Windows operating system , including functions to browse the Internet .
The second company would market everything else -- including the Microsoft Office programs -- and would also be allowed to sell Internet software , the source said .
A Microsoft spokesman said any proposal to break the company up was outside the scope of the trial and would require extra time for the company to respond .
The government and 19 states suing Microsoft are to present proposed remedies this week , after District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ruled on April 3 that the company abused its monopoly in the Windows operating system .
News of the proposed break-up , along with disappointing fiscal third quarter results reported on Friday , sent Microsoft shares down sharply , dragging other technology stocks and the Nasdaq market in its wake .
Microsoft shares closed 12-5/16 lower at 66-5/8 , its lowest close in more than a year .
Microsoft Chief Operating Officer Bob Herbold told CNBC any remedies that include breaking up the company are " completely inappropriate .
They do n't match what 's going on in the marketplace . "
Microsoft has argued for years that changing markets make any case against it obsolete , because the market will solve the problems .
But those on the government side have argued that although Microsoft 's products may change , its illegal business tactics have not and that measures must be taken to prevent it from muscling new competitors .
Microsoft spokesman Jim Cullinan told Reuters that breaking up the company was beyond the scope of the trial so far , and would result in drawing the already long-running proceedings out even further .
" It 's almost like a whole new trial , " Cullinan said . "
They 're going to have to justify their remedies . "
" There 's a need for us to fully explore the government 's proposal and develop and present a response that addresses all of our concerns about the proposed remedy and the potentially damaging impact it can have on Microsoft , the industry and consumers , " Cullinan said .
A spokeswoman for the Justice Department had no comment .
A spokesman for Iowa Attorney General Tom Miller , who is heading the states ' effort , also had no comment .
In addition to proposing to break the company up , the source said the department is also likely to seek stringent limits on the firm 's conduct while the case is being appealed , the source said .
Microsoft could ask a higher court to stay the conduct limits when it appealed .
Once the government files its proposed remedies , Microsoft will reply on May 10 with its objections , its own proposed remedy and its suggestions for the process during the remainder of the trial .
The government will file once more on May 17 .
Jackson will hear oral arguments on a penalty on May 24 .
The source said Attorney General Janet Reno has already been briefed on her department 's proposal .
The Justice approach is being reviewed by the states as they decide whether to come on board with the plan .




DSL In Every 550 MHz-Plus Pot

NEW ORLEANS -- Life with DSL can be hard , but new software-based products may soon make getting fast Internet access much easier .
In an effort to spur demand for broadband , Motorola and PCtel demonstrated technology at the Windows Hardware Engineering Conference on Monday that puts DSL hardware inside the next generation of PCs .
digital subscriber line
Because of a myriad of standards and lack of compatibility between consumer products and telecom equipment , getting DSL installed generally requires buying both the hardware and service from the same company .
And even after paying for the external DSL modem and its installation , consumers frequently must make repeated tech support calls to get the equipment to work .
" is in the painful growing stage , similar to what happened with analog modems a few years ago when there were competing technologies , " said Michael Tramontano , Motorola 's marketing director .
DSL
Motorola demonstrated softDSL , technology that uses the computer 's CPU instead of fixed-function DSL devices , which can cost more than $ 200 , and may only work with a specific telecom carrier .
SoftDSL-enabled PCs will be software upgradeable , so if you buy a new computer and can n't connect to your DSL carrier , you can download a patch .
Tramontano warned that DSL will be in a state of flux for the foreseeable future -- similar to analog modems which featured faster speeds and new features almost every year -- often requiring costly hardware upgrades .
He said SoftDSL should help minimize some of the headaches as the DSL standards shakeout occurs over the next few years .
Although Tramontano said the company was unlikely to guarantee that its products will work with every DSL service , he 's confident that it will work with the majority of DSL flavors .
" our lawyers do n't like to say guarantee "
Tramontano said softDSL cuts the cost of the hardware by between 30 and 40 percent , and although the company has not announced any partners , he think companies such as Gateway and Dell may include it in their $ 1,500 PCs early in 2001 .
And if they build it in , he said , consumers will come .
" If they already have the capability in their computers , they are much more likely to try DSL than if they have to buy a separate box , " he said .
Tramontano said that one-third of all modems sold today similarly offload some of the processing to the CPU .
Tramontano said that a 550 MHz or faster processor is required , and although the first softDSL-enabled PCs will use Windows , the company is working on moving the technology to Linux .
PCtel , a Milpitas , California communications company , was also demonstrating a software DSL product , which it expects will be available by the third quarter of this year .
PCtel 's card will include both a V.90 modem and DSL , and will cost PC makers only about $ 30 to add , according to James Horng , director of technical marketing .
Horng said consumers can start using the familiar V.90 dialup service , and upgrade to DSL by downloading software .
And , of course , dialup service is a good backup strategy for those inevitable DSL problems .
He said the technology will be used in more expensive PCs at first , and requires processors of 500 MHz and greater .
Horng said they are currently testing the hardware with the leading telecom equipment to make sure it is compatible .




Handy DNA Analysis

A biochip company is closer than ever to producing a handheld device to look at DNA in a doctor 's office .
Clinical Micro Sensors Monday announced the results of a research study showing its technology , called the eSensor biochip , could allow doctors to quickly and accurately diagnose or help tailor medications to patients according to their genetic make-up .
The researchers said the technology , which consists of shooting electrons through the center of a DNA double helix , works as well as more laborious technology now used for analyzing genetic material .
And eSensor could eventually do it in one step , on the spot .
" The puts different mutations on one chip and unequivocally gives you an answer , " said Daniel Farkas , director of clinical diagnostics at CMS , and leader of the study .
technology
This is superior to PCR-RFLP analysis -- the method currently considered to be the gold standard -- Farkas said .
PCR-RFLP analysis takes up to 48 hours to turn around results , involves several steps , and the results must be interpreted by highly trained medical technologists .
Researchers at Pasadena , California-based Clinical Micro Sensors , along with colleagues at the University of Wisconsin , tested the eSensor technology by using cells from patients who had been tested for hereditary hemochromatosis -- a disease characterized by too much iron in the body .
The disease is caused by two gene mutation in particular , which the technology picked up in the 66 patients studied .
The research team compared the eSensor results with the gold standard and found the two techniques produced the same results in every case .
Farkas and his team used hemochromatosis , which affects about 1.5 million Americans and can be fatal , as an example of why using genes to diagnose disease can be so important .
The condition is easily treated by having the patient donate blood about every four weeks , but ambiguous symptoms -- including anything from joint pain to headaches -- make diagnosis difficult .
Identifying a specific gene mutation removes the guesswork from diagnosis .
Farkas said the eSensor technology will be instrumental in detecting SNPs .
SNPs or single nucleotide polymorphisms are tiny differences among individuals that can indicate that a patient is predisposed to a certain disease , or predict how an individual will respond to a specific drug .
" Who should take what drug is based on your genetic makeup , " Farkas said .
There are other biochips available , Farkas said , " but none is as low density and low cost as ours . "
Nanogen disagrees .
The San Diego-based company makes the NanoChip , which it says in studies has proven up to 11 percent more accurate than PCR-RFLP , and 8 percent more accurate than DNA sequencing .
" We believe this is a significant advantage for Nanogen 's technology that will position the NanoChip Molecular Biology Workstation as the new standard , " said Bud Bromley , senior vice president of business development & marketing at Nanogen .
The NanoChip is also available in a handheld device and designed to examine SNPs cheaply and on the spot .
CMS hopes to have a clinical version of the instrument ready for hospital laboratories as soon as 2002 or 2003 , pending approval from the Food and Drug Administration .




Study : Joysticks Lead to Mayhem

" Harris and Klebold enjoyed playing the bloody , shoot-'em-up video game Doom , a game licensed by the U.S. military to train soldiers to effectively kill . "
So reads the introduction to a new report on the relationship between video games and violent behavior , which cites high school gunmen Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold , who went on a killing rampage last year .
The study , published in the April issue of the Journal of Personality and Social Psychology , was released on the Web on Sunday , just days after the one-year anniversary of the Columbine High School shootings .
Following the shooting , Klebold and Harris -- who shot and killed 12 students and one teacher , wounded 23 others , and finally killed themselves -- were found to have been video game enthusiasts .
Researchers Craig Anderson and Karen Dill concluded in two related studies , which involved notably violent games including Mortal Kombat and Wolfenstein 3D , that playing violent video games made players , especially men , act more aggressively .
" In the short term , playing a violent video game appears to affect aggression by priming aggressive thoughts , " they reported . "
Longer-term effects are likely to be longer-lasting as well , as the player learns and practices new aggression-related scripts that become more and more accessible for use when real-life conflict situations arise . "
One of the two studies found that violent video games promoted both aggressive behavior and delinquency .
The relationship between games and aggressive behavior was stronger in men and in individuals who were already characteristically aggressive .
The second study also found that " laboratory exposure " to a graphically violent video game increased aggressive thoughts and behavior .
" In both studies , men had a more hostile view of the world than did women , " the report said .
The report said results from both studies are consistent with the " General Affective Aggression Model , " which Anderson and Dill created prior to the study for predicting aggressive behavior .
The model expects aggressive behavior after violent game play in both the short term -- subjects getting more aggressive right there in the lab -- and the long term , i.e. juvenile delinquency .
The research was supported by the Psychology Department at the University of Missouri-Columbia .
The study does n't put all the blame on video games , but points to them as a likely factor in the Columbine killings .
" Although it is impossible to know exactly what caused ( Eric Harris and Dylan Klebold to attack their own classmates and teachers , a number of factors probably were involved .
One possible contributing factor is violent video games . "
The report noted that Harris ' website included a customized version of the violent video game Doom .
The personalized game featured two shooters with extra weapons and unlimited ammunition and opponents unable to fight back , according to the findings of the Simon Wiesenthal Center , which examined the shootings as part of its campaign to raise awareness of hate-related violence .
" For a class project , Harris and Klebold made a videotape that was similar to their customized version of Doom ...
.
An investigator associated with the Wiesenthal Center said Harris and Klebold were ' playing out their game in God mode .
' "
Anderson and Dill concluded the active , learning nature of video games make them potentially more dangerous than TV and movie violence . "
As scientists , we should add new research to the currently small and imperfect literature on video game violence effects and clarify for society exactly what these risks entail . "




' Bizkit Bonds With Napster

LOS ANGELES -- Hard rock band Limp Bizkit has teamed up with controversial Internet company Napster Inc. to launch a free U.S. concert tour , and the group 's singer Monday criticized fellow artists who have accused Napster of promoting music piracy .
Napster allows users to trade and search for MP3s .
free downloadable files of musical performances
A fan can type in the name of the desired song , click on the desired version and instantly download it -- all for free .
The music industry 's trade group , the Recording Industry Association of America , sued Napster in December , charging that the San Mateo , California , company 's website promotes piracy and copyright infringement .
Rock band Metallica and rap pioneer Dr. Dre have also waded in against Napster in recent weeks .
But the controversy has washed over Limp Bizkit singer Fred Durst , who told a news conference that Napster was a great way for fans to sample an album before buying it .
" I would think the only people worried about that are people that are really worried about their bank accounts , " he said .
In the opposite corner , Metallica drummer Lars Ulrich accused Napster and several universities that allow access to it of " trafficking in stolen goods " when the band announced a copyright infringement and racketeering lawsuit against the company April 14 .
" It is ... sickening to know that our art is being traded like a commodity rather than the art that it is , " Ulrich added .
Dr. Dre demanded last week that Napster take his music off its directory , saying his copyrights were being infringed .
Durst countered that Napster was " an amazing way to market and promote music " to a massive audience .
" The Internet is here , and anybody trying to fight that , which would be people who are living by certain standards and practices of the record industry -- those are the only people who are scared and threatened , " Durst said .
Asked to comment specifically on Metallica 's stance , he replied , " I do n't think anything about what Metallica thinks . "
Napster is underwriting the cost of the tour , which Limp Bizkit manager Jeff Kwatinetz estimated at about $ 1.8 million .
Beginning in July , the band will play multiple dates at 3,000-5,000-seat venues in Chicago , Minneapolis , Detroit , Boston , New York , Dallas , Denver , San Francisco , Seattle , and Los Angeles .
Dates and venues will be announced later .
The tour coincides with the release of Limp Bizkit 's third album , Chocolate Starfish and the Hot Dog Flavored Water , due out in August .
The band 's current album Significant Other , has sold about 8 million copies worldwide .




Gadgets Drive New Jersey Man

To say Philip Torrone is a gadget freak is an understatement .
At all times the 25-year-old New York designer has at least a dozen gadgets with him .
In addition to a cell phone and a couple of PDAs , Torrone lugs around a bag stuffed with essentials , including a home-made solar recharger for his organizers and a jerry-rigged infrared amplifier to boost their feeble beams to more than 50 feet .
Torrone 's obsession recently cost him his girlfriend .
" She 's my ex because of all the gadgets I have with me all the time , " said Torrone , who lives in Hoboken , New Jersey , and is director of new media at Braincraft . "
She called me up at work and said , ' It 's either me or your odd fetish for technology .
' I said , ' Can I send you an email about it when I get home ?
' and that was that . "
" Automating the apartment kind of got to her as well , " he added .
Torrone described the lights that automatically come on , the auto cat-feeder and a litter tray with a robot arm to scoop out the cat droppings .
" Slowly she went nuts , " he said . "
But the cat likes it . "
Torrone 's interest in gadgets goes back to his childhood .
When he was a kid he dismantled the TV to see how it works .
His dad ordered him to put it back together .
He managed it , but the TV was never the same again .
More recently , Torrone took a screwdriver and soldering iron to his sports car , with markedly better success .
Torrone has outfitted his Mazda Miata with the kind of wireless Net connection that still seems beyond the technical prowess of most automakers , despite years of promises to the contrary .
Torrone 's " geek mobile " boasts full email and Web access , a wireless video-conferencing system , a voice-activated navigation computer , and an MP3 stereo .
" In a few years all this stuff will be commonplace , " Torrone said . "
But for now I have to build it myself . "
At the heart of the system is a modified laptop running Linux .
Hidden in the trunk , the machine can play hundreds of hours of digitized MP3s and is controlled by a Palm V mounted up front .
" I 'm concerned about getting pulled over by the RIAA , " Torrone joked .




Midwest Gets Green Power Online

SANTA CLARA , California -- Automated Power Exchange , a provider of e-commerce services for the electricity industry , opened the APX Illinois Market in Chicago earlier this month to facilitate the exchange of buying and selling of wholesale and commercial electricity in the region .
The service brings together a trading community of investor-owned and municipal utilities , power producers , power marketers , and large end users .
Operating in Commonwealth Edison 's northern Illinois service area , traders can deal in renewable energy -- so-called Green Tickets -- which represent the premium price buyers are willing to pay for environmentally friendly power .
Suppliers who wish to sell into the APX Green Power Market must be Registered Renewable Suppliers with the California Energy Commission .
Only energy provided from wind , solar , geothermal , biomass , landfill gas and small hydro power plants may be sold into the APX Green Power Market .
less than 30 megawatts
Buyers can purchase any blend of green and brown power , up to 100 percent of either .
Participants access the markets using special software designed for electricity trading by APX .
" This private , commercial power exchange addresses the needs of the deregulating retail and wholesale markets in Illinois , " said APX chairman Edward Cazalet . "
All buyers and sellers now have a level playing field where they can trade on the same terms with verifiable prices continuously available . "
Green power pricing is separated into two components : commodity energy , traded and scheduled hourly from generators through the electric grid to end users ; and the Green Tickets , which represent the green attribute for which generators receive and buyers pay a green premium .
Green Tickets are traded in a yearly market so buyers can lock in their green premium up to a year in advance .
Buyers purchase Green Tickets equal to their customer 's metered demand .
Sellers have Green Tickets to sell equal to their actual metered output .
Participants in the APX Illinois Market also can access markets in Ohio and Pennsylvania .
Privately held Automated Power Exchange operates Internet-based exchanges and clearinghouses for the buying and selling of electricity , energy transmission , and related products , and provides the core market and scheduling technologies and services needed to support power system administration .

French Pols Say , ' Open It Up '

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Three socialist French MPs have proposed a law that would require the use of open standards software in all public administrations and organizations throughout France .
This law would also allow anyone to " freely develop , publish , and use compatible software , even in the case a patent or a trademark was filed for some communication standard , " according to the proposal 's text .
where
The MPs , Jean-Yves Le Daut , Christian Paul , and Pierre Cohen , say that the proposed law is based on five historical , judicial , and/or constitutional principles in the Constitution Franaise : free access to public information , retrievability of public data , national security , consumer security , and interoperability .
The " interoperability principle " is in line with the 1991 European directive on software which states that " interfaces are not protected by copyright , " that " only the expression of a computer program is protected , " and that " ideas and principles which underlie any element of a program , including those which underlie its interfaces , are not protected by copyright " .
Le Deaut , Paul , and Cohen belive that the law , if passed , can be implemented immediately because " most publishers of proprietary software , including Microsoft , have also publicly stated that they are ready to grant the French administration access to the source code of their products . "
In an interview with Libration , a major French newspaper , Olivier Ezratty , VP of marketing and communication for Microsoft France , said that Microsoft would eventually be ready to grant some independent technical authority full access to the source code of Microsoft software within government control .
Linux Magazine executive editor Robert McMillan says that , in principle , he favors the law .
" I think that it makes sense for a business to want to base itself on open standards , so why not a government ?
Nobody wants to be held in bondage to a software company , " he said .
Harvey Jacobs , of Jacobs &#038 ; Associates , a firm specializing in Internet and computer law , says that he sees no possibility of this type of law being enacted in the United States .
" It would be technological suicide and unconstitutional to decree that there is a basic human right to develop software based on another 's proprietary source code .
in the United States
Article I , Section 8 of the U.S. constitution says , " The Congress shall have the power ... to promote the progress of science and useful arts , by securing for limited times to Authors and Inventors the exclusive right to their respective writings and discoveries . "
Jacobs says that while he can understand that some companies may make the economic decision to give away their source code , governmental " taking " of valuable private property like source code should never be allowed .
He also said that the MP 's pronouncements are " riddled with logical fallacies . "
" For example , they refer to ' public data ' without defining why certain data belongs to the public , " Jacobs said . "
They make the unsupported statement that ' more competition means more choice for the consumer , thus more security .
' How does more security logically follow from more choice ? "
McMillan feels that the move toward open source software should be fueled by technical , rather than political , decisions .
" While open source software is often the best of breed , it is not technically the best in every category .
If all public institutions in France must only use open source software , what office suite will they use ?
What publishing software ?
Certainly not Quark , " he said .
But he notes that in the United States , software patent law seems to be used more and more as a weapon for large companies looking to " flummox " smaller competitors .
" It is beginning to have a stifling effect on innovation , " McMillan said . "
I do n't know if this approach will help things , but at least they 're addressing the problem . "




MS Beats Sun Copyright Claims

SEATTLE -- Software titan Microsoft has won a battle in its legal war with archrival Sun Microsystems after a federal judge ruled their fight is a contract dispute rather than a more serious copyright violation , as Sun had claimed .
Judge Ronald Whyte of the U.S. District Court in San Jose , California , issued two decisions late Monday that dismissed Sun 's allegations that Microsoft violated copyrights on Sun 's Java programming technology .
Microsoft spokesman Mark Murray said the decisions mostly reaffirmed earlier rulings by Whyte on the issue and did not amount to a dramatic development in the case .
" We are pleased that this ruling supports Microsoft 's position that this is a contract dispute between two large and sophisticated companies , and not a copyright case , " Murray said .
Sun said while the rulings knocked back its argument for copyright violations , they did not affect its claims of trademark infringement , breach of contract , and unfair competition .
Sun , which filed the case in 1997 , says Microsoft broke its licensing agreement for Java , a " write once , run anywhere " computer language that lets software run on a variety of operating systems .
Sun , a maker of powerful server computers and software , says Microsoft , fearing a threat to its Windows operating system , tried to sabotage Java 's appeal as a crossover technology by creating a version that would only run on Windows , which is used on over 80 percent of personal computers .
The rulings followed a minor victory for Microsoft in April when Whyte rejected Sun 's interpretation of its contract with Microsoft concerning updated versions of Java .
Both sides have claimed small victories in the case .
Such skirmishes are laying the ground rules for a full-blown trial .
A trial date for the case has not been set .
Shares in Sun fell 4-1/8 , or about 5 percent , to 81-1/4 in mid-afternoon trading on the Nasdaq on Tuesday .
SUNW
Microsoft fell 2 to 67-13/16 .
MSFT
The company is due on Wednesday to present its proposed remedy in the antitrust case brought against it by the U.S. Justice Department , which is seeking to split the company in two for breaking antitrust law .




Windows , Windows , Everywhere

NEW ORLEANS -- Windows .
You will n't be able to live without it if Microsoft has its way .
Even as the courts are deciding if Microsoft should be broken up , the company has no plans to let up from expanding its reach into your everyday home activities .
During presentations on the future of the Windows operating system , Microsoft executives repeatedly told the audience of engineers at WinHEC that their developers are the heart of the digital revolution .
" Every home will be a distributed computing platform , " said Carl Stork , Microsoft general manger of Windows hardware strategy group .
Stork and Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates , who described the PC as " the most empowering tool of all time , " foretold how the next versions of Windows -- Windows Millennium Edition and Whistler -- will work with a wider array of devices .
Windows Me
Windows Me , which is due out in the second half of this year , adds support for Universal Plug and Play compatible devices .
UPnP was developed by Microsoft as a way to network consumer electronics devices and kitchen appliances with PCs and each other .
Greg Sullivan , a Microsoft program manager , said that the UPnP consortium was working on making the technology compatible with Bluetooth , a wireless standard struggling to gain acceptance .
Why create an architecture for appliances that does n't require Windows ?
Microsoft sees the 45 million homes that do not currently have a PC as an opportunity to sell software and services to new devices , said Sullivan .
Sullivan said a company in the Microsoft partner booth is exhibiting a camera that runs on Linux .
He said the company had no plans to bridge its products with Sun 's Jini , however .
For the first time in the nine-year history of WinHEC , Microsoft executives spent as much time talking non-PC devices as PCs .
Working with entertainment devices that play music , digital images , and television , are keys to future versions of Windows , they said .
" PCs add value to appliances .
Entertainment industries are all going digital , and PC companies are the most knowledgeable in creating digital devices , " Stork said .
Gates demonstrated a digital camera being plugged into a Windows Me computer , which automatically previewed the images , and saved them to a website without having to create directories or use HTML .
Gates said that Whistler , due out sometime in 2001 , would allow music files to be copied directly to CD-recordable and CD-rewriteable drives , eliminating the need for specialized " ripping " software .
Gates said that digital music is now one of the top-three most used applications on PCs .
Microsoft executives also showed off a concept PC that included an integrated noise filtering microphone , digital volume controls , and proximity awareness sensors that awaken the computer when a user re-enters the room .
Monday 's breakup speculation and resulting drop in its stock price was only referred to once during the morning events , by an executive who said he noticed " some real buy options " on Monday when surfing business sites .
MSFT
Perhaps coincidentally , the company Tuesday restructured the embedded operating systems divisions into a single group .
And in an effort to alleviate consumer confusion , all non-PC devices that run a version of Windows will be labeled merely as " powered by Windows . "




Moo : Salmonella-Resistant Cows

The controversial practice of giving antibiotics to cattle apparently led to the development of salmonella resistant to the antibiotic ceftriaxone , according to a study in Thursday 's New England Journal of Medicine .
The work fuels a controversy in which some scientists believe the addition of antibiotics to animal feed and the practice of using them to treat sick livestock is breeding new generations of bacteria resistant to those antibiotics .
The newest case is alarming because ceftriaxone is one of the few antibiotics to which most bacteria have not developed a resistance .
But there are signs that resistance is emerging as more ceftriaxone is used -- and abused .
In the latest study , a group led by Paul Fey of the Nebraska Public Health Laboratory examined the case of a 12-year-old boy infected with salmonella .
The bacterium was found to be resistant to ceftriaxone and a dozen other antibiotics .
Tests revealed the same resistant strain of salmonella in local cattle , the researchers said .
The boy had apparently picked up salmonella from the family 's cattle , which had been treated with the antibiotic during an outbreak of diarrhea , the researchers said .
Precisely how the boy was infected or how many other antibiotics the cattle had been exposed to could not be determined .
" Our findings add to the accumulating body of evidence suggesting that the use of antimicrobial agents in livestock is the dominant source of resistance " in salmonella , a disease that can be fatal , they said .
The results also " illustrate the need to use antimicrobial agents prudently both in domestic animals and in humans , " the Fey team said .
" Restricting the use of certain antimicrobial agents in livestock may slow the evolution of antimicrobial resistance in salmonella and prevent the transmission of resistant strains of salmonella from livestock to humans , " they said .
and other techniques
Ceftriaxone is sold under the brand name Rocephin by Roche Laboratories , a unit of Swiss pharmaceutical giant Roche Holding .

That was more than triple the same period a year ago , when Amazon lost $ 36 million , or 12 cents a share .
The consensus analyst estimates compiled by First Call/Thomson Financial expected Seattle-based Amazon.com to lose 36 cents per share .
Revenue for the most recently ended quarter climbed 95 percent to $ 574 million , up from $ 294 million a year ago .
In its previous quarter , Amazon said its losses had peaked and would narrow through the end of this year .
Investors and analysts had become increasingly impatient with the company , which has invested and spent liberally to boost its product offerings and build customer loyalty .
Shares in Amazon climbed 1-1/16 to close at 53-1/2 Wednesday .

It announced financial results after the close of market .

Shares in the Brampton , Ontario-based company surged 8-7/8 to 116-1/4 on a volume of 12 million shares as the company posted net income of 23 cents per share , bettering analysts ' estimates of 18 cents .
NT

Nortel , which will hold its annual meeting Thursday , is expected to unveil plans to expand that area 's research and development division .
The addition to Nortel 's existing 14,000 area staff will likely boost the company 's ability to produce Internet equipment .
Expansion news will be the icing on the cake for analysts , who clearly are impressed by Nortel 's strong showing in what is traditionally a slow quarter .

" I thought there was a typo .
This is such a hug , " said Lucey , who maintains a " buy " on the stock . "
They 're taking share -- they 're putting the boots to Lucent while they can . "

Breakup Good for MS ?

So the word is , the DOJ wants to break up Microsoft .
Not surprisingly , Microsoft is n't happy about it .
Company officers spent much of Monday complaining that any breakup proposal would be draconian .
But while Microsoft laments , a number of antitrust experts and business analysts are arguing that a breakup could well be a good thing for Microsoft , its shareholders , and consumers .
Or , at least , a better thing than a consent decree in which Microsoft agrees to curb its suspect behavior , generally considered a lighter punishment .
The thinking goes like this : If Microsoft and the government enter into a consent decree , the DOJ will have to scrutinize Microsoft 's every move for years to come , micro-managing the company 's business strategy at every turn .
The government will essentially be in the software business -- the greatest fear of Microsoft 's supporters .
If the company is broken up , however , the new units can forge ahead on their own , relatively free from federal handlers .
" Essentially , Judge Jackson would be in the shorts of Microsoft for as long as the consent decree exists , " said Glenn Manishin , an antitrust attorney at Patton Boggs in Washington , and a vocal proponent of a Microsoft breakup . "
If they break up the company , however , the court rules , then walks away . "
Theoretically , the new companies -- in this case one that develops operating systems and runs Microsoft 's Internet business , and one that develops the Office suite of applications -- would be more nimble , and would have more incentive to innovate .
Developers of Office would have to work up applications for alternative operating systems like Linux , instead of just Windows .
Once Linux and other OS 's could run the world 's most popular office applications , consumers would have the incentive to buy those OS 's .
Poof , there goes the Windows monopoly .
Thereafter , developers of Windows would have to improve their product to protect its market share .
Both companies would be smaller and more nimble , more innovative , more exciting to work for -- and potentially more lucrative to investors , some analysts argue .
The sum of a monopoly company 's parts tends to increase when those parts are broken off into separate companies .
Just look at AT&T , which divested the Baby Bell companies in the '80s , said David Smith , an analyst for the Gartner Group .
In theory , the government would n't have to do much of anything .
" The last thing they want to do is create a software business conduct division at the DOJ , " said Erik Olbeter , a senior analyst at Schwab Washington Research Group .
While a breakup can theoretically be simpler and less obtrusive than a consent decree , it could , if done poorly , be both more complex and obtrusive , analysts said .
" The devil 's in the details , " said Smith , who notes that the government will still have to set limits on the behavior of the new companies .
" It 's very important that the DOJ sets clear , limited conduct rules for what the divested companies can and can n't do , " Manishin said . "
Otherwise , they face the risk of corrupting the structural remedy . "
In other words , the DOJ might have to go through all the work of breaking the company up , then wind up micromanaging two companies anyway .
Whether the government proposes a breakup or not , it will n't likely happen soon , if at all .
Microsoft will certainly appeal any such decision , and the breakup would n't happen until the appeal is complete .
That could be years from now .
Analysts give any breakup proposal a 30 to 50 percent chance of surviving through the appeal .




Despite ' Piracy , ' CD Sales Up

At the heart of two music recording industry trials is whether digital piracy will make people stop buying CDs .
As the judge prepares to rule on the first of the lawsuits , statistics show that people are buying more albums than ever .
The world of brick-and-mortal retail looks to be in fine shape , which should be a big boost for everyone in the music business .
Soundscan sales figures -- which are measured by tracking purchasing by recording barcodes -- show that the music industry has grown about 8 percent over last year 's first quarter .
That 's good for the digital music distribution businesses -- MP3.com and Napster -- facing down the recording industry in court , in part due to fears that digital music piracy would hurt sales of CDs .
For the Recording Industry Association of America , the news could n't have come at a worse time .
" If you start looking at what MP3.com is doing , the company is providing the music from records to people who have already bought them , " said digital music lawyer Whitney Broussard . "
Even if this is illegal , what are the damages because there are n't really any lost sales ?
People still have to purchase the CDs .
That could prove damaging to the recording industry 's chances in court against Michael Robertson and MP3.com this Friday .
That lawsuit centers on whether Robertson violated copyrights when his company purchased 80,000 CDs and digitized the content on its servers .
Users could then stream music from those servers by proving they had a copy of the same CD .
As part of their case , the recording industry has to prove that this distribution had caused consumers to stop purchasing CDs .
The bright side is that Robertson is arguing that his database falls under fair use -- a statute that allows individuals to make copies of information they already own for personal use .
According to Broussard , that might make the rise in sales a moot point .
" There are certain things that are clearly non-infringing , such as a journalist quoting from a copyrighted work , " he said . "
Other things would not be fair use , such as bootlegging albums .
There is n't a bright line that determines what is and is n't fair use .
As a result , not many people run around using it as a defense unless they have to because each court and each judge can deal with the fair use issue differently . "
Still , the industry has been claiming rather loudly this year that digital piracy would hurt music retail .
Despite the fact that the issue might not come up as focal point in the lawsuit , the fact that people are purchasing CDs at a higher rate than they were in 1999 is going to have to be addressed in the court of public opinion .
Alex Walsh , the vice president of market research for the RIAA said that just because sales are up does n't mean that its time to declare that digital piracy has n't hurt the music business .
" If we grew 3 percent as an industry , maybe we could have grown twice as much , " she said . "
There is just no way to tell how much we could have lost .
There is no scientific or empirical way to determine how much more music we could have sold . "
She also said that using only one set of numbers posed problems in industry analysis since the music retail is so large and complex .
Regardless of the current litigation , the bump in music sales is a boon to retailers .
National Association of Retail Merchants president Pam Horowitz said the Soundscan numbers do a lot to back up what retailers have known for some time -- that people are still going out to the store to buy the music that they like .
NARM
" We 've learned that brick and mortar retailers are still very formidable , " she said . "
What we are seeing is that a whole lot of these little girls who are online might not be downloading music .
Instead , they are talking about N'Sync in chat rooms . "
Still , she said , the early anecdotal evidence NARM has been gathering has shown that MP3 files have been in a big factor in the college market this year .
But not enough of a factor to drive down sales .
What the lawsuits have done , she said , is given the industry a chance to take a deep breath and figure out how to make sure that overall music sales continue to climb with the help of digital distribution .
" Most retailers are interpreting these numbers in terms of an overall percentage of change , " Horowitz said . "
The change in Internet retail looks like a tidal wave from where it started , but in terms of actual dollars this is just a drop in the bucket .
We are still selling a lot of CDs in stores .
We have time to figure out what the new business models are going to be .
We just have to start now . "




Boeing Gives the Web Its Wings

NEW YORK -- Aerospace giant Boeing Co.
Thursday unveiled a new service providing airline passengers access to the Internet , television , and other news and entertainment over a high-speed , satellite-based communications network .
With partners including CNN , CNBC , Mitsubishi Electric Corp. , and Loral Skynet , Boeing said the service , called Connexion , will cost about the same as a cellular telephone call .
It will allow passengers to use laptop computers to surf the Internet , send email , or log on to any computer network .
" With Connexion by Boeing , not very far in the future you 'll be able to operate on an airplane much as you do in your home or office , " Boeing Chairman Phil Condit told reporters here .
Developed for about $ 100 million over three years , most of that to produce an onboard antenna , the service will be offered to airlines flying aircraft built by Boeing or its rival , Airbus Industrie .
Analysts see a potential market for such services that could be as big as $ 70 billion over 10 years and Condit said Seattle-based Boeing would try to capture as much of that as possible .
Condit declined to say how those revenues would be parceled out , or to characterize Boeing 's relationships with a half a dozen partners providing content or hardware .
The service will be available to North American airline customers at first , with installations beginning late next year .
Beginning in late 2003 Boeing will offer the service in Europe , over the Atlantic and Pacific oceans and then in Asia .
" Commercial information and communications are areas where we understand the customer , where we bring unique solutions no one else has the capabilities or resources to provide , " said Jim Albaugh , who heads Boeing 's space and communications group .
Albaugh hoped to announce by this summer which airlines would take the service .
Boeing declined to say how much it would cost to retrofit an existing airliner with the service , or to build it into new commercial jets , which range in price from $ 20 million to $ 200 million .
Passengers without a laptop will not have Internet access , but will be able to watch television and other video programming through the existing " dumb terminal " video screens already on many airliners , Albaugh said .
Connexion will not initially supply voice service , he added .
In addition to the antenna , Connexion will require a server and router -- powerful machines used to operate computer networks .
Boeing will also wire the aircraft to carry the service , potentially building a data port into every seat on the plane .
Seattle-based Boeing has announced plans to buy Hughes Electronics Corp. 's satellite-building business as part of its goal to become the leading player in satellite communications .




Patent Hangs Up Phone.com

The furious battle over the validity of broad technology patents has surged from the hard-wired Web to the wireless front .
The new combatants : Phone.com , which makes software that Internet-enables cell phones , and Geoworks , a company that claims to hold a patent that covers " flexible user interface technology " used on " all devices , including mobile phones , which are based on the specification and placed into the stream of commerce in the United States and Japan . "
Wireless Application Protocol
In other words , just about any wireless device hooked up to the Web .
Geoworks has busily solicited patent-licensing fees from its competitors in the wireless arena , and a number have complied , including Toshiba .
" They 've treated it pretty much as business as usual , " said Geoworks spokesman Bob Bogard , who insists the licensing terms are modest .
Phone.com , however , has n't paid up , and it filed suit in U.S. District Court on Tuesday challenging the validity of Geoworks ' patent claims .
" This lawsuit seeks to put an end to Geoworks ' repeated and unjustified accusations that virtually the entire wireless Internet industry infringes a Geoworks patent , which is directed to unrelated technology , and its threats to sue entities unwilling to succumb to its demands to take a costly and unnecessary license , " reads the opening sentence of Phone.com 's legal complaint .
Phone.com wants the judge to rule that Phone.com does n't infringe on Geoworks ' patent , and that the patent itself is invalid and unenforceable .
Uncowed , Geoworks shot off a press release Wednesday defending its patent and accusing Phone.com of self-interested public grandstanding .
" We are surprised and disappointed that Phone.com has chosen this unprofessional course of action , " Geoworks CEO Dave Grannan said in a statement . "
We created a very straightforward licensing program and announced it to the Forum in accordance with the Forum 's rules , which Phone.com helped establish .
Wireless Application Protocol
" Now it would seem that Phone.com has decided these rules no longer apply and is pursuing a lawsuit against us .
Phone.com 's management favors litigation over the widely accepted business solution of licensing . "
Phone.com counters that Geoworks ' 1994 patent " simply does not cover the wireless Internet technology , " .
No. 5,327,529
and does not even mention
The company also said that Geoworks ' announcement to the WAP Forum essentially amounted to a notification that forum members were potentially infringing upon the dubious patent , and that some licensing deals had best be forthcoming .
Geoworks , in turn , accuses Phone.com of hypocrisy .
" Phone.com has also filed a patent with the WAP Forum which covers much of the WAP architecture and is holding this over the heads of the entire industry , " said Adam de Boor , Geoworks ' chief technology officer .
It will be up to the courts to decide whose patent is bigger .
The ugly dispute is the latest in a serious of nasty battles over broad technology patents .
Amazon.com recently sued barnesandnoble.com for patent infringement , then came under siege by critics who accused Amazon of shameless patent bullying .
Sue-counter-sue patent spats have become so commonplace in the tech industry , experts have taken to coining names for the phenomenon :
" It 's what I like to disparagingly refer to as ' Mutually Assured Crap , ' " said Greg Aharonian , a patent researcher and an oft-quoted critic of the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office . "
It 's like the Cold War strategy of mutually assured destruction . "




Backdoor Exposes Credit Cards

( Editor 's note : This story has been modified since its initial posting .
The original publication of this story included the password in question . )
Thousands of credit card numbers stored on e-commerce websites are available to anyone with a backdoor password , a British consulting firm has discovered .
Cerberus Information Security said on Thursday it found a secret password that allows someone connecting to a website running " Cart32 " shopping cart software to gain access to the server .
McMurtrey-Whitaker , the Springfield , Missouri firm that sells Cart32 , confirmed the backdoor -- which can reveal such data as credit card numbers , order information , and shipping addresses -- and said they would distribute a repaired version of the program next week .
Hundreds of small-to-medium websites , including Jazzworld.com , MusicWorld CD , ComputerShop.com , Wirelesstoys.com , and ChocolateVault.com , use Cart32 shopping software , which runs on Windows 95 and Windows NT machines .
" We 've been notified of it , " said Matt Humes , a technical support representative at McMurtrey-Whitaker .
Right now , Cart32 administrators can edit the executable file and manually delete the password to close the security hole . "
By Monday &#91;or&#93 ; Tuesday , there 's going to be a much easier fix to make everything completely secure , " Humes said .
Larger firms like Amazon and CDNow tend to use custom shopping cart software .
Smaller ones turn to programs like Cart32 , or competitors like WebGenie Software 's shopping cart , Open Market 's ShopSite , or Mercantec 's SoftCart .
The Cart32 password could have been inserted by a malicious McMurtrey-Whitaker employee who hoped to steal credit card numbers , or the firm could intentionally have enabled it so their technical support staff could fix customers ' problems from afar .
McMurtrey-Whitaker said that the vulnerability was included in earlier versions of Cart32 , which means that anyone who knew the password could have had access to sites ' personal information for at least a year .
Cerberus ' David Litchfield said he stumbled across Cart32 after seeing a banner ad for the product , and decided to explore its potential vulnerabilities on Wednesday evening .
" My brother and I spent about two hours looking at it , " Litchfield said . "
before we discovered the backdoor
I 'm extremely surprised that it 's in there . "
Litchfield said his eight-person security consulting firm has released eight security advisories this year , and they decided to publish the password because of the magnitude of the problem .
To gain access to customer files , an attacker could use the password to alter the shopping cart to leak information when users connect to the site .
Cerberus said it also discovered a way to change Cart32 's administrative password without knowing what the original one was .
Litchfield also found some odd information about the program 's designers embedded in the 700 KB cart32.exe file .
One example : " My Name / Bryan L. Whitaker / My Wifes Name / Melissa K. Whitaker and Kaylee . "
our baby
One expert criticized the company 's planned bug fix as unduly tardy .
" If they 're waiting until Tuesday or Wednesday to fix this problem , that 's definitely a bad idea .
It does n't take a genius to figure out what 's going to happen all weekend , " said Steve Manzuik , the moderator of Win2K Security Advice , referring to malicious hacker attacks .




Intel Nixes Chip-Tracking ID

Hoping to avoid another campaign by privacy activists , Intel has decided not to include a controversial user identification feature in its forthcoming 1.5 GHz Willamette chip .
Absent from Willamette 's design are a unique ID number and other security measures that could be used to limit piracy by tracking users , an Intel source said Wednesday .
" The decision has been made and the engineers have already been told , " said the source , who spoke on the condition of anonymity . "
The gains that it could give us for the proposed line of security features were not sufficient to overcome the bad rep it would give us . "
In January 1999 , Intel said it would wire a unique ID into each Pentium III chip , but then disabled it after privacy activists began a boycott and a prominent House Democrat denounced the plan .
An Intel management committee , after hearing from marketing , privacy , and engineering representatives who were opposed to the idea , reportedly made the decision not to include similar features in the much-anticipated Willamette chip , the source said .
Besides the serial number , the other missing features include support for hardware digital certificates -- something banking and finance firms would have preferred , the source said .
David Sobel , general counsel of the Electronic Privacy Information Center , cheered the move .
" We 've always said that certain institutional users might want it , " Sobel said . "
But it 's always been a question of user choice .
And the vast majority of individual users did not want their machines to be branded with an identifier . "
At the RSA Data Security conference in January 1999 , an Intel executive said the ID number could be used to boost security in e-commerce .
" You think about this maybe as a chat room , where unless you 're able to deliver the processor serial number , you 're not able to enter that protected chat room and providing a level of access control , " said Patrick Gelsinger , an Intel vice president .
But privacy activists saw it differently , and mounted a campaign against the ID number .
EPIC even fired off Freedom of Information Act requests to find out if the feds pressured Intel to include the ID . "
No agency has yet acknowledged any involvement .
But they have not all responded yet , " Sobel said .
The Chinese government , according to one news report , was so spooked by the ID number that it cautioned against using computers with Pentium IIIs .
Intel released a software program -- albeit a buggy one -- to disable the serial number , and then a BIOS modification .
Jason Catlett of Junkbusters says he 's glad to see that Intel decided to avoid a repeat of the controversy when Willamette is released in fall 2000 .
" I 'm not surprised , but I 'm still delighted .
It 's a chapter that I and all privacy advocates are very glad to close , " Catlett said .
" We can finally call off the boycott , " he said .




On Opening Up the Windows

NEW ORLEANS -- It 's a tough task , coming up with a solution that 's not worse than the Microsoft monopoly .
Since breaking up the company has been viewed so negatively by the stock market , how would another possible remedy -- forcing the company to open up the source code to its Windows operating system -- affect the industry ?
The developers who build Windows hardware say it could foster competition and enable them to build better products .
But at the same time , engineers at WinHEC said it could cause confusion and complicate the process .
Giving developers access to the Windows source code , one of the possible remedies that the DOJ and states ' attorneys could recommend , would give developers a greater ability to innovate , Motorola marketer Michael Tramontano said .
" It would only better allow us to tailor modems , " he said , and would enable the company to create products that were " more reliable and more robust . "
WinHEC is one of the forums that Microsoft uses to provide OS information to developers of PCs and peripherals .
Microsoft charges premiums to companies to attend workshops , license software development kits , or provide various levels of technical support .
James Horng , director of technical marketing at telecommunications company PCtel , said that Microsoft will provide the necessary information to companies that are willing to pay to partner with Microsoft .
But not all companies are treated equally .
Opening up the Windows source code could spawn a new industry of Windows service specialists , as Red Hat and Caldera have done for Linux , Horng said .
But Microsoft might not have the same incentives to provide support if it does n't have total control of the operating system , which could create headaches for developers who would then have to deal with third-party companies .
But Horng said that some censuring of Microsoft might be appropriate because " we do n't want them to become more powerful . "
Open-source development , where code is written by a community of developers instead of a single company , continues to gain popularity in government circles .
Three French lawmakers have proposed requiring the use of open-standards software in all of the country 's public administrations and organizations .
On Tuesday Microsoft said that the French proposals could threaten intellectual property rights .
Kim Akers , Microsoft 's program manager in the embedded operating systems group , said the company has taken a bad rap .
It is willing to license and share information about its operating systems , she said .
" The perception of Windows that it is all or nothing is wrong , " Akers said , adding that Microsoft is increasing the number of options for developers .
" We let developers get into the goo enough to make products without messing with reliability . "
Akers said developers prefer to work with Microsoft over open-source vendors because " Microsoft is going to be around in six to eight years . "
But David Chu , product application engineer at networking company Conexant , said having just a single vendor to deal with is efficient . "
Since they are a monopoly , you just go to one company , " he said , adding that it is always preferable to deal with the company that originated the software .
Microsoft has until May 10 to respond to the suggested sanctions , which are expected to be announced this week .
The government attorneys must file a rebuttal by May 17 , and a hearing to consider possible remedies is scheduled for May 24 .




PCs Take On VCRs and HDTV

NEW ORLEANS -- PCs may soon be the cheapest way to watch HDTV and " timeshift " television broadcasts .
At WinHEC on Wednesday , software companies Ravisent and Ligos showed off inexpensive alternatives to purchasing new televisions and dedicated boxes .
Companies including Tivo and ReplayTV have created the category of digital VCRs that enable users to pause , rewind , fast-forward , and even record broadcasts through boxes connected to the television .
PC companies are mimicking these features by adding controls to their MPEG software , which uses the CPU for playback instead of the expensive decoding chips .
Ravisent Technologies showed off its CineMaster software , which it 's licensing to computer manufacturers and video-card makers .
Ravisent CTO Michael Harris said ATI has signed on to incorporate the software with its TV tuner cards , and should have the product available by August .
He said the current version of the software makes a copy of whatever program is being watched into a temporary file that uses available disk space and requires about one gigabyte per hour of video .
Ravisent will eventually add TV program guides that enable users to schedule recording as well as picture-in-picture features .
Harris expects PC makers such as Dell and Gateway , which currently license their software DVD playback technology , to also distribute the software .
Ravisent marketing manager Lori Crenny said the software will be sold with Conexant 's $ 150 HDTV tuner card as an alternative to buying a TV , which can cost several thousand dollars .
The company said its software requires 600 MHz or faster PCs .
Ligos Technology demonstrated similar software that is being used by ATI 's All-In-Wonder TV tuner card and products from 3 dfx .
The company also is talking to set-top box manufacturers and additional video-card partners .

The device will be sold by both Siemens and Casio , and includes the Cassiopeia 's color touch-screen along with Siemens ' leading wireless GSM technology .
The unnamed product enables users to browse the Web using the wireless access protocol , or even to watch streamed videos .
It will be launched early next year in Europe , and then the United States and Japan .

SDMI Do n't Think So : Dave Rossum , chief scientist at audio hardware company Creative Labs , said the SDMI initiative to protect digital music copyrights only has a 50/50 chance of succeeding .
He said it 's tough to enforce something that has no apparent consumer benefit . "
People do n't mind paying artists for music , but SDMI only works to pay the labels , " he said .
Rossum also said some music publishers are releasing content with less content protection than they mutually agreed to under SDMI guidelines .
If that continues , the domino effect will take all of the teeth out of SDMI , he said .

An IBM engineer said he could not disclose how the company is packing in the extra data or provide pricing information , but he did say it would still be too costly to use in MP3 players anytime soon .




E-Biz Keeps Humming Along

Tech stocks may be taking a pounding , and dot coms may be disappearing almost as fast as they turn up , but the overall picture for e-commerce remains pretty rosy .
The most recent consumer survey reports that Web shoppers spent about $ 7 billion online in the first quarter of 2000 , about the same as they did during their holiday frenzy last year .
An additional $ 13.8 billion in phone sales and in-store shopping was generated by the Net , the survey said .
Although there was no rise in revenue between the two quarters , the survey -- conducted by Harris Interactive -- concluded that it amounts to a net gain since the phenomenon continues to grow : The total number of shoppers has increased by 15 percent since the holidays .
Items that were hot sellers during the holidays -- toys , clothing , and consumer electronics -- cooled off during the first quarter .
Auction sites , led by eBay , are the big winners so far this year , along with sites selling health and beauty products and travel services .
Growth was also steady among sites pushing personal computers , books , music , and videos .

ContentGuard , which was developed at the Xerox Palo Alto Research Center , provides software that gives publishers and authors more control over how books and music are distributed over the Web .
Xerox said it will retain a majority stake in ContentGuard , which was formerly known as Xerox Rights Management Group .
The exact amount of Microsoft 's investment was not disclosed .

It will not cover air transportation services .
The six founders are Air France , American Airlines , British Airways , Continental Airlines , Delta Air Lines and United Airlines .
The company , as yet unnamed , will be based in the United States .
A technology partner will be selected later , a spokesman said .

Some of that reflects the sag in technology stocks , which have taken a beating since the original deal was announced in early February .
