This could explain Anjabi 's link in Tanzania -- she was launch pad No. 2 , " he said .
" One thing is for sure , this was not a single launch , " said Gagn . "
Just like a fire , the spread was too quick . "




Flash Is a Gas , Gas , Gas

Not so long ago , Web designers who wanted to create fancy sites with dynamic interfaces had to take a deep breath and code their pop-up menus and glowing menu buttons in Sun 's Java .
But buggy Java engines , performance problems , and design tools geared toward programmers instead of graphic artists has prompted a mass exodus from Java to a once-obscure format originally intended for animators : Macromedia 's Flash .
These days Flash , a vector format for delivering interactive graphics over low bandwidths , is turning up all over the place .
For the first time , entire e-commerce sites are being created in it , including those for big names such as Coca Cola , Sean " Puffy " Comb 's BadBoy conglomerate , and Volkswagen .
Another sign of its increasing popularity is the number of banner ads produced in Flash .
" That says a lot about the reach of the Flash plug-in , " said Taylor , an interface designer with Red Industries , a San Francisco design firm .
" Flash is everything Java applets were supposed to be , " said Phillip Torrone , director of new media at BrainCraft , a New York Web development shop . "
People are putting it in cars and cell phones .
I think it 's the way to display ads in Times Square or read books in an e-book .
It 's an exciting time to be a Flash developer . "
Torrone , a Macromedia partner who sits on the Flash advisory board , is building the first online bank entirely in Flash .
" You could n't do a whole bank in Java , " Torrone said . "
It 's too unstable .
There are too many different implementations on different browsers and different platforms .
It has lower penetration and there are security issues like malicious Java applets .
Flash is almost foolproof .
It 's just graphics .
There 's no key to the door . "
When it comes to building user interfaces , Flash 's big advantage over Java is its ease of use , said Jeremy Clark , associate product manager for Flash at Macromedia .
" People can pick it up in a couple of days and just start playing with it , " he said . "
You do n't have to be a programmer . "
" It 's a beautiful tool , " agreed Florian Schmitt , co-designer of the critically acclaimed Soulbath site . "
It 's very easy to learn and you can do so much with it .
It 's a little plug-in and very reliable . "
" Java does a lot of things but there 's a steep learning curve , " said Phil Stephenson , who used Flash to create a room planner while at InterNoded that lets shoppers see if the sofa they are interested in will fit in their living room .




Cisco Earnings on the Money

Cisco Systems Tuesday reported third-quarter operating profits that rose 58 percent while sales surged 55 percent as the biggest maker of data networking equipment sold more Internet gear to businesses , telephone and cable companies , and Internet service providers .
For the period ended April 29 , Cisco said it had earnings before one-time items of $ 1.03 billion , or 14 cents a share , up from $ 649 million , or 9 cents , a year ago .
CSCO
Sales rose to $ 4.92 billion from $ 3.17 billion .
The results topped analyst forecasts of 13 cents a share , according to First Call/Thomson Financial .
Even though Cisco stock fell 7 percent on Monday amid investor concern over its valuation and acquisition strategy , the shares have soared 131 percent in the last 12 months , more than double the gain of the Dow Jones Communications Technology Index .
Cisco is benefiting from the rapid roll-out of the Internet and its embrace by governments and businesses .
Including one-time items , Cisco said it had net income of $ 662 million , or 9 cents a share , compared with $ 636 million , or 9 cents a share , in the year-ago period .
This was the ninth quarter in a row the company has reported operating profits that topped analyst forecasts by precisely one penny .
Cisco stock ended the day unchanged at 62-3/4 .
The company 's shares had taken a beating Monday , however , following a bearish report in Barron 's that questioned its high market capitalization .




Windows-Haters Crow Over Worm

While most of the world convalesces from the Love Bug worm , people running alternatives to Windows are smugly congratulating themselves for knowing better than to use Microsoft software .
The Love Bug and its variants over the last few days have melted down millions of computers worldwide and caused billions of dollars in damages .
But clever users running Macs , the BeOS , and various flavors of Unix happily gloat that they were immune to the attacks .
Many of these users gleefully pointed out on message boards and mailing lists that the worm did n't do damage to all computer users ; it only harmed Windows users who employ Microsoft 's Outlook and Outlook Express email software .
" The point is that the root cause of these mass virus proliferations is a pathetically insecure email client foisted upon the public by a certain evil monopoly whose name I need not mention , " wrote Seldolivaw Ssov in an email . "
Hey , this * only* happens when you use Outlook and Outlook Express ! "
" I think the reason it spread is because so many people use Outlook Express , " said Jessie Liu , an analyst with market research firm Dataquest . "
And the second reason is , people need to get more education about how to protect themselves from the network . "
According to Dataquest , approximately 95 percent of the world 's PCs are Intel-compatible , and the vast majority run Windows in one flavor or another .
As for Outlook and Outlook Express , Dataquest estimates 60 percent of business users are running those products , a number that is likely to increase as more and more IT managers dump Lotus Notes in favor of Microsoft products , Liu said .




Cybersex Visits the Ivory Tower

SAN FRANCISCO -- It 's back to the three Rs at San Francisco State University : reading , ' riting and , of course , raunchy cybersex .
Beginning Sunday , SFSU will sponsor a university-level course on cybersex .
Instructor Mary Madden said the two-day seminar will address everything from images of cybersex in films like Sleeper to the basics of " hot chat . "
" The time has come for cybersexuality to be studied on an academic level , " she said . "
It 's a medium that 's just emerging so far , but it 's come a long way in just a few years . "
She also wants to show how adult sites have pushed the development of online technologies and continue to champion new tech-like Web-controlled sex toys .
" As technologies emerge , they 're being pushed along by pornographers , " she said . "
Live Web video , interactive chat -- they got their start at adult sites , and once perfected there these technologies began to be a possibility for other kinds of sites . "
Anyone can sign up for the extended-learning course , though it does n't count for credit toward a degree.
" A degree in cybersexuality -- that 's a few years away , " Madden said . "
Right now we just want to turn people on to what 's technologically out there and see the possibilities for the future . "
The course is $ 100 and will be offered May 7 and 14 , as well as during the summer .




Dinos Too Cool for School

LOS ANGELES -- Dinosaur-crazy execs at Disney wanted a new adventure film , but how do you top the Jurassic Park films for special effects ?
That was the dilemma facing Disney animators when they began pulling together plans for Dinosaur , an epic about what happened when a calamitous meteor shower smacked into the earth and snuffed out all the dinosaurs .
What they 've dreamed up for the May 19 release is a combination of digitized real-life and dreamed-up images that blurs the boundaries between live-action and animated films .
" This film is 87 minutes of special effects , " said Fred Tio , Walt Disney Motion Picture Group 's senior vice president of marketing . "
The characters are computer-animated and all of their environment is live action , " said Tio .
To create the backdrop for the movie , Disney animators traveled to spots around the world , ranging from Africa to Hawaii to the Los Angeles Arboretum .
There they took digital pictures of landscapes and vegetation from every conceivable perspective .
They brought those images back to a new , four-story computer graphics complex near the Burbank Airport to insert rough animations into each scene .
Then they traveled back to the original spots to catch the lighting , shadows and other details to make the integration of animation and background as seamless as possible .
The special effects do n't come cheap either : at $ 130 million , Dinosaur is the most expensive animated film ever made , and dwarfs the roughly $ 70 million Disney spent on Toy Story .
The film continues a long Disney tradition of combining live-action and animated footage , from " Mary Poppins to its Wide World of Disney television series to Who Framed Roger Rabbit ? "
" In an interesting way , it 's really pushing Walt 's vision of what he wanted Walt Disney to be , " Tio said .
The scenes are realistic enough that you might want to think twice about taking your preschooler to it .
Disney 's first PG-rated animated film has enough carnivores-feasting-on-gentle-plant-eaters stuff to make some folks squeamish .
That 's partly by design .
" They 're really after the young teen market , " said Robert Bucksbaum , president of Reel Source , a box office market research firm . "
The younger kids will want to come , too , because their older peers are watching and there 's a ' cool ' factor . "
Bucksbaum predicts that the film will gross around $ 215 million , which would make it the fourth most successful animated film of all time after three other Disney movies , The Lion King , Toy Story II , and Aladdin .
" The film is a slam-dunk , " he said . "
Dinosaurs are one of the things kids care most about , along with bugs .
A lot of people are also going to come just to see what $ 130 million of animation can buy . "
Disney has clearly also spent big on the Dinosaur website .
It features the movie soundtrack playing continuously , plenty of flash animation for viewing dinosaurs from every conceivable angle , " dino cards " that kids can send to their friends and , of course , the movie trailer .
Soon-to-launch interactive sections will focus on the making of the movie , allowing users to animate a brachiosaur foot , construct a scene , or use a " location scouting " tool that simulates the process animators used to decide where to shoot backdrops .
Dinosaur is the first of what could be a flood of films over the next few years that blend reality and digital animation .
Sony , for example , is planning Final Fantasy , the Movie , which reportedly will feature real-life and digitally animated characters that are impossible to tell apart .




Newspapers Link to the Future

When the Post and Courier newspaper in Charleston , South Carolina , went to press on Monday , it became the first printed paper to include hyperlinks in its stories .
These are not just printed URLs , but rather tiny barcodes embedded within news stories and advertisements .
Readers scan the barcodes , which contain URLs , with a Post and Courier-provided laser pen attached to a PC with Internet access and they are taken directly to the specific websites .
" I think newspapers ought to be doing all we can to get involved in new media , " said Larry Tarleton , the newspaper 's assistant publisher . "
This new technology is a great way to connect the reader of the printed word with the Internet .
And it gives the newspaper the ability to get readers as much information as we possibly can . "
The technology developed by GoCode is an experiment for the newspaper and is currently being used by only about 100 people .
The Post and Courier has a circulation of 110,000 .
GoCode chairman Tom Pickens said the technology is an attempt to help bridge the gap between newspapers and online media by creating a seamless network of information .
" We use the paper to get people around the Internet because people have a trusted relationship with the editors and reporters at the papers they read , " he said . "
People see an article in the paper and they clip it out to use later at their computers .
This technology is going help make this less painful for the readers to do that . "
This technology can help print versions of newspapers maintain viability while also driving traffic to the Web -- a problem that newspapers have been dealing with for several years .
Overall newspaper revenue in the United States for 1999 reached $ 58 billion with classified ads making up about $ 19 billion of that , said Kevin McCourt , director of online classified advertising for the Newspaper Association of America .
While classified advertising has continued to grow over the past several years , for a while it looked like online businesses such as monster.com that aggregate employment listings might cut into print media 's revenue stream .
So newspaper groups began forming large classified cooperatives such as Classified Ventures to aggregate advertisements from large papers into one giant searchable pool .
With this new technology , print advertisements can be sold for more money and provide more value to the consumers .
" Readers expect their newspaper to help link them to the Internet , but they do n't expect that their multimedia sites are going to help them link to the print papers , " said McCourt . "
If we can make it easier to get our readers from the print classified ads to the online ads , we 've made it easier for our readers to not go somewhere else to get the same information . "
While maintaining the business operations of a newspaper is important , Craig Branson of the American Society of Newspaper Editors said that using technology to maintain local flavor is what counts .
" It 's obvious to me that the newspaper in 20 years will look much different than the newspaper now .
Whether it looks like the barcodes that are coming out today or electronic paper in the future , people are always going to be seeking the news about their local communities .
And the great thing about this technology is that it helps local papers bring local news and information to people in a richer way . "




MyMP3.com Nixes Major Labels

MP3.com on Wednesday halted access to major-label music for users of the company 's controversial my.mp3.com service as MP3.com and the recording industry continued to try to settle the industry 's copyright infringement lawsuit against the company .
My.mp3.com allows registered users to access music from the company 's database , which translates the songs into a library of MP3s .
Before users can have the music streamed to them , they have to load a physical CD that contains the album into their computer .
Users signed up for the service still will be able to listen to over 400,000 songs from independent artists and smaller labels in the library , just not those from major labels .
The move comes after the Recording Industry Association of America won its court battle against the company last month .
U.S. District Court Judge Jed S. Rakoff ruled that the digital music company 's creation of a database of 45,000 CDs infringed on the labels ' copyrights .
" MP3.com is vigorously in pursuit of both a settlement of the copyright infringement claims and an ongoing licensing agreement with all the major labels , " MP3.com CEO Michael Robertson wrote in an open letter to my.mp3.com subscribers released on the company 's website Wednesday .
One industry watcher called the move a potential negotiating point for the suit .
" There has n't been an injunction issued by the judge so MP3.com didnt have to do this , but I can n't imagine this is anything other than a negotiating point , " said Mary Rasenberger , an Internet entertainment lawyer with Morrison & Foerster in New York . "
MP3.com had no leg to stand on , and whatever you think politically about this service , under the current law they do n't have a good case even on appeal . "
In the suit , the recording industry had asked for damages that could have put the company out of business .
Copyright law states that those damages fall between $ 750 and $ 30,000 per copyright infringement .
With 45,000 CDs in the database and 12 songs per CD , that puts likely damages in the neighborhood of $ 800 million at the very minimum , although the penalties could reach into the billions .
Recent talks have put the settlement figure around $ 100 million , which would allow Robertson 's company to continue to operate .
With $ 370 million in the bank and a cash-burn rate of about $ 3 million per quarter , MP3.com is financially sound .
Robertson also said that since my.mp3.com service was free , even if the service is shut down , the company would not be losing any revenue .
" This is a groundbreaking time for digital music , copyright law and the Internet in general .
You have my word that MP3.com will act responsibly , work tirelessly  and remain a beacon of progress in the digital music space , " he wrote in the open letter .




Worm Suspect : ' I Did n't Mean It '

MANILA , Philippines -- A Filipino computer school dropout under investigation over the " Love Bug " virus may have mistakenly transmitted the crippling cyber-worm but did not mean any harm , his lawyer said on Thursday .
Onel de Guzman , a 24-year-old former student of AMA Computer College in the Philippine capital , held a news conference with his lawyer on Thursday after investigators summoned him and his sister Irene for questioning over the virus .
AMACC
Officials said Irene de Guzman owns a flat which was searched on Monday by police trying to trace the source of the virus that crippled computers around the world and caused billions of dollars damage .
De Guzman dropped out of AMACC after submitting a thesis describing a program similar to the destructive " Love Bug " virus .
He was asked at the news conference if he might have mistakenly transmitted the " Love Bug " virus , which crippled computers in the United States , Great Britain , and other countries and is estimated to have cost $ 7 billion in damages .
" It is possible , " his lawyer Rolando Quimbo said , answering for de Guzman .
On Wednesday , AMACC distributed copies of de Guzman 's thesis proposal describing a programme designed to steal passwords and gain free access to the Internet .
Asked if his client was unaware of the potential destructive capacity of the program , Quimbo said : " I would say he was not aware and he did not even know that any act on his part would really come to the results that had been reported . "
The National Bureau of Investigation said earlier that it had summoned de Guzman and his sister for questioning on Thursday over the virus .
NBI
But Quimbo said he had advised them not to comply since no court order had been issued for them to appear .
" No subpoena or warrant of arrest has been issued , so why should they give themselves up ? "
Quimbo said .
NBI officials were not available for comment .
The school said de Guzman had excelled in his computer courses but dropped out after his thesis proposal was rejected as unethical .
School officials have not heard from him since .
" The Internet is supposed to be educational so it should be free , " de Guzman 's lawyer quoted him as saying .
Quimbo said de Guzman was fond of computers and usually spent an average of four to five hours every time he went online .
De Guzman could not recall where he was on the days the virus first spread last week .
De Guzman , whose whispered answers to questions from reporters were mostly translated by his lawyer , said he was afraid because his name had been thrust into the limelight .
The NBI said they had followed up clues from data retrieved from the virus program and via two Philippine e-mail addresses through which the " Love Bug " penetrated the Internet .
Analysts in New York told Reuters that de Guzman 's proposed " E-mail Sender Trojan " was similar to the " Love Bug " virus .
This week , the NBI arrested Reonel Ramones , a 27-year-old bank employee who lives with de Guzman 's sister , and later released him .
Ramones is due to face charges on May 19 .




Napster Users Get the Boot

Napster on Wednesday blocked access to its software for hundreds of thousands of users the heavy-metal band Metallica claims is offering its music for illegal trade .
The move , affecting 317,377 people , may prompt future legal battles between the band and its fans .
" Napster has taken extraordinary steps to comply with Metallica 's demands to block hundreds of thousands of its fans from using the Napster system .
Napster has always stated that it would act in response to notice from copyright holders and it has lived up to that commitment in good faith , " said Napster lawyer Laurence Pulgram .
Users who sign on to their Napster accounts receive a message saying they are being denied access to the file-sharing program because they have been accused of illegally swapping files .
Those who have been blocked will n't have an easy time regaining access to the service .
According to a release posted on the Napster website , users who claim to have been unfairly targeted can file a " counter-notice , " which essentially challenges the validity of their dismissal from the system .
According to rules outlined in the Digital Millennium Copyright Act , Metallica then has 10 working days to take legal action against the user .
If no action is taken , the user 's access to the Napster application will be reinstalled .
" The problem with counter-notice is that you have to stand up and identify yourself by putting your name and address up , " said Fred Von Lohmnann , a copyright lawyer with Morrison & Forester . "
That makes it much easier for Metallica to find you .
And I 'd hate to be the first guy to stand up and have the band decide to make an example of me . "
Users who do n't want to make themselves known and instead try to register for a new account are faced with technical challenges that could perplex novice users , Von Lohmann said .
Reinstalling the Napster software requires more than deleting the cookie file and creating a new account , he said .
Von Lohmann was unaware of any effective way of getting around this .
Metallica sued Napster last month , charging that the company encourages piracy by enabling and allowing its users to trade copyrighted songs through its servers .
The Recording Industry Association of America filed a similar lawsuit against the company in December , claiming the application had created a safe haven for piracy .
Napster unsuccessfully requested that the court dismiss that suit since the company considers itself an ISP and therefore exempt from liability under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act .
A federal judge refused to dismiss the case , in part because Napster had not posted and enforced its policy on banning access to those who have violated copyrights .
Reuters contributed to this report .




Call it Slash-and-Burn.org

Thursday just was n't a good day for geek-culture destination Slashdot .
First came the news that Microsoft ordered Slashdot to delete discussions of one of the company 's security products .
Just as angry Linux users were furiously lashing out at the nastygram from Redmond 's legal department , a distributed denial of service attack hit Slashdot , taking it intermittently offline for a few hours .
" About 400 readers weighed in over the first 30 minutes .
Then we got hit by a DDOS , " wrote Slashdot founder Rob Malda in email to Wired News .
Slashdot staffers initially did n't know what the problem was .
At noon EDT , Robin Miller , the editor in chief of Andover.net -- which owns Slashdot -- said he thought the network outage was due to a recent change in servers .
By 4:30 p.m. , engineers had identified it as a denial of service attack .
Malda said he could n't provide details , " and we 're still cleaning up , " he said .
Discussion then turned back to the first threat Slashdot received : The lawyer letter from Microsoft .
Miller said he has not deleted the 11 messages that Microsoft claims are illegal under the Digital Millennium Copyright Act , and is waiting to hear from legal counsel and readers .
DMCA
The response from Slashdot regulars was fast and furious .
In the first hour , hundreds of readers weighed in , many condemning Microsoft 's action as another example of the company 's desire to crush free-wheeling discussion in general , and the Linux community in particular .
" No matter what Microsoft threatens , no matter what they say , do not give in to them .
This is not because it is Microsoft , but because free speech is far too important , especially on a forum such as Slashdot .
Give them hell , " wrote one respondent .
" Under the provisions of the DMCA , we expect that having been duly notified of this case of blatant copyright violation , Andover will remove the above referenced comments from its servers , " says the email from Microsoft 's J.K. Weston .
The letter is particularly galling to Slashdotters since it includes a generous helping of everything they love to hate : Microsoft , lawyers , and the DMCA , which the motion picture industry has already used in one prominent lawsuit to try to stamp out a DVD-descrambling utility .
Microsoft is concerned about a Slashdot thread from May 2 that talks about the company 's proprietary extensions to the Kerberos security protocol , which was originally designed at MIT in the 1980s and has been adopted by the Internet Engineering Task Force as an open standard .
Microsoft Kerberos as used in Windows 2000 is partially incompatible with the rest of the computing world .
As if that were n't offensive enough , to read Microsoft 's own Kerberos specification , developers had to run an .exe file with a confidential license agreement included .
That kind of hiding-technical-information approach did n't sit well with members of the Slashdot community , which quickly posted ways to download the specification and bypass the restrictive license agreement .
Microsoft was n't amused .
It accused Slashdot of " unauthorized reproductions of Microsoft 's copyrighted work .
...
In addition , some comments include links to unauthorized reproductions of the specification , and some comments contain instructions on how to circumvent the End User License Agreement that is presented as part of the download for accessing the specification . "




MS Proposes Own Remedies

Microsoft will n't be broken up without a fight .
The Redmond , Washington software maker proposed restrictions on its business practices Wednesday , asking the court to reject a government plan to divide the software giant in two to curb its monopoly power .
The company said it would allow computer manufacturers to drop Microsoft 's Internet Explorer desktop icon , and also promised to prominently feature any software , including from Microsoft rivals , on the Windows desktop .
In addition , Microsoft said it would offer equal contracts to computer makers , regardless of whether they agreed to support competitors ' software .
It would also provide equal access to technology that would allow any software maker , including the company 's competitors , to easily write programs for Windows .
District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson had ordered Microsoft to submit its own plan after ruling April 3 that the company broke U.S. antitrust law by abusing its monopoly in operating systems for personal computers .
Microsoft , which has insisted it followed the law and promised to vigorously appeal Jackson 's findings , said if the judge insisted on considering the breakup plan then further hearings should be held , starting in December .
The company said the trial had failed to find that there would be greater competition for operating systems in the absence of Microsoft 's conduct .
" The government 's adventurous request to split Microsoft into two companies should be rejected as a matter of law , " Microsoft submitted to the judge .
The legal brief reiterates themes company executives have put forth in the last month : A breakup will harm consumers , stifle innovation , and slam the brakes on future software development in all areas at Microsoft .
" Even without the extreme breakup proposal , many elements of the government 's proposed regulations are unwarranted , outside the scope of this case , and very damaging to consumers , " Gates said . "
The government 's proposals would take away Microsoft 's property by forcing us to disclose the source code for our products , even though Microsoft spent hundreds of millions of dollars to develop these products .
The government also seeks to interfere with the design of Microsoft 's products . "
Added CEO Steven Ballmer : " The government 's proposals really represent government regulation of software design and an unwarranted taking of Microsoft 's intellectual property . "
Among Microsoft 's remedies were the following points , according to a media release issued by the company :
Microsoft would be required to allow computer manufacturers to delete the Internet Explorer icon from the Windows desktop and Start menu , offer their own Internet sign-up process in the initial Windows boot sequence , display icons for non-Microsoft platform software products on the Windows desktop , and configure non-Microsoft Web browsing software as the default browser ; Microsoft would not be allowed to deny any independent software developer timely and complete access to the technical information Microsoft makes available to the software development community at large .
Microsoft would be enjoined from entering into contracts to promote any product or service through Windows in exchange for the other party agreeing to limit distribution of non-Microsoft platform software ; Microsoft would not withhold the release of any software product designed to run on a non-Microsoft platform that is ready for commercial release in order to urge the vendor of the platform to limit the development , manufacture , distribution or promotion of a platform software product that competes with Microsoft ; Whenever Microsoft releases a major Windows operating system such as Windows 95 or Windows 98 , the company would be required to make the predecessor operating system available to computer manufacturers at a royalty no higher than the existing royalty .
Under Microsoft 's proposal , the company would pay the attorneys ' fees and other costs of the 19 plaintiff states that were party to the lawsuit .
This is Microsoft 's first non-defensive stance since Jackson ruled that Microsoft was a recidivist monopolist .
When the Justice Department and state attorneys general responded to Jackson 's decision by urging him to split Microsoft into two companies , that defense grew more frantic . "
This company will not be broken up , " Ballmer said two weeks ago . "
Microsoft will continue to move forward . "
Not if lawyers at the Department of Justice 's antitrust division have their way .
Not only would their plan break up the company into operating system and applications software components , it would impose extraordinarily strict regulations on what Microsoft can do for the next few years .
The proposed remedy would limit what discounts Microsoft can offer , create a new antitrust bureaucracy inside the company , and provide for day-to-day oversight over software development operations .
During a speech Tuesday at the University of California at Berkeley 's business school , the Justice Department 's top antitrust official described the proposal as an appropriate punishment for antitrust wrongdoing .
" A separate applications company would have the incentive to develop the best possible office suite , not only for Windows , but also for other computing platforms like the Apple and Linux operating systems , " assistant attorney general Joel Klein said in prepared remarks .
" Indeed , much like the browser was in 1995 , before Microsoft commenced its illegal campaign , Office has the very real potential to be a cross-platform middleware threat to the dominance of the Windows monopoly .
" Now , there are some who are suggesting that the reorganization will result in a loss of efficiency currently generated by the coexistence of the operating system business and the applications business under one roof .
That argument is wrong as a matter of fact , and wrong as a matter of history as well , " Klein said .
Jackson has set a May 24 date for oral arguments on the proposed penalty , though Microsoft has signaled it may want more time to prepare .




Ultra-Wideband on Its Way ?

WASHINGTON -- Federal regulators took a step toward approving an innovative wireless technology known as ultra-wideband Wednesday but acknowledged concerns it could interfere with some key existing technologies such as the global positioning system .
GPS
The Federal Communications Commission unanimously backed a proposal to consider ultra-wideband for operation on an unlicensed basis and gave until October 30 for interested parties to submit test results .
As its name suggests , ultra-wideband uses a broad swath of the radio spectrum but in millions of pulses of low-powered emissions per second .
The technology has the potential to support an array of new uses from radar imaging of objects buried in the ground or behind walls to high-speed data transfer over short distances .
Huntsville , Alabama-based Time Domain Corp. received an FCC waiver in June last year to sell a limited number of its RadarVision units to police and emergency units to evaluate their ability to locate criminals behind walls or find survivors in an earthquake .
But the aviation community has expressed concern that ultra-wideband could interfere with the low-powered signals emitted by the GPS satellite system .
GPS , with its ability to precisely fix location and time , is increasingly being incorporated into efforts to safely squeeze more aircraft into the crowded U.S. air route system .
The Air Travelers Association said the FCC had put ultra-wideband on a fast track in response to an extraordinary lobbying effort on behalf of the new technology .
" This rush to judgment could be a potential disaster for airline safety , " said association president David Stempler .
FCC Chairman William Kennard said Wednesday 's action would allow the agency to determine where it could be safely used for the benefit of the American public .
" Ultra-wideband is a promising , spectrum-efficient technology that could provide tremendous benefits for public safety and for persons seeking broadband Internet access , " Kennard said in a statement .




Sega Owners Eye Sony Games

Lo , Sega Dreamcast owners : Thou need no longer covet thy neighbor 's Sony PlayStation games .
Soon you can play them , too .
A new line of software emulators previewed Thursday will allow Dreamcast owners to play hundreds of titles originally written for the PlayStation .
Each of four emulators , known collectively as bleem ! for Dreamcast , can run 100 different PlayStation games on the Sega console .
The maker , Bleem Inc. , is already embroiled in legal battles with Sony over software that allows PlayStation titles to run on PCs .
More courtroom wrangling can probably be expected following Thursday 's announcement .
Bleem plans to release the four game backs -- selling at $ 20 a pop -- sometime this summer .
Meanwhile , Sony is reportedly close to announcing that its answer to the Dreamcast -- its long-awaited PlayStation2 console -- will be available in Europe and the United States on Oct. 26 .

IBM bulks up : Big Blue , moving to challenge Sun Microsystems in its core computer market , unveiled three new computers Thursday designed for running online businesses .
The servers , which use performance-boosting , copper-chip technology , are built to carry out basic website tasks such as e-commerce and traffic management , IBM said .
This represents the boldest move yet by the world 's largest computer maker to join the Internet party , to which it was more than fashionably late .
IBM said the selling point for the new RS/6000 machines -- the M80 , F80 , and H80 -- was the use of copper-chip technology , which is said to deliver better performance at a lower cost than rivals ' systems .
Sun currently dominates the market for mid-range computers , defined by market researchers as machines costing between $ 100,000 and $ 1 million .
- - -
Virtual everything : Intel said Thursday that it plans to spend $ 200 million over the next two years building an Internet media business that will allow customers to transmit everything from movies to conferences to online training over the Internet .
The plan is the latest effort by the world 's biggest chipmaker to broaden sales beyond the microprocessors that account for 80 percent of its revenue .
Intel Internet Media Services will turn the Web into a conveyance for transmitting audio and video , which might include conferences , movies , online training , and concerts .
- - -
Copy this : Punctuated by an emphatic " No comment " from Xerox , Rick Thoman submitted his resignation as president and CEO of the world 's largest copier manufacturer Thursday , according to the online edition of the Financial Times .
Although Xerox directors met to consider management issues associated with Thoman 's resignation , the company had nothing to say , other than " Any reports you 've seen are based on rumor and speculation , and Xerox can not comment . "
Paul Allaire , the man Thoman succeeded at the helm of Xerox , will take over on an interim basis .

New drug on the Street : Novartis AG , the Swiss pharmaceuticals company , made the transatlantic jump Thursday , joining the New York Stock Exchange .
It will be listed under the symbol NVS .
Reuters contributed to this report .




Big Three Come to Play at E3

LOS ANGELES -- Sega , Sony , and Nintendo all have monstrous booths next to each other here at the Electronic Entertainment Expo , but booth size is about the only thing that puts the big three on an even keel at the show .
Sega is trying to hold on to the renewed momentum from its Dreamcast , Sony is preparing a massive retail onslaught , and Nintendo was relatively quiet .
Nintendo only made a few Nintendo64 announcements , the most notable being release of " The Legend of Zelda : Majora 's Mask . "
The game is the sequel to " The Legend of Zelda : The Ocarina of Time , " which sold 7 million units .
It will ship in November for $ 69.95 .
The company 's Dolphin console , the successor to Nintendo64 , remains as vaporous as the brown haze hanging over Los Angeles .
Also hiding in the vapor is Microsoft X-Box .
At the product 's introduction in March , the Redmond , Washington , company said it would reveal more information on the console at E3 .
But that was n't the case .
Nintendo and Microsoft may have been quiet , but Sony Computer Entertainment of America grabbed the spotlight by announcing the PlayStation2 would ship in October for $ 299 , the same price as the original PlayStation when it launched in 1995 .
" The PlayStation is not the future of video game entertainment , it is the future of entertainment , period , " said Kazuo Hirai , president and chief operating officer of Sony .
Sony also announced that the PlayStation2 will not come with the 8 MB memory module that the console features in Japan , but instead will sell the module as an add-on for $ 34 .
The American version of the unit will be modified with an expansion bay that can support broadband modems and a hard drive .
Sony expects to sell almost 1 million units in advance of the console 's launch and to sell 3 million units in the United States by March 2001 .
Not to be outdone , Sega of America announced a $ 50 rebate and one month of free access to the SegaNet online service for buyers of the Dreamcast console , making its effective price $ 149 .
This comes one month after the company offered a $ 200 rebate to customers who sign up for the SegaNet service , which launched in September with 12 games .
" We have secured our base of hardcore gamers , and now with the $ 50 introductory offer and the free SegaNet subscription , Sega Dreamcast will reach a broader installed base of consumers and deliver networked gaming to the masses , " said Chris Gilbers , vice president of sales at Sega .

Sega also announced a major concert promotion plan for the summer , including sponsoring the Ozzfest , Family Values Tour and Blink 182 tours .




Visible DNA Idea Wins MIT Award

CAMBRIDGE , Massachusetts -- In one of the most closely followed competitions of its kind in the world , MIT announced this year 's winner of its $ 50,000 entrepreneurship grand prize Wednesday night : the genetic imaging company-to-be EyeGen .
The 11th annual MIT $50K Entrepreneurship Competition encourages MIT students and researchers to apply their expertise to establishing and running their own businesses .
Indeed , since 1990 , previous 50 Ks have launched more than 50 firms -- which , in toto , are now valued at $ 15 billion .
However , considering that this year 's crop alone boasts 40 projects that will be taken to marketplace , the 50K is apparently in the midst of its own youthful growth spurt .
In his introductory remarks , MIT Board of Trustees Chairman Alex d'Arbeloff joked that this time around , he started to worry " like a college basketball coach who fears losing his star players to the NBA . "
" But do n't succumb to that temptation , " he added . "
Finish that degree.
You 'll thank me for this advice someday . "
The 206 teams that entered the competition last fall all followed a year-long series of events and activities led by a team of mentors from the business , finance , and venture capital worlds .
The schedule -- involving workshops on team-building , entrepreneurial strategy , intellectual property , global startups , and strategic partnerships -- centered around helping the participants develop and refine their business plan .
These business plans then formed the basis of the competition , which winnowed the initial field down to 48 semi-finalists in December , and finally , in March , seven finalists .
As a whole , the seven finishers represented the sort of tech-intensive interests one might expect from the world 's most famous nerd sanctuary .
The blue-ribbon winning team from EyeGen told the full house at MIT 's Kresge Auditorium that the company is now looking at an estimated $ 230 million market opportunity for its product : The patented EyeGenRed dye that makes DNA visible to the naked eye .
Currently , radioactivity and ultra-violet fluorescence are used in marking and identifying genetic information in the lab -- both involving expensive equipment , time-consuming processes , and potential hazards for the researcher .
All three , they asserted , are eliminated with EyeGenRed .
" Now we no longer need those stinking badges , " said EyeGen 's Zoran Zdraveski , pointing to the radioactive exposure-monitoring film badge many genetic researchers wear today .
The two 50K runners-up tackled two of the leading technical Internet issues today : distributed computing and network security .
Centrata , which brought its own cheering section to the awards ceremony , borrows from the success of the network number-crunching SETI@home project .
But instead of appealing to users ' curiosity in searching for extraterrestrial intelligence , Centrata appeals to the bottom line .
" I 'm guessing that each of you here tonight has a computer at home that you 're not using right now , " said CEO Shishir Mehrota . "
Well , with Centrata , you can get back value for your computer .
...
We 're creating a marketplace where PC owners can sell unused computing resources . "
Centrata , he said , will offer downloadable software that leases part of a user 's CPU time and hard-drive to Centrata for its clients ' applications .
In the process , he said , Centrata will be combining the world 's fastest computer -- boasting teraflops of processing speed -- with the world 's largest disk drive , offering petabytes of storage space .
Mazu Networks , which will be incorporating next week , bases its technology on Mazu founder Eddie Kohler 's PhD thesis , now in preparation .
The " Mazu box " is a network router that , according to Mazu 's Paul Hsiao , " adapts and learns about network traffic problems and performs network-level congestion control . "
Mazu boxes , Hisao explained , are the ideal antidote to the denial-of-service attacks that have recently plagued such high-profile sites as Amazon.com and eBay . "
DoS
They can detect DoS attacks at gigabit speeds and stop attacks at the source , " he said .
Other finalists included Amtek , which markets the winning invention of this year 's MIT-Lemelson student invention award , Amy Smith 's no-electricity lab incubator for water quality testing in developing countries ; microEngine , which commercializes MIT 's micro jet engine technology to power miniature generators that increase laptop battery pack lifespans by a factor of ten ; and Strong Numbers , which offers a comprehensive database of going rates and bidding strategies for online auctions .
Citing examples of the personal computer , electric car , and the Internet , keynote speaker and former governor William Weld commended the students for championing the " disruptive technologies " that are now entering the marketplace .
" The residual lessons I 'd offer you tonight are two , " he said . "
First , you should circle back to &#91;partner with&#93 ; big , fat , Main Street America .
...
And tell them you 'll still respect them in the morning .
" But , second , when morning comes , " he added , " I want you to fly from your Main Street partners as fast as you can . "




Napster May Not Matter Anymore

Napster may be on its way to becoming irrelevant .
The company came under fire last week as it lost the first round of its court fight against the Recording Industry Association of America and then blocked access to 317,377 people whom Metallica claims have been trading its music illegally on the service .
If Napster strikes a deal with the recording industry or users are charged a fee to trade files , the company could quickly lose its outsider status -- the very thing that gave it cachet with its members .
" It 's really going to be interesting to see what the reaction in the hacker community will be if Napster is forced to sign a deal with the recording industry , " said New York-based copyright lawyer Whitney Broussard .
Regardless of the future of Napster , file-trading applications will continue to exist on the Web , said software consultant David E. Weekly .
" The amazing thing about Napster is n't the program , it 's the idea , " Weekly said . "
You can n't litigate the idea .
You can n't tell people that they need to stop thinking about the idea .
Already we 've seen commercial alternatives pop up with Scour Exchange , so even if Napster is sued out of existence , there are alternatives popping up everywhere . "
a commercial file-trading exchange
What most likely will spring up in its place is a series of open-source programs like Gnutella .
" People download the Napster program and that connects to a Napster server owned by Napster , Inc. , and then the users can begin sharing data , " said Weekly , who reverse-engineered the Napster application and posted the source code on the Web , helping facilitate the open-source coding of the program . "
Once somebody understands the application 's protocol , they can create a client that looks like the Napster program or you could create a server that looks like Napster . "




Who Do Cops Call ?
Virus-Busters

Police investigating computer viruses are increasingly turning to a trio of amateur computer sleuths when they need help tracking cybercriminals .
Love Bug investigators have called on a team that includes a retired East Coast entrepreneur and a pair of Swedish students .
Each member plays an important role in uncovering the digital clues .
To help track down the origin of the Love Bug , dubbed the most destructive email worm unleashed to date , Richard Smith , Fredrik Bjorck and Jonathan James have again joined together to find its origin .
The three first came together to help find the author of the Melissa email worm , which set a new precedent in destructiveness when unleashed last year .
The trios elder statesman , Richard Smith , is a retired programmer from Brookline , Massachusetts , who founded and still owns Phar Lap software , which builds software for embedded systems .
Smith started looking into Web security issues a couple of years ago as a hobby , and in 1999 documented RealNetworks ' sneaky data-gathering practices , uncovered Microsoft 's suspicious registrationprocedures , and was the first to publicize the unique identifying numbers in digital documents .
He later joined with Bjorck and James to track Melissa worm author David Smith .
Fredrik Bjorck is a 27-year-old Ph.D. student in information security at the University of Stockholm and a consultant for a major international tax and accounting firm .
Bjorck said he bought in James , an 18-year-old high school student from Uppsala , a town about an hour north of Stockholm , to do some to help with the laborious task of combing through the source code .
We met via Usenet, explained Bjorck .
Richard was going to try to track down the author of Melissa , and I contacted him to share some information .
From there , we working as a team.
began
Since then the trio has kept in contact through email and phone , but the Swedes and Smith have never met in person .
Last Wednesday , when the Love Bug hit , the three started down different , but ultimately converging , tracks .
Bjorck said he was the first to point out that ISP Access Net in Manila was infected and tracked it to an apartment in Manila .
The group was able to quickly close in on the suspected perpetrators within hours of the worms release .
And as it swept across the world bringing down computers everywhere , the digital detectives quickly identified people who were later questioned by authorities .
The group fingered Filipino college students Onel de Guzman and Michael Beun days before the authorities announced that they wanted to speak to the pair .
James had downloaded the virus and examined the source code revealing the embedded resume of Michael Buen -- a clue , in Bjorcks opinion , that the virus was not meant to be released onto the Internet .
According to Smith , James made the major breakthrough by finding a link between the Love Bug and previously-released viruses , which pointed the trio to the AMA Computer College in the Philippines .
It then became a question of linking the apartment and the college .
So when an MSNBC reporter told Smith about Onel de Guzman , a dropout from the college who also lived in the apartment , Smith connected the dots .
Although Onel de Guzman has been brought in for questioning by authorities in Manila , the team hasnt ruled out the involvement of others .
Bjorck said he may yet turn out to be primary distributor rather than the original author .
He said De Guzman appears to be a member of Grammersoft , a hacking group of AMACC students that ran a business that sold term papers and small business software , according to the college .
The trio is hesitant to talk about its interaction with the FBI .
Smith said only that the FBI was informed at all times .
Bjorck said he wanted to stress that he has only a casual relationship with the authorities .
Just to make this clear .
I personally do not have any formal working agreement with the FBI, said Bjorck .
We do not have a formal relationship , not even a stable informal one .
It is just when we have something that they phone us..
Jim Margolin , a special agent in the FBI 's New York office , which is leading the US investigation , said it was normally against FBI policy to discuss citizens ' investigative contributions .
But in this case , he was willing to confirm the trio were working with investigators .
He would not , however , characterize the nature of their contributions , except to say : " They are recognized by our people to generally know what they are talking about . "
Margolin said the FBI has been in continual contact with the authorities in the Philippines , and said that the FBI is talking to the US Attorney 's office about the possibility of extraditing suspects because of a lack of applicable statutes in the Philippines .
The three sleuths are motivated by the thrill of the chase rather than any mercenary urges .
Basically , we are asking the question , Is it possible to make the Internet secure enough for e-commerce , education and entertainment? Bjorck said .
Its also the challenge " he said . "
Im motivated by gaining knowledge about how this large network really works.

Sony Emulator Plays on Sega

LOS ANGELES -- Software company Bleem has introduced emulation software that allows the popular Dreamcast console to run PlayStation games .
At the Electronics Entertainment Expo here Thursday , the company demonstrated Bleem for Dreamcast software that it claims will play games written for the original PlayStation better on the competing Dreamcast than on Sony 's upcoming PlayStation 2 .
Bleem previously created emulation technology that enabled PCs to use games authored for the PlayStation .
In the new software , Bleem took advantage of the superior processing power in the Dreamcast to double the resolution over PlayStation and add anti-aliasing technology , which makes the graphics appear much smoother .
PlayStation games are displayed in 320x240 pixel resolution on the television set , while Bleem for Dreamcast displays images at 640x480 .
Even though PlayStation 2 will be backwards compatible with PlayStation games and have improved hardware , it will n't support a higher resolution .
" We built a better PlayStation than Sony , " said Sean Kauppinen , director of marketing for Bleem .
Officials from Sony and Sega were unavailable for comment Thursday .
Each $ 19.99 game pack includes emulation software that , once loaded onto the Dreamcast , will enable 100 different games to run .
Users must also have copies of the game software .
The first pack will ship in mid-June , with a second in August and two more by Christmas , providing a total of 400 PlayStation games that will eventually run on Dreamcast .
Kauppinen said Bleem also is developing hardware for Dreamcast players .
The Bleem Pad for Dreamcast , also due out in June , will be a PlayStation-style game controller .
Bleem also is working on a visual memory unit-reader that would enable PlayStation games to be saved on the Dreamcast .
Bleem , based in Los Angeles , currently is locked in a court battle with Sony over the distribution of its PC software .
The company was victorious in two other court cases with Sony last week .
Sony 's attempt to block Bleem from exhibiting was denied .
The other win related to advertising .
Sony had fought to prevent Bleem from using screen shots in advertisements comparing Bleem for Dreamcast to the PlayStation , Kauppinen said . "
Sony argued that screen shots would hurt their sales , but the judge said if their sales slip , it will n't be because of the ads , it 's because the Bleem technology is superior . "




EU Doubles Renewable Energy

BRUSSELS , Belgium -- The European Commission today unveiled its long-awaited proposal for a directive on renewable energy support in the 15 nations of the European Union .
The draft law aims to double the proportion of green energy from 6 percent to 12 percent of primary energy supply by increasing the share of renewably generated electricity from 14 percent to 22 percent by 2010 .
Today 's adoption of the draft directive marks the end of a tortuous process which has seen two previous proposals fall at the final hurdle after opposition from member countries , industry , and environmental groups .
EU Energy Commissioner Loyola de Palacio outlined the thrust of the directive last month and the final draft introduces no changes .
Member states will be able to keep national financial support schemes for at least five years but should eventually adopt a harmonized EU system .
Non-binding indicative national targets for renewables will be set to ensure the overall European Union target is met .
Member states will have to report annually on their progress , and the Commission will propose mandatory targets if national goals are " inconsistent " with the EU target .
With the issue of support schemes side-stepped for the moment , all attention is now likely to fix on the draft indicative targets .
Though these are based on existing national targets for around half of member states , the Commission is proposing that several of them take stronger action .
At least six countries under pressure to launch new , more ambitious policies -- Finland , France , Greece , Luxembourg , the Netherlands , and Portugal .
The renewable energy industry and environmentalists accept that the proposed targets are ambitious but argue that they should be made immediately binding to have real effect .
They predict that finalization of the directive will be delayed as governments try to reduce their share of the burden of reaching the 12 percent target .
Commissioner de Palacio admitted today that there " may be problems " agreeing to final targets in the Council of Ministers .
The directive proposes several other supporting measures for renewables .
Member states would have to certify green energy schemes to enable producers to guarantee that electricity they sell is renewably generated .
The certification requirements would ease green electricity trades if the EU eventually decides for such a system , the Commission said .
Member states will also have to review planning and administrative procedures to " reduce regulatory barriers " to renewables uptake .
This will include setting up single reception points for project applications , better cooperation between authorities , and " fast-track " land-use planning procedures .
Although no mandatory rules will be introduced on sharing the costs of electricity transmission , system operators will be obliged to grant priority to renewable energy generators .
Connection charges , meanwhile , will have to " reflect the economic costs and benefits associated with the connection " so that costs for small generators are not " unfairly prohibitive . "

Los Alamos Fuming Over Nukes

As firefighters struggle to extinguish the ball of fire in Los Alamos , New Mexico that came within 300 yards of a plutonium storage facility , charred 20,000 acres , and drove 20,000 people from their homes , all eyes turn toward the cloud of smoke that is slowly drifting over the city .
Email messages are flying , message boards are overflowing , and the dreaded word on everyone 's lips is " radiation . "
" The fire in Los Alamos , NM is the beginning of the end , " read one message on a posting board . "
I have been sitting in here , watching my television , and looking out my window at the smoke , and it is crazy . "
Residents say they 're worried that the smoke might be contaminated because the fire came so close to the Los Alamos National Laboratories , the nation 's largest nuclear facility .
Officials say they 're monitoring the air for contamination and have found nothing unusual .
" There is no indication of any release from initial sample analyses , " said U.S. Department of Energy spokeswoman Tami Toops at the Joint Information Center in Santa Fe .
And just because the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory has stepped in to monitor the smoke does n't mean anything , officials say .
" We 've been tracking the smoke plumes , " said Livermore Labs spokesman Stephen Wampler . "
The smoke 's really thick . "
He said the reason they were tracking the plumes had nothing to do with radiation concerns .
" Not at this point at all , " he said .
But the " not at this point " kind of response from the government does n't do much to quell the fears of local residents who look out their windows and fear the worst .
Environmentalists and residents have a long history of worrying about the environmental damage that may have resulted from years of weapons work at the Los Alamos laboratory .
Though lab officials say the facility is designed to withstand the impact of a 747 aircraft , area residents are concerned that not all the residue radioactive material is contained within the facility .
According to the Albuquerque Journal , the lab has buried or otherwise discharged toxic and radioactive wastes into nearby canyons , underlying ground water , and at least 1,000 sites over a 56-year period .
According to a recorded message from the Los Alamos Study Group , an independent monitoring team recommended by Concerned Citizens for Nuclear Safety , independent testing has n't turned up anything . Yet .
" We believe there is no real danger to anybody downwind , " the message reads .
But it goes on to say , " We do n't think that the Department of Energy is being very forthcoming .
If there was a problem I do n't think we would hear about it . "
Jim Ellis , director of the National Atmospheric Release Advisory Center , a branch of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory that has responded to past disasters including Three Mile Island , said his department 's involvement in the fire should not indicate an expected repeat of that nuclear accident .
" You can n't read anything into this , " he said . "
When they called us in , it was , ' Hey , we need help with the weather forecast .
' "
Asked whether there could be a threat from the burning of outside areas that may be contaminated , Ellis said , " Draw your own conclusions . "




MS Finally Addresses Email Hole

SEATTLE -- Microsoft said Monday it will issue a patch for its corporate email software that will help defend customers against computer viruses like the recent Love Bug that shut down many company and government networks .
The patch , which is a small bit of programming code that fixes a software bug or changes the way an application works , will stop users of Microsoft 's Outlook software from receiving certain types files that hold the most common viruses .
" Given the fact that Love Bug was a global economic event , we need to do our part ... and take pretty decisive steps here , and we think this will eradicate this class of viruses , " Tom Bailey , Microsoft 's group product manager for Office , said in an interview .
The Love Bug spread by making copies of itself and sending them out to listings in a victim 's email address book in Outlook , Microsoft 's scheduling and communications application for corporations and institutions .
In the wake of the virus attack earlier this month , many analysts pointed a finger at Microsoft , saying the software giant 's products were far too vulnerable to hackers and malicious software programs like the Love Bug .
Microsoft 's fix , which will be available here on May 22 , will not let users open files containing the suffix " .exe , " " . bat , " and others that indicate the file is a program that performs certain functions , Bailey said .
It will not affect picture , document , or Web page file types such as " . jpg , " " .doc , " or " .htm , " because the software tools used to view those files already contained strong security measures , Bailey said .
Outlook would also be updated so that if a program tried to access a user 's address book , a warning would pop up on screen asking whether or not to let the program proceed .
" That is trying to attack the malicious replication and put users back in control , " Bailey said .
pop-up message
Bailey said the pop-up could appear for other legitimate software , such as that for personal digital assistants , that try to access the address book .
Information on what programs will be affected will be posted on the Web page .
" We always try to strike a balance between the openness of the product and security , " Bailey said .
" We 've tried to be reactive to this thing , like antivirus software writers are .
What we are trying to do going forward is to take a more proactive response to this , " he said .

It worked .

You would n't believe how many people microwaved their AOL CDs and sent them to AOL , saying ' Do n't ever advertise in PC Accelerator ever again , ' " said one former staffer .

' Love Bug ' Suspect List Grows

Investigators in the Philippines said they have identified 10 additional suspects in the " Love Bug " virus case .
The names were culled from 17 computer disks seized from the Manila apartment where police say the virus may have been launched .
The virus was tracked to the apartment with relatively simple technology : caller-ID .
The new suspects have not been named , but investigators said many are current and former students at the Amable Mendoza Aguiluz Computer College .
Onel de Guzman , 23 , who lives at the apartment where the computer was taken , attempted to submit a thesis about a Trojan horse that strongly resembles the Love Bug .
He admitted last week that he may have inadvertently launched the virus .
Michael Buen , 23 , an AMACC graduate fingered by college officials last week as a possible collaborator in the computer virus , held a press condference Sunday to deny his involvement .
" In an effort to restore some semblance of normalcy to my life and that of my family , I should like to categorically state for the record that I have no involvement or participation whatsoever in the design , development , creation , or dissemination of the ' I Love You ' virus , " he said in a statement read by his attorney .
According to officials at AMACC , Buen submitted a thesis on the creation of multiple copies of computer files .
Investigators say he may have been working with de Guzman .
The virus is estimated to have caused up to $ 8 billion in damages since its detection May 3 .

And a significant number of the Classic 's fans are going to absurd lengths to upgrade these aging , painfully slow machines .
In Japan , the Club for Creating the Strongest Color Classic , which boasts more than 300 members , has figured out how to slice and dice Power Mac motherboards so that they fit inside the Color Classic 's diminutive case .
Maxus Computer Upgrade Service will shoehorn an iMac motherboard into a Color Classic chassis for a cool $ 2,500 -- the price of two brand-new iMacs .
Tom Owad , who runs AppleFritter , a site dedicated to odd Mac modifications including building a Mac into a suitcase , suggested that the cramped living quarters of many Japanese apartments lends the diminutive Classic its air of desirability .
" The land shortage has a lot to do with it , " he said .
First released in 1992 , the Color Classic is in many ways the progenitor of the iMac : a compact , all-in-one box about the size of a small portable TV .




N.Y. Gets Hip to Cybersex Woes

NEW YORK -- " Cybersex is the crack-cocaine of sex addiction . "
Even in Hicksville , USA , a statement like that would be old news .
But in New York ?
That 's the message Patrick Carnes , clinical director for sexual disorders services at the Wickenburg , Arizona , addiction treatment center the Meadows Institute , was giving this week .
The hook : His message was being delivered to 75 fellow therapists at the Meadows Institute Symposium .
Digital technology is turbo-charging age-old sexual compulsions , creating virulent new strains of sex addiction unheard of just a few years back , he told colleagues gathered at a Manhattan hotel .
" The anonymity of the Internet , the perceived lack of risk , is leading large numbers of people to have problems with sex addiction that would have never had them before , " Carnes said .
Those who already have sexual compulsion problems , moreover , are finding out that the Internet can make things much worse .
Example : A former Meadows patient , Sue , was constantly having affairs during her 13-year marriage .
not her real name
Shortly after discovering the Net , Sue became involved in sexually oriented chat rooms .
Despite a self-imposed , hour-per-night limit , she was soon up all night chatting .
Then , Sue starting giving her phone number out , and having phone sex with men she met online .
Finally , Sue began to meet the men in person .
" She met a guy in a hotel room in a Southeastern state .
He beat her and left her for dead .
When she came out of her coma , she finally decided to get help , " Carnes said .
Not all sexual compulsives are as easy to identify .
And of course , not everyone who checks out Playboy or Penthouse online should be considered a cybersex addict .
But there are ways to identify addicts .
Carnes offers these criteria :
Overuse .
More than six to eight hours per week are spent in online sex .
Recognition of the problem .
Understanding that there 's something wrong .
Interference with life .
Work and relationships become compromised .
Inability to stop .
There have been efforts to set boundaries that have failed .
Sexual compulsion often begins , Carnes said , with the " arousal template " -- a story , image , or a process , often created in youth , which leads to heightened sexual feelings .
All people have such templates .
But for some -- especially those abused in childhood -- accessing the template can lead to feelings of shame , fear , and anger .




Mac OS X Slips Again

SAN JOSE , California -- The delivery date for a shrink-wrapped release of Mac OS X -- Apple 's eagerly awaited next generation operating system -- will not be this summer as planned .
The client version of Mac OS X will be available as a finished , boxed product in January 2001 -- six months later than promised .
Instead , this summer Apple will embark on deploying a wide-scale public beta testing of the same software , Apple 's CEO Steve Jobs announced on Monday at the company 's annual developers ' conference .
The server version of OS X shipped in January of 1998 .
During his keynote speech , Jobs called the modified plans a name-change and not a delay .
" Like a lot of things in life , you can do what you were going to do but change the names of things to make a lot of people happy , " Jobs told the standing-room-only audience for his keynote address .
This is n't the first time the release date for Mac OS X has changed .
When it was announced in 1998 , the operating system was scheduled for a fall 1999 release .
But in 1998 Apple pushed the release date back to early 2000 , and has now pushed it back to early 2001 .
An Apple press release from January said : " Mac OS X will go on sale as a shrink-wrapped software product this summer and will be pre-loaded as the standard operating system on all Macintosh computers in early 2001 . "
But Apple officials insist the company has not delayed the product .
Phil Schiller , vice president of worldwide product marketing at Apple , said this summer the company will be delivering the same engineering build of Mac OS X , with the same features as originally promised , but that " we have changed the name . "
He said customers asked Apple to do this in order to get feedback on the product .
Apple 's attempts to update the famous but aging Macintosh operating system go back at least five years .
Previous attempts , like the doomed Copland , were abandoned wholesale when Jobs returned to Apple in 1997 .
Mac OS X , which is widely perceived as Jobs ' baby , is an attempt to make the Mac OS a truly modern operating system that is easy to use , handles multiple tasks simultaneously , and will n't crash .
The final version will be available pre-loaded onto new Macs in January 2001 , Jobs said .
The postponed ship date left many developers unfazed .
" I do n't think the slip really matters , " said Michael Peirce , director of emerging technologies at Granitar , a Web applications developer . "
What 's six months in the grand scheme of things ?
I think it 's more important for it to be stable and solid and slick . "
" I think it looks terrific , " said Sanford Selznick of Selznick Scientific Software .

NEW YORK -- Spanish Internet group Terra Networks SA agreed Tuesday to buy U.S. Internet search company Lycos Inc. for $ 12.5 billion in stock , or $ 97.55 a share , in a move to create one of the world 's largest Internet companies and broaden its geographic reach .
The combined company , which will be called Terra Lycos Inc. , will have pro forma 2000 revenues of about $ 500 million and together currently have an estimated 50 million unique users and 175 million page views per day .
Juan Villalonga , who is chairman of both Telefonica and Terra , will head the merged Lycos-Terra .
Robert Davis , currently Lycos president and chief executive , would be the chief executive , the source said .
As part of the agreement Germany 's Bertelsmann AG , the third-largest media company in the world , agreed to purchase $ 1 billion of advertising , placement and integration services from Terra Lycos worldwide over five years .
Terra-Lycos , meanwhile , will gain access to Bertelsmann 's books , music , television , film , and other media content , on preferred terms .
This alliance builds on the existing Lycos-Bertelsmann joint venture in Europe , Lycos Europe , of which Bertelsmann will remain a significant shareholder .
Lycos is the parent company of Wired News .
