DVD Audio : New Fave or Failure ?

The long-awaited DVD audio format is finally rolling out , allowing users to play DVD movies and CDs as well as DVD audio discs on a single player .
Panasonic Consumer Electronics , a division of Matsushita Electric Corporation of America , announced two new DVD audio players for July release -- one under the Panasonic brand name , the other under the Technics brand name .
Also in July , the company will release a line of DVD audio ready components , including the DVD audio-ready receivers and speakers .
Later in the year will come a DVD audio/video player from Panasonic that goes into cars and SUVs .
DVD audio uses the high capacity of DVDs to store far more music information .
Because of this , DVD audio can play back music either in two-channel form , the way CDs do now , but with much higher resolution , or in six-channel form using a surround sound system .
Currently , CD audio has a 44.1kHz/16-bit bit rate , while two-channel DVD audio is 192kHz/24-bit playback .
Six-channel is 96kHz/24-bit , meaning the six-speaker mix of music is higher quality and has greater depth than two-channel compact disc .
The higher frequency and bit rate mean much better audio range for the music , allowing for more depth and all kinds of subtle , softer details to be heard .
The narrow bit rate of CDs means only so much data can get through , so a lot of subtleties are lost .
Panasonic thinks this will bring back one of the few advantages that vinyl had .
" When CD first came out a lot of people said it 's very nice , but it 's missing the warmth and atmosphere that records had because it did n't have the full range of data from analog records , " said Gene Kelsey , vice president and general manager of Panasonic 's audio division in Secaucus , New Jersey .
the
" DVD audio can put some of that back , but in a digital format , " he said . "
It can bring back the fuller experience because of the amount of data you can put on the DVD . "
Whether existing CDs are issued as DVD audio discs is up to the recording artists and record labels , but Panasonic says all of the major labels are on board and plan to issue music in this format by this summer .
In addition to the audio support , DVD audio-players will support interactive menus , just like the menus currently available on DVD movies .
The trick now is getting a mass market .
Playing a DVD audio-player requires an amplifier with six audio inputs on the back , something only newer and mid- to high-end players have .
" We think there is potential to be a mass-market product , " Kelsey said . "
Will it take over CD ?
That 's still up in the air .
Even among DVD audio owners there may be artists where the CD is enough for them . "




Strange Hazards of a News Site

WASHINGTON -- For most fledgling news websites , the biggest obstacles are mundane : Getting funding , recruiting reporters , then praying they will n't ditch you for a pre-IPO dot com .
Not so with Michael Tunick .
Instead of battling venture capitalists , the 41-year old publisher of eurasia.org.ru is fighting the Russian secret police .
Government agents stabbed one of his editors , forced an Internet service provider to block access to his website , and even created fake news sites to discredit the opposition party , Tunick claims .
Tunick , who was in New York to speak at the International Network 2000 conference organized by Rising Tide Studios and Silicon Alley Reporter , chatted with Wired News on Friday afternoon .
" It 's politics , " Tunick said . "
It 's a very dirty business .
Sometimes I do sort of think I should abandon politics and be more in business . "
For now , though , his news site , devoted to often-scarce central Asian news , reportedly attracts 2,000 visitors a day and includes active , unmoderated discussion forums .
It 's a non-commercial site , and the staff makes money from fee-based research assignments for corporations and embassies .
Tunick candidly describes himself as an activist-journalist , and some of his writers have close ties to the opposition party in Kazakhstan .
He said Igor Poberegsky , the content editor who was stabbed with " a sharp piece of metal -- almost an ice pick " -- during the daytime on a busy street in Moscow , had such connections .
According to a report in the Moscow Times last week , the Russian government has proposed that news sites must register with the government or face penalties .

Dilbert in D.C. ?
As if we needed more proof that the U.S. Patent and Trademark Office has gone slightly bonkers , along comes Scott Adams to make that point in a cartoon this week .
" My patent for no-click shopping was granted , " the cuddly-yet-demoniac Dogbert character tells Dilbert . "
You 'd better click something or I have to ship you some books . "
The comic strip is , of course , mocking the PTO 's new bad habit of awarding software patents even when they make little sense .




Car-Sharing Goes Online

A new concept in car use , called car-sharing , allows motorists to reserve cars on an hourly basis -- and the auto-rental outfits that offer these membership services are hoping the Internet will connect them with more urban dwellers who do n't own cars but occasionally need one for a short length of time .
The programs promise to help alleviate city congestion , parking hassles , and environmental abuse by giving current car owners a reason to give up their vehicles while still having use of a car when they need it .
As an alternative to owning a car , or paying by the day to rent one , these car-sharing programs have proven quite successful in Europe , and are mobilizing interest all over North America .
While not an option for those who commute to work every day or drive frequently , car-sharing does give city dwellers an alternative to ownership , and helps redefine their relationship with the automobile , said Christine Anderson , spokesperson for the Seattle car-share service Flexcar .
" We can n't meet the needs of everyone , " Anderson said . "
But rather than paying for a car to sit on the street for five days a week , we give them the freedom to dump it . "
The Web has played a big part in driving this idea by serving as an education platform to spur community interest , advertise , and allow car-sharers to join up and schedule their automobile usage .
Interested users and activists can log on to learn more about the car-sharing concept , see if their neighborhood has convenient access to an automobile in the fleet , or apply for membership .
Cambridge , Massachusetts-based Zipcar will launch June 23 with a fleet of 12 cars , and expects to serve an initial membership of 120 .
It will add 30 more cars by the end of the year and hopes to accommodate over 1,000 drivers .
Zipcar members will apply for membership , reserve a car with the company , and pay online .
To access the car , members will use smartcards to prove their identity and track their usage to tally the monthly bill .
" We 've invested our energy into making an online reservation system as seamless as using an ATM , " said Zipcar CEO Robin Chase .
At some locations , such as Switzerland 's Mobility , drivers can reserve their time slot and the car they want online .
Almost every site features data on car-sharing 's environmental benefits , but another , The Carsharing Network , features an entire library and discussion group on the topic .
The car-sharing idea , said to have begun in Switzerland in 1987 , now has over 30,000 members in that country .
Switzerland 's achievement inspired other efforts in Sweden , Germany , and throughout the Continent , with car-sharing serving 70,000 members in more than 350 European cities .




Worm Turns on Wireless

SAN FRANCISCO -- A new computer virus that has targeted mobile phone users in Spain -- calling them up to deliver an insulting email about a Spanish telephone company -- has dramatically demonstrated what could be the newest headache to afflict the wireless world .
Computer security specialists reported Tuesday the worm-type virus , called " Timofonica , " had hit customers of Spain 's Movistar service , sending text messages scrolling across the screens of their GSM mobile phones .
" This virus is not a big threat for the general public , " said Mikko Hypponen , manager of anti-virus research at Finland 's F-Secure Corp. , which along with Russia 's antivirus Kapersky Lab first noted the spread of the new bug .
" But the most important thing is it is wireless .
It is the first virus we have seen which targets cell phones , " Hypponen said in an telephone interview from Finland .
Security researchers said the virus was transmitted by email , did not destroy computer files and was more an annoyance than a real danger .
So far it appeared limited largely to Spain , they added .
The GSM , or Global System for Mobil Communications , wireless standard dominates in Europe , while the rival CDMA , or code division multiple access , standard is widely used in the United States .
By taking the same basic recipe that spread the notorious " I Love You " virus around the globe last month and applying it to cell phones , the Spanish bug could presage a new breed of viral attack against pocket communicators , palm organizers , and the rest of the wireless world .
The object of Timofonica 's wrath is Spain 's Telefonica telephone company , a telecommunications giant that is trying to become a global leader on the Internet , recently bidding , through its Terra Networks arm , to acquire search engine Lycos for US$ 12.5 billion .
parent company of Wired News
A hacker or hackers using Microsoft 's Outlook program , the same route taken in the " I Love You " virus and other outbreaks , spread the Timofonica via self-generated email to all of the addresses contained in victims ' electronic address books , Kapersky Lab said in a news release on the virus .
But in a new twist , Timofonica also took to the airwaves , sending a message to a Short Messaging Service gateway , a computer server that converted the message to telephone signal reaching thousands of random cell phone users .
SMS
Computer specialists stressed that the virus itself was not transmitted wirelessly -- only its insulting text message .
But a computer infection designed to afflict wireless products was seen as an unnerving new twist .
" I do n't think cell phones and Palm Pilots are more vulnerable today than they were yesterday before this hit .
All the worm did was send an email message .
It just happened to send it to a cell phone , " said Vincent Gullotto , director of AVERT Labs for Network Associates , another antivirus firm .
But he said that as wireless devices become more popular , more sophisticated , and more standardized , their vulnerability to destructive viruses was growing .
The attack Tuesday underscored this threat , experts said .
" We can n't say when specifically ... it could be a year , it could be six months , it could be two years , " Gullotto said . "
My guess is yes , at some particular point . "
it will happen
While the Spanish infection appeared to be running its course , Hypponen said other viruses could easily be designed to mimic the " denial-of-service " attacks that hit Yahoo , CNN , and a number of other major websites earlier this year .
At least one already has -- the so called 911 bug that hit a small number of 911 emergency operator systems in Texas and Florida in April as a simple " zombie " program targeted them with thousands of computer calls without any knowledge on the part of the computer 's owner .
" What if you did that to the cell phone of the prime minister ? "
Hypponen said . "
We have n't yet seen viruses to be used by terrorists , which obviously would be the next step . "




Commerce Dept. : We Like Tech

WASHINGTON -- Industries built on telecommunications and computers accounted for nearly a third of U.S. economic growth last year and have played a major role in boosting productivity and holding down inflation , the Commerce Department said on Monday .
In its third annual report on the Digital Economy , the department said the broad category of Information Technology -- which covers everything from computer hardware and cable lines to television broadcasting and the Internet -- has played a key role in driving the record U.S. expansion .
" Information technology and the Internet are having a deep and significant effect on the way the U.S. economy performs , " Undersecretary of Commerce Robert Shapiro told a news conference .
" The rapid rate of growth in the IT sector tells you that IT is selling across the U.S. economy , " he said . "
That is , more and more companies and more and more industries from both the old and new economies are investing in telecommunications and related gear . "
The report , called the " Digital Economy 2000 , " was compiled by the Economics and Statistics Administration , an arm of the Commerce Department that analyses data produced by its two main economic statistics agencies , the Census Bureau and the Bureau of Economic Analysis .
Despite IT 's increasing importance , it represented a fairly small share -- roughly 8 percent in 1999 -- of the economy 's total output .
But IT contributed 32 percent to overall economic growth , the study found .
During the period 1994-1998 , IT reduced overall U.S. inflation , as measured by the gross domestic product price index , by half a percentage point to 1.8 percent from 2.3 percent .
" The rates of decline in IT prices accelerated through the 1990s -- from about 1 percent in 1994 , to nearly 5 percent in 1995 , and an average of 8 percent for the years 1996 to 1998 , " the report said .
A key factor in that trend has been tumbling computer prices .
Commerce said IT industries have been an important source of productivity-enhancing research and development .
Between 1994 and 1999 , overall research and development investment rose by an inflation-adjusted average of around 6 percent .
More than a third of that occurred in IT .
For those in IT jobs , there were big financial rewards .
Occupations in IT-related jobs paid average wages of $ 58,000 a year -- more than double the $ 31,400 averaged for all private industries .
Right now , the government produces very few detailed statistics on such areas as Information Technology and the Internet , but Shapiro said Commerce is working to expand that .
The Digital Economy 2000 report examined broad trends in IT , but there is no breakdown of IT in more frequent and up-to-date reports like the gross domestic product , which Commerce estimates three times per quarter .
The government compiles data on a host of economic sectors but in an era of rapid technological change , it is struggling to keep pace with the newer areas of the economy .
Earlier this year , Commerce began issuing quarterly estimates of online retail sales .
Shapiro said the department expects to start a new series sometime this year on business-to-business electronic commerce .




Indie Bands Get Cable Showcase

Indie musicians looking to broaden their exposure have a new venue : a new , commercial-free cable television channel .
Connecticut-based Falcon Entertainment on Wednesday debuted the Independent Music Network , which features all original content .
IMNTV broadcasts original programming 24 hours a day , seven days a week , culled from indie band submissions .
Falcon also will webcast the videos on its site .
IMNTV gives independent artists the opportunity to be seen in up to 3 million households in five cable markets : Los Angeles , San Diego , Miami , Orlando , Florida , and Norfolk , Virginia .
James Fallacaro , president of Falcon Entertainment , said he also is negotiating with EchoStar Communications , a satellite cable system that would expand the network 's reach .
The company plans to operate both the website and cable channel commercial-free , relying on other ventures , including its Invision indie music label , for revenue .
" We are n't interested in the present time in taking advertisers because suddenly the show becomes their show , " Fallacaro said . "
If you look at any other network , website , or music label , you know there 's money to be made , so if the people like the network , we are going to do very well . "
Fallacaro said he is n't worried about cash .
Falcon Entertainment went public last year , raising about $ 9 million in cash , and he expects the record label to make enough money to justify the TV and Internet costs .
INDE
Analysts say that could be a risky proposition .
" You could try to leverage this kind of business model into a subscription service by using the video technologies to add value to someone else 's subscription service , " said Billy Pidgeon , an analyst at Jupiter Communications . "
But that depends on people 's willingness to purchase music on the Web . "
Pidgeon said content needs to be customized for the Internet . "
Offering the same content across various platforms is n't going to work .
You really need to repurpose that content to fit the medium you are using . "
Each month , viewers and the company 's artists ' advisory board will select the top 10 artists seen on the channel .
Those bands will then be given a 30-minute feature segment on the channel , and the top band will be offered a recording contract with Falcon 's development company .
Fallacaro said that unlike the other dot-com music shows , IMNTV will be an eclectic independent film and music network that considers any indie artist .
" We are n't out to hurt anybody or out to take advantage of anybody , " he said . "
We are just offering a band a contract , but we are n't requiring them to sign with us to be played on the air .
And we encourage all the bands to get management and lawyers to represent them . "
Other music programs have hit both the airwaves and the Internet in recent months .
The Universal Music-affiliated website farmclub.com has unveiled its television show of the same name on the USA Network .
However , its contract requiring independent bands to turn over their websites in order to get on the television show irked some musicians .
One band , the Rosenbergs , criticized the company and in a mass email campaign that distributed the contract .
Independent music website Riffage.com filmed 13 episodes of its new series , Riffage Live , which will also appear on the Burly Bear cable network .




IBM Banking on New ThinkPads

A new line of ThinkPad notebooks , both cheaper and lighter than their predecessors , went on the market Monday as IBM bids to recapture some of the PC market lost to its competitors .
The ThinkPad i Series starts at $ 1,200 and weighs in at six pounds .
All models include updated options for connecting to the Internet .
One is Ethernet technology , which provides high-speed access using either traditional phone lines or cable modems , as well as the ability to connect to corporate , home , or school networks .
There are also two USB ports and new keyboard-based audio controls to simplify listening to music .
IBM 's personal computer business has been struggling in recent years , losing money while it loses market share to rivals such as Compaq , Dell , and Gateway .
Some Wall Street analysts have questioned whether IBM should be selling computers at all .
The new line of ThinkPads is IBM 's way of saying that it should .
At least for now .

New Hope for AIDS Gene Therapy

Gene therapy company GenStar last week announced findings that show preliminary success with treatments for both HIV and hemophilia .
The researchers presented their findings at the American Society of Gene Therapy Conference in Denver and said they hope to begin clinical trials soon .
" These promising results underscore our efforts to develop innovative gene therapy products engineered to provide enhanced activity and favorable safety profiles , " said Dr. Robert Sobol , chief executive officer of GenStar in San Diego .
Approximately 33 million people are infected with HIV worldwide .
HIV is the virus believed to cause AIDS .
Hemophilia is a hereditary disease characterized by a deficiency in a blood-clotting protein .
The disorder causes abnormal bleeding and affects about 20,000 people in the United States .
Researchers at GenStar studied the gene therapy technique by creating a genetically modified human immunodeficiency virus that is not able to replicate .
Instead of replicating and causing disease , the altered virus infects cells and induces immune responses , but stops at that .
GenStar recently acquired the HIV and other gene therapy technologies from Allegro Inc.
GenStar also presented data on a gene therapy product for hemophilia A , which showed that the therapy safely delivered a gene called human factor VIII into patients .
And they reported in a recent issue of the journal Blood that the product can correct bleeding abnormalities in mice and sustain therapeutic levels for about one year .
The data reported from GenStar 's hemophilia gene therapy product showed no significant toxicity when administered to animal subjects at dosages 10 times higher than those planned for future clinical evaluation .
Another gene therapy company , Cell Genesys in Foster City , California , reported success with a hemophilia treatment on Monday .
The company said it was able to deliver therapeutic levels of a blood-clotting protein in non-human primates with hemophilia B after one administration of gene therapy .
Investors liked what they heard .
Shares of GenStar rose 20 percent , or 15/16 , to 5-3/4 on the research news , while Cell Genesys was up 3-1/8 points to close at 24-1/2 on Monday .

A Data Sanctuary Is Born

WASHINGTON -- A windswept gun tower anchored six miles off the stormy coast of England is about to become the first Internet data haven .
A group of American cypherpunks has transformed the rusting fortress , erected by the British military during World War II to shoot down Nazi aircraft , into a satellite-linked virtual home for anyone looking for a secure place to store sensitive or controversial data .
The founders of HavenCo , which will announce operations on Monday , believe the concept will appeal to individuals and businesses looking for a " safe haven " from governments around that world that are becoming more and more interested in Internet regulation and taxation .
It 's for " companies that want to have email servers in a location in which they can consider their email private and not open to scrutiny by anyone capable of filing a lawsuit , " says Sean Hastings , the 32-year-old chief executive of HavenCo .
Hastings says that because a 1968 British court decision effectively recognized the basketball court-sized island as a sovereign nation called Sealand , HavenCo can provide more privacy and legal protections then anyone else on the planet .
To create HavenCo -- which will offer Linux servers for $ 1,500 a month -- the founders signed an agreement with Roy Bates , the quirky " crown prince " of Sealand who landed on the abandoned platform in 1966 and claimed it as an independent nation with its own currency , stamps , and flag .
Bates , a former British Army major , has undertaken a string of failed business ventures in an attempt to make use of the world 's tiniest country -- a platform just 10 by 25 yards that perches atop two cement caissons in the North Sea .
One plan was to build Sealand into a three-mile-long , man-made island with an airport and banks .
Another venture included working with German investors to build a $ 70 million hotel and gambling complex -- a scheme that fell apart with the Germans taking over the fortress in 1978 and Bates regaining control in a dramatic helicopter raid at dawn .
This time the elder Bates , now about 80 years old , is taking no chances on his business partners : His son and royal heir-apparent , Michael , is HavenCo 's chief logistics officer and the royal family has a seat on the board .
But today Sealand 's potential adversaries include not merely a few expansion-minded Germans , but nervous government officials who are aggressively trying to pull the plug on unapproved offshore activities .
During a Paris summit in May , for instance , representatives of the Group of Eight nations met to hammer out an agreement on international Net law . "
G8
The idea is to produce a global text so there can not be ' digital havens ' or ' Internet havens ' where anyone planning some shady business could find the facilities to do it , " French Interior Minister Jean-Pierre Chevenement said at the time .
When Sealand was simply an eccentric 's hobby , the British government largely ignored the smallest country in the world .
But if HavenCo becomes a popular destination for gambling , money laundering , or other socially disapproved activities , governments could move against it .
The Home Office in London could restrict the microwave links that provide HavenCo with its lifeline to the outside world , and the companies offering satellite connectivity could come under pressure from regulators in their home countries .
HavenCo could even find its bank accounts imperiled .
For their part , HavenCo executives say they hope to avoid negative publicity . "
We do n't intend to make anyone angry at us .
We simply want to provide online businesses a place with a sane set of rules that are not constantly changing , " Hastings said .
" If larger nations have a problem with unrestricted information flow , then their problem is with the increase in information technology , and not with us .
They can n't put the genie back in the bottle until every individual on the planet has had their three wishes come true , " he said .
Somewhat ironically , bandits recently set up a fake " Principality of Sealand " website to sell citizenship to unsuspecting visitors .
Spanish authorities reportedly are investigating a gang involved with drug smuggling and arms trafficking using those passports .
In a bizarre incident , one " Sealand " passport of dubious origin surfaced in connection with the July 1997 murder of fashion designer Gianni Versace in Miami .
The British Embassy in Washington declined to comment on what would prompt London to take action against the legitimate prince of Sealand . "
What it comes down to is that this is a hypothetical , and so we can not speculate on this , " said Peter Reed , the embassy 's press officer .
situation




MP3 Site Sues RIAA Over Linking

The recording industry got a bit of a shock on Monday when a digital music search site filed a lawsuit asking the judge to stop the Recording Industry Association of America from attempting to shut its website down .
Since last October , the RIAA has sent numerous cease-and-desist letters to MP3Board.com -- a website that provides hyperlinks to MP3 music files available for download over the Internet -- requesting that the site voluntarily shut down or face legal action .
On May 25 , RIAA sent a letter stating that legal action would be taken if the digital music company did n't shut down its website by June 2 .
MP3Board filed a preemptive lawsuit on June 2 in federal district court in San Jose , California , asking a federal judge not only to end the RIAA 's attempts to shut its service down , but also to rule on whether providing hyperlinks constitutes copyright infringement .
" We 're mindful of the notion that there are infringing files out there , but there are non-infringing ones as well , " said Internet litigation lawyer Ira Rothken , who represents MP3Board . "
The RIAA should go after the sites that are actually doing the infringing , not a site like ours .
This is a pattern of abuse by the RIAA against my client . "
Rothken is requesting that the judge clarify the requirements of how MP3Board should monitor its site for illegal content , grant an injunction to block the RIAA 's attempts to shut down the company , and award the company monetary damages for the recording industry 's interference in its business .
" would mean every search engine would have to go through the RIAA 's database before they could do a search , " Rothken said . "
Preventing sites from linking to illegal MP3 content
That would paralyze the Internet , " he said . "
So someone has to step in to say that linking services can n't be infringing on copyright just for hyperlinking . "
A ruling against linking could pose a problem for other MP3 search or browse sites like listen.com , gigabeat.com , myplay.com that aggregate downloadable music available on the Web .
But listen.com managing editor Tim Quirk does n't think aggregation companies are in any danger .
Unlike other music search sites , listen.com uses editors instead of automation to create its links .




Search the Web -- And Users ' PCs

If you listen to Manish Vij , CEO of newly launched Pointera , Web searching needs a good push into the Napster age .
" We 're taking Napster-style file-sharing , we 're broadening it to all documents , and we 're allowing Portals to play , " Vij said . "
So when you 're searching Yahoo , if you type in ' Britney Spears , ' you 'll get not just text documents , but also links to documents on people 's hard disk . "
The company launched Monday and calls itself an application service provider for portals .
It hopes to license its " sharing engine " to portals and search sites like Yahoo and AltaVista -- much the way search company Inktomi licenses its technology to portals including Yahoo , AOL , and MSN .
Vij said he hopes to convince Web portals to append their search results to include personal files residing on users ' own computers -- just like the file-swapping model of controversial music-trading software Napster and its cousin Gnutella .
The Pointera technology would allow users to find , download , and share all types of files -- songs , movies , Web pages , or word-processing documents -- running as a Java applet in any standard Web browser software .
" From the user 's perspective , it 's just Yahoo -- you 're searching all file types and your results look like they 're coming from the Web browser .
So it 's pretty much indistinguishable for any normal user from a search engine . "
The company has yet to name partners but said it is in talks with one of the three major portals .
To Vij , the Napster age brings a major shift in the meaning of an Internet search , allowing major portals and content sites to participate in what he refers to as the " legitimate file-sharing revolution , " in which " Yahoo enters the Napster space legitimately . "
" Legitimately " because right now Napster is being sued for its role in facilitating the easy swapping of copyrighted media .
But by taking the search engine route , Vij said Pointera would have legal protection from the get-go .
Built-in copyright enforcement features would enable search sites to safeguard the rights of copyright holders , the company says .
And Vij said the Millennium Copyright Act provides exemption from copyright liability for search engines .
But Danny Sullivan , editor of Search Engine Watch , is n't so sure the Web search needs a Napster-like appendage .
" Using that kind of Napster technology be great for different kinds of uses , but I do n't see it as a replacement for search engines themselves , " Sullivan said . "
can
It 's really going to depend on what it is you 're looking for . "
Many other file types are best served by existing search services , he said . "
If you 're trying to seek out , say , images on the Web -- and images are simply files -- you 're probably going to be better off using an image search engine like AltaVista ... because those images -- nobody 's trying to put them up or take them down in a hurry . "




HavenCo : Come to Data

WASHINGTON -- For the intrepid crew of cypherpunks who are erecting a data haven off the stormy coast of England , making sure the technology works will be the easy part .
A more serious threat is likely to be governments alarmed by HavenCo 's offer to host individual and corporate sites that are illegal in some parts of the world .
Some countries consider gambling or sexually explicit websites to be illegal .
There 's also broad international agreement that money laundering " havens " should be put out of business .
According to HavenCo officials and the company 's terms of service , everything but spamming , obscenity , and child pornography is legal .
The company plans to begin operations by September .
Could nations act against HavenCo , a startup company perched on a tiny manmade island called Sealand with uncertain legal independence from Britain ?
" It depends largely on who this entity 's backers are .
Are they well connected ? " says James Feinerman , a professor of international law at Georgetown University .
" I suspect we could blow them out of the water , although I would n't recommend that , and if they were in fact propagating illegal material I bet nobody would really care .
There would be few consequences if nobody is interested , " Feinerman says .
London 's Home Office could restrict the microwave links that provide HavenCo with its lifeline to the outside world , and the companies offering satellite connectivity could come under pressure from regulators in their home countries .
HavenCo could even find its bank accounts imperiled .
In 1996 , a U.S. government agency pulled the plug on Iran 's Internet connection , which was routed through Austria 's Vienna University .
Direct action also has precedents .
In October 1983 , the U.S. invaded Grenada and installed a pro-American government .
Commandos working for the French government blew up Greenpeace 's Rainbow Warrior in 1985 when it was anchored in Auckland , New Zealand .
In 1995 , the French military seized five Greenpeace ships that were protesting nuclear testing in the south Pacific and arrested the crew .
" If the U.S. administration objected strongly , and was suitably motivated , it might simply undertake a covert military action .
There is historical precedent for such actions .
I doubt this would ever happen , " says Peter Rosti , webmaster for the John Galt Society , which advocates offshore banking and tax avoidance .




Gene Now Out of the Bottle

SASKATOON , Saskatchewan -- A Canadian farmer went toe to toe with agribusiness giant Monsanto Co. in court Monday as arguments started in a case that questions the environmental safety of growing genetically modified organisms .
Monsanto Canada Inc. , is seeking damages from Percy Schmeiser , a 68-year-old farmer from the province of Saskatchewan .
It accuses him of illegally growing Monsanto 's genetically modified Roundup Ready canola seeds in his fields in 1998 .
The case could set precedents because the use of genetic modification -- altering plant genes to resist pests or herbicides , for example -- is relatively new and the legal ramifications have yet to be tested to any great degree in the courts .
" I believe there are some real principles involved and that 's why I am taking them on , " Schmeiser told reporters in Saskatoon , in the heart of Canada 's prairie grain-growing region .
In rendering a decision in the trial , which is set to last three weeks , the Federal Court of Canada will consider whether to order Schmeiser to pay Monsanto Canada Inc. damages for growing its canola seeds in 1998 .
Canola is a Canadian variant of rapeseed .
Schmeiser has questioned Monsanto 's right to patent genes and has said the GM canola arrived on his fields by accident , likely blown by the wind from nearby farms where the Monsanto seed was being grown .
" It is just too much , far too much to happen by anything else than a deliberate plant , " Monsanto 's lawyer , Robert Hughes , told the court , presided over by Justice Andrew Mackay .
In his opening arguments on Monday , Hughes said 90 percent of Schmeiser 's 1998 crop was composed of Roundup Ready canola -- a herbicide-resistant version of the plant altered to work exclusively with Monsanto 's Roundup weedkiller .
Schmeiser said in court documents that the samples should be ruled inadmissible because the company illegally obtained them from his land after he was reported by neighbors on a Monsanto " snitch line . "
The case is expected to be closely watched by those who support GM technology and those who abhor it , particularly Europeans , as being untested and unsafe .
Another issue taken up by environmental and consumer groups is that GM crops can contaminate non-GM crops as the seeds get blown from field to field .
" It is our position that this gene is like a genie out of a bottle .
It was never attempted to be controlled and was not controlled , " said Terry Lakreski , Schmeiser 's lawyer .
" Mr. Schmeiser did not deliberately plant Roundup-resistant canola on his land , " the lawyer said , disputing Monsanto 's contention that it had patented a plant and not a gene .
The majority of Canada 's canola crop is genetically modified , and Monsanto said 55 percent is Roundup Ready .
Schmeiser , who sat alone in court listening intently to the proceedings , indicated to reporters that a countersuit against Monsanto may be launched once this case is over .




Video Clothes : ' Brand ' New Idea

SAN FRANCISCO -- An inventor has created a wearable computer that he hopes will turn people into mobile billboards playing TV ads , movie trailers , and music videos .
Stephan Fitch , a graduate of the MIT Media Lab , which is well known for its research into wearable computers , has sewn a diminutive but fully functional Windows computer into the lining of a leather jacket .
But instead of putting the display on the jacket 's sleeve or a head-mounted eyepiece , Fitch put the machine 's 6-inch LCD screen on the back of the jacket , which allows everyone but its wearer to see what 's going on .
" Instead of having a Puffy Combs patch on the back of your jacket , you could play a Puffy Combs video , " Fitch said as he showed off the jacket in a hotel suite here last week . "
It allows people to use video as a form of self-expression . "
" It is a very thought-provoking product " said Jop Van Beurden , VP of marketing for flat display systems at Philips .
Van Beurden said his company is working on flexible display technology , which will " open up a whole new realm of applications , " such as handheld computers that can be folded like wallets , and large screens that can be rolled up like newspapers .
But Van Beurden said flexible displays probably will n't be built into clothes for three to five years .
Fitch 's jacket was commissioned and built to order for MSN , which debuted it at last month 's ad-tech interactive advertising conference , where it was used to play Microsoft ads as the wearer strolled the show floor .
" It got a fantastic response , " Fitch said . "
A flock of people were following him around . "
The jacket will be on display at this week 's Web Attack show in New York .
The jacket is a fully featured Windows computer with a 233-MHz Pentium II processor , a 1 Gigabyte IBM micro hard drive and a broadband wireless Internet connection .

Kiwis Lift Lid on #*!@& !
Domains

WELLINGTON , New Zealand -- A ban on seven words deemed too offensive to register as part of a domain name in this country has just been lifted .
The crude swear words have been banned for years .
The list , some old Internet hands thought , was originally linked to words banned by broadcasters .
However , the Internet Society of New Zealand has decided it is time for the policy to change .
Society Chair Peter Dengate Thrush said the policy was " was too narrow in terms of preventing obscenity . "
Many other combinations of words could be combined to create offensive domain names , he said .
Also , the offensive word list was limited to English-language swear words , meaning words offensive in other languages and cultures could slip through , Dengate Thrush said .
The censorship role did n't fit with the society 's purpose , which its website states is " to foster coordinated and cooperative development of the Internet . "
" It should not be us making these decisions , " Dengate Thrush said .
So at a meeting last week , the society decided to allow the banned words to be registered as domain names beginning June 1 .
Domainz , the body which handles the registrations of New Zealand domain names and is owned by the country 's Internet society , can now automatically register most local domain names .
The banned words had necessitated a manual check .
Now only names which use . govt , .mil , . cri and . iwi require checking .
New Zealand government research institutes
for Mori groups
A public call for comment before the change brought little response , but since the decision a lively discussion has flared on the local society newsgroup .
" Why is it not considered necessary to protect our children ? " one woman asked in a post to the newsgroup . "
Most sensible nations have strong laws to protect children against public obscenity , and this in no way impinges on the issue of free speech , which is a religion there , and a good thing too . "
I 'm talking about the U.S. here
Others argued that deciding what is obscene should n't fall on the Internet society 's shoulders . "
The issue of obscene domains is quite similar to that of trademarks .
Anyone should be free to register whatever they like .
If someone else subsequently has a problem with the registration , they can then make complaints via appropriate channels , " a user named Oliver argued in another post .
In New Zealand , the Department of Internal Affairs , the police , and customs are all involved in enforcing the Classification Act , the local censorship law .
So far only four of the seven previously banned words have been registered .
One registrant says he did n't register the name and that he is canceling the registration .
