Another registrant registered one of the names " purely because of a joke , " according to his brother .
But a third registrant , who registered two of the seven names , views his purchases as an investment . "
I 'm pretty pleased with the ' f ' and ' s , ' I must say , " Ross Hendy said , " as a collectible . "
Already he has listed one name on a domain-name auction site .
For now , he 's hanging on to the other .
In the future , he says , the hitherto obscene word " may be more acceptable . "




MP3.com , RIAA Close to a Deal

NEW YORK -- The five largest record labels are close to asettlement of a copyright infringement suit with MP3.com that would allow the online music site to include the labels ' songs as part of its controversial MyMP3.com service , according to a record label source .
The proposed settlement calls for San Diego-based MP3.com to pay $ 75 million to $ 100 million to the Recording Industry Association of America , the trade group representing the labels , in exchange for the right to include the labels ' songs .
RIAA
The service allows users to store music digitally and then access it using any computer .
" There are ongoing discussions among the affected parties , " an RIAA spokeswoman said , declining further comment .
MP3.com was not immediately available for comment .
" We are close to a done deal , " a label executive said . "
There are some small issues to be settled .
But it looks like MP3.com will pay between $ 75 million and $ 100 million to be distributed among the labels by the RIAA . "
A U.S. District Court judge in Manhattan ruled on April 28 that MP3.com infringed on copyrights held by the major labels by creating a database of more than 80,000 albums .
MP3.com designed software that lets computer users with an original copy of one of the recording in the database register that CD .
It then allows the user to listen to that album over the Internet from any computer , without having to insert the original disc .




Judge Dumps on MS Again

SEATTLE -- The judge trying the Microsoft antitrust case dealt another blow to the software giant 's legal strategy Tuesday , refusing to rule quickly on a company request that he stay his order for restrictions on how it does business .
In a terse statement , Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said he would delay his ruling until Microsoft filed a formal notice of appeal .
Jackson agreed with a filing made on Monday by the U.S. Justice Department asking him to postpone a ruling in hopes of prodding the company to move the case along faster .
" The court reserves ruling on Microsoft 's motion until such time as timely notice of appeal is filed , " Jackson wrote . "
Consideration of a stay pending appeal is premature in that no notice of appeal has yet been filed . "
In its own filing on Tuesday , Microsoft asked the judge to rule immediately on its motion for a stay , saying the request was in line with court procedure and that the government 's request was unjustified .
Jackson ruled last week that Microsoft should be broken in two to prevent further antitrust violations .
Although he said a breakup should be delayed until the end of the appeals process , he also ordered a set of restrictions on how the company does business , to take effect 90 days from the ruling .
Those restrictions include forcing Microsoft to reveal to competitors more of the carefully guarded source code of its Windows operating system , restricting its ability to strike exclusive deals with partners , and requiring it to set uniform pricing for Windows among its different customers .
Microsoft , which has seen the judge rule against it at almost every turn in the case , said it was eager to move the case along quickly even though it expected Jackson would eventually deny its request for a stay .
" We expected a swift decision likely to reject our motion to stay so we could move ahead with appeals process , " Microsoft spokesman Jim Cullinan said . "
the
We are following the appropriate process to seek a stay and hope to move this along as quickly as possible . "
Justice , saying Microsoft was trying to drag the case out even longer , hopes Jackson 's decision to hold back a ruling on the stay will spur the company into filing its appeal sooner .
Many observers and analysts agree that Microsoft is hoping to stretch out the appeals process , perhaps thinking that the industry will change so drastically in the meantime as to render the original decision irrelevant .
" It does appear that that 's part of their strategy , and it does appear that that strategy is not working , " said Rob Enderle , an analyst with technology consulting firm Giga Information Group .
Justice is trying to move the case on a fast-track to the U.S. Supreme Court , bypassing a lower appeals court that has ruled in Microsoft 's favor in the past .
Microsoft has said it prefers the normal appeals route and opposes going directly to the Supreme Court .
" The bad news is that most of the rest of this does appear to be negative until the case moves to the Supreme Court , " Enderle said . "
The judge feels very strongly that the Supreme Court will hear this case and that they will ... put this thing to bed fairly rapidly . "
Shares in Microsoft were slightly lower , down 1/4 at 66-5/8 in afternoon trade on the Nasdaq stock market .




The Ruling : Break MS in Two

WASHINGTON -- In a historic ruling that could reshape the software industry , a federal judge has begun the lengthy process of splitting Microsoft into two competing companies .
U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson released his order on Wednesday , chiding Microsoft for " untrustworthy " behavior in court and approving without alteration the Justice Department 's sweeping divestiture of the world 's largest software company .
Jackson said he " reluctantly " came to the conclusion that a breakup was necessary .
" Microsoft as it is presently organized and led is unwilling to accept the notion that it broke the law or accede to an order amending its conduct , " he wrote .
Microsoft immediately said it would appeal the ruling and , as a procedural matter , would ask Jackson to delay his order .
" This is the beginning of a new chapter in this lawsuit , " said Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates . "
We have a very strong case on appeal , and we look forward to resolving these issues through the appeals process and putting this case behind us once and for all . "
Jackson 's order is written in biting language rarely seen in a U.S. district court .
In no uncertain terms , he condemned Microsoft as a recidivist monopolist and said its attorneys ' request for more time to prepare a response to a breakup plan was disingenuous .
" Microsoft 's profession of surprise is not credible .
From the inception of this case Microsoft knew , from well-established Supreme Court precedents dating from the beginning of the last century , that a mandated divestiture was a possibility , if not a probability , in the event of an adverse result at trial , " Jackson said .
As punishment for stifling competition in the computer industry , Jackson signed the breakup plan that the Justice Department and the states proposed this spring , without changing one word of the proposal .
The plan splits Microsoft into two firms : One sells the Windows operating system products , and the other will have rights to the software application programs along with the company 's far-flung Internet operations .
Microsoft will have four months to submit to Jackson an outline of how it will accomplish such a complicated proposal .
While the appeal of the breakup order is underway , Microsoft will have to abide by a host of far-reaching restrictions on what it may or may not do .
The company has said it will appeal the conduct restrictions as well , but they will be in place until at least one appeals court overturns them .
Microsoft 's appeal could bypass the normal appeals court process and go straight to the Supreme Court under a mechanism available in major antitrust cases .
But several legal experts said they believed the high court would decline to receive the case on an expedited basis .
In addition to arguing it has not violated the law , Microsoft will also argue that Jackson did not provide adequate time to prepare .
" We believe the proceedings in the district court were flawed from the beginning , and strayed further and further off course , both procedurally and substantively , as the case progressed , " Microsoft Vice President William Neukom said in a statement .
Prospects of a breakup aside , however , Wednesday 's widely anticipated round of bad news did n't do much damage to Microsoft 's recently battered stock .
Shares rose 88 cents to $ 70.50 on the Nasdaq .
After-hours trading in the stock was temporarily halted following the release of the ruling .




Dreamcast Gets Java Jolt

SAN FRANCISCO -- Sega.com and PlanetWeb , a developer of Internet software products and services for consumer electronics devices , have teamed up to provide Java support for the Web browser that comes with the Sega Dreamcast console .
The Web browser currently shipping in the Dreamcast , which came out last November , has no support for Java applications .
While the browser included JavaScript , it did not support the ability to have multiple windows open .
The lack of Java support is not a problem for most Web surfers , unless they are trying to access Java-based features such as chat rooms or Web-based email .
In those cases , users were either out of luck or had to go through a number of difficult and less-powerful HTML-driven steps to access those features .
For Sega , Java support comes by using PersonalJava , the small-footprint version of Java for handheld and consumer devices .
The PlanetWeb browser for Dreamcast will also allow for secure transactions using Secure Sockets Layer encryption .
SSL
" We want the browser to be everything a consumer would want in a regular browser , " said Aimee Cardwell , vice president of Sega.com .
The new browser will support Macromedia Flash animation and MP3 playback as well .
The company said the upgraded browser will ship with Dreamcast consoles beginning in August .
The September issue of Dreamcast Magazine , will come with a CD featuring the enhanced browser .
Sega officials said they expect vendors to use Java in their games coming out next year , allowing for more seamless connectivity on the Internet .
For example , with one click people could upload their top score on a game to a website where a contest is being held for players of that game .
But the main interest is in encouraging development of Java-based games that people can play online .
" We think this browser will help bring in a community of Java games to Sega.com , perhaps from developers who have not written for Sega before , " said Gordon Short , vice president of marketing and business development for PlanetWeb . "
This could bring in new developers and possibly increase the scope of developers writing games for the Dreamcast . "
To that end , Sega and PlanetWeb are sponsoring a contest for developers to create and submit Java-based games , to be hosted on Sega.com .
The grand prize is an original Sega arcade game machine .
Runners-up get a Dreamcast and five games .
Submissions must be received by September 30 .




The World Wide Washing Machine

LONDON -- Washing machines will soon be surfing the Internet and electronic paper will start making telephone calls , technology guru Nicholas Negroponte told the International Advertising Association on Wednesday .
IAA
In a future-gazing keynote speech to the IAA 's World Congress , Negroponte , who is director of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Lab , said that in the next three years machines , rather than people , will be the heaviest users of the Web .
MIT
" I 'm not talking about WAP phones or PCs but machines that will download their intelligence from the Net , " he said .
He cited the Italian white goods manufacturer Merloni which has developed a washing machine with an internal cellphone that communicates with the company .
It will scan the washing instructions of clothes and contact the Internet to find out the right soap to use and the correct temperature for the water .
It will also be able to download upgraded software from the Web .
" Advertisers will have to advertise Tide to the machine , not to the housewife , " he said .
He said that toys will also increasingly communicate with the Internet .
" I believe that the highest level of semiconductor content in the home will be in toys , not PCs or TVs , " he said .
" In time , kids will learn French from Barbie dolls -- the French program will n't be in the Barbie doll but downloaded from the Net . "
He also said that MIT is working to produce paper that can be impregnated with the circuits needed to run a mobile phone .
" You could wave it around to activate it and then crumple it up and throw it away , " he said .
Negroponte also predicted that consumers in the developing world will be the most sophisticated users of the Internet in the next three years .
" It 's going to be a really big surprise .
The developing world will be way ahead and that is because culture is a stronger force than infrastructure , " he said .
He said that forecasters who predict that the United States will account for 50 percent of world e-commerce by 2003 are wrong .
" Latin America will be huge and that is because it has a very young population , cash-based underground economies , and a healthy disrespect for authority , " he said .
In Mexico there are currently 300,000 Internet accounts but behind every account holder there are six people who share the account .
He added that Latin America will make enormous progress because it is investing heavily in education .
" In Europe , education ministers are generally satisfied with standards of education but in Latin America they are desperate and so are prepared to try much bolder things , " he said .
He added that the use of computers in primary schools is more advanced in Costa Rica than anywhere in Europe .
However , he added that if companies are to sell products to consumers in the developing world then new payment systems will be crucial .
" Debit and credit cards are n't prevalent in these countries so we are going to have to create new forms of payment . "
Increasing use of the Internet around the world will also mean that consumers will become ever more powerful .
" It puts the consumer in absolute control , " he said .
" Retailers will become indoor advertising for products .
Consumers will browse , take down the serial number and then order it over the Net because it will be cheaper and they will n't have to carry it home themselves . "




NSI 's Webjacking Epidemic

Alan Meckler runs a $ 500 million public Net media company whose value rests in good part on its eponymous Web address -- Internet.com .
Thirteen-hundred other domains help flesh out Meckler 's media empire , which delivers news and information to seasoned Web vets .
Last weekend , a thief armed with nothing more than a fax machine and a piece of paper made off with the whole enterprise .
" It appears some forged documents were sent via fax to Network Solutions indicating that the domains should be transferred to someone in Canada , " Meckler said .
Much to Meckler 's chagrin , Network Solutions promptly made the transfer . "
There was no double-checking on the part of Network Solutions , " he said . "
What kind of business would fax in a letter saying , ' Just turn over these 1,300 domains ?
' "
After several days of wrangling with Network Solutions and Open SRS -- the Canadian registrar to which the stolen domains were transferred -- Meckler has his domains back , but not his confidence in Network Solutions .
" It 's resolved until it happens again to us or someone else , " he said . "
There 's no safeguard .
" Who would think that property you 've paid for , you 'd have to double-check ? "
Meckler asked . "
There 's a definite flaw in the system . "
Not to worry , says Network Solutions : It 's a flaw that 's being fixed .
" We 're taking steps to ensure that this type of thing does n't happen again , " said Network Solutions spokesman Brian O'Shaughnessy .
O'Shaughnessy said he could n't specify what steps were being taken without comprising their effectiveness in preventing further domain heists .
Net entrepreneur Gary Kremen might be forgiven for failing to take much comfort in the registrar 's assurances .
A domain he owned , Sex.com , was allegedly stolen by an ex-felon who , just like the Internet.com booster , forged a phony transfer document to Network Solutions more than four years ago .
" It 's outrageous , " Kremen said of the Internet.com heist . "
It 's exactly what happened to me .
This is the exact thing !
Can you imagine ? "
Unlike Meckler , Kremen never got the Sex.com domain back , though he hopes to recover it following a pending lawsuit .
Meanwhile , Web Networks , a nonprofit ISP that hosts websites for other nonprofits , is still assessing the damage after losing its domain , Web.net , to a thief last week .
In the Web.net heist , the thief forged an email to Network Solutions authorizing the transfer to Open SRS .
Web.net executive director Tonya Hancherow spent a week battling Network Solutions reps before she regained control of the site .
In the interim , more than 3,500 of her customers went without email and other Net services .




Venter : Protect Our Genes Now

WASHINGTON -- It will be impossible to keep details of people 's genes secret in the future , so Congress should pass laws to make sure such information is not abused , Craig Venter , founder of gene-mapping company Celera Genomics , said on Wednesday .
" I argue that it is virtually impossible to achieve full medical privacy , " Venter , whose company is working furiously to map and identify all the genes in the human genome , told a " high-tech summit " held by the Joint Economic Committee of the House of Representatives and Senate .
" Accepting this fact highlights our need for legislation prohibiting discrimination on the basis of genetic information .
It is essential if the biotechnology revolution is to be realized . "
Scientists who are mapping the human genome hope they will eventually be able to identify the genes that make people susceptible to diseases ranging from cancer to Alzheimer 's .
They also hope to be able to identify who responds well to which drugs , so that medicine can be tailored to individuals .
Already many genes associated with disease have been identified , including many cancer genes , a gene for Huntington 's , which is an inherited and incurable brain illness , and genes associated with haemophilia .
People have already expressed worries about being tested for such genes , saying they fear being denied health insurance and losing jobs if it became known they were at risk of disease .
In February , President Bill Clinton signed an executive order prohibiting the government from using genetic information in hiring or promotion decisions .
And Congress is working on this , in the form of the Genetic Nondiscrimination in Health Insurance and Employment Act of 1999 .
The legislation , introduced by Senate minority leader Tom Daschle , a South Dakota Democrat , and New York Democratic Representative Louise Slaughter , would extend federal genetic employment protections to the private sector .
" The biggest concern is genetic discrimination , " Venter said .
" Because we differ subtly from one another , some people want to over-interpret this in terms of genetic determinism -- that you are what you are because of your genetic code , " he added . "
It does n't quite work like that . "
Venter stressed that environment is at least as important as genetics .
He pointed out if one identical twin has schizophrenia , a disease with a genetic component , the other twin has only a 50 percent chance of developing the illness , even though the two have exactly the same genes .
Venter said everybody has one gene or another that could give insurance companies an excuse not to provide cover . "
Every one of us is uninsurable , " he said .
He said people should not want their genetic make-up to remain secret , because there are benefits to knowing about it .
" Each one of us , when our genetic code is determined , and if I have my way every one of us will have our genetic code determined within the next 10 to 15 years , will be able to do tailored and preventive medicine , " he said .
Referring to the prostate-specific antigen test used to find a protein over-produced by prostate cancer cells , Venter said : " Hopefully , from this we will have a new blood test for cancer like the PSA test . "
Another fear is that people who wish to discriminate against various ethnic groups might try and use genetics as a weapon . "
We do n't want the genetic code to be used ... by people trying to justify their previous biases , " Venter said .




When a Dot Com Goes Bust

NEW YORK -- Internet casualties are beginning to pile up from the shakeout in e-commerce , and financial experts are finding that it is easier to liquidate a factory than a Web page .
" You do n't have assets in the traditional sense , " said Lawrence Hamermesh , a corporate law professor at Widener University Law School in Delaware . "
You get a hodgepodge of goodwill , intangible rights , intellectual property .
...
The only way to place a value on that is to ... estimate what it will bring in the future .
In the dot-com world , that is crystal-balling that amounts to speculation of the highest order . "
Hamermesh said that what happens depends entirely on whether somebody thinks the idea is worth salvaging and is willing to buy it .
There were two buyers waiting to snap up some of the assets of the trendy British fashion retailer Boo.com after it ran through $ 135 million in investors ' money , closed up shop , and hired KPMG to liquidate .
Within days the technology sold for a bargain $ 368,800 to the British information technology firm Bright Station , and the website went for an undisclosed amount to the U.S. fashion portal , fashionmall.com .
But the education toy retailer Toysmart is still looking for a buyer and 170 employees are still looking for work since majority owner Walt Disney Co. cut off funds last month .
" It 's all going to be played out over the next several months , " said Stephen Miller , a partner the Ozer Group , a Massachusetts dot-com salvage firm .
His statement echoes a recent Barron 's study of 207 Internet companies that predicts at least 51 of them will burn through their cash and fail by next March .
" There 's been a lot of money thrown at the dot-com businesses to build an Internet infrastructure .
...
Those that fail are going to create opportunity for those that succeed , " Miller said .
Ozer buys and liquidates assets like websites , software , intellectual property , domain names , chat rooms , customer lists , and graphics .
Miller expects buyers will come from dot-coms looking to grow through acquisitions , and traditional brick-and-mortar companies aiming to branch into Internet commerce at bargain-basement prices .
" You can always define value based on what the market will bear , " said Miller .
Some will call in liquidators , like Ozer , and some will just shut off the lights and walk away , figuring it 's not worth the effort to sell some office furniture and a domain name .
Some may follow the lead of Craftshop.com , an Internet retailer of sewing , art , and hobby supplies , which last month filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in Delaware .
Chapter 11 protection is the traditional refuge sought by debt-laden traditional companies when they plan to keep operating but need the court to hold creditors at bay while they shed debt and reorganize .
" But what 's to reorganize ? " asked veteran bankruptcy attorney James Patton .
His firm , Young Conaway Stargatt & Taylor , has represented more than 200 corporate debtors in the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in Delaware since 1990 , including Continental Airlines , Columbia Gas , and Planet Hollywood .
" Dot-coms are put together with equity , not bond or bank debt .
Typically , startups have n't had a profit , and that makes it nearly impossible to reorganize , " Patton said .
" Besides , to these dot-com entrepreneurs , bankruptcy does n't look like a lot of fun , and I predict that they are n't going to stick around but will say ' the hell with this ' and turn around and start a new business . "
Craftshop said in its bankruptcy petition that it had debts of nearly $ 2 million but its asset value was " uncertain . "
Patton speculated that " Craftshop chose Chapter 11 because they have a controlling stockholder ... who can exercise control over the decisions of the debtor . "
Craftshop attorney Jillian Aylward says she persuaded founder Angus Mackie and his backers , including the Internet incubator CMGI and publisher Primedia , that bankruptcy was a " smart option . "
" As long as it 's a going concern , you can get a better price for it , " said Aylward .
Mackie had to shut down when backers , whom he calls " exceptional businessmen , " released only half of the $ 15 million they had committed to his start-up because revenue goals fell short .
But he is convinced that with more time and money , " Craftshop would be well on its way to a successful public stock offering . "
Apparently backer Primedia agrees .
According to court papers , " Primedia had expressed interest in purchasing the assets of . "
Craftshop
When asked why Primedia stopped financing Craftshop but now wanted to buy the assets , spokeswoman Eileen Murphy said , " I do n't know the answer to that question right now . "
A dot-com 's uncertainty may be an investor 's opportunity .




Give Your Opinions , Pay a Price

SEATTLE -- Empowering people to connect with virtually anyone on the globe could change the way people interact with businesses and newsmakers .
Some are calling the new trend that allows businesses and celebrity-types to get a single email that contains the opinions of a multitude of folks C2B , for " Consumer to Business , " or C2C for common-folk to celebs .
The basic idea of combining the letters from numerous people into a single entity for heightened effect is not a new idea , but it 's just starting to take hold in the online world .
Some , like the Canadian website the Squeaky Wheel , charge a fee for posting a complaint and provide a way to get others to join in.
Others are free , like TellThemNow.com , the brainchild of Seattle public relations executive Wiley Brooks .
Brooks is using his extensive stock of email addresses to put people in touch with almost anyone they read about in the newspaper .
However , visitors must register and have the option to give extensive demographic information about themselves .
Users also are asked to rate their own messages on a five-point scale from very positive to very negative .
" People are sophisticated enough to understand that market-research plays a role in getting your voice heard , " said Susanne Rosenkranz , a vice president of TellThemNow .
Steve Vonder Haar , an analyst with the Yankee Group , said the key to success for TellThemNow is the company 's ability to get users to provide the demographic information that will make the premium service valuable to recipients .
" If they 're successful in getting people to enter their personal information , " they have " a great potential " to be a profitable business , he said .
" That can be a very powerful tool to politicians and celebrities alike , whether they 're trying to get folks to vote for them or to sell them music or whatever , " Vonder Haar said . "
The big challenge for these guys is to gather the information to provide that . "
Vonder Haar said that getting even 25 percent of users to provide that kind of data can be difficult , and predicted that " at some point they 're going to have to provide some incentives for people " to fill out the demographic forms .
" Whether or not that will burst their business model is something I do n't know , " he said .
While he refused to give exact numbers , Brooks said twice as many people have been providing the demographic information as the company had originally projected .




MS to AOL : End IM Stranglehold

On the day it was ordered split in two for violating monopoly laws , Microsoft joined 42 other Internet companies to break America Online 's stranglehold on the instant-messaging market .
The group , FreeIM.org -- which includes Excite@Home , AltaVista and MSN.com -- petitioned both the Federal Trade Commission and the Federal Communications Commission on Wednesday to facilitate instant messaging standards that would create a seamless chat network .
" The government should make it clear to the marketplace its expectation that no single provider will be allowed to put a wall around the market , either to keep their customers in or to keep competition and innovations out , " the petition says .
The proposal comes as the government continues to scrutinize the proposed America Online-Time Warner merger .
The consortium hopes the FTC and FCC will make IM interoperability a condition for the merger because AOL controls over 90 percent of the IM market through its AIM and ICQ applications , said independent consultant Blair Levin , the FCC 's former chief of staff .
The agencies could legally require AOL to open its standards as a condition of the merger , Levin said .
AOL could also simply stop blocking other companies from accessing its network or work with the Internet Engineering Task Force to develop a single standard which would be available to every company to access its chat applications .
If no standard is developed , consumers will n't have easy access to new communication technologies , said Ross Bagully , CEO of Tribal Voice , one of the founding members of the consortium .
" Instant messaging today is where the telephone was in 1910 , " he said . "
If there were no standards developed back then , the telephone system as we know it today would n't have developed .
Instant messaging is the future of communication because it gives consumers the ability to transfer information instantly and know when someone is available .
This is absolutely going to change everything we know about communication . "
But AOL spokeswoman Tricia Primrose said government intervention is unnecessary as the company supports developing an open standard that everyone can use .
" We are very supportive of the industry-wide efforts that would create an instant-messaging open-standard , " she said . "
We also think the IEPF is the exact forum to derive this standard .
" Where we have drawn a line in this process is over privacy and security issues , " she said . "
The IM environment we have now is one that we are able to control since it exists through the company .
So before we just rush out and come up with a flawed system , we should take some time now and come up with a solid , open system that is consumer-friendly . "
AOL already licenses out its IM technology to about a dozen companies , including Apple and Earthlink .
This is the latest skirmish in a battle that began last July , when Microsoft introduced an AOL-compatible , instant-messaging service .
The two companies then played a game of chicken , with AOL blocking MSN Messenger clients from accessing the network and Microsoft updating its software to restore access .
Eventually , Yahoo joined the fray as well , trying to connect its users to the popular AOL services .




Appeals Court Rules for MS

Microsoft won a round in its battle against the Justice Department Monday , when the U.S. Court of Appeals agreed to consider freezing a lower court order that forces the software giant to change its business practices , but the victory may be temporary .
The ruling contained something for each side and both claimed victory in a narrow procedural action that stopped far short of dealing with the lower court 's order to break up the company to stop it from abusing monopoly power .
" This moves things along about a foot , with several miles to go , " said Robert Litan , vice president and director of economic studies at The Brookings Institution .
The appeals court 's action is part of a complex interplay between the government , Microsoft , the trial court , the appeals court and the Supreme Court -- where the case is ultimately expected to be decided .
Earlier this month , District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson ordered stringent conduct remedies to take effect September 5 for Microsoft .
He also ordered a break-up of the company , but delayed action on that until all appeals are complete .
Among other things , the conduct remedies require Microsoft to treat major computer makers the same and to permit them to customize how Microsoft 's Windows operating system appears on their screens .
Microsoft also would have to permit other software applications writers the same access to the company 's code that Microsoft 's own software writers enjoy .
Microsoft asked the appeals court to freeze Jackson 's conduct remedies from taking effect , denying all allegations and telling the appeals court it does not even hold a monopoly .
The Justice Department told the appeals court that Jackson should have a chance to act first on whether to halt the remedies .
The appeals court sided with Microsoft stating it would decide the question without waiting for Jackson .
The appeals court accepted a 39-page brief from Microsoft -- even though it was over the ordinary limit -- and told the Justice Department to reply within 10 days .
After that , Microsoft will have another seven days to comment .
" Clearly , we are pleased that the Appeals Court unanimously sided with Microsoft and rejected the government 's invitation to delay this process , " said Jim Cullinan , a Microsoft spokesman , from company headquarters in Redmond , Washington .
But the victory could be short-lived .
The government has asked Jackson to certify the landmark antitrust case directly to the Supreme Court .
Judge Jackson may send the case straight to the high court under a law that applies in antitrust suits brought by the United States , skipping the appeals court .
Microsoft was to file later on Monday , explaining why Jackson should not send the case directly to the Supreme Court .
But Jackson has said in the past that he thinks sending the case straight to the Supreme Court is a good idea .
The appeals court ordered in its Monday ruling that if Jackson sends the case straight to the Supreme Court , then its briefing schedule would be automatically suspended .
" We are very pleased with the court 's ruling that it would stay further proceedings if the District Court certifies the case for direct appeal to the Supreme Court , " a Justice Department spokeswoman said .
But that victory , too , may or may not last .
If five Supreme Court justices decide against taking the direct appeal , they will send it back to the appeals court .
At that point , under the order issued Monday , the schedule would pick up where it left off -- without counting the time in between .
" This is a temporary victory for Microsoft , " said the Brookings Institution 's Litan . "
They got what they wanted , which is to have the circuit court hear the stay motion without waiting for Jackson to act . "
But Litan said Judge Jackson " can step in and rain on Microsoft 's parade by certifying the case directly to the Supreme Court .
If that happens , then the circuit court is basically in a holding pattern waiting for the Supreme Court to decide what to do . "




Gauging Game Violence

With the DOOM remake on the horizon , gamers -- and parents -- may wonder just how far a computer game can go in depicting hardcore violence .
Pretty far , judging from the recently released Soldier of Fortune .
Developed by Raven Software and published by Activision , Soldier of Fortune casts gamers in the role of a mercenary hunting for stolen nukes in a variety of global hot spots , including Kosovo , Central Africa , and the New York subway .
While Soldier of Fortune serves up run-of-the-mill shooter fare , the game stands out for its unmatched level of violence .
Limbs severed by shotgun blasts , pulsating intestines protruding from gaping stomach wounds , and exploding heads are the norm .
" Soldier of Fortune definitely reached a new level of gore , " said Robert Coffey , associate editor of Ziff-Davis ' Computer Gaming World magazine .
Coffey believes Raven has upped the violence ante for future games .
" I 'm sure other games will follow , " Coffey added . "
Raven is already soliciting ideas for a Soldier of Fortune sequel , and the call from fans so far has been for more gore .
Other games will try to jump on board the violence bandwagon , hoping to exploit the shock value . "
The flip side of the shoot 'em up craze , of course , is the public backlash against violent games .
To this end , Raven has hedged its bet with Soldier of Fortune by releasing a " Tactical Low-violence Version . "
Translation ?
You still shoot hundreds of people , but they do not bleed .
Bloody or not , game violence is a genuine concern , according to Dr. KarenDill , a researcher at Lenoir-Rhyne College in Hickory , North Carolina .
Dill recently co-authored a study linking violent games to aggressive behavior .
Ironically , Dill used Wolfenstein 3-D as the test game in her research .
Although Dill has n't played Soldier of Fortune , she expressed concern that gore levels might be ratcheted up industry-wide .
" As the graphics of video games in general get more realistic the danger of them eliciting aggression in the consumer would be greater , " Dill said .
" When you are exposed to violence like you are in video games where kids and others play them for so many hours at a time , that desensitizes you to what you are seeing . "




Startup Eyes Disability Market

SAN FRANCISCO -- A San Diego startup is developing a technology that dynamically generates custom-user interfaces for all kinds of computing devices -- laptops , handhelds , and cell phones .
Edapta 's technology will initially be targeted to disabled users , but the company said it hopes it will take off in the wireless , post-PC world when information is delivered to a variety of gadgets , ranging from set-top boxes and game consoles to Net-connected cars .
Introduced at this week 's JavaOne conference , Edapta 's Edaptive Engine is server-based software that queries a device for its display profile and adapts the interface elements according to things like screen size and resolution and the presence or absence of a keyboard or mouse .
Based on Sun 's Jini , a networking technology that automatically recognizes new devices connecting to a network , the Edaptive Engine can automatically adapt interfaces for disabled users , who also have a wide range of interface needs .
For example , the technology could adapt a website for blind visitors who use screen-reader software to access the site .
Because navigation buttons and advertisements are clutter to a screen reader , the site would trim these elements and display only the most important information on the site .
" You need to tell a blind person what 's on a page before telling them how to navigate it , " said Jack Berkowitz , Edapta 's chief technology officer .
Likewise , the technology can dynamically modify the same site for Braille readers , increase the contrast for partially sighted visitors , or add oversize scroll bars and icons for visitors with disabilities that affecting their motor control .
It even can translate the page into a variety of different languages , company officials said .
The user simply sets up a digital profile listing their needs or preferences , and the software , which sits on the server , generates the appropriate interface on the fly .
The software initially was developed for the military for use in command centers where changing battlefield conditions dictate how information is presented .
Edapta said it will initially target big companies that need to accommodate staff with disabilities .




Games Distracting at JavaOne

SAN FRANCISCO -- Companies from all over the world have shelled out thousands of dollars to send delegates to Sun 's JavaOne here this week .
But instead of going to the talks and seminars and soaking information about Java , hordes of shiftless employees are wasting time playing computer games , watching movies in the conference center 's lobby , and checking out new cars .
Actually , the car , which is displayed on the show floor , is Ford 's concept car that looks like a butt-ugly mix between a Humvee and a VW Beetle .
Called the 24.7 because of its constant wireless connection to the Net , the car dispenses with traditional buttons , dials , and speedometers in favor of voice commands and virtual-status displays , which are digitally projected onto the dashboard .
The digital dash can display traditional controls -- things like speed , engine temperature , and radio settings -- but also shows maps and driving directions .
It can even be used to watch videos , read email , or see what 's in the rearview mirrors , which are actually backwards-pointing video cameras .
While the digital dash was being used to display loud pop videos during the show , it is entirely configurable in terms of what and how it displays information .
" Think of it as a canvas , " said Ganapathy Chockalingham , a software engineer who helped build it . "
You can paint whatever you want to see there . "
Put together by Ford 's own designers , the vehicle has some nice touches .
The gas pedal is marked with a big " plus " sign , the brake pedal a " minus . "
The tread of the tires are cut so the tracks look like a bar code .
The car has been shown at several auto shows -- the king of Sweden recently went to the Swedish motor show just to see it , Chockalingham said -- but JavaOne is the first computer show it has been rolled out for .
Why ?
Ford wants to attract Java developers .
" It 's silicon , not just metal , " Chockalingham said .
Chockalingham said most people are clearly impressed with the digital dash , but one bystander expressed alarm .
" It really scares me a lot , " the onlooker said . "
To me it 's very scary to see all that activity and multimedia going on under the windshield . "
Chockalingham gently assured him the car was purely experimental .
" What we 're trying to see here is what features we 're going to put into future cars , " he said soothingly . "
It 's a concept car , not a prototype . "
While some cruised the floor for the latest and greatest Java-related information , others hung out in the lobby and relaxed with games and movies .




Feds Worried About Cell Phones

WASHINGTON -- U.S. health officials said on Thursday they would oversee new industry-funded studies to address lingering questions about whether radiation from cellular phones may be harmful to users .
The Food and Drug Administration said it would recommend the research design and review the progress of the studies , which were being funded by the Cellular Telecommunications Industry Association .
The FDA advises people concerned about cell phone use to limit phone time or choose a model that puts some distance between their bodies and the phone 's antenna .
Third-party researchers will conduct the studies , and the FDA will review the results .
The research is expected to last three to five years .
The CTIA said studies so far show cell phones do not cause health problems .
The FDA , which has authority over devices that emit radiation , said it does not have enough information to conclude whether cell phones pose any risk .
" Although research to date does not show that mobile phones pose a significant health hazard , there is not enough information at this point to be absolutely certain that these products are without risk , " the FDA said in a statement .
Some studies " have raised questions that need further exploration , " the FDA said .
Some people have wondered whether long-term exposure to the low levels of radiation that cell phones emit could pose a safety risk .
A debate began in 1993 when a Florida man alleged that cell phone use caused his wife 's brain tumor .
Research to date has not erased concerns , and industry groups had been seeking government oversight of future studies .
" The wireless industry is committed to consumer safety and to addressing concerns the public might have about wireless phones , " Tom Wheeler , CTIA 's president and chief executive , said in a statement .
The new research will include both laboratory studies and studies of cellular phone users , the FDA said , adding that it would convene meetings of international experts to help oversee the studies .




New School of Thought on Piracy

The male college student is generally considered to be the archetypical Web music pirate .
Not so fast .
A survey conducted by the Pew Internet and American Life Project , a nonprofit research center , contradicts that view .
In fact , it found that the majority of those illegally downloading music are not college students at all .
The phone survey of 2,503 American adults taken in April indicated that of the 13 million American " freeloaders , " only 37 percent are college students .
In fact , fewer than half are between the ages of 18-29 .
48 percent
Forty-two percent are between 30-49 , while the remaining 10 percent are over 50 .
Men are more likely to download illegal music files than women : Sixty-four percent of the respondents who admitted pirating music are male .
Even though the Recording Industry Association of America has devoted considerable effort towards squelching piracy on college campuses through a campaign to educate administrators about copyright law , the RIAA still lauded the study .
" The behavior tracked by Pew and the attitude toward the value of information is a central public policy issue of our time , " wrote Amy Weiss , the RIAA 's vice president for communications , in an email . "
The evidence they have uncovered is disturbing and no surprise to us . "
But the demographics of music pirates has turned some heads in the industry , said Amanda Lenhart , a Pew research specialist .
She said the study should encourage label executives to create easy-to-use alternatives to programs like Napster and Gnutella because people are willing to pay for music they find online .
" We did go back to a sample of the freeloaders we had interviewed that one of the trends was that people used Napster and Gnutella to sample music and to find new music , " said Lenhart . "
and found
We also found that as a trend ... people are going out and purchasing the music they 've downloaded . "
Chuck Mitchell , the president of independent label Transparent Music , said the major labels need to take the demographic information and begin to think about digital music in a new way .
" There will be changes in music content brought on by the digital technology , " said Mitchell , who used to run Universal 's Verve Records . "
We might create an entire class of music that is meant only to be downloaded -- that holds no interest to brick-and-mortar retail -- that we market only for a digital audience .
I think a subscription model with specific artists , or in the case of trusted brands like the Blue Note jazz label , can be branded and people will pay for it . "
they
The recording industry is struggling to find secure technologies that are also easy to use , Lenhart said . "
We do n't have any numbers to back this up , but anecdotally we 've heard that people go to Napster because it was so easy to use , " Lenhart said . "
You just go to the application and boom , you have the song . "
The industry is starting to catch on .
On the same day the Pew study was released , BMG Entertainment announced a deal with digital music company MusicBank that will allow users to access on-demand streaming of their personal music collections .
People have been reluctant to pay for digital music when it 's more convenient to download it for free .
Only 2 percent of those surveyed said they had ever paid to download a song , which is bad news for a company like emusic.com .
According to Listen.com , there are approximately 500,000 legitimate MP3 songs available to users .
The Pew study estimates that Napster 's network provides access to 1 billion copies of various songs .
Fortunately for the music industry , the study found that not everyone on the Internet is rushing out to steal music .
Over three-quarters of the Internet users polled had never downloaded a music file , and 62 percent had never even listened to online music .




BMG First Label to Sell Streams

As two of the major labels finalized settlement deals behind closed doors with MP3.com that will allow the company to license music content through its streaming music service , one recording company announced a similar deal on Thursday with a competing digital music company .
A source familiar with the current settlement talks confirmed that both Warner Music and BMG Entertainment signed deals with MP3.com on Thursday , although terms of the deal were not released .
But BMG announced an agreement with San Francisco startup MusicBank that will enable the users to stream music from a personal music collection on demand .
The service will allow music to be instantly " beamed " into a virtual storage locker from either online or offline retail stores .
" We have wanted to be involved in on-demand digital streaming for some time , " said Kevin Conroy , chief marketing officer and president of new technology for BMG Entertainment . "
We 've been in discussions with MP3.com and MusicBank , but we chose MusicBank because they offer a very innovative service which will provide fans convenient access to their favorite music from BMG 's artists . "
According to Conroy , technical engineers from the label have been working with MusicBank for several months to create a secure environment for streaming .
The MusicBank service mirrors my.mp3.com , MP3.com 's application that allows registered users to access music from the company 's database of encoded music .
Before users can have the music streamed to them , they have to load a physical CD that contains the album into their computer to prove they own the music .
Like MP3.com , MusicBank has compiled a database of roughly 100,000 albums , but CEO Michael Downing said the music will not be streamed until his company has obtained all of the necessary licenses from EMI , Warner Music , Sony Music , and the Universal Music Group .
MP3.com stopped streaming major-label music in May after it lost a copyright infringement lawsuit to the Recording Industry Association of America .
But Downing said that his service actually provides the novice Internet user with safe and legal access to major-label content .
At the company 's launch this August , users will be able to move music purchased online directly into a virtual storage locker .
Downing said that in September , traditional retail outlets would have the ability to move music into the virtual music locker as well .
" There has been a split between the benefits from the illegal models out there for delivering streamed music and the comfortable process of purchasing a CD , " said Michael Downing , co-founder , president and CEO of MusicBank . "
We are trying to go after the mass market , not people engaging in the download market .
We are going after the mass audience who may not have had any experience in ripping CDs . "




Analysts to Corel : Keep Cutting

OTTAWA -- Corel , the Canadian software maker that 's treading water in an ocean of red ink , must make deeper cost cuts to keep the company afloat , even after axing one-fifth of its work force , analysts say .
Ottawa-based Corel , which laid off 320 staffers Thursday and said its chief executive would not draw his salary this year , will need to slash another $ 10 million to $ 20 million in costs to meet its $ 40 million savings target , analysts said .
" The cuts that they announced yesterday look to me to get maybe half of the cost savings that the company has announced they are going for , " said BlueStone Capital Partners ' Jean Orr , one of the few analysts who follows Corel .
" I think there are going to have to be other cuts made .
Whether or not they can do that without cutting more people , I 'm not sure . "
The company , which analysts expect to lose about $ 20 million in both its upcoming second and third quarters , has been struggling since a merger with Inprise/Borland Corp. was aborted , derailing its recovery plans .
The death of that deal in May snatched Inprise/Borland 's approximately $ 240 million in cash reserves from Corel 's reach and nixed a $ 29.5 million termination fee .
Corel said it can not disclose the savings or severance costs from Thursday 's layoffs because it is in a quiet period after filing a prospectus for a recent financing .
In late May , Corel secured a desperately needed , $ 20 million financial lifeline in a deal with Canaccord Capital Corp. , for which it will issue 7.3 million shares .
Corel warned that without the Inprise/Borland deal or financing it faced a cash crunch by July .
Best known for its graphics and word processing software , Corel entered the Linux software market last year , but has not seen that technology make a major contribution to revenues .
First-quarter sales sank nearly 40 percent from the fourth quarter as demand for flagship WordPerfect and CorelDraw software lines stalled and Linux sales slipped to $ 2.3 million from $ 3.2 million .
Corel reported first quarter expenses of $ 43 million and fiscal 1999 expenses of $ 170 million .
Annual expenses included $ 48 million for advertising , $ 82 million for sales and administration , and $ 40 million for research and development .
Corel is widely expected to trim about $ 10 million from its advertising budget , but the source of further cuts remains a matter of speculation .
There are limited pools from which Corel can skim further costs because software companies spend the bulk of their money on staffing .
If layoffs were primarily aimed at junior staff , rather than high-cost developer talent , Corel may still need to make dramatic cuts .
" If that 's the case , then this looks like it 's a half or a third of the way there , " said David Wright , a technology analyst at BMO Nesbitt Burns . "
I 'd want to see who the people are who are being trimmed . "
Corel may also consider selling core assets or its stake in the string of Linux startups in which it has recently invested .
" I think that the recent financing means that they do n't want to sell any of the assets -- at least in the near term , " said Orr . "
Of those companies , GraphOn is the only publicly held company and that stock is quite depressed at this point . "
Corel sold 541,000 shares of California software developer GraphOn Corp. for $ 8.9 million in the first quarter .
Corel , which exchanged its Java business for a stake in GraphOn , has a remaining 1.8 million shares .
Duncan Stewart , a fund manager at Tera Capital Corp. , who has previously held Corel stock in the technology funds he manages , expects further cuts will involve fine tuning .
" They 're most of the way there .
They have to do some cuts on advertising and buying new computers and that sort of stuff -- the discretionary stuff , " said Stewart , who does not currently own any Corel shares and has no short or long positions on the stock .
Shares in Corel rose 9.5 percent early Friday but then slipped back to a modest increase of 20 Canadian cents at CN$7.60 on the Toronto Stock Exchange in early afternoon trading .
On Nasdaq , the issue added 1/8 to 5-5/32 .
" Getting expenses under control is positive and the fact that Microsoft is having some problems with the Justice Department is positive for Corel , " said Louis Kates , technology analyst at Credifinance Securities Ltd.




Germans Dumping Nuclear Power

BERLIN -- The German government and the country 's electricity industry appear ready to agree on a phase out plan for nuclear power this week , following a negotiating breakthrough achieved last week .
Chancellor Gerhard Schrder and Manfred Remmel , president and CEO of the power firm RWE Energie , reached a tentative agreement last Wednesday .
However , no deadline has been established for when all of Germany 's 20 nuclear power stations would have to be shut down .
Tough negotiating is expected to continue on several areas , but a draft of the consensus paper leaked to the German press shows most of the agreement is in place .
One stumbling block , the fate of the Mlheim-Krlich nuclear reactor , has been overcome .
It was closed in 1988 after only 13 months in service , but now its owner , RWE has won the government 's acceptance of the station 's inclusion in what the leaders called a " burden sharing " framework .
Under this arrangement , the industry will be allowed to generate a set volume of electricity and to share this between power stations -- including the generating capacity of Mlheim-Krlich .
A key element of the deal yet to be decided is how much electricity the industry will be allowed to generate from nuclear plants , though figures of 2,600 to 2,700 terawatt hours of electricity are reported to be under discussion .
It is unclear how this will translate into reactor lifetimes .
Previously , the government was pushing for a maximum 30-year life span per reactor , while the industry wanted each reactor to be allowed 35 years of actual operations .
Utilities that generate power will be free to trade or share whatever level of production is allowed .
This , and the fact that the agreement still lacks a final cap date by which power stations would have to shut down , is expected to lead to friction within the Red/Green coalition government , especially if the power generators win generous terms .
The minority Green coalition partner has already compromised significantly on its initial demands in agreeing to a common position with its Social Democratic Party partner .
SPD
Other elements of the draft deal include a commitment by the government not to require closure of Germany 's two oldest reactors -- started up in 1968 and 1972 -- before the end of 2002 at the earliest .
This marks a further setback for the Green party , which wanted some power stations closed before the next general election , due in 2002 .
In addition , the government is pledging not to change current safety standards for nuclear power stations or to introduce new taxes or other measures that would discriminate against the industry .
The deal will include a ban on transport of spent fuel for reprocessing from July 1 , 2005 , with companies being urged to stop the practice sooner if possible .
This provision will be a blow to nuclear fuel reprocessors French owned Cogema and British Nuclear Fuels , already under fire for radiation leaks and safety management problems .




Harnessing Money for Eco-Power

One of the worlds largest companies wants to capture $ 1 billion in the global market for wind power and other renewable energy technologies .
Asea Brown Boveri outlined its strategy for alternative energy solutions at an online news conference held Thursday in London .
ABB
It says its share of the green power market will reach the $ 1 billion mark within five years .
" We have developed technologies that make wind power and other renewable and alternative energies economically attractive for the first time , " said president and CEO Goran Lindahl .
" Especially important is the information technology and communication features that weve built into the systems , making them easier to operate and maintain and much more cost effective than conventional approaches . "
Demand for alternative energy sources and small scale power generation -- wind farms , fuel cells , and plants generating combined heat and power known as cogeneration -- has been sparked by deregulation around the world , which has forced power suppliers to put a higher priority on profitability .
Small-scale power requires less up front capital investment , and often can meet this need better than conventional large power plants , Lindahl explained .
" With deregulation in the power market , global efforts to cut pollution , and government initiatives to boost electricity production from alternative energy , especially in Europe , we think this market is poised for tremendous growth , " said Lindahl . "
With our technologies and global scope , we intend to be a leader in this market worldwide . "
ABB unveiled its new Windformer technology during the news conference , which it claims will enable the economical development of windfarms with outputs of 300 megawatts or more .
MW
This size is equivalent to a medium-sized fossil fuel power plant , but the Windformer reduces power losses and can be used to connect wind farms directly to larger power grids , even from offshore .
ABB is currently testing a 500 kilowatt prototype .
kW
Vattenfall , the Nordic energy group , has agreed to install a 3 to 3.5 megawatt demonstration plant expected to go into operation in the summer of 2001 .
MW
Governments are reducing their emission of greenhouse gases from the combustion of fossil fuels .
The European Commission recently set a target of 22 percent of electricity on the continent to come from renewable energy by 2010 , a 50 percent increase from 1997 .
Distributed power generation can reduce emissions of carbon dioxide , the major greenhouse gas linked to global warming .
ABB estimates that the continuing shift to renewable and small distributed power facilities will reduce emissions while increasing power output .
ABB , headquartered in Zurich , Switzerland , has shifted its corporate strategy from being primarily a builder of large fossil fuel powered plants , and has targeted alternative energy as a growth opportunity .
In July 1999 , ABB merged its power generation interests with those of ALSTOM of France to form ABB Alstom Power .
The company specializes in transmission and distribution of power .
" This will not replace large scale power generation , " said Lindahl in reference to renewable energy technologies . "
Its a complement ... that will offer a more economically viable and environmentally preferable solution , demanded in many parts of the world .
which is
" More than 750 million homes around the world do not have access to electricity , and small-scale power generation could reduce the need to build large-scale power projects in the developing world .
This would have significant environmental and financial benefits , Lindahl explained .
ABB has been a supplier to the wind power industry for 20 years .
Currently , ABB has more than 25 percent of the market for wind turbine generators , with more than 7,000 generators in operation in Sweden , Denmark , the Netherlands , Germany , and elsewhere .
The ABB Group offers power transmission and distribution ; automation ; oil , gas , and petrochemicals ; building technologies ; and financial services .
It employs 165,000 people in 100 countries .

Stephen King , the E-Publisher

An open letter to his readers appeared on Stephen King 's official website Friday that has far-reaching implications for the publishing industry .
" Dear Constant Reader , " the letter begins , going on to describe an epistolary novel called The Plant which King began in the 1980s but gave up when other projects intervened .
His letter continues : " Now it has occurred to me that it might be amusing to put it up on this website , in installments of 5,000 words each -- something like that , anyway .
If this idea interests you , will you email the website and say so ?
By the same token , if it sounds like a bad idea , will you tell me that ? "
King explains that he has been intrigued by the success of Riding the Bullet -- his e-book novella released early this spring which sold over 500,000 copies .
" Stunned , " would probably be a more accurate word , he wrote .
Since Riding the Bullet , he has been eager to try something similar .
Commenting on issues of ownership when it comes to creative work on the Net , King admits to being puzzled by , but applauds , Metallica 's decision to " try and put a few spikes into the big , cushy radial tire that is Napster . "
Creative people should be paid for their work , King writes , just as plumbers and carpenters and accountants are paid for theirs .
" On the other hand , " King 's letter continues , " I think that the current technology is rapidly turning the whole idea of copyright into a risky proposition -- not quite a joke , but something close to it . "
King proposes fans pay $ 1 per installment and suggests everyone be on the honor system .
He said he 'll cease publication if too many people steal the story .
" But I just do n't believe that will happen .
I mean , we 're talking a buck a pop here , right ? "
King finishes up by asking .
King appears to be picking up the torch raised last November by Jason Epstein of Random House .
Epstein suggested that as e-books and print-on-demand books gained acceptance , authors would become their own publishers , cut out the middle-men -- the bookstores and the publishers themselves -- and sell books from their own websites .
" The future of publishing , indeed its salvation , is on the Internet , " said Epstein , who predicted authors who would not need or want publishers , would handle their own marketing or outsource it , and would communicate directly with their readers .
At the time , industry executives were skeptical .
In fact , in March , Stephen King 's own agent , Ralph Vicinanza , said in Publisher 's Weekly that King had no desire to become his own publisher .
" Well , this sure looks like King is going into publishing to me , " said a publishing industry source who requested anonymity . "
It 's just the beginning -- there are going to be more and more creative alternatives to traditional publishing via the Web and I think a lot of publishers are getting nervous . "
In light of King 's newest Internet venture , Epstein predicts that in the electronic future publishers and authors will have to agree upon an equitable distribution of proceeds reflecting their respective contributions which will bear little resemblance to traditional formulas .
" Since authors enjoy the stronger negotiating position , the outcome will be in their favor , although publishers will certainly put up a struggle , " he said .
Douglas Clegg , who posted the Net 's first serial thriller in 1999 and is the winner of the Bram Stoker Award and the International Horror Guild Award for The Nightmare Chronicles , is thrilled that King has discovered what many novelists on the Internet have known for a few years : When there 's a new medium , there 's a new message .
" And the message of the Internet is ' global community , ' " Clegg said . "
Welcome to it , Stephen , look around and find out what many of us have been doing here for the past few years .
It 's a trusting and trustworthy community . "




Not All is Fair at Expo 2000

BERLIN - As it turns out , the Americans are n't the only ones staying away from this year 's World 's Fair in Hannover , Germany .
The United States may be the only major country without a pavilion at this year 's Expo 2000 , but the crowds seem to have stayed home as well .
Despite the concerted effort to make the fair surprising and compelling , Expo 2000 , which features exhibits from more than 150 countries , has failed to attract the huge crowd anticipated by organizers .
While 150,000 visitors showed up for opening day on June 1 , attendance has been averaging just 70,000 visitors per day .
That has some wondering if World Fairs have outlived their usefulness .
" The bottom line is that World Fairs hardly make sense these days , " according to a commentary in the Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung . "
Information about new products and machinery is passed on through other channels , or through trade fairs .
The digital images which have deluged the public at recent expos can now be downloaded elsewhere . "
Organizers originally projected crowds in June to number 150,000 per day .
Those figures are expected to skyrocket with an anticipated 300,000 to 400,000 visitors per day in August and September .
The goal of 20 million to 25 million visitors would still leave organizers with nearly $ 200 million in losses .
The last World 's Fair , held two years ago in Lisbon , Portugal , also had a slow start , and ended up falling more than $ 300 million below the break-even point .
CeBIT , the massive computer trade show held in March in Hannover , drew more than 700,000 people in one week .
It was not the U.S. 's foresight about such expos that kept it away from the World 's Fair , but cash considerations .
Not enough corporations were willing to sponsor and pay for the U.S. pavilion .
" We certainly tried and I personally put some time into trying to get something to happen , " U.S. ambassador to Germany John Kornblum told The New York Times . "
But in the end , globalization did us in. "
The low turnout resulted in layoffs for more than 100 souvenir-stand workers .
So far projections of hundreds of more layoffs have yet to happen .




Benefits Seen in MS Split

Microsoft product aficionados may resent Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson 's order to break up the company , but they have nothing to worry about , consumer affairs experts say .
If the company was to lose an appeal and split into two parts , consumers in the long run are most likely to benefit from a broader array of operating systems and applications , observers say .
" In the present immediately after the breakup , neither the consumer or investors are likely to see anything different , " said Richard Gilbert , an economics professor at the University of California at Berkeley .
" A few months after the breakup , I would n't be surprised if we see a price increase for either operating systems or applications , " he said . "
Microsoft
The reason is that right now both the applications side and the operating systems side profit from sales made by the other side , and that serves as an incentive to keep prices down . "
Jackson ordered that the company be sliced in half to have one company represent its operating system and the other its applications .
Gilbert said the two new companies would be forced to become more innovative by having to design products compatible with competing operating systems and applications .
" That should be good for consumers , " he said .
But as usual , Microsoft is putting up a fight , arguing that its innovation will be stifled by a breakup .
Evan R. Cox , a San Francisco attorney who has represented Microsoft on piracy issues in the past , said the split would certainly hurt the operating systems side of the company because it could not become a player in the future wave of handheld devices and wireless communication .
Under the judge 's order , any speech and handwriting-recognition products and developer tools can only be developed and distributed by the applications company and not the operating systems side .
And unlike the AT&T split-up , which Cox called voluntary and not government-enforced , the entire infrastructure of Microsoft would have to change , possibly halting production .
One of the premises for Jackson 's ruling is that the Windows operating system is integrated into the Internet Explorer browser .
The ruling forces Microsoft to create applications without the integration of the Windows operating system .
" Do you put efforts in developing an operating system if there are no apps ? " he asked . "
How do you write apps if you do n't know what the operating systems will do ? "
Gilbert said the split would not mean that the companies could not still work together .
" It 's important to realize that the proposed breakup does n't keep the other side from investing in each others ' businesses as long as they do it independently , " Gilbert said .
Observers who attended Friday 's PC Data 2000 Trends Conference in San Francisco also were unfazed by Microsoft 's impassioned claims .
Lynette Latta , director of consumer marketing for Encore Software , said consumers could only benefit from the innovations of smaller companies that do not have the money or clout of Microsoft .
Brian Wu , project supervisor for marketing and business development at Primax , a computer peripheral manufacturer , said a breakup would n't phase out the Microsoft products he owns .
" Maybe the way they operate as a business will change , but on the consumer side , not much will change , " he said .




Bluetooth Love Triangle

Motorola will be working with computer makers IBM and Toshiba to offer Bluetooth technology across parts of its personal computer lines , it said Monday .
Bluetooth is a radio link that enables electronic devices such as cellphones and computers to hook up remotely .
The telecommunications equipment and chipmaker said it will also be offering cards and accessories that would allow a personal computer and a handheld computer to wirelessly exchange files and synchronize data .
Motorola is working with its Digianswer subsidiary to supply an embedded Bluetooth technology for use inside personal computer and peripheral devices such as printers .
The company said smaller , lower power modules are expected to be available later this year and in early 2001 .
Motorola also said it is introducing a Bluetooth-enabled car kit , which allows users to transfer calls between a cellphone and a car phone .
Motorola said it expects to announce specific automotive Bluetooth contracts later this year .
