DirecTV 's Swiss Army Box

Microsoft and its technology partners hope a new integrated television/Internet service will keep viewers glued to their Barcalounger .
The new television platform combines four TV and Internet technologies in a single box : DirecTV programming , digital video recording , enhanced TV , and Internet access .
The set-top box , which will be available for the holiday shopping season , has both the ability to record up to 30 hours of programming and the functionality of enhanced television , including advertising interaction and email capabilities .
According to Microsoft , the system is the first " picture-in-picture " DirecTV system that enables viewers to watch one program while recording another .
" This is about taking software and services that will make TV great by allowing you to control when and what you watch as well as offering interactive components to your television , " said Rob Schoeben , senior director of marketing for Microsoft 's WebTV Networks .
Schoeben said the company is de-emphasizing Web surfing in this product because " the PC offers the best platform for that . "
To access the new services , users need the RCA DirecTV system which includes two satellite tuners and a hard drive for recording and watching multiple shows .
Also included in the system is a digital satellite receiver , and an optional wireless keyboard that can be used with interactive TV programming .
Pricing information was not released .
" People are going to buy this because digital video recording is the killer app , " Schoeben said . "
That 's the point of this , because the TV is such a household purchase that we needed to come up with an array of functions . "
A Forrester Research report estimates that by 2004 , the personal recording market will grow to 14 million consumers who spend an average of $ 400 more on goods and services than regular television viewers .
Those same consumers will then spend an additional $ 200-300 every few years to upgrade their systems .
Later this year , Microsoft competitor TiVo will debut an all-in-one set-top box with DirecTV that offers similar services sans Internet access .
" We 've found that primary interest is getting a better television experience , so adding that Internet function is not a priority for us , " said Brodie Keast , vice president of marketing for TiVo . "
consumers '
Our belief is that the PC is a better platform for general-purpose Web browsing . "
TiVo currently has a stand-alone product that works with DirecTV .
But Keast said when the new device rolls out this fall , users will have a more efficient set-top box that is still compatible .




Do ' Dissed ' Teachers Have Case ?

Go to any consumer-oriented website and you 'll find reviews of the newest refrigerators , PDAs , and cars .
So what happens when people are reviewed for the job they do ?
The reviewers end up in court .
Several professors from San Francisco City College are suing the webmaster of a site that posts evaluations of their classes .
What happens with the case may have implications for other sites that follow the same model .
Teacher Review provides a forum for students at the college to voice their opinions about their professors .
The entries range from enthusiastic raves to venomous personal attacks .
Here 's one of the good ones , from a student who places a professor on the A-list : " He 's very well organized , always available for office hours , and always available for questions .
He gives plenty of practice material and detailed answer sheets for them .
His lectures were interesting and engaging . "
Here 's one from the bottom 10 , concerning a professor given an F : " It is difficult to be thoughtful and proper when writing or talking about this pompous , misoginyst , racist , socially impaired , power-hungry , butt-hole from outer space .
sic
...
Do n't take his classes , he should be thrown out of City College .
Try him for a day or two if you must , but as soon as you see the madness creep in , get the hell out of there .
He should not be a teacher . "
Negative posts like this sparked two professors to take legal action against the school , the posters , and Ryan Lathouwers , the creator and webmaster of the site .
Professors Daniel Curzon-Brown and Jesse David Wall are asking for damages for defamation , spreading false light , and intentional infliction of emotional distress .
" It 's criminal behavior , " said Curzon-Brown , an English professor at City College . "
It destroys our reputations . "
The defendants filed a motion to dismiss .
Whether or not the professors have a case will be decided on June 14 .
" If he 's not making any money off of the site and it 's purely provided as a public forum , it 's likely to be a purely First Amendment issue , " said Jason Epstein of Baker Donelson Bearman & Caldwell . "
In this case , most probably wins . "
Lathouwers
On the other hand , Epstein said , if he is making money from the site , and he can control what the poster is saying -- for example , if he edits the postings -- then he may be liable .
In addition , if the plaintiffs can track down who posted the derogatory comments , they may be able to collect damages .
" These reviews said I killed a student ; one said that I had sex in the classroom , " Curzon-Brown said .
" You always have a right to sue the alleged direct defamer , " Epstein said .
But that does not mean you win , he added .
And there needs to be proof of damages , as well .
Lathouwers did not return calls seeking comment on the suit .
Another site , TeacherReviews.com , will watch what happens in the case .
The site follows a similar format , but includes reviews from universities all over the world .
" We 've thought about , but it has n't concerned us , " said Dylan Greene , the site 's co-founder and president . "
the lawsuit
We 've got bigger , better things to worry about . "
The site has been around for a year , and so far , there have been few complaints , according to Greene .
Lathouwers , a defendant in the case , is the site engineer for TeacherReviews.com as well .
" We 're trying our best to make it a site you can trust and there have n't been any problems yet , " Greene said .
Epstein , who specializes in the Internet and e-commerce , said that these types of sites are getting more and more common .
But Curzon-Brown is angry that the focus is on teachers at all .
" This is a way to extort grades from teachers , " he said .
" Why should it just be teachers ?
Why not judges ?
Why not journalists ? " he said .
And Curzon-Brown admits that he 's been frustrated with the lack of responses from other teachers .
" They 're afraid to speak up , " he said . "
A lot of them are in denial .
They think if they bury their heads in the sand , it 's not there . "




Online Learning 's Long Curve

You are a student in class .
You have already logged on to your computer and are watching a PowerPoint presentation by your teacher .
Have a question ?
Click a button to " raise your hand . "
This is n't a typical classroom because less than one percent of the U.S. population has taken an online course , according to an estimate by market research company IDC .
But mass virtual learning , or " distance learning , " is far from e-decades away .
In the last year alone a rash of startups providing virtual classrooms have emerged on the serious money pumped in by venture capitalists .
Financial manager and advisor Merrill Lynch , which has invested money in such e-learning sites as notHarvard.com , projects the e-learning space will be worth $ 25.3 billion in 2003 .
This represents a 63 percent increase per year , from last year 's estimate of $ 3.6 billion .
However , disappointment looms for people seeking knowledge online in , say , philosophy or American history .
The future of distance-learning , it appears , will be dominated by employer-paid technology courses .
That revenue model is the only lucrative one today in the e-learning world .
" There is very little consumer spending on the market , " said Cushing Anderson , program manager for learning services at IDC . "
It 's hard to make individual sales when the value of one consumer is not so great . "
The estimated corporate space of online learning was worth $ 1.1 billion last year , according to IDC research .
Revenues for e-learning sites that offer services to other businesses - and not classes directly to consumers - will skyrocket to $ 11.4 billion by 2003 , Cushing said .
One prominent e-learning site struggled with this lesson and recently altered its business model .
After launching in September 1999 and offering consumers online courses like The History of Sex and Astrology 101 , Hungry Minds shifted to offering more courses in professional development .
It altered its business-to-consumer model for a business-to-business one by syndicating its " experts " or teachers to other companies .
Hungry Minds senior vice president of business development and sales Gary Millrood said consumers were not willing to pay for online recreational courses .
" We shifted more into professional development and training , " Millrood said . "
There 's more demand there . "
But the company faces stiff competition .
Other sites like notHarvard.com are better funded and already offer an array of courses from C++ to film .
NotHarvard.com has always operated with a B2B model and offers other companies content , teachers , and software necessary for cyber-teaching .
The site recently closed a second round of venture capital funding of $ 26 million and has aligned itself with key players in the education market like Barnes & Noble .
" validates our business model being B2B , " notHarvard.com CEO Judy Bitterli said . "
The funding
A B2C model is expensive to acquire customers .
A B2B model takes advantage of an already present customer base . "
Millrood said HungryMinds.com is backed by the $ 18 million it received in angel funding in May 1999 , and he would not say whether the company is poised to receive additional money .
Venture capitalists are enthusiastically investing in e-learning because there is a potential return from addressing high-tech companies ' need to train and obtain employees , said Jeanne Metzger , director of marketing for the National Venture Capital Association .
However , they are weary of funding e-learning sites that are solely based on content and an advertising revenue model , Metzger said .
Most e-learning companies have already keyed in on the market 's need to train workers .
Knowledge Planet opened shop in January and has already provided the infrastructure for companies like Chevron , Hershey , Prudential , and Fidelity to train their employees online .
KnowledgePlanet.com , which is backed by $ 30 million in venture funding , provides both content and technology .
Zvi Frank , president and cofounder of another e-learning site called InterWise.com , said the company has offices all over the world including Israel , Switzerland , and the United States .
The company , which two weeks ago closed $ 30 million in funding from sources like JP Morgan and SAP , sells software and hosting services so that businesses can school their employees online .
Companies are cutting costs by not having to accommodate employees in outside training sites , Frank said .
" This is less expensive than a physical class , " Frank said . "
A virtual class is eliminating hotels and flights and time away from the job . "




NBCi Tanks on Restructuring News

Shares of NBC Internet Inc. , the Web-based companion company to the NBC television network , slumped in early trading on Tuesday following news of a corporate restructuring , a company warning about low sales and earnings , and a Wall Street downgrade .
NBCI stock was down $ 9.19 to a new low of $ 15.44 in the first hour of trading on the Nasdaq .
Its 52-week high is $ 106.13 .
Goldman Sachs analyst Tonia Pankopf said the investment firm had cut its rating on NBCI shares to " market outperformer " from " trading buy . "
Late Monday , the San Francisco-based company unveiled a restructuring plan under which all of NBC Internet 's Web sites and products , including Snap.com , Xoom.com and VideoSeeker , will be combined under a single banner , NBCi.com .
The new , comprehensive Web site will debut this fall .
The restructuring , coupled with costs of recent acquisitions and low revenues due to a soft advertising market from dot-com companies , will result in NBC Internet reporting lower-than-expected revenues and earnings for the second quarter and the remainder of the year , the company said .
Analysts ' consensus earnings estimate is a net loss of 70 cents a share for the second quarter and a net loss of $ 2.84 a share for the full year , according to First Call/Thomson Financial .
NBC Internet said it has about $ 700 million in cash and future NBC TV promotional credits to help it move forward , and it intends to tighten its cost structure in line with revised revenue and earnings estimates .
The company said it expects to become profitable in 2002 , after accounting for non-cash expenses .
NBC Internet is about 47 percent owned by NBC , a wholly owned unit of General Electric Co.




Music Bigwigs : Stop Napster Now

SAN FRANCISCO -- The record industry sought an injunction against Napster.com on Monday , saying it was depressing sales of compact discs near college campuses .
The motion for a preliminary injunction was filed Monday in U.S. District Court in San Francisco by the Recording Industry Association of America and the National Music Publishers ' Association .
The groups argued in their court filings that Napster Inc. , a closely held song-swap software company , was responsible for widespread copyright infringements and industry harm .
They cited a study by the Field Research Corp. comprised of 2,555 college students who are Internet users , which showed a direct correlation between Napster use and decreased CD sales .
" of Napster users ... described the nature of its impact on their music purchases in a way which ... explicitly indicated or suggested that Napster displaces CD sales , " said the Field study .
Nearly half
Napster officials were not immediately available for comment .
The RIAA filed suit against San Mateo , California-based Napster in December , alleging it was a haven for online music piracy .
According to statistical analyses filed with the court , nearly every Napster user sampled had engaged in some form of copyright infringement while using Napster services .
The groups asked the court to " enjoin Napster 's facilitation of music piracy " because the music industry would likely succeed on its claims of " contributory and vicarious copyright infringement , " and because " Napster is causing irreparable harm to plaintiffs and the entire music industry . "
The groups presented evidence demonstrating what they described as " ongoing harm to CD sales , harm to the emerging legitimate market for downloading music , and a devaluing of music , as Napster teaches a generation of music consumers that artists do not deserve to be paid for their work , and their creative efforts are free for the taking . "
" This is not just about online versus offline , " said Hilary Rosen , president and CEO of the RIAA . "
Most in the online business community recognize that what Napster is doing threatens legitimate e-commerce models -- and is legally and morally wrong . "
people
Edward Murphy , president of the Music Publishers , agreed , saying , " We hope the court will act to preserve the rights of songwriters and music publishers , who are being deprived of compensation for their works , and the Internet businesses that have acted responsibly in respecting the creators of music and taken licenses accordingly . "
MP3.com Inc. CEO and Chairman Michael Robertson submitted a declaration in support of the motion , stating that file-sharing services like Napster did nothing to promote emerging artists and that MP3.com had not authorized Napster to distribute the music of MP3.com artists .




Does P2P Fit Consumers ' Bill ?

There 's big money in small transactions .
At least that 's the hope of a swarm of new services that give Net-goers a chance to pay each other by email .
Already , millions of wired auctioneers of Beanie Babies , card tables , and EverQuest characters are using X.com 's PayPal service and other money-transfer systems to get paid without waiting for a check to clear .
" I am small-time , just selling stuff around the house and maybe some garage sale items .
is nice because I am able to get items to people faster , and every so often have PayPal send me those payments to stuff in the bank , " emails one online auctioneer , Glenn McGloughlin . "
PayPal
It is great because I am not in business for online auctions , but I 'm able to act like one of the big boys by accepting credit card payments . "
The tchotchke transfers have also helped make X.com the Web 's leading financial site , with more than 2 million weekly unique visitors -- more than double the traffic of E-Trade , the nearest competitor .
As many as 20,000 new users are signing up daily .
More than $ 4 million passes through its system every day .
And the company just secured $ 100 million in funding from Nokia Ventures , Goldman Sachs , and others .
So it 's no wonder that dozens of companies are tripping over themselves to get into the person-to-person , or " P2P " payment race .
Western Union is the latest contestant in a derby that includes Bank One 's e-money mail , as well as start-ups like eCount and ProPay.com .
Ecommony and others hope to persuade sites to handle their P2P infrastructure .
EBay itself has even teamed up with Wells Fargo Bank to offer a PayPal alternative , Billpoint .
For the moment , these companies are mostly focused on the auction market that PayPal pioneered .
But these companies are looking to leverage P2P auction traction into the broader spectrum of small payments -- anteing up in the office pool , sending money to the kid in college , paying for a share in a summer house on the beach .
X.com CEO Elon Musk says it 's already made the jump , with two-thirds of his payments now in the mainstream market .
Some experts are n't so sure . "
Family and friends are seen as the next big area , but there 's no evidence of action , yet , " says James Van Dyke , who covers the P2P market for Net researcher Jupiter Communications .
No matter who 's involved , the P2P services all work in essentially the same way . "
There 's not a lot of difference between what 's on the networks , " Musk admits .




Internet Satellites Going Cheap

A would-be space entrepreneur is proposing an ambitious network of Internet satellites made from off-the-shelf Macintoshes and a variation of Apple 's Airport technology .
Dennis Wingo , founder and CEO of SkyCorp , a startup based in Hunstville , Alabama , is hoping to launch a constellation of satellites for accessing the Internet at high speed from almost anywhere on the globe .
If it gets off the ground , Wingos ' network would rival systems planned by giant corporations like Hughes and Teledesic -- but at a fraction of the cost .
With help from NASA , Wingo plans to build 544 orbiting Web servers from Apple 's G4 Power Macintosh computers and a souped-up version of the company 's Airport wireless networking technology .
Swooping over the globe in low-Earth orbit , the satellites would be accessible from cell phones , computers fitted with inexpensive PC cards , or clip-on wireless modems for devices like Palm 's handhelds .
As well as using off-the-shelf technology , Wingo hopes to save large sums of money by having the satellites flown into space in pieces and assembled by space station crews -- the satellites would not have to withstand the rigors of a space launch .
Wingo has applied for a patent for his " gossamer " satellite designs , which use inexpensive , lightweight materials and , he estimates , would save between 70 and 90 percent of the cost of standard fare .
" All satellites are designed for an environment they only see for 12 minutes , " he said . "
That 's a tremendous amount of over-engineering just to get something into space .
" You can n't shake something to pieces that 's already in pieces , " he added .
The satellites ' pieces would be assembled in about 20 minutes by astronauts on the International Space Station or cosmonauts on Mir , and then literally thrown into space from a dock or cargo bay before being guided to their final orbit by on-board thrusters .
Wingo said SkyCorp is in talks with NASA to put a prototype satellite into orbit next year .
According to Wingo , SkyCorp has a " memorandum of understanding " with NASA , which he described as NASA-ese for an agreement to work together .
Dr. Lance Bush at NASA 's Washington headquarters confirmed that the space agency is in talks with SkyCorp but declined to elaborate , saying the negotiations were proprietary .
If NASA launches Wingo 's prototype , the satellite will become the world 's first orbiting Web server , covering 90 percent of the Earth 's surface , Wingo said .
The satellite will be in touch with any spot on the planet for only 40 minutes to an hour every 24 hours .
However , it will be able to receive and store data for download later to a head-end connected to the terrestrial Internet , Wingo said .
The satellite will transmit and receive data at broadband speeds using a more powerful variation of Apple 's Airport , which is based on the IEEE 802.11 standard for wireless Ethernet local area networks .
As SkyCorp adds more satellites to the network , the ability to hook up to it will become more constant , he said .




Trappin ' Your Cheatin ' Heart

Mike had only been married four years when he started to become suspicious that his wife was up to no good on the Internet .
" She was on the computer all the time , until 2 or 3 a.m.
When I asked her what she was doing , she 'd just flip out , " he said .
Mike suspected his wife was up to more than the simple " research " she insisted she was doing on the couple 's home computer .
So when his co-worker started a business called Infidelitybusters.com to catch cyber-cheaters , Mike took a deep breath and signed up .
Fifty bucks and less than a month later , Infidelitybusters.com confirmed his worst fears : His wife had responded enthusiastically to chat-room propositions from the company 's infidelity buster , a 25-year-old woman posing as a cyber-suave Casanova .
Even though the " affair " did n't take place in the physical world , Mike was convinced his wife had been unfaithful to him .
" I told her it was over , " said Mike . "
She tried to say it was only the computer , so it did n't matter . "
Mike and his wife are now divorced , and Infidelitybusters.com has put one more cyber-cheater out of commission .
There are no hard statistics on extra-marital affairs occurring online , but Elizabeth Field , a 25-year-old finance manager at a Chicago car dealership who launched Infidelitybusters.com from her bedroom earlier this month , said she knows increasing numbers of people who have been burned by this kind of cheating .
" To me , it 's a sign of the times ...
I do n't agree with at all , " said Field .
cyber-cheating
Of course , it does n't hurt that she can make some money while catching the bad guys in the act .
or gals
But she 's not the first person to make a dime from people 's predilections for online peccadilloes .
An enterprising British company recently launched its Alibi Agency , an Internet-based agency that arranges alibis for people willing to pay for them .
" With the pressures of modern life many of us have occasion to stray from our long-term partners and dally with a brief sexual or emotional relationship with a third party .
...
With modern communications , and media , it has become increasingly difficult to be able to carry on such a temporary dalliance , without risk of detection , " the agency 's Web site explains .
A simple call to the Alibi Agency will score the dallier a suitable alibi , which varies in price according to its complexity .
Faking a doctor 's appointment would run about $ 25 , while a creating fictitious business could cost thousands .
Infidelitybusters.com , the antithesis of the Alibi Agency , is a site that was just waiting to be conceived .
Its premise is simple -- as long as the suspected cheater uses AOL , all that 's needed is a screen name and a simple profile , including hobbies , race , and age .
" little things , so I can create my profile to match theirs , " explained Field .
It 's just
Once she 's got the info , Field goes online and attempts to lure the suspected cheater into a compromising position .
" I 'll Instant Message the person with a pick-up line like , ' Hey , nice profile .
' " Field said .
If the suspect bites , Field will push further and further until she gets her target to agree to a meeting .
That 's when she presents her client with the evidence she 's amassed .
Oftentimes , as in Mike 's case , the client is n't really surprised when he or she gets the bad news .
" I knew , " he said , " but I did n't know .
You know ?
You know , but you want proof .
It gives you closure . "




They Love Microsoft in Asia

SEOUL -- Fueled by an Internet boom , Microsoft 's sales in Asia are set to grow by 30 percent this year , the president of Microsoft Asia said on Wednesday .
Pieter Knook said brisk sales of personal computers , PC servers , mobile phones , and other electronic gadgets meant Asia had now become the fastest-growing market for the U.S. software giant .
South Korea and China were stellar performers , while Japan and India were also strong , he said .
" There is n't a weak spot in our business now , which is fantastic , " Knook told Reuters in an interview .
" We 'll grow in excess of 30 percent this year . "
Knook attributed the surge to several factors : a search for efficiencies by companies jolted by the 1997-1998 financial crisis , global competition in Japan and elsewhere , and consumers eager to rush out and buy the latest electronic wizardry .
The financial crisis , he said , gave Asian countries time to invest in technology training .
" So when growth restarted , boy did it really start .
We 've had boom here for the last two or three years , " he said .
" There 's been an incredible impetus for people to say ' we 've got to re-evaluate to see if we 're being as efficient as we should be .
' "
Knook said Microsoft would achieve revenues of more than $ 2 billion this year in Japan , which accounted for about 75 percent of total Asian business .
He declined to give profit details .
Asians were embracing new technologies even more enthusiastically than many Europeans , he said .
In Korea and Taiwan , for instance , Internet and wireless penetration was higher than in the developed markets of Western Europe .
There were more PCs in homes in South Korea , which has a population of 47 million , than in France or Germany .
Singapore and Hong Kong consumers were also avid buyers of new gadgets and devices .
" In some senses Asia , you could argue , has a greater propensity to adopt these types of new technologies than , say , Europe , " Knook said .
" There is that thirst for technology . "
While established businesses in other parts of the world might expand their computing ability by installing more mainframes , many Asian companies were skipping that technology altogether and moving straight to PCs .
About 80 percent of PCs globally use Microsoft operating systems .
" People are saying , ' Why install a mainframe ?
' " he said .
The growing Asian view was that PCs were " far more effective and far cheaper . "
The challenge posed by rapid growth in information technologies in Asia was that " it puts enormous strains on the service capacity side of the business , " Knook said .
" There are n't enough qualified people to meet all of the demands , " he said .
" It is a bottleneck -- and especially in developing countries . "
Among other factors holding back even faster growth was software piracy , a particular problem in China where annual PC sales of six million were about half those of Japan , but where revenues were only 1/30 th or 1/40 th the size .
Piracy accounted for the difference , Knook said .
" China has all the right laws in place , the issue is enforcement , " he said .
The problem was less severe in India where huge software exports and the world 's largest film industry meant intellectual property protection was seen as a national good , not just good for foreign multinationals .




Hotmail Cold In Some Parts

Many users of Microsoft 's free Hotmail service in the United States and Canada have been unable to access their accounts for more than a week .
A Hotmail spokeswoman who requested anonymity said one of the service 's servers is the cause of the problem , and that it 's affected less than half of 1 percent of Hotmail 's 66 million users .
" There really is n't much more that they can tell you other than we have isolated one server that is having problems and are working as quickly as possible to get it back up and running , " another Hotmail spokeswoman said . "
We do not anticipate any data loss , and will let you know when users are able to log in to the server again . "
Hotmail 's customer service hotline was busy all day Tuesday .
And users who have been unable to access their accounts for the last eight days are still waiting to hear when they will able get their email .
For now , they get this error message when they type in their user name and password : " This delay does not affect the entire site or relate specifically to your account , but the machine that holds your account information is temporarily unavailable .
We do not expect this delay to last much longer , so please continue to check our site for your account status . "
Cynthia Servetnick , a Hotmail user and campus planner at University of California at Berkeley , said a Microsoft customer service representative named " Bazil " sent her an email message on an alternate account explaining the problem .
" Accommodating a tremendous increase in MSN Hotmail usage required us to take the machine which hosts your email account offline for network improvements , " the message said . "
We try to do these upgrades in the early morning hours , so that your service is n't interrupted while we upgrade our system .
" Unfortunately , in this case , the job took longer than usual to complete .
This is an extremely rare occurrence and your account should now be working as you have come to expect . "
Servetnick still waits .
But many users are short on patience .
Sean McCormick , a support technician and software trainer at Red Deer College in Alberta , Canada said he and two coworkers were unable to access their accounts for a week .
McCormick , who says he receives about 67 emails a day on the account , had to open a mail.com account instead .
One of his co-workers is still waiting to hear from a Hotmail technician or customer service representative .
" I can n't afford to have my email down , " McCormick said . "
I had to stop relying on the email . "
Servetnick said it is frustrating not having a contact person or website to turn to for information about the problems with Hotmail 's email services .
Another user echoed Servetnick 's complaints .
" I am very upset about what is going on , " said Henrique de Souza . "
Even though the service is free , they should respect their customers . "
This is n't the only time the reliability of Hotmail services been in question .
Last August , Hotmail accounts were shut down for seven hours when it became known that anyone could access a Hotmail account by simply typing in a user name .
Microsoft responded with an apology to Hotmail users .
" In light of the inconvenience that such an action can cause users , this is not something that we take lightly but felt that , given Microsoft 's commitment to protecting people 's private data and information , it was the appropriate course of action , " the company said .




Look Ma , No Tape

AOL is partnering with TiVo to provide video-on-demand , company representatives announced Wednesday .
" We will have the potential of delivering a far richer , more entertaining TV experience , " said TiVo executive Mike Ramsay .
Under a three-year strategic partnership , AOL will invest $ 200 million in TiVo to build AOLTV-branded set-top boxes .
AOLTV subscribers will be able to use TiVos Personal TV Service , which digitally records television shows without videotape , allowing users to watch " what they want , when they want to watch it , " a company spokesman said .
Users will be able to pause , slow-motion , or instantly replay live television .
TiVos service will also recommend shows that match consumers interests .
The companies said the AOLTV set-top boxes could be available in early 2001 .
In a separate announcement , Time Warner said they struck a deal with Sea Change International to develop Time Warners own video-on-demand effort .
Time Warner Cable said it will use Sea Changes Interactive Television System , which can store hundreds of full-length movies at cable operators facilities .
In comparison , the TiVo boxes have a more limited capacity , but the boxes reside with the users .

The wary , wary month of May : Charles Schwab , the leading U.S. discount and Internet brokerage , said Wednesday its customers put in far fewer stock trades in May , a sign investors cooled off due to the slumping market .
Schwab , which has more than 7 million brokerage accounts , said it processed 198,400 stock trades a day in May , down 37 percent from 317,300 a day in April .
It was the second month in a row that Schwab reported declining trading volumes , after it processed a record of about 345,000 trades a day in March .
But customers kept putting money into their brokerage accounts , Schwab said .
The company reported it attracted $ 9.6 billion in new customer assets in May , up 22 percent from April 's net new inflows of $ 7.9 billion .

EPiCON makes software that lets application service providers , companies that rent software applications to businesses over the Internet , send out and manage software at thousands of desktops from a central server , Nortel said .
EPiCON 's software would become part of Nortel 's newly launched open platform for ASPs , Nortel said .
Nortel said consulting firm Gartner Group has forecast that the ASP market will expand to $ 23 billion in 2003 from about $ 900 million in 1998 .
EPiCON was founded in 1997 and has 60 employees .

Such a deal would be among the largest corporate transactions ever sold .
Deutsche Telekom said proceeds from the deal would be used for general corporate purposes .
But bankers in London identified the escalating cost of third-generation UMTS mobile phone licences - the bidding for which gets underway in Germany on July 31 -- as the driving force behind the plan .

SAP did not say what percentage this stake represented .

MS Appeals Process Set in Motion

WASHINGTON -- It helps to have friends in high places .
When an appeals court this week agreed to hear Microsoft 's antitrust case , the judges signaled they thought it was important enough to take immediately .
The procedure bypasses the usual three-judge panel and allows the full appeals court , minus a few judges who have recused themselves , to act with dispatch .
It 's a victory , however fleeting , for Microsoft .
The company opposes sending the case directly to the Supreme Court , which is now somewhat less likely to intervene .
In an unusual order , the appeals court said on Tuesday " in view of its exceptional importance , " they could begin setting a schedule for briefing and oral arguments straightaway .
The court seemed to be telling the Supreme Court , its neighbor a few blocks away on Constitution Avenue , that it will act so quickly there 's no reason for the justices to intervene .
A federal law allows the Supreme Court to take antitrust cases directly in some circumstances .
For that to happen , U.S. District Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson must certify the case as important enough to warrant the direct appeal .
He 's expected to do that this week , and perhaps as early as Wednesday .
The Justice Department and the state attorneys general have argued for sending the case directly to the high court , claiming that Microsoft has such an industry-controlling monopoly that a breakup can n't wait .
Last week , Jackson signed the Justice Department 's request for a two-way split of Microsoft , and day-to-day controls on its business practices until the breakup takes effect .
Microsoft filed a brief motion on June 7 asking Jackson to stay his breakup-and-regulation order .
On Tuesday , Jackson replied with an order saying " consideration of a stay pending appeal is premature in that no notice of appeal has yet been filed . "
That 's when it got nasty .
That was enough for Microsoft to say , in effect : Jackson is being so darned unhelpful that we 're going to bypass him and go upstairs to the appeals court .
In a related case , a three-judge appeals panel has reversed Jackson 's rulings against Microsoft .
Microsoft lawyers immediately filed a 105 KB document they appear to have had ready for a while .
The strongly-worded appeal says Jackson is guilty of " serious substantive and procedural errors that infected virtually every aspect of the proceedings . "
In stark terms , it says that unless the appeals court acts within the next three months , Microsoft may not be able to release new products such as Windows Millennium and will have to " redesign " all of its existing operating systems to comply with Jackson 's order .
One major theme underlying this first glimpse at Microsoft 's appeals strategy is that Jackson is so biased against the defense he did n't give Microsoft a fair trial .
For example , the company says that Jackson 's uncritical acceptance of the DOJ 's breakup request is " an astounding abdication of the judicial function . "
Microsoft also takes aim at Jackson 's odd habit of chatting with reporters from The New York Times , The Wall Street Journal , and the Washington Post during the trial -- and telling them his views on Microsoft . "
I am not aware of any case authority that says I have to give them any due process at all .
The case is over .
They lost , " Jackson told the Times , Microsoft stesses in its brief .
" The government 's breakup and regulate plan will impose huge costs and burdens on Microsoft and our customers almost immediately .
We 're asking the courts to stay this judgment so that the appeal can go forward quickly without unnecessary disruption to the company , to consumers , and to the high-tech economy , " said Microsoft vice president William Neukom in a statement .




Bluetooth 's Promises , Hurdles

In a demonstration they hope heralds the coming of a completely wireless world , representatives of nearly 1,000 technology companies are meeting this week in Monaco to unveil their latest bluetooth capabilities .
Bluetooth , developed by Nokia , Ericsson , and Intel , is a low-cost , shortwave radio link that allows computers and wireless devices to interact .
Although telecommunications analysts say it will take years before bluetooth replaces wireless interface cards and modems as the standard , the companies convening in Monte Carlo this week were eager to show what bluetooth devices can do .
Retrieving email in remote areas and synchronizing data are two key attributes , bluetooth boosters say .
" It allows devices to talk to each other and the Internet , " said Linda Billhymer , director of marketing for Motorola 's personal networks group . "
For example , you could pull up a phone number on your organizer and email that to your cell phone . "
On Monday , Motorola introduced a car kit or cordless headset that allows users to transfer calls from cellular phones to car phones .
The company , which worked with IBM and Toshiba on the project , also demonstrated a modem card for personal computers that can exchange files and synchronize data between PCs and handheld devices .
Motorola is one of 1,600 members of the Bluetooth Special Interest Group , the organization behind the Bluetooth Congress in Monaco .
The congress , which ends June 16 , is the largest exhibition of bluetooth companies and products in the world .
As more wireless devices are adopted , bluetooth is expected to become ubiquitous because of its almost instant Internet connection and $ 5 price tag .
The sale of bluetooth silicon is expected to reach $ 3.4 billion , according to financial manager and adviser Merrill Lynch .
The Bluetooth Special Interest Group estimates that by the end of 2001 , bluetooth wireless technology will be a standard feature in more than 100 million mobile phones .
" It 's a big trend , " said Simon Gawne , vice president for marketing and business development at wireless Internet service-products manufacturer Red-M . "
The range of applications is enormous .
If you are in an airline lounge , information on a flight could be sent to my mobile phone . "
Red-M plans on working with Ericsson to create bluetooth technology for wireless application protocol phones .
The capability of the new technology was on display in Monte Carlo .
Bluetooth-enabled WAP phones will allow users to check schedules , synchronize data , and access the Intranet at a local calling rate , as well as letting users within the same building communicate with each other , Gawne said .
However , do n't expect people to access the Internet with bluetooth devices anytime soon , said Amanda McCarthy , a telecommunications analyst for Forrester Research .
While McCarthy said she 's seen some bluetooth devices that are " pretty darn interesting , " she also believes the prices must drop before they are universally adopted .
Additionally , some of the logistics of how bluetooth boxes will be set up must be ironed out , she said .
For example , a WAP phone can not retrieve flight data unless the airport installs enough boxes on the walls to support bluetooth 's signals .
Companies are predicting that it is these " piconet " boxes that will someday allow for soda machines to communicate with people 's mobile phones and summon the user by name on a hot day .
" I do n't think too much will happen in 18 months , " McCarthy said . "
Though I can n't wait for this stuff to make it .
I hate cords . "




Nasdaq Japan : Wait and See

TOKYO -- In Japan 's answer to Silicon Valley -- a collection of cramped buildings in a corner of Tokyo 's trendy Shibuya district known as " Bit Valley " -- the imminent arrival of Nasdaq Japan is met with guarded optimism .
" It 's good to see exchanges competing with each other , which enables startups to select the best market for their IPOs , " said Taiga Matsuyama , a 25-year-old director of the Bit Valley Association , a body set up last year to back Web startups .
Nasdaq Japan -- set to open its doors next Monday -- is targeting people like Matsuyama and the 6,000 members in his organization , hoping the new exchange will sparkle with the best and brightest in Japan 's flowering Internet industry .
But Matsuyama stresses there are options for high-tech entrepreneurs other than Nasdaq Japan , and loyalties will follow exchanges that best reflect advances in the fast-changing industry and offer the most attractive environment .
" It 's wrong to assert firms will forever stay in the market they initially listed on .
They can move to another ... which means exchanges must make tireless efforts to make them more attractive , " he said .
Matsuyama said it is hard to pick the best among the three domestic markets for startups : Nasdaq Japan , the Tokyo Stock Exchange 's Mothers market launched last December , or the traditional over-the-counter market .
" We need to take some more time to make an assessment , " he said .
" Competition , however , will not be limited to the three .
...
With startup activities becoming more global and borderless , some may also think of the U.S. Nasdaq for their IPOs . "
Another option for raising funds is mergers and acquisitions , an attractive choice for ventures fearing the treacherous waters of the stock market , where some core Japanese tech stocks have lost 80 or 90 percent in value since February .
Matsuyama said a highly valued startup could take over another dot-com firm via a share swap , while big blue-chip firms could take over dot-com firms to strengthen weak areas .
It is even possible for reverse takeovers , with a dot com snapping up a conventional company , he said .
Members of the Bit Valley Association include entrepreneurs from Shibuya 's " Bit Valley , " along with blue-chip corporate executives , venture capitalists , and university students .
The group became known for its monthly " bit style " events that attracted thousands of devotees to a cramped nightclub near central Tokyo .
The event , seen as a symbol of Japan 's dot-com boom , was discontinued because it became too big and unwieldy .
But a savaging in shares of core Internet stocks such as Softbank and Hikari Tsushin since February has also robbed the industry of some of its momentum , putting the pricey valuations of some Web startups under scrutiny .
Seven out of 10 startups listed on Japan 's Mothers market are now trading below their IPO prices , forcing local Internet startups to do far more to prove their true value .
Matsuyama played down the impact on startups of the slide in shares of Hikari and Softbank , both of which are known for their active investment in Web startups .
He said the fall mainly hit the relatively small number of startups already listed .
" Unless a startup has actual business transactions with Hikari , they would not be hurt by the firm 's troubles , " he said .
" Even if Hikari went under , that would only mean its stake in the startup will move to another investor .
I think their capital ties must be viewed separately from Japan 's traditional ' keiretsu ' ties , " he said .
Matsuyama also dismissed criticism that Japanese Web startups were becoming the target of a money game by drawing far more funds than they needed .
" Money is not our target .
What we want to do is to contribute to society in an area we are good at , " he said , noting that Japan 's Web startups are still in their infancy .
" Startups here are in a learning period .
It 's not right to assert that we are already head-to-head since big gaps still remain in our Internet infrastructures . "

U.S. Predicts GM Popularity

HONG KONG - New types of genetically modified foods will win popular acceptance when consumers see more of their direct benefits , U.S. Department of Agriculture officials said after a wide-ranging trip in Asia .
But the officials , who spoke on condition that their names not be used , declined in a briefing this week to project future demand for U.S. biotech crops like soybeans , corn , and cotton .
" It is hard to make any conclusions right now because we are only seeing the tip of the iceberg in terms of the types of products that we can expect to see through the use of this technology , " a USDA official said . "
I would say that the market is still pretty fluid . "
Besides Hong Kong , the officials visited South Korea , Taiwan , and the Philippines to exchange information with food and agriculture regulators in those countries .
In genetically modified foods , a gene from one organism is typically transferred into another to improve a trait , such as resistance to pests or disease .
GM foods have encountered opposition from the public in South Korea and Japan , but nothing like that seen in Europe , where opponents to the technology say it can have detrimental effects on health and the environment .
Five years ago field testing of GM products focused on agronomic traits modified for pesticide and herbicide tolerance , but the benefits to consumers were not easily appreciated .
New , value-added products , such as " golden rice , " will offer nutritional enhancements , the officials said .
Golden rice has been genetically altered to provide more iron and vitamin A than other types of rice .
" If we look at the future , we may see that there is easier acceptance .
There will be a lot more increased inputs in the products , " an official said .
These include changing the amino acid content in potatoes with higher solids so that when they are fried they do n't take up as much of the fat .
Another example is soybeans that have a different oil composition intended to be healthier for consumers .
All countries on the tour are large markets for U.S. agricultural products and all had government departments and research agencies doing research on genetically modified foods .
" For countries which have an active agriculture sector , this will be a technology that will be important for them , " an official said .
The International Rice Research Institute , based in the Philippines , was conducting field tests on new strains of GM rice .
Other researchers there were studying a new type of virus-resistant papaya .
In Taiwan , GM agriculture research was focused on aquaculture .
China was not on the group 's itinerary , but the officials said there was no evidence at this point that China was opposed to GM products .
The USDA tour was not aimed at promoting or advocating GM foods , officials stressed . "
We are not here as advocates of the technology .
You could say we are agnostic towards the technology , " an official said .




Napster 's Cousins Go Legit

To better its odds at fending off copyright lawsuits , Napster is searching for noninfringing uses of its technology .
Two other file-trading applications seeking to avoid similar legal woes have gone legit -- sort of .
Both the open-source Gnutella network and Michael Ovitz-backed Scour Exchange got a boost on Wednesday when movie and animation content providers released their work on their file-trading networks .
The move could offer Napster a bit of help as well .
That 's because in a 1983 case involving Betamax , a judge ruled that the sale of copying equipment is n't illegal if there are other noninfringing uses for the technology -- which is why copy machines and cassette tape recorders are not illegal , said copyright lawyer Whitney Broussard .
Another component of the ruling is that some copyright holders supported the new technology .
" I know that Napster knows this , " Broussard said . "
There are a lot of other noninfringing uses out there and Napster is going to have a pretty good argument because there are a lot of free MP3s out there available for trading . "
Other copyright holders have supported file-trading technologies , including Courtney Love and Limp Bizkit .
Now two other media companies can be added to that list .
Digital animation and video site Romp.com will release selected , licensed content on Scour Exchange , and movie-distribution company Sightsound.com released a dozen movie titles , including the Internet feature film Quantum Project , on the Gnutella network .
" We believe in the Internet 's boundless potential for media distribution as much as we do in its potential for artistic freedom and openness , " said Bruce Forman , co-founder of Romp.com , in a statement .
" We 're excited to ... use Scour Exchange as a cutting-edge outlet for our viewers to enjoy and share our programming . "
Scour Exchange has been licensing content from partners for some time .
In April , Dimension Films gave Internet rights to the network to premier the Scary Movie trailer , which attracted 30,000 downloads in less than two weeks .
While licensed content will now be accessible over the file-trading networks , it will n't all come free .
But this will test the popular theory that consumers will purchase high-quality , easily accessible content on the Internet .
" A new generation of computer users has embraced file-sharing software to obtain their entertainment and now they have legally available movies , " said Sightsound.com CEO Scott Sander in a written statement . "
File-sharing does n't have to mean file-stealing . "
Sightsound.com , which will distribute 12 Miramax films , released them as encrypted movie files .
Once someone downloads the file , they must either pay to rent or purchase a license to view the movie .
Executives were not available to comment on the announcement because the company is in a pre-IPO quiet period .




Kodak Sitting Pretty With Digital

NEW YORK -- Eastman Kodak Co. , the photography giant that has been trying to persuade Wall Street that its digital business makes its shares worthy of higher " new economy " valuation , said Wednesday it sees digital products accounting for nearly half its revenues by 2005 .
The Rochester , New York , company also cheered up Wall Street by stepping up its share buyback plan and reaffirming its revenue and profit expectations for the second quarter .
Its second-quarter revenues are on track to achieve full-year growth of 6 percent to 7 percent and it remains comfortable with current profit expectations for the quarter and year , the company said .
" Kodak has done two very important things , " said Goldman Sachs analyst Jack Kelly said . "
First , it stepped up the pace of its share buyback .
And second , it tried to demonstrate a better path to profitability with more detail than they 've done in the past . "
Shares rose 2.3 percent , or 1-3/8 , to close at 60-1/8 , on a day in which the Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 0.6 percent .
EK
Kodak also said it would accelerate its stock buyback plan and would repurchase between $ 1 billion and $ 1.2 billion in stock this year .
The company said it would start increasing its purchase of its own stock to between $ 9 and $ 10 million a day , from it current daily average of about $ 1 million .
At Wednesday 's closing price , Kodak shares had rebounded from a 52-week low of 53-3/16 hit on May 9 .
But they remain well shy of their year high of 78-1/4 .
Their price/earnings ratio , or ratio of stock price and earnings per share , is at 12.6 , a far cry below the ratios of such new economy standouts as Cisco Systems or even slumping Microsoft .
CSCO
MSFT
Company president and chief executive Daniel Carp said at a press conference that by 2005 , Kodak expects revenues to jump nearly 70 percent to $ 23.8 billion from $ 14.1 billion in 1999 .
Its digital portfolio is expected account for 45 percent of those revenues compared with 20 percent in 1999 .
He expects operating earnings to increase more that 75 percent to $ 4.4 billion from $ 2.5 billion in 1999 , with the digital portfolio accounting for 27 percent of those earnings in 2005 , up from 1 percent .
Carp said he expected the digital business to earn $ 370 million in 2002 compared with $ 20 million in 1999 , based on 21 percent annual revenue growth .
Most of the growth is expected to come from the commercial sector , which includes health imaging and scanners , contributing $ 485 million in 2002 , up from $ 115 million in 1999 .
The consumer digital business , which includes digital cameras , its Picture CDs , printers and Internet services , is still expected to be a drag on earnings , Carp said , losing $ 115 million in 2002 from a loss of $ 95 million in 1999 .
He was encouraged , however , that the company was making headway in the cutthroat digital camera market , where its U.S. market share has grown to 25-26 percent from 16-17 percent in late January and expects to challenge Japan 's Sony Corp. for the No. 1 position .
He acknowledged that Kodak was still losing money in the digital camera business but expected to breakeven by 2002 .
The company 's bedrock film business has grown 8 percent so far this year with pricing remaining relatively flat , according to Robert Keegan , president of Kodak 's consumer imaging division .
" We see no reason why we should n't see 8 percent volume growth for the rest of the year .
" Pricing is harder to predict because of the competitive nature of the business , " he added .
Kokak is locked in a heated battle in the film business with Japan 's Fuji Photo Film Co Ltd.
The company has an approximate 40 percent market share globally in consumer color film and 50 percent in the professional color film business .
The company said it continues to expect second-quarter net earnings per share in the range of $ 1.60 to $ 1.70 .
Analysts polled by research firm First Call/Thomson Financial now expect Kodak to earn $ 1.65 per share in the quarter , up 8.5 percent from the $ 1.52 it earned in the same period a year earlier .
Chief financial officer Robert Brust also reconfirmed the company 's expectations that full-year net earnings will be in the range of $ 5.50 to $ 5.80 per share .
Analysts in the First Call poll are forecasting a profit of $ 5.67 per share , up 12.7 percent from the $ 5.03 per share it earned in 1999 .
In a statement , Brust said higher revenues and improved earnings , combined with lower costs , reduced spending , and improved asset utilization , are expected to provide strong free cash flow this year and significantly enhanced cash flows over the next five years .




Visa , MC Nixed Smart Cards

NEW YORK -- Close ties between Visa and MasterCard deprived U.S. consumers of a new type of credit card , a government witness said on Wednesday during a trial of alleged collusion between the two top credit card networks .
MasterCard was poised to launch credit cards with embedded computer chips in the United States in the late-1980s but its bank owners refused to go ahead without Visa , John Elliott , a former MasterCard executive , testified in court .
So-called smart cards , widely used in some European countries , let people store personal financial data and money on the chip , unlike the magnetic stripe on the back of credit cards that enables merchants to authorize card purchases .
Visa and MasterCard are owned by major banks and together control more than 75 percent of U.S. credit card sales .
They say the cost of launching smart cards outweighed the returns , and demand for the card was weak .
The U.S. government filed suit against the networks in October 1998 , alleging their organizational set-up stops them from competing with each other .
Since U.S. banks often own both networks , they do not pit Visa against MasterCard , the government alleges .
The heated antitrust trial , which could reshape the U.S. credit card industry , started on Monday in a federal court in New York and is expected to last all summer .
Elliott , who worked at MasterCard from 1984-1989 as head of electronic services , indicated banks did not want MasterCard to take the lead over Visa by introducing the cards first .
Elliott is now an independent consultant doing work for card rival American Express Co. , which paid him $ 504,000 from 1998-1999 , partly to work on this case , the networks allege .
" U.S. members of MasterCard 's executive committee were dual members and indicated they wanted the program to go forward only if it went forward with Visa , " Elliott said .
smart card
MasterCard 's U.S. bank members , which also had stakes in Visa , expressed this view at a 1987 meeting after Elliott put forth smart card plans .
MasterCard would have had a two- or three-year lead over Visa if it had gone ahead , Elliott said .
The card networks counter they shelved plans for smart cards because it would have been too expensive .
The migration to smart cards from the existing magnetic stripe technology would have cost MasterCard $ 1.3 billion over five years , for a net loss of $ 200 million , MasterCard lawyer Ken Gallo argued on Wednesday in a cross-examination of the government witness .
With Visa , the card 's economic prospects would have been better , the networks argue .
Visa and MasterCard then hired consulting firm Booz , Allen & Hamilton Inc. to study the economic viability of launching smart cards in the United States .
Booz did not recommend the networks proceed in a 1988 report , documents showed .
Elliott also is biased because of his ties to American Express , which paid for his personal lawyer in this case , Visa and MasterCard have said .
" Today 's court developments further reveal the intense level of cooperation between the government and American Express , " Visa U.S.A. spokesman Kelly Presta said . "
The fact that Mr. Elliott , the government 's half-million dollar witness , was hired by American Express to work in collusion with the government to build their case drives this point home . "
Elliott was an executive at American Express from 1996 to 1998 .
A spokeswoman for the financial services company said it is standard practice to pay legal fees of a former executive called to trial on a matter related to his time at the company .
In a vocal public relations campaign leading up to the trial , Visa and MasterCard have claimed American Express instigated the trial by lobbying the Justice Department .
American Express could benefit if the government wins , because it would gain access to the bank networks now controlled by Visa and MasterCard .
Right now , banks that issue Visa and MasterCard credit cards are not allowed to issue cards from competitors like American Express and Discover , owned by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Co.
American Express repeated its oft-stated view that Visa and MasterCard are merely trying to distract attention from their own anti-competitive behaviors .




Qbe : Does Its Cost Compute ?

In the early '70s a Utah State post-grad named Alan Kay dreamed of a portable wireless computer that could be carried around like a book but would be as dynamic as a modern PC .
Kay went on to earn fame and fortune at Xerox PARC and Apple , where he pioneered graphical user interfaces and the Newton , but his dream of a " DynaBook " went largely unrealized .
Now a small company based in Irvine , California is trying to resurrect Kay 's dream with the Qbe , which it calls " the world 's first personal-computing tablet . "
Resembling a hybrid between a Palm and a full-featured notebook PC , Aqcess Technologies ' Qbe is a large computing tablet with a big , bright , touch-sensitive screen .
The Qbe started shipping late last month .
It comes in three models , starting at $ 3,995 and climbing to $ 5,395 , depending on options .
Set-up could n't have been easier .
Within minutes the machine was running , and on the network retrieving email and surfing the Web .
Like a notebook computer , the Qbe -- pronounced " cube " -- is designed to be lugged around , from home to office , coffee shop , park and beach , and back again .
But unlike a notebook , the Qbe does n't have a built-in keyboard .
Instead , users take notes and launch applications as they would on a Palm , using their fingers or a special pen that plugs into the top of the machine .
Alternatively , there 's a virtual keyboard that pops up onto the screen .
The Qbe does come with a separate plug-in keyboard and mouse .
They work well but are an impediment to the machine 's portability .
The Qbe can also be voice-controlled and comes with speech-recognition software and a special headset for reducing background noise .
Unfortunately , neither the speech nor handwriting recognition worked very well -- which possibly has more to do with the reviewer 's British accent and scribbly handwriting than any shortcomings of the software .
The Qbe can do everything a good notebook can do and more .
Running Windows 98 , it has a CD-ROM drive , built-in Ethernet , and a 56K modem .
which can be hot-swapped for a rewriteable CD or DVD drive
It has connectors for USB and FireWire and a pair of PC card slots for plugging in wireless modems or GPS receivers .
Unfortunately , neither were included .
Its 400 MHz Pentium II chip launches applications quickly and the 12-GByte hard drive is roomy and responsive .




Network Replaces Nosy Neighbors

SAN FRANCISCO -- Instead of relying on the Mr. Wilsons of the world to watch over your block while you 're away , neighborhoods may soon be monitored by community intranets .
Silicon Valley startup Vicinium is developing technology for automating neighborhoods that would provide local information and warn neighbors of imminent natural disasters .
Vicinium claims to be the first company building software for residential broadband service that reaches beyond the home and into the neighborhood .
Vicinium 's NeighborMation software can be used by cable companies , telcos , and ISPs to offer services through the Internet to residential customers .
Broadband service providers currently offer home security and automation systems to control home infrastructure and automate appliances , allowing homeowners to remotely control heating or lights .
The NeighborMation system would go one step further , providing homes with always-on connections to participate in neighborhood-wide programs , including digital neighborhood watch schemes and community-wide news and information services .
" It essentially creates an intranet in your community , " said Leo Shulman , Vicinium 's president and CEO .
For example , if a tornado or snowstorm were about to strike , the system could turn on televisions in all the connected homes and broadcast a warning message , Shulman said .
Likewise , the system could warn residents of local traffic problems before the morning commute .
While other systems will warn homeowners if anything goes wrong by e-mail , pager , or cell phone , Shulman suggests the Vicinium platform could also alert neighbors to something that needs their attention , such as when intruders trip a security alarm .
" A lot of home security systems turn on the porch light if someone tries to break in , " Shulman said . "
But so what ?
Who notices ?
But what if all the street lights go on ?
That gets people 's attention . "
Shulman said the system could be used to provide news and information directly from local schools , merchants , and businesses .
Utility companies could tap into the system to provide neighborhood-wide power management , allowing it to regulate the use of sprinklers or air-conditioners .
The NeighborMation system could provide a convenient way to transfer permission slips or grades reports from schools to homes .
A school could broadcast permission slips for the entire third grade , which would appear on a TV screen and could be returned with the remote control .
It also could give access to the garage for package or grocery deliveries , automatically unlocking the garage door at the scheduled time for the delivery person to drop off the goods .
Vicinium , whose name comes from the Latin word for " neighborhood , " plans to start trials later this year and to begin selling the NeighborMation platform later this year .




Europe Clamps Down on E-Trash

The European Commission has set its sights on household electrical and electronics equipment waste , calling upon manufacturers to replace dangerous heavy metals used in their products .
Under its Directive on Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment approved Tuesday , the commission adopted two proposals to limit the use of various heavy metals in electrical and electronics equipment , and make producers responsible for taking back and recycling old units .
The EC asked electronics and electrical goods manufacturers to replace lead , mercury , cadmium , and hexavalent chromium with less harmful substances by the year 2008 .
Manufacturers must substitute two types of brominated flame retardants -- PBB and PBDE -- by the same date , unless replacements are unable to meet fire safety standards .
Although industry and public interest groups are relieved that a concrete proposal exists after a seven-year drafting process , the EC 's plan has drawn a mixed response .
While one commissioner , Margot Wallstrm , called the proposals a major step toward sustainable production and consumption , European electrical and electronic equipment manufacturers argue that they need cadmium , lead , and mercury to sustain their manufacturing processes .
A ban , they say , could hurt the industry .
The association representing Europe 's electronics industry , Orgalime , lobbied the commission last year to exempt harmful substances in certain applications .
Orgalime -- also known as the Liaison Group of the European Mechanical , Electrical , Electronic , and Metalworking Industries -- claimed that there are no viable alternatives to the banned substances in many applications .
Its 25 member trade federations , representing some 100,000 companies in 16 Western European countries , will now find themselves paying for the new legislation .
In line with the " polluter-pays " principle , producers will have to organize and finance the treatment , recovery , and disposal of waste .
Since more than 90 percent of electrical and electronics equipment waste is disposed of improperly , member states will have to organize collection from private households .
Producers will then channel the waste into certified treatment facilities .
Treatment standards will be in force by 2006 .
The commission hopes manufacturers will heed these measures and , in addition , reduce hazardous substances at the design stage of their products .
Discarded electrical and electronics equipment is a major biohazard .
Its waste is one of the largest sources of heavy metals and organic pollutants entering municipal landfills and incinerators .
From refrigerators and washing machines to TVs and toasters , this waste consititutes 4 percent of municipal waste in the European Union , and these numbers are growing by 16 to 28 percent every five years , EU statistics show .
That 's three times as fast as the growth of average municipal waste .
