Building a Smarter Circuit

Blending neurobiology with computer design , scientists have created artificial neurons on a silicon chip , a step that may lead to everything from better artificial-vision systems for robots and computers to better prosthetic eyes and ears for humans .
Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Lucent Technologies ' Bell Labs made the chip from a network of neuron-like circuits that behave in many ways like cells in the brain .
The chip -- believed to be the first hybrid digital and analog electronic circuit -- has been hailed as a breakthrough in " neuromorphic " engineering .
The chip , which is described in a cover story in the June 22 issue of Nature , was constructed out of ordinary transistors arranged into a ring-shaped network of 16 artificial neurons and the synaptic connections between them .
Each neuron connects to four of its neighbors , and like their biological counterparts , tends to fire when receiving incoming impulses .
But the neurons also are connected to a central inhibitory neuron , which acts as a regulator .
The regulator keeps the circuit from working itself into an uncontrolled chain reaction of neuronal firings , the researchers said .
" If there was only positive feedback , this thing would blow itself to death , " said co-creator Rahul Sarpeshkar , an assistant professor of electrical engineering and computer science at MIT .
The negative feedback also allows the artificial neurons to amplify or suppress their firings according to the behavior of their neighbors , a distinctly analog trait that until now has been seen only in biological computers like the brain .
Computers , which perform calculations in the binary logic of ones and zeros -- on or off -- are purely digital .
Biological computers , however , blend digital and analog processing .
In the brain , nerve cells fire in response to impulses received from their neighbors -- a digital response -- but frequently the nerve 's response is modulated by factors like the delay between a pair of input signals , an analog process that could n't be readily mimicked by digital circuits -- until now .
" It 's a hybrid of digital and analog , " Sarpeshkar said . "
You do n't see that in electronics today . "




Luxury Giant Is Finally Online

In the image-conscious world of luxury retailing , Bernard Arnault has a rule : Never underestimate the power of a prestige brand .
Over the last decade , the CEO of LVMH Mot Hennessy Louis Vuitton has played a key role in transforming the company from a struggling string of status brands into the largest luxury goods empire in the world .
LVMHY
In the process , the Paris-based company that owns such status manufacturers as Louis Vuitton , Christian Dior , and Dom Perignon saw its stock market worth balloon to over $ 40 billion .
Arnault himself netted a few billion in paper wealth .
But so far , the golden touch of France 's reigning luxury tycoon has n't reached online .
Over the past two years , Arnault poured hundreds of millions of dollars into Internet startups in the United States and Europe , hoping to build an online investment powerhouse to rival his luxury empire .
The results have been mixed .
His biggest investment vehicle -- Europ@web , a fund that owns stakes in more than 30 Internet ventures , most of them private -- surprised the investment community this week when it failed to follow through with plans for an IPO filing .
Meanwhile , some of Arnault 's other investments in Net commerce players , including the ill-fated Boo.com , tanked .
This time around , Arnault focuses on what he knows best : selling luxury goods .
On Monday , Arnault 's Europ@web and LVMH launched eLuxury , a website devoted to selling goods from LVMH 's vast stable of pricey brands .
The launch marks the first time LVMH has permitted most of the luxury manufacturers it owns to sell on the Net .
At first glance , the venture might not seem a particularly radical move for LVMH , but eLuxury CEO Alain Lorenzo insists that there was much soul-searching before taking the plunge over concerns that going on the Web might tarnish the elite image of LVMH .
" What characterizes the luxury world is people are paranoid about their brand image , " said Lorenzo , formerly chief executive of Parfums Givenchy .
To get backing for his website , Lorenzo had to reassure manufacturers that the presentation online of their high-end products would reflect the renowned names and lofty price tags .
Unlike just about every other retailer , luxury-goods manufacturers are notoriously cautious about selling their wares online .
Although they might sell a greater volume of products , luxury brands worry about lessening their prestige by selling through a venue as mundane as a website .
Hence the preference of luxury lines for showcasing their pricey trinkets in velvet cases in exclusive boutiques serviced by ultra-attentive staff . "
They are supposed to be promoting the luxury lifestyle , " said Heather Dougherty , digital commerce analyst at Jupiter Communications .




Bloody Good Wireless

BT Cellnet launched the world 's first " always-on " mobile network on Thursday , introducing GPRS technology that is expected to revolutionize the way people use the Internet .
Britain 's second largest mobile operator is initially making GPRS , or general packet radio service , available only to businesses , allowing travelling workers to form wireless connections between their laptops and their head office computers .
But consumers will get access to the technology by the first quarter of next year , with the launch of mobile handsets that are permanently connected to the Internet .
Users will be able to access WAP websites and receive email without first having to dial into an Internet service .
wireless application protocol
Analysts say GPRS phones will initially run at speeds approaching twice that of dial-up computer connections -- a smaller improvement than claimed by the industry -- but will get much faster in time .
GPRS is expected to encourage computer-phobic people onto the Internet , and analysts predict wireless devices will overtake computers as the most popular way of connecting to the Web by 2003 .

Consumers will soon have the ability to dynamically assemble custom books and obtain standard titles in a wide variety of formats , including print and leading e-book media .
John Kilcullen , chairman and chief executive officer of IDGB said , " This partnership will allow consumers to selectively mix and match content from hundreds of books and put them into new , custom printed or digital versions . "

Online space network : Carl Sagan 's widow has her eyes on the stars again .
Ann Druyan has joined Joe Firmage , a venture capitalist and co-founder of USWeb , to launch a new media network focused on space and science .
The new company , which is code-named Planet Voyager , has raised $ 23 million in seed financing by Softbank Venture Capital and Crosspoint Ventures .
Firmage is chairman and CEO of the new company .
Druyan , widow of the late astronomer , author , and television personality , heads up the studio division .
The company plans to have a name by late summer and launch internationally later in the year .

Kozmo layoffs : Kozmo.com , which operates a one-hour delivery service for goods purchased online , laid off 24 employees , or about 5 percent of its salaried workers , at the company 's corporate headquarters in New York last week .
A company spokesman described the layoffs as a reorganization aimed at " fine tuning " the business .
The layoffs , which did not target a specific sector of the company , occurred across all divisions .
Kozmo.com , which filed for an IPO in March , said it believes the layoffs will not affect its planned public offering .
However , the company declined to explain the timing of the offering .
Kozmo.com employs roughly 2,600 people , the majority of whom are hourly staff .

Eating up Nabisco : Carl Icahn offered to pay $ 28 a share , or about $ 8.26 billion , for the remaining stock he does not already own in Nabisco Group Holdings , according to a SEC filing made Thursday .
Under the proposed bid , Icahn and his shareholder group offered to pay $ 19 a share in cash and a two-year , 14 percent note worth $ 9 a share .
Nabisco Group holds about an 80 percent stake in Nabisco Holdings Corp. , the maker of Oreo cookies and Ritz crackers .
The food unit is Nabisco Group 's sole asset .

A Healthy Bounce for Handspring

Handspring Inc. did n't do nearly as well as rival Palm in its stock market debut .
Market analysts say that 's probably a good thing .
Shares of Handspring , the second handheld device maker to go public this year , rose 35 percent in first-day trading Wednesday .
HAND
The Mountain View , California company started by former Palm executives priced its shares at $ 20 .
The stock price rose to $ 28.25 before dipping to close at $ 26.94 .
That performance did n't set any IPO records .
It certainly did n't come close matching the stock market debut of Palm , Handspring 's arch-competitor , which more than doubled in first-day trading .
PALM
However , analysts said Handspring came in well ahead of expectations , now dampened by the after-market performance of many high-tech flyers .
" Even though its 35 percent gain is pretty weak compared to the screamers we saw at the height of the IPO market , this debut is an unqualified success , " said George Nichols , IPO analyst at Morningstar.com .
Investors have grown considerably more gun-shy in recent months about putting money in new stock offerings , Nichols said .
It 's no longer common for stocks to double or triple in first-day trading as they did earlier this year .
Given the changing investment climate , he says Handspring 's success in completing a $ 200 million offering is impressive .
David Menlow , president of IPOfinancial.com , was relieved that Handspring investors are n't poised to repeat the ill-fated IPO history of Palm .
Shares of Palm soared as high as $ 140 in first-day trading in March , but then plummeted , hovering around $ 27 in recent days .
Because Handspring 's first day run-up is much smaller , its stock price is likely to be more sustainable over the long term .
" There 's not going to be this false embrace that we saw with Palm , " Menlow said .




Musicians , Go Home

SAN DIEGO -- Musicians and their managers are impeding technological advances that would curb digital music piracy , a wireless expert said Wednesday at a conference on music and the Internet .
Drawing rousing applause throughout his speech , Onehouse.com CEO Jim Griffin said the recording industry has created a digital world that is difficult to navigate and has failed to provide consumers with products they are willing to pay for .
" The refusal of artists and their management to put a price tag on their music , with a description of where that money will be going and whom we should make the check out to , and then responsibly collecting that money , has gotten in the way of progress , " Griffin said at the MP3 Summit here .
The problem is particular to the United States , Griffin said .
In the next 10 years , China and Africa will become leaders in the wireless world because those countries have n't focused on building cable networks for connectivity .
But Americans do n't see the value of wireless networks because they have n't seen how they work in places such as Finland and Japan , he said .
Instead , the music industry has focused its efforts on locking down music instead of creating new opportunities to distribute it .
" The business model that the music industry adopts must destroy the motive for piracy , " Griffin said , echoing the general theme of MP3.com CEO Michael Robertson 's opening remarks on Tuesday .
" The lawyers will n't solve this and the technologist will n't solve this piracy problem , " Griffin said . "
Anyway , anything that a 41-year-old thinks up , a 14-year-old can undo . "
The lack of consumer content , he said , has led to the sluggish development of wireless networks .
Samsung will be unveiling an MP3 phone at the end of the year that stores playlists , reproduces stereo-quality music , and has Web browsing capabilities .
A similar version of the phone has already been available in Korea for 18 months .
Meanwhile , the industry continues to miss out on the opportunities that wireless and digital technologies offer .
The average American spends about $ 4.40 a month on music , Griffin said .
So developing subscription models such as the $15-per-month models proposed by the Webnoize research report on Napster has a chance to grow the music industry from $ 40 billion worldwide to a projected $ 100 million .
Lydia Gable , senior vice president of marketing at digital media company Voquette , agreed that creating a ubiquitous digital network is important .
" Unless wireless is made easier , and put at a lower price point , there is n't going to be a real simple way for consumers to access their information , " Gable said .
The danger in not developing the networks and creating security to lock down information has the potential to do damage far beyond slowing the progress of the music industry , Griffin said .
" We must not use digital wrappers to lock up content based on the size of your wallet or the size of your parents ' wallet , " Griffin said . "
People should be able to get access to books , music , and information so that they can become everything that were meant to be . "

MS Unveils ' Dot-Net ' Strategy

REDMOND , Washington -- Bill Gates is catching up to the little guys .
Unveiling Microsoft 's vision of the future Thursday , Gates for the first time emphasized the Web browser as the central application of computing .
Echoing remarks made by counterparts Marc Andreessen and Scott McNealy four years ago , Gates said the network is even more important than the computer .
Gates , in his role as Microsoft 's chief software architect , rolled out a retooled company strategy that would integrate its software with the Internet and make it easier to swap information between computing devices .
Among the prototypes were computers that recognize voice and can answer back , a digital book and notepad that can recognize natural handwriting and connect to the Web , and cell phones that let users dictate email .
" The Internet is the starting point , " said Gates , and the Web browser is the " universal canvas " upon which the information landscape will be painted .
" It 's a bet-the-company thing , " Gates said , speaking to several hundred analysts at the Forum 2000 briefing in describing the " dot-net " initiative .
In the mid-1990s , when Netscape held a dominant share of the browser market , then-chief technician Andreessen championed the Web browser as the central computing application , an idea eschewed by Gates .
But now Microsoft has an overwhelming lead in Web browsers , and Gates is zealous in his support for the browser-centric universe .
Gates repeatedly emphasized that data has to be stored centrally to be made available to wireless devices , reminiscent of the mantra by Sun Microsystems ' McNealy , who said , " The network is the computer . "
Thursday 's announcement is " more analogous to the announcement of Windows than the Internet strategy announcement of 1995 , " Gates said . "
This is a new platform that will affect every piece of application code that is written . "
The international audience greeted the casually attired Gates with unusual silence , and withheld applause until a wireless demonstration nearly an hour into the program .
Gates described the dot-net platform as the company 's next generation of Web-centric Windows services , which shifts storing data in the company 's proprietary Office formats to open standards .




Hurricane Season Outlook : Linux

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Forecasters predict a wet , windy , and wild hurricane season .
Twelve major tropical storms are expected to roar across the Atlantic Ocean , eight of them likely to develop into hurricanes , which by definition have winds of 74 mph or more .
If that does n't scare you , maybe this will : The predicted " Hurricane Destruction Potential " is 100 ; the average season is 71 .
HDP
Aware that bad weather means heavy traffic , the Weather Channel 's Web site , weather.com , is battening down its hatches and switching to Linux-based IBM servers .
The site is changing to a new architecture that utilizes specialized hardware for each function it offers , Angela Herndon , public relations manager of weather.com , said .
" Today we have images , content , Web servers , and ads all running on multifunction boxes , " Herndon said . "
Our new architecture will have several layers with separate hardware for each function .
" Our image servers will now be running on 700 Mhz IBM Netfinity boxes running Apache Web servers , under the Linux operating system .
The price point is very competitive and the performance is excellent . "
Herndon also said that Linux is well suited to horizontal scalability , allowing weather.com to easily and quickly increase the number of visitors it can handle .
Adverse weather typically drives the number of weather.com visitors from an average of 4-5 million per day to over 25 million per day .
Scheduled to re-launch with Linux this fall , the new weather.com will also include planning tools to help people understand how the weather will affect activities such as travel , driving , outdoors , and skiing .
The site will offer expanded personalized features -- delivering information such as severe weather alerts directly to a user 's pager , Palm Pilot , Web phone , email , or personal Web page .




Court Says Anti-Smut Law Illegal

WASHINGTON -- A federal anti-smut law violates Internet free-speech rights , an appeals court ruled on Thursday .
The 3rd U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Philadelphia upheld a lower court 's decision against the Child Online Protection Act , saying in a strongly-worded opinion that the measure was so unconstitutionally broad it affected even non-pornographic websites .
" To avoid liability under COPA , affected Web publishers would either need to severely censor their publications or implement an age or credit card verification system whereby any material that might be deemed harmful by the most puritan of communities in any state is shielded behind such a verification system , " a three-judge panel wrote in its decision .
" COPA essentially requires that every Web publisher subject to the statute abide by the most restrictive and conservative state 's community standards in order to avoid criminal liability , " they said .
The Clinton administration , which defended the law in court , can choose to appeal the loss to the Supreme Court or wait for a full trial before U.S. District Judge Lowell Reed Jr. , who in February 1999 barred the government from enforcing the criminal law .
The Justice Department did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the latest decision .
" We 're delighted , " says Chris Hansen , a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union , which brought the suit in October 1998 .
" The real question is going to be what happens next : whether the government petitions for cert , whether the case is remanded for trial , or whether the case is effectively over , " Hansen said .
the Supreme Court
If anything , the Justice Department seems to be leaning toward asking for a trial .
In April , Wired News reported that government lawyers had contacted anti-filtering advocates and invited them to testify in any possible future proceedings .
During the preliminary injunction hearing before Reed , a hotly contested topic was whether or not COPA would outlaw innocuous material that an overzealous prosecutor might find to be " harmful to minors . "
Website operators , including PlanetOUT and Salon magazine , testified that they feared they would be harmed by the law .
" If a preliminary injunction were not to issue , COPA-affected Web publishers would most assuredly suffer irreparable harm -- the curtailment of their constitutionally protected right to free speech , " the appeals court said .
The Justice Department in April 1999 appealed Reed 's decision to grant the ACLU a preliminary injunction .




From Genomics to Eugenics ?

LONDON -- Scientists heralded a brave new world Monday but skeptics said a genetic breakthrough could usher in a sinister era of perfect people and death to the disabled .
" The further science goes , the further the worst case scenario goes , " Steve Jenkins , a spokesman for the Church of England , told Reuters . "
I 'm not anti-science but there is no way that God is now out of a job . "
He spoke after an international team of researchers said they had mapped 97 percent of the human genome -- the genetic makeup of the human body -- in a scientific accomplishment on a par with the discovery of penicillin or the lunar landing .
" This is the outstanding achievement not only of our lifetime but in terms of human history , " said Dr. Michael Dexter , whose Wellcome Trust funded the British arm of the project .
Carried out in 16 centers around the globe , the researchers have effectively whittled down the human body to a complex string of letters that should revolutionize the way doctors see the body and treat its shortfalls .
The potential benefits are huge : drugs tailor-made for individuals , predictive testing , improved understanding of disease , along with gene therapy to change built-in wrongs to right .
Others fear the possible misuse of science in man 's drive to create a perfect world and say few will benefit .
" It 's the difference between using genetics to correct something that has gone wrong and using them to create something considered perfect , " said Jenkins , who trained in science . "
The idea of designing humans from scratch along with the prospect of an enormous increase in abortion is not the world we want . "
While the scientists emphasized their so-called " book of life " was just the beginning of a long road ahead , doubters said it would benefit few and could turn out to be a giant step back to the sort of eugenics practiced in Nazi Germany .
" Mapping the human genome is a great human achievement , " Richard Nicholson , editor of the Bulletin of Medical Ethics , said . "
Like climbing Mount Everest , it will benefit few people , leaving most untouched .
But unlike climbing Mount Everest , it has the potential to damage large numbers of people . "
Designer babies could be created , flawed fetuses killed .
The stigma of being anything less than perfect could soar .
" Disabled people feel a responsibility to raise the alarm , " said Agnes Fletcher of the Royal Association for Disability and Rehabilitation . " ' New hope ' for disabled people is accompanied by the danger of disabled people and others experiencing increased discrimination in employment , insurance , healthcare provisions , and education . "
U.S. lawmakers have already raised the alarm about medical insurers screening out high-risk groups and employers passing over genetically flawed staff .
" Social policy must keep pace with science .
The abuse of genetic information must be prevented , " said New York Democrat Louise Slaughter , who is pushing for a bill to outlaw genetic discrimination .
Yet scientists say they are a long way from making sense of their new alphabet soup and putting it to practical use .
They point out that the anatomy of the heart was worked out in 1543 , while the first heart transplant did not come until 1967 .
Yet man has been dabbling in eugenics for centuries .
Plato 's Republic depicts a society chasing self-improvement through selective breeding while references to eugenic ideals appear as far back as the Old Testament .
English statistician Francis Galton took it further in 1869 by proposing a system of arranged marriages between men of distinction and women of wealth to produce a gifted race .
Indeed it was Galton who coined the term " eugenics , " and the American Eugenics Society took up his baton in 1926 by proposing restrictions on immigrants from " inferior " stock , along with sterilization for the insane , retarded , and epileptic .
The German Nazi party of the 1930s went to the wildest extremes , using eugenics to justify its attempted extermination of European Jews and other groups of people .




Why GM Is Going E-Crazy

BRESCIA , Italy -- General Motors Corp. has poured $ 1.6 billion into electronic commerce initiatives like the Covisint Internet supplier exchange as part of a four-year drive to integrate its e-business systems , executives of the world 's largest automaker said Thursday .
The broad " e-structuring " has generated $ 800 million in cost savings and helped drive down the automaker 's total information technology spending to $ 3.2 billion annually from $ 4 billion in 1996 , GM 's Chief Information Officer Ralph Szygenda told reporters and analysts from around the world at the end of a three-day company presentation here .
The Internet ventures , as well as related in-vehicle communications systems like OnStar , are set to pick up speed in the coming months and years as GM pushes to use its global breadth to grow sales and profits in new ways , Chief Executive Officer G. Richard Wagoner said .
Among the changes being made possible through Internet technology will be the ability to receive a custom-ordered car in 10-15 days by 2003 , said Harold Kutner , the company 's supply chief , who is overseeing GM 's participation in Covisint , the Internet buying exchange GM formed with Ford Motor Co. and DaimlerChrysler AG .
Kutner said research GM conducted has found that 80 percent of buyers would consider placing a specific order for a new vehicle if the wait-time were no longer than two months .
Currently , less than 10 percent of new car buyers in the United States custom-order a vehicle , usually opting to take what dealers have on their lots .
The number is higher in Europe , about 30 to 40 percent .
Although some automakers have discussed building special-order cars in three to five days , Kutner said many customers would be willing to wait longer to ensure they got the vehicle they want on a reliable date .
" We 're not emphasizing the time as much as the reliability , " he said .
Kutner added GM would have to cut its vehicle inventory by 50 percent and trim its 5,000 suppliers to streamline the system and get cars to customers faster .
Mark Hogan , president of GM 's e-commerce unit , said the company 's GM BuyPower Internet selling site is getting 2-1/2 times the number of " hits " in the United States of its Ford counterpart since a revamping of the site in April .
GM BuyPower will be rolled out to 16 countries by the end of this year .
The four-year-old OnStar , the communication system that allows drivers to make dinner reservations or call tow trucks from their cars , currently has 220,000 subscribers and is on pace to have 4 million by 2003 , Hogan said .
The company is on plan to add Internet and telephone links to OnStar later this year and is experiencing a 70 percent renewal rate from some of the early users in the Cadillac Escalade sport utility vehicle , Hogan said .
Wagoner estimated OnStar is " a few " years away from profitability , adding the company plans for now to keep ownership control , although he did not rule out a spinoff in the future .
" Today there 's no question it 's going to grow faster and realize greater potential if it 's part of GM , " he said .




The Valley 's Costly Power Cuts

SAN FRANCISCO -- When soaring temperatures and low electricity supplies force power cuts in Silicon Valley , as they did last week , economists estimate that it could cost the booming high-tech industry there at least $ 75 million a day .
The price tag for lost production in other industrial sectors throughout the San Francisco Bay Area , including oil refineries and pipelines , could run tens of millions of dollars daily .
" Silicon Valley must have a reliable supply of electricity to continue to be a strong economic force for California and the nation 's economy , " said Tapan Munroe , an economist who studies energy in the technology sector .
" We can expect a hit from $ 75 million up to $ 100 million a day in Silicon Valley if there is n't enough electricity to keep industry on line , " said Munroe , a former chief economist for Pacific Gas & Electric , California 's largest utility .
Measuring the economic impact of power shortages depends on a number of factors , among them the duration and timing of blackouts on design , engineering , and production cycles for computer hardware and software companies , Munroe said .
On June 14 , PG&E cut off electricity to more than 100,000 industrial , business , and residential customers in neighborhoods throughout the Bay Area in an attempt to prevent its power system from collapsing under the strain of a record heat wave .
Temperatures soared as high as 109 degrees Fahrenheit in San Jose , and San Francisco tied an all-time high of 103 degrees .
These emergency steps were taken after PG&E had already cut service to dozens of " interruptible " customers -- those industrial customers who buy power at discounted rates in exchange for power cuts whenever the load on the grid can not keep up with demand .
The blackouts led to temporary shutdowns at high-tech companies like Apple Computer , Advanced Micro Devices , and Solectron Corp. , according to the Silicon Valley Manufacturing Group , a trade organization .
Hewlett-Packard and Sun Microsystems voluntarily cut their use of electricity .
The trade group , which represents 175 companies , could not estimate the overall economic impact of the blackouts but noted that one unidentified company was shut down for three hours at a cost of $ 1 million an hour .
Such losses " are a very serious concern for the city of San Jose and Silicon Valley , " said Marty Woodworth , assistant director of economic development for San Jose .
" We need a solid power system , " he said .
Technology businesses are especially vulnerable because many require an uninterrupted flow of " high quality " electricity for manufacturing processes .
Some , like Oracle , are building their own backup power systems .
The power crisis also led to shutdowns of oil and fuel pipelines and restricted operations at major local oil refineries owned by Chevron and Equilon Enterprises , a joint venture between Texaco and Royal Dutch/Shell Oil .
California Governor Gray Davis has called on state regulators to investigate the recent power emergency .
The state Public Utilities Commission and the California Electricity Oversight Board are to report on the failures by August 1 .
The power industry is struggling to catch up with the region 's economic expansion and fast-growing demand for electricity .
While demand is increasing about 2 percent a year in all of California , it is surging about 5 percent annually in Silicon Valley , said Munroe .
" We have badly underestimated the strength of the digital economy and its need for electricity , " Munroe said . "
We must see the shortfall as a real emergency and rapidly develop new power plants and improve and expand the transmission and local distribution systems . "
Calpine Corp. , an independent power supplier based in San Jose , plans to add more than 2,500 megawatts of electricity to the market from four new plants in Northern California .
One megawatt can power about 1,000 homes .
But Calpine 's first plant will n't be operational until next year .
Moreover , Calpine 's plan to build a 600 megawatt plant in south San Jose was sharply opposed by Mayor Ron Gonzales because of its location near a residential neighborhood .
The California Energy Commission will decide the plant 's future .
While the area awaits new plants from Calpine and other developers , PG&E plans to spend more than $ 200 million upgrading the aging transmission system that delivers electricity to Silicon Valley , San Francisco , and other Bay Area communities .
PG&E and state energy officials also are studying a plan to attach a new 230,000-volt , $ 100 million transmission line to the Bay Bridge or bury it in a Bay Area Rapid Transit underwater subway tunnel to help keep power flowing to San Francisco .
The California Independent System Operator , which manages most of the state 's power grid , forecasts that the San Francisco Bay Area must add about 1,500 MW of electricity by 2005 to meet peak demand , with 300 MW earmarked for Silicon Valley alone .




Andreessen , MS Form Alliance

SAN FRANCISCO -- Marc Andreessen , whose former company Netscape battled Microsoft in the storied browser war , announced on Thursday plans to become an Internet software development partner with his former nemesis .
Microsoft and Andreessen 's new company , Loudcloud Inc. , announced a strategic alliance to provide software and services for companies setting up Internet businesses .
The alliance was part of what Microsoft called its most ambitious project since the Windows operating system , unveiled Thursday .
The so-called " dot-net " strategy will integrate its software with the Internet and make it easier to swap information between computing devices .
Microsoft CEO Steve Ballmer heralded the Loudcloud alliance as an " endorsement of Windows 2000 Server . "
By enlisting Andreessen in an alliance , Microsoft has the backing of the co-founder of Netscape Communications , now part of America Online Inc , which created the first commercially successful Internet browser .
Microsoft launched its own browser , Internet Explorer , which toppled Andreessen 's Netscape in a vicious market-share war dubbed the Browser War .
Despite its browser success , Microsoft has lagged in providing software to run larger Internet operations .
Its new Windows 2000 Server is part of the upgraded Windows NT operating system , an ambitious effort by Microsoft to catch up in the handling the infrastructure of the Internet , where it has trailed Sun Microsystems , Cisco Systems , and Oracle Corp.
Windows 2000 aimed to fix the widespread perception that Microsoft software , built for desktops , has been unable to handle the rigors of large-scale Internet sites .
Andreessen spoke to that point , saying , " Microsoft products are key to providing highly scalable and reliable infrastructure services to Loudcloud 's customers . "
In an interview , Andreessen , who is chairman of Loudcloud , said that his company will not be wedded to any single technology but will try to provide services for any technology customers request .
" The whole space is evolving fast and there are lots of different kinds of software out there , " he said in an interview . "
We basically insulate customers from those issues . "
Loudcloud will create a central computing center where e-commerce companies can draw on technology skills that are " hosted " for many users , letting others concentrate on their area of expertise .
" We will provide support whether it 's Sun Solaris or Oracle or Linux technologies , " Andreessen said , describing Loudcloud as " a software power grid in the sky that you can plug into and draw as much capacity as you need . "
Andreessen said that his company needed to work with Microsoft because its technology is influential and widely used , even for Internet backed shops where it is seen as a laggard .
" The conventional wisdom around Silicon Valley is that Microsoft has gotten a lot weaker , " he said . "
I do n't think that 's true ; in most ways they are stronger than they have ever been . "
Under the terms of the agreement , Loudcloud will license Microsoft Windows 2000 Server and other Microsoft technologies for use in Loudcloud 's Smart Cloud services .
Loudcloud will receive Microsoft consulting and training resources for Windows products .




At Sanger , Science Is Religion

HINXTON , England -- Visitors to the Sanger Centre near Cambridge , where scientists helped lead a global effort to plot the human genetic code , could be forgiven for thinking they have arrived at a church .
A large stained-glass window at the entrance depicts humans in a tree of life , some of them glancing toward the heavens .
A parallel image of the distinctive double-helix structure of DNA winds its way alongside .
A pious silence hangs in the air , broken only by the murmurs of men and women coming and going with purposeful strides to carry out what some say is a moral mission .
Yet here the people preach about DNA and if there is religion then that religion is science .
For it is in this two-story building of gleaming steel and glass where rows of robotic machines and their human masters helped scientists unravel the human genome -- an accomplishment formally announced on Monday and one which should revolutionize medicine in the coming decades .
" It is a milestone in the very largest sense in humanity 's understanding of the universe and itself , " said John Sulston , head of the centre .
The Sanger Centre and its surrounding " genome campus , " set near the quaint village of Hinxton , sequenced about a third of the human genetic map .
The rest was done by the Maryland-based Institute of Genomic Research , the Whitehead Institute in Massachusetts , and other institutions from Germany to Japan .
All were part of the publicly funded Human Genome Project , one of the biggest scientific undertakings to date and one separately matched by the private U.S. firm Celera Genomics .
Despite having finished a rough draft of the 3 billion chemical letters that make up the genome , the machines at the Sanger Centre will not be switched off any time soon .
Scientists must still fine tune the map over the next two years and then decipher over the next few decades how the code actually works , shedding light into what makes each of us unique and how most disease begins .
Nearly everything here is tied to the task at hand .
The cafeteria where workers eat calls itself the " DiNA , " and there is a polite warning to patrons that some of the food they are about to eat " contains genetically modified soya and/or maize . "
Away from the stained glass and the cafeteria , hundreds of young lab technicians in white coats mind row after row of sleek machines that analyze DNA 24 hours a day .
They cast a ghostly bluish glow as people go about their work .
" It 's a bit like Star Trek , " said Chris Clee , sequencing facility manager , as he stood next to a row of machines with names like the 3700 DNA Analyzer and the Quadra 96 S.V.
Samples of DNA from sperm or blood are removed and inserted into colonies of bacteria , which pump out copies of DNA like little factories .
Robots probe the growing colonies to find the purest samples of DNA and then break them into pieces so they can be sucked up by hair-like capillaries in machines like the 3700 .
As the DNA makes its way up the tube , it spills over the top , read by a laser that transmits the information to a computer .
In the early 1990s , most of the process was done manually by scientists , one of whom could process 20,000 chemical base pairs , or letters , a year .
Now , teams process 40 million per month .
Since the process is random -- called " shotgunning " -- many of the bases simply repeat existing code .
So increasing numbers need to be sequenced to fill in the missing bits .
If there is a villain here -- someone who invokes disdain from the faithful -- he is Craig Venter , the head of arch-rival Celera Genomics which kept its DNA sequence private and wants to patent information from its database .
The publicly funded project , meanwhile , made its information available on the Internet every day so scientists and drug companies could start putting it to use .
During a tour of the facilities for visiting reporters last week , the lights suddenly went out .
One of the scientists murmured : " Brought to you by Rockville , Maryland , " referring to Celera 's U.S. headquarters .
" There is a common philosophy here that holds people together , " said Rachael Ainscough , a 31-year-old cell biologist and sequencing manager .
" Most people here feel quite strongly that this moves science forward , rather than having lots of individual people trying to do it themselves and not sharing the information , " she added .




Sketch Software Still Suspect

Although police departments are increasingly switching from sketch artists to software for creating composites of crime suspects , many experts believe that machines are no match for the human hand .
In a recent example , the computer proved inferior at creating a sketch that accurately reflected the suspect 's ethnicity .
Police in Madison , Wisconsin wanted to create a composite of a serial rape suspect , and used Interquest 's popular Faces program as well as asking the sketch artist on staff to create an image .
The computer 's rendition ended up looking more Asian or Hispanic , while the drawing created by police officer and sketch artist Philip Yahnke more accurately reflected a white male , the Wisconsin State Journal reported .
One officer commented to Yahnke that , with the program , " the end result looked kind of like an android -- he compared it to Data on Star Trek . "
Victims who provided input also agreed that the artist 's sketch was more accurate .
Yahnke said that although the software allows the user to specify race , individual components like the eyes or nose may have been modified to create more of an Asian appearance .
Madison is one of many cities testing or relying on software from companies such as ImageWare , InterQuest 's Faces , Smith &#038 ; Wesson 's Identi-Kit 2000 , and Sirchie .
Victims select characteristics from a database of thousands of facial features .
The officer then touches up the image to the witnesses ' specifications .
But despite the fact that forensic sketch artists are more highly regarded in the law enforcement community than the computer method , technology seems destined to replace them .
Anne Punter , president of the International Association for Identification , a forensic trade association , believes that the traditional method " is almost a lost art . "
The profession will shrink further as composite software technology is improved , she said .
Punter said the software is beneficial for smaller departments that may not have the money to hire a forensic artist . "
In a larger department , you have a lot more freedom , and the option to have a forensic artist on board , " Punter said .
" That 's a resource that 's not available to us , " said Detective Mike Lederle of the Columbia , Missouri Police Department . "
This is a great substitute . "
But some forensics experts believe there 's no substitute for artists .
" does n't replace an artist at all -- ever , " said Ruth MacDonald , a forensic imaging specialist at the Wisconsin State Crime Lab .
The software
" There are programs where you can move the eyebrows closer together , but you can n't do those hairline kind of changes , " agreed Amy Nelder , the forensic artist for the San Francisco Police Department . "
It 's just not malleable enough . "
Nelder adds out that talking to a human in a relaxing environment is a crucial personal connection that a victim needs when recounting a traumatic experience .




Analysts Send Amazon Down River

NEW YORK -- Lehman Brothers Inc. urged in a new report that investors avoid the convertible bonds of the world 's leading Internet retailer Amazon.com , sending the bond prices tumbling on Friday .
" From a bond perspective , we find the credit extremely weak and deteriorating , " Lehman said in the report , warning that Amazon.com risks running out of cash by the middle of 2001 .
Lehman analysts Ravi Suria and C. Stan Oh wrote that Amazon.com 's " negative cash flow , poor working capital management , and high debt load in a hyper-competitive environment will put the company under extremely high risk " as it enters " what is arguably its most challenging holiday season . "
After Lehman issued its report , Morgan Stanley , Dean Witter & Co. quoted its top-ranked Internet analyst Mary Meeker as saying she saw no upside and possible modest downside to her second- and third-quarter revenue estimates for the retailer of books , music , entertainment and home-improvement products .
In its research alert , Morgan Stanley 's Meeker also saw no catalyst for the stock " until they make or break the December quarter . "
Analysts said the two reports helped trigger a steep slide in the Seattle-based company 's stock .
By the middle of Friday afternoon , on trading volume of more than 43 million shares , Amazon.com stock (AMZN)traded on Nasdaq at 33 7/8 , down 8 1/8 from Thursday , when it reached a 52-week closing low .
It had reached a 52-week closing-high of 106-11/16 on December 10 .
Amazon.com 's 4.75 percent convertible bonds maturing in 2009 were quoted by traders Friday at $ 58 with a yield to maturity of about 13 percent .
On Wednesday , Lehman said , the bonds were quoted at $ 75.035 with an 8.97 percent yield to maturity .
Lehman , in its report dated Thursday , said Amazon.com is evolving fitfully from being a " virtual " business to being a more conventional , " real world " retailer .
Among the factors Lehman cited is a steady slowing of Amazon.com 's inventory turnover , which Lehman said reflects " an inability to effectively manage sales growth . "
Amazon.com , " as one of the e-commerce pioneers , " has a very well established brand , Lehman said .
Nevertheless , it said , the company " has been unable to turn that brand value into what we believe is the most important value of a brand -- turning a cash flow profit per unit of product sold . "
Lehman said it " does not anticipate " Amazon.com will default on its next three interest payments .
It added , though , that in a best-case scenario the company will run out of cash in the next four quarters " unless it manages to pull another financing rabbit out of its rather magical hat . "
For Amazon.com " o continue its operations and grow , " Lehman said , the company must either generate sufficient operating cash flow or keep raising capital until that cash flow turns positive .
John Everhart , a securities analyst with American Express Financial Advisors in Minneapolis , said he found Lehman 's broad assessment " realistic . "
" Amazon 's roadmap to profitability is my concern , " he said .
For the three months ended March 31 , Amazon.com reported a pro forma net loss of $ 122 million , or 35 cents a share , on revenues of $ 574 million .
In 1999 , Amazon lost $ 390 million on revenues of $ 1.64 billion .
In January 1999 , Amazon.com sold $ 1.25 billion of the 4.75 percent convertible bonds maturing in 2009 .
In February 2000 , it sold 690 million euros of 6.875 percent convertible bonds maturing in 2010 .
then worth about $ 681 million
The stock is now worth less than half of the conversion prices .
Standard & Poor 's rates Amazon.com 's convertible bonds CCC-plus , its seventh-highest junk grade .
Moody 's Investors Service rates them Caa3 , roughly two notches lower .
Both grades are considered low junk grades .




Revenge On the One-Armed Bandit

EDMONTON , Alberta -- WMS Gaming of Chicago is suing an Edmonton man for $ 10 million , alleging that he threatened to publicize a software flaw in its slot machines that allowed players to consistently win large amounts of money .
The company filed suit in the Alberta Court of Queen 's Bench in late February after Zues Yaghi , an Edmonton software consultant , began to post information about the software glitch on the Internet .
The flaw came to light after a publication ban on the suit was lifted in court earlier this week .
The flaw may easily have cost the slot machine manufacturer $ 50,000 a day , Yaghi said in an interview .
But lawyers for WMS estimate the losses at between $ 1-2 million , because they say some Edmonton gamblers visited three states in the U.S. between December 1999 and February 2000 , where they used the flaw to win at gaming .
In Alberta alone , some 300 machines were affected .
WMS Gaming is one of the largest manufacturers of slot machines in the world , with annual revenues in 1999 of $ 125.9 million .
The flaw involves players doubling their bets on an electronic poker game in conjunction with several other commands .
Yaghi said he first discovered the flaw in December , doing what he called " field intrusion testing , " a technique he described as probing functions on a machine for weaknesses .
Yaghi said tapping on the " draw " button as the last credit registered would get players into what he believed was a so-called Easter egg .
Easter eggs are deliberately inserted pieces of code meant to produce a hidden option for users .
Normally , Easter eggs are harmless mini-games or puzzles .
Yaghi demonstrated the flaw for Alberta Gaming and Liquor Commission officials last December .
Within five minutes he emptied a single slot machine of about $ 600 three times .
His problems began when Yaghi offered his services to WMS Gaming as a consultant for $ 250,000 .
WMS counter-offered with about $ 50,000 .
The counter-offer enraged Yaghi , according to Edmonton lawyer Mark Lesniak , who has been retained by WMS Gaming .
Yaghi began describing the glitch on Internet message boards in late February .
He wrote that he was " amazed to discover a huge open door in the programming of these slot machines .
I can literally empty thousands of dollars in minutes from these machines . "
Yaghi said in the interview he has not used the technique himself on the slots .
Shortly after the postings , WMS obtained a search-and-seizure order , entering Yaghi 's Edmonton home three times and seizing computers and data files .
The company then filed suit .
" At that stage , when we started seeing Internet postings , something had to be done , " said Lesniak . "
It 's just not legal to try and destroy somebody 's share value . "
Shortly after Yaghi demonstrated the glitch , the gaming authority issued a notice recommending casinos bar Yaghi from entering .
Yaghi has filed a countersuit for C$1 million against WMS Gaming and has also filed a $ 2 million suit against Alberta Gaming for defamation .
Alberta Gaming is trying to recover an unspecified portion of the losses from WMS Gaming .
The losses would be revenues that would normally have gone into the Alberta Lottery Fund .
The government 's revenue is 70 percent after prizes .
Lesniak said gaming regulators in Alberta , Michigan , Iowa , and Illinois are investigating to see if they can lay criminal charges against the individuals who took advantage of the flaw .
WMS Gaming claims to have fixed the glitch with a software patch , but Yaghi says he believes other models may have similar problems .
Scott Schweinfurth , WMS Gaming 's CFO , said the company has no comment on any aspect of the issue .




Yahoo Goes Gaga for Google

PALO ALTO -- Yahoo Inc. on Monday dropped Inktomi Corp. as its default search engine and signed on with Google Inc. in a major shake-up that illustrated how quickly cutting-edge technology providers can be outdone by new players .
The cancelled deal was not expected to have much of an immediate impact on Inktomi , which sells its Internet search technology to more than 80 customers and says the Yahoo alliance accounted for less than two percent of its revenue .
But the loss of such a prominent partner left investors nervous that Inktomi could lose more valuable deals in the future .
Inktomi 's stock plunged over 25-5/16 to close at 115-1/16 on Nasdaq .
INKT
" We believe investors are currently most wary of potential pressure on Inktomi to lower prices or risk the loss of other customers , " Bear Stearns analyst Robert Fagin wrote in a research report .
Inktomi sought to play down the significance of Yahoo 's decision , suggesting that Google may have simply offered it a better price .
" We 're a competitive bunch and we do n't like to lose , " said Inktomi chief operating officer Dick Pierce , noting the company had in the past lost , and then won back , a similar deal with Microsoft . "
But I do n't think Yahoo 's decision was based on functionality as much as it was based on price . "
Others , though , saw it as one more in a string of wins for Google , an up-and-coming Silicon Valley company that has been selected for numerous awards for its search technology and has rapidly built up a large base of loyal users with little marketing .
On the same day it announced the deal with Yahoo , Google , based in Mountain View , California , unveiled what it called the " world 's largest search engine . "
It said the new-and-improved service covers more than 1 billion Internet pages , or about two-thirds of all the content on the World Wide Web .
The company says it now provides a service equivalent to scanning a stack of paper more than 70 miles high and doing it in less than half a second .
It also enables Internet users to search in more than 10 different languages .
In an interview , Google co-founder and chief executive Larry Page credited the company 's success to its commitment to search and search alone .
It is a focus that few companies can claim .
Even Inktomi , a prominent search provider , has an altogether separate business managing the flow of Internet traffic .
" Search is an incredibly important area , " said Page , who added that building a quality search engine is an ever-moving target as more and more content is posted online .
At the same time Yahoo exited one deal with Inktomi , it entered another , selecting Inktomi as the search provider for its new Corporate Yahoo service , designed to help companies offer portals that combine general Web content with specific corporate information .
Although Yahoo did not disclose the terms of that deal , or its new deal with Yahoo , Inktomi said the corporate deal has the potential to bring in more revenue than was lost from the plain search deal .
It also takes issue with Google 's claim of being the world 's biggest and best search engine , saying it has not yet demonstrated it can consistently execute and that many users prefer to be directed to a smaller number of quality Web sites .




Better Living By Application

DANA POINT , California -- Last year 's Digital Living Room show greeted visitors with the world 's first Internet-enabled refrigerator .
This year , no refrigerator -- and to a large extent , no Internet .
Instead , products that used the Internet as an invisible backbone for a range of functions -- from buying groceries to linking appliances and computers in the home -- crowded the display floor .
" People at the show were less interested in the Internet per se than an application that brings in paying customers , " said Tim Bajarin , president of technology consulting firm Creative Strategies . "
Almost everything you saw on the floor was application-driven . "
Some of this year 's products actually are for sale -- a step up from last year 's " proof-of-technology " demos such as the Internet refrigerator and the first fully equipped Internet car .
Home networking , for example -- an impractical concept last year -- blasted into commercial reality this season as companies such as Intel , 3Com , and Coactive Networks pointed to significant sales of home networking products and services .
Among the show 's standouts :
Coactive Networks : The Sausalito , California-based company 's system links computers and appliances in a home or business through existing cable , telephone , or power lines .
According to co-founder Adam Marsh , the company recently won a contract to create " residential gateways " for 300,000 Swedish homes .
Its potential applications include monitoring and controlling power consumption remotely , as well as and turning lights , TVs , and other appliances on and off .
Coactive also is beginning to implement an agreement with an affiliate of Detroit Edison to monitor and control electricity usage by business customers .
Vicinium : The San Francisco-based company and Coactive announced a venture at Digital Living Room to bring services such as home security , control lights -- even turning a TV set on and off -- through a broadband connection such as cable or DSL .
Vicinium plans to install its technology in 18 Seattle houses next fall .
NCR : Best-known for staid products like ATMs , NCR is pushing strongly into the Web kiosk business , landing recent orders from chains like Walmart , Albertson 's , and Shop Rite .
Particularly intriguing are kiosks that Web-enable grocery shopping .
A deli kiosk lets customers punch in what they want and come back for it later -- a feature that helps prevent long lines during peak hours .
Another allows customers to browse a store 's wine section , learn the characteristics of different vintages , and find out whether the store has bottles in stock .




NYT Site Exposes CIA Agents

A freedom of information activist plans to publish online a classified CIA document that was pulled from The New York Times ' site after newspaper officials learned it exposed the identities of Iranians involved in the 1953 U.S. and British-backed coup that overthrew Iran 's elected officials .
The Times used the graphic to accompany an article detailing the coup .
In a technical glitch , those who visited the Times website on June 16 were able to read the names of the agents when they downloaded the graphic .
The Times put a layer of black boxes over the names in the 200-page Portable Document Format file , allowing viewers who " froze " the page while it was being downloaded to read the names underneath .
" We notified the Times of this and another method was used to conceal the edited material , " said John Young , who runs the popular freedom of information site . "
then
The Times urged not to reveal the information and we said we would not . "
us
Times officials did not return calls seeking comment Friday night .
Times reporter Jim Risen told Young in an email that the names were obscured " at the urging of historians and Iranian scholars who warned that families of Iranian agents of the CIA may face retribution in Iran . "
Rich Meislin , editor-in-chief of New York Times Digital , told Young in an email on June 20 that the newspaper " would strongly urge you to respect that judgment . "
Meislin added that the Times was pulling the document from its site until the agents ' names could be properly hidden .
But Young learned from email lists that others read the edited names when the document was first released , he said .
Young told Meislin in an email June 21 that " since the information is now public , we are preparing to publish the report unredacted , " with the previously blackened text exposed .
Young said Friday that he 'll post a text version of the complete document this weekend .
He said he is not putting the lives of agents in danger , but is trying to help them .
" It is more dangerous to withhold the document , " Young said Friday . "
It 's important that those who were threatened by the leak know it is out there . "




Brits Tone Down Email Bill

LONDON -- The British government tabled a series of amendments to its bill allowing police and security services to view private emails on Tuesday to head off a brewing revolt in the upper chamber of parliament .
Government sources said ministers wanted to define more clearly what information police could have access to without a warrant .
Home Office minister Charles Clarke has also signaled he would look at the potential cost to business of the Regulation and Investigatory Powers Bill .
interior ministry
The government says the bill merely updates police powers to intercept and monitor communications , bringing them up to speed with technologically sophisticated criminals .
People who refuse to yield encryption codes could face up to two years in jail .
But some groups claim the plans , as they stand , could saddle business with a 640 million pound bill over the next five years .
$ 961 million
Civil liberties groups are also up in arms over what they see as an invasion of privacy .
Changes to the bill were lodged in the House of Lords .
A rebellion in the upper house , something the Lords are getting a taste for , had been threatened .
Opposition Conservatives have had their teeth into the legislation ever since it was hived off a broader e-commerce bill and handed to the Home Office .
" Throughout we have pressed for amendments to ensure that British businesses are not forced into bankruptcy or to leave the country and to protect the rights of individuals on the Web , " Conservative home affairs spokesman Oliver Heald said .
" At last it seems that the government is beginning to listen . "
Nick Higson , head of the Confederation of British Industry 's e-business group , said the amendments were a step in the right direction .
CBI
He welcomed a government concession that , in most cases , companies will be able to hand over printed text rather than encryption keys needed to unscramble coded e-mail .
But he said the CBI would continue to press government to pay for interception equipment -- the so-called black box -- that an Internet service provider would have to install so that the forces of law and order could access e-mail traffic .
" Companies would like to see all legitimate businesses excluded from the need to supply encryption keys , " Higson said .
The bill is being watched closely by a clutch of European countries that have yet to legislate on the Internet and email .
Business chiefs have warned it could drive e-businesses away from Britain in droves -- not only on cost grounds , but also over the issue of commercial confidentiality .




Sizing Up Nanotechnology

BETHESDA , Maryland -- Some scientists believe that nanotechnology will transform computing , biotechnology , and medicine , even proclaiming that the technology will one day solve every problem from hunger to disease .
But researcher Steven Block has one thing to say to these nanotech Polyannas : Wake up .
" One of the problems is that nanotechnology enthusiasts dont know much about biology , " said Block , a biophysicist at Stanford University , during a speech on Sunday to 650 scientists and academics at the Nanoscience and Nanotechnology : Shaping Biomedical Research conference .
Nanotechnology is the science of building devices out of individual atoms or molecules , and was first theorized by Nobel Prize winner Richard Feynman in 1959 .
But Block said that ever since K. Eric Drexler published Engines of Creation : The Coming Era of Nanotechnology , scientists and science fiction fans alike have overstated the immediate impact of the technology .
" Lets get real .
Theres a lot of basic science work that needs to be done , " Block said .
The National Institutes of Health convened the conference to help promote better understanding of a field that is fraught with promise but short on answers .
Block , whose lab pioneered the use of laser-based optical traps or " optical tweezers , " to study the detailed motion of single molecules , offered a sobering assessment of what nanotechnology can and can not do .
" We simply dont know how to design ... complex macromolecules that work , " Block said .
Block said Drexler and his nonprofit Foresight Institute , which is developing guidelines for nanotechnology , are getting ahead of themselves .
" Biologists and nanotechnologists need to figure out how natures machines work " before trying to manipulate them or develop their own , he said .
Nanotechnolgy research will continue to expand during the coming years thanks to a boost from President Clintons 2001 budget , which created the National Nanotechnology Initiative .
The program earmarked $ 495 million for research projects , an 83 percent increase over funding for this year .
Seventy percent of the money will go to university-based research .
Later on Sunday , researchers discussed the promise that nantotechnology offers in the field of medicine and public health .
Chad Mirkin , acting director of the Center for Nanofabrication and Molecular Assembly at Northwestern University , said nanotechnology has already had an impact in the field of diagnostics and is used in tests for tuberculosis and colon cancer .
Mirkin said he believes one area in which nanotechnology will have a major impact is drug delivery .
Nearly half of all potential new drugs dont dissolve easily , but they will dissolve more readily if they are nanometer sized , he said .
Eugene Cooper of Elan Pharmaceutical Technologies said that by utilizing a technology called NanoCrystals , his company can speed the delivery time of an over-the-counter pain killer in the body from three hours to 20 minutes .




PC Expo : It 's All About the Hand

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
NEW YORK -- Technology tradeshows are always centered around showing off the latest crop of faster things that will make your life immeasurably better .
Never mind the technology has n't been as easy to use as it should be -- but hey , that 's coming in the upgrade .
The 18th annual PC Expo has plenty of snappy tools on display , powered by technology that CEOs at next year 's event will no doubt be telling us is now easier to use .
But the promise of this convention is not just sleeker , snappier , and sexier .
This year , tech companies are also promising us that we 'll never have to be alone , ever again .
We 'll be forever connected to the ultimate power , that supreme cybergrid in the sky , by way of our Palm/Pocket/Handspring PDA .
Announcements of mobile devices , wireless connectivity options , and things that are smarter than they have any right to be are the core of this year 's expo .
Handspring 's Visor will boast a number of new add-on modules : an MP3 player , voice recorder , and several GPS devices among a slew of new content modules .
GoAmerica pre-announced it would be offering wireless Internet access for the Visor .
Dubbed Go .
Web , the service module will be available in the fall .
Palm , meanwhile , announced that it will support a different module/expansion slot than those currently used by Handspring and the soon-to-be-debuted Sony .
Palm 's official add-ons will be built around the Secure Digital slot technology , from Toshiba , Matsushita , and SanDisk .
Sony 's highly anticipated handheld is still officially somewhat under wraps , but details are slowing leaking about the company 's first entry into the PDA market .
All of the unit 's technical specifications still have n't been finalized but the five-ounce blue and metallic-striped device will run the Palm OS , and include a MemoryStick slot that will allow users to add additional storage space .
The unit will be available with a black-and-white or full-color display , with menus that are navigated by a ' Jogdial ' thumbwheel that will allow for one-handed operation .
The as-yet nameless device lacks wireless connectivity options , but will feature what the company refers to as ' interesting video and audio capabilities .
Sony has so far refused to be specific about exactly what these capabilities might be .
Company reps are answering press queries about whether the Palm OS is capable of supporting multimedia by explaining that they are working with Palm to find ways of building support for these options into the operating system , without compromising the streamlined user interface that is one of Palm 's big selling points .
The machine will hit the shelves in Japan mid-July , with a US release in the late fall .
Pricing has not been set .
Meanwhile , Microsoft is vigorously promoting Pocket PCs , perhaps with the idea in mind that this is the one OS the Justice Department has n't gotten its claws on yet .
Step into the Microsoft partners pavilion and you 'll be pelted with announcements of Pocket PC services and success stories .
The company claims the devices will be revolutionizing all aspects of everyone 's life , pointing to their use in such settings as Madison Square Garden and Colorado 's Coors Field where PocketPCs power a system that allows fans to pay stadium vendors by credit card .
Microsoft and Aether Systems also announced a B2B purchasing service for Pocket PCs and wireless service .
Targeted at large-volume enterprise customers who want their own corporate and customer deployment , Aether will manage order fulfillment and customer support of the wireless Enterprise ISP service which will use the Compaq iPaq Pocket PC and the Sierra Wireless AirCard 300 .
The $ 39.99 monthly cost of Aether 's Enterprise ISP service for Pocket PCs will include unlimited usage and access to email and the customer 's choice of Web content .
And to keep your little pocket pal safe from prying eyes , Ethentica offers the Ethenticator MS 3000 , a Type II PC Card with a pop-out fingerprint sensor that replaces passwords with touch verification .
You place your finger on the sensor and it matches it to the scanned print in memory .
If the whirls and loops match , you 're granted access .
