The Age of E-Sigs Is Here

WASHINGTON -- Critics of an electronic signature law that President Clinton signed on Friday say it comes at a cost to consumers ' protections and wallets .
Portions of the law may weaken consumers ' abilities to control their online and e-commerce experiences , say some consumer advocates .
" There is no doubt that this law has a huge potential for big companies to sell big ticket items online .
What 's not clear yet are the safety concerns , " said David Butler of the Consumers Union , which publishes Consumer Reports . "
We would have liked to have seen more consumer protection in the law . "
Instead of allowing secure cryptographic digital signatures , used by companies such as Verisign and PGP , the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act instead allows companies to count touch-tones or perhaps click on hyperlinks as legally binding contracts .
Secure digital signatures automatically become invalid when a contract or document is altered .
The phrase " digital signature " never appears in the law .
Electronic signature is vaguely defined as " an electronic sound , symbol , or process , attached to or logically associated with a contract . "
" The process of clicking now generates a legal relationship with a vendor , and can bind the consumer for categories of records , " said William Simpson , a cryptographer who is active inside the Internet Engineering Task Force . "
This gives legal weight to website product disclaimers , poor privacy practices , or installer shrink-wrap conditions , simply by making them available . "
Simpson argues that the broad definition of e-signatures leaves open the possibility of the consumer consenting to the electronic contract by merely clicking " continue " on a software installer , and could allow vendors to charge a fee if a customer backs out of the transaction at the last minute .
President Clinton signed the bill on Friday in a ceremony at Philadelphia 's Independence Hall .
" will open up new frontiers of economic opportunity while protecting the rights of American consumers , " Clinton said . "
It
Companies will have the legal certainty they need to invest and expand in electronic commerce .
They will be able not only to purchase products and services , but to contract to do so .
also
And they could potentially save billions of dollars by sending and retaining monthly statements and other records in electronic form . "
The computer industry backed it , and argues that the law covers privacy and protection by adhering to the principles and practices of fair trade . "
The bill basically covers the superset , " said Tom Arnold , chief technology officer at CyberSource , an e-commerce transaction firm . "
You 've got notice , disclosure , authentication , and authorization .
I would say that that clicking engages the consumer into a binding contract with the vendor is a broad and vague interpretation of the law . "
the fact
Many in the computer industry feel the same way .
" This marks the beginning of a new era , " said Ben Isaacson , executive director of the Association for Interactive Media . "
Now , digital signatures will allow more secure trading and will decrease fraud in electronic transactions by use of encryption keys .
As businesses and consumers recognize the power of the Internet for e-commerce , these first regulatory steps will pave the way for a windfall of economic progress . "
After months of negotiations with Democratic legislators and the White House , in early June Republicans reached a compromise deal on the legislation .
The law grants the same legal weight to e-signatures and records as currently held by paper documents and is designed to boost e-commerce and the U.S. economy .




Whose Genes Are They , Anyway ?

So we 've got a genome map , but whose DNA is it anyway ?
Is it Craig Venter 's ?
He 's the CEO of Celera Genomics , the company that helped lead the race to map the human genome .
" There 's rampant speculation in the industry that it 's Venter 's , " said Cyrus Harmon , president and CEO of Neomorphic , a genomics company in Berkeley , California . "
He 's the type of person who would do that . "
In this case , doing " that " probably means providing the sperm from which the DNA was extracted .
Venter is n't talking .
Celera is mapping the genome of as many as six unidentified individuals .
The first person to have his or her genome mapped was called the First Assembly , the completion of which the company announced on Monday .
Human Genome Project researchers , who also announced they had completed their own map on Monday , used samples from several anonymous individuals , although the majority of the DNA was taken from one male .
Blood from females and sperm furnished the DNA used to create the publicly funded Human Genome Project map .
While the female samples lack the Y chromosome , the sperm is a more complete source of DNA molecules because it contains both the X and Y chromosomes .
" Nobody really knows anything about the identity " of the donors , said George Weinstock , co-director of the Baylor College of Medicine Human Genome Sequencing Center , one of the labs that worked on the Human Genome Project . "
We go out of our way to insure maximum genetic privacy . "
The donors ' identities do n't " make a whit of difference whatsoever , " said Leroy Hood , director of the Institute for Systems Biology .
That is because all people 's genes are 99.9 percent the same .
Race does n't make a difference in the human genome .
Neither does the presence of disease , or other attributes like height , weight , eye color , or who can curl their tongue .
The genomes of the famous jockey Willie Shoemaker and basketball great Wilt Chamberlain " are probably about the same , " Weinstock said .
Variations in genes , not the genes themselves , are what cause differences in people .
Companies like Orchid Biocomputer , Millennium Pharmaceuticals , and Nanogen , as well as a government project , are working on discovering one type of these variations called single nucleotide polymorphisms , or SNPs .
pronounced snips
Variations in human genes developed among discrete populations who lived in one geographical area over time , according to John McPherson , co-director of the human genome sequencing center at Washington University in St. Louis .
An example of this would be thalassemia , which includes a number of different forms of anemia .
red blood-cell deficiency
The most severe form of alpha thalassemia affects mainly individuals of Southeast Asian , Chinese , and Filipino ancestry .
" People traveling around , and moving so much , is a recent event in evolutionary history , " he said .




When You Send Spam to Yourself

Carl Toups usually does n't blink at unsolicited junk mail in his Hotmail account , but a piece of spam recently caught his eye .
It looked like he sent an ad for a dream vacation to himself , because his email address appeared on the " sender " line .
" The funny thing about it was that there was no sponsor name anywhere to be found on the message , " said Toups , a construction mechanic for the Navy in Gulfport , Mississippi . "
They did ask for all of your demographics , including credit card information . "
Toups is n't the only Hotmail customer receiving unsolicited self-addressed spam .
Pauline Mang , a marketing consultant in Ontario , said she received two similar spam messages with her Hotmail email address listed as the sender -- one promoting university degrees and another with a tongue-in-cheek header " Tired of Spam ? "
" The other one contained an HTML page with two clickable lines , and I think it was headed up , ' Tired of Spam ?
Click here , ' " she said . "
Of course I do n't click those puppies because I 'm pretty sure it 's a way to scan my login and password . "
Microsoft 's free Hotmail and other free email service providers expressed no surprise at Toups ' and Mang 's findings .
They say concealing the actual sender 's email address with the recipient 's address is an old-school tactic spammers use to trick people into clicking on their message .
" You can pretty much make the ' from ' address be whatever you want it to be , " said John Movena , co-founder and vice president for the anti-spam group Coalition Against Unsolicited Commercial Email . "
CAUCE
Spammers have always put fake addresses , they never use their real addresses .
But for some reason , they try to confuse people by using the recipient 's address instead . "




Baseball 's Andro Controversy

Get ready for the controversy over the testosterone-booster androstenedione -- the Mark McGwire drug -- to get bigger than ever .
Barry McCaffrey , the head of the White House Office of Drug Control Policy , came out strongly last week against andro , which McGwire was taking two seasons ago when he broke Roger Maris ' home-run record .
McGwire later announced that he had stopped using andro , and did not want others to emulate him .
But in the year since the Associated Press first reported he was using andro , sales increased tenfold , according to industry information .
McCaffrey predicted the government would classify andro as a steroid " within a few months , " which would make it illegal to distribute or use as a performance-enhancing substance .
" I 've got to do something about andro , " McCaffrey said . "
I 've got to get valid testing completed , and I bet that 's the way it comes out : that andro is a steroid . "
Reached by mobile phone in Sydney , Australia , International Olympic Committee medical director Patrick Schamasch said it was about time .
The IOC , like numerous other sports bodies , bans andro , which it already classifies as an anabolic steroid .
" We spoke out two years ago and nothing was changed , " Schamasch said . "
We 're happy to see this .
It 's a bit late , but better late than never .
John Hoberman , a University of Texas professor writing a book on steroids , said McCaffrey will have to make a more forceful statement if he wants to have a serious impact .
" As soon as he says he needs testing before he can determine if andro is a sex steroid , he has let the wrong people frame the issue , " said Hoberman , author of Darwin 's Athletes . "
Of course it 's a sex steroid . "
Even if the U.S. government does not classify andro as a steroid , Major League Baseball could still be put in an awkward position .
Doping critics have even suggested that McGwire 's record might need to have an asterisk in the record books .
Sandy Alderson , baseball 's No. 3 official , declined to discuss McCaffrey 's comments in detail .
But he said baseball would update its policy on andro when more information was obtained .
" Baseball has a continuing research effort at Harvard University , " he said . "
When that project is completed , I 'm sure baseball will review the results and take action , if appropriate , in accordance with the report . "
That sounds like baseball is ready to ban andro eventually .
The Harvard researchers mentioned by Alderson -- Dr. Joel Finkelstein and Dr. Benjamin Leder -- have already published the results of one study on andro that found it indeed boosted testosterone levels .
" That oral androstenedione administration increases serum testosterone levels suggests that it could have androgenic or anabolic effects , " Finkelstein , Leder , and their fellow researchers wrote in the Journal of the American Medical Association earlier this year .
" High doses of testosterone increase muscle size and strength in healthy men .
While testosterone levels increased in the subjects receiving the 300-mg dosage , levels returned to normal by the following day .
This is expected given that the half-life of testosterone in circulation is 60 to 80 minutes .
Because many users probably take much higher and more frequent dosages of androstenedione , it is likely that some individuals may experience sustained and larger increases in testosterone levels compared with those observed in the present study . "




NASA : Hacker Threatened Mission

LONDON -- A computer hacker put space shuttle astronauts ' lives at risk by overloading NASA 's communication system in 1997 , the agency told the BBC in a program to be aired Monday .
The hacker interfered with computer systems monitoring the heartbeat , pulse , and medical conditions of the space shuttle crew as it docked with the Russian Mir space station , NASA inspector general Roberta Gross told the BBC program Panorama .
" We had an activity at a NASA center where a hacker was overloading our systems ... to such an extent that it interfered with communications between the NASA center , some medical communications , and the astronauts aboard the shuttle , " Gross said .
Although NASA had backup communication systems , the incident " shows the potential that hackers have for doing some real damage to NASA 's mission and astronaut safety , " she said .
Panorama interviewed Gross for an investigation into how Internet and computer systems have become the vulnerable spots in the defenses of Western nations .




Winning the Next Space Race

WASHINGTON -- There 's another space race heating up between the United States and Russia , but this time it 's the tourism industry that 's up for grabs .
" There 's something wrong here when entrepreneurialism has to go to the ' Evil Empire ' of years past , " said Peter Diamandis , CEO of ZeroGravity Corp. , which sells weightless flights to the general public using Russian aircraft .
Diamandis cited the recent announcement by MirCorp , a Dutch-based company , that it plans to launch commercial space flights to the Russian-owned Mir space station for private citizens .
Diamandis , who previously founded International Microspace , was speaking at an event Monday on Capitol Hill organized by the Space Transportation Association .
Other members of the STA include Boeing , LunaCorp , and Lockheed Martin .
At the event , other executives asked Congress to reduce regulation and boost NASA 's budget for the agency 's space exploration program .
Some STA members are government contractors and stand to benefit from the spending increase .
Diamandis complained , for example , that Federal Aviation Administration rules interfere with ZeroGravity 's ability to send would-be aeronauts into free-fall dives that provide some 30 seconds of temporary weightlessness .
Currently launching from the Yuri Gagarin Cosmonaut Training Center in Star City , Russia , the zero-gravity flights cost about $ 5,000 .
An FAA spokesman did not immediately respond to a request for comment .
" It is said that in a mature society , there is a law against everything .
Well , we are living in a mature society .
If a Russian team beats us because of poor legislation , it 's going to look pretty bad on the front page of The New York Times , " Diamandis said .
Other speakers at the conference said the U.S. government needed to spend more in the area of space tourism -- and that such a move would bring the reality of such ventures out of the far-off future and into the present .
" The federal and state governments have traditionally provided money for all forms of mass transit , airlines , the major railways and the like .
However , after 40 plus years of space exploration , we 've seen no public funds allocated toward space tourism , " said Bob Haltermann , director of the STA 's tourism division , at Monday 's conference .




Top Business Schools E-Align

Beginning this fall , three high-ranking , competing business schools will collaborate to offer classes to each other 's students via full-motion video-conferencing and other Internet technologies .
School officials expect it to become a popular feature , despite logistical difficulties and a prevailing belief among detractors that the quality of the education might suffer .
The Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley , the University of Michigan Business School , and the Darden School at the University of Virginia will offer each other 's students classes specializing in e-business .
" So much of business education is the network-building between the students , " said Haas Dean Laura Tyson . "
What is nice here is that people in each location will now be able to have a new selection of classes to choose from , and a new selection of people to work with . "
" In essence , this program is not only about sharing knowledge but about sharing communities , " she said .
Each school will offer its own courses in e-business and technology .
Class preparation materials and research will be distributed over the Internet , and students will communicate during class with each other and with faculty via video-conferencing and Internet chat rooms .
For example , a student at Berkeley 's Haas School could elect to take Darden 's course on e-business .
The Haas School will offer a course on financial issues in the Internet sector , including valuation of high-technology companies .
Michigan will teach a course on understanding and strategically applying Internet technologies .
The University of Michigan 's alliance with the other two schools grew out of its video-conferencing and Internet chat room classes used by its MBA students studying abroad in Brazil and Korea .
The university 's MBA abroad program began in Hong Kong in 1985 , when professors used video-conferencing and other Internet technologies .
Although that program is no longer taking place , programs in Korea and Brazil are .
Michigan Dean of Business B. Joseph White went to Brazil to teach students who were using the technology .
" I came away from the teaching experience with the feeling that the students were achieving a very strong level of education , " White said . "
I feel very confident in the quality of education and fairness of grading that can be achieved through video-conferencing and the Internet . "
" If I did n't feel it would work , I would n't propose , " he added .
the alliance between Michigan , Haas , and Darden
There are skeptics out there .
Mihir Mankab , a recent graduate of the J.L. Kellogg Graduate School of Management at Northwestern University , said it was difficult to enroll in a popular e-business class offered at his school .
Due to its popularity , the class used video-conferencing and Internet chat rooms so that more students could participate .
Mankab said he participated in the video-conferencing course for a few weeks , but dropped the class because of scheduling conflicts .
Ultimately , he heard mixed reviews from the other students who used the technology .




NASA Probes Crashing Explorer

When Columbus and his fellow European explorers landed in the Americas , they unwittingly unleashed an invisible menace that annihilated many of the New World 's people -- small pox .
The local population had no natural resistance to the alien virus , and it quickly killed off millions .
Five hundred years later , scientists are taking steps to ensure that another explorer with an Italian name -- the Galileo Space Probe , currently in orbit around Jupiter -- does n't unleash a similar scourge upon the possible inhabitants of Europa , an icy Jupiter moon whose oceans may support living organisms .
" Over the past 15 years , ethical and philosophical papers have been published on the rights of alien beings , no matter how simple those beings , " wrote scientists at the National Research Council , in a recent research report examining the threat to life on Europa .
The report emphasizes " the need to encourage public discussion and dissemination of information concerning the steps taken to prevent planetary cross-contamination . "
In keeping with its report , last week the NRC sent a letter to NASA recommending that the Galileo craft be intentionally crashed into Jupiter before the probe runs out of fuel or fails .
The intentional crash would prevent a drifting Galileo from blundering into Europa , and possibly contaminate the moon with earthly organisms .
NASA had originally planned to let Galileo expire in orbit , but began considering the Jupiter-crash plan when it became clear that Galileo might collide with Europa if left adrift .
NASA solicited the NRC 's opinion on the matter .
Because Galileo was never intended to be a landing probe , it was not sterilized to prevent the accidental transport of " extremophiles , " tiny , prevalent organisms from Earth capable of surviving extreme heat , cold , pressure , or radiation .
Certain types of extremophiles that may be resident on Galileo could conceivably survive or even thrive on Europa .
But according to the NRC report , Jupiter can not support life , and would therefore be a more appropriate burial ground for Galileo .




A Quiet , Exhaust-Free Ferry

SYDNEY , Australia -- It looks like a houseboat with a metallic Mohawk haircut .
But it 's probably the world 's most non-polluting vessel .
A solar-and-wind-powered ferry now plying the waters of Sydney Harbor collects energy mostly through a series of tilting panels on its roof .
Pivoting like a mobile sculpture to capture the sun and wind , the panels power the ferry along .
" Sun and wind are two of the most abundant forces on Earth , " says Robert Dane , a New South Wales country doctor who dreamed up the vessel . "
Why not use them both ? "
Dane 's solar sailor is going into commercial service shortly for harbor sightseeing tours .
The 60-foot vessel carries 100 passengers and has a top speed of 12 knots .
Best of all , it 's quiet and does n't pollute -- eliminating the two most common complaints about traditional ferries , Dane says .
Dane hopes to replace the natural gas generator with a device manufacturing hydrogen from seawater that could feed a hydrogen engine , thus making the vessel completely dependent upon only renewable energy .
With patents now filed in the United States , Australia , New Zealand , and Turkey , Dane has given up delivering babies and taking temperatures , and is now courting municipalities , eco-tourism operators , and ferry companies with his invention .
With ever stricter environmental regulations going into effect -- especially in European waterways -- a reliable , renewable energy ferry should find a ready market for commuter transport .
That 's what Dane is banking on , anyway .
Dane believes his vessel could find a niche among recreational boaters , who now must constantly worry about where they can buy more marine fuel .
The boat also would be suitable for use in sensitive areas such as coral reefs and , because they 're so quiet , might even have military applications .
" It could serve as a patrol or reconnaissance vessel with unlimited range and complete stealth , " Dane said .
What 's more , he says , his boats are essentially mobile power plants and could be used to generate instantaneous power for places with devastated infrastructures, like East Timor .
Dane built the Sydney Harbor boat to show off his concept , and notes the technology is readily scalable .
That 's because unlike solar-powered cars -- where the weight of additional batteries rapidly offsets energy gains from additional solar panels -- the opposite principle is at work on the water .
" The bigger the boat , the better this works , " Dane said . "
In the case of boats , batteries provide welcome ballast .
Eventually , there 's no reason floating cities could n't be created adrift on the seas , garnering all their energy from the wind and sun . "
But that lies well over the horizon .
Right now , Dane is busy signing up sightseeing tours around Sydney Harbor .
He 'll then start focusing on the global market for environmentally sensitive boats .
One potential early market is San Francisco Bay , which Dane says is similar to Sydney Harbor : It 's sunny , windy , environmentally sensitive , and has lots of commuters .
Russell Long , executive director of the Bluewater Network , a clean waterways environmental group , agrees .
He believes the solar sailor would work well on busier S.F. Bay routes such as Sausalito , Tiburon , and Alcatraz .
In Sydney Harbor , Dane 's vessel makes two or three cruises daily on weekends .
And , with the Olympic Games approaching , it 's also available for charter , said Kim Styles , spokeswoman for Captain Cook Cruises , which is handling bookings .
Captain Cook itself operates eight old-fashioned , diesel-powered sightseeing boats on Sydney Harbor , which travel at average speeds of 9 knots .




From Old Big Blue to ASCI White

Dave Nichols , who worked the night shift at a check processing center at a Boston bank in the mid-1960s , laughs when an image of ASCI White -- IBM 's new supercomputer at Lawrence Livermore Lab -- is described to him .
Resembling row upon row of black refrigerators at a local Sears , the supercomputer -- which may perform an astonishing 12 trillion operations a second -- is eerily quiet .
The only sign of life is the gentle hum of hundreds of cooling fans .
Back when Nichols was paying his way through college by working with an IBM 1401 , the din of a typical computer room was much different .
The 1401 was Big Blue 's first all-transistor machine , one of the first to replace the vacuum-tube models of the previous era .
" The printers and check sorters would roar like machine guns all through the night , " he said . "
It was deafening .
If you stood next to them you could n't hear a thing in the morning .
" It was a very physical experience you do n't get today . "
Nichols had to load the machine 's operating system on giant trays of stacked punch cards , which he often managed to drop on the floor .
If the computer did n't work , he 'd kick it .
And he was always smoking .
" We used to smoke like bandits and we would be constantly dropping ash down into those computers , " he said . "
There was cigarette crud all over them . "
Nichols went on to sell mainframes for IBM in the early 1970s .
Stationed in New Mexico , he began wooing the Los Alamos National Laboratory as one his customers .
At the time , Los Alamos ran Cray supercomputers , but it eventually bought one of Nichols ' mainframes as the front end for a custom-built data storage center .
" It was a Rube Goldberg contraption , " he said . "
It was an incredible giant -- 50 feet long or more and 10 feet high .
It stored all the data for the lab on small film cartridges or something like that .
Whenever someone wanted something it would fetch them with an arm and open them up .
It was like a huge robot . "
Walter Donovan also recalls the early days of big iron .
Donovan was a college grad in the early 1960s when he went to work for the System Development Corporation , a private company funded by the U.S. Air Force to develop software for early air defense systems .
Based in Santa Monica , California , Donovan helped program an IBM Q7 vacuum-tube computer , constructed out of 30,000 glowing vacuum tubes .
Deployed in pairs to ensure a backup if one went down , the Q7s consumed three floors of the building where Donovan worked , one floor entirely devoted to air conditioners .
Every day , the 60,000 vacuum tubes and cooling equipment sucked down 10 percent of Santa Monica 's power , Donovan said , and were left on day and night for fear of causing destructive surges in the city 's power .
" Shutting it down was a big deal and would probably have caused a huge spike , " he said . "
We never did it . "
Despite its phenomenal size , the Q7 had a single CPU running at about 12 KHz -- that 's kilohertz , not megahertz -- and 64K of RAM .
Donovan was one of " hundreds " of programmers who coded the machines in assembly language , which were encoded on a long paper ticker tape .
But in many ways , the machine was surprisingly sophisticated .




Yahoo Has a Big Quarter

PALO ALTO , California -- Yahoo , the leading consumer Internet portal , reported unexpectedly sharp increases Tuesday in its second-quarter earnings and revenues and said it did not view the widespread troubles of other dot-com companies as a serious threat to its business .
The numbers and comments from company executives seemed to instantly revive investors ' faith in the company .
Yahoo 's shares , which had been drifting lower in recent days , shot up $ 15 a share in after-hours activity .
Prior to the release of earnings , Yahoo stock had lost 4-1/2 to close at 105-1/2 in daily trading .
YHOO
Yahoo said its pro forma net income , excluding certain unusual items , totaled $ 74 million , or 12 cents per diluted share in the second quarter , nearly triple the $ 27.1 million , or 5 cents per diluted share in the year-ago period .
The earnings exceeded the consensus analyst forecast for a profit of 10 cents per share .
Sales also surpassed most forecasts , totaling $ 270.1 million from $ 128.6 million the year before .
Page views , a key measure of traffic to Yahoo 's network of online properties , rose about 9 percent to an average 680 million per day in June , from 625 million in March .
Including all the unusual items , Yahoo reported net income of $ 65.5 million , or 11 cents per share in the quarter , compared with a loss of $ 263,000 , or break even per share last year .
Although the company emphasized its success in several areas , from building the international part of the business to adding more wireless services , the big issue on the minds of financial analysts was the stability of the company 's domestic advertising base .
A wave of dot-com failures in recent months has caused some big Internet companies like NBC Internet Inc. to lose valuable advertisers and concerns have been mounting that even Yahoo was not immune to the slowdown .




Student Entrepreneurs ' Go Global '

Silicon Valley is known worldwide for its startup mentality .
And a new international student competition is attempting to bring that mindset to the rest of the world .
Student teams from Australia to Singapore met last week for Stanford University 's Global Entrepreneurs Challenge to see how their business plans stacked up against those of their global competitors .
" The impetus was to get the brightest students from different countries to come here , immerse themselves in Silicon Valley culture , and hopefully take back what they 've learned to further their own entrepreneurship , " said Robert Koturbash , vice president of marketing for Stanford 's Business Association of Stanford Engineering Students .
Teams from 20 universities and 14 countries gathered for three days to compete before a panel of high-level Silicon Valley executives .
The lure ?
Prizes worth $ 250,000 and a chance to snare thousands of dollars in seed money .
But the Challenge is more than just an awards competition .
Top entrepreneurs , professors , venture capitalists , and management consultants shared their perspectives in clinics and workshops on topics ranging from how to negotiate a term sheet to marketing a venture to protecting intellectual property .
Delegates from winning student teams received guidance on turning their business plans into a real ventures .
On excursions to Silicon Valley startups , venture capital firms , and incubators , participants learned valuable lessons about launching startups and gained hands-on experience that will be applicable in their home countries .
" One of the key ways to develop an entrepreneurial culture is through these competitions locally , " said Koturbash , one of the founding organizers who foresees the Challenge becoming an annual event . "
By instilling entrepreneurship in undergraduate and graduate students , you plant a seed so that people realize these opportunities are available to them .
" By sponsoring these local competitions and helping to create companies , that creates a synergy so that far-out technical research gets commercialized by surrounding areas , " he said .
Student teams from the University of Sydney in Australia , the University of Buenos Aires in Argentina , MIT , and Stanford earned the top awards .




Old News , Different Stream

While big entertainment-content developers have faced major financial problems recently , Internet news organizations are hoping the Net holds a more promising future for them .
In just over a month , two high-profile sites -- DEN and Pseudo.com -- were faced with the financial realities of the current marketplace .
DEN was forced to shut its operations down after burning through its cash , while Pseudo.com has restructured its original business model into an interactive , streaming chat site .
Now , several new streaming media websites are hoping to avoid the same fate by melding offline news sensibilities with new distribution channels over the Internet .
" Entertainment websites are asking you to take time out from your day to watch a crummy presentation done on a low budget , " said Jonathan Klein , president and CEO of feedroom.com . "
But news is relevant and it comes naturally suited for the computer because the average package is about 90 seconds . "
Klein and his executives have their roots in the network television news business .
Klein and his chief technology officer Jay Fine both worked for CBS , while Feedroom 's vice president of business development , Matthew Shapiro , worked at NBC .
Launching in July , the company will repackage television news from around the country into one , giant newsfeed on the Web .
" There 's been a beta test going on for 50 years called the television that has told us that people like to get their information in pictures , " said Klein .
" When I was a TV executive at CBS and we launched a cable channel and success was defined as having an audience of 10 million .
There are 31 million broadband users right now .
Mainstream media executives who dismiss broadband do so out of ignorance .
It 's an immense audience that is growing wild in the next few years . "
To keep their broadcasts chock full of new content without spending millions of dollars developing original reporting , the company has struck up partnerships with 29 television stations , two major networks , USA Today , and the Reuters news service .
An anchor will come on at the top of the hour to update the latest news stories , but viewers are largely responsible for seeking out the video news they want by drilling down through the links on the site .
One advantage Klein sees of being an aggregator of news from around the world is the ability to package stories together so viewers can watch trends unfolding across the land .
Where local news coverage is limited by the scope of a city , Feedroom will package similar stories from around the nation into a series of stories .
" We 're going to be sitting on the biggest vat of video news , " Klein said . "
We do no original reporting , but ... being able to see news from all over the place will allow us to repackage stories into new and interesting ways that local news can not possible do .
This is news on an atomic level . "




Things to Watch for in 2020

SAN FRANCISCO -- At the fourth annual Next 20 Years series , a quartet of future-thinkers gathered at San Francisco 's Palace of Fine Arts to hand out visions of our techno-world come 2020 .
A few outtakes follow :
Way-new post-urbanism : Fifty years ago , tract homes , cheap cars , and gasoline shaped modern suburbia .
Now the Internet and advances in fuel cells and cheap bandwidth will sever the power line -- that last cable tethering workers to the city and the ' burbs .
Institute for the Future Director Paul Saffo predicted that consumers will be able to buy a washing-machine-sized device filled with petrochemicals that will produce electricity with only fresh water as the by-product .
The result is not as environmentally friendly as you might think .
" It 's going to mean a huge push into the ' exurbs , ' " Saffo said . "
It means any fool with a double-wide trailer and a satellite dish can tow it onto a piece of unoccupied land in the middle of the Nevada desert and have enough power to compute . "
That 's not necessarily going to translate into a better quality of life on Earth . "
My fear is that we will see the vast wasteland of suburbia replaced by the vaster wasteland of ' cyburbia , ' " Saffo concluded .
Tele-presence : Devices with sufficient sensory sophistication and massive information transmission power will give everyone the emotional experience of " being " anywhere .
Stanley Williams , director of the quantum structures research initiative at Hewlett-Packard Labs , expects football fans will be able to experience a game " from the standpoint of any of the players on the field , or the referees .
You could watch a drama or a comedy as some sort of disembodied spirit somewhere within the scene , or even from the perspective of one of the characters in the scene . "
Scientists will have their " Fantastic Voyages , " Williams said -- their experiences of traveling through the blood vessels of living organisms by transmitting information gathered by a remotely controlled sensor traveling through any body .
Browsable desktop economies : Napster heralds the true social power of the Net , as new economy guru and Benchmark Capital General Partner Bill Gurley sees it .
With every computer connected Napster-style -- a very different architecture from the server-client Web common today -- people will be able to log onto the Net and " play " the economy -- just as they play multi-user games and eBay auctions today .
" The economy is a game as well , " Gurley said . "
So all of a sudden -- with everyone connected to the Web and an easy way to transfer money , and the ability to compete for your time or expertise -- I think you 'll see a world evolve literally within the next 20 years very similar to what 's described in Neal Stephenson 's Snow Crash .
...
The notion that you might wake up one day , take a shower , walk into your office , put on a headphone , and sit down to a keyboard , and literally jack into an entire different economy is very possible . "
Big-lipped email attachments : And now for something a little more immediate : Within 10 years , you 'll be able to take the collected works of the Rolling Stones and attach it to an email , Gurley predicted .
With such huge attachments -- about as noticeable as Word attachments today -- the music industry is going to have to face up to the problems presented by technology , and soon .




The Year 2020 , Explained

SAN FRANCISCO -- Gadgetly speaking , the year 2020 is sure to be darned neat-o , but it will also be more than a little taxing on the human being .
" We will continue to live as we do today in an age of creative destruction -- technologically induced creative destruction , " said Paul Saffo , director of the Institute for the Future , where he studies long-term technology trends and their influences on society .
" The gales of creative destruction are blowing through every industry on the planet today , touched by the Internet and digital technology .
Biology is the next thing to come , " he said .
Saffo was among a quartet of future-thinkers gathered at San Francisco 's Palace of Fine Arts last week to offer their snapshots of the world come 2020 .
Such is the forward-looking purpose of the fourth annual Next Twenty Years discussion series .
The panel warned the future-wary that if the pace of change seems a nuisance now , you ai n't seen nothing yet .
To keep up , humans are going to have to figure out how to keep their education nearly constant , panelists warned -- and develop the wisdom to deal with a state of almost impossibly accelerated scientific advance .
The hardest trick could be to stay sane amid a snowstorm of paradigm shifts .
" People to learn throughout their lives is going to be absolutely crucial if we 're going to keep abreast of this -- and keep our mental health , " said Stanley Williams , director of the quantum structures research initiative at Hewlett-Packard Labs .
being able
Watch for struggles with human identity as machines on the other end of the phone acquire the thinking and responsive capacity of the human brain .
Be prepared for a time when your doctor will be able to map your personal genome as fast as he draws blood .
And as far as our darling computer is concerned -- well , you and your spanking new Pentium IV are n't so hot .
" I can safely say that the age of computing has n't even begun yet , " Williams said . "
We 're still playing around in essentially Stone Age times technologically . "
Williams sees pathways in quantum research that will overcome the current physical limits of silicon chips .
These paths will lead technology down a road where only the fundamental limits of electrons themselves will put a cap on information-processing capacity .
In 2020 , " our electronics will be 10,000 times as capable as they are today , " Williams said .
Overarching all this change will be the parallel progress of not one , but multiple industrial eras .
" At the beginning of this millennium , we 're actually watching the birth of three great new technologies , all simultaneously , " Williams said . "
Those technologies are biotechnology , information technology , and nanotechnology . "
Each technology alone would be classifiable as an industrial revolution .
But having all three progressing simultaneously -- sometimes competing , often complementing -- " it 's going to be completely beyond anything we 've ever experienced before , " Williams ventured .
As for the already-amazing here-and-now , it turns out we 're only now at the very end of the information science era -- not at the beginning of a new one .
Sage and cautionary futurist Saffo knows that to be true , because whenever he imagines the future , he simultaneously looks an equal distance back .
His vantage point shows that over the last 150 years , major new scientific disciplines take center stage every three to five decades , with each setting the stage for the innovation to follow .




Steroids Still Spoil Sports

Doping continues to be a hot topic around the world , beyond the controversy over androstenedione and the problem it presents for Major League Baseball .
The former boss of the East German sports machine , Manfred Ewald , and his medical director , Manfred Happner , are on trial for causing bodily harm to more than 100 former East German athletes who were given steroids and told they were " vitamins . "
It was in Ewald 's laboratories that andro , first isolated by European scientists in the 1930s , was developed in the late '80s as a so-called bridging drug to tide over East German athletes when they had to ease off their usual regimen of steroids prior to being tested at competitions .
" It 's not important that you can say Ewald must go to jail for a month or whatever , " former discus-thrower Brigitte Michel said . "
What 's important is that there is a process that will make this public .
For me that 's very personal .
" It is important to teach people how to think about steroids and their dangers .
In all the disciplines of sports , you need power and energy .
But steroids are a time bomb .
They are always dangerous .
I would tell athletes around the world , ' Keep yourself off steroids .
' I hope they pay attention . "
The trial has taken a dramatic twist .
The court has concluded that the two former East German functionaries are culpable , but the question of sentencing remains open .
Early last week , senior public prosecutor Klaus-Heinrich Debes argued for a suspended two-year prison sentence .
But on Friday , another prosecutor involved with the case argued for a minimum of three years for Ewald and 2-1/2 for Happner .
Last month , the United States Olympic Committee 's top drug-testing official , Dr. Wade Exum , resigned in protest .
He charged the USOC both with racism and with " deliberately encouraging the doping of athletes without considering the consequences to the health . "
International Olympic Committee Patrick Schamasch said Friday that he could not comment specifically on Exum 's allegations , but that he knew him to be a good man .
" I 've known Wade for a long time , and I know he was fighting on his own and doing a good job , " he said . "
For a long time he was really the lone voice in the United States . "

Oracle Shares Keep Sliding Down

SAN FRANCISCO -- Shares of Oracle tumbled for a second session running on Wednesday amid lingering concerns over the departure of the software company 's highly regarded No. 2 executive and fresh profit warnings by other technology companies .
The stock 's two-day loss reached 14 percent after bearish earnings forecasts by BMC Software and Computer Associates International(CA) , as well as a negative report on Oracle , the leading maker of database software , issued by an influential broker .
BMCS
The stock -- which has risen four-fold over the past year with almost no pullback -- was also seen as a prime candidate for profit-taking .
Oracle , the world 's No. 2 software maker , topped the list of most active issues on Nasdaq in afternoon trading , falling 7-7/16 to 72-3/4 on volume of nearly 40 million shares .
ORCL
On Monday , Oracle stock lost 3-7/8 to 80-3/16 .
The market was closed on Tuesday for the U.S. Independence Day holiday .
The resignation of Ray Lane as Oracle 's president and chief operating officer , announced on Friday , came in the immediate aftermath of the embarrassing disclosure that private investigators paid by Oracle rummaged through the trash bins of lobbyists who support its archrival , Microsoft .
MSFT
" There 's a lot on the worry list today for Oracle , " said Bob Austrian of Banc of America Securities , " whether it 's dumpster diving or Lane 's departure .
But there 's more sensationalism here than there is any real business impact . "
Most analysts saw the loss of Lane as likely to create a void at Oracle , as he was viewed as providing a calm and steady balance for Oracle 's volatile chief , Larry Ellison .
On Wednesday , J.P. Morgan analyst William Epifanio cut his rating on Oracle stock to " market performer " from " buy , " calling Lane 's departure as " extremely negative " news for the company .
Oracle said late Friday that Lane , long rumored to be on the verge of leaving the database software giant , would step down , although he will remain on the company 's board of directors .
Oracle later said Ellison , now chairman and chief executive , would assume the duties of president and chief operating officer after Lane 's departure .
Epifanio also said he believed Oracle 's big earnings gains were behind it and that the stock was expensive , trading at 88 times estimated fiscal 2001 earnings , and 73 times 2002 earnings .
Still , Credit Suisse First Boston reiterated a " strong buy " on Oracle , citing cautious optimism that Lane 's departure was not likely to create a meaningful disruption .
" The timing is unsettling , " said Austrian of Banc of America Securities . "
The company is on the verge of enjoying some of the most unique prosperity in its history .
He 's been a great contributor .
But it 's not a really big issue .
They have a great management team . "
Lane , who joined Oracle eight years ago from consulting company Booz Allen & Hamilton , is widely credited with helping Oracle modify aggressive sales and accounting practices in the early 1990s that dragged down its stock price .
Ellison , who founded Oracle in 1977 , has been responsible for Oracle 's overall strategic direction , but Lane had been lauded by Wall Street analysts for restoring Oracle 's credibility with the investment community .




Dreamworks Launches A&R.com

Dream Weaver : Following in the footsteps of farmclub.com , Dreamworks Records launched an A&R website that allows bands to upload songs directly to the record company .
While the website does n't promise to streamline the signing process , A&R executive Luke Wood said this opens up opportunities for bands to be discovered .
" In the record business , we do n't normally take unsolicited music , " Wood said . "
Traditionally , labels have n't accepted music that did n't come from an agent or manager . "
Bands located outside big cities will now have a greater opportunity to compete for recording contracts as well , although the odds are still stacked against them .
" Much of the recording industry has been regionalized so that big city bands always had an advantage , " Wood said . "
With this , small town bands now have a chance to be heard .
We 're saying now that the doors are open , but not wide open . "
Bands can submit one song every three months to the site .
If the tune happens to catch the fancy of one of the execs , the band then enters the same old A&R pipeline .
But even if a band does n't get picked up by the label , Wood said he hopes to develop other avenues for bands unsuitable for Dreamworks .
" Ultimately , we are going to have unsigned streaming radio , taking the best music that we get and putting that into a channel , " he said . "
I see this site as a significant step in the direction . "
While Wood emphasized that this venture was drastically different than Universal 's farmclub.com site , they have taken one lesson to heart .
" This is a non-exclusive agreement , " Wood said , referring to who owns the rights to songs uploaded to the site . "
We do n't own anything . "

Canada Takes DNA Database Lead

OTTAWA -- Canada unveiled on Wednesday what it said was the world 's most sophisticated DNA database , capable of identifying criminals through analysis of minute amounts of blood , semen , or skin cells .
The DNA Data Bank will include samples of DNA -- the unique building blocks of every living thing -- from young offenders as well as adults who are convicted of serious crimes .
It will also include DNA taken from crime scenes .
DNA databases already exist in the United States , Germany , Britain , Norway , Finland , Belgium , and Denmark .
But Canadian officials said the new C$10 million database , located at the Royal Canadian Mounted Police headquarters in Ottawa , was the most automated and sophisticated of its kind .
" I would think that Canada stands on firm ground as being one of the forerunners in this technology and certainly we 've done a great deal to improve the speed of the analysis , " said Dr. Ron Fourney , who is in charge of the database .
" The innovations we 've developed that make it unique will be the robotics and certainly the cost effectiveness , " he told a news conference at the official launch .
Solicitor-General Lawrence MacAuley , the minister in overall charge of Canada 's law enforcement agencies , said the database was a powerful tool that would change the way in which police conducted many criminal investigations .
" It will help solve serious crimes more quickly and assist in identifying repeat offenders more effectively and with more certainty .
It will help police to focus their resources on key suspects by excluding the innocent more quickly , " he said .
The Mounties have been using DNA analysis since 1989 and the new database marks a major step forward in the fight against violent , sexual and repeat offenders , who will be required to give blood samples .
The database -- will cost C$5 million a year to run -- takes five days to process a single sample .
Police estimate some 30,000 samples from known serious offenders , suspected criminals , and crime scenes will be processed a year .
" When we started 10 years we might have needed a biological sample which was the size of a penny .
ago
Today 's technology is so revolutionary that 10 percent of what would fit on the head of a pin is all we 'd need to do a case , " Fourney said .
Officials stressed that to protect the right to privacy , stringent safeguards had been built into the system to ensure suspects ' names did not appear on the DNA samples .
Fourney said Canada was negotiating with other nations that possess DNA databanks to set up a system whereby genetic information can be exchanged .
Samples from convicted criminals will be kept permanently on file so that they can be processed again once more advanced technology becomes available .
" I think the DNA Data Bank will be as revolutionary a tool for law enforcement today as fingerprinting was when it was first introduced 100 years ago , " said Superintendent Lee Fraser , manager of Canada 's Forensic Identification Service .
" Our goal is to catch criminals and in the game of crime , knowing who the bad guys are , being able to single them out and linking them irrefutably to their crimes is a very important tool , " he told the news conference .




No More Cold Doctor Hands

When a doctor performs an abdominal examination on a patient , she often has to rely on her hands to do much of the guesswork , pushing and probing and ferreting out bumps and lumps .
Tender livers , pea-size tumors , and swollen spleens are often diagnosed this way , and followed up with high-resolution scans that take precise recordings of the size and location of those bumps and lumps .
This meshing of touch and technology does n't work so well , however , for folks who live in remote locations where there are no MRIs .
Rural patients often find themselves traveling long distances for tests and pictures .
But a new virtual reality glove being developed by researchers at the State University of New York at Buffalo promises to change that .
Thenkurussi Kesavadas , director of the university 's Virtual Reality Lab and principal investigator on the project , said the glove -- equipped with tiny sensors in the fingertips -- will truly allow sensations of pressure to be transmitted to another person .
Here 's how it works : A doctor , wearing the glove , examines a patient .
The data from the exam is stored in a computer system , where it will remain until it is transmitted to a second doctor who needs to access that data .
The information will be transmitted to the second doctor through a haptic feedback device , a small , transportable robot that fits on a user 's hand like a thimble .
The robot allows a user to manipulate an image on a computer screen and feel the physical results of that virtual manipulation .
" He pokes there and he would feel in his finger that he 's actually touching it , " Kesavadas said .
at the computer screen with the pointer
In short , the glove means a patient and his doctor will n't necessarily have to be in the same room , or even in the same state .
The glove is expected to create a big stir in the medical world .
" From a medical standpoint , it 's important for a number of reasons , " said James Mayrose , assistant professor at University of Buffalo 's department of emergency medicine and one of the glove 's designers .
He said the glove has important teaching implications , and could drastically improve the way a new doctor learns how to palpate a patient .
The glove system is based on the National Institutes of Health 's Visible Human Project , a detailed , three-dimensional representation of the complete male and female human bodies initially envisioned as a high-tech teaching tool .
But the Visible Human Project is strictly a visual aid , a digital cadaver of sorts .
The glove is different .
" To teach medical students what to feel and what to look for when they palpate is very difficult , " he said . " tells us how much force is being applied , and the direction to which the force is being applied . "
The glove
Researchers expect the glove , which is being tested in a clinical study with human subjects at Erie County Medical Center , will be available for use within two years .
Mayrose said he expects some initial hesitance from doctors who might think they 're being replaced by a fancy glove .
But he insists that 's not the case .
" With the glove , the physician does n't lose their sense of touch .
We want to enhance it , not replace it , " he said .
The new glove will be officially announced at the World Congress on Medical Physics and Biomedical Engineering in Chicago next month .

SAO PAULO , Brazil -- A Brazilian city has decided it is time to gag those who gab on mobile phones in public places where concentration is prized .
Residents of the thriving city of Campinas will be yanked out of their movie seats , escorted out of libraries , or barred from classrooms if their cellular telephones ring , a local legislator said on Wednesday .

Failure to post the warning will incur a fine of 425 reais , according to a law that went into effect last week .
US$ 236
" People who can n't manage to switch off from the world for just two hours deserve our pity , " said Luis Yabiku , a sponsor of the law and a councilman in the city of 1 million , located 60 miles from Sao Paulo .
" I do n't have anything against cellphones but we have to educate people in their proper use , " said Yabiku , who wants to promote similar legislation nationwide amid an explosion in Brazil 's mobile phone market that pits tranquillity-seekers against communication addicts .
The number of cellular phones in Brazil is forecast to almost quadruple in three years to 58 million -- one phone for every three Brazilians .

Virgin Atlantic said on Thursday it had become the first airline to allow passengers to receive phone calls to their mobile phone numbers while in flight .

Verio Stock Slides on WSJ Report

Can the FBI put a wiretap on a Japanese phone line , or intercept emails scuttling about a Japanese ISP 's backbone ?
Presumably no , at least not without first getting permission from the Japanese government .
In the U.S. , of course , the FBI taps wires and snares emails all the time , but its jurisdiction to do so stops at the border .
But what if a Japanese company buys a U.S. Net-services provider ?
Will that Japanese-owned service provider continue to give the feds free reign to listen in ?
The FBI apparently is n't so sure .
According to a report in the Wall Street Journal , the FBI has told the U.S. Treasury Department it has " national security concerns " about the proposed sale of American ISP Verio to NTT , Japan 's dominant telco .
In response , the Treasury Department 's Committee on Foreign Investment has begun a 45-day review of the planned sale .
NTT confirmed the committee review last week , but says it fully intends to comply with all U.S. laws and expects no snags in the review .
Nonetheless , the news is putting a dent on Verio 's stock price , which has fallen almost 10 percent since the news of the Treasury review first surfaced last week .
It fell $ 1.60 , or 3 percent , Thursday to close at $ 54.50 , well below NTT 's $60-per share cash offer .
While the FBI has voiced concerns about the acquisition of U.S. telcos by foreign companies before , it 's never thrown the flag on a Net deal .
And the timing of its objection to the NTT/Verio tie-up has some experts wondering if the agency is helping the Clinton administration play trade-policy politics .
Washington and Toyko have been in a pitched trade battle in recent months over the fees charged by NTT , Japan 's former state phone monopoly , for allowing other carriers to connect to its nationwide local phone network .
The Clinton administration has demanded that NTT lower the fees .
NTT has n't budged .
But it might budge if the U.S. waves around the threat of scotching the Japanese firm 's $ 5.5 billion bid for Verio , said some professional stock traders .
" It 's a political lever the government is sort of groping at , " said one professional stock arbitrageur .
Still , other experts believe the FBI 's concerns are heartfelt .
The FBI 's biggest fear , the Journal reported , is that NTT might move Verio 's Net traffic offshore and out of U.S. jurisdiction .
The FBI wants U.S. Net traffic to go over U.S.-owned , and therefore easily tapped , wires .
" There 's a debate in the community as far as how much of this is based on the trade dispute versus legitimate FBI concerns , " one professional arbitrageur said . "
arbitrageur
We happen to be of the camp that there 's an element of both , but mostly that there are valid concerns by the FBI , " he said .
Reuters contributed to this report .




It Pays to Cheat , Not Surf

With the proliferation of " pay-to-surf " sites comes a growing number of users who are cheating the system .
At last count , there were over 50 pay-to-surf sites on the Internet -- and with it are numerous opportunities for Web swindlers .
Any popular search engine can help aspiring cheaters find a plethora of available programs for " P2S " websites .
In a matter of minutes , cheaters can find and install a program that will allow them to bypass the ad viewbars and other features mandated by the sites .
One experienced cheater first started using the programs in March 1999 and says he makes a few hundred dollars each month by cheating .
" There 's literally no limit to how much you can earn , " said the hacker , who goes by the alias " Spike . "
" If you max out one of the accounts you have , you just create another and refer another account to your main account .
Then you get double the money plus a little extra for the referral . "
The majority of P2S companies work through a viewbar on the surfer 's desktop .
When activated , the viewbar tracks sites visited on the Web in addition to displaying ads based on online activity .
Users are paid on a per-hour basis and can make more money if they refer others to the site .
Cheaters generally target newer P2S companies that are more likely to have weaker security .
The cheat programs are relatively simple ; most of them merely cycle through websites or move the mouse -- making it appear as if the user is actively surfing .
A basic knowledge of Delphi or Visual Basic is all that 's required to write up one of these programs , said one hacker .
" Moving a mouse -- or telling the browser to surf to another page -- is not really a hard job to do , " said " TFR , " a hacker affiliated with the United Hackers Association . "
Programs that have more features are mostly coded by people with good programming skills . "
A number of websites have sprung up in response to the growing digital chicanery .
AllAdvantageCheats allows surfers to get the latest updates for utilities that allow them to bypass many of the features for AllAdvantage , the seminal P2S website .
In addition , there are several forums for newbie cheaters to obtain information .
One bulletin board catering to cheaters boasts over 3,000 members where users can get the latest updates for cheat software and swap advice and tips .
Richard Kahn , CEO of PaidForSurf.com , said that his company deletes around 100 cheat accounts daily .
" are responsible for a good amount of money coming out of the program , about 40 percent , " he said . "
Cheaters
They are lowering the payout for other users . "
Kahn said his company recently installed filters that will catch 90 percent of all cheaters .
" These people are hurting our industry as a whole .
Advertisers pick up on and they do n't want to advertise with them , " said Kahn . "
vulnerable companies
If there are any pay-to-surf companies that want to be here for more than six months , they have to find a way to get around the cheaters on the network . "
In addition , Kahn said that his company is working with the FBI in catching cheaters and is building a database of names , email , and mailing addresses , in addition to IP addresses .




' Carnivore ' Eats Your Privacy

WASHINGTON -- An FBI surveillance system called Carnivore is alarming privacy advocates and some members of Congress .
Agents typically install the specialized computer on the networks of Internet providers , where it intercepts all communications and records sent to or from the target of an investigation , the Wall Street Journal reported on Tuesday .
An FBI spokesman told the paper that the agency typically has about 20 Carnivore computers on hand to use when conducting Internet monitoring in compliance with court orders .
But some critics say the practice of intercepting the network traffic of all users , even for a brief period of time , could run afoul of federal privacy laws and even the U.S. Constitution 's prohibition on unreasonable searches and seizure .
" It 's the electronic equivalent of listening to everybody 's phone calls to see if it 's the phone call you should be monitoring .
You develop a tremendous amount of information , " Mark Rasch , a former federal prosecutor , told the Journal .
Representative Bob Barr , a conservative privacy advocate , said , " If there 's one word I would use to describe this , it would be ' frightening .
R-Ga .
' "
Not all Internet service providers seem to like the idea of a government computer silently recording their network traffic , especially since Carnivore systems are typically kept in locked boxes , and at least one company is challenging the practice in court .
The FBI reportedly dubbed the system " Carnivore " because it has the ability to get at the " meat " of interesting or suspicious communications .
The FBI says such automated monitoring is necessary to perform surveillance on packet-switched networks , and successfully persuaded Congress in 1994 to require telephone companies to make their digital networks readily snoopable .
The bulk of legal wiretaps are used to investigate drug-related crimes , according to annual statistics published by the U.S. federal court system .
FBI Director Louis Freeh has in the past pressed for limits on what encryption technology Americans may use , and the FBI last year unsuccessfully asked the Internet Engineering Task Force to build support for wiretaps into network protocols .




Nuke Cleanup a Chernobyl Effort

BERLIN -- Forty countries have pledged $ 370 million to clean up the Chernobyl nuclear reactor , which killed an estimated 30,000 people during the world 's worst nuclear disaster in 1986 .
In return , the Ukraine has promised to shut down the entire Chernobyl plant .
The announcement came Wednesday after a two-day pledging conference in Berlin , co-chaired by German Foreign Minister Joschka Fischer and Ukrainian Prime Minister Viktor Yushchenko .
It brings to $ 715 million the Chernobyl Shelter Fund pledged by international governments and the European Union for urgent repairs to the concrete structure covering Chernobyl 's ruined fourth reactor .
The potential danger of the fourth reactor persists because of the highly radioactive material contained under the existing facility .
Water is thought to be penetrating through many leaks and there are thought to be high risks of radioactive dust escaping into the surrounding atmosphere and of highly contaminated water seeping into the national water supply .
The total pledge announced Wednesday includes the equivalent to $ 152 million by the European Commission , the executive branch of the 15-nation European Union .
The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development set up the Chernobyl Shelter Fund to pay for the Shelter Implementation Plan , which was adopted by the Ukraine and the Group of Seven industrialized nations in 1997 .
An international team of experts developed the plan in an effort to make the structure safe .
The Chernobyl explosion was caused by a combination of human and design failures .
A substantial portion of fission waste and fuel in the reactor core was released directly to the environment .
Workers at the power plant , 120 kilometers north of Kiev , were carrying out an experiment with its safety system when the accident blew the roof off the reactor building .
75 miles
Chernobyl 's second reactor was closed in 1991 after a fire and its first reactor was closed in 1996 after pressure from the G7 nations .
Last month , Ukraine 's President Leonid Kuchma said Chernobyl 's third reactor will close in December .
Repairs to the Soviet-built reactor cover , due to be completed in 2005 , are expected to ensure Chernobyl 's safety for another 50 to 100 years .
Long-term safety plans include constructing a hermetically sealed dome over the existing plant , or more ambitiously , removing the radioactive debris and returning Chernobyl to a green field site .
As well as paying for repairs , the shelter project will fund projects to study , assess , and mitigate the consequences of the Chernobyl accident .
Money will also be used to help decommission the remaining Chernobyl reactors , to address the social and regional consequences of Chernobyl 's closure , and to support power sector reform , including non-nuclear energy projects in Ukraine .
The Ukrainian government currently expends nearly 12 percent of its national budget on dealing with the consequences of the Chernobyl accident .
