Protesting Gene-Altered Animals

Violence broke out this week during a demonstration outside an animal genetics conference in Minneapolis , prompted by worries over genetically modified animals .
Demonstrators outside the annual International Society for Animal Genetics conference in Minneapolis , Minnesota , reportedly rolled canisters of cyanide toward police trying to control the crowd .
ISAG
The protestors also hurled rocks and allegedly sprayed tear gas at police .
Police retaliated by using pepper spray and batons against the crowd .
No major injuries were reported , but 71 people were arrested for unlawful assembly , disorderly conduct , assault on a police horse , and assault on a police officer , said police spokeswoman Cyndi Montgomery .
The crowd was protesting the prospect of genetically modified animals -- animals altered genetically to , for example , yield more meat or ward off disease .
" People are worried engineer cows , horses , and sheep , like people have engineered tomatoes , corn , and wheat plants , " said Joseph Nadeau , a professor of genetics at Case Western Reserve University in Cleveland , Ohio . "
that scientists will
All of the concerns about genetically modified food apply also to animals . "
ISAG shares information on genome studies of various animals .
One focus of the group is so-called " comparative genomics . "
By mapping the genome of various organisms , scientists can compare them to humans to learn about the function of human genes .
But activists are worried that the genetic engineering of animals could endanger biodiversity and delicate ecosystems .
In a statement , a group referring to itself as the " ISAG Welcoming Committee " called genetic engineering " runaway science ... that threatens our most basic humanity . "
A phone number listed on the statement from the welcoming committee was no longer in service .
The welcoming committee statement also denied that anyone in the crowd deployed tear gas , calling the accusation " a lame attempt to defame us , " and a " police-media smear job . "
In an attempt to avoid violence , police had erected concrete barriers and steel fences around the downtown hotel where about 650 scientists were meeting through Wednesday .
Police said they designated two areas that the demonstrators were free to gather in , but the group wanted to march .
Police conceded to a specified route for a march , but about a half mile before the end of the designated course , some of the protestors broke away and chaos broke out .
" We had tried to work with protestors on demonstrating their cause , " police spokeswoman Montgomery said . "
We support everyone 's right to free assembly and free speech . "
The Associated Press reported that one protestor thought the police were unduly violent in their response .
The police said they felt compelled to react as they did when the demonstrators threw rocks and sprayed gas .
And with the discovery of cyanide at the protest cite , the police felt justified in their actions .
" That 's serious , can be deadly , and Minneapolis police are there to protect the citizens , " Montgomery said .
cyanide
The FBI has taken over the investigation of the cyanide canisters .
Nadeau said he thinks that more and more , genetics conference organizers should be ready for demonstrations .
At a recent Human Genome Project conference in Germany , he said , peaceful protestors gathered bearing signs that read " Stop ! " and " Do you know what you 're doing ? "
" I suspect this is going to be more and more common as people begin to believe will influence their lives . "
genetic research




Amazon.com Shakeup Downplayed

SEATTLE -- Amazon.com went all out to reassure its employees and the investment community that the departure of Joseph Galli from the top ranks of the company would not affect the Internet retailer 's bottom line .
Despite reassurances from both Galli and Amazon 's founder and CEO Jeff Bezos that the move was strictly personal , the stock 's price fell on the news that the former Black & Decker executive was heading east .
Meanwhile , more ominous developments hit the high-profile e-tailer on Wednesday , with the site going down temporarily during the morning .
Amazon.com was back in operation as of 11:15 a.m. PDT .
Galli appeared on cable news shows throughout Tuesday , saying that his reason for the move was to be closer to his family , rather than because of any friction with Bezos .
Galli will head up VerticalNet , a business-to-business portal near Philadelphia .
Galli 's family , including two small children , remained in Baltimore for the past year while he worked at Amazon 's Seattle headquarters .
" I want you to know this is a peaceful parting , I 'll tell you that I served as Joe 's top reference , " Bezos wrote in e-mail to company employees following the announcement . "
Joe is a talented executive who really helped us over the last year .
I would ask all of you to join me in wishing him the very , very best . "
Amazon spokeswoman Patty Smith said the issue " came down to a geographical challenge for Joe . "
" He thought he could make it work , going back there every weekend and it just was n't working to his satisfaction , " Smith said .
She said Bezos will resume the position of president , which he held before hiring Galli , and that the company does not expect to be looking for a replacement in the near future .
Several news reports published since the announcement quoted friends who said Galli was also unhappy with Bezos 's laid-back West Coast approach to running the business .
The Wall Street Journal reported that Galli would give up a $ 3 million bonus from Amazon to take on the CEO position at VerticalNet for an estimated $25-million compensation package .
Wall Street 's reaction to the news was mixed , with most analysts willing to accept the story of Galli 's friendly departure at face value .
Nonetheless , the stock 's price tumbled both Tuesday and Wednesday on expectations that the heavily indebted company would announce further losses for the second quarter .
Amazon 's price sank 2-9/16 points to 35-1/16 in early trading Wednesday , after losing 1-1/8 points on Tuesday .
" Amazon 's down based on valuation , not because of , " said Steve Farley , a broker with Dean Rauscher in Seattle .
Galli
" When senior management leaves any company , especially Amazon , your lights go on because that 's a big sign , that they have to replace a big person , especially an emerging company like Amazon who needs to show a profit or they 're in serious trouble , " Farley said . "
On the outside , sure it 's bad , but when you dig deep , if he 's going because of his family and not because of the compensation , that 's not a big deal . "
While Galli may not be leaving for compensation , VerticalNet 's option offer , which promises Galli shares below market value , has to look attractive compared to his Amazon option package .
While Galli has vested options to buy 140,000 Amazon shares -- and unvested options on 3.7 million more -- his exercise price on those shares is $ 57.95 , more than $ 20 higher than Amazon 's current share value .
Tim Albright , an Internet and high-tech analyst for Salomon Smith Barney , said investors would make their decisions based on Wednesday 's quarterly earnings report .
He predicted that the stock was likely to rebound if the company could report less of a loss than expected by at least three cents a share .
" While Galli was a talented COO we do not believe he was irreplaceable , " Albright said in a prepared statement . "
The management bench at Amazon is certainly sufficiently deep to weather his loss until a replacement is found . "




Ireland 's ' Mad ' New Media Lab

DUBLIN -- Bono might have told MIT Media Lab Director Nicholas Negroponte this week that " the Irish were Italians who could n't dance , " but they were certainly ready to celebrate at the launch Monday and Tuesday of Media Lab Europe .
MLE is the new , 150 million pound , Dublin-based independent arm of the Media Lab whose doors will open to students in September .
Along with a kickoff reception and dinner in the MLE 's refurbished premises in a former Guinness brewery warehouse -- at which wine was the only alcohol served -- an select 300 attended a two-day symposium presented by a dozen Media Lab researchers .
Negroponte headed the event , which numbered artificial intelligence pioneers Marvin Minsky and Seymour Papert among its speakers .
Negroponte said MLE would strive to be as productively " chaotic " as the Media Lab itself , with a particular emphasis on the arts and education .
The lab is " an intellectually different environment , " and MIT chose to locate MLE in Ireland because he felt those unusual strengths would be valued there . "
Ireland is a country that has a great respect for madness , " he quipped .
Certainly , the audience of academics , artists , students , technologists , corporate donors , and prospective donors seemed unfazed by a string of unorthodox projects with titles like Lifelong Kindergarten , Opera of the Future , Personal Information Architecture , Nanoscale Sensing , and Machine Listening .
And no one tittered at discovering that some eminent researchers hold titles such as the Toshiba Professor of Media , Arts and Sciences , or Lego Professor of Learning Research .
They were told about Media Lab experiments such as micro machines that can be printed out by an inkjet printer , a sensor chair in which people can make music by waving their arms about , interactive cinema , electronic ink , a silicon pen tip that draws lines a single atom wide , speakers that emit a laser-like stream of " ultrasound " that gets louder as you move away , and all sorts of other objects that think , thanks to the merging of bits and atoms , machine and body .
Playfulness in particular is central to the Media Lab approach , said many of the researchers . "
When you play , you 're never more creative , " said researcher Michael Hawley , who specializes in interactive toys . "
A toy is a tool for making your imagination real . "
MLE 's focus on arts is apparent in two of its first faculty members .
Glorianna Davenport specializes in interactive cinema and new forms of narrative , while Tod Machover is the wildly inventive music and technology specialist behind the Brain Opera , a large scale " interactive music experience " .
Both say that while the Media Lab has always fused art and technology , it also tends to emphasize the technology behind the work rather than the piece of art itself .
They believe MLE is well positioned to tap into Europe 's deep artistic culture and create a research environment where art can take center stage .
" MLE is new .
It 's a new space , a new context , a new set of people , " Davenport said .
Machover said he felt Ireland had little of the artistic bureaucracy and hierarchy that can hinder artistic productivity in other European states . "
It definitely has an openness of spirit , " he said .
The center will rotate faculty and bring in outside faculty from Ireland and across Europe .
Students will be selected globally , with the majority coming from European states .
MLE will eventually take over a second , neighboring warehouse and transform it into a performance space , Machover said .
Both he and Davenport say they are particularly interested in inventing new , large-scale formats for performance , a futuristic , technology-infused version of narrative or of opera which goes beyond the boundaries of those genres . "
We have to think bold , " Machover said .




Why Music Trading Will n't Die

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Amid the howls of protest and shouts of glee over Wednesday 's court order forcing Napster to shut down its file-sharing application , some members of the open-source software community are quietly discussing the possibility that Napster 's loss in court may not be such a bad thing .
" Shutting Napster down will n't stop file exchanges , " said Joseph Valliente , an open-source software developer . "
But what it may do is drive people to the many open-source alternatives that are out there .
" And maybe , just maybe , they 'll take a closer look at what open-source standards offer to all of us while they 're downloading their tunes . "
Two of the programs that most MP3-seeking surfers will now turn to , Gnutella and Freenet , are both based on open-source or free-software standards which stipulate sharing of information and decentralized control over that information .
Both allow users to send and receive all kinds of files without going through a central , single server .
Once a file is " set free " onto open servers , it is nearly impossible for anyone to stop anyone else from downloading it .
" You 'd have to shut down the Internet to stop Gnutella or Freenet , " said " Pheron , " a Linux developer . "
There 's no main artery for the suits to tie off that can stop the flow of information in a truly open system . "
Scour , the other likely alternative to Napster , is " closed source " and already faces its own day in court .
Many advocates of Gnutella and other open-source file-transfer programs believe that these applications have n't been widely adopted because people find them hard to use .
Freenet , for example , is n't searchable in the same way that Napster is .
" And that 's a feature , not a bug , " said " Swine1 , " a Freenet user . "
It keeps people from easily finding where something is stored on the network , so they can n't tell you to remove it .
Instead , you have to find things by using ' keys .
' You do this by telling someone what key you 're using , making an educated guess , or checking out key indexes .




Microsof Loses Case
No Typo

GENEVA -- Microsoft will be allowed to evict the holder of the Internet address microsof.com , the U.N. 's anti-cybersquatting board said on Thursday .
It is the software giant 's second victory in such a case .
Microsoft filed a complaint in June at the Geneva-based World Intellectual Property Organization against Tarek Ahmed , of Brooklyn , New York , who was the first to register the address as an Internet domain , a WIPO statement said .
WIPO
In ruling for Microsoft , the U.N. agency said Ahmed had registered the Internet address in bad faith .
WIPO runs an arbitration system that evicts cybersquatters -- Internet users who register famous names in the hope of making an easy profit .
A WIPO panel also ruled that the domain name was confusingly similar to the trademark already owned by Microsoft and that its owner had no legitimate interest in the Internet address .
" The respondent ... has engaged in abusive registration of the domain name ' microsof.com ' .
The panel orders that the domain name ' microsof.com ' be transferred to the complainant , Microsoft Corporation , " the panel ruled .
As the meteoric rise of the Internet has made domain names more valuable , the current first-come , first-served system has created a market for opportunists to grab Net addresses .
But the fast-track arbitration system of WIPO , the specialized U.N. copyright and intellectual property agency , allows firms and individuals to avoid costly lawsuits in pursuing squatters when mischief is the obvious motive or serious money is at stake .
Companies that have won back their names from alleged cybersquatters through WIPO so far include Christian Dior , Deutsche Bank , Microsoft , and Nike .
Hollywood 's highest-paid actress , Julia Roberts , evicted a New Jersey man who had registered juliaroberts.com as an Internet domain after filing a complain with WIPO .
But WIPO also said on Thursday it had ruled that British pop star Sting had failed in his bid to evict the holder of sting.com , saying among other things that sting was a common English word and the star had not provided evidence he had registered the name as a trademark .
Microsoft , owner of the domain names microsoft.com and microsoft.net , won in April a case against an individual residing in Arizona who had been the first to register the address microsoft.org .
In the latest case , WIPO said the holder of the microsof.com page prominently displayed the images of two Microsoft software boxes with the pitch : " We offer a wide variety of software , hardware and valuable services to help your business grow . "
Microsoft first asked the holder of the page to transfer the address , saying the name was confusingly similar to its own .
But WIPO said that Ahmed refused , telling Microsoft 's representatives in an e-mail : " I am a user and developer of Microsoft products .
I am right now seeking funding for a development project that ... will definitely enhance Microsoft 's customer relations . "
He also turned down an offer by the company to reimburse him for the registration fees he had paid for the address , saying : " ... you should contact Microsoft and tell them my situation and return with a much better offer . "
about
The respondent , according to WIPO , later complained on his website : " Microsoft is trying to rob me .
This is not (a) Microsoft.com site .
All I did was sell products and support Microsoft products .
Now they want to take away my domain name .
What happened to free trade ? "




A Wheelchair for the World

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Where do you want to go today ?
If you 're a wheelchair user , the 200-year-old technology that you sit in may not be able to take you there .
Wheelchairs are notoriously lousy at moving people over anything more than perfectly smooth and flat ground .
But a new high-tech transport device is set to change that .
The Independence 3000 IBot Transporter , demonstrated Wednesday in the Senate and at Vice President Al Gore 's home , uses computers to conquer the accessibility problem .
The IBot can roll smoothly on four wheels or two wheels .
In the two-wheel position , the user can be raised to the same eye-level as he or she would be in when standing .
It uses on-board sensors and gyroscopes that allow it to automatically readjust itself to changes in the terrain and its user 's center of gravity .
When confronted with an activity that requires a change in its current settings , the IBot polls its internal computer and sensors , which " vote " on the correct action to take depending on the data it has gathered and its user 's commands .
This built-in intelligence allows the IBot to perform actions such as rotating and realigning its wheelbase itself into " feet " -- allowing the user to climb stairs , mount high curbs , and move effortlessly and safely over virtually any kind of surface , be it high grass , sand , rocks , or shag carpeting .
Dean Kamen , founder of DEKA Research and Development , invented the device .
Kamen has patents for several quality of life devices like the portable dialysis machine .
He also holds a Guinness record for the longest interrupted span of time spent dressed in denim .
Kamen said that he came up with the idea for the IBot when he stumbled out of the shower one day but managed to recover his balance before crashing to the floor .
He figured that if he could do it , a computer should easily be able to replicate the process of rebalancing for mechanical objects like wheelchairs .
Tom Minutaglio , a retired financial market software systems engineer , has been closely following the development of the IBot .
" From what I understand , it can climb stairs about as fast as a non-disabled person can , can turn on a dime , can elevate you up to eight feet and is near impossible to tip over .
It is the sort of machine that will enable me to do things and go places I simply can n't with the current powered mobile scooters or wheelchairs , " Minutaglio said .
" And yes , " he said , " it can even take you the water 's edge on a sandy beach which for me would be nirvana .
Dean Kamen is a compassionate genius . "




The Softer Side of UV

Ultraviolet radiation , the leading cause of skin cancer , could be used to protect drinking water from potentially deadly parasites and other harmful microorganisms .
Researchers say UV radiation could become an environmentally friendly alternative to standard water disinfection methods .
" Theres the potential for a major paradigm shift in terms of whats appropriate disinfection technology for drinking water , " said Mark Sobsey , professor of environmental microbiology at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill .
Parasites like Cryptosporidium parvum , which get into reservoirs and rivers through infected feces , are hard to kill .
Filtering them out or preventing them from getting into reservoirs have been the two most common approaches to protection until now .
Cryptosporidium can be deadly for the elderly , infants , and people withHIV/Aids or cancer who have weakened immune systems .
Close to 100 people died in an outbreak in Milwaukee in 1993 .
Though 90 different antibiotics have been tried , the infection does not respond to drug therapy , and no one knows for sure how much exposure can make people sick , adding urgency to the quest of finding ways to eliminate the pathogen .
UV radiation has now been shown to damage the DNA that instructs the single-celled parasite to multiply in mammalian intestines , causing the diarrhea , stomach cramps , and low fever symptomatic of cryptosporidiosis . "
UV doesnt kill the cell right out .
It just stops it from replicating , " said Karl Linden , an environmental engineer at Duke University who is part of the technical working group advising the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency on UV disinfection .
EPA
The process is also effective against giardia , bacteria , and other microorganisms . "
It kills everything , depending on the dose you use , " said Linden .
As an added environmental benefit , the use of UV could eliminate disinfection byproducts -- potentially cancer causing leftovers of the chemicals now used to disinfect tap water .
DPBs
The EPA is currently considering limits for cryptosporidium in drinking water as well as new lower limits for DBPs to be proposed next spring .
UV is also being considered by the EPA as an approved technique to inactivate cryptosporidium .
The new advances are quickly finding their way into the commercial arena .
Last month Calgon Carbon Corporation was awarded a contract from West View Water Authority in Pittsburgh , Pennsylvania to treat 40 million gallons of drinking water a day with UV radiation . "
Its environmentally safe .
It does not produce disinfection by-products , " said Calgon Carbon representative Gail Gerona .
DBPs such as trihalomethane and haloacetic acid are formed from chlorine , added to drinking water in the United States to kill bacteria .
Scientists are concerned that prolonged exposure to DPBs may cause cancer .
Since UV also kills bacteria , its addition would allow for less chlorine and possibly eliminate the formation of DPBs . "
The thought is to use UV followed by a little bit of chlorine -- not enough to produce disinfection by-products -- then you add some ammonia to create chloramine and thats what actually goes into the distribution system to protect the pipes , " said Linden .
Prior to the latest research , ozone was the only agent known to be capable of killing cryptosporidium .
Ozone is widely used as the primary disinfectant in Europe , where residual chlorine in the water is neither desired nor required as it is in the United States .
Ozone works well on very clean source water , but is expensive and can result in bromide DPBs .
Anticipating new EPA limits on cryptosporidium and DPBs , Seattle Public Utility is asking for bids on ozone treatment in combination with UV for its new water treatment plant at Cedar Hill . "
Theres still a lot of research that needs to occur , but UV is really shaping up to be a very economical and very effective treatment for cryptosporidium , as isozone , " said Julie Hutchins , chief engineer of Seattle Public Utility .
A handful of large cities , including Seattle , have watersheds and reservoir systems so clean that they were exempted from filtration requirements mandated by the EPA in 1989 .
Water quality in these watersheds is maintained by programs such as waterfowl management , farmer education , upgrade of sewage treatment plants , and limits on development -- all geared to reduce the amounts of human and animal waste , and close to 80 other pollutants with limits set by the EPA , that enter the reservoirs .
In May , the Massachusetts Water Resources Authority won a court battle against the EPA to keep their right to avoid filtration for the Boston metropolitan area .
MWRA
They proposed treating water from the Wachusset reservoir with ozone and chloramines , while continuing watershed protection . "
That will radically reduce our disinfection levels in the system , down to perhaps a quarter or third of what they are now , " said Stephen Estes-Smargiassi , director of planning for MWRA .
With the new research on UV , MWRA may eventually include UV as a disinfection option , even though their planned ozone plant would inactivate 99 percent of the already extremely low levels of cryptosporidium in regional reservoirs . "
We are scratching our heads , " said Estes-Smargiassi . "
This late-breaking news on UV is causing us to think a bit about what we should do . "
MWRA officials were concerned that installing a filtration plant would lead to increased public pressure to open restricted watershed lands to general recreational uses . "
We feel we have some pretty good evidence from what we see out there in the watershed , that a movement to a higher level of treatment would result in our seeing a lessening of support of watershed protection , " said Estes-Smargiassi . "
All the evidence we see says that a well-protected watershed reduces public health risks . "
Watershed protection of nearly pristine watersheds , rather than filtration , is the preferred way to protect drinking water and the environment . "
Watershed protection is a more environmental way of keeping drinking water clean , " said Mary Mears , New York State EPA representative .
New York City is another of the major metropolitan areas exempted from filtration .
Mears warned that willingness to spend money on watershed protection could diminish if New York City is forced to spend $ 6 billion on a filtration plant , as the EPA has recently proposed . "
Environmentalists would then be concerned that the city would do no watershed protection,"she said .
In fact , protection is already an issue in New York , where Riverkeeper , an environmental watchdog on clean water issues , has threatened to sue the city for failing to prevent development around the Hudson River and elsewhere in the watershed .
" Our biggest concern about water quality is trying to control and prevent inappropriate development projects east of the Hudson , " said Marc Yaggie , watershed attorney for Riverkeeper .
As far as the environment is concerned , " Prevention is better than any treatment technology , " he said .
Technology such as UV radiation could be added to existing water treatments , both filtered and unfiltered , to reduce the risk of disease , problems like DPBs , and perhaps avoid the need for massive filtration projects . "
Theres still a lot of research being done .
Theres a lot of excitement about using UV , " said EPA advisor Linden .

Ben & Jerry 's Dioxin Controversy

MONTEREY , California -- Ben & Jerry 's , a popular brand of gourmet ice cream , offers more than tasty flavors .
The frozen treat also serves a hefty helping of dioxins -- suspected carcinogens -- according to a study released Thursday at the Dioxins 2000 conference .
But the problem is not limited to any one brand of ice cream -- dioxin is a problem in all dairy products .
The study shows that the level of dioxin in a sample serving of one variety of Ben & Jerry 's ice cream is about 2,200 times greater than the level of dioxin allowed in wastewater discharged into San Francisco Bay from the nearby Tosco oil refinery .
Dioxin is a byproduct of industrial processes such as the bleaching of paper with chlorine , and the incinerating of garbage and medical wastes .
It is also created naturally through combustion of wood and other plant materials .
Because dioxin is fat soluble , it builds up in fatty tissues of wildlife , domestic animals and humans .
Dioxin is present in all dairy products such as ice cream because of its build up in milk fats .
The Environmental Protection Agency is in the process of reassessing the health risks of dioxin .
In a draft report released in June , the EPA warned that infants and children are most at risk of cancer , developmental problems , and reproductive problems from exposure to dioxins .
But all people , particularly those who eat diets high in animal fats , may be at risk .
Preliminary results of the current study sponsored by Junkscience.com set off a storm of concern about Ben & Jerrys products when announced last November .
Junkscience.com , a website supported by industries that examines health and science claims , bills itself as covering " all the junk thats fit to debunk . "
In anticipation of the EPAs long awaited reassessment , Junkscience.com tested Ben & Jerrys " Worlds Best Vanilla " ice cream to prove a point : At the dioxin " safe " levels set under current EPA regulations , some foods are already unsafe .
The study 's authors report that , according to Ben & Jerry 's and current EPA standards , the level of dioxin measured could cause about 200 additional cancers among lifetime consumers of Ben & Jerry 's ice cream .
Under the EPA 's pending reassessment of dioxins risks , the estimate would increase to about 2,000 extra cancers .
" The level of dioxin in a single serving of the Ben & Jerry 's World 's Best Vanilla Ice Cream tested was almost 200 times greater than the ' virtually safe &#91;daily&#93 ; dose ' currently used by the EPA , " said Michael Gough , an author of the study .
Gough is a former government scientist who chaired the Health and Human Services advisory panel on the effects of dioxin contaminated Agent Orange on U.S. Air Force personnel in Vietnam .




Napster Gets Stay of Execution

SAN FRANCISCO -- It seems reports of Napster 's demise were greatly exaggerated , as two federal appeals court judges on Friday granted the file-trading company 's request to halt an order that would have shut down the service .
The Napster application was scheduled to go offline Friday at midnight , after U.S. District Judge Marilyn Patel ruled Wednesday that the company was likely to lose its copyright infringement case against the music industry 's top record labels .
In a written statement , the two 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals judges said that " having raised substantial questions of first impression going to both the merits and the form of the injunction , the emergency motions for stay and to expedite the appeal are granted . "
Napster executives were obviously pleased with the news .
" I believe the Napster technology can help everyone involved in music -- including artists , consumers , and the industry , " Napster CEO Hank Barry said in a statement . "
New technologies can be a win-win situation if we work together on building new models -- and we at Napster are eager to do so . "
Not surprisingly , the Recording Industry Association of America was none to pleased with the court 's decision , implying that the case might be headed for a higher court .
" The Court of Appeals ' decision today granting Napster a temporary stay of the preliminary injunction is obviously a disappointment , but we remain confident that the court will ultimately affirm once it has had an opportunity to review the facts and the law , " RIAA CEO Hilary Rosen said in a statement .
" The Court of Appeals apparently regards this case as the first of its kind , and wants to consider it before any injunction takes effect , " Rosen said . "
The court 's order sets an expedited schedule for that review . "
The company also announced that it will continue its planned " Buycott , " asking its member base of 20 million to purchase the CDs of musicians like Limp Bizkit who have come out in support of San Mateo , California-based Napster .
Opening briefs in the case are now due on August 18 .




MP3.com Settles With EMI

MP3.com reached an agreement with EMI Group that will allow the online music company to use songs owned by the British record label in the my.mp3.com Web-based database , a source familiar with the talks said Thursday .
" An announcement is expected Friday that says MP3.com can use EMI 's music as part of the my.mp3.com service , " the source told Reuters .
EMI 's family of labels is home to such luminaries as the Beatles , the Rolling Stones and Frank Sinatra .
MP3.com assembled a database of over 80,000 albums , which when combined with its software allows users to store music digitally and then access it via any computer .
The service is called my.mp3.com .
A federal court ruling found that the San Diego company ran afoul of copyright law by creating the database , forcing the company to pursue settlements with the labels or risk court-imposed damages that could add up to billions of dollars .
A hearing is scheduled for August 28 in U.S. District Court in New York to determine the damages .
News of the settlement comes a day after a federal court in San Francisco granted a preliminary injunction to the major record labels , forcing song-swapping software company Napster to shut down the most attractive part of its service : the ability to download major-label songs for free .
The record labels ' vigilance against piracy stems from the advent of MP3 , a file format that allows users to store digital music files on their personal computers in small packets of data that are easy to copy and distribute .
The my.mp3.com service lets computer users with an original copy of one of the recordings in the data register that CD .
It then allows the user to listen to that album over the Internet from any computer , without having to insert the original disc .
MP3.com is expected to pay EMI roughly $ 20 million in damages to settle the suit and would also pay a fee each time that label 's CDs are registered by a user and another fee each time a user accesses one of its songs .
The deal is believed to be similar to the two deals reached last month with Time Warner 's Warner Music Group and Bertelsmann AG 's music arm BMG .
" We 're in negotiations with all of the remaining companies , " an MP3.com spokesman told Reuters , but declined to comment further .
EMI executives declined to comment .
That leaves two major labels that have outstanding claims against MP3.com : Sony Music Entertainment , which declined to comment , and Seagram 's Universal Music Group , where officials were unavailable for comment .
The gap between Universal and MP3.com had been pretty wide , several sources familiar with the negotiations said . "
But the two sides have begun to have some meaningful talks in the last week , " one source said .
Universal agreed to a licensing agreement on Tuesday with Musicbank , a privately held company based in San Francisco which operates a service that competes with my.mp3.com .
On Monday , MP3.com said it took a $ 150 million charge against its second-quarter earnings for the estimated lawsuit costs .
There is also a pending copyright infringement suit filed by song publishers .
The court is expected to rule Friday on whether the damages for copyright infringement are to be levied on a per-song basis or a per-album basis .
It will also rule on whether or not MP3.com violated the law with " willful intent , " which could give the presiding judge broad powers to impose dramatically increased damages .
However , MP3.com 's legal troubles pale beside those of Internet song-swapping service Napster , which was engaged in a legal fight for its life after a federal judge late Wednesday ordered it to shut down its site by midnight Friday .
Major record companies have charged it allows users to avoid paying copyright fees by letting them download music for free in the form of computer files .




I 'll Pay Anything for Optical !

Corvis Corp. , a little-known developer of optical networking equipment , set a new IPO record Friday with a $ 1.1 billion offering that more than doubled in first-day trading .
The Columbia , Maryland company , which is developing technology that makes data travel faster across fiber-optic networks , was met by an exuberant reception from investors .
The stock , initially priced at $ 36 a share , rose as high as $ 98 before closing up 135 percent at $ 84.72 .
The deal was remarkable for two reasons .
First , the Corvis offering marked the only time in U.S. history that a company selling more than $ 1 billion worth of stock saw its share price more than double in first-day trading .
Second , and perhaps more astonishing , Corvis achieved this feat despite having no revenue , no profits , and no product on the market .
In its three years of operation , the company has lost more than $ 125 million .
Only in the field of optical telecommunications networking could a company that has so far made so little could have gotten so much for its stock , analysts suggested .
" Optics is this year 's Internet , " said Richard Peterson , market strategist at First Call/Thomson Financial .
While a large portion of last year 's big IPO market winners were dot-com firms , the most lucrative stock market debuts in recent months have come from companies involved in optical networking or other technologies for speeding up traffic on telecommunications systems .
Investors ' interest in optical networking comes as an increasing volume of voice and data traffic puts pressure on telecom firms to install devices that move information more quickly along congested fiber-optic networks .
Optical technology allows companies to split a single fiber cable into multiple channels and to route traffic more efficiently .
Corvis and other newly public companies are also benefiting from the generous stock market valuations of more established networking firms like Cisco Systems , which owns 6 percent of Corvis , Nortel Networks and optical components maker JDS Uniphase .

JDSU
Those companies have shelled out billions in the past year to acquire smaller networking firms , further pushing up the value of startups with expertise in optical networking .




Keeping Up With the Phoneses

Robert Meldrum is banking his company 's future on the belief that people who juggle multiple phone numbers actually want to be reachable by everyone at almost any given time .
His vision is that people will pay to ensure that all their phones ring at the same time .
As co-founder and chief executive of SimulRing , a ten-month-old Redmond , Washington , startup , Meldrum is gearing up this week to launch a service that will allow Seattle-area residents to route phone calls to multiple extensions .
He 's hoping the service , dubbed Simultaneous Ring , will appeal to busy professionals and other folks who are sick of missing calls because they 're not around the right phone at the right time .
With SimulRing 's technology , a single call can ring on a cell phone , a home phone , an office phone , and up to seven other lines , all at the same time .
Messages can be routed into a single voice mailbox .
" What we 're doing is we 're divorcing a phone number from a physical piece of equipment , " said Meldrum , a former account manager with Lucent , who teamed up with James Cheshire , a former Bell Labs engineer and now SimulRing 's chief operating officer , to develop the simultaneous ringing technology .
Although the service is currently available only in the Seattle metropolitan area , Meldrum plans to move into the San Francisco Bay Area , New York City , Washington DC , Los Angeles , Philadelphia , and Boston later this year and to expand to 100 cities by the end of next year .
The service will cost $ 29.95 to activate , plus $ 9.95 a month for up to three phone lines .
SimulRing is n't the first company to offer a service targeted to cut down the confusion of maintaining multiple phone lines .
AccessLine , a company in nearby Bellevue , Washington , lets users forward a call from one extension to another , until a person answers or the call goes to a voice mailbox .
Whether individuals and businesses will show much demand for a service that makes a bunch of phones ring at the same time has yet to be determined .
SimulRing currently has about 150 Seattle-area customers that either participated in its beta test or heard about the company by word of mouth , but will only start offering its service to the general public on Wednesday .
For now , Meldrum is optimistic about the market potential , although he admits he 's heard some criticism .
" I 've heard a couple of people say " Gosh , I do n't think I know if I want to be that in-touch , " he said .
Meldrum reassures critics that the service does allow customers to change settings and stop getting calls sent to a particular number .
In addition , he advises , one can always just turn off the phone .
How often he takes his advice , however , is open to question .
In a recent call to Meldrum to test his new service , the SimulRing CEO answered from his car , where he had two cell phones simultaneously ringing .




Let the Games Be Streamed

If anyone has grand visions of hitting the Web to bypass NBC 's time-delayed offerings from the Summer Olympics in Sydney , they 'll probably be disappointed .
An International Olympic Committee spokesman confirmed this week that webcasting sports action from Sydney will be prohibited because the normal national boundaries that cover broadcast rights do not apply in cyberspace .
" Since the Internet has no borders , there 's no way we could , for example , give Internet rights in the United States that would n't impinge on the rights we 've already given to networks , " the spokesman said .
But a number of ideas have been kicked around for offering geographically limited access to websites that could then offer streaming video of Marion Jones winning yet another gold medal or , perhaps , some Australian in a high-tech sharkskin suit setting a world record .
For example , a site based in Germany could block a user in the United States from accessing proprietary video prior to its television broadcast back home .
The IOC is glad to hear any and all ideas -- and , in fact , has called a two-day summit December 4-5 in Lausanne , Switzerland , to plan for future Olympics and explore " the challenge of the emerging media and sports , " as the spokesman put it .
Among those who will be there is Quokka.com , which is teaming up this year with NBC to offer extensive coverage of the Olympics .
" We will definitely be participating in that conference , " said Tom Newell , general manager for NBC/Quokka Ventures .
" The next games is in February 2002 , here in the United States , and I expect the IOC will review their entire position before then , " Newell said . "
in Salt Lake City
You may have new technologies that are available .
Certainly you will have more people in closed systems , with cable modems or DSL connections . "
But Newell said that , given current technological limitations , Quokka and NBC are not overly worried about not being able to use video from Sydney .
" We went into this venture with NBC knowing there would probably be some kind of limitations , " he said . "
Frankly , the video experience is n't very good .
We probably would n't have changed a lot if we had n't had this as a variable .
One of the problems with streaming video is bandwidth problems that most people have .
If you 're sitting on a 28.8 modem , it does n't work very well .
It breaks up .
It 's not very good .
" What we try to do is to provide an entertainment experience that will n't rely on video .
We 'll use some video as a source material , " he said . "
NBC is going to have their own unilateral cameras .
We 'll be able to access the marvelous images that come from the broadcasts and display still pictures . "
If that sounds a little boosterish , that 's how it goes with Olympics sports .
But no one can accuse the NBC/Quokka Ventures site of not being thorough .
In addition to commentaries from NBC sportscasters like Ted Robinson or bearded Alexi Lalas and features on the individual athletes , the site also has as much information as anyone could want on Sydney and all the sports to be represented there .

Get Your Music Mojo Working

LAS VEGAS -- A new file-sharing system could best rivals like Napster and Gnutella through more anonymous and efficient transfers .
The service has an innovative feature that rewards users for uploading and distributing files : payment in a form of digital currency called " Mojo . "
" It 's a cross between Napster and eBay , " says Jim McCoy , the 30-year-old CEO of Autonomous Zone Industries , which created the open-source MojoNation software .
McCoy 's goal is nothing if not ambitious : to create the first file-sharing economy of agents , servers , and search engines in which senders and receivers can agree on prices for each transaction and use micropayments to get paid .
The prospect of millions of users spending Mojo tokens on pirated movies and songs is sure to draw the wrath of the entertainment industry , which has sued to shut down Napster and erase a DVD-descrambling program from the Web .
Another probable early use is pornography copied from other sites , and companies such as Penthouse 's publisher also have shown they 're willing to take legal action .
Autonomous Zone says that since it -- unlike Napster -- does not keep a master index of files , its employees are simply unable to remove references to illegal files stored on MojoNation servers . "
We are a bigger threat because we can survive most attacks , " McCoy says .
But the startup claims it wants to work with Hollywood through a voluntary-payment-for-downloads feature that the firm 's programmers have dubbed " PayLars , " a reference to Metallica drummer and Napster foe Lars Ulrich .
" When the president of Sony comes to us , we 'll say Gnutella 's never going to do anything for you , " says the Autonomous Zone programmer who goes by the name Zooko Journeyman . "
Fight them or die -- or join us and prosper . "
In an attempt to spread MojoNation quickly through the hacker underground , Autonomous Zone plans to release the beta version at the DefCon convention this weekend in Las Vegas .
Versions will be available on sourceforge.net for Windows and Linux machines .
MojoNation 's current stage of development is somewhere between a working prototype and a polished final product .
It works , but a friendly interface is still being shaped , and as of Friday , company programmers were still unearthing some remaining bugs .
At least when its development is complete , MojoNation should combine the ease of use and search capabilities of Napster and Gnutella with the kind of distributed server network that FreeNet uses .
Files that are uploaded to a Freenet server remain online after a user disconnects , but Freenet does not support searching or micropayments .
But will MojoNation be compelling enough to make other users switch ? "
It does n't seem to buy anything over Gnutella , " says Jon Lasser , author of Think Unix . "
It 's not clear to me who is served by this system . "
The libertarian-leaning cypherpunks -- only about seven so far -- who work at Autonomous Zone are pinning their hopes on creating an emergent network of electronic buyers , sellers , and service providers , all exchanging tokens that might represent as little as one-thousandth of a cent .
Another addition : A limited form of reputation-tracking , so you can determine which service providers are the most reliable .
The first time you log on , you generate a public and private key pair that the system uses to identify you .
" It is an ant colony of sorts -- tons of agents , each with its own specialized goal , " says McCoy , a former Yahoo engineer who founded Autonomous Zone last summer and is providing the seed capital .
By pinning even an infinestimal value on all transactions , the company plans to discourage piggish folks who download more than they contribute in return .
To earn Mojo tokens , users can sell their extra bandwidth or disk space and act as servers , or create their own service that others want to pay for .
A successful system would also likely include money exchangers who buy and sell Mojo tokens in exchange for dollars .
Before a MojoNation user uploads a file , the client software splits it into eight pieces using an algorithm akin to that used in RAID hard disk arrays : Only four pieces are necessary to reconstruct the entire file , and the sender can try to use the network to cloak his or her identity .




Napster : Not Just For the Music

Gene researchers and computer virus engineers alike want their Napster , but not for swapping the latest tracks from Da Brat .
All sorts of people have found ways to use Napster-like technologies , which connect individual computers to one another via a central server in order to share data .
But as a copyright infringement case against the company threatens to shut down the exceedingly popular music-swapping site , those dealing in perfectly legal data worry they could be stifled as well .
On Wednesday , U.S. District Judge Marilyn Patel ruled that Napster must stop allowing its users to share copyrighted music .
Since the program has no way to distinguish between music that 's copyrighted and music that 's not , her injunction would have effectively shut down the site .
But Napster 's not gone yet .
On Friday , 9th U.S. Circuit Court judges granted Napster a stay of the injunction , allowing the file-trading application to remain up and running on the company 's site .
Napster 's attorneys have until August 18 to file their paperwork regarding the injunction .
The trial date has not been set .
Should the trial turn out badly for Napster , some are concerned that it could set a precedent for all Napster-type technologies , even those that are legal .
" I worry very much that certain types of software may be banned because they can be used for illegitimate purposes , without regard for the fact that they have extremely and purely legal functions as well , " said Lincoln Stein , associate professor of bioinformatics at Cold Spring Harbor Laboratories in New York .
Moreover , Stein said he worries that the judge 's decision could have far-reaching implications that would thwart more than just peer-to-peer technologies .
" If we take the judge 's ruling to a logical conclusion , we would have to ban the World Wide Web as well , " Stein said . "
I shudder to think the RIAA might bring suit against the World Wide Web consortium because many people are using the WWW routinely for sharing MP3 files . "
When Stein first encountered Napster , he thought scientists might be able to use it for sharing genetic information .
He began investigating ways to use Napster-type technology to allow scientists to share their research on the human genome .
" Napster has a similar architecture , but it allows for ' peer-to-peer ' data exchange and it dawned on me that it would be marvelous for our annotation system . "

Defcon : The Hacker 's Bacchanalia

LAS VEGAS -- What do you get when you mix 6,000 hackers and hacker-wannabees with booze , gambling and some of the hottest temperatures in the history of Sin City ?
Defcon , an annual gathering that holds the Alexis Park Hotel 's all-time record for the most alcohol consumed by one group in a weekend .
Defcon has always been an event known as much for its intensive technical content -- talks on " advanced buffer overflow techniques " are de rigueur -- as its social opportunities , but this year it seems to have become more party than conference .
Call it the new American geek holiday .
An example : Some 6,000 paid attendees showed up -- organizers ran out of badges at 5,000 -- but the hotel reports the three conference rooms used for Defcon hold a combined total of just 2,800 people .
The rest of the attendees seemed to be content occupying their time with poolside lounging , private parties in hotel rooms and , naturally , beer-tinged teenage high jinks .
Hotel staff patiently spent Saturday evening clearing smoke bombs and bubble bath from the three swimming pools -- as well as concrete that reportedly was poured in at least one toilet .
At one point , when a few malcontents became even more rambunctious , conference organizer Priest had to warn the crowd . "
If I find you , you will go to jail , " Priest said . "
You will go to jail for assault and trespassing . "
But for the most part , Defcon was a way for a young audience -- over half of the conference-goers seemed to be under 21 -- to gather in person and quietly talk tech .
San Francisco criminal defense attorney Jennifer Granick -- who is representing an increasing number of hackers accused of crimes -- gave legal tips on Friday , while the MojoNation folks spoke about their new better-than-Napster software on Saturday .
Anyone who revels in arcane Apple II and Commodore 64 hacking trivia would love the two rounds of Hacker Jeopardy , hosted by longtime infowar alarmist Winn Schwartau .
One of the best-attended events had little to do with hacking but everything to do with subversiveness : an hour-long tutorial on lock picking .

EBay Accused of Monopolization

The judge in the eBay v.
Bidder 's Edge case has refused to throw out antitrust allegations leveled by the auction listing re-aggregator against auction giant eBay .
Bidder 's Edge contends that eBay behaved anticompetitively and that therefore the company is guilty of monopolization or at least attempted monopolization .
" Bidder 's believes that the two companies are participating in a market involving online auctions , " said Bidder 's Edge attorney John Cotter . "
EBay prevented Bidder 's Edge from participating in the market . "
EBay disagrees .
" Their filing of an antitrust counterclaim was unsurprising , " said eBay attorney Jay Monahan . "
We consider it to be completely meritless . "
The antitrust law violations that Bidder 's Edge has alleged against eBay come in the larger context of eBay 's suit against Bidder 's Edge , in which the auction giant accuses Bidder 's Edge of trespassing on its servers , unfair competition , and other claims .
Judge Ronald White of United States District Court for the Northern District of California issued an injunction against Bidder 's Edge ordering the company to stop crawling eBay 's server with its automated spiders .
The injunction is on appeal .
This week , however , Judge White denied eBay 's motion to dismiss the antitrust claims made by Bidder 's Edge .
The judge suggested in a footnote of his order that , if eBay 's suit fails , the company 's technologic self-help measures may be evidence of antitrust activity .
" If automated crawling of eBay 's website is determined to be lawful , eBay 's alleged blockage of search activity may also provide a basis for an antitrust violation , " the judge wrote .
Bidder 's Edge 's
Bidder 's Edge 's
To be sure , the judge 's preliminary ruling is no legal slam dunk for Bidder 's Edge .
The order only established that the claim may continue and that more facts will be needed to address its merits .
Antitrust drums of war do beat about eBay , although they beat softly .
A MotleyFool study completed in February put eBay 's market share in the consumer-to-consumer auction space at 85 percent -- a figure that sets off bells in an antitrust attorney 's mind .
Also , the Department of Justice recently initiated a preliminary probe of eBay 's activities .
EBay 's Monahan dismissed both the market share arguments and the DOJ 's probe , saying that eBay and Bidder 's Edge were not competitors in the same market and that the DOJ has been quiet since eBay met with regulators almost nine months ago .
" We did have some discussions with DOJ staff , " Monahan said . "
We were actually quite happy to talk to them . "
Because there are many markets in which eBay competes , determining which one eBay allegedly attempted to monopolize would be difficult at best , Monahan said .
In any event , the attorney said , eBay and Bidder 's Edge do n't compete .
" We 're in the business of providing auctions and they 're in the business of providing auction listings , " he said .
Peter Ward , an attorney who has worked for the Federal Trade Commission on antitrust issues , said he sees no smoking guns in the antitrust claims made by Bidder 's Edge .
" An 85 percent market share has been in some cases evidence of monopoly power but the critical question is eBay 's ability to keep other people out of the market , " Ward said . "
Proving monopolization is a pretty steep hill to climb in a market that 's changing on a daily basis . "
As for the eBay 's blocking of access to its servers , Ward said the company would likely be able to defend itself against accusations of attempted anticompetitive behavior by saying that it had a legitimate business interest in doing so .




Ford Gets Wired With Qualcomm

Ford Motor and Qualcomm , a provider of wireless phone technology , announced the creation of a new company that will develop and deliver wireless information services into cars and trucks .
Dubbed Wingcast , the new company will offer voice , entertainment , Internet access and safety services in Ford vehicles .
The first services will be available in late 2001 .
Terms of the deal were not disclosed , but Ford and San Diego-based Qualcomm will each own equity in Wingcast .
In addition , Cartell , a supplier of telematics equipment to automakers , is a minority stakeholder .
Ford expects more than a million of its new cars and trucks to be equipped for mobile communications by the end of 2002 , three million by 2003 and nearly all of its cars and trucks by the end of 2004 .

High-security restroom : Germany 's telecom watchdog , intent on ensuring the utmost fairness in its auction for new high-tech phone licenses is keeping security so tight that officials can n't go to the bathroom unattended .
The level of security reflects how much is at stake for the German government , expected to reap a windfall 30 billion euros from the auction , and for telephone firms , for whom the third-generation mobile phone licenses hold the key to their future .
$ 27.73 billion
Bidders are being strictly segregated from each other and from the 200 media representatives covering the auction , which started on Monday in the spartan surroundings of a former U.S. Army barracks near Mainz , in southwestern Germany .
Mobile phones are strictly " verboten " in an attempt to remove any scope for price-fixing collusion among bidders .
The rules are enforced by police and private security guards , who resemble nightclub bouncers in their black bomber jackets .
Seven companies and consortiums are bidding for the four-to-six Universal Mobile Telecommunications System licenses on offer that are crucial to the European strategies of some of the world 's largest telecom groups .

Pearson shares were down 5.7 percent at 18.96 pounds at 0920 GMT after dipping as low as 18.75 pounds as the market took fright at the size of the rights issue .

Aussies to Trade Green Power

SYDNEY , Australia -- Fifteen energy companies in Australia have agreed to implement a new way to trade the rights for electricity that is generated from renewable energy facilities .
The Green Electricity Market Project will be an Internet-based exchange that allows members to trade green power generation .
GEM
The extensive consultation between the electricity industry and the government is expected to provide a major boost to Australia 's renewable energy sector as it prepares to meet requirements arising from the federal Renewable Energy Target , as well as to meet retail customer demand for green power .
As of January 2001 , competition and customer choice will be introduced into the Australian electricity market .
Large companies can already choose their electricity provider , and from January 2001 , residential and small business customers will be able to make the same choice .
" To meet the renewable energy contracting requirements of power companies , GEM will deliver the worlds first industry governed green e-marketplace by early next year , " says Ken Chapman of M-co , the company that will implement the project . "
It will also support the fulfillment of the governments compliance reporting conditions for market participants . "
" GEM will give a real boost to the renewable energy market in Australia , " says Philip Harrington of the Australian Greenhouse Office 's Sustainable Energy Group . "
It will make it much easier for market participants to buy and sell green power and it will reduce transaction costs . "
Charter members include AGL Electricity , Aurora Energy , CS Energy , ENERGEX Retail , Ergon Energy , Hydro-Electric Corporation , Macquarie Generation , Optima Energy , Origin Energy Electricity , Pacific Hydro , Pacific Power , Primergy , Powercor Australia , Snowy Hydro Trading , and Stanwell Corporation .
Initial financial support will come from these companies .
Shortly , GEM will be opened to all industry participants .
GEM will allow the members to track their generation under the mandatory target of providing 9,500 GWh of renewable energy as of next January , and to build an efficient market for renewable energy certificates .
" We support market-based mechanisms for the supply of renewable energy because markets can deliver effective outcomes at least cost , " says Harry Schaap of the Electricity Supply Association of Australia . "
GEM will assist renewable energy based electricity generators , green power retailers , and other GEM participants to trade effectively and efficiently in green electricity rights , and that will help to stimulate a dynamic green electricity market , " Schaap says .
The Marketplace Company is the Australian subsidiary of M-co , the firm that administers the New Zealand electricity market .
It transacts more than A$1 billion worth of trading each year through its proprietary Internet based trading systems .
