Miracle Engine 's Tank Is Empty

For the last six years , a small startup company in Youngstown , Ohio , has been promising to bring to market a revolutionary engine that would provide unlimited power for free , requiring no fuel and producing no pollution .
Too good to be true ?
Well , it seems so .
Entropy Systems now says it has no immediate plans to release Entropy Engines , despite raising about $ 3.5 million from private investors and hawking the breakthrough technology in the media since at least 1994 .
Instead , Sanjay Amin , the engine 's inventor and Entropy System 's CEO , said he will continue to develop the technology away from the limelight while concentrating on a new venture : Abika.com , an online e-book retailer .
According to the story Amin has told to numerous reporters and potential investors over the years , Entropy Engines will revolutionize the energy industry .
The engines require no fuel , relying only on ambient heat energy in the atmosphere , which they would efficiently convert into power .
Entropy Engines would power all kinds of devices , from cooling systems to generators and automobiles .
They would be free to run and would n't create any pollution , directly or indirectly .
In September last year , Amin grabbed international headlines with the announcement that he was on the verge of releasing the first Entropy Engines for boats , lawnmowers , and electrical generators .
Amin claimed to have developed a working prototype and that the first products would be on sale by early 2000 .
At the time , he planned an outboard motor for small boats , simply because it was the easiest market to break into , he said .
Later refinements of the engine would generate more power , possibly enough to run a car , he said .
Despite his fantastic claims , Amin appeared to have the backing of respected academics and savvy businessmen .
The company , which was incorporated in 1994 , was launched with the help of Youngstown State University 's Cushwa Center for Entrepreneurship , with the center 's director , Charles Cushwa , an early cheerleader .
According to Amin , he raised close to $ 3.5 million from 49 private investors in three rounds of financing .
The technology had been patented in the United States , Europe , and Australia , Amin said , and tested by experts at the Ford Motor Company , Youngstown , Purdue , and Pennsylvania State .
Not surprisingly , given the claims , Amin 's Entropy Engine drew a lot of attention , generating articles in newspapers and magazines around the world .
But now that 2000 has rolled around and Entropy Engines are still not on the market , Wired News contacted Amin for an update on the company 's plans .
After what appeared to be some initial reluctance to talk , Amin said last September 's announcement had been premature and that the Entropy Engine still was n't ready for prime time .




How Demos Will Upstage GOP

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
The Republicans may have had the honor of hosting the first convention to be broadcast over the Internet , but Democrats say that their big show will be the real E-convention .
The 2000 Democratic National Convention will be the first political convention to utilize electronic voting , virtual reality , complete start-to-finish Web-based coverage , and Palm Pilot-powered information services , said Democratic National Convention Committee Chairman Terry McAuliffe .
DNCC
Using technology provided by Election.com , delegates will electronically cast their votes for a presidential candidate .
Ballots will then be tallied and uploaded to the convention website within seconds .
" Electronic voting is part of our future .
We are proud that the 2000 Democratic National Convention will feature so much cutting-edge technology , " Democratic National Committee Chairman Joe Andrew said in an Internet press briefing .
The DNCC will also supply delegates with conference and city information via Palm handheld computers and technology developed by Aether Software and Eventcentric .
The Aether/Eventcentric application lets convention attendees update and share information by connecting their Palm Pilots to any of the 96 synchronization cradles that will be located throughout the convention floor .
Delegates and other attendees can also use the Palms to create personalized schedules , access news and convention speeches , discover information about other delegates , participate in interactive event surveys and evaluations , or locate a nearby restaurant .
The application 's content is also being translated into Spanish , and the possibility of providing the data in other languages is under consideration .
The DNCC has invited convention attendees to BYOP to the convention -- Aug. 14-17 at Los Angeles ' Staples Center -- but will also provide the handheld devices to 250 delegates and state chairpeople to try with the option to buy .
Bring Your Own Palm
Those who can n't manage to buy , beg , or borrow a Palm Pilot will still be able to access much of the information at any of the 90 information kiosks throughout the convention center .
Delegates will be furnished with " smart cards " and with a swipe will be able to view platform votes , convention calendars , and general information about the city of Los Angeles .
These kiosks will be powered by Voter.com .
Stay-at-home Democrats can plug into the convention from their own computers or Web-enabled devices .
DNCC 's McAuliffe says that the convention will feature what she calls " E-mersion Coverage , " a merger of broadcast and Internet technology .
The convention will be streamed in its entirety over the Internet , a feature that did n't quite work at the Republican Convention when Apple Computer and Xybernaut 's streaming video suffered some glitches and the Web video feed was delayed .
Visitors to the convention website will be able to virtually navigate through 360-degree panoramic views of the convention stadium , and view online-only video clips and webcasts featuring behind-the-scenes chats , greenroom gatherings , after-hours parties , and community events .
And while the Republicans had their Internet Alley , the DNCC will have " Internet Avenue , " a special area located in the convention 's media center which will be home to 100-plus companies showcasing technology services .




Sell Music Offline to Sell Online

For independent musicians , the Internet only works for the bands that market themselves well offline .
Of course , that poses a problem for bands that are new to the digital age .
To that end , Tim Sweeney and John Dawes have written a book called The Complete Guide to Internet Promotions for Musicians , Artists and Songwriters .
Divided into five sections , the book outlines how to put together a marketing strategy , how to promote a website and the dos and don'ts of creating a website .
But Dawes said all of the online marketing is irrelevant unless bands do what they do best -- play music in clubs .
" I encourage my artists to concentrate on performing as much as possible and then creating a website to feed the demand from that , " said Dawes . "
What does n't work is hosting songs on large portals at first .
Most of the users from those services are looking for established artists .
If you are unknown , you are unfound . "
But independent bands that are successful have a shot at real success on their own if they market themselves well .
With the average major label band making about 54 cents per CD sold , according to Dawes , the potential for mid-level selling artists just is n't there .
Independent artists however , have the opportunity to sell their own CDs for a much higher profit while charging less than retail outlet prices .
That can allow musicians to shed their part-time day jobs and concentrate entirely on their career .
While it might seem more economical for the bands to do the online promotions in-house , Dawes said is usually best to look to partner with other companies that can focus on marketing that is specific to the Internet , such as Web page development and back-end retail .
What bands should do , said Dawes , is focus on making the website an extension of the live performance so that fans will continually return to the site to find out the latest news .
By creating that fan-friendly environment providing interactivity , daily updates , and information that can n't be accessed at other places , bands will have an easier time creating traffic .
He also said that giving away music might be fine for some bands , but not if you hope to make a living .
" I suggest that artists put a track that could end up on the radio , something that has friendly airplay , " Dawes said . "
But I never , ever recommend putting up all of their tracks on the website .
You want to have enough to tantalize people to know that if they if buy the CD , they get more . "




Pentagon Still a Hacker 's Magnet

BETHESDA , Md. -- Defense Department pleas to computer hackers to quit their mischief-making appear to be falling largely on deaf ears , which makes spotting potential national security threats more difficult , a top Pentagon expert said Tuesday .
Despite recent appeals , " we 're not seeing any diminishing " of the pace of attacks on Defense Department systems , said Richard Schaeffer , who heads the cyber-security office in the Pentagon arm responsible for command , control , communications , and intelligence .
Last year , a total of 22,144 " attacks " were detected on Defense Department networks , up from 5,844 in 1998 , Air Force Maj. Gen. John Campbell , then vice director of the Defense Information Systems Agency , told Congress in March .
Through Aug. 4 of this year , a total of 13,998 such " events " have been reported , according to Betsy Flood , a spokeswoman for Arlington , Virginia-based Defense Information Systems Agency , which provides worldwide communication , network , and software support to the Defense Department .
Flood , updating the statistics in reply to a query from Reuters , defined " events " as probes , scans , virus incidents , and intrusions .
Schaeffer , speaking at a Bethesda , Maryland , " Web Defense " conference on business solutions to cyber-crime , said the government would like to take hackers " out of the equation as much as we can " to make it easier to track cyber threats that are may be tied to foreign foes .
Asked whether he expected recreational hackers to comply with the Pentagon request , he replied : " Probably not , " even though the Pentagon was crying " uncle " and telling hackers " you got our attention . "
Last month , the Pentagon , along with representatives of the armed services and federal law enforcement authorities , called on cyber vandals to turn their talents to defense .
Assistant Secretary of Defense Art Money urged hackers in attendance at the DEF CON 8.0 convention in Las Vegas to join the government or private industry and get on the " defense side . "
Once an underground event , the eight-year-old DEF CON computer hackers ' convention drew 5,000 people .
Schaeffer attributed the jump in reported attacks on Defense Department systems between 1998 and 1999 , in part , to improved intrusion-detection procedures and technology , along with stepped-up awareness and reporting .
But the " sophistication " of attacks also increased , he said .
The often-present " noise floor " from computer hackers " makes it a whole lot easier for to slip in. "
a serious threat
Schaeffer said only unclassified networks have been pierced , and the Pentagon is highly confident that its classified systems have never been penetrated by hackers because of very strong access controls .
Richard Thieme , a Milwaukee-based consultant on human dimensions of technology , chaired the panel at DEF CON at which the Pentagon made its appeal .
Thieme said that all but 1,000 of last year 's reported attacks were attributed to recreational hackers .
Schaeffer , in an interview with Reuters , said it was " highly probable " that at least some of the 22,000 attacks last year were undertaken by foreigners probing U.S. security gaps .
But he said he had never seen documentation of any such effort by China , the nation often cited by U.S. national security experts as probably developing offensive cyber weapons .




E-Privacy 's Foggy Bottom

Disturbing behind-the-scenes activity at Toysrus.com came to light last week : The company was whisking shoppers ' personal information down an unmarked Internet side road to a little-known data-processing firm .
As customers browsed and shopped at the toy retailer , third-party data-analysis firm Coremetrics was sucking name , address , and shopping cart information into its database .
The discovery spurred a controversy over the role of this unseen third party -- as well as lawsuits targeting Toysrus.com and Coremetrics .
The suits focused on the seemingly inflammatory fact that the hand-off was not mentioned in Toysrus.com 's privacy disclosures even though the information handed over was explicitly personal .
But the alleged privacy transgression is n't as clear as it might seem .
Coremetrics was a contractor to Toysrus.com , which was turning over its customer activity data for analysis to Coremetrics .
That outsourcing relationship between the two companies shed light on an area of relative obscurity in the debate over the acceptable ebb and flow of private information online .
Attorneys in one proposed class action lawsuit against Toys ' R ' Us and Coremetrics called the matter bigger than the DoubleClick controversy . "
It 's far worse than DoubleClick , " said Bill Doyle , attorney with Milberg Weiss .
The firm has handled many privacy and consumer fraud cases .
" It may not be as widespread as a DoubleClick or third-party advertisers , but it takes it to a new level , " he added .
Ad network DoubleClick , a ubiquitous third party on sites across the Web , came under fire last July for plans to acquire an offline-marketing firm that owned a huge database of personally identifiable consumer data .
If combined with anonymous cookies DoubleClick placed on millions of computers , the company might have had an unprecedented ability to track users online .
The controversy brought the role of third-party companies that interact with consumer information at websites into sharp focus .
The Federal Trade Commission and a consortium of ad networks recently came to agreement over self-regulatory privacy standards for third-party ad networks .
But is Coremetrics also a third party in addition to being Toys ' R ' Us ' outsourcing partner , and therefore subject to the same privacy rules ?
Absolutely , as critics like Doyle see it . "
We 're not talking search terms or just an ID number , or stuff that may or may not get linked up later , we 're talking everything , " he said . "
about
Your name , your address , your phone number , the ship-to names and addresses .
That 's a lot of information . "
But Coremetrics counters that its relationship with websites like Toysrus.com is being confused .
The nature of its third-party relationship to client websites is different than that of an ad network firm .
In addition to being much smaller in scope -- Coremetrics provides data analysis services to approximately 40 customer websites -- the company says it does not collect and use customer data for its own business ends .
Instead , it processes the data for the websites to use themselves .
Coremetrics says it is contractually prohibited in its client deals from profiling individuals across multiple client sites .
" based on the assumption that we collect data across multiple sites with the intention of re-selling it to third parties , and that 's just absolutely false , " said Brett Hurt , Coremetrics ' CEO and co-founder . "
The privacy concerns are
Their data is going into our database , but it is their property . "




Work ?
Who Needs It ?

Silicon Valley companies are becoming so desperate to snare the best employees from an ever-decreasing pool of qualified workers that tactics to entice applications are going from the sublime to the ridiculous .
In the past , companies have offered stock options , sports cars , and other employee benefits , but these handouts only materialized once the contract was signed and the lucky individual was securely on board .
Now AirPrime , a wireless data transmission company in Santa Clara , California , is upping the ante even further .
It 's offering free tickets for this weekend 's area Sting concert to qualified engineering applicants who send in a suitable resume .
" Companies are doing a lot of things that have n't been done in the past , " said Sandy Taylor , director of human resources at the pre-IPO AirPrime . "
I 've seen job ads on the sides of trucks parked in shopping center parking lots , or even directly outside competing companies . "
Until now , AirPrime has relied on headhunters and word of mouth to spread the news of current vacancies , said spokeswoman Liz Crawford .
Now , " engineers in Silicon Valley are a hot commodity , " she said . "
We 're a fun company , and we 're looking for unique ways to stand out . "
In June , the unemployment rate in tech-saturated Santa Clara County where AirPrime is located was a mere 2.2 percent -- less than half the 5.2 percent figure for California as a whole , and well below the national jobless rate of 4 percent .
In other counties in the area , the figure was as low as 1.8 percent .
" As technology moves forward , there are less and less qualified people , so employers are digging from a smaller pool of candidates , " said Jeremy Petrosino of Alpine Recruiting in San Francisco .
AirPrime 's generosity does n't stop with its prospective staff .
The company has also given pairs of Sting tickets to its 45 employees and is hosting a pre-concert party , " so potential employees have a chance to get to know us ahead of time , " Crawford said .
Earlier this year another company , Interwoven , lured in applicants with the promise that if they were hired , they 'd receive a $1,200-per-month taxable car allowance towards the purchase or lease of a BMW Z3 .
The company received over 1,000 resumes as a result , although of the 15 people who were hired , only three took the car .
The rest preferred Option No. 2 , a $700-per-month taxable bonus for the two-year duration of the incentive program .
" In this environment , we need to be creative , " said Gary Wimp , vice president of human resources at Interwoven . "
We need to attract good talent , and also be able to retain it , " he said , adding that long-term employee benefits now include fitness training from Brad Kearns , a world class triathlete who recently joined the staff .
ArsDigita , a software company with offices in San Francisco , Palo Alto , California , and other cities worldwide , believes that its current employees know who the best people are .
Workers referring 10 friends who are subsequently hired by the company get a Ferrari 355 TB .
Five friends are worth a Honda S2000 convertible , and one friend wins a bonus of $ 2,000 .
ArsDigita has already bought several Ferraris , ready to give out to their employees at a moment 's notice .




Mitel Makes ' Breakthrough ' Chip

OTTAWA -- Mitel Corp. said Thursday it has scored a key technical breakthrough and produced working prototypes of a chip that could cut costs and dramatically boost the performance of fiber-optic networks .
Shares in the phone system and semiconductor company surged by as much as 21 percent after the announcement , as the market continued its love affair with firms developing equipment for the red-hot fiber-optic sector .
Mitel said it is developing a chip that will help create more lanes to carry the voice , data and video traffic on fiber-optic networks .
That would make it cheaper and more efficient to transport information over the glass fibers used in those networks .
Known as dense wave division multiplexing , the chip technology boosts the number of wavelengths , or channels , that are used to carry traffic from a single beam of light .
Mitel said it is developing a device that may cram as many as 80 channels , or wavelengths , onto a beam of light using standard semiconductor materials .
Presently , most technology can handle 16 channels , with 40 channels available in products that use a technique called arrayed waveguide grating , Mitel said .
" We 're working on something that has a lot more horsepower to it , " said Mitel vice president of communications Jacques Guerette .
Mitel said it is using a technique called echelle grating to boost the number of channels rather than arrayed waveguide grating , which it said has capacity , precision and production constraints .
With echelle grating , a laser is fired at a piece of reflective glass shaped like a stair that is mounted on a chip .
Multiple reflections are then produced , with some wavelengths canceled and others reinforced .
The technique results in a greater number of reinforced wavelengths , and corresponding channels , than are produced by other grating techniques , Mitel said .
Arrayed waveguide grating splits light by creating parallel waveguides on glass substrate , with each waveguide longer than the last so that light entering the device comes out as different wavelengths on the other end .
" The existing fiber-optic industry is a competitor .
This is a technology that seemingly nobody else has -- at least nobody else is talking about it , " said Duncan Stewart , a fund manager and technology analyst at Tera Capital Corp. who holds Mitel shares . "
So if it works...that's very , very positive for Mitel . "
Companies developing fiber-optic equipment for internal and external sales include JDS Uniphase Corp. , Corning Inc. , SDL Inc. , Nortel Networks Corp. , and Lucent Technologies Inc.




Iconoclast Says Show , Do n't Tell

If Roger Schank had his way , schools would do away with multiple-choice tests and lectures .
" What we teach in schools is just the wrong stuff , " said Schank , director of the Institute for the Learning Sciences at Northwestern University and the founder of Cognitive Arts , a designer and developer of educational software and curriculum .
" Your education starts when you start doing things , " he said . "
Let 's create everything in a learn-by-doing environment because that 's what works . "
Schank believes that students learn better through experiential and emotional learning rather than through memorizing names and dates .
If used correctly , technology can enable such learning .
No one would board a plane with a pilot who had learned to fly by taking a multiple-choice test , he said .
And because learning to fly on a real plane would be too dangerous , new pilots use a flight simulator .
Schank believes the same approach can be applied in all areas of learning .
Simulating real-world environments is central to the online learning courses that Cognitive Arts is developing for Columbia University and Harvard Business School .
Online classes in C++ , Java , and business writing for non-native speakers of English will be released this fall through Columbia 's continuing education program .
In a programming course , students are put in a job situation where they must write a particular program .
The programs get progressively more difficult .
Schank will also develop more mainstream courses like introductory economics and psychology for Columbia , which will be released sometime in 2001 .
For a psychology class , a student may be asked to play the role of a psychologist and see a virtual patient with a behavioral problem .




Developers Warm Up to Linux Watch

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
When IBM announced that its research department had produced a Linux-powered watch on Monday , officials expected the news to be greeted with joy , if not downright reverence .
Instead , many in the media and open source community responded with jokes about " cluster clocks " and " Dick Tracy watches . "
" People do n't seem to be getting the importance of what was accomplished here , " said Alex Morrow , head of IBM 's Linux Watch development team .
Morrow said that the real issue is the overall scale of the prototype &ndash; - that it has the smallest motherboard -- almost the size of a postage stamp -- that presently is capable of running Linux .
" It was a technical challenge , " he continued . "
The ultimate goal here was to demonstrate that Linux could be reduced for a very small form factor . "
and therefore was proven to be scaleable
Morrow said that the constraints imposed by the physical size of the unit required special manufacturing technology , particularly when building the motherboard .
The small display and limited input mechanisms also presented significant challenges .
" Fitting the components involved the use of advanced hardware packaging technologies , " Morrow said . "
We used Surface Laminar Circuit technology for fabrication of the circuit boards .
SLC
Wire bonding was used to attach the CPU to the circuit board .
Surface mount packaging was used for most other components . "
From a software standpoint , Morrow said the developers had to address issues of limited memory .
And he notes that IBM researchers are still working on solutions for the limited power that will be available when the unit has a self-contained battery .
" Proving Linux is workable on this small scale is important in itself , " Morrow said . "
It was an interesting challenge to create a Linux environment on a self-contained device small enough to fit into a wristwatch . "
Although IBM 's Linux watch is a prototype that will not be marketed , Morrow said that it should be considered an open invitation for developers .
" We hope they will be inspired to imagine what it would take to add new features to the watch , even if kernel changes are required , " he said . "
The availability of source code and a well-understood application programming environment makes it relatively easy to add new operating system facilities .
This makes Linux an ideal platform for this type of research . "




' Super ' Macs to Reach 1 GHz

While processors in PCs are running at faster than 1 GHz these days , Apple 's Macs have been stuck at 500 MHz for nearly a year .
A small Swedish startup has plans to change that .
Xtrem , a privately funded company based in Stockholm , plans to release custom-built Macs running at 1.2 GHz by the end of the year .
" You always want a faster machine , " said Mats Wallberg , Xtrem 's CEO and chief engineer . "
This will be the fastest machine on the market . "
According to Wallberg , the XtremMac G4 will be made using off-the-shelf Macs from Apple , which will void the Apple warranties .
Xtrem will install a special over-clocking device on the computer 's PowerPC processor to crank up the clock rate .
A refrigeration unit that chills the CPU , its cache , the machine 's ROM chip , and parts of the motherboard will prevent the components from melting down .
KryoTech has sold similar PCs based on over-clocked chips from AMD , which are cooled to minus 40 degrees .
Wallberg declined to say which chips the XtremMac will be based on , or whether the cooling mechanism would be built by Xtrem or KryoTech .
" We do n't want to disclose too much information to our competition , " Wallberg said .
Wallberg said Xtrem will use motherboards from Apple because the company has eliminated its hardware licensing to third parties .
He said they will also increase the speed of the system bus -- a data pipeline and a crucial bottleneck -- from 100 MHz to 150 MHz .
Wallberg said that regardless of where the final components come from , the XtremMac will be up to three times faster than PCs with equivalent speed processors from Intel or AMD , thanks to what he calls the inherent advantages of the PowerPC processor .
The machine will also run at twice the speed of Apple 's current line of G4 Macs , executing more than two gigaflops -- or 2 billion floating-point operations -- per second .
And unlike Apple 's dual-processor G4s , which accelerate only those rare applications that have been specially written to run on multi-processor machines , the XtremMac will double the operating speed of all Mac software .
Wallberg said the company will market the XtremMac to power-hungry professional users who are always on the lookout for the fastest box available and are willing to pay a premium .
The XtremMac will be encased in a polished aluminum shell , which also helps to cool the computer , and made to order with options ranging from faster hard disks to souped-up graphics cards .
Herbert Wahl , Xtrem 's general manager , said it was too early to determine pricing .




Search for Alien Life
Cont .

SETI@home -- the massively popular public computing project that scans radio signals from space for signs of alien life -- will not end next May , as originally planned .
Instead , SETI@home directors said Tuesday that they have formed a partnership with The Planetary Society , a space interest group , and Project Voyager , a media start-up , that will provide enough funding to keep the project going for at least two years beyond May 2001 .
Backers cited SETI@home's huge community of users -- and the vast quantity of data left to crunch -- as key reasons for keeping the project alive .
" It taps into a lot of people 's passions and interests in a way that other things do n't , " said Joe Firmage , the former US Web CEO who recently co-founded Project Voyager , a media company that will focus on science and space-related news .
" There are millions of people out there who have a true love of science and discovery .
What SETI@home offered was the first science nonfiction that could be participated in simply through a screensaver , " he said .
SETI@home , headquartered in Berkeley , California , launched its project in May 1999 , after creating a system that uses spare CPU cycles on desktop PCs to hunt through radio signals beamed at earth for signs of alien intelligence .
Its screensaver software downloads radio data from SETI@home's central computers and then sifts through it , looking for a nonrandom pattern that stands out from the white noise of the universe 's background radio transmissions .
The project 's founders had originally figured they could make do with about 100,000 volunteers offering idle capacity on their computers , but wound up attracting far more interest .
Currently , SETI@home says it has 2.2 million users , concentrated in the United States and Europe , whose computers process data accumulated from the Arecibo radio telescope in Puerto Rico .
" In some sense , this is the largest science project in which the public has ever been involved , " said Louis Friedman , executive director of The Planetary Society .
Friedman said that although his organization has signed a contract to continue the project for only two additional years , he hopes to keep it going much longer .
The Planetary Society , Project Voyager , and SETI@home did not say how much money they were putting in to continue the computer-aided search for alien life , but said it would be substantially more than the current budget .
So far , SETI@home has operated on a budget of several hundred thousand dollars a year , supplemented by donations of equipment and technical assistance .
SETI@home project director David Anderson said that participants have not turned up anything that looks like an extraterrestrial signal , but noted that the project is still at an early stage .
" We are looking at a very narrow band of frequencies , " he said . "
Ideally , we would want to cover 1,000 times the range of frequencies . "
The project 's new backers say they plan to upgrade SETI@home in the near future by adding telescope data received from the Southern Hemisphere and increasing the speed at which SETI@home participants can send , receive , and process data .
The Planetary Society and Project Voyager also see the partnership with the alien search project as a way to possibly drum up traffic to their own sites .
Both plan to add links to content on their own sites from the SETI@home website .
SETI@home's Anderson , however , emphasized that the project 's screensavers would not contain advertising and that volunteers would not be subject to direct marketing from outside parties .
None of the project 's participants was comfortable offering any prediction of how long it might take for SETI , and its millions of users , to isolate a signal from a civilization far off in the cosmos .
" Those of us who track SETI believe that there 's a high likelihood of eventually unveiling a signal , " Firmage said .
However , he did n't specify how long " eventually " might take , noting only that , " It might just go on for longer than any of us live . "




The Web : It 's a Women 's Thing

PALO ALTO , California -- In an indication of how much the Internet has evolved from its roots as a male-dominated research medium , a new study shows that women on the Web now outnumber men , and their ranks are growing far faster .
The study , released on Wednesday by Media Metrix and Jupiter Communications , shows strong increases of women using the Internet in the United States in all age groups , except for those between 18 and 24 .
The usage of this age group actually declined from last year .
" Women in the college age group appear to have more offline interests , and more offline business to take care of , " suggests Anne Rickert , a Media Metrix analyst and co-author of the study .
" Everyone has a life offline , but some age groups find their offline lives are better served by online resources .
For the 18 to 24 age group , aside from academics and some shopping , the Web perhaps does not directly relate to their lives . "
Overall , the study found that during the first quarter of 2000 , women and girls made up 50.4 percent of the total U.S. Web audience -- the first time in the history of the Internet that they have outnumbered men .
And going forward , they appear poised to pick up more market shares .
While the total number of Web users grew by 22.4 percent during the past year , the number of female users grew by 34.9 percent .
Particularly strong growth was found among teenage girls .
The study found the number of female Web users between 12 and 17 shot up 125 percent over the past year , a jump that researchers credit to the success of teen-focused sites such as Gurl.com and Kibu.com , which cater to the adolescent yearning for a sense of belonging .
" The Internet is really tailor-made for this , " said Rickert . "
To me , the teen statistics were a real highlight of the study . "
If teens go online for social reasons , as women get older they appear to make more practical use of their time online , often logging on for information about health , childcare , vacations , and financial planning .
The study also found that many consumer product sites , which provide information on a range of items from indigestion medicine to dog food , have disproportionate numbers of female users .
Many women are making the buying decisions for their households , the study suggests .
Across all adult age groups , the list of top women 's websites looks a lot like the choices of the entire population .
America Online 's network of Web properties is the most popular destination among women over 18 , followed by the Microsoft Corp and Yahoo Inc sites .
Although several of the women 's community sites like ClubMom.com , Women.com , and Oxygen.com , reach large numbers of women , the general-interest , gender-neutral Internet portals remain far more popular .
The study 's final surprise is that several women 's community sites like Women.com and iVillage have male users that comprise upwards of 30 percent of their total audience .
" We do have a lot of good generic content , " said Annie Ellicott , vice president of marketing for Women.com .
She suggested men might use women 's sites for games , horoscopes , and " other information that they feel uncomfortable talking about . "
The findings were based on a survey of 55,000 people in the United States .




Strange Reality Streams on Web

First came Road Rules , then Survivor , and then Big Brother .
Is there no end to reality television ?
Now an entrepreneur from Calgary , Alberta , is taking the concept to the Web with the launch Wednesday of an interactive , reality-based webcast channel .
Intertooob.com will go live at 4:50 p.m. MDT with a 24-hours-a-day lineup of more than 50 shows .
They include talk shows , comedies , and newscasts .
The channel 's first show will be Extreme Beings , which features people with outlandish hobbies such as fire juggling .
Preceding the show will be a 10-minute introduction to the channel from company president Christopher Dores , who will explain the Intertooob.com concept .
The shows will be interactive and viewers will periodically receive questionnaires inviting them to direct the action -- changing endings and story lines . "
I want the audience to tell me what kind of shows they 'd like me to build for them , because it 's their channel , " Dores said .
The actors , videographers , digital editors , and screenwriters working on the shows , including Clone Wars and Fred 's Drunken Poets , are volunteering their time .
A staff of 12 , who currently earn about CN$1,000 a month , runs the station .
The show emanates from a studio above a popular watering hole for Calgary 's creative types , The Ship and Anchor , with many of the actors and crew having been recruited from the bar .
Funding for the venture comes from an anonymous Vancouver investor .
Intertooob.com has received sponsorship from Microsoft Canada , which is providing the broadcast software ; and from Calgary 's MaxLink Communications , which is donating wireless broadband access .
" We have funding , but we do n't have cash to burn , " said Dores , who would not reveal how much capital has been raised , or how much the channel costs to produce . "
So I 'm always on a shoestring budget .
The amount we get done with what we have is unbelievable . "
Viewers will tune in using Microsoft 's Media Player and should have either a cable modem or an ISDN line to get a proper feed .
Streaming over a 56K modem , Dores said , will be choppy .
Dores hopes digital commercials -- he calls them webmericals -- will pay for the programming . "
The pricing for these is extremely competitive , even as compared to small market TV advertising , " Dores said .
Like everything else associated with the fledgling webcaster , the marketing budget is tight .
On Monday , Intertooob.com staff plastered Calgary with 12,500 posters showing the company logo , a circle with a line underneath it .
That 's the logo for the first test pattern ever used on television .
The poster campaign may have been a bit too successful .
Shortly after the notices went up , Calgary authorities contacted Intertooob.com and ordered them to remove some .
Dores hopes the streaming webcast will attract some 7,000 viewers in its first couple of days . "
Everybody will want to watch this , " he said . "
It will be hilarious while you 're waiting for your e-mail from Aunt Betsy to download . "
Jordan Worth , a technology analyst with International Data Corporation Canada , is n't as certain about the concept . "
It 's always nice to be in the market early , " he said . "
On the other hand , I 'm not convinced it 's the greatest market to be in for a number of reasons . "
Worth said streaming technology still lacks quality and pointed out that the penetration rate of broadband Internet access is much higher in Canada than in the U.S. , where it encompasses only about 15 percent of the overall market .
The cost of producing webmercials might not be extreme , Worth said , but getting people to watch them could be challenging . "
People will n't necessarily want to use the bandwidth to watch that , " he said .
Still , on the eve of the launch , Dores remained optimistic .
" I understand where I 'm about to go is going to be an amazing journey .
If myself and the people around me are right and do our job , we can effectively change the way people use the Internet for entertainment . "




Napster Cloner Seeks Job

He may have been smart enough to graduate high school two years early , but Jeff Freeman was a little nave about how his self-promotional file-sharing project would be used .
Swapoo , modeled after Napster , has a central server that users can connect to and share video and game files .
Freeman intended the service to be used for freeware file sharing .
Instead , it has turned into a pirate 's tool for gamers , and the industry is paying attention to see if legal action is warranted .
In September 17-year-old Freeman will begin his second year at New Jersey 's Camden County College , where he is majoring in computer science .
He said he wrote Swapoo to highlight his programming abilities , and insists it was meant only for trading freeware .
To make himself as accessible as possible , Freeman posted his resume , phone number , and AOL Instant Messenger name on the Swapoo website .
But with all the attention Swapoo is getting , Freeman 's abilities will be further tested as he scrambles to build in anti-piracy measures .
On Tuesday , he posted an updated beta versions of the client and server software .
" I did n't think the program would get big enough for it to be an issue , " he said . "
When I produced the product , I did so I would have something for an interview on jobs . "
it
He plans to create a database of copyrighted materials , and have the Swapoo program scan all the compressed files on a user 's hard disk for copyrighted material .
Anything that matches up against the database will not be made available for trade .
Freeman now wants to turn Swapoo into a business .
He said he would like to add features for users to pay companies if they want buy copyrighted materials .
Beyond that , he would not give out any details on his business plans .
A lot of the file trading via Swapoo is taken from video game cartridges and CDs , such as Nintendo 's N64 and Sega 's DreamCast .
Game companies and their allies are watching to see if piracy becomes a major problem . "
We watch the whole Internet for these things , " said Charles Bellfield , director of marketing communications at Sega of America , in San Francisco . "
If he stops all copyrighted content from being traded through that site , great . "
Sega 's rival , Nintendo of America , said it is investigating Swapoo , but would not comment further .
The Interactive Digital Software Association , which handles anti-piracy cases for video game companies , is also watching the site , but only offered a prepared statement :
IDSA
" The IDSA is concerned about any technology that facilitates the piracy of copyrighted works . "




File Trading Takes AIM at AOL

A new Napster-like file-sharing program that allows users to trade files with " buddy " groups over America Online 's instant-messaging service was unveiled Tuesday .
Developed by independent programmers and dubbed Aimster , the application appears to enable trading to take place in a more secured environment than either the centralized servers of Napster , where user names can be tracked using software like Media Enforcer , or decentralized networks like Gnutella where end users do n't know the parties who are offering up files for sharing .
Although America Online 's AIM service allows users to send individual files to one another , Aimster adds search and retrieval functions .
The program is designed only for people using AOL instant messaging tools , not for use between AIM users and those using other companies ' software .
" There is huge market potential for tools that allow people and businesses to easily set up private , peer-to-peer networks , " said Jeff Nixon , managing partner for venture capital firm Interactive Capital Partners and who is familiar with Aimster .
" It 's the next natural evolution in personal communications after email and instant messaging , and it helps further unlock the most powerful part of the network -- the knowledge of each person that makes up the network , " Nixon said in a statement .
In 1999 , America Online posted the technical details that enable third parties to communicate with its users , but has routinely blocked companies that have developed compatible services .
The application works with the Windows 95/98 / NT platform .




NZ Cops Stalk Mob -- Virtually

WELLINGTON , New Zealand -- They 're not just the thin , blue line against organized crime : In a small corner of New Zealand , the police are also the thin , blue URL .
In a suburb of New Zealand 's capital city of Wellington , the Mongrel Mob rules the criminal roost .
But tougher laws and a campaign of information about the gang are helping cut the serious crime they commit .
A website , the police in the Wellington suburb of Porirua decided , would be one way to undermine one of the Mongrel Mob gang 's key ways of maintaining criminal supremacy : intimidation .
The website recounts Mongrel Mob history , tells how gang membership -- acquiring the coveted " patch " -- is gained and gives details of the crimes the gang and hangers-on commit .
The website acknowledges the lure of the mainly Mori gang for the suburb 's disaffected and unemployed young , but says " regardless of the unfortunate circumstances that turn young Mori to the Mob , that is no excuse to victimize innocent people in the wider community . "
Potential police informants are urged to have backbone : " The power of the gang to intimidate people into silence will last only as long as we let it , " the website declares .
The gang is unusual in New Zealand : It does not have to compete on its turf with any other gang .
That gives them an impression of omnipotence , but in fact their numbers are relatively few .
The website , says Constable Mark Duncan , " was just to let people know that ... there are only 100 or so , and let 's not give them more attention than they deserve . "
gang members
The Mongrel Mob 's crimes have run the gamut from murders to armed robberies to extortion to rape .
But serious crime has slowed .
A new law has made a crime of witness intimidation .
That , coupled with a police resolve to prosecute with or without witnesses , has helped subdue the gang . "
We have n't seen serious offending for 9-12 months , " Duncan says .
It 's also more difficult for the gang to intimidate the public around the suburb : A law making it an offense to belong to a criminal gang means Mongrel Mob " patches " -- worn by full-fledged members of the gang -- are no longer worn with ease around Porirua streets .
Constable Duncan says the gang has n't completely eschewed crime : " They are by far the biggest dealers in cannabis in the Porirua area , " he said .
And while serious offenses may be down , crime still helps finance the gang .
According to figures on the website , about a quarter of all the crime in Porirua can traced to the gang or their associates .
Duncan and his colleagues set up the Porirua website on their own , well before any official guidelines had been set .
The lack of official imprimatur means the Porirua website has no official domain name and the police officers do all the website work themselves , sometimes having to leave the site without an update for weeks .
But the Porirua police officers could see websites were going to be used more and more by New Zealand police . "
We wanted to be in at the beginning , " Duncan says .
At national headquarters , meanwhile , the powers-that-be are still deliberating .
A national strategy for use of websites " will be developed over the next few months , " according to Susan Milner , who heads up public affairs for New Zealand 's police .
That strategy could encompass everything from paying fines online to displaying crime data .
The Porirua website would probably have to align with a national standard .
Duncan admits his team 's website has n't produced any gang-related tip-offs .
Most email to date has been about local traffic problems .
But the constable is pleased word has got around that the page exists .
For one of the less-affluent suburbs of Wellington , the website is " a bit avant-garde , " he says .
The website , Duncan says , has been " a very , very useful exercise , " despite the lack of gang information . "
You were n't going to break organized crime in one night , " he said .




Getting a Line on Nanochips

The technology may be small , but the advance is big : Scientists at the National Research Council of Canada have come up with a way to grow organic wires for nanoscale devices .
NRC
By prompting organic molecules to line up spontaneously along natural pathways on a silicon crystal , the scientists have taken what they are calling a key step in microchip development .
NRC researchers have fabricated tiny devices that sense and respond to information in their environment .
" We are approaching the limits of standard microchip technology , " said Bob Wolkow of NRC 's Steacie Institute of Molecular Sciences in a statement . "
SIMS
We 're are talking about devices on a scale about 1,000 times smaller than a single bacterium . "
The NRC scientists ' paper , titled Self-directed Growth of Molecular Nano-Structures on Silicon , was published in the July issue of Nature .
Using atoms and molecules , the SIMS team created what is essentially a self-assembling nanoscale wiring system by adding organic matter to silicon devices .
Their calculations show electronic coupling between adjacent molecules , which suggests that some molecular lines could be capable of transmitting signals along a pathway .
The organic wires could offer an alternative to current lithography methods for creating transistors .
Much of the research in this area is predicated on Moore 's Law , which postulates that every 18 months the speed of processors doubles while their size drops by half .
This has led to problems with more conventional lithography methods such as light , which fails to work below a certain size , according to Peter Will , co-director of the Lab for Molecular Robotics at the University of Southern California .
" The obvious thing to do is the end run , " Will said , " and the end run would be some other way of doing connections .
If you could grow the wiring , clearly you 'd get a wire few molecules thick , so you get enormous density and you break the current barrier to Moore 's Law . "
Dan Wayner , an organic chemist and one of the scientists who worked on the project , said they have demonstrated the ability to grow molecules in a line , but the next step is to figure out how to direct them to turn corners .
" If we can learn how to control whether that 's left or right , then you have the basis of a brand-new molecular form of lithography , where you can draw any arbitrary pattern on a surface by understanding the chemistry , " Wayner said .
To create its organic wire , the SIMS team began with a nonreactive silicon surface coated with hydrogen atoms .
Using a scanning tunneling microscope , they plucked off one hydrogen atom , leaving a single atom-sized reaction spot .
Once that dangling bond had been created , they exposed the entire crystal to a gas of styrene molecules , making the bond unstable and causing a chain reaction of grabbing adjacent molecules in a line .
The team 's research showed that exposure to the proper molecule would cause multiple lines to grow simultaneously .
Organic molecules also have the capacity to sense changes in their environment and react to them , giving scientists the opportunity to explore the possibility of making custom devices to perform very specific functions .
Along with surface scientist Bob Wolkow and condensed matter physicist Gregory Lopinski , Wayner began work on growing the organic wires three years ago . "
It 's when you start to mix disciplines in this way , that you really start to push the boundaries , " he said .
Wayner said the idea is still far from having a commercial application and suggested that it would be at least five years before they would be able to make functional components for processing or storing information .
" We expect this is the first hint of how we can go about building in a very controlled way nanostructures on surfaces , and by understanding their chemistry to be able to control and predict their function , " Waymer said . "
We think it 's a serious step forward . "




Dreamcast Seaman : Talk to Papa

I 've been talking to my Dreamcast lately .
Even stranger , it 's been talking back .
My wife thinks I 've lost it , but actually I 'm playing Seaman , a new videogame from Sega .
Seaman is the first interactive title released in North America to utilize microphone technology as its primary player interface .
More of a curiosity than a game , Seaman challenges Dreamcast owners to raise and study a fictitious character who is half man , half fish .
Seaman resides in a virtual aquarium and responds to spoken words , as well as controller-delivered tickles and flicks .
With over 12,000 lines of scripted dialogue , the wisecracking Seaman has the ability to recall past conversations and can vary his responses based on factors such as the age and gender of the player .
Created by noted Japanese designer Yoot Saito , Seaman is somewhat reminiscent of the virtual Tamagotchi pets so popular with children in recent years .
In order to successfully raise their Seaman , Dreamcast users must interact with the fishy character for at least 10 minutes each day over the course of a month .
Benevolent owners will ensure that their charge is properly fed , kept warm , and stimulated with tickling and good conversation .
Negligent Seaman keepers will find that their creature has grown sullen and unresponsive .
The $ 49.99 package includes the Seaman game disk as well as a small microphone that attaches to the Dreamcast controller .
Leonard Nimoy , of Star Trek fame , serves as narrator .
While Seaman is the first microphone-centric game , it certainly will n't be the last .
Nintendo demonstrated Hey You , Pikachu to eager crowds at this year 's Electronic Entertainment Expo in Los Angeles .
Scheduled for November release , Hey You , Pikachu lets Nintendo 64 gamers interact with the ubiquitous yellow Pokemon via bundled microphone .
If you 're beginning to smell a trend here , step to the head of the class .
As low-cost voice-recognition technology continues to improve , there will be numerous potential uses for electronic games .
These have not gone unnoticed by game designers and industry analysts alike .
" Seaman or Hey You , Pikachu are really only early indications of where this technology could go , " said Joe Fielder , site director of ZDNet 's popular GameSpot website .
" Think of how the advanced AI seen in Mindscape 's virtual pet sim Creatures could be applied to an actual game , and you can see a parallel to where voice recognition could possibly be headed , " Fielder said .
" The idea of literally being able to hold conversations with characters in a role-playing game like Final Fantasy is pretty appealing .
To me , talking to a character is n't quite a game , but it could be a great part of one . "
And therein lies the rub .
While some users will be fascinated with Seaman 's snide repartee , there 's not a lot happening much of the time .
Its voice technology is amusing , but Seaman is hardly the kind of game you 'd invite friends over to enjoy with pizza and beer .
Still , it 's fun in an offbeat sort of way , and represents an important historical milestone in gaming .




AOL Axes MP3 Searches

As the battle over intellectual property rights on the Web heats up , America Online has removed the search engine on its Winamp music player that allows users to locate music files in the MP3 format .
" The goal was to add a search function to the Winamp site .
Now that it 's up , we see we do n't have an efficient process for distinguishing between legal and illegal MP3s .
Until we figure out how to address this , we 're going to take the search function down , " said Jim Whitney , a spokesman at AOL , on Thursday .
The search engine function for Winamp , an audio player for downloading and listening to digital music , was implemented a month ago .
The decision to take it down came as the recording industry cracked down on Internet services that made it easier to find pirated music on the Web .
A person close to the matter , said America Online , whose merger with entertainment giant Time Warner is expected to close in the fall , took a look at the search engine as the issue of rights versus free distribution heated up and the possibility of illegal MP3 files turning up in the search gained attention .
AOL
TWX
At the moment AOL does not expect to put any similar search engine back up .
The battle between the Recording Industry Association of America and Internet companies that facilitate the distribution and sharing of music hit a boiling point with the industry 's suit against Napster , a free service that allows Internet users to download digital music files from other people 's computers .
The court battle between the RIAA and Napster is seen as a landmark case that could decide the fate of copyright protection in cyberspace and eventually books , movies , and television .
Time Warner 's Warner Music Group is part of the recording industry group that recently sued MP3 Board , a company that provides links to music-related Web sites and Internet files , to prevent it from linking users to pirated copies of their copyrighted music .
MP3 Board has countersued over the group 's role in shutting down the site .




Taking ' Toxic ' Out of Toxic Waste

OAKLAND , California -- A protest over the release of toxic chemicals at a medical-waste incinerator is aiming to do more than call attention to the environmental dangers .
Organizers say two alternate technologies are safer and already widely available worldwide to process medical waste without toxic air emissions , particularly dioxin .
The emission of even small amounts of dioxin has been linked with cancer and a host of serious health conditions , including autoimmune diseases .
" We have two types of technology available that are not only cleaner and better for the environment , but will also preserve the jobs of workers at the plant , " said Greenaction spokesman Bradley Angel .
The first , autoclaving , uses a steam-heat process to treat the waste .
The second , a microwaving system , shreds and then heats the waste .
Both processes significantly reduce the volume of the waste by up to 80 percent .
The Friday gathering in front of Integrated Environmental Systems ' two medical incinerators in Oakland is part of a larger conference , the Peoples Dioxin Action Summit , from Aug. 10-13 .
Labor , health , environmental , and scientific activists are gathering at UC Berkeley to discuss last month 's report by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency linking dioxin and cancer , and to strategize directions for the future of activism .
IES officials have become accustomed to the presence of protesters in front of their plants and to public criticism in general .
But despite more than 250 citations since 1990 for air quality violations , IES continues to downplay any role autoclaving and microwaving could play in medical-waste incineration .
" Autoclaving and microwaving are approved technologies , and in some cases they 're appropriate , " said Integrated Environmental Systems representative Robert Reed .
Reed said there is no guarantee the steam from autoclaving or the heat of microwaving destroys 100 percent of the infectious products . "
After all , we live in an age of HIV infection , " Reed said .
The argument that dioxin causes not only cancer but creates hormonal fluctuations , suppressed immune systems , and other health problems was given a significant boost last month by the EPA .
Their report linking dioxin with cancer joins existing EPA regulations identifying eight different emissions that medical-waste facilities handling 2 million tons a year have to reduce , including dioxin , mercury , nitrous oxide , sulfur dioxides , particulate matter , hydrochloric acid , and sulfuric acid .
There are more than 100 medical-waste disposal sites using either autoclaving or microwaving , according to Joe Wilson , CEO and president , Sterile Technology Industries , Inc. , one of an estimated 10 autoclaving manufacturers .
Costs vary , but growing criticism and government regulations are likely to make autoclaving and microwaving more attractive options for hospitals or off-site disposal contractors , industry officials predicted .
" Incinerators will just be too costly to keep up with those guidelines , " said Mark Taitz , vice president at microwaving manufacturer Sanitec International .
Microwaving , he said , kills pathogens by shredding the materials and then running them through a series of heating elements . "
It changes the nature of it without creating hazardous air emissions , " said Taitz .
Reed said IES ' emissions of dioxin are " less than 10 percent of what we 're allowed to emit , in one of the toughest air quality districts in the world .
Our emissions are barely detectable . "
Reed attributes the violations to minor events -- including excessive amounts of steam , a monitor that needs to be replaced , or a " paperwork issue , " he said .
A third alternative is truly low-tech technology -- recycling . "
Most of the waste is like household garbage .
It 's mostly packaging , " said Jackie Hunt-Christensen , spokeswoman for Healthcare Without Harm .
The plastic packaging is as responsible for toxic byproducts as the actual incineration is , according to Greenaction .
Hunt-Christensen said many hospitals are already slashing the costs and volume of medical waste simply by using traditional recycling methods : separating packaging from other materials .




E-Clothes Here , So Is Fear

Futuristic thinkers have long predicted the rise of wearable computers able to do everything from communicate body temperature to a room 's air conditioning system to diagnosing certain medical conditions .
Those predictions may become reality next month when the world 's first commercially available electronic clothing hits the European market .
Along with it come concerns about potential health dangers .
The first designs from the ICD+ line , a collaboration between European electronics giant Philips and American clothes manufacturer Levi 's , are four jackets equipped with a Philips-made GSM-standard mobile phone , MP3 player , and a remote-control device to power both .
" We 're looking at a very targeted audience -- the new nomads who are constantly on the move and need to be connected constantly to technology , " says ICD+ spokesperson Neil Stevens . "
This is aimed at the very technologically sophisticated and urban customer who wants functionality , convenience , and simplicity in technology . "
That functionality comes at a high price : from US$ 600 to US$ 900 , costly enough to render them an interesting oddity to all but a few moneyed geeks .
Accordingly , ICD+ is producing only 600 of the jackets and sprinkling the units in select retail stores in Italy , France , Great Britain , Sweden , Germany , and Greece .
But it was the potential bodily effects of tech-integrated clothing that has elicited the most controversy on geek discussion boards and mailing lists .
Some people are concerned about the potential for electric shocks , a hazard Stevens insists is baseless due to the jackets ' waterproof construction .
Yet a more nagging risk lingers .
In the wake of reports and studies that link mobile phone usage to cancer , concentration lapses , and long-term memory loss , many experts are concerned that devices worn in constant proximity to the body may prove even more dangerous .
" This is currently a very hot topic , particularly as more people use wireless devices and use them more often , " says Lawrence Pizzi , director of The Brain Tumor Society . "
So far , studies are not conclusive and no one can say for sure whether or not mobile phones and other devices pose a danger . "
The mobile-phone-cancer controversy was ignited in 1993 , when a Florida man alleged that cell phone use caused his wife 's brain tumor .
Since then , scientists have looked at the rates of brain tumors in humans and studied the effects of cell phone radiation in animals .
" Nothing 's been proven yet , but yes , there are concerns , " says Stephen Fickas , a professor in the Wearables Computer Group at the University of Oregon . "
Wireless technology uses radio frequencies to communicate with a satellite and that emits radiation that 's the center of concern . "
The most recent flap involves a lawsuit filed Aug. 3 by a neurologist with a malignant tumor behind his right ear .
The neurologist , Dr. Chris Newman of Baltimore , claims the mobile phone industry has failed to inform consumers that the high levels of radio frequency radiation produced by mobile phones may cause or contribute to cancer .
Newman bolsters his claim with a 1994 study on rats that showed breaks in DNA -- a possible indication of future cancer -- after the rats were exposed to radiation .
Results of that study have not been replicated , and human trials have so far shown that mobile phone users do not have significantly higher rates of brain cancer .
Nonetheless , studies like the 1994 rat trial , a 1999 study underwritten by the cellular phone industry , and a May 2000 study by Swedish researchers that linked cell phone usage to an increased risk of cancer , continue to worry physicians and consumers .




Intel Pushes Pedal to 2 GHz

SAN JOSE , California -- Intel CEO Craig Barrett is fired up about e-commerce , and has refocused his company on platforms instead of processors .
Fresh off his Montana ranch where he bought 4 bulldozers to fight the wildfires , Barrett barely mentioned the microprocessors in a Tuesday address to developers .
Barrett said his " 100 percent e-company " is focusing on providing hardware for distributing computing and " Napster-like " peer-to-peer applications to let the projected 2 billion connected PCs and wireless devices to share data .
Albert Yu , vice president of the Intel architecture group , unveiled the successor to its popular Pentium III processor -- the Pentium 4 , a wholly redesigned chip that could have PCs running at an astonishing 10 GHz within a few years .
At this year 's gathering , transplanted to San Jose to better accommodate the record crowd of about 5,000 , Intel also introduced speedy new chips for high-end servers and workstations , and is expected to announce a low-power processor for smart phones and handhelds devices .
INTC
The Pentium 4 , which will debut in the fall , runs at 1.4 GHz .
But Yu demonstrated an overclocked chip that topped 2 GHz .
If the Pentium 4 follows Moore 's Law , which dictates that chips double in processing power every 18 months , the Pentium 4 will hit 10 GHz in about 2004 , analysts predict .
" It will play essentially the same role as Al Gore , " said analyst Nathan Brookwood of Insight 64 , a market research firm based in Saratoga , California . "
And that 's to carry on the tradition of the last four years .
Intel hopes it will bring continued prosperity to the PC industry by boosting the Pentium 's performance . "
To get the extra juice , Intel has completely redesigned the chip 's architecture , introducing special sub-systems for turbo-boosting frequently executed commands as well as adding a host of new instructions for enhancing video , audio , and 3-D .
The new processor also includes a 400 MHz system bus , 3 times the speed previous chips .
Yu saved the best for last during his presentation , wowing the subdued audience with a 3-D rendered image of a pool , in which he generated life-like ripples by touching the screen .
The rendering , which was met with hearty applause , included lighting and shadow effects that factored the surrounding trees into the waves .
The Pentium 4 will have 42 million transistors , compared with 26 million in the Pentium III .
" It was really designed for the visual Internet going forward , " said Yu , adding that streaming media on the Internet , real-time video compression , better speech software , and the need for encryption are demanding more performance from microprocessors .
Yu said that even at modem connection speeds of 56 kilobits per second , users would notice a marked increase in performance .




It 'll Be an Open-Source World

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Open-source standards will completely reshape the software industry by 2004 , according to a recent report by Forrester Research .
IBM and Dell will eventually triumph , while Oracle and Microsoft will struggle to cope with a changing marketplace .
Forrester forecasts that within four years , all traditional software vendors will need to change their proprietary business models to open-source ones , or drastically lower the price of enterprise application licenses .
" Proprietary software vendors will suddenly see software development as an unfair fight : their mercenary band of captive developers against a battalion of Internet-armed revolutionaries , " Forrester analysts note dramatically in the report .
" Open Source Cracks the Code " also predicts that IBM will soon regain its position as the " Infrastructure Gorilla " since the company already offers open-source development and support across much of its product lines .
Dell will evolve into a profitable open-source player , with strong support and service offerings , the report said .
Oracle and Microsoft will be hardest hit .
The report predicts that Oracle will n't be able to compete with the widespread emergence of no-cost database and server software and will be forced to open its applications .
But the company will eventually recover by transforming itself into a service/support vendor .
Microsoft will n't be as lucky .
Forrester analyst Carl D. Howe predicts that Microsoft 's business model will clash so severely with the new open-source-fueled development and distribution models that the company 's market share will shrink for the first time in its history .
And eventually , the report forecasts , MS will become little more than a " legacy vendor , " offering support for its antiquated products .
Officials at the four companies detailed in the report could n't immediately be reached for comment .
But George Nobick , a network administrator and Linux developer , was gleeful .
" Hah !
Microsoft may own the desktop now , but we own the future , " he said .




Windows Shuttered at LinuxWorld

SAN JOSE , California -- Embed . Embed . Embed .
That 's the buzzword at the LinuxWorld Conference and Expo here , where startups and industry veterans alike are trying to prove that Linux can run on everything from a wristwatch to an industrial robot .
At the Compaq booth Wednesday , the spotlight was on handhelds .
Three of the company 's iPAQ handhelds graced the platform , looking just like your average Windows-based pocket computer .
" But these are totally stripped of CE , " a Compaq representative beamed , referring to the Microsoft operating system that has no fans at LinuxWorld .

But why would you want Linux on an iPAQ ?
The Compaq rep hesitated .
What sort of question is that ?
Nobody asks Why Linux ? at LinuxWorld because the answer is wafting in the air : You want Linux so you do n't have to deal with Microsoft .
Or , as a software engineer from Monta Vista Software explained it , one should want Linux " to defeat Microsoft . "
Monta Vista was just one of the many " embedded Linux " companies at LinuxWorld .
Such firms help companies get Linux on everyday appliances , from ATM machines to golf carts .
Monta Vista showed off an Internet radio running the Linux OS .
