Biz : The Bot That Will n't Shut Up

AOLiza is n't the only chatbot lurking on America Online 's instant messaging service .
Another " conversation simulator " called BizzaroKiehl , or Biz for short , is gaining a following among AIM users , thanks to the utterly unpredictable things it says .
Run by Tom Kiehl , a computer scientist at General Electric 's R&D lab in upstate New York , Biz converses with up 30 people at a time while it 's logged on .
" When he 's running reliably , people talk with him well into the night , " Kiehl said . "
People come back time after time just to see what random stuff he 'll say next , or to teach him some ' useful ' information about someone else 's sex life or whatever .
People are constantly referring him to friends , and talking to him when they are lonely or bored at work . "
Unlike Kevin Fox 's AOLiza , Biz is n't based on a handful of pre-programmed phrases .
Biz has the ability to learn from its conversations and remembers everything it is told -- hence the desire to teach it about other 's sex lives .
The embarrassing details may emerge in subsequent conversations .
The software looks for keywords in people 's utterances , and depending on the context , regurgitates the sentence or fragments of a sentence , it deems appropriate .
Sometimes the software 's response is dead on , giving the illusion it is intelligent .
But more frequently , the result is garbled nonsense .
Take this exchange from earlier this week :
AIM user : Is your name Chuck ?
BizzaroKiehl : My name is Dan , and my English does n't need as much as the boughs bend .
And I betcha know Humpty 's nose if large .
That 's right , I 'm not interested in your name Chuck .
" While Biz is not as convincingly human , it is definitely more creative and more entertaining to talk to , " Kiehl said . "
as AOLiza
You never know what he 's going to say . "
Biz is based on Jason Hutchens ' MegaHal , the 1998 runner-up in the Loebner Prize , a version of the Turing Test that every year attempts to find the most convincingly " human , " chattering robot .
Available as a free download , Hutchen 's MegaHal was converted by Kiehl and some friends to Java and hooked up to AIM at the beginning of July .
Hutchens said that since he released MegaHal under the GNU public license , it has been downloaded thousands of times .
It is also included in every copy of Debian 's distribution of Linux , and has been converted to the Mac , BeOS , and Amiga .
Hutchens said that in the last six months , he 's received a lot of email from people who tell him about their adventures connecting MegaHal to ICQ , MUDs , and even Usenet .
" All sorts of weird things have been done with MegaHal , " Hutchens said . "
People send it a week 's worth of postings from a Usenet newsgroup , get it to generate something random and post it back to the newsgroup .
" It usually has some degree of relevance but is garbled in a weird way , " he said . "
They get a payoff when someone falls for it and thinks it 's a real person . "




Emulex Victims : Who Can We Sue ?

With the manhunt for the perpetrator of the Emulex fraud apparently over , investors burned by the company 's $ 2 billion post-fraud swing are now hunting for someone , anyone , to sue for legal damages .
Two lawsuits have already been filed , one against Internet Wire , which originally distributed the bogus press release , and one against both Internet Wire and Bloomberg , the financial news service that sent out a story based on the press release .
Lawyers say it 's only a matter of time before scores of individual stockbrokers get sued , too .
And let 's not forget Nasdaq , which some have criticized for the way it handled the trading halt in Emulex shares .
And Emulex itself might even be sued for failing to ensure that its correspondence with Internet Wire could n't be effectively aped , lawyers said .
EMLX
Still , despite the big stock losses and investors ' understandably hard feelings , legal experts say there 's not much chance that any of the aforementioned parties will be held legally liable for any part of the Emulex fiasco .
" For Internet Wire and Bloomberg , there 's no legal duty to make sure that what they print is accurate , unless they have some clear reason to know it 's not accurate , " said Jason Epstein , an Internet lawyer with the Washington , D.C. , law firm Baker Donelson Bearman & Caldwell .
Publishers of all stripes -- print , wire , or Internet -- are n't held legally liable for unwittingly printing inaccuracies , because if they were , they 'd be reluctant to publish anything at all and free speech would suffer .
If publishers knowingly print false information , they can be held liable , but in the Emulex case , Internet Wire and Bloomberg both apparently believed the information to be true when they published it .
Even if publishers were n't protected by reams of First Amendment-related case law , Emulex investors would have a very difficult time proving that Internet Wire or Bloomberg have any legal fiduciary duty to investors , lawyers said .
There 's no contract between a news service and its readers that guarantees sound financial information .
In a famous case in the 1980's , the Wall Street Journal was sued for publishing wrong information about bond prices .
The plaintiffs , who apparently lost money as a result of the bad info , also lost their suit .
Upshot : " Any suit against will be a very weak suit , " said Geoffrey Stewart , a securities lawyer with Jones Day Reavis & Pogue in Washington , D.C.
Internet Wire and Bloomberg
Brokers that advised clients to sell based on the Bloomberg report probably will n't be called to account either , lawyers said .
Although brokers , unlike news services , clearly have a legal duty to their clients , investors would be hard-pressed to prove that their brokers acted negligently in the Emulex case .
" If the broker 's relying on the normal , trusted information service he uses , you can n't fault him , " said Stewart .
In the age of instant news dissemination and instant market reaction , a broker who waits for a company to verify news published by trusted source before advising a client would normally lose his client a lot of money .
In the 99.99 percent of cases where news is n't a hoax , the broker would be negligent not to act quickly .




The Michelangelo of Lego

There are a lot of unusual jobs , but very few people put bread on the table by sculpting Lego bricks .
But thanks to the enduring lure of the brightly colored building blocks , especially among the technology crowd , Eric Harshbarger is beginning to carve out a niche as a professional Lego artist .
Lego are n't just for kids .
The Lego Users Group Network , the largest community of adult Lego builders on the Net , has about 10,000 members worldwide and receives 100,000 visitors to the site every year .
Lugnet has started 700 newsgroups devoted to the art and science of Lego building .
Ostensibly , that bodes well for Harshbarger 's Lego artistry .
" My hobby of making Lego sculptures is turning into a source of part-time income , " said the 29-year native of Auburn , Alabama , who still makes most of his revenue from contract programming . "
Maybe one day it will make me more money than coding . "
Harshbarger is on his way .
Since going through his " Lego renaissance " last summer -- the period when Legophiles rediscover their childhood passion -- he has sold dozens of large-scale sculptures .
His latest creation is a 35,000-piece Lego desk for a Seattle e-commerce company , which wanted the desk to lure a new employee it was keen to hire .
The desk was even written into the worker 's employment contract , Harshbarger said .
" They were frantic , " Harshbarger said . "
After seven or eight months they had n't found anyone to build it .
Evidently , it was n't as easy to find someone as they had hoped . "
Declining to provide details about the company or the employee , Harshbarger said the employee was always being teased at his previous job for his ever-overflowing inbox .
He would jokingly retort that he could make a bigger inbox if he had a desk made of Lego .
But Harshbarger said he suspects the employee wanted a desk he could build models on .
" I offered to make the desktop smooth , so he could write on it , " Harshbarger said . "
But he wanted the bumps left exposed . "
In the three months it took to make , Harshbarger built a full-sized prototype , finalized the design with the company , and then disassembled it and rebuilt it with glue .
" I took it apart one piece at a time and glued it back together one piece at a time , " he said . "
All 35,000 pieces . "
The desk cost $ 2,000 in bricks alone , though Harshbarger said he charged the company considerably more to make it .
It weighs 125 pounds and was shipped to Seattle this week at a cost of $ 800 .
" Let 's hope it arrives in one piece , " Harshbarger said .
While the desk is his biggest commission , Harshbarger 's most popular design is a model of the Linux Penguin .
He 's sold about half a dozen , though he says he would have sold more if not for the price .
" People think it 's going to be $ 50 , not $ 500 , " he said . "
They do n't understand how much time and energy goes into these things . "
Harshbarger has built sculptures of Alice in Wonderland , R2D2 , the Earth , and seven-foot grandfather clocks .
The clocks are made entirely of Lego , including the time-keeping mechanism .
With about 5,000 pieces , they cost between $ 2,000 to $ 2,500 .
" It 's my favorite , " he said . "
Technically and mechanically it 's quite an achievement . "
Harshbarger , who is single , said he is running out of room at his house for his sculptures .




Tech Workers ' Burn ' Out of Town

The automated out-of-office replies have been written .
The Palm VIIs are tucked neatly in their cradles .
Cellphones ?
Who needs them ?
An estimated 28,000 new media bohemians and their hairdressers have descended on Burning Man 's playa in the Black Rock Desert of Nevada , leaving their dot-com jobs on autopilot until the last glowing cinder turns to ash .
" Our entire office will be shutting down for Burning Man as of Wednesday , " said Dawn Andreas , a producer for the six-person S.F. Orange Design Inc. "
We made this decision months ago and have planned all our jobs around being gone during this week . "
While most do n't close up shop completely , few Bay Area high-tech companies are left untouched by the week-long festival , now in its 14th year .
It 's not just wage-slaves who are attending .
A number of CEOs are expected , including Webby Awards founder Tiffany Shlain , Google creators Sergey Brin and Larry Page , and Brian Behlendorf of Organic , a company with roots in the Bay Area rave scene .
" Organic basically shuts down .
I 've never seen anything like it .
About a week beforehand , the mental exodus starts , " recalled a former staff member at the Web development agency , who requested anonymity . "
People spamming to the junk list so everyone knows where to find them in their camps .
...
The elaborate planning far surpasses any semblance of production work I witnessed at any time while working there last year . "
One-third of Get-Topica 's 100-person staff , including its P.R. director , has already set up camp in Nevada .
Staffers at Productopia were treated to the sight of their product management director struggling to set up her tent in the office .
" She 's never camped before , " Productopia P.R .
Manager Melissa Sheridan explained .
" We have five or six people out of 150 who went to Burning Man , " Listen.com spokesman Sean Garrett said . "
It 's impacting us because we do n't have a copy editor for this week , but I do n't suppose that 's any different from any random vacation . "
Small companies will obviously be hit harder than large ones , and certain departments are certainly more susceptible to Burning Man absences . "
I would think that marketing types would be less likely to attend Burning Man .
I hope so , " said Gina Sanfilippo , a LAN administrator with TechTV , who is attending for the second time .
But while dot-com absences number in the thousands this week , rumors of a city-wide industry brownout -- as reported this week in the San Francisco Examiner and USA Today -- have been greatly exaggerated .
" Of course , a number of employees are attending .
By no means does that stop Organic 's work or work week or anything like that , " Organic 's Laura Uribarri said .
" It 's business as usual here at Topica , " added an employee there , who asked not to be named .
The Examiner reported that some departments at Critical Path all but shut down for the festival . "
That 's totally untrue , " said Sharon Wienbar , the global messaging company 's vice president of marketing .
Julie Brodeur , who works in Critical Path 's technical publications department , said she only knew of one person in her immediate group who was going . "
We are n't all Playa-cyber-hippies , " she quipped .
Companies finding themselves short on employees this week should weigh the costs and benefits before cracking down on Burning Man absences , advises Bruce Tulgan , a management consultant and author of the book Managing Generation X.
" In an economy where employers are short-staffed and scrambling to hire enough people to get all the work done , this plays in two ways , " he said . "
On the one hand , an employer who has good people and they want to take a week off to go to this festival does n't want to make this a deal-breaker .
On the other hand , it 's frustrating and difficult to have a number of people out at a time . "
Tulgan also cautions that experiences shared between colleagues at Burning Man could create interoffice tension later on . "
On the one hand you could say , this would be an outside-the-box corporate culture experience , " he says . "
But you have to be careful about crossing the line .
When you go back to work together , have you shared an experience that makes it uncomfortable to go back ? "




The Future of File Trading

Sharing files might be all the rage on the Internet , but creating a viable business model around file trading applications has proven to be very difficult .
On Monday , Scour Inc. laid off 52 of its 70 employees after failing to obtain additional financing , which it sorely needs as it tries to fend off legal challenges from both the recording and motion picture industries .
Dan Rodrigues , Scour 's president , tried to sound upbeat .
" We remain hopeful that our dispute will come out the same way that the original David and Goliath battle did , " Rodrigues said in a statement .
The Scour website offers a multimedia search engine along with its Scour Exchange file trading application that allows users who download the program to trade files with others on the network .
The Recording Industry Association of American and the Motion Picture Association of America filed a copyright infringement suit against Scour on July 20 .
Despite the suit , Rodrigues believed that neither of the major entertainment organizations had developed an antagonistic relationship with Scour .
" We have intentionally not created a high profile for ourselves and been antagonistic to the industries , " Rodrigues said in a interview with Wired in July . "
When we went to these companies , we told them they we wanted to be the technology solution for their concerns .
Right now , they prefer the litigation strategy , but I hope this is just part of the negotiation process . "
At present , the suit does n't appear to be a part of the negotiating process and the future of Scour remains very much in doubt .
But finding a way to capture even a portion of the 25 million registered Napster users is a compelling reason for companies to continue to search for viable file-trading business models , despite the specter of a lengthy , and expensive , court battle .
Even Intel has been linked with a new file-trading appilication called Aimster , which piggybacks on America Online 's Instant Messaging service .
INTC
AOL
The network has already attracted nearly a million AOL users since the program was launched Aug. 8 .
While efforts to establish viable and litigation-free companies in America have been largely unsuccessful , an Australian executive is working on a plan that he hopes will solve many of the inherent copyright issues that have plagued file trading applications .
Channeling advertising revenues to artists and musicians from free music search engines and download sites could help solve some of the copyright issues involved in online music file swapping , says an Australian CD retailing entrepreneur .
Rob Appel , founder and CEO of Sydney-based ChaosMusic , is doing just that .
Since early August , he has been setting aside 15 percent of gross advertising revenues from Chaos ' Freetracks music search engine for eventual distribution to artists whose music is downloaded .
" We need to shift the focus from control to commercializing what 's going on , " Appel says . "
The 15 percent we 've seen as just a kind of minimum benchmark to introduce the concept . "
At present , the kitty amounts to only several thousand dollars .
But with traffic on the retailer 's free music search engine growing at roughly 50 percent every month , the amounts set aside for artists could grow significantly over time , he says .
Right now , the money is being held in a trust account until a means of distributing it equitably is worked out .
For his part , Appel hopes the funds will be disbursed by an organization like the Australasian Performing Rights Association , Australia 's copyright collection agency .
Richard Mallett , APRA 's director of broadcast and online licensing , says he 's intrigued by Appel 's idea , particularly since it 's one of the few constructive compromises to surface since the Napster controversy entered the public consciousness .
" We 'd much prefer this sort of dialogue coming from those involved in swapping of online music , rather than people just saying ' we 're going to do this no matter what , and not pay anything to anybody , ' " Mallett said .
While Appel 's proposal is n't ideal , it at least recognizes that online exchanges of copyrighted music should not be free , Mallett said .
And 15 percent of something may be better than 100 percent of nothing , especially if it serves to bolster the principle of copyright in cyberspace , he added .
" If you devalue intellectual property online to where you do n't pay for it , it may be good for today 's generation , but in the end there 'll be no incentive to artists to create new music , " Mallett said . "
Future generations will have less and less to choose from . "
Appel 's proposal will be discussed later this month by the Australasian Mechanical Copyright Owners Society , the unit within APRA representing the specific interests of music publishers and writers in Australia and New Zealand .
Both Mallett and Appel acknowledge music file swapping is already so entrenched it will be hard to stop completely , so the issue now is living with the genie .
Given the rapid increase in online music swapping , Appel says new ideas are sorely needed .
" Artists who were energized by the Internet have become disillusioned , because they believe the Web has given them so little back after taking so much , " he said . "
Our hope now is to generate a business model on this new reality in which everyone can win . "
One high-profile backer is Microsoft Australia , which has kicked in several thousand dollars to help the plan get off the ground , said Frank Arrigo , Microsoft Australia 's business development manager for Windows Media Technologies .
" As best I can tell , this ChaosMusic plan is novel , " Arrigo said . "
I have n't seen anything like it done elsewhere . "
For its part , Microsoft has created a music file format called Windows Media Audio .
Embedded in the format is technology that could be used to attribute copyright monies more precisely to individual artists .
As such , any file swapping system that bolsters music copyright protection in cyberspace could benefit the WMA format and its chief backer , Microsoft .
Back out in file swapper land , Appel 's idea has sparked predictable controversy .
One poster on Freetracks ' own discussion board , identified only as " Starving Musician , " sees Appel 's plan as merely a convenient corporate subterfuge to muscle in on Napster 's turf .
" There is no way you can correctly distribute these royalties to the deserving artists from such a flimsy concept , " wrote Starving Musician . "
I really see Freetracks as only one step removed from Napster , ultimately ripping off us starving artists struggling to make a living . "
However , another poster , identified as " KZ5 " and claiming to be another Australian musician , was more upbeat .
" We are a small , independent band and it is very hard to compete with record companies ' promotion and advertising budgets , " KZ5 wrote . "
The Internet is giving bands like us some even ground .
Any advancements in the realm of creating royalties can only be a good thing .
Keep up the good work Chaos . "
Appel founded ChaosMusic in 1995 as an Australian online music retailer .
The company listed on the Australian Stock Exchange in December 1999 .
ASX:CHS
Brad King contributed to this report




Tech Sex Is Great (Ab)Normalizer

LINZ , Austria -- Not too many people , least of all scientists , would argue against the notion that science needs help from other quarters in understanding the sweeping cultural changes unfolding as science and technology become the great theme of 21st century life .
What the 21st annual Ars Electronica festival on the banks of the Danube River has dared to claim is that artists are at least as equipped as anyone else to offer science the help it so badly needs .
As the two-day Next Sex symposium wrapped up on Monday evening , this somewhat bold idea seemed more viable -- and more intriguing -- than ever .
The point may have been best made by a sociologist .
Joanne Finkelstein , an Australian , gave an intelligent , funny presentation Monday morning that proved unmistakably the limited efficacy of sociology in helping out on crucial and timely questions of the day .
Finkelstein , author of " Slaves of Chic " and " The Fashioned Self , " was not without insight , of course .
Discussing the dramatic increase in people having sexual experiences via the Internet , she noted : " Instances of technology providing substitutes for the real thing are too popular to be called substitutes .
They ARE the real thing . "
Hear , hear .
But Finkelsteins core message , delivered after a brief tour of the Kinsey Report , the Hite Report , and Foucault , was that even by studying great populations of people , sociology can not tell you much about the interior mysteries of the human sexual experience .
ha ha !
ha !
all hail !
Thanks for the honesty .
Artists , in contrast , seemed to have a lot to offer .
That was especially true of the appearance a day earlier of Natacha Merritt , who grew up in San Francisco and has become somewhat renowned for images she makes of herself that tend to draw strong reactions .
Merritt brings her digital camera into the bedroom in the most literal sense , and talked with such deadpan honesty about the experience , many in the crowd were taken aback .
What was clear was that her " Digital Diary " and her frank talk about her sexual appetites offered insights into a reality many or most in the post-industrial , tech-savvy world can understand , whether they want to admit it or not .
Sergio Messina , an engaging Italian electronic musician and journalist , gave a thorough presentation on the thriving sexual community online .




Mad Mac Users Target Jobs

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
A self-proclaimed " guerrilla group " of Mac users plans to disrupt the keynote speech of Apple CEO Steve Jobs at the Apple Expo in Paris later this month .
The protest is scheduled for Sept. 13 , the day Apple is slated to release the public beta of Mac OS X.
AAPL
According to an email credited to the " Expo Protest Team " that was sent to Wired News , the group will be griping about three key issues : Apple 's treatment of its users , the company 's legal threats against websites and people who release information about Apple products before a product 's official release , and Apple 's treatment of its European customers , particularly those in the Great Britain .
The email says that the planned protest will take the form of an " alternative " speech by team members that will be delivered " in the middle " of Job 's keynote speech .
According to an anonymous email sent by a person who claimed to be a member of the group , the protesters will " have a number of people planted in the audience , so that as one protesting speech-giver is ushered from the room , another will pop up to take his or her place , and so on .
" Every single member of the group will know the full text of the speech we want to deliver and we will have a sufficient number of people there to ensure that our message is heard , " the email warned .
Piers Brown-Hill , a London-based Apple IT supervisor , said he 's spoken with members of the group , who contacted him asking for support during the protest .
" They are upset about Apple 's threats to take legal action against ' gossip sites ' and are particularly upset over the cancellation of U.K.-based expos and events , " Brown-Hill said .
" They feel that the U.K. event was cancelled in favor of holding an event in Paris , which has a small number of Mac users compared to the U.K. community .
And they are also upset the lack of a U.K.-specific version of the Mac operating system , " Brown-Hill said .
over
John Davies , a computer repair technician in London who plans to attend the Paris Expo , believes that many would welcome an " English , not American " version of the Mac operating system , and agreed that Apple has been " rather snarky " with its users lately .
But he does n't support the protest .
" There are better ways to handle this , " Davies said . "
Interrupting Jobs ' speech will just get people annoyed at the protesters .
Jobs gives brilliant speeches , and the protesters may be clubbed like baby seals if they dare to interrupt his spiel . "
But it seems that the group is particularly set upon interrupting Jobs ' keynote .
The text of the group 's email accused Apple -- and Jobs in particular -- of growing " arrogant " and not recognizing the loyalty of the users who " stuck with the company during the dark years . "
" Apple needs to realize it is in a unique position within the computer market , in as much as it has fans as well as customers , " the email said . "
Apple needs to adapt the way it deals with these people and find some other way of dealing with them other than sending in the lawyers . "
The group promises a peaceful protest , with " no throwing of rotten apples . "




MP3.Com Must Pay the Piper

NEW YORK -- A federal judge ruled Wednesday that MP3.com willfully engaged in thousands of acts of copyright infringement when it created an 80,000-album , digital database that allowed users to stream music from its servers .
U.S. District Judge Jed S. Rakoff said that MP3.com knowingly violated copyrights when it created its my.mp3.com service .
With damages to the company assessed at $ 25,000 per CD , MP3.com could be out by roughly $ 118 million .
Universal , the lone plaintiff remaining in the case , had submitted claims on 10,000 albums .
Nasdaq halted trading in MP3.com shares at 1:54 in advance of the court ruling .
MP3.com began trading again in the after hours market and promptly plunged 32.5 percent to an all-time low of $ 5.31 .
MPPP
Rakoff noted that while he could have awarded as much as $ 150,000 per CD , he chose to impose damages of a significantly smaller amount because MP3.com had acted " more responsibly than other Internet startups , " a likely reference to Napster , which also is fighting a copyright infringement lawsuit .
" The decision is n't shocking , " said Harold Shapiro , a copyright lawyer who has been following the case closely .
" And it will n't kill MP3.com , " said Shapiro , noting that the company recently set $ 150 million aside in order to pay the expected damages .
But Shapiro said it is absolutely crucial that MP3.com establishes a licensing agreement with Universal .
" Universal has a huge song catalog .
MP3.com can survive this judgment , but it can not survive a continued battle with Universal , " he said . "
They have to come to terms . "
Despite damages being less draconian than the $ 450 million that Universal 's lawyers urged the judge to award , MP3.com attorney Michael Rhodes said that the company would appeal the decision .
He said MP3.com simply " built technology that lets people listen to their own CD collections . "
A trial to determine the specific number of CDs that MP3.com made available to its users is set to begin Nov. 13 .
" We&rsquo;re obviously pleased with today&rsquo;s ruling , said Cary Sherman , senior vice president and general counsel of the Recording Industry Association of America . "
This should send a message that there are consequences when a business recklessly disregards the copyright law . "
MP3.com has challenged the validity of Universal 's hold on song copyrights .
Yet another trial will be held to determine exactly which copyrights Universal holds .
The outcome of Wednesday 's trial seemed decided a week ago , when Rakoff cut short MP3.com 's cross-examination of Seagram CEO Edgar Bronfman Jr.
Seagram is the parent company of Universal Music Group .
MP3.com 's defense hinged on the fact that Seagram refused to settle its copyright infringement suit so that the major label could put the music company out of business .
Rakoff determined that the motives of Bronfman and Seagram did not justify MP3.com 's actions .
Universal Music Group , which has an equity stake in a potential MP3.com competitor , Musicbank , is the last remaining plaintiff in the copyright infringement suit brought by the Recording Industry Association of America on behalf of the five major labels .
Wednesday 's decision came months after Rakoff ruled that MP3.com violated copyrights by creating its my.mp3.com service without first obtaining licenses from record labels and song publishers .
The other labels -- EMI , Warner Music , BMG , and Sony -- reached settlement agreements with MP3.com .
The terms of those agreements have not been disclosed , but reports had the company paying a reported $ 20 million to each label .
Included were licensing provisions that would have the company pay 1.5 cents per song stored by people in virtual lockers , and one-third of a cent each time a song is streamed .
The deals would allow MP3.com to use music from four of the major labels in its my.mp3.com service , although the company still has a pending lawsuit with the music publishers to settle as well .




U.S. , Russia Sign Plutonium Pact

WASHINGTON , DC -- The United States and Russia have signed an agreement to turn tons of weapons-grade plutonium into fuel for nuclear reactors .
Critics at the independent Nuclear Control Institute say the pact is " premature and dangerous , " and could lead to increased risk of nuclear proliferation or terrorist capture of bomb materials .
On Friday , Vice President Al Gore signed the United States-Russian Federation Agreement on behalf of the United States .
The agreement , announced in Moscow in June by U.S. President Bill Clinton and Russian President Vladimir Putin , aims to turn excess weapons-grade plutonium into forms that can not be used for weapons .
Russian Prime Minister Mikhail Kasyanov had already signed the agreement , which took effect Sunday with Gores signature .
" This accomplishment advances the critical task of reducing stockpiles of excess weapons plutonium and contributes to key U.S. arms control and non-proliferation objectives , " says a White House statement .
But the Nuclear Control Institute , a Washington , DC based independent research and advocacy center specializing in issues of nuclear proliferation , says the agreement only delays the day of reckoning for the excess plutonium .
NCI
" This agreement kicks the tough decisions about plutonium disposition down the road , " said Paul Leventhal , president of NCI . "
If the safeguards and liability questions could have been resolved easily , they would have been .
The complicating factor in all this is both nations insistence on using warhead plutonium as fuel in nuclear power plants . "
The agreement requires that each country dispose of 34 metric tons of weapons-grade plutonium -- enough for thousands of nuclear weapons .
Most of the plutonium will be turned into mixed-oxide fuel and irradiated in nuclear reactors .
MOX
The balance will be combined with high level radioactive wastes , and disposed of in permanent underground repositories .
The U.S. intends to use 25.5 tons as fuel and immobilize 8.5 tons for disposal .
The Russian Federation intends to use all 34 tons as fuel .
" With strong technical support , the alternative of directly disposing of weapons plutonium by immobilizing it in highly radioactive waste would be faster , cheaper and safer than using it as fuel in reactors , " noted NCI research director Steven Dolley . "
It would be much easier to resolve safeguards and liability issues if the primary disposition method were to immobilize plutonium in waste rather than turn it into fuel . "
The new agreement does not resolve , but merely calls for further negotiations on questions related to liability in case of a MOX fuel accident , safeguarding and monitoring of disposition , and financial assistance arrangements , NCI charges .
The U.S. has pledged $ 200 million to help Russia implement the agreement , but millions more in funding has not been secured .
" Without settling these issues , the agreement is clearly premature , " said Tom Clements , NCI executive director . "
Plutonium disposition will not proceed in either nation , and stubborn insistence on the complex and risky plutonium fuel approach will be to blame . "
Both countries will need to build new industrial-scale facilities to convert the plutonium into fuel or immobilize it with other wastes .
By 2007 , these facilities must be converting or disposing of two metric tons per year , the agreement says .
Both countries must seek to at least double that rate , although there is no timeline set for this part of the pact .
Under the agreement , the process of converting or immobilizing the plutonium as well as the end products created will be subject to international monitoring .
Any additional plutonium that either country designates as " excess " to national defense needs will fall under the same program , so the final total could be more than 68 tons of plutonium .
" Plutonium advocates worldwide view this program as a shortcut to reviving a plutonium industry now in decline , and introducing this dangerous fuel into U.S. nuclear power reactors after it was abandoned two decades ago , " said NCIs Leventhal . "
This program could become a model for other nations that covet plutonium for civilian applications that easily can be diverted for military use . "

Peapod Cuts Back , Expands

Peapod Inc. , an online grocery delivery service in the midst of a corporate turnaround , said it is shutting down operations in four cities and opening up shop in Washington , DC .
On Thursday , the Skokie , Illinois company announced that it agreed to buy assets of grocery delivery competitor Streamline.com for $ 12 million .
Executives said the purchase will allow Peapod to move into Washington , DC and expand in Chicago .
At the same time , Peapod announced that it is closing its delivery service in Columbus , Ohio as well as in Austin , Houston , and Dallas .
Executives said they did not think the company could turn a profit in those cities , where instead of relying on a central warehouse , Peapod employees purchased groceries at local stores and delivered them to customers ' homes .
" We do n't believe the future is in in-store picking , " said Peapod President and CEO Marc van Gelder . "
We believe in a centralized distribution model . "
Peapod 's move to expand in new markets and shut down in others is part of a long-term effort by the money-losing firm to turn around its financial fortunes by developing a cheaper , more efficient system for filling orders .
This past spring , Peapod was perched on the brink of collapse .
PPOD
The abrupt departure of its former CEO and failure to obtain an expected round of venture capital investment left the company almost out of cash .
But in late April , the company got a fresh infusion of cash and support from a major industry player , grocery holding company Royal Ahold .
The company , which owns Stop And Shop and a host of other supermarket assets , invested $ 73 million in Peapod in exchange for a majority ownership stake .
Over the last four months , Royal Ahold and Peapod have been moving the grocery delivery service away from a personalized shopping and focusing on using warehouses and storage space in Ahold-owned stores to stock goods for Peapod customers .
Van Gelder said Peapod chose to exit markets in Texas and Columbus largely because Ahold did n't have stores and storage space in those cities that the company could use .
Executives said the closures would affect only a small percentage of Peapod 's customers , who numbered 135,000 at mid-year .
In addition , the company will ship products via mail to customers in the cities it is leaving , as part of a nationwide service .
The announcements had a modest impact on Peapod 's stock .
Shares rose 3.3 percent , or 6 cents in afternoon trading to $ 2.06 .
Shares of the company have been hovering close to $ 2 since April .




Pop Go the Hollywood Dot-Coms

LOS ANGELES -- In Hollywood , people like to say it 's all about who you know .
But even dropping the biggest names in Tinsel Town , such as Steven Spielberg , Ron Howard or David Geffen , is n't enough to salvage a sinking entertainment dot-com company .
In the latest installment in a saga that could be a miniseries called " The Rise and Fall of Hollywood Web Sites , " two companies -- Pop.com and Shockwave.com , which had touted big celebrity ties -- confirmed on Wednesday they had laid off staff .
Pop.com , the would-be Web site backed by filmmakers Steven Spielberg , Ron Howard and other Hollywood moguls confirmed it had laid off most of its staff , which industry sources said presumably meant pulling the plug on the troubled upstart .
" Although the Internet continues to represent an exciting creative opportunity for us , the market has shifted dramatically since our original announcement , resulting in this being a less viable business for us , " a spokeswoman for Pop.com said .
" We will retain a small staff to maintain our creative endeavors .
At this time , we have not made a decision regarding distribution of the original content we produced or acquired , " she said .
Lawrence Levy , chief executive of Shockwave.com , which has created some online programs with stars like Tim Burton , Jim Belushi , James L. Brooks and Ben Stein , said it cut back on costs and has laid off about 20 out of 170 employees .
" This is a challenging time for everybody in this space , " said Levy . "
The market 's going through a very healthy shakeout and we 'll be left with the companies that drive this medium and will become the major brands two to three years from now , " he said . "
It 's a matter of getting focused and efficient . "
Indeed , sources said Pop.com , which never aired a single show , had been plagued by infighting and uncertainty about the company 's direction and business plan .
The formation of Glendale , California-based Pop.com was announced in October with much fanfare by its famous founders , which include Spielberg ; Jeffrey Katzenberg ; David Geffen of DreamWorks ; Imagine Entertainment 's Howard and Brian Grazer ; and Vulcan Ventures , the investment vehicle for Microsoft 's co-founder Paul Allen .
In a last-ditch effort , Pop.com had recently entered into talks to merge with popular entertainment Webcaster Ifilm , but those negotiations collapsed by last Friday without a deal .
" Nobody in this space has really found the magic or killer application yet and just because someone is good at making movies does n't mean they 're good at making Web sites , " said Malcolm Maclachlan , analyst with International Data Corp.
" Attaching a bunch of famous people to a Web site is not going to make it successful , " he said .
Levy of Shockwave said he has been taking a hard look at the company since he joined three months ago . "
We 've come to the conclusion on how to create a viable business over next 12 months to 18 months , " he said , adding that Shockwave will continue focusing on original content and interactive games , but will also look outside the company for content .
" We 'll make some of the content ourselves through our own Shockwave studio , but we 'll also go out and do deals with talent and creative developers , " he said .
Experts said that many of the online entertainment companies have failed because they have just tried to repackage traditional content for the Internet .
" Your content has to leverage the new medium .
You can n't just republish content made for other mediums and then put it on the Web .
It has to have interactivity and a community , " Levy said .
The list of troubled Hollywood dot-coms goes on .
Back in June , Digital Entertainment Network filed for bankruptcy and is now being investigated for possible fraudulent asset sales prior to its filing .
DEN
And Scour , an online multimedia company backed by Hollywood power broker Michael Ovitz , late last week announced that a pending copyright infringement lawsuit filed against it by the film and music industries has scared off potential investors and prompted it to lay off 52 of its 70 employees .
Two trade groups filed the suit against Scour on behalf of more than 20 companies , including the film and music arms of such giants as Sony Pictures , Time Warner Inc. and the Walt Disney Co.




Amex Deals Disposable Credit

On Thursday , American Express announced Private Payments , a new program which allows consumers to buy online without transmitting their real credit card numbers over the Internet .
For each online purchase , the customer receives a random number that expires after the transaction .
Private Payments is the latest attempt to foil Internet fraud and encourage safety-concerned consumers to spend their dollars online .
" Consumers have a real fear of having their credit card stolen , " said Alfred F. Kelly , Jr. , group president of U.S. consumer and small business services at American Express . "
AXP
This fear is the biggest obstacle for a real boom in e-commerce . "
New York-based American Express also said that it will work with digital privacy company Privada Inc. on a second product that will let consumers choose how much information to reveal when browsing the Web .
Kelly declined to offer details on what it calls its " Private Browser " program , but said the two services will be part of a series of initiatives aimed at addressing Internet security and privacy .
Private Payments will be available next month to American Express consumer and small business cardholders in the United States .




Sega Seeks Net Profits

Sega is betting big that gamers would much rather frag their friends than kill off random alien beings .
The company , which is third to Nintendo and Sony in the competitive console gaming market and faces a looming threat in Microsoft 's X-Box , hopes that Net-enabling their products will put them back on a winning streak .
During Thursday night 's MTV Video Music Awards , the video-game company behind the critically acclaimed Dreamcast system will unveil SegaNet , the centerpiece of a comprehensive online strategy intended as a pre-emptive strike against the October 26 North American launch of Sony 's PlayStation 2 system .
SegaNet is a full-fledged Internet service , offering standard functions such as Web access and email .
For gamers , however , SegaNet 's allure is online competition with hotly anticipated Dreamcast titles such as pro football sim NFL2K1 , first-person shooter Quake III Arena , and role-playing adventure Phantasy Star Online .
Sega 's service will also offer chat rooms , cheat codes , and other game-oriented content .
Gamers who opt out of SegaNet can continue to access its game lobbies via their current service provider .
Although computer gamers have been playing titles like Age of Empires and Unreal Tournament on the Net for years , online gaming is virgin territory for most of the console crowd .
" Our aim , " said Charles Bellfield , Sega 's director of marketing and corporate communications " is to get the play ability patterns of the consumer into a different mode , to get them used to going online through a console , and get them used to playing against their friends . "
Initially available only in the 48 contiguous states , SegaNet will cost $ 21.95 per month .
That makes it one of the more pricey ISPs , but Sega will rebate the full price of a Dreamcast purchase to gamers who sign on for an 18-month hitch .
Speaking of that Dreamcast price , Sega slashed it by $ 50 last week , to $ 149 .
Even without the rebate , that 's roughly half of what PlayStation 2 will sell for at launch .
While Sony executives have repeatedly taken the position that PlayStation 2 will support broadband Internet access sometime in the future , Dreamcast owners will be able to connect to SegaNet and begin playing immediately , via the system 's built-in 56K modem .
By pushing a narrowband solution , Sega is banking on market research , which indicates that only 31 percent of U.S. households will have broadband access by 2004 .
In a concession to Dreamcast owners with cable or DSL access , however , Sega will offer a broadband adapter for the system in the fourth quarter of 2000 .
" Our aim is to give consumers an experience they will n't get from Sony , they will n't get from Microsoft , and they will n't get from Nintendo , " Bellfield said . "
The concept of online games to us is where the future of this industry has got to go . "
SegaNet 's infrastructure is provided by Genuity , and promises low-latency online play for selected computer game titles as well as Dreamcast games .
formerly GTE Internetworking
Sega hopes that the new ISP revenue will help the company return to profitability after three consecutive years of losses .
The company president resigned in May after the most recent annual figures came out .
Sega also wants to make the Dreamcast more of a general computing device , and has announced that peripherals including an MP3 player , Ethernet card , and Zip drive will be out before year 's end .




Eudora Retards Flames

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
If you have a hot temper or do n't liked to get flamed , Eudora 5.0 may be the email program for you .
The newest version of the Qualcomm software features MoodWatch , an automated emotion monitor that scans the text of both incoming and outgoing email for the sorts of " aggressive , demeaning , or rude language , " that typically appear in flames -- or abusive electronic communications .
QCOM
" Studies have shown that people tend to be more aggressive in email than in other forms of communication , " said Jeffrey K. Belk , senior vice president and general manager of Qualcomm Eudora Products .
" MoodWatch simply helps them be more aware of how they may be coming across . "
MoodWatch graphically grades incendiary mail using a scale of one to three chili peppers , with three chilies marking the most flammable missives .
A one-chili-pepper rating warns that you " better hope you know the person " you are sending the email to .
Two chili peppers alerts you to the fact that you should " Watch out , you 're playin ' with fire . "
Three chili peppers translates to " Whoa , this is the kind of thing that might get your keyboard washed out with soap . "
" It 's a whole lot of fun , " said Belk , who notes that MoodWatch can be configured for user-defined levels of sensitivity or turned off altogether .
" Or maybe you 're the sort who will wear the chilies with defiant pride . "
MoodWatch is based on theories developed by David Kaufer , chairman of the English department at Carnegie Mellon University , and employs an algorithm to identify words and phrases that might be offensive .
The fine art of flaming is explored in a helpful white paper by Kaufer that explains the rationale and the technology behind MoodWatch .
Kaufer explained that MoodWatch breaks flames down into eight basic categories .
There 's the " Screw you ! " flame that intimidates though " direct aggressiveness against the reader " and the ever-popular " Screw everyone ! " flame that attacks entire subgroups and can upset readers because of the " speaker 's callousness and zest for degrading other human beings . "
MoodWatch also looks for emails employing the " heated denial " defense which takes the form of comments such as " that 's bullshit . "
Kaufer explained the software will even watch for the " paranoid " type of flame , which incorporates " phrases that indicate that the speaker sees him or herself cut off from a hostile and conniving world , " along with those pesky " face threats , " which put the emailer " right in the face of the reader " with such upbeat sentiments as " f*** you . "




Tiny Screens , Big Images

Have you ever been on an airplane and wanted to watch a racy DVD on your laptop but were too embarrassed ?
Later this year you may be able to , thanks to a new range of microdisplays -- tiny screens that when magnified appear as large as a regular monitor but offer total privacy .
Based on a new , high-resolution and low-cost display technology , microdisplays will start appearing on the market toward the end of the year , and may impact everything from how you use a computer to the way you watch TV .
Microdisplays work by magnifying a tiny screen to fill your field of vision , allowing a display measuring one-tenth of an inch to look like a full-sized theater screen .
Thanks to their diminutive proportions , microscreens can be built directly on top of silicon chips and easily mounted on special glasses , monocles and other lightweight , head-mounted displays .
In the third quarter , for example , inViso plans to introduce a pair of eShades that can be plugged into a laptop or portable DVD player .
The potential uses for microdisplays are legion , said Gary Jones , the CEO of eMagin , an upstate New York manufacturer of screens for microdisplays .
EMagin recently developed the first chip-sized , active-matrix screen with the resolution of a standard 1,280 by 1,024 monitor .
The screen boasts more than 1 million pixels packed into an area smaller than a postage stamp .
Measuring only 0.77 of an inch diagonally , the screen can show real-time video in 256 shades of gray , the company said .
Within a year , microdisplays will turn up in headsets like inViso 's that can be plugged into notebooks or desktops , Jones said , as well as a wide range of digital camera and camcorder viewfinders , cell phones , handhelds , car audio players , and instrument panels .
Jones said he also expects to see microdisplays for handhelds that solve the problem of trying to squint at unreadable , monochrome screens .
" You could have an ultra-portable laptop , " he said . "
The headset folds up in your pocket and connects to a handheld with a fold-out keyboard .
So you have a large , virtual CRT monitor and a keyboard , but it all fits in the pocket of your coat . "




IBM 's Olympic Nervous System

SYDNEY , Australia -- First , there 's a metal detector at the building 's front door .
Then , a security ID-operated elevator .
Finally , three tough metal doors have to be penetrated with a special-issue magnetic swipe card .
Only then -- properly escorted , of course -- can you approach the inner sanctum .
There , from inside a plexiglass human fish tank , you can look out over that holiest of holies : the central nervous system of the Summer Olympics .
Hunched over 300 computers is a mostly male , young , and pasty-white collection of cyber-age data traffic cops who , for the next three weeks , will control just about everything you see , hear , and read from the Games .
Day and night , this three-shift-a-day army of binary gatekeepers will bundle billions of bytes of news and data from this antipodean city onto the world 's fiber and satellite pipes , and eventually to the hungry sports mavens and couch potato athletes of the world .
After the technological black eye it suffered at the Atlanta Olympics in 1996 , IBM is leaving nothing to chance at the 2000 Games , which begin here Friday with the opening ceremonies .
IBM
Over the past year , IBM has tested its technology and its people at virtually every qualifying sporting event held in Australia , said Vickie Regan , vice president of Sydney Olympic technology .
And in the last three months , IBM has conducted two major rehearsals of Olympic conditions , the most recent one just a few weeks ago .
Those rehearsals included going through the paces of Sept. 22 , expected to be the busiest single day of the Games .
Twenty-three events are scheduled that day .
Now , with just about everything in place and the drills completed , it 's not so much the computers and technology that worry Regan anymore .
It 's the hothouse chemistry of human relations -- under stress -- for 17 days .
From this one floor of a central Sydney office building will be collected and aggregated the raw material of the biggest tribal gathering on the planet .
And for the first time the right and left brain of the Olympics , as well as winged messenger Mercury , all will be located in one place .
in a technological sense
The left brain will be IBM 's raw data collection team , feeding everybody and everything from broadcasters to scoreboards with official data -- 4.7 terabytes of it by the time the games are over .
The right brain will be the creative types running the official Olympics website , pushing out more information to more people over the Internet than any sporting event ever held .
And the winged messenger Mercury will be the top-level telecommunications network managers from Australia 's telecom giant Telstra .
For the first time , one telecommunications company will bear total one-stop , end-to-end responsibility for just about anything Olympic going up or down a phone wire , fiber-optic cable , or satellite .
It 's Telstra on the hot seat .




Test Your DNA for Only $ 99.95

WASHINGTON - Genetic testing may take hours , instead of days , and be performed in a doctor 's office , instead of at a distant lab , with the use of a new gene identification technique developed at Northwestern University .
Researchers report Friday in the journal Science that the technique uses tiny gold beads and a modified photo-developing solution to highlight the presence and density of DNA in a test specimen .
The new technique reads the results using a simple photo scanner costing less than $ 100 , said Chad A. Mirkin , a co-author of the study .
The most widely used current DNA testing technique requires a $ 60,000 microscope , he said .
" Once this system is developed , it may be possible for a doctor to do DNA testing in his office , or for soldiers in the field to do tests to identify biological weapons , " Mirkin said .
Just as do the current test methods , the new technique starts with DNA chips , glass slides imbedded with strands of synthesized DNA .
The slide is placed in a solution containing the test specimen , and target DNA in the specimen binds to the DNA strands on the slide .
Mirkin said the new element in the technique is the use of gold beads a nanometer in diameter .
A nanometer is one-billionth of a meter .
The width of a human hair is about 100 nanometers .
The gold beads are covered with about 200 strands of DNA .
When they are spilled over the DNA slide , the beads match up and cling to the corresponding DNA in the specimen .
Mirkin said the slide is then immersed in a photographic solution .
Silver ions in the solution bond with the gold and form black beads of metallic silver that may be 100,000 times bigger than the gold beads .
The whole slide is then put onto a photo scanner .
The silver beads , which mark where there has been a DNA match , show up as gray to black dots .
The darkness of the dot shows the amount of target DNA present in the specimen , said Mirkin .
Mirkin said the technique is about 100 times more sensitive than current methods and is able to detect as few as 60 molecules of DNA .
To achieve that sensitivity , current DNA tests require that the DNA detected be amplified by a laboratory process .
The new DNA test is still in the early stages of development , said Mirkin , but eventually it could be used to genetically identify diseases -- from cancer to AIDS -- and to detect gene mutations .
On the battlefield , he said , the technique could be used to identify biological warfare agents , such as anthrax , so that soldiers could quickly be given the appropriate drugs .




Fodors for Free Speechers

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
NEW YORK -- People here are turning to a news source outside the mainstream to get an insider 's view on how to survive the United Nations ' Millennium Summit .
Multi-block areas of Manhattan are being closed off to accommodate both foreign dignitaries and protesters , so locals are participating in the creation of an open-source survivor guide .
Many New Yorkers feel that the " open source?open content " Independent Media Center website is doing a better job of getting the real news out than the mainstream media , despite the fact that the city has refused to issue press passes to that group and to other nonprofit sites .
" There are going to be 90 or so demonstrations near the United Nations that police will have to close the streets for , " said Cindy Magulus , head of human resources for Film Opticals , a special-effects production company .
" Not only does the website tell you where the protests will be , especially the unofficial ones , they also are providing great information on how to get around the city by foot and subway , " Magulus said . "
Frankly I do n't think I 've ever seen a better source of local information for what really is starting to feel like a crisis . "
The site has a complete " care package " for marching protestors , including pointers on cheap hotels and restaurants , detailed city maps , and a list of designated meeting places , along with services for roving reporters , such as copy shops , film processing centers and cafes .
Residents have been warned that huge stretches of the city can and will be closed without warning to allow the assembled 150 world leaders free passage through the streets , or to contain any of the protests that are breaking out all over the city .
Bike messenger Harim Veracruz says that the IndyMedia site has been " a godsend " for him and his colleagues .
" All the messengers are using it , " he said . "
There 's a map of the city , information on who is going to be where , what parts of the city to avoid , how to get from here to there fast , even restaurant recommendations .
It 's a very helpful site . "
Veracruz said he 's even " gotten educated as to why these people are so angry " by reading some of the political news on the site , and is considering joining a protest walk to the U.N. on Friday .
IndyMedia was launched by activists during the World Trade Organization protests in Seattle last November ; 28 local sites now span the globe from Canada to the Democratic Republic of Congo .




Attack of the Uber Tomatoes

In preliminary findings , a team of researchers has developed a tomato that packs a greater nutritional punch than one that is grown conventionally .
The tomato has more than twice as much of the antioxidant lycopene and a longer shelf life , according to researchers with the U.S. Department of Agriculture and Purdue University in West Lafayette , Indiana .
Antioxidants are compounds that prevent free radicals from damaging cells .
Free radicals are natural byproducts of the metabolic process .
" Antioxidants are very important to fight blindness in children , prevent cancer and benefit cardiovascular health in humans , " said Dr. Autar K. Mattoo , a plant physiologist with the USDA 's Agricultural Research Service .
The tomato has been modified to include a gene from yeast .
Scientists reconstructed the gene in a test tube so that it would be switched on during the ripening process , thereby slowing the amount of time it takes a tomato to mature .
A slower ripening process allows more time for lycopene to accumulate .
Mattoo stressed that his findings have not yet been published and it will be years before consumers can buy the genetically modified fruit in stores .
Still , the findings come in the midst of a fierce global debate over the potential health risks and environmental impact of genetically modified foods .
In May , the U.S. Food and Drug Administration announced that it would create a " GE-free " program , in which manufacturers could voluntarily label products that had not been genetically engineered .
In Europe , consumer opposition to genetically modified foods has had an impact on U.S. exports .




Study : Computers Do n't Help Kids

Billions of dollars spent on school computers and Internet connections deliver little long-term benefit and could be better spent on more teachers and other improvements , a group critical of technology in the classroom said Tuesday .
" We 've gone down this highway of bringing computers into elementary schools with so little debate , and spending such huge sums , " said Joan Almon , a former Baltimore kindergarten teacher and head of the U.S. branch of Alliance for Childhood .
" If we were spending so much money on other aspects of education with so little evidence of gain , we 'd be ashamed of ourselves , " she said .
A major Clinton administration goal has been eliminating the " digital divide " by bringing computers and Internet access into the nation 's schools .
The alliance , an international partnership of educators , doctors , and psychologists based in College Park , Md. , wants a " time-out " from policies that emphasize computers as an ideal educational tool for toddlers , preschoolers , and elementary school students .
Many experts say there is little direct evidence linking computer use and higher school achievement .
A study performed in 1998 by the Educational Testing Service found that fourth- and eighth-graders scored 15 percent higher on math tests after using computers to play learning games , but derived no benefit using computers to practice basic skills .
The new report said that despite the limited research on the impact of computers on education , U.S. public schools have spent more than $ 27 billion on computers and related technology in the past five years .
That money , the report concludes , could be better spent on other educational priorities such as reducing class sizes , repairing schools , and eliminating lead poisoning .
The report warns that computers may account for a rise in health problems among children , including repetitive stress injuries , eye strain , and obesity .
Focusing too much on technology can also distract children from the social interaction they need to develop language skills and bonds with adults .




Live from DEMOmobile 2000 !

PASADENA , California -- Mobile computing has n't quite achieved Star Trek tricorder levels of complexity yet , but it 's getting there .
What 's readily apparent here at IDG 's DEMOmobile 2000 conference on mobile technology is that the technology is getting far more advanced , and that because of it , we 're going to have more items to carry around , not less .
Simplicity is Best
San Francisco-based Scout Electromedia was one of several companies showing off new toys , the most interesting of which was the modo , a pager-sized device with a decidedly alien look to it .
Designed as a consumer product , the modo will be sold in places like Virgin Records Megastore and fashion outlets like DKNY .
Modo offers a free service in which information on news , restaurant guides , nightlife activity and local events is beamed down to the unit .
Content is localized for each city , and the player is transportable -- so a user in New York can go to San Francisco and automatically receive San Francisco-oriented content .
But the modo is designed to receive information , not send it : The unit has only a small LCD graphical screen and three navigation buttons .
The design focus was simplicity , said the company .
" It 's not easy to make something people can pick up and get in two minutes , " said Geoff Pitfield , president and CEO of Scout Electromedia .
The modo unit will sell for $ 99 and the service is free , with no subscription rates or charges .
Scout Electromedia will make its money through banner ads displayed on the unit 's LCD screen .
The modo will also transmit sale alerts -- in one promotion , customers who bring the unit in to Virgin Records will receive a discount .
" So the modo unit becomes the coupon , " said Pitfield .
Modo uses the pager network , said Pitfield .
Data is regularly pumped out from Scout to the device by a team of local editors in each city who create new content and aggregate information , such as movie and event listings .
Modo is launching in New York next week , in Los Angeles and San Francisco in October , in Chicago in November , and in Atlanta , Boston and Miami in early 2001 .
Does Size Really Matter ?
According to a panel of vice presidents discussing the future of portable technology , convergence is n't going to happen any time soon .
Part of the problem is due to size constraints .
" There are some diametrically opposed issues &#91;in convergence&#93 ; -- battery size versus the physical size of the keypad , " said Joe Siphler , vice president of product marketing for Handspring , a developer of handheld devices and peripherals . "
You have to stuff that all into a form factor that 's attractive for a customer and it 's not easy to do . "
Sprint , a lead competitor in the wireless Internet market , said it will focus on delivering applications and content , rather than on developing wireless devices , because there will always be different types of access devices .
" Customers want to access information in multiple ways , " said Jay Highley , vice president of business marketing for Sprint PCS . "
Customers want choice .
I would say you will always see multiple form factors , some of which we have n't seen yet . "
The biggest problem is not the device , but the limitations on bandwidth .
Wireless Internet access is delivered at 14.4 kbps speed , which is 1992 modem technology .
" The reason people are amazed at the speed &#91;of wireless Internet access&#93 ; is because you 're only bringing down slices of HTML , we 're not bringing down the whole Web experience , " said Highley .
Sprint is launching a 56 kbps network with new compression techniques and plans to deploy a 144 kbps network by early 2002 .
Something New from Big Blue
IBM introduced a new laptop with built-in wireless LAN connectivity as well as support for the Bluetooth wireless communication protocol .
The ThinkPad i Series uses IBM 's High Rate Wireless LAN technology to transfer data at up to 11Mbits/sec , using a 2.4 Ghz frequency , which gives the laptop a range from 80 to 1,750 feet from the receiver , depending on the construction of the office .
Older Thinkpad notebooks can get on a High Rate Wireless LAN network through PCMCIA cards that sell for $ 179 .
The new ThinkPad i Series 1300 notebook computers will be available in the early fourth quarter , starting at $ 1149 .
The new Bluetooth PC Card from IBM will be available in October starting at $ 189 .

Give Microsoft credit for hanging in there .
It introduced Handheld PC 2000 , the latest generation of its handheld operating system .
HPC 2000 is based on Windows CE 3.0 and features an integrated client for Windows 2000 Terminal Services , an IE 4.0-compatible browser , Windows Media Player , and handheld versions of Microsoft Office .
