Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Entertainment Web portal iCast will cease to exist on Jan. 31 , 2001 if a buyer for the struggling site can n't be found , CMGI announced on Monday .
Some reports , officially unconfirmed but widely believed throughout the industry , had indicated that Rupert Murdoch 's News Corporation was interested in buying iCast .
But CMGI executives stressed they were still looking for a buyer .
CMGI had pledged in September that it would strengthen its bottom line in 2001 , and CEO David Wetherell said during a conference call that this goal required CMGI to " refocus only on properties and investments with the potential for a dramatic profit . "
Wetherell said the company still believes in the potential profitability of online entertainment sites .
But he added that the capital investment required to produce content for entertainment sites , combined with CMGI 's long road to profitability , precluded any additional CMGI investment in iCast , which was not expected to show a profit for " several years . "
CMGI 's decision to shut down or sell iCast was n't unexpected .
ICast has long been " the black sheep in CMGI 's cozy incubator , " said Robert Buckman , a digital music reporter . "
ICast has never turned a profit and has recently experienced two major layoffs and the very raucous departure of several top executives . "
Hopes remain for salvaging the site .
ICast public relations director Stu Zakimt told the media after the last round of layoffs on Sept. 14 , " nobody 's pulling the plug on this site .
...
We 're stronger than ever . "
But after Monday 's announcement , " the countdown to iCast 's extinction has officially begun , " said Buckman .
CMGI , which owns or has investments in more than 70 online companies , has seen its stock plummet 90 percent from a peak of $ 302 in April 1999 to a close of $ 14.13 on Monday .
CMGI
ICast offers Web radio , streaming video presentations of short films , MP3s and iCaster , a downloadable player that supports CDs , MP3s , live streams , and instant messaging .
Most of the site 's content centers heavily on self-promotional vehicles for new artists .
ICast , which employs about 200 people , did not return calls or e-mails requesting comment , nor did potential buyer News Corporation .
" ICast is another site that 's in the repackaging business -- they repackaged content from traditional media and put it onto the Web .
They did n't offer anything that a hundred or so other Internet-based entertainment sites offer . "
did n't
Incubators have invested money and time into making these sites work , but none of them have really clicked .
Scour , Pop.com , and the Digital Entertainment Network have all fallen on hard times in the past few months , said Nathan Vonder , an analyst with digital media consultancy firm Petersen and Pover .
Vonder said profit potential for entertainment sites is only possible when a company is backed by a strong partner with access to commercially recognized and highly popular content .
He cites the Bertelsmann Music Group/Napster marriage as an example of a company that " may pull together something interesting . "
He also said he was interested to see what happened with the " ever-pending " AOL/Time Warner partnership .
" And obviously Murdoch 's far-flung entertainment and news empire would be a good match for iCast , " Vonder added .




Sea Launch No Longer Adrift

WASHINGTON -- It 's a scene right out of a James Bond movie : A rocket blazes into orbit from a launch pad perched atop a renovated oil rig in a deserted corner of the Pacific Ocean .
But instead of a death laser aimed at Washington , the rockets departing from Sea Launch 's platform at the equator carry far more commercial payloads : Direct TV , radio , and cellular telephone satellites .
At least that was the plan .
Sea Launch 's third mission met an agonizing end in March when a Ukrainian- and Russian-made Zenit 3 SL rocket failed to reach orbit and crashed into the ocean about 2,700 miles away from the launch platform .
An internal investigation blamed a software error that failed to close a valve before liftoff .
The chastened company got its space legs back last month , when it successfully sent the Thuraya-1 communications satellite into orbit on Oct. 21 .
At 11,260 pounds , company representatives say it was the heaviest payload ever to be sent successfully into geosynchronous transfer orbit .
At a Washington Space Business Roundtable on Monday , Sea Launch executives stressed that they feel confident the company can continue to deliver successful launches .
" Obviously , I have complete confidence in our operation , " Sea Launch president Will Trafton said . "
Look , our business is based on confidence , and primarily our customer confidence .
If that confidence is not there , then we 're out of business . "
" I like where we are right now and think we 're here for the long haul , " Trafton said .
Customers do n't seem to be particularly worried .
Trafton said Sea Launch , which launches from the equator because it reduces fuel cost and increases accuracy , is planning on four missions in 2001 ; and plans to increase that to seven a year by 2003 .
He said 14 launches are already sold for the future , and that the company can launch eight times per year .
The company is trying to position itself as the first choice for heavy commercial launches .
Trafton said it hopes to increase its payload capacity to upwards of 13,200 pounds by 2002 .
But it 's facing stiff competition from companies like International Launch Services , an American-Russian joint venture that has successfully completed 12 missions this year , including one last month that carried a U.S. government communications satellite aloft .
Arianespace , a French firm , has completed nine missions this year and is scheduled to launch an Ariane 5 rocket on Tuesday .
Sea Launch was founded in 1995 .
Its investors include Boeing , which owns 40 percent of the operation ; RSC-Energia of Moscow , which owns 25 percent ; Anglo-Norwegian Kvaerner Group of Oslo , which owns 20 percent ; and SDO Yuzhnoye/PO Yuzhmash of the Ukraine , which owns 15 percent .
According to Sea Launch 's statistics , the renovated oil platform is self-propelled , 436 feet long by 220 feet wide , and it can accommodate 68 people .
Nicholas Morehead contributed to this report .




Old Ideas in ' New ' PC Games

PC gaming is caught in a cycle of copycatting as it enters the holiday season , according to both industry watchers and hardcore gamers .
" There are no original ideas anymore , just reshapes or rehashes , " complained William Harms , executive editor of CNET 's Gamecenter , a site devoted to gaming news and reviews .
Consolidation in the PC game industry has created big , public companies that are forced to focus on near-term profits -- or face investors ' wrath .
So many manufacturers turn to games that can be churned out quickly and have a built-in audience .
In other words , sequels and knock-offs .
" The general level of quality has gone up .
But it 's gotten harder to innovate , " said Greg Kasavin , senior editor at Gamespot , another gaming-focused site .
This malaise could n't come at a worse moment .
The holidays are the gaming industry 's most important time of the year , with nearly 60 percent of sales traditionally coming in the fourth quarter , according to MCV , a gaming-trade publication .
" This year 's expectations are lower than last year 's , " gaming enthusiast Chai Lim said . "
There are no real high-impact games running into the Christmas season . "
Several highly anticipated games -- including god simulation Black and White and team-based adrenaline fix Tribes 2 -- are delayed and may miss the holiday window .
And most of the year 's big games have been long released .
PC Data reports that seven of the top 10-selling PC games for the week of Oct. 15 are from the franchises that have been dominating sales charts for most of the year -- Diablo II , Age of Empires II , Roller Coaster Tycoon and The Sims .
Signs point to the rankings staying fairly stable over the next few months .




It Ai n't Easy Being Light

Over 1,000 designers , engineers , and students gathered in Amsterdam this weekend to address the issue of lightness in design , and , as organizers put it , the fact that " a strange thing happened to the ' weightless ' and dematerialised economy we thought the Internet would bring : It never arrived ! "
The sixth Doors of Perception conference , taking place in Amsterdam Nov. 11-13 , started with discussions of what lightness actually means , as well as suggesting new ways to perceive and map it .
Its finale will focus on actual applications of this knowledge .
The conference tackled many nettlesome issues : the role of open-source and file-sharing software on design methodology , the need for more strategic alliances in order to withstand impending ecological doom , and ways to dismiss the clichs that reflexively associate " ecological " with , as festival moderator John Thackara put it , " less stuff , less change , less fun . "
Through its varied assortment of speakers and presentations , the conference successfully showed that green does n't need to be a dirty word .
The tone was breezy , mildly flippant , and lightness was woven into the very fabric of the event : Its symbol is a trippy doily , its drab conference-hall setting spruced up with diaphanous textiles , and the short presentations added lots of space to the program itself .
Except for a few episodes of unreconstructed corporate chest-pounding -- more suited to this week 's Comdex fair in Las Vegas -- the eclectic speakers here all stressed the inherent value of a light touch .
and not the market
The ideas on display addressed wastefulness in the design of both things as well as information .
One example was the home , which used to be a simple place .
Over time it has been stuffed to the brink with weighty technologies like TVs and stereos , but the convergence of technologies is allowing it to shed some pounds .
Webby Award founders Maya Draisin and Tiffany Shlain demonstrated how the Internet was born very light , grew unsustainably bloated , and is now downsizing itself in step with what users actually want , i.e. anything but megabytes of indecipherable icons and skippable intros .
Witness the Digital Entertainment Network , which sank under its own weight , while Napster remains light , aloof , and ascendant .
Spanish designer Mart Guix demonstrated how a series of simple twists can provide graceful solutions to problems of design and waste .
Among them , temporary tattoos that serve as rulers and subway maps , a shoe store that uses its leftover boxes as furniture , and branded food that pays its own way : CK emblazoned on our pizzas , IBM writ large on our black beans .
Of course , no one 's saying that achieving all this lightness is simple .
As in ballet , it takes a lot of effort to make something complex look easy .
As Doors ' spokeswoman Jane Szita eloquently noted , " less is more work . "
In a conference of this scope , it 's not surprising to encounter a host of contradictions .
Brian Eno presented the Long Now Foundation 's ultralight Rosetta Disk , which stores a text written in a thousand languages on a 2-inch nickel plate that will outlive any data rot or discarded operating systems .
along with clues for future cryptographers to make sense of them




Put Transit Time to Work

LAS VEGAS -- Those idle hours in the car and on the plane do n't have to be spent reading bumper stickers or watching bad movies anymore .
Companies that grew out of GM and Boeing want to make every moment of your commute time productive with services to keep you connected while doing 60 or 600 miles per hour .
At the Comdex IT trade show on Monday , Onstar launched a traffic service aimed at alerting drivers to anything that could slow down their commute .
Onstar , through partnerships with location-based services company Etak and broadcaster Westwood One , will deliver information to a vehicle about possible travel delays -- including accidents , road congestion , construction , and bad weather -- based on the vehicle 's location .
The company , a General Motors spin-off , also announced the OnStar Virtual Advisor , which enables subscribers to personalize the delivery of Internet content including stock quotes , sports reports , news , weather as well as provide e-mail access .
The voice-activated service plays through the car stereo .
The service will launch in the northeastern United States in December and in the rest of the country in early 2001 .
The Virtual Advisor will not distract the driver because it lacks a display , Onstar president Chet Huber said .
He said that customers will be able to enter their preferred traffic routes and receive warnings if any part of the trip could be hindered .
In the future , subscribers will also be able to query the system to find out if there are delays on the highway for the next 20 miles .
Huber said that in the future the location-tracking capability could be used for commerce .
Customers could request the nearest restaurant , entering a credit card number to correspond with their vehicles so that the company could track where the order came from .
Huber said Onstar will be installed in more than 1 million GM cars by the end of the year , and the company will also offer the service to some models of Lexus , Audi and Honda vehicles in 2001 .




Bluetooth Comes to Your Notebook

LAS VEGAS -- Your boss says you need to meet on Thursday at 3 p.m. to discuss the budget , so you write it down in your daily organizer .
As you leave her office , she says " Make sure you enter our 3 o'clock into your Palm , " to which you humbly reply , " It 's already in there . "
Swedish startup Anoto is making this a reality with wireless digital paper that can be printed as any notepad , personal organizer , memo pad or Post-It note .
At Comdex this week , Anoto announced that nine leading office-products manufacturers would be integrating the technology into their paper products .
" Pen and paper is the most common communication interface in the world , so we decided to integrate it with the digital world " said Anoto Vice President Anders Tormod .
The digital paper looks just like an ordinary page , but has an almost imperceptible layer of dots forming a pattern that uniquely identifies the pages .
Information from the page gets passed on by the pen to a nearby Bluetooth-enabled device , including PDAs , mobile phones or PCs .
The pen , which looks like a thick fountain pen , includes a Bluetooth transmitter , a camera , an image processor , and of course , some ink .
The camera actually traces your pen stroke , and converts the " mini-movie " of the pen 's path into an image that is sent wirelessly to a device .
Tormod said that the company has built up an index of billions of unique patterns that can be printed on pages so that each one can be identified by the receiving device .
This enables , for example , the November 19 page of a hard copy organizer to tell your PC to add a meeting to the November 19 section of your Palm 's calendar .
Tormod said the dots do not interfere with other printing on the page , and the company has signed up with office products companies including At-A-Glance , Esselte , Filofax , Franklin , Covey and Mead to incorporate the technology into their notebooks , organizers and other products .
Companies can also add " action " sections to their paper products .
For example , filling in an e-mail address on a section of a memo pad could generate a message that will be automatically forwarded to a Bluetooth-enabled mobile phone .
Anoto also demonstrated a business card with a check box that will e-mail its contents to a person 's PDA .
A catalog could have a " buy me " check box that will automatically create an online order .
Tormod said companies can combine the technology with handwriting-recognition software to automate filling out forms .
Tormod said the company is very closely replicating the pen and paper experience -- which means that , like the real stuff , the digital ink can n't be erased .
He said the paper products and Anoto 's pen should be out in the third quarter of 2001 , and he expects it to help fuel the demand for Bluetooth , the recently introduced short-distance wireless transmission technology .
Anoto , of Lund , Sweden , is a spinoff of C Technologies and has considerable experience with Bluetooth .
Anoto chairman Orjan Johansson created Bluetooth while working at Ericsson .
Anoto is creating what it calls the " world 's largest Web server " to index all of the unique patterns that it will license to the paper 's manufacturers .
Anoto will distribute the patterns to its partners so that the pages they print will correctly understand how to interact with the digital devices and not conflict with other digital paper .
Tormod said the cost of the extra ink for printing the patterns is marginal , and that the support from the paper companies will turn Anoto 's digital paper technology into a de facto standard .




Cubism , Web-Browser Style

LAS VEGAS -- A new browser that displays multiple Web pages inside a 3-D , cube-shaped window is being touted by its inventor as a breakthrough that will revolutionize the way people surf the Internet .
Developed by Philadelphia architect Mike Rosen , the 2 Ce browser is being shown for the first time to analysts and the press at this week 's Comdex .
In a hotel suite off the show floor , Rosen is demonstrating an early version of the 2 Ce browser , which displays six Web pages simultaneously as though they were the inside walls of a cube .
pronounced " to see "
" This will be the interface of choice for the information age , " said Rosen . "
When you turn on your computer in the morning , this is what you 'll see . "
The browser works with ordinary Web pages and is an alternative to having half-a-dozen browser windows open at once .
Instead , the 2 Ce browser allows six pages to be worked on simultaneously -- in the same window .
For example , Rosen showed the browser set up to display a search engine on the back wall , a stock trading page on the right and a news page on the left .
A calendar application was on the ceiling of the cube , and a Web-based e-mail page was on the floor .
Using a floating menu bar , Rosen swung around inside the cube and highlighted different sides on the back wall , which made it easier to work with them .
" When I was designing this , I knew the room metaphor -- with walls , a floor and a ceiling -- would be very easy to navigate and intuitive , " he said . "
It 's a very architectural . "
Rosen also showed a number of pre-set cubes , such as a " news cube " that displayed CNN on the back wall , The Wall Street Journal on the right , the Red Herring on the left , and so on .
" It concentrates information , " Rosen said . "
It 's a much more efficient way of looking at information . "
Rosen has founded a company , 2 Ce , based in Philadelphia , to bring the browser to market .
It will be available as a free download in the middle of next year .
He hopes to sell programming tools to Web developers and companies for use in corporate Intranets .
The tools will help developers optimize sites for the browser .
For example , a Web retailer could display its wares in 3-D along a corridor , Rosen said .
The browser will be also be useful for developers designing information-rich systems such as help desks , where operators need simultaneous access to numerous sources of information , Rosen said .
Rosen showed an iterative cube -- where each side is a cube , and each of that cube 's sides is a cube , and so on , with hundreds of pages in all .
While the pages were unreadable , Rosen said the system could be used to track stocks .
If there 's any change in a stock , the stock 's page flashes a warning and the user zooms right in.
As well as displaying multiple Web pages simultaneously , the browser can provide a visual record of where it has been , as well as how different pages are related to each other .




Dreaming About Nano Health Care

CAMBRIDGE , Mass. -- Leading health , technology and health technology professionals gathered on Monday to dream the increasingly possible wellness dream .
MIT 's Media Lab hosted the first gathering of its deceptively simply titled Health Special Interest Group .
This debut Health SIG gathering proposed to do no less than rethink the entire multibillion dollar medical industry and envision a future where the health-care dollar depends more upon the informed consumer and less on the passive patient .
" My basic idea is that new tools are giving consumers -- not patients -- the ability to take control of their health and maintain their lifestyle , " said Alex Pentland , academic head of the Media Lab and a prime mover behind the Lab 's new health-care focus .
" That will be the main front line where people take care of themselves , learn about themselves and take action for themselves .
Rather than a doctor contending only with the sick or the ' worried well , ' they may find a much more informed populace coming to their doorstep . "
As he presented it in the morning 's introductory remarks , four potential directions for research and development beckon : creating systems to encourage and enhance healthy behavior and learning ; designing wearable systems and smart environments ; creating and processing " data-rich , " personalized medical service and developing micro-fabricated biosensors for health maintenance , observation and early disease detection .
Pentland was n't the only dreamer in the crowd , though .
Indeed , one exercise for the afternoon was for the participants -- including many of the lab 's own free-ranging thinkers as well as representatives from across industry , academia and government -- to scribble out their wish lists : What 's the most important development in the " health industry " that they could hope for ?
Some saw it as an opportunity to get an early word in with Santa Claus ; others forecast a political , social or legal climate change as the key component to making the Health SIG 's dreams come true .
" ' Tricorder ' technology ? " one correspondent asked .
Other gadgetry must-haves included biological sensors in a pill , a personal health card that " does it all " , and even an oral health sensor on a toothbrush .
while guaranteeing privacy
On the other hand , one Health SIG participant wrote that the most important change was to " focus on the home as a center of health-care delivery , " while another requested " natural interfaces good enough for kids and elderly . "
And , seeking the ultimate e-nanny , one wrote : " The ideal product : An agent that will have access real-time to all my biometric info and that will nag me to do all the right things . "
Media Lab faculty , students and post-docs held court for most of the day , showcasing their health-related technological innovations -- although , at times , the relevance to the topic of the day involved some roundabout diversions by way of advanced statistics or toy castles made out of Lego bricks .
Perhaps the most far-reaching developments on display were found in the interface between wireless communications , biological sensors and nanotechnology .
The Lab 's new recruit , Scott Manalisnow , leads the nanoscale sensing vanguard -- moving toward remote microscopic laboratories that conduct body chemistry and genetic tests from anywhere , including inside a person 's body .
Manalis ' work was not only on display at Monday 's Health Initiative kickoff but also is one of the centerpieces of Tuesday 's Silicon Biology symposium .
" There 's a company that 's developed a pill that you can swallow that measures temperature in your body , " Manalis said . "
The pill is a little bigger than a vitamin C pill , but it has inside it a battery , an antenna and an oscillator so when the temperature changes it changes the frequency that comes out .
And you can wear something on your side , so you can measure the temperature inside your body . "
Other projects highlighted during the day included printable semiconductor chips for interfaces to biological sensors , wearable personal health monitors , computer applications for children undergoing kidney dialysis and diabetes therapy and a prototype " smart medical home . "
But , amidst the gee-whiz , a few voices from outside the Lab tempered their enthusiasm with notes of caution .
Jake Galler of Quest Diagnostics reminded that while consumers will be seeking more control over their health care -- as the group anticipates -- they 'll still be demanding a vigilant privacy policy over their records .
" I know I would not like to see my genomic sequence up on a website somewhere like sometimes you 'll see these financial returns of Hollywood stars , " he said . "
So that really is critical as we move forward . "
Furthermore , Mary Jo Deering of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services added two other crucial caveats .
" Eighty percent of the problems are not technology , " she said . "
They 're sociology and psychology .
The barriers are personal .
Professional and institutional behavior is more addictive than lifestyle behavior -- it 's harder to change .
You have to work overtime .
So as you design these systems , think of yourself as trying to change slow-moving oil tankers .
Pace yourself and be in it for the long term .
" And my final suggestion to you is in all the testing that I 've heard about and all the advisory panels , I have n't heard of any consumers and patients as your advisers .
I strongly urge that you do that .
To the extent that you have a home-based , person-based delivery system , you had better hear from the people who are going to use it . "




Holiday Bug May Be Catching

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
' Tis the season for surprises , some nice and some naughty .
A new worm called Navidad and a musical New Year 's virus known as W95.Ussrhymn@m are slowly spreading a not-so-festive holiday message through corporate computer systems .
Navidad has n't damaged any systems so far , and security experts say that the virus is currently rated a moderate threat .
W95.Ussrhymn@m is far more dangerous , but is spreading more slowly .
Both bugs have a holiday theme in common -- " Navidad " means Christmas in Spanish , and W95.Ussrhymn@m is programmed to start destroying files when it plays an old Soviet Republic hymn on Jan. 1 .
" Christmas time always seems to bring forth a deluge of dire bug warnings , and a couple of supposedly humorous real viruses , " said Tony Gont , a systems security adviser for the New York state 's government offices .
Navidad taunts users by telling them not to push a dialog box button and then claims that their system will be destroyed when they succumb to temptation and push the button .
But the worm does n't actually destroy files .
" W95.Ussrhymn@m " does affect the systems it attacks , causing lockups and slowdowns and overwriting basic systems operations .
W95.Ussrhymn@m will trigger itself on infected systems January first , and will then spread rapidly , attacking root system files .
The virus has the potential to cause serious damage , and is spread across networks via sharing infected files .
W95.Ussrhymn@m can also disable some virus scanning and security programs .
Navidad does n't annihilate your network , but it certainly is annoying , said Ian Murray , a London computer security administrator .
Navidad spreads through Microsoft 's Outlook e-mail application , and automatically mails itself as a reply to any messages that are sent to an infected machine .
" It 's one of those gifts that keeps on giving , " said Murray . "
If the recipient opens the attachment , " NAVIDAD.EXE , " and runs it , they 'll see a dialog box and a message in Spanish that reads : " Never press this button . "
If they press the button , they 'll see a message that says : " Feliz Navidad .
Unfortunately you have given in to temptation and will lose your computer . "
Vincent Gullotto , an antivirus researcher at security company McAfee.com , said that many of the worm-ridden Navidad e-mails originally appear to have come from Brazil and so he assumes that this bug originated in South America .
He declined to name the North American companies that have been infected so far .
" Navidad is not destructive , but it may cause your Windows system to lock up , " Gullotto said .
Navidad also places an icon of an eye in the computer 's system tray , and some users have reported that clicking on it caused their machines to slow down or freeze .
Some experts speculate that the virus may be able to do more damage to computers running the Spanish language versions of Microsoft 's Windows operating system , but this has not been confirmed .
" I doubt that it 's a language-localized virus , " said Murray . "
I think the writer who created this worm just has a wicked and warped sense of humor .
He or she was n't out to hurt people , just to test their lameness quotient . "




Random House Sets Royalty Rate

Random House becomes the first major publisher to deal with an issue debated between publishers , authors and agents for the last year , when it announced it will raise the royalty rate on electronic books from 15 percent of the cover price to 50 percent of net revenues .
" The old model had different incentives for the publisher and author , and we could sometimes end up in conflict , " said Erik Engstrom , president and chief operating officer of Random House . "
pricing
If we do it this way , we have exactly the same economic incentives . "
But while the 50 percent of net revenues seems like a giant step , it should be noted that the new royalty rate is based on net revenue after current distributor payments and allowances .
Most publishers use distributors who add Digital Rights Management software to the e-book files , and that 's an incremental cost .
" Fifty percent of net profits may not wind up being all that much more than 15 percent of the cover price , " said Adam Rothberg of Simon and Schuster .
Other publishing houses , including Time Warner and HarperCollins , are not ready to set rates .
They say it 's too soon to fix an e-book royalty rate since the market is not yet profitable .
Michael Cader , an industry analyst and editor of Publisher 's Lunch said the decision was sending an important message .
Higher royalty rates that make authors partners in the profit picture encourages them to stick with their publishers instead of trying to self publish their e-books as Stephen King and Seth Godin have recently done .
One of the most reliable , effective bookselling tools ever in publishing , Cader said , is the passionate author willing to reach out to and connect with his audience .
Such an author helps drive sales .
" Broader back-end participation and a sense of fairness gives authors a strong incentive to rely on major publishers as their partners in growing this market and reaching the electronic audience , " Cader said .
Smaller back-end participation , he suggested , even with advances , encourages authors to stay out of the fray or to go build these markets themselves .
E-books at Costco ?
Costco , BJ 's and Sam 's Clubs are among the stores that will soon offer e-books via their websites .
It 's the result of an agreement between Reciprocal -- a digital rights management and digital commerce services -- and Advanced Marketing Services -- a provider of customized services to book retailers and publishers in more than six countries .
AMS
It 's an interesting concept -- selling e-books at stores better known for good buys on traditional fare such as paper towels in bulk quantities .
But will it work ?
" A store like Costco 's strength is selling product , but that does n't mean they can evaluate all that content equally , " said Janet Lawson , the proprietor of BookBrowser . "
We are librarians , book readers and reviewers , and provide the context that helps people find material and make a good purchase . "
we
This development could work in BookBrowser 's favor .
As more websites that are n't bookstores sell books , content from readers-guide sites like BookBrowser , which posts 40 professional book reviews a week , could become more popular .




ICANN : The Winners Are ...

MARINA DEL REY , California -- Seven domains of the future on the World Wide Web were selected on Thursday .
Sometime next spring , companies , organizations and individuals very likely will be able to register with dot-biz , dot-info , dot-name , dot-pro , dot-museum , dot-aero , and dot-coop .
That 's the unanimous decision of the Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers , the Internet 's managing authority , which ended a long process to create new spaces in the Domain Name System in front of a tense meeting in this Southern California beachside town .
The new top-level domains and their winning sponsors are : Dot-biz , by JVTeam , LLC , which is composed of Neustar and Melbourn IT .
A suffix specifically for businesses , ICANN found it the strongest of several .biz proposals .
It is unclear how the company would handle requests from individuals and non-business groups .
Dot-info , by Afilias , LLC .
This international consortium of 19 companies dot-info as a truly global option , as most .com registrations are in the United States .
Dot-name , by the Global Name Registry Ltd. , which wants a category for individuals .
It would reserve second-level names such as smith.name and let individuals register john.smith.name or betty.smith.name .
It is not clear how the company would deal with multiple individuals named John Smith .
Dot-pro , by RegistryPro , Ltd , which is composed of register.com , Virtual Internet and Baltimore Tech.
This TLD is for professionals .
Physician John Doe , for example , could register as johndoe.med.pro .
If John Doe were a lawyer , he could register as johndoe.law.pro .
Individuals would have to prove their professional status .
Existing .com , .net and .org addresses do not require that documentation .
Dot-museum , by the Museum Domain Management Association , a group created through the International Council of Museums .
It wants the suffix for accredited museums worldwide .
Dot-aero , by the Societi Internationale de Tilicommunications Aironautiques .
Dot-coop , by the National Cooperative Business Association , which wants a special designation for business cooperatives such as credit unions and rural electric coops .
The suffix would be available for members of the group and its counterparts worldwide .
Needless to say , the operators of these future name spaces were pleased with the result .
Paul Hazen , president of National Cooperatives Business Association , said that the dot-coop domain will service the more than 750,000 cooperatives world wide along with the more than 750,000,000 cooperative members around the globe .
" This will make it easy to find cooperatives on the Web , " he said .
Sloan Guon , director of business for Regsiter.com , said that the dot-pro TLD will likewise help consumers . "
When they go to a dot-pro URL they 'll know that the information there is realiable , " he said .
Only credentialed professionals will be able to register dot-pro domain names , Goan said .
Register.com will be providing the back-end registry services for the top level domain .
The Domain Name System has not seen the introduction of new generic top-level domains since the mid-1980s when dot-net , dot-com and dot-org were added .
Since then , a number of country code top-level domains have been added -- .ps for the Palestinian Authority was the latest of these -- but the number of general-purpose TLDs of the dot-com variety has remained static .
ccTLDs
Much of the prime space in the dot-com registry is in private hands .
Because of this artificial scarcity and the value of name spaces on the Net , some companies have partnered with country-code TLD managers to turn country-specific , two-digit domain extensions into general-purpose top-level domains .
One example is dot-tv , which was repurposed from the ccTLD for the country of Tuvalu into more of a general-purpose top-level domain .
Since it began operating as a dot-com-like registry , the dotTV Corporation has seen 140,000 dot-tv domain name registrations .
Other repurposed ccTLDs include Tonga 's dot-to , and dot-ws -- which represents Western Samoa 's space on the Net .
Western Samoa is now known as Samoa .




Hey Computer , Read My Mind

ARLINGTON , Virginia -- Any serious Star Trek buff remembers the famous " Spock 's Brain " episode , in which the apparently primitive denizens of Sigma Draconis put the Vulcan 's prodigious mind to work as an environmental control computer .
When Dr. McCoy realizes the technically advanced surgery the natives have successfully performed , he exclaims aloud , " That 's not possible ! "
" But it is , " says Melody Moore , a research scientist at Georgia State University . "
Not in that capacity yet , but we 're beginning to understand brain activity , " she said . "
We can listen in on it .
We can intercept it .
We can interpret it . "
Moore was speaking on Tuesday not to a crowd of bespectacled Trekkies , but to the Association for Computing Machinery 's Conference on Assistive Technologies .
The event is designed to explore how computers can help disabled or handicapped people .
Moore and her colleagues are attempting a feat that 's nothing if not ambitious : controlling a computer through brain signals .
The key technology involved is called a neurotrophic electrode , which is about the size of the head of a ballpoint pen , and is designed to be directly inserted into a brain so it can interface with neurons .
It 's connected to a tiny amplifier and transmitter , which are inserted closer to the surface of the skin , just under the scalp .
Also present is a small power source that allows wireless transmission of the signals to a nearby computer .
Together the system allows a person such as a quadriplegic to perform on a computer basic functions that were heretofore impossible .
The PCs receiving the neural-signal data sport custom software as well as modified off-the-shelf components for signal-data acquisition , analysis , device control , communication and training aids for the patients .




Blazing a Trail in Home Recording

LAS VEGAS -- Pioneer New Media Technologies is the first optical media vendor to hit the market with a combined CD-RW and DVD-RW unit , putting two types of recordable optical storage into a single unit .
At Comdex this week , Pioneer began showing off the DVR-103 , which supports recording in CD-R , CR-RW , DVD-R and DVD-RW formats , the last of which can be rewritten up to 1,000 times .
write once
CD rewritable
write once
The drive records DVD-Rs at twice the speed of previous products , and also is compatible with all of the CD formats , including CD-ROM and CD-RW .
The DVD-RW has a storage capacity of 4.7 GB , which is the target capacity for the DVD Forum , developer of the DVD specification .
There have been recordable DVD drives on the market , DVD-RAM drives , but they only had a capacity of 2.5 GB .
The company expects that demand for converting home movies to the longer-lasting digital format could make DVD as popular as CD .
" Archiving videotapes will be the killer app for DVD-R , " according to Andy Parsons , senior vice president at Pioneer New Media Technologies .
He expects that people will convert their aging videotape libraries , which are only rated to last 15 years , with DVDs that are rated to last 100 years .
The internal drive will have inputs for both analog and IEEE 1394 Firewire , Parsons said .
The drive will come with video editing software for producing DVD-R discs that are then loaded into DVD players for enjoying through the television .
Parsons said that DVD is quickly becoming entrenched as a consumer electronics standard , and that more than 15 million DVD players will ship this year . "
Computer platforms come and go , but consumer electronics platforms stay around , " Parsons said .
like CDs and videotapes
Pioneer did not announce pricing for the DVR-103 , but said it would be substantially below the $ 5,400 price of its previous generation offering .
Parsons said the drive is expected to be available to OEMs in the first quarter of 2001 , and that the cost of media should drop to $ 10 per disc .
Parsons said the DVR-103 supports copyright protection by hiding the CSS key on the discs , which prevents disks from being unlocked and played .
content scrambling system
The DVR-103 is compliant with version 1.1 of the DVDRW specification , which creates a pre-embossed area on the disk , which protects against " bit-for-bit " copies of encrypted movies .




Sega 's Sooooo Sorry About Sony

Video game marketing has come to this : Nyah nyah nyah !
That 's the message put out by Sega in a postcard sent to the press , analysts and retail stores this week .
The postcard shows a freckled kid of about 7- or 8-years-old , sticking his tongue out at the camera .
The caption reads , " Our deepest condolences to Sony on their PS2 shipping difficulties . "
The message refers to Sony 's PlayStation 2 video game console , which was released last month in the United States with much fanfare .
Due to shortages , though , hardcore gamers have had a frustratingly difficult time getting their hands on PS2s .
So Sega saw a stumbling Sony , and it decided to kick the electronics giant in the chin .
SEGA
SNE
Besides the postcard , Sega 's red-headed taunting kid found a place in Gameweek magazine , and on a billboard truck that was driven around San Francisco 's multimedia gulch .
The truck even made a few swings around Sony 's Metreon , the shopping center that 's home to the world 's only PlayStation store .
" That particular message was targeted at the retail community , " said Joe Culley , Sega 's vice president of marketing . "
It was basically a reminder to them saying , ' We 're here to support you , ' " he said .
Culley went on , getting in another dig at Sony : " Clearly the shortfall from Sony put retailers in a very difficult position , and as good business partners , we wanted to remind them that the Dreamcast was out there . "
Attempts to reach Sony for comment on the Sega ad were unsuccessful , so Wired News was n't able to determine whether the company would be surreptitiously taping Kick Me signs to the backs of Sega execs in retaliation .
Sega 's kid ad is probably a bit understandable , given the tsunami of press that accompanied the PS2 's launch .
Sega , with its " next-generation " Dreamcast system already a year old , had to make sure that people did n't forget it existed .
" So we communicated our message in a very ' Sega-like ' way , " said Culley .
Billy Pidgeon , a gaming analyst at Jupiter Communications , agreed that Sega has always been the kind of company that teases its competition .
" They 've always been thumbing their nose at the competition , " Pidgeon said of Sega , presumably meaning that they 've also been sticking their tongues out . "
They did that with Nintendo , quite effectively -- that 's their modus operandi . "
Sega hopes that when people go to the store looking for a PS2 and do n't find one , they might consider purchasing a Dreamcast instead .




New Pet Robot Will n't Stain the Rug

LAS VEGAS -- The second-generation model of the popular Aibo pet robot was launched on Thursday by Sony , but unlike its predecessor , it will n't pee on the rug .
In an attempt to make the plastic pet less dog-like , Sony removed its bark and leg-cocking action , which was accompanied by the sound of running water .
" It 's not a cat or a dog , " said Jon Piazza , Sony PR manager . "
It 's a robot companion . "
" Personally , I think it looks like a little terrier , " he added . "
But people can pretty much decide what they want it to be . "
The new Aibo is a big draw at Comdex .
The plastic pet is attracting crowds so large , people at the back are complaining they can n't even see what 's on display .
The booth handed out more than 8,000 brochures on the first day and the Aibo website is having problems handling all the traffic , Piazza said .
Piazza said Sony hopes the new Aibo will be even better than its predecessor at eliciting strong bonds of attachment from its owner .
" It 's amazing , " he said . "
People refer to it as a living , organic creature .
They know it 's not but if you play with it all the time , it has that effect .
They call it by name and take it to the store or on vacation .
" With this one , it 's going to be even stronger because it has voice recognition . "
The new Aibo responds to 50 voice commands like " sit , " " stand " and " dance . "
It can also be conditioned .
Behaviors like playing and dancing can be positively reinforced with gentle strokes to touch sensors located on the Aibo 's head , back and under its chin .
But sharp taps to the touch sensors act as negative reinforcement and will eventually eliminate the behavior altogether .




3D Projection Without the Glasses

LAS VEGAS -- Perhaps the most exciting technology at Comdex this year was a 3D display that projected volumetric images into thin air , prompting show goers to gasp , burst out laughing and run around the booth in excitement .
At the back of one of the exhibit halls , Dimensional Media set up a booth full of 3D displays that projected images -- of objects such as cell phones or soda cans -- into space in front of the viewer .
The effect was not unlike the famous special effect in Star Wars where R2D2 projects a holographic display .
But unlike R2D2 's grainy video , the images at Comdex were often as vivid and concrete as real objects .
And unlike most other 3D displays , Dimensional Media 's does not require special glasses or any kind of headgear .
" It 's magic , " said Anna Zharkova , an event manager from Russia , who was running around the booth like a headless chicken . "
I can not believe it .
It 's just magic . "
Her colleague , Natasya Savina , said : " I think it is incredible .
I never thought at this exhibition to see something so wondrous .
Everything is quite common .
But this is so new , so amazing .
Next year , I would like to use it for myself so that my image can be at the booth , and I can be somewhere else . "
Dimensional Media , which is based in New York , originally developed the technology for the military with funding from Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency .
DARPA
The military wanted a true , volumetric 3D display that did n't require special glasses or complex electronics .
The simplest version of the technology is based on a system of mirrors and lenses .
The object whose image is being projected sits inside a pedestal , which projects the object 's light into space above the pedestal , where the image is reformed .
The effect is as if the object itself is hovering above the pedestal 's surface .
The company also demonstrated video versions of the technology , which projected video images in 3D .
The Russians played with a 3D teller-machine whose buttons floated in space in front off the viewer .
To activate the system 's virtual " buttons , " the viewer simply pointed a finger at the image of the button .
The system uses a grid of infrared lights -- similar to systems in stores that beep when a shopper enters -- to calculate the position of the viewer 's finger .
Dimensional Media said its images are already starting to turn up in advertising displays at shopping malls and airports around the world , and they should become quite common this year as more and more are installed .
" We are really starting to sell these systems , " said CEO Daniel Pfeffer .
Dimensional Media said the company will start testing the first volumetric 3D computer monitor early next year , which it hopes to sell to medical providers , the military and CAD/CAM companies .
Pfeffer said for the first time , the display will give viewers full " look around " of a projected image .
" I could project the image of your face and have full look-around , like you were really in front of me , " he said .
As an example of its use , Pfeffer said the monitor could project X-Ray or NMR data in 3D , creating a precise image of the inside of a patient 's skull and the location of , say , a tumor .
The display could then overlay another image onto the patient 's actual skull , showing the surgeon the exact place to cut .
" It 's the most unbelievable technology , " he said .




France 's First Gene-Screened Baby

PARIS -- A French woman has given birth to the nation 's first genetically screened baby after she lost two other children to a deadly genetic disease , doctors said Wednesday .
The baby boy , known only by his first name , Valentin , was born early Monday at the Antoine-Beclere Hospital in Clamart , outside Paris , doctors said .
His parents ' identities were not disclosed .
Doctors said the baby 's condition was " satisfactory , " though he was born six weeks before term .
The couple , who have no trouble conceiving naturally , underwent in vitro fertilization and a process called pre-implantation genetic diagnosis , or PGD , in an effort to ensure their baby did not have the gene defect .
Doctors would not specify which genetic disease the couple were trying to avoid , other than saying it destroys the liver .
In the United States , the same process resulted in the birth this summer of Adam Nash , in the hopes that his umbilical cord blood could save his older sister , Molly , who was suffering from Fanconi anemia , a rare genetic disease .
The French medical team studied the technique used at the Reproductive Genetics Institute in Chicago , where baby Adam was conceived .
Embryonic research is currently against the law in France , and doctors plan to ask lawmakers to repeal the ban on such research , the medical team said at a news conference .
" The couple had no problem having children , " Dr. Arnold Munnich , the genetic pediatrician who heads the Genetics Department at the Necker-Enfants Malades Hospital , said on France-Info radio . "
French
Their problem was having healthy children . "
Besides losing two young children , the baby 's mother also underwent an abortion after the fetus she was carrying was discovered to harbor the gene , doctors said .
Munnich said the principles and techniques were the same as in traditional prenatal diagnostic testing , " except that here we intervene at the moment of fertilization , in the earliest stages of the embryo 's development , before its implantation in the uterus . "
Munnich said he did not believe the procedure would lead to eugenics , the science of selecting genes to improve the human species .
Munnich worked closely on the operation with France 's leading obstetrician , Dr. Rene Frydman , who was responsible for the country 's first test-tube baby .
Jean-Francois Mattei , president of the centrist Liberal Democracy Party and member of the National Assembly 's Ethics Committee , called the birth a success .
The technique " allows families that have undergone terrible suffering to have the children they desire in safe conditions , " he said .
Twenty-one couples in France have already expressed interest in using the technique , and five women are currently carrying fetuses conceived using the screening technique , doctors said .




Jeepers Creepers , MP Peepers ?

WASHINGTON -- The U.S. Army is testing a wearable computer that links military police to one another and allows them to share streaming video feeds .
Dubbed " Digital MP , " the system has soldiers wear special eyeglass frames and electronic gloves , according to a report this week from the Army News Service .
Digital MP , developed by ViA Inc. , MicroOptical and Honeywell , uses a voice-activated interface and is designed for reconnaissance and anti-terrorism missions .
Clinton administration exodus : Here 's another politico who 's fled , albeit a little late , to the dot-com world : Mike McCurry .
This week , President Clinton 's former top spinmeister became the CEO of Grassroots.com , a political activism site .
" There is one thing clear from this remarkable election year , " McCurry said in a statement . "
There will be abundant need for tools that help organizations and citizens make their case to the new administration and the new Congress .
Grassroots.com is poised to bring the $ 35 billion political marketplace , the online products and services , advocates need for success . "
Dirty pixels : A criminal law banning morphed child porn is constitutional , a federal appeals court recently decided .
The 3-0 ruling from the U.S. 4th Circuit Court of Appeals largely agrees with similar decisions from the 6th Circuit and the 11th Circuit , but it breaks with the 9th Circuit , where a divided panel said the Child Pornography Protection Act of 1996 was overly broad and vague .
This split sets the stage for a review by the Supreme Court .
Watch , out Photoshop users : The law makes it a felony to create or possess a JPEG or any other graphical image that " appears to be of a minor engaging in sexually explicit conduct . "
Election humor : As in any political crisis , the real winners in Florida 's perpetual election have been humorists .
This week saw a hilarious parody of an Al Gore vs. George W. Bush discussion -- as if they were playing a Dungeons and Dragons role-playing game .
The Great Britain Guardian newspaper got in a nice jab with an " electile dysfunction " cartoon , while the presidency itself went up for sale on eBay .
And , of course , here 's another graphical parody ballot .
Media bash : If you secretly suspected the Washington media was shallow and crass , here 's a new report from the venerable Brookings Institution that seems to confirm it .
The report is a transition guide for Beltway neophytes who are thinking of taking high office in a Bush or Gore administration .
About 1,000 posts require Senate confirmation , which can be a nerve-wracking process for someone not used to the way that the nation 's capital city treats its officials .
The authors do n't paint a very flattering picture of reporters : " Journalists do want to gain your confidence , and it 's not because they want to be your friends . "
Replies Will Rodger of USAToday.com : " No , reporters generally do n't want to be friends to their sources .
Most of us want to air all sides of a story and do it ethically . "




Carnivore Can Read Everything

WASHINGTON -- The FBI 's controversial e-mail surveillance tool , known as Carnivore , can retrieve all communications that go through an Internet service , far more than FBI officials have said it does , according to a Bureau documents and a recent FBI test .
An FBI official involved with the test stressed Friday that although Carnivore has the ability to grab a large quantity of e-mails and Web communications , current law and specific court orders restrict its use .
Nevertheless , privacy experts said they are worried about the breadth of Carnivore 's capability and questioned why the FBI even conducted such a test in June if it intends to use the tool only for narrow purposes .
" That really contradicts the explanation that the FBI has provided as to the purpose of the system and how it works , " said David Sobel , general counsel for the Washington-based Electronic Privacy Information Center . "
We 've been led to believe that the purpose of Carnivore is to filter and pinpoint the particular communications that the FBI is authorized to obtain .
If that 's true , then why are they testing the system 's ability to store and archive everything ? "
Sobel 's group recently obtained the FBI documents that provide the test results , as part of litigation it brought under the Freedom of Information Act .
In the lab report , FBI officials said Carnivore " could reliably capture and archive all unfiltered traffic to the internal hard drive " and could save the information on removable high-capacity disks as well .
Marcus Thomas , head of the FBI 's cybertechnology section , said in an interview with The Associated Press that the test was only done to check Carnivore 's " breaking point . "
He said the tool would not be used to capture broad swaths of Internet communications in a real-world situation .
Thomas was one of the FBI agents who approved the lab report .
" Certainly , in operation , you could set the filters up to do nothing , " Thomas said . "
But our procedures are very detailed , we 'll only do what we 're allowed to in a court order . "
The difference of opinion is the latest in what has become a debate between Carnivore 's capabilities and its actual use .
While law enforcement officials have admitted that Carnivore can capture much more than e-mail , including Internet chats and Web browsing , FBI officials insist it is only used to copy e-mails to a criminal suspect or from a criminal suspect in accordance with a court order .
Opponents say the " black box " nature of the system keeps the public from knowing what it can really do , and its installation at an Internet provider may cause network problems .
The Electronic Privacy Information Center started receiving batches of Carnivore-related material in October , after a court ordered the FBI to release the information .
EPIC representatives said they have received about 550 pages so far , and expect to get only about 30 percent of the 3,000 documents related to Carnivore .
Most of the released documents have large portions blacked out .
FBI officials say Carnivore has been used in about 25 cases , most of them involving national security .
Congress considered several measures this year to rein in Carnivore , but none survived .
Lawmakers have said that they may consider measures again next year .
An independent review of Carnivore was ordered by Attorney General Janet Reno .
That report is due to be received by the Justice Department on Friday , Justice spokeswoman Chris Watney said .
Watney said the report is expected to be released to the public early next week , after it is edited to eliminate references to Carnivore 's internal blueprints and other sensitive material .




Creating a Digital Music Empire

LAS VEGAS -- To Sim Wong Hoo , the mission is simple -- build a platform that will become the standard for delivering digital music to consumers around the world .
At Comdex , the founder and CEO of Creative Technology described how his company 's recently released Nomad Jukebox player is the proper foundation for doing just that .
Mr. Sim , as he is known at Creative , believes the portable music player will be " 10 times more successful " than his company 's Sound Blaster line of sound cards .
Sound Blasters created , and now control , the market for PC audio .
Creative has sold more than 120 million Sound Blasters during the past 10 years .
CREAF
But Sim sees the Nomads as not limited to PC audio enthusiasts -- instead wandering far beyond computers to become a consumer electronics phenomenon .
He expects to ship more that 200,000 of the $ 500 Jukebox players during the first year of distribution , but expects that will be a fraction of the potential demand .
Sim is investing heavily in content providers and infrastructure companies while simultaneously pursuing relationships with record labels to bolster future Nomad Jukebox products .
With 6 GB of storage , the Nomad Jukebox , which launched in September , can hold the equivalent of 150 CDs ' worth of music in MP3 , Windows Media Audio or .WAV format .
Sim said this makes it appropriate for becoming a home music server that happens to be portable .
Creative first entered the crowded MP3 player space with the Nomad , Nomad II , and Nomad II MG players , which offer up to 64 MB of storage , but the company has much bigger plans for the Nomad Jukebox .
A plethora of consumer electronics vendors , including Sony , RCA , Samsung , and Diamond Multimedia , offer portable MP3 players that store music in RAM .
But Creative has first-mover advantage with its hard-disk-based Jukebox that provides about 100 times the capacity .
Sim expects the capacity on the Nomad Jukebox to double in the next six months , and is developing partnerships . "
We want the Jukebox to be the legal version of Napster " for distributing digital audio , Sim said .
Forrester Research analyst Jeremy Schwartz believes Creative is taking the right approach to become a mass-market device . " a great little device , " and is a good product to build a new business on , Schwartz said .
The Nomad Jukebox is
He believes the high price may limit the market penetration initially , but expects it to become less expensive over time .
Sim said acquiring a wide variety of content is essential to turning the Nomad Jukebox into an indispensable music repository .
In October , Creative released Savantium software and a complementary website for downloading news , sports , stock and weather information from publishers including Rolling Stone and The New York Times .
Creative is looking to release Jukebox models that come preloaded with dozens of albums from a particular genre of music , such as jazz or classical , Sim said .
The songs can be deleted , or purchased and unlocked after obtaining a key from the Internet .
Creative is also aggressively pursuing relationships with online music sellers and with major and independent labels to develop subscription models for delivering music to Nomad devices .




It 's New Media , But Is It Art ?

Artists have long toyed with the latest technologies to create pioneering works of art .
In that tradition , Tom Kemp has created what he calls the first " serious " contemporary artwork produced entirely on the handheld Palm computer .
Putting aside the merits of Kemp 's specific work , his claim begs a larger question : Is artwork " serious " simply because it has been done using a previously unexplored medium ?
" While such pioneering work is often interesting , the question is whether novelty alone is a useful criterion for art or merely a great excuse for talking about technology , " said Peter Lunenfeld , who teaches in the graduate program in Communication and New Media Design at the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena , California .
Not everyone thinks that novelty is enough .
" What difference does it make if it has been produced with a Palm of not ? " said Benjamin Weil , curator of media arts at the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art . "
I think that deeming it the ' first serious work of art ' is somewhat preposterous .
" I am really suspicious of techno-driven and techno-celebrating projects that desperately seek to be called art .
Art is about ideas , not about technology .
I would therefore suggest we stop being techno-fetishist , and getting all excited at the gizmo-ization of a practice that is obviously more than just gee whiz ! "
While other artists have created palmtop computer artworks , Kemp insists that his piece , Analysis is different .
" There are a lot of paintings .
done on the Palm
Some have been immaculately crafted , " Kemp said . "
But they are exhibitions of skill , not necessarily exhibitions of art . "
Analysis differs from other works of palmtop art in part because of the enormous energy it took to create the work , Kemp said .
Using the TealPaint application on a Palm Vx , Kemp produced 1,000 small paintings , each the size of the Palm 's screen , about two-and-a-half inches square .
Each painting captures small movements made with an electronic paintbrush to create unique characters .
Kemp assembled the small paintings in Photoshop on a Macintosh computer , printed them out on canvas and placed them in a huge grid , 4 feet high and 17 feet wide .




From Russia , With Drugs

A new biotech company 's drug pipeline is being fed directly from the former Soviet Union .
Feeding the drug pipeline from Russia gives Novelos , of Newton , Massachusetts , a significant leg up , said Harry Palmin , the company 's president .
Its business model is based on waiting for drugs to first get approval in Russia , and then to develop and commercialize them in the United States and the rest of the world .
" When we bring a drug into development and commercialization we already know how the drug performs in patients , which is invaluable , " Palmin said .
The concept is not lost on other , bigger pharmaceutical companies .
Several have drugs in trials in Russia where the drug approval process is cheaper and a bit more liberal .
In the United States , the Food and Drug Administration approves drugs for very specific indications , such as " non-small cell lung cancer . "
In Russia , they 're approved more broadly , i.e. , for " cancer . "
It takes about 10 years and a half a billion dollars to bring one drug to market in the United States .
But in Russia , according to a report in the business-to-business newsletter Concise Consumer , it takes only three to seven years and up to $ 7 million .
Novelos , however , enjoys an advantage that few if any pharmaceutical companies have -- its unique relationship to its counterpart in Russia , a biotech called BAM Medical Ltd.
Since 1998 , Palmin 's father has been a director at BAM , which performs all of the research and development for both BAM and Novelos drug development .
" It 's all in the family , " the younger Palmin said .
Another scientist at BAM is the father of the Novelos ' director of clinical and regulatory affairs .
Another reason Russia is attractive to drug prospectors is the population 's eagerness to participate in clinical trials .
Finding subjects for studies is a major challenge for researchers in the United States , where the population tends to be wary of being treated as " guinea pigs . "




Archimedes Gets a Makeover

A new study of an ancient manuscript means that 2,300 years after Archimedes ran naked through the streets of Syracuse shouting " Eureka ! " scientists will finally discover exactly what the Greek mathematician was bragging about .
It 's not that scholars do n't have a clue about his theories written in the two treatises On Floating Bodies and Method of Mechanical Theorems .
After all , much of modern science is based on materials in those aged manuscripts .
But thanks to the latest imaging technology being used on this third century B.C. manuscript , scientists will finally be able to read and study the whole thing .
The manuscript outlines Archimedes ' explanation of the pulley , the fulcrum and the lever , and the physics of flotation -- why boats float -- the discovery that compelled his famous , gleeful , and immodest streak during which he exclaimed in Greek , " I found it . "
" It 's the only original Archimedes manuscript .
It 's the Eureka manuscript -- Archimedes ' brain in a box , " said William Noel , curator of the Walters Art Gallery in Baltimore . "
It 's the most reliable example of a 2,000-year-old dead genius .
How much more important can you get than this ?
It 's absolutely seminal -- it cuts right to the heart of his persona . "
Deciphering the 174-page manuscript , however , is not an easy task .
Not only is the parchment in very poor condition , but the original text has been erased and the parchment recycled as a prayer book .
Scientists believe a scribe copied the manuscript in the 10th century from Archimedes ' original Greek scrolls .
Some 200 years later , the text was erased by a monk who re-used the parchment , creating a twice-used parchment book known as a " palimpsest , " a Greek word meaning " scraped again . "
" If it had survived complete and been known in the Italian Renaissance , the history of mathematics would almost certainly have been different , " wrote Nigel Wilson of the University of Oxford and a member of the advisory group responsible for the conservation and publication of the Archimedes manuscript , in an e-mail interview .
Once the restoration is complete , " we shall have a more intelligible text of the most important essay that Archimedes wrote , " Wilson said .
The original recycling process was painstaking .
The original manuscript was taken apart and the original ink scraped off .
The monk also cut the sheets in half , rotated the pages by 90 degrees and then reassembled the book .
This type of recycling was very common in the 12th century .
Parchment , made from animal skin , was often in short supply and very expensive .
Also , religious tracts -- containing exorcisms and prayers for the sick -- were all the rage , while advanced treatises on mathematical theories did n't exactly make the Top 40 charts .
A Danish scholar , Johan Ludvig Heiberg , discovered the Archimedes palimpsest in 1907 , and was able to make out parts of the text by using regular sunlight and a magnifying glass .
Heiberg published his research , and his text became the standard edition that school children sweat over today .
" Heiberg focused on recovering simply the text .
We are bound to gain a lot of insight from looking at the mathematical diagrams that Heiberg neglected .
...
There is no question that the text is going to be changed dramatically , " said Reviel Netz , professor of ancient science at Stanford University .
The palimpsest disappeared between the time that Heiberg studied it and the 1930s , when it resurfaced in a private collection in Paris .
On Oct. 29 , 1998 , it was sold at Christie 's Auction House in New York for $ 2 million .
The anonymous owner of the manuscript has entrusted the document to the care of the Walters for conservation and study .
To reconstruct the original document , Walters set up a competition to search for a team of scientists able to decipher the work . "
We had lots of applications for the job globally and we whittled it down to two , " Noel said .
The two winners were the Rochester Institute of Technology and Johns Hopkins University .
RIT
Both teams were given five pages of the palimpsest to work from . "
The five pages had a variety of problems -- faint text , mold -- one had a forgery on it , " Noel said .
The manuscript was so badly damaged that traditional methods of imaging , using visible or ultraviolet light , proved ineffective .
" It 's in terrible condition .
It 's had an awful lot of damage , " Noel said . "
It 's suffered from mold .
It 's animal skin , so it 's very durable , but mold can damage it .
It 's also been in a fire ; the edges are charred . "
The teams had the added problem of having to decipher the text without damaging the very frail parchment . "
We can n't remove material from the palimpsest , " said Johns Hopkins ' Bill Christens-Barry . "
It 's very fragile , so we can n't go into it or get in contact with it , so we have to use benign techniques . "




Behold the New Pentium 4

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Intel 's new Pentium 4 desktop PC chip promises snappy speeds and delivers enhanced multimedia performance , but it may not dazzle users of typical office applications .
The P4 , released Monday , features what Intel said is the first completely new desktop processor design since its 1995 release of the Pentium Pro processor .
Intel said the P4 chip has been redesigned to speed the delivery and creation of Internet-based multimedia content , with better graphics , voice and video performance .
The chip supplies swift rendering of multimedia content in part by anticipating what chunks of data will be needed next by the user , a task that it performs well when handling data like streaming video or large graphics files .
But , according to some experts , the P4 is n't very intuitive when it comes to standard office applications .
" People who do a lot of work online -- plus graphics artists and game players -- will like the P4 .
People who use word processing applications and spread sheets will n't see much of a difference in performance , " said John McCormick , CEO of Mtech , a corporate computer consulting firm .
McCormick , who bills himself as a consumer advocate for businesses , said that the P4 chip has some interesting new features , but he is advising clients who work outside of Web-based industries to wait before they buy .
Intel is offering two Pentium 4 chips running at 1.4 GHz and 1.5 GHz .
McCormick said both P4 chips are running office applications at only about " 10 percent " faster than the 1 GHz Pentium III , and so he sees no burning need for most of his clients to upgrade .
" Intel is using what they 've dubbed ' Hyper Pipelined Technology ' which allows the P4 chip to handle more processes at one time , " McCormick said . "
HPT
And its ' Advanced Dynamic Execution ' feature allows it to juggle more data .
ADE
So essentially what you have is a CPU with more multitasking capability , which &ndash; - via the ADE feature -- also attempts to anticipate what you might do next . "
But McCormick says he has n't been impressed with the P4 's ability to foresee the needs of office application users .
" The P4 is excellent at retrieving graphical information before the user asks for it , but it 's so-so with figuring out where you 're going next in a word document or spreadsheet , " he said . "
So most people do n't get much of a speed increase in their daily rounds of chores .
Frankly , from what I 'm seeing , I 'll tell my corporate clients to wait on the 1.13 GHz Pentium III , due early next year , which I really believe will produce faster speeds in basic applications than the Pentium 4 , " said McCormick .
The lack of speed increase puzzled some experts , who say the P4 's snappier system BUS , which now runs at 400 MHz -- compared to 133 MHz in top end PIII chips -- should have produced a greater speed increase across the board .
" A system bus moves information to and from the memory to the CPU and back again , " explained Andrew Minken , a technician at TekServices . "
So in theory , a faster bus should absolutely give you better overall performance .
And with the higher clock speed of the P4 CPU , we should be looking at a smoking configuration .
But I did n't see a huge jump in the speed of standard office-type applications .
I think that the ADE feature is n't as intuitive as Intel is saying it is . "
Where the P4 does shine , according to both Minken and McCormick , is in rendering multimedia content .
" The P4 incorporates 144 new graphics and multimedia instructions - &ndash; something that Intel calls ' Streaming SIMD Extensions 2' -- which absolutely speeds up image rendering and editing , video feeds , and anything with sound and motion .
SSE2
It 's a stunning chip for graphics use and may sway some of our Mac-addict art directors over to the darkside , " said Terry Ponti , a computer graphics instructor at the School of Visual Arts .
But Ponti pointed out that the software is n't yet available that will allow users to get the full benefit from the P4 architecture . "
Once we have applications in place that take advantage of these new multimedia instructions , only then will you see real performance improvements , " Ponti said . "
There 's a definite increase now in graphics apps , but the P4 will n't really come into its own until the applications support it . "
Intel has announced that major companies like Macromedia and Microsoft will add SSE2 support to their programs .
Microsoft , according to Intel , will incorporate SSE2 into its DirectX 8 driver .
The company also expects to deliver an even snappier P4 chip running at 2 GHz in the third quarter of 2001 .
Dell and IBM have both released PCs with the new chip .
Dell 's Dimension 8100 desktop includes a 1.4 GHz Pentium 4 , 128 MB of RDRAM , a 40 GB hard drive , and a 19-inch monitor .
$ 1,999
IBM 's NetVista A60i PC also sports a 1.4 GHz Pentium 4 , priced at $ 2,199 , sans monitor .
McCormick said he did n't want to give the impression that he was " slamming " the P4 .
" I think it has some interesting options and a lot of potential .
But people tend to judge the value of a CPU by its stated clock speed and that 's a mistake , " McCormick said . "
What Intel is offering with the P4 , to my mind , is a chip targeted towards people who do very specific types of work . "
Minken also felt that the P4 chip is an excellent choice if you " will be working in the areas that Intel clearly states that the chip is designed to impact &ndash; graphics and multimedia .
In its current incarnation , the P4 will n't do much for the standard cube-dweller .
" This is not a slap across Intel 's face - &ndash; they have been very clear about this chip 's intent and potentials , " Minken added . "
People simply need to stop making buying decisions based solely on techno lust and how fast something might be able to go given the perfect conditions , and start looking at how and for what they use their machines . "
