Cantwell Leave Tech Alone ?

SEATTLE -- Without any of the courtroom drama or street-side protests that have marked the presidential ballot recount in Florida , America 's other interminable election finally concluded late last Friday .
Maria Cantwell -- the 41-year-old dot-com mega-millionaire who financed her upstart campaign for U.S. Senate against three-term incumbent Slade Gorton -- was declared the winner in the closest statewide race in Washington 's history .
The Democrat 's victory was significant , perhaps more than anything because it gives the Senate a 50-50 split between Democrats and Republicans .
What influence she 'll wield in terms of the future of technology legislation is unclear .
Cantwell is closely associated with the Internet and technology industry that has fueled Seattle 's financial renaissance , and she carried the tech-heavy Seattle area .
However , during the campaign , Gorton blasted her for not supporting Microsoft as strongly as he did in the company 's antitrust battle with the federal government .
Gorton led the charge on Capitol Hill against the Department of Justice 's antitrust suit .
Cantwell has said she would seek a seat on the commerce committee , where her expertise in so-called new-economy issues ostensibly will be put to good use .
What that means specifically will be determined .
Cantwell was one of the first hires at streaming media pioneer RealNetworks , riding the company 's success over the last several years to become a senior vice president and a multi-millionaire before taking a leave-of-absence early this year .
That said , the former state legislator and one-term congresswoman did n't campaign on new-technology issues .
Mostly , she campaigned on the themes of campaign finance reform and the need for new blood .
" I will be a senator for all of Washington , " Cantwell said after the official tally was announced .
Cantwell carried just five of the state 's 39 counties , but won decisively in the Puget Sound area .
Joe Cerrell , a spokesman for RealNetworks , said the company is clearly happy for its former executive .
" We think Maria will be an effective and an outspoken advocate in Congress for the technology industry as a whole , but in general as well ... representing the state of Washington , " he said .
Cerrell said he had no independent information on the senator-elect 's future relationship with the company .
What 's clear is that the money she earned at RealNetworks and used to finance her campaign played a major role in her victory .
Shortly after the state 's September primary , a close Gorton aide acknowledged that Cantwell 's deep pockets were a major concern for the incumbent .
" We 're scared to death , " said Cynthia Berger , who had left her post as Gorton 's press secretary to head his re-election campaign communications unit .
Berger went on to deride Cantwell as " the poster child " for dot-com millionaires who run for Congress because they " need a hobby . "




MP3.com Lets Streams Flow

MP3.com re-opened its streaming music service on Tuesday after settling its year-long battle with the recording industry and agreeing on a licensing structure to compensate the labels and publishers .
The new service has two-tiers : a free , limited service which allows consumers to store 25 CDs , and a subscription service that holds 500 CDs .
Both services include banner ads , although the $ 49.95 annual subscription fee service has less intrusive pitches .
MP3.com had halted access to the my.mp3.com service on May 10 after legal action was taken by the major-label music industry .
Users who sign up for the my.mp3.com service can stream music from MP3.com 's database to Internet-enabled devices .
Consumers who purchase music from MP3.com 's online retail partners can also have their music automatically added to their lockers without the CD being counted toward their limit .
" This is a great day for music fans , " MP3.com president Robin Richards said , in a written release . "
It 's also terrific for artists and labels who stand to benefit from potential new revenues .
We believe that the service will stimulate CD sales and generate enthusiastic activity from our users . "
Those revenues will come primarily from the streaming fees that MP3.com agreed to pay as part of a settlement it signed with the labels and publishers .
Along with hefty awards for past infringements that ranged between $ 20 and $ 57 million dollars per major label , the digital music company must pay per-stream fees each time listeners access music from their lockers .
The labels will receive 1.5 cents each time a song is stored in a virtual lockers , and the publishers will get an undisclosed , one-time storage fee .
Each time a consumer accesses a stream from their account , the labels receive one-third of a cent each and the publishers expect to garner a quarter-of-a-cent charge .
The licensing fees could prove to be a hefty burden for MP3.com and its competitors , who must pay similar charges as they try to develop viable locker services .
" They are going to have to wrap other services around the model , " said IDC analyst Malcolm Maclachlan . "
You have to provide very personalized services to people so that the music becomes portable , and then people would be willing to pay for that service . "
MP3.com has the benefit of first-mover status -- for now .
As Richards pointed out , " There 's not another service out there that is comparable to my.mp3.com . "
That might not hold true much longer as several competitors are expected to ramp up or launch their streaming locker services very soon .
" I think there are enough businesses that are entering the space that it was important for them to launch as soon as possible to sign up users , " said Maclachlan . "
MP3.com 's money is already spent , so they have no reason not to launch .
Other companies like Musicbank start losing money when they launch because they are n't going to be profitable right away . "
Musicbank has investments from the major labels and has been working with the National Music Publishers Association to secure its licensing .
The streaming service is expected to launch before the end of the year .
Myplay.com was the first locker service when it launched in October 1999 , but has slowly been acquiring users .
Myplay.com avoided the legal issues by requiring users to upload their own music into a personal locker .
Unlike its competitors , however , Myplay.com 's service requires users to spend several minutes uploading each CD .
Sony also plans to unveil its Unsurface digital media service later this year .
The service will link Sony customers to online repositories that can include music , movies , videos , photographs , and video games from a variety of devices .
The Recording Industry Association of America won its copyright infringement suit against MP3.com in April .
In that suit , U.S. District Court Judge Jed Rakoff ruled that the digital music company 's creation of a database of 45,000 CDs infringed on the major labels ' copyrights .
MP3.com spent the next seven months settling with the five major music labels and the publishing industry in order to re-establish the my.mp3.com service .




Son-in-Law Wanted : Geeks Apply

MUMBAI , India and SAN FRANCISCO -- In India , love and longing are chiefly resolved by a concept called arranged marriage .
And a large number of families subscribe to the reasoning that if their daughter has to marry a stranger , let her future husband be an IT professional working in the United States .
Purushotam Narang , a marriage broker in Mumbai , explains this phenomenon with an Indian joke . "
Definition of heaven : American salary , Indian wife , Chinese food and British accommodation .
Definition of hell : American wife , British food , Chinese accommodation and Indian salary . "
So where does a family go when searching for a suitor ?
The Web , of course .
Matrimonial websites are the cyber version of the traditional " seeking bride/groom " Sunday section found in any Indian newspaper .
While the newspaper classifieds are still thriving , it is estimated that there are over 1,000 such websites with over half a million listings .
" I saw that a lot of my South Asian friends were having trouble meeting people with whom they could have serious relationships .
I started the website to help them out and it has grown since , " said Rajiv Giri , founder of Indianmarriages.com .
Some sites like A1 Indian Matrimonials and INDOlink matrimonials are free and require just a registration , while others like Jeevansathi.com charge a monthly fee to enable contact with a potential amour .
" The matrimonials are a huge business , " said Paul Singh who runs Sikhnet Matrimonials out of New Mexico . "
More and more people definitely want to use this .
It is not a dating service and this not a mail-order bride service . "
So , when Ninad Vengurlekar , of Mumbai , began the husband-search for his sister , he chose matrimonial websites over advertising in the newspaper .
After all , if you want to find Net-savvy men , it 's a good idea to search for them on the Net .
" To my pleasant surprise , 80 percent of the queries I got were from Indian boys in the American IT industry , " said Vengurlekar , who said he gets about 20 queries every month .
That does n't mean the tech industry is overflowing with romance .
The lure is more practical .
Frankly , if tomorrow chemical engineers are earning more than IT people , then the focus will shift , Narang said . "
So the loyalty of the woman 's parents is not to information technology but who is earning more .
And currently IT men are hot property . "
Dhanesh Joshi , 29 , is beginning to realize this .
He is a software engineer with Veritas Software in California .
He has come to Mumbai for a month to " find a girl and get married to her . "
In the first week alone , he met four women , spoke to more and examined several horoscopes .
" People here are very eager to get their girls married to a software engineer working in the United States , " Joshi said . "
There is no dearth of proposals .
I am going through them carefully . "
But there is one small problem .
He wants to return to India in around four years .
That alone can be a deal-breaker .
" I come clean about it to the girl 's parents .
I tell them that I want to return to India in the near future , " Joshi said . "
Some parents get disappointed and I do not hear from them again . "




Bluetooth 's Popularity Contest

SAN JOSE -- It 's conventional wisdom in the wireless technology industry that Americans lag behind Europeans and Asians in cell phone adoption and usage of the " wireless Web . "
To the chagrin of wireless evangelists , this trend will repeat itself in the rate at which North Americans adopt Bluetooth -- a much-heralded wireless technology that allows devices within 30 feet of each other to communicate .
Three bigwig phone manufacturers -- Motorola , Nokia and Ericsson -- introduced at the Bluetooth Developers Conference in the San Jose Convention Center this week their first Bluetooth-enabled phones and wireless accessories .
Most are to be shipped early next year .
Players in the industry say Bluetooth chips will initially be embedded in portable devices such as laptops and mobile phones .
Larger devices such as car dashboards and household appliances will be Bluetooth-enabled in a few years .
But Nokia and Ericsson 's Bluetooth products are for their Global System for Mobile Communications phones , not compatible with the more popular Code-Division Multiple Access and Time Division Multiple Access infrastructures and phones in the Americas .
Both GSM and TDMA are network standards that use the same frequency to transmit data , while CDMA uses multiple frequencies .
Users of certain cell phones will receive error messages if their service provider does not offer its services on the same network as the cell phone .
A Nokia spokesman could n't say when the " Nokia Connectivity Pack " -- a battery with a Bluetooth chip for the Nokia model 6210 phone , a connectivity card and PC card adapter -- would even reach the American market .
The Pack , which allows consumers to use their 6210 phones as GSM modems to connect to laptops -- is expected to be available to Europeans and Asians in the first quarter of next year .
" Please note that there are huge differences in market maturity , " said Waldemas Sakalus , general manager for applications business management at Nokia . "
Europe has been more advanced than the United States . "
Sakalus ' hailing of Nokia as a Bluetooth market leader was immediately rebuffed by competitors .
" This is the very first thing they 've announced , " said R.E. Skip Bryan , director of technology market development for the American Standards Business unit of Ericsson . "
I 'm puzzled by what they are going to do .
You are the first to tell me they 've announced those . "

Forever Amigos with Amiga

The Amiga faithful struggling to keep their antiquated systems running and former Amigans who are now stuck with PCs , can savor their lost love with the newest version of emulator software Amiga Forever .
Amiga Forever 4.0 , released last week , is the latest update to an emulation technology for PC and Macintosh hardware that fully simulates the beloved Amiga environment .
For PC owners clamoring to keep the platform alive , Amiga Forever is a chance to stick with their favorite environment , said Michael Battilana , CEO of Cloanto , in Las Vegas , Nevada .
Amiga Forever 4.0 is primarily a cosmetic upgrade that mirrors some of the design changes that were put into Amiga 's latest OS upgrade , version 3.9 , which was released earlier this year .
The emulator has adopted the GlowIcons and some other " look and feel " elements of version 3.9 .
The software also includes Amiga Explorer 4.0 , a combined Amiga-to-PC connectivity and disk utility , plus more than 20 new tools , and a 20-percent speed improvement , according to Battilana .
Users who like to relive history can change Amiga Forever to operate like all of the previous Amiga OS versions , from the original 1.x OS releases right up to the latest version .
Although Amiga Forever will n't work with software that requires Amiga-specific hardware , such as the Video Toaster , developer Cloanto said it can run most other Amiga programs .
The software can be run in Motorola 68000 , 68020 or 68030 emulation modes since some applications break on the different chips .
The user can also control how much memory is allocated to the emulator , since applications can crash when using too much or too little memory .

A Wireless Doctor Is in the House

As the Internet changes the face of health care , allowing consumers access to more medical information than ever , it 's also changing the way patients interact with their physicians , and how health insurance is being packaged .
Add into the equation the influence that wireless tools and technologies have on how doctors receive information , and it becomes clear that health care will sport a radical new look in the not-too-distant future .
All those trends were evident at the eHealthcareWorld conference this week in New York .
And all of them were tempered by concerns about privacy .
One popular concept is Internet-enabled patient call centers .
Such centers will " provide patients with diverse communications vehicles , " said Victor Otley , president and CEO of Intellicare , a South Portland , Maine , vendor that provides technologies for the centers .
Patients using online call centers will be able to communicate with doctors and other care providers via voice-over Internet protocol , e-mail , secure chat , collaborative Web browsing and , of course , the telephone .
And a skill-based routing system knows what types of questions need to go to a live agent .
For instance , if a person sends a message requesting an appointment , the system will automatically send it to the person handling appointments .
Dr. Daniel Sands , clinical director of electronic patient records and communication for CareGroup HealthCare System and Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center , is a proponent of what he calls ePatient Centered Communications , or ePCC .
Sands uses a system called PatientSite , a Web-based communications program that integrates into his patients ' records .
It allows patients to view and even annotate their own records , with the doctor 's permission , including X-rays and lab results .
The system archives e-mail messages , whis is an important feature , said Sands during a seminar on ePCC systems -- because it gives doctors and patients a " paper trail " of messages sent back and forth .
PatientSite also uses intelligent routing to send clinical messages to the doctor , prescription-refill requests to prescription nurses , and appointment requests to the administrative staff .
The Internet will drive consumer-choice health care , according to Dr. Regina Herzlinger , author of Market-Driven Health Care and a business administration professor at Harvard Business School .
Herzlinger told a keynote audience that , just as the Internet 's " control , choice and cost-effectiveness " spurred growth in the financial services industry on the Web , so it will be with " consumer-choice health care , " an insurance system that lets consumers select services from a large menu of choices using money provided specifically for health care by their employers .
Where employees generally have between one and three choices for insurance now , their options will soon include items such as amount of coverage , types of benefits , provider composition and length of contract .
In addition , the Internet will spur " performance ratings of insurers , a flow of personalized information and health care guides , " Herzlinger said .
Wireless technologies and handhelds are also sending health care into new terrain .
Charlottesville , Virginia-based Unbound Medicine , for example , offers a Palm-based knowledge-management product that helps physicians answer patient questions on the spot .




Do You Know Where Your Kids Are ?

BERLIN -- To many parents , it may be a dream : A little gadget that can track where a child is at all times .
To many kids , it may a fun thing : Their own cell phone , complete with a backpack shaped like a stuffed animal to house the global positioning technology that makes it all happen .
That at least is the vision of Susanne Mueller-Zantop , under whose guidance Siemens has developed a child 's mobile phone with stepped-up monitoring capability .
" I want us to apply technology in a smart way to have kids participate in what we enjoy about mobile life , " she said . "
We do n't want parents to force the devices on their kids .
We want kids to happily carry them with them .
That 's why I talk a lot about fun .
It must be playful . "
Tests begin this month in Germany , where 50 families have agreed to take part , and the service is scheduled to debut in Germany and Great Britain next spring .
Expected to cost between $ 100 and $ 200 for the hardware , and less than $ 20 a month for the service , the devices are intended for children between the ages of 3 and 11 .
It may be appropriate that the first tests are in the Munich area , although Siemens also plans to offer the service in Hamburg and Berlin .
West Germans have traditionally had more access to technology than their counterparts in the former East , some of whom are used to seeing high-tech monitoring devices as something to be feared .
" There is a little feeling of ' Big Brother is watching , ' " said Maxim Leo , a 30-year-old lifelong East Berliner . "
In the Eastern times , until '89 , it was n't necessary to have such electronic control of things , because there was a wall and the child could n't go very far . "
But Leo , father of a 6-month-old baby girl , thinks that the new idea from Siemens could have practical applications .
" I think for older children , around 10 or 11 years old , it could be a good thing .
I heard about children who go into discos at a very young age .
If you have the possibility to know where your child is , it could be a good thing .
But for very young children , I do n't know if it 's really a good solution . "
Mueller-Zantop , mother of a 10-year-old boy , said her inspiration in developing the project started out being personal .
" I once had a terrible day because there was that Swissair plane crash and I had evidence that my son was on that plane , but I could n't reach him , " she said . "
That was the worst day of my life .
He was n't on the plane , but it was terrifying until I was able to talk to him . "
How does it work ?
Every 15 minutes , the child 's phone communicates exact coordinates to a call center .
Parents can phone into the call center to get information about their children 's whereabouts .
A child can hit a button , providing instant location information to the call center which , in emergencies , can listen in on whatever the child 's handset is picking up .




Music to Bluetooth 's Ears ?

SAN JOSE , California -- It 's the wireless version of Napster .
Imagine being able to swap music files with a friend by using MP3 players embedded with Bluetooth chips -- a wireless radio link that allows devices within 30 feet of each other to interact .
No company present at this week 's Bluetooth Developers Conference in San Jose announced it would release MP3 players with embedded Bluetooth wireless technology .
But in what may be another thorn in the side of the recording industry , a company from Ireland demonstrated a precursor to what may become the next rage in wireless technology .
Parthus Technologies , which develops and licenses software to power mobile devices , led numerous journalists to a suite displaying its MP3 and Bluetooth platforms .
The demonstration consisted of two laptops that streamed MP3 files through a 24-bit digital signal processing circuit -- or a wireless communications filter -- into a box with a couple speakers that represented MP3 players .
" One of the scenarios we 're looking at is kids with MP3 players with Bluetooth can swap tracks with each other , " said Bob Tait , senior product marketing manager for the Bluetooth wireless business unit of Parthus Technologies .
" Yeah , the music industry is n't going to like that . "
Indeed , cords will n't be in the way of the Recording Industry Association of America fighting wireless file swapping .
" The recording industry has been working on many different delivery systems so consumers can enjoy music when they want it and how they want it , " said Amy Weiss , RIAA senior vice president for communications . "
But whether music is on-line or off-line , wireless or wired , it is important that intellectual property and copyright is protected . "
Wired News was unable to reach Bertelsmann for comment .
Bertelsmann , after months of legal tangling with Napster , is now working with the online music file exchanger .
Still , many exhibitors milling about in the San Jose Convention Center expect to see , toward the end of 2001 , " multi-point access " Bluetooth devices such as the MP3 player , which can send data to up to seven other devices .
Many multi-point access products are still undergoing testing for " master-slave switching " -- to make sure that certain devices are the ones sending information to the other intended devices .
Initially , single point products , such as Bluetooth-enabled wireless headsets and mobile phones , will be offered to consumers .
" There 's more complexity " in single point to multi-point access , said Frank Hennekens , a manager of key accounts and licensing for Ericsson 's Bluetooth division .




FBI Hacks Alleged Mobster

WASHINGTON -- Nicodemo S. Scarfo , the son of Philadelphia 's former mob boss , was almost paranoid enough .
Scarfo , who has been charged with masterminding a mob-linked loan sharking operation in New Jersey , reportedly used the popular PGP encryption software to shield his computer 's secrets from prying eyes .
But when the feds learned of Scarfo 's security measures , they decided to do something that would bypass even the best encryption software : FBI agents sneaked into Scarfo 's office in Belleville , New Jersey , on May 10 , 1999 , and installed a keyboard-sniffing device to record his password when he typed it in.
A seven-page court order authorized the FBI and cooperating local police to break into Scarfo 's first-floor " Merchant Services of Essex County " office as many times as necessary to deploy , maintain , and then remove " recovery methods which will capture the necessary key-related information and encrypted files . "
The case , which is awaiting trial , appears to be the first in which the U.S. government used such aggressive surveillance techniques during an investigation , and some legal observers say the FBI 's breaking-and-entering procedures go too far .
" I do n't think it 's constitutional , " says David Sobel , general counsel of the Electronic Privacy Information Center in Washington , D.C. " This case has the potential to establish some very important precedents on this issue . "
Scarfo 's prosecution comes at a time when the FBI 's Carnivore surveillance system is under increasingly heavy fire from privacy groups , and the use of data-scrambling encryption products appears to be growing .
Last week , for instance , news leaked out about Yahoo 's encrypted Web-based e-mail service it introduced through a deal with Zixit , a Dallas firm .
Scarfo has been charged with supervising " an illegal gambling business " in violation of state and federal law and using extortionate loan shark tactics , according to a three-count indictment filed in federal court in June 2000 .
He has pleaded not guilty .
" There 's nothing that we can talk about or are at liberty to talk about in the case , " says Michael Drewniak , a spokesman for the U.S. Attorney 's office for the District of New Jersey .
Drewniak would not comment on the use of encryption , saying " we do not discuss evidence . "




Books , Cooks and Marketing Hooks

Whats cooking at Random House ?
Going right to the readers of the cookbooks they publish , Random House is offering an online " Ask the Expert " section .
Readers can ask popular cookbook editors questions , or browse through a list of questions that have already been answered .
The publisher hopes the Q&A section will help increase sales volume as well as strengthen brand recognition with online book buyers .
" Historically , publishers have been dependent on retailers to communicate with consumers .
The Internet allows publishers to bridge that gap , " said Terrance Cheng , director of corporate website marketing for Random House .
The software , created by Broad Daylight , allows a company to be " self-service enabled , " while saving on expensive call centers and help desks .
And since the Q&A is immediately published to the companys website , other customers can benefit as well .
It used to take a hundred phone calls to answer a hundred identical questions about oven time for the turkey ; now all frantic cooks have to do is call up the site .
Broad Daylight will adapt its software to a number of areas , including business books , reading groups and the academic market .
" Down the line this technology could also be used to help authors communicate directly with their readers , thus developing community and fan-base efficiently , " Cheng said .
- - -
What 's in an author 's name.com ? : The Authors Guild has filed a compliant on behalf of nine authors -- including R. L. Stine , Joanna Lindsey , Elizabeth Strout , Susan Elizabeth Phillips and Billie Letts -- to get back their dot-com names from the British firm , Old Barn Studios .
Adam Cohen , an intellectual property attorney with the New York City firm Kane Kessler , P.C. , makes the case that an author has common law trademark rights in his or her name by virtue of international reputation .
And that Old Barn Studios does not have proprietary rights to those names .
" Each of these authors names has come to be recognized by the relevant public as indicating a source of the literary and other works of the authors , " said Cohen .
Even without a registered trademark , he explained , these names have acquired distinctiveness and function as common law trademarks .
Since Old Barn , Cohen said , has no proprietary interest in the domain names and registered them in " bad faith " as defined by ICANN , the company must transfer those domain names back to their rightful owners .
" For authors , whose names and reputations are their most valued stock-in-trade , bringing this proceeding was absolutely necessary , " said Letty Cottin Pogrebin , president of the Authors Guild .
According to the Guild , many administrative panels that have resolved claims brought pursuant to the ICANN policy have ruled that an individuals can have common law trademark rights in their names even without having registered the trademark .
In one such case , author Jeanette Winterson won her domain name back from British scholar Mark Hogarth .
Last year , Hogarth registered the dot-com , dot-org and dot-net names of 130 well-known authors -- including nine of the plaintiffs in this Guild suit -- and then allegedly attempted to sell them to the authors for a portion of their royalty earnings .
According to the Guild , Hogarth has now transferred all of the dot-com authors ' domain names to Old Barn Studios .
But he still owns the dot-org and dot-net names .
- - -
And whats in a name change ? : Reflecting a change in what it perceives as the markets needs , SoftLock.com has renamed itself Digital Goods .
It has partnered with DRM giant , Reciprocal , and is offering up a suite of interactive marketing services .
These tools include an affiliate retailer network with thousands of online partners , a customized search engine registration capability that leverages major search portals and the ability to embed offers for specific relevant content in news feeds and other website content .
For example , you might be reading this article and receive , in real time , an offer to purchase specific publishing analysis reports from content provider Dun & Bradstreet .
" Our goal is to help publishers unleash the value of their content by providing the next-generation tools and services needed to deliver rights-protected multimedia content to a maximum audience of consumers , " said Scott Griffith , chairman and chief executive officer of Digital Goods .
Digital Goods is also promoting viral marketing through its Passalong technology -- a patented system that turns friend-to-friend content sharing into a sales channel .
Recently one of the most intriguing examples of viral marketing bypassed digital management rights , offering an unencrypted e-book .
Seth Godin offered the entire text of his book , Unleashing the IdeaVirus free online .
Over 250,000 people downloaded the book and passed it on to a total of at least 600,000 .
His idea was to spread the word by sending the book for free online in the hopes that people would want to buy the hardcover copy .
It worked , leading to sales of almost 30,000 copies of the $ 40 hardcover version .
But whether viral marketing of e-books for the expressed purpose of selling e-books will work is another matter .
Godin does n't believe that charging for content on the Web will work .
He sees the whole e-book phenomenom as a way to market something else , something other than the e-book itself .
" Digital content wants to be free and people just wont pay for it , no matter how hard you get them to try , " Godin said .

Basically , it allows any company to have a branded e-publishing business on its own site .
Mary Westheimer , president of Bookzone.com , is launching the service with several clients , including the Independent Publishers Group , Specialty Books -- which provides books to 58 online universities -- and the Audio Publishers Association .

Joys and Sorrows of the Mac OS X

I had the same reaction to Mac OS X that a lot of people have had -- how the heck do I make it work ?
After installing the software , which went effortlessly , I struggled to figure out how to eject the installation disk .
I expected to drag the disk 's icon to the Trash , but there was no icon on the desktop where I expected it to be .
It took about five minutes of dickering around to figure out that the disk icon was now in the Finder window .
My first reactions to this confusion were frustration and anger -- not a good start to working with the new system .
But after a few days of casual use , I 'm really warming to Mac OS X.
The fluid , dynamic Aqua interface is a pleasure to watch .
Like a kid , I spent a long time opening and closing applications just to watch the Dock at the bottom of the screen expand and contract as it added and removed program icons .
And then , like Jerry Lewis , I ran the mouse up and down the Dock , laughing as the application icons ballooned to twice their size as the mouse cursor passed over them .
I like Mac OS X 's sparse look .
It 's even more stripped down than Windows 2000 , my current operating system of choice .
And I like the details : the see-through menus , the drop shadows , the glowing buttons .
The whole machine -- the iMac and its iMac-like interface -- look slick and modern .
Older operating systems , especially Windows 98 , look hopelessly old-fashioned and stale by comparison .
Mac OS X 's underlying system seems fast , though the original 233 MHz iMac I installed it on sometimes struggles to do some computationally intensive tasks , like redrawing windows as they are dragged across the screen .
Applications also seem to take a long time to load up and I sometimes found myself banging the keyboard or the mouse in an attempt to make things go faster .
I also found myself irritated by the bouncing icons that accompany the launch of an application .
However , I was pleasantly surprised to discover that Mac OS X ran just fine with only 32 MB of RAM -- the standard configuration for the original Bondi Blue iMacs .
Apple recommends 128 MB .
Trouble is , there was n't enough memory to open a browser or do much else , and so I upgraded the machine with another 128 MB of memory .
It 's a good thing RAM is relatively cheap .
Now it zips along nicely .
For a long time , PCs have rendered Web pages faster than Macs , but Mac OS X seems to be very responsive when it comes to Web browsing , a welcome improvement .
I installed Omni Group 's OmniWeb browser , which -- in keeping with Mac OS X -- has a nice simple interface that is bright and colorful .
It does , however , have some unusual default settings .
The browser asks you every time whether you want to accept a cookie , a chore that quickly becomes tiring , and I was unable to log into Hotmail , a problem that I have n't yet figured out .
The biggest disappointment was Mac OS X 's Classic Environment -- the part of the operating system that runs traditional Macintosh applications .
The Classic Environment was painfully slow and unstable .
After crashing a couple of times , I gave it up .
If I need the classic Mac OS , I 'll boot right into it at startup .




Privacy a Likely Loser in Treaty

WASHINGTON -- A controversial cybercrime treaty supported by the Clinton administration likely will not be amended to include privacy protections , a key European official said on Thursday .
" We can not find an acceptable international standard in terms of privacy as it applies to this treaty , " said Henrik Kaspersen of the Council of Europe , which expects to finalize the document this month .
" We do n't want to exclude privacy .
We very much want to include it , " said Kaspersen , chairman of the council 's committee of cybercrime experts . "
But there are a number of existing case laws dealing with privacy throughout Europe , and we 're also dealing with countries like the United States and Japan that have differing legal systems . "
The treaty , which is being circulated among more than 40 nations , is designed to aid police investigations by requiring websites and Internet service providers to collect and record information about their users , a move privacy groups insist goes too far .
It could also make it illegal to distribute some kinds of security products used by system administrators to secure their networks against intruders .
Kaspersen 's remarks came at an event highlighting the release of a report by McConnell International , a Washington policy consultancy founded by Bruce McConnell , a White House aide under Presidents George Bush and Bill Clinton .
The Cyber Crime and Punishment report reviewed the state of computer crime laws in 52 nations .
Ten different offenses were sorted into four general areas : data crimes , network crimes , access crimes and related misdeeds , such as computer forgery and computer-related fraud .
Of the countries analyzed , the report found that nine had extended their criminal laws online to prosecute a majority of the offenses on the list .
" The long arm of the law does not yet reach across the global Internet , " McConnell said . "
Organizations must rely on their own defenses for now .
Governments , industry and civil society must all work together to develop consistent and enforceable national laws to deter future crimes in cyberspace . "
The McConnell International report strongly supports the Council of Europe 's approach , and says the group has been " realistic , practical , efficient , balanced , and respectful of due process that protects individual rights . "
But Jim Dempsey , senior staff counsel for the Center for Democracy and Technology , said the council has not adequately addressed privacy concerns .




Mac OS Facelift Turns Back Time

A graphic designer is working on a complete facelift of Mac OS X that would replace the system 's glitzy new look with one more closely resembling the traditional Mac interface .
Raul Gutierrez , a graphic designer and photographer from Los Angeles , is developing a software patch that would strip away OS X 's striking new look -- replacing it with one that looks more like the interface in the current Mac OS , which is often referred to as " Platinum " because of its distinctive silvery gray color scheme .
" I 'm trying as much as possible to create something that looks like the standard Platinum theme that most Mac users are used to , " Gutierrez said . "
It 's not an exact copy but it 's a good approximation . "
Apple 's new operating system , which is currently undergoing a public beta test in preparation for its release early next year , has garnered equal amounts of praise and criticism .
A lot of people like its candy-colored interface , but some Mac traditionalists miss cherished features , or are having trouble adapting ingrained computing habits to the new system .
A large number of these critics have tweaked OS X in one way or another with various hacks and utilities to make it more closely resemble the system they are accustomed to .
But Gutierrez 's project is more ambitious .
Instead of putting together a grab bag of tweaks and hacks , Gutierrez plans to completely overhaul the interface .
He is using an interface editor called Theminator , which is currently unavailable because of what appears to be a legal tussle with Apple .
Neither Theminator 's author , Dave MacLachlan , nor Apple could be contacted for an explanation .
Gutierrez , who has been using OS X for more than a year , said he is retrofitting the system 's interface because he can n't get used to switching between the old interface in OS X 's Classic Environment -- the part of the system that runs older Mac applications -- and the new Aqua interface that overlooks everything else .
" I find the transition jarring and annoying , " he said . "
I actually do n't mind the look of Aqua but sometimes it gets in your face . "
Gutierrez said he knows of at least two other designers working on similar projects .
Gutierrez is the author of Winfix , a software patch released last year that removes the metallic " skin " from Apple 's Sherlock search engine and restores a more traditional look .
The Winfix patch has proven incredibly popular , Gutierrez said .
He estimated it has been downloaded between 60,000 and 70,000 times , and has been included on scores of shareware disks .
Gutierrez expects to finish his OS X project in a couple of weeks and plans to post it as a free download on his website .
" It 's incredibly tedious and boring , " he said . "
I 'm doing it pixel by pixel . "
However , because Apple has n't provided software tools to work with OS X 's interface , Gutierrez can only alter surface details like color and appearance , rather than deeper features like the placement of scroll bars or menus .
" Unlike previous Mac OSs , it 's a closed system , " he said .
Apple in the past has been very tolerant of interface tinkerers , but that seems to have changed with OS X.




China 's Telecom Catch-Up

HONG KONG -- Hong Kong 's chief executive officer had a number of reasons to praise his territory 's Internet savvy as he opened this week 's giant International Telecoms Union show in the former British colony .
Only Scandinavia has more cell phone users , nine out of 10 households have a broadband connection , every second family has a PC , and one out of three people uses the Net , Tung Chee Hwa said .
Tung told the audience that citizens have pride in Hong Kong 's 1997 return to Chinese rule , and that " one country , two systems " is no longer a political concept but an everyday reality in Hong Kong .
It was a positive statement , since it 's the Chinese government 's ambition to unite the former colony with the republic without infringing on the factors that made Hong Kong a financial success .
The former British colony is doing well when it comes to its telecom and information technology infrastructure , and mainland China , along with other countries in the region , appears to be catching up .
However , in many ways China and Hong Kong are less like " one country , two systems " and more like two nations operating on totally different platforms .
For instance , it 's so difficult to obtain a visa to Hong Kong that Chinese telecom executives make jokes about it .
They call it the " prisoner 's ticket , " because once it 's awarded and validated for 18 days , visa holders are not allowed to re-enter China during the period , even if the holder is only visiting a company or family member just one hour 's drive from Hong Kong .
Hong Kong housewives , on the other hand , can take the train to the Chinese city of Schen Zen , where groceries are cheaper , as often as they like .
The explanation is money , of course , since Hong Kong 's per capita household income is huge compared to China 's .
Figures from the 1998 United Nations ITU report put incomes at $ 24,612 compared to just $ 768 , respectively .




Turn On , Tune In , Drop Cash

Can n't wait to get to the store to purchase that song you just heard on the radio ?
No problem , if you 've got a cell phone .
Two emerging services -- Buzzhits and * CD -- allow users to immediately identify and purchase a song playing on the radio .
Both are confident they can succeed despite the failure of a similar company , Xenote iTag .
That service allowed users to bookmark music heard on certain radio stations with a keychain-sized clicker , which stored key data that could be retrieved by a computer .
" We power impulse response , " said George Wu , president of Buzzhits . "
Our technology platform allows businesses to capture consumers . "
Users call an 800 number when they hear a song on the radio , punch in the station ID , and receive a five-second sound clip and the option to purchase the CD .
They can also have information e-mailed to their accounts or posted on their personal websites , which can be accessed from any computer .
Wu hopes to play the major radio stations off one another -- corporations such as Clear Channel and Infinity Broadcasting -- to start a bidding war for the data he collects .
The winners , he said , could then use the aggregate data to try and draw listeners away from a competitor .
For example , if Buzzhits tracks a big spike from one station when a particular song comes on , they 'll relay that information to its partner station .
Then , using the aggregate e-mail database that the company has amassed , the partner could go out and do an interview or event with the artist or band and turn it into a direct marketing campaign .
" On the music product , the radio station gets a better understanding of their P1 -- their most avid listeners , " said Wu . "
They understand the value of capturing their listeners to market back to them .
But these stations do n't capture the listeners of other radio stations .
The service will work with any radio station , but we will n't work with every radio station to help them direct market . "
The business model relies heavily on radio station involvement , and Infinity Broadcasting 's Los Angeles station is n't so sure the new technology can help them .
The station has good relations with the traditional retail market , and would n't want to suddenly appear as a competitor , said Gene Sandbloom , KROQ 's assistant programming director .
More importantly , Sandbloom said his station was preparing to launch its own Web-based information gathering service .
" I think that it 's kind of a misnomer , that if someone browses a CD that they love it , " said Sandbloom . "
I browse websites constantly looking for information for our jocks .
That does n't mean I like the music . "




Big Brother Watches Your Weight

Is n't technology a wonder ?
Global Positioning System satellites were originally used by the U.S. military to keep track on troop movements .
Now , in Switzerland , they 're being used to find new ways for overweight people to burn off excess fat .
Research , conducted at University of Lausanne , uses GPS satellites to track the energy output and activity patterns of overweight men and women .
The thinking is that by tracking the patient 's position -- by measuring movements -- doctors and nutritionists will be able to determine the amount of energy expended .
" The GPS logger can measure the position , speed and displacement of the patient , " said Yves Schutz , professor of physiology and nutrition at Lausanne .
While it may seem obvious that overweight people would benefit from exercising , Schutz believes the devices will be able to show patients , in a very concrete way , how much more energy they could expend by choosing the stairway over the elevator .
" It is important to say to the patient , ' Be more active , ' and the patient may walk a little more , or not take the elevator , but he has no way of knowing how many calories he 's burned , " said Schutz . "
If you are able to record this data , you will be able to see if the duration of the exercise is beneficial -- you can calculate and tell the patient if his exercise was worthwhile . "
Schutz said this information can be very encouraging to the patient , a source of motivation to continue exercising .
The device , called a GPS logger , is about the size of a cell phone and can be clipped to the patient 's belt .
It comes with a small antenna that can be attached to a hat or the back of the patient 's jacket .
When the patient is wearing this equipment his every move can be tracked .
Unlike most applications of GPS technology -- which range from keeping tabs on armies to telling the auto club where you 're stranded -- Schutz insists that the physical location of the patient is of no interest here .
" We do n't care whether the patient is downtown , by a garage or in a restaurant , " Schutz said . "
We do not use the GPS logger to be intrusive , but just to track their energy output . "
What they do n't track , however , is trips to the neighborhood McDonald 's .
While Schutz 's research does include an evaluation of nutritional intake , the tracking devices are not used to keep tabs on the patients eating habits .
When the patient is inside a building or vehicle , the GPS signal is blocked .
This is where the accelerometer kicks in.
This device monitors the patient 's activities by using small , 1-centimeter sensors integrated into a belt .
The sensors record frontal acceleration , or forward movement , and vertical acceleration , such as jumping .
The patient 's every move can be recorded , whether he is walking on a flat surface , up a flight of stairs , cycling or jogging .
The combination of the two devices " allow us to measure physical activity both outside , in free living conditions , and inside at home and at work , " Schutz said .
The patient wears the devices from the time he gets out of bed to the time he gets back into it , he can discard it when he dons his pajamas . "
When static , the patient does not need to wear the device , " Schutz said .




Devising Invisible Ink

WASHINGTON -- An ambitious effort to protect online anonymity will kick off this weekend .
A working group of about a dozen technologists , called NymIP , is gathering before the Internet Engineering Task Force 's meeting to take the very first steps toward devising a standard that will foster untraceable communications and Web browsing for Internet users .
Currently , commercial products such as Anonymizer.com and Zero Knowledge 's Freedom client permit anonymous or pseudonymous Net-surfing .
The NymIP effort aims to create standard protocols that would be more widely adopted and not tied to one company 's product or service .
Zero Knowledge , a Montreal firm , began the project last month , but the working group is now headed by Harvard University 's Scott Bradner , an IETF veteran .
Quips Zero Knowledge engineer John Bashinski : " I 've been heard enough as it is , and am trying to moderate my natural big-mouthed tendencies and let others speak for a while . "
One probable topic of discussion : The tradeoffs between bandwidth and security .
Absolute security requires scads of cover traffic to mask the communications that a user wants to conceal , but it also eats up bandwidth .
" Scalability is n't too bad if you 're looking at scaling the number of users , " writes Bashinski in a post to the NymIP mailing list . "
Where scaling seems to bite you is with the size of the anonymity group , defined as the set of users that , given the information the recipient or an eavesdropper has , could have sent a given message .
In high-security systems , more or less those with meaningful resistance to traffic analysis , scaling in the anonymity group size seems to be superlinear , maybe even N^2 . "
Translation : That 's enough to clog a lot of T-3 lines .
The meeting is set for Sunday afternoon in advance of the IETF gathering in San Diego .

Cyber-sensibilities : Privacy advocates may get headlines , but it 's business lobbyists that congress critters listen to .
That means Internet users may not have to fret about a controversial " cybercrime " treaty after all : The U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Friday said it publicly opposed it .
" The United States must not agree to any treaty that fails to protect the rights of consumers and places unnecessary and costly burdens on e-Commerce companies , " said Rick Lane , the chamber 's director of e-commerce , in a statement . "
The treaty proposed by the Council of Europe goes too far and could undermine the incredible growth we have seen in electronic commerce . "
The chamber says it represents over 3 million businesses and organizations .
An official from the Council of Europe , which is drafting the treaty with the help of the Clinton administration , said this week that it would likely not include the privacy protections that civil libertarians had demanded .




Speed Is Key for Intel

Intel said on Monday it had built the smallest and fastest transistor , the key building block for microprocessors , allowing it to build speedier microprocessors for computers and other devices in the future .
The new transistor , which can finish 2 million calculations in the time it takes a speeding bullet to travel an inch , needs only low voltage to operate , Intel said .
Within five to 10 years , the transistor will allow Intel to build microprocessors that contain more than 400 million transistors , operate at speeds as fast as 10 gigahertz , and require less than one volt to operate , the company said .
In contrast , today 's Pentium 4 processor contains 42 million transistors and runs at 1.5 gigahertz .

IBM
The new technology , named CMOS 9S can be used to build chip circuits as small as 0.13 microns , or nearly 800 times thinner than a human hair .
The smaller circuitry and improved materials can pack more processing power on a single chip , helping electronic products from computers to cell phones support new , performance-hungry applications like speech recognition , fingerprint authentication and wireless video .

Newsmax Knows Its Audience

One imagines that when the presidential election finally ends , Florida will be littered from the Panhandle to the Keys with political signs .
If TV news is any indication , the Sunshine State will be buried to its knees in canned invectives like " Sore-Loserman " and " Katherine the Terrible . "
And among those will be another banner , which you might have found a bit cryptic if you saw it on TV : " Newsmax.com . "
Newsmax , a two-year-old right-leaning news site , has been well served by the election fight over Florida .
Perhaps as a result of having its banners flashed behind unsuspecting TV reporters , its popularity has skyrocketed during the last couple of months .
On a shoestring budget compared to other media sites , Newsmax has attracted a loyal audience of a few hundred thousand visitors a month , many of whom swear that it offers the only unbiased news available in the United States .
If its growth trends continue , Newsmax 's founder , Christopher Ruddy , says the site will one day become " the CNN of the Internet . "
That 's because , Ruddy said , Newsmax is reporting something that others in the media are skipping : the truth .
To be sure , the truth according to Newsmax is very different from the truth according to , say , The New York Times .
On a given day , Newsmax will feature headlines like " Gore 's Swan Song : Hail to the Cheat ! " and " Democrats Plot Against Bush . "
Much of the site is a Matt Drudge-inspired index of the Web 's other news sources , but unlike Drudge , Newsmax also features original content .
It has a stable of conservative columnists who report such delicacies as the latest goings-on in the independent counsel investigation of Bill Clinton , or how democratic judges in Florida are conspiring to give Gore the White House .
And it 's this kind of stuff , Ruddy says , that 's attracting people to Newsmax . "
There 's tremendous antipathy in the middle of the country , " he says . "
People feel that they 're being ignored by the traditional media .
So they come to our site for something different . "
When Ruddy talks about the " traditional media , " he 's alluding to the famous " liberal media bias " that the right has always pinned on mainstream news and TV media .
Whether or not that bias actually exists is n't really important , Ruddy thinks ; people believing it exists is what drives them to search for alternatives like Newsmax , he said .
In a sense , that 's why Ruddy started Newsmax -- he saw that there was a market of people who were sick of traditional media , and he saw the Internet as a great way to deliver to them something different .
After working as a reporter at the New York Post and the Pittsburgh Tribune-Review , Ruddy wrote The Strange Death of Vincent Foster : An Investigation , a book that questioned the apparent suicide death of the former White House counsel .
This put him into the camp of journalists like Michael Isikoff , who helped break the Monica Lewinsky-scandal story -- they were hated by the left , and idolized by the right .
According to some Newsmax readers , part of why they trust Newsmax is because of Ruddy 's previous reporting experience .
Robert Fanning , an avid reader from Montana , said that Newsmax " dares to dig to the other side .
They get to the bottom , and they refuse to believe the other side .
They have the gall and audacity to take on the system . "
Of course , depending on political persuasion , some might say that what Ruddy actually pursues at Newsmax is better termed " punditry " than " journalism " -- but most everyone would likely agree that it could also be termed , more simply , " business . "
In November , Newsmax turned profitable , Ruddy said .
Total investment in the company so far has been less than $ 10 million , which is substantially less than other news sites , many of which are still money-losers .
Solid traffic statistics for Newsmax are a bit hard to pin down .
According to the traffic-monitoring company Media Metrix , Newsmax does n't attract anywhere near the number of readers as sites like Salon and Slate : more than a million people visited each of those sites in October , Media Metrix reported , while Newsmax had about 300,000 readers .
But Ruddy rejected Media Metrix 's numbers , saying that ratings agencies are " notoriously off " for new sites .
He pointed to statistics from Doubleclick , the firm that runs ads for Newsmax , which showed that the site received more than one million unique visitors in November .




New Film ' Dungeons ' Drags On

Too many films based on a tale with origins far from Hollywood suffer from that irksome flaw of not being true to the original , leaving fans to gnash their teeth and moan like an orc with gastritis .
Not so Dungeons & Dragons , which is afflicted with the related but equally vexing ailment of hewing too closely to the awesomely popular role-playing game that gave it life .
To wit : The 100-minute flick from New Line Cinema is less a story of love and adventure than a convenient vehicle for some occasionally-phenomenal light shows in dungeons and hordes of swooping dragons flapping around the Empire of Izmer looking like nothing so much as oversized pterodactyls equipped with +5 fireballs and terribly bad attitudes .
But successful real-life D&D games require far more -- well-drawn heroes and convincing antagonists are not at all optional .
And in devising this wide screen adaptation that opened Friday , director-grand-poobah Courtney Solomon has failed repeated saving throws against the chaotic-evil forces of blandness and blah .
By itself , the story shows promise .
A vaguely medieval society is sharply divided between the Mages -- an elite and somewhat stuffy breed of magic users who skulk around their towering stone fortress -- and everyone else .
Izmer 's teen empress wants everyone to be " equal , " a vague but unobjectionable idea , while the evil Mage Profion has successfully convinced the legislature otherwise .
an unremarkable Thora Birch
Jeremy Irons
A power struggle that makes the Florida election look like an endearing display of bonhomie ensues , and the winner is the side that can find the fabled Rod of Savrille and thus command the mighty red dragons .
Enter two thieves , Ridley and Snails , who join a cute young female mage , a grumpy dwarf , and an aloof elf -- your classic D&D traveling companions -- to trounce the bad guy , help the good one , and perhaps encounter a love interest or two along the way .
Justin Whalin
Marlon Wayans
It 's a good start , but not much more .
The director , Solomon , can n't seem to decide whether to take the film seriously or allow it to spoof itself -- and neither can the actors .
The performance by Academy Award-winning Irons is remarkable only in how lackluster it is , and Wayans ' inner-city slang is as out of place as he would be in any believable Thieves ' Guild .
Note to Solomon : Thieves should be lithe and sneaky , not bumbling trolls .
At least -- spoiler alert -- this Jar Jar Binks stand-in is slaughtered halfway through the movie .




Maybe It < i>Is</i> Safe to Swim Again

SYDNEY , Australia -- Twenty-six years after filmmaker Steven Spielberg turned ocean swimming into a heart-pounding angst fest , it could soon become a lot safer to go in the water .
By carrying a unit emitting a field of electrical charges , surfers , swimmers and scuba divers may be able to disgust the taste buds of sharks , encouraging the finned carnivores to look elsewhere for food .
Given a spate of recent shark attacks in Australia , the technology could be a win all around .
Swimmers will feel better , sharks are less likely to mistake humans for more tasty seals or turtles , and fishermen may be less likely to string the creatures up on dockside piers .
The technology , called SharkPOD was originally invented in South Africa .
for Protective Oceanic Device
Current units , available since 1995 , are roughly the size of a football and weigh about 10 pounds .
They 're generally strapped on to a scuba tank .
But an Australian firm is racing to reduce the units to the size of two cigarette packs that could be wrapped around the waist for swimmers and snorkelers .
In September , the technology was demonstrated during the triathlon event of the Sydney Olympics , which featured a harbor swim by 50 competitors near the Sydney Opera House , just three miles from Sydney Harbor 's opening to the Tasman Sea .
To reassure everybody , divers carrying SharkPODs swam beneath the triathletes to ensure the Olympians finished in one piece .
They all did .
But then , heavy boat traffic in Sydney Harbor during the Games would by itself have been enough to chase off any but the most diehard fish -- sharks included .
Experts estimated the chance of competitors getting attacked by sharks during the event at roughly nil , said George Faulkner , technical operations manager for the Olympics triathlon event .
Even so , race organizers opted to use the technology anyway to help competitors focus on winning gold medals and huge sponsorships instead of sharks in the water .
Apparently , no one thought whether the lack of such a reassurance might have led to quicker swimming times --- and a more exciting race .
Those questions are academic now because no one got bitten .
But whether that was the SharkPODs ' work or not is anyone 's guess .




Net Monitoring Service Pays Users

Tracking how fast data really moves around the Net has been about as accurate as predicting the weather , so Distributed Science is asking you to help share the load .
Distributed Science , one of several companies looking to commercialize the once-voluntary distributed computing phenomenon , is teaming with Internet monitoring service Envive to get home PC users to make money by logging on .
Distributed computing uses the processing power of ordinary PCs to tackle difficult computational problems such as scanning radio waves from outer space or deciphering gene sequences .
Distributed Science got its start with Gamma Flux , a nonprofit research project , working on a project to determine the best means of storing nuclear waste .
Teaming with Envive marks its first for-profit job .
Envive 's monitoring services , called Prophecy and Sensory , monitor the performance of transactions with commerce sites and applications providers on the Internet .
The websites use the results to determine where customers might be getting poor performance , such as in a certain region or on a certain ISP , then tune content delivery or application for improvement .
However , this assessment previously only covered the connection from the provider to the " edge server , " which relays the content -- not " the last mile , " the connection to the end user .
Adding the Distributed Sciences client to Envive 's technology enables a complete measurement from host to user .
" want to get the end user , not the ISP , " said Armin Lenz , vice president of marketing for Distributed Science . "
E-commerce companies
They have to make sure that they are reachable , so they want to be able to trace where they are unreachable . "
The modified Distributed Science client , due out in the next week , will not only communicate from PCs to their servers , but also among other machines in a PC 's region .
Each area will have a preferred machine that handles responses to Envive performance checks .
When that machine goes offline , one of the other machines in the peer group takes over as the representative machine .
So if there are a dozen computers in a city , one will be the designated primary response computer -- and when it goes off , another takes over for it automatically .
This allows for twenty-four hour coverage , seven days a week , said Lenz .
The DS client runs in the background , and there should be no impact at all in performance on the system when the client is doing the performance measurements , he said .
" It 's really critical that know the real customer experience , " said Bill Leavy , vice president of marketing for Envive . "
the websites
If it 's not working well enough customers will look for alternative places to go . "
Envive customers , including Sony , Military.com , Wal-Mart and AutoWeb , can see traffic readings about their performance in different cities , states , regions and countries or network backbones .
They can also zoom in on problem regions for more details to attempt to diagnose problems .
With 146,000 volunteers worldwide running the DS client , Envive expects to be able to offer a much wider and more accurate means of covering the Internet .
" This offers more locations and a better quality of response than if we were to set up in a data center , " said Leavy . "
If we had to do this ourselves , there is no way we could do that in a timely manner .
It gives us deep coverage in any location . "
The Envive network will go live in January , with 75 cities in the initial test before scaling up nationally to a few hundred cities .
Distributed Sciences expects to land venture capital money some time in January and announce new commercial clients in the next six months , according to Lenz .




Do Pocket PCs Have Blue Teeth ?

The Consensus among the vendors that packed the San Jose Convention Center last week for the Bluetooth Developers Conference was that smart phones with Bluetooth-embedded chips would be the killer application for the wireless technology .
But amid the bigwig phone manufacturers Ericsson , Motorola and Nokia , were the Microsoft representatives and backers who believe that Pocket PCs , powered by the Windows CE operating system , will also play a significant role in the Bluetooth market .
ERICY
MOT
NOK
MSFT
But even if people wind up liking the Pocket PCs , is it realistic to believe that they will want to carry both Pocket PCs and Web-enabled phones ?
Let 's face it , cell phones rule .
Thanks to the huge and growing numbers of them in the world , they 're almost certainly going to be the killer application , said Socket Communications spokesman Gerald Houston .
But just because cell phones are all the rage , that does n't mean smart phones will make people ditch their Bluetooth-enabled Pocket PCs .
" Guys that buy Palm devices ... are not going to want to squish them into weird phones , " Houston said .
- shaped
Socket Communications , a California company that develops and sells connection products for Windows-based devices , displayed at its booth a " personal network card evaluation kit " that consists of two CompactFlash Type I forms , plug-in cards with embedded Bluetooth radios , baseband hardware and an antennae .
The kit also included two PC card adapters and Windows CE compatible software .
These devices , which would replace the cables of any Windows CE-powered device , give users wireless Internet access .
Socket also has a digital phone card , or low-power plug-in card , that allows Motorola 's StarTAC , Timeport , Talkabout and V phone series to connect to any Windows-based Pocket PC , handheld PC or notebook .
But are they going to want to carry two devices in their pocket ?
That 's the question that will be answered in the next couple of years as companies put out personal digital assistants , cell phone attachments and integrated smart phones .
PDAs

The project , which begins this month , will give users in a building located on 241 Peachtree Street wireless Internet and Intranet access on their laptops , personal digital assistants and mobile phones .
Strio will also manage the building 's technology that will run over a network provided by Bluetooth product developer Red-M .

USB
