Sun , Sand and Surfing the Net

SANTA BARBARA , California -- Looking over the pool area at the new $250-million Bacara resort , Shad Lofgreen sees not red-tile roofs , white stucco walls or luscious landscaping , but instead a kind of quietly purring high-tech machine .
The natural beauty of a white sand beach and the sweeping blue Pacific Ocean panorama are just a few steps away , but this place is all Star Trek underneath .
" You come here to get away , " says Lofgreen , Bacara 's full-time technology officer . "
But what if you get a call and you are on your third day of a seven-day spa package ?
Someone needs something right away .
How are you going to get it there ?
" We have designed our technology infrastructure to accommodate that .
And everything else you might want . "
Welcome to your vacation , new millennium style .
New resorts are wired to the hilt these days and older resorts undergoing renovations are all jumping on the bandwagon -- not only providing high-speed Internet access in the rooms , but using technology in other ways to increase the quality of service , entertainment and conferences .
Nowhere is this trend displayed better than at Bacara , which has been designed and marketed , in part , to attract both entertainment industry types from Los Angeles , which is about two hours south , and dot-com CEO types from Silicon Valley , about four hours north .
The thinking behind it is , essentially , if someone is wealthy enough to stay here , you better provide the kind of technological marvels to which he 's become accustomed .
This explains the presence of an $ 18,000 , 42-inch , Fujitsu flat plasma screen television in the Presidential Suite .
The suite also offers a built-in custom stereo system , marble floors and a panoramic ocean view .
All for just $ 5,000 a night .
Bacara also employs a full-time " technology concierge , " whose main responsibility is to help guests with any and all tech needs .
Most of the time , this involves helping them figure out their dial-up number or providing the right plug-in cord , which they may have forgotten in their haste to get out of their cubicle at work .
Bacara 's temporary tech concierge , Jude Augustine , said they will shy away from assisting guests with hardware issues , but everything else is fair game .
" So far we have been able to resolve every situation we 've faced , " he said .
The resort , which charges a rack rate of $ 450 minimum per night , is filled with technological wonders .
Each room was fitted with three phone lines .
Each room also has an atomic clock and a DVD player for guests to view movies checked out from the main desk .
At the pool area , each of the 26 private pool cabanas has a high-speed Internet jack .
Food and drink servers use wireless technology -- Mitsubishi XPN tablets -- which cut the waiting time by more than half .
Bacara has flat-screen monitors at the front desk .
It has tiny speakers hidden in the ballroom chandeliers .
And with ubiquitous wireless service throughout the resort , guests with wireless devices can keep in touch without plugging in.
About mid-way through their two-year construction process , Bacara hired Loftgreen .
It also enlisted RockIt Group , a Los Angeles " hospitality technology " firm , to help out .




This Just In : Lunch Lines Suck

While Tom Brokaw and Dan Rather banter about dimpled and pregnant chads , one ambitious group of eighth graders is busy webcasting the latest news for preteens -- on the Net .
Students at Aviara Oaks Middle School in Carlsbad , California , write , produce , and star in a news program on AOTV .
The 10-minute news show is broadcast on closed-circuit television and the Internet Monday mornings at 8:30 and 11:30 PST .
While it is not unusual for schools to produce their own television shows , Aviara Oaks is the only known middle school in the country to webcast a weekly program .
Eastview High School in Apple Valley , Minnesota , webcasts a weekly Internet news program as well .
While AOTV 's coverage may seem simply entertaining to some -- recent pieces have included stories on the school surf team and an investigative piece on long lunch lines , for example -- their technical skills and editing prowess are anything but sophomoric .
The class uses two Trinity systems , a so-called television studio in a box that allows students to make digital edits , switch cameras , create special effects and graphics , and build virtual sets .
One Trinity system cost $ 12,000 , which was paid for by the school district when the school was built almost three years ago .
Play Incorporated , the company that makes Trinity , was so impressed with the student-run show that they donated a second Trinity machine to the school .
The second machine , called Globecaster , encodes the data , enabling the program to be streamed on the Net .
Doug Green 's 120 broadcasting students also learn how to operate cameras , use the teleprompter , and generate , write , and produce original stories .
" It 's probably more sophisticated than most college TV stations , " said Green , who ran a local video production company before becoming a teacher in the 1990s .
" I think this is just fantastic , " said Philip Cruver , the president of Kidz Online , a nonprofit organization staffed by kids who teach other kids technology skills . "
It 's not that difficult but typically schools are technophobic with cutting-edge stuff like this . "
to use
" It can be really exciting and really nerve-wracking , too , " said Steven Wolfson , an eighth grader who aspires to be a sports broadcaster . "
You can n't go back and fix anything .
You have to be right on it . "




Travel E-Book Means Business

The new animated and free guidebook , The Magic Mountain , is both a multimedia e-book and travel agency .
It 's also an online experiment in convergence that advertisers and publishers will be watching .
As a 1,000-page e-book , The Magic Mountain offers photography , detailed text , 3-D resort-specific landscapes , illustrations , geometric maps of 16 key destinations , and a listing of 200 hotels and 1,000 Alpine establishments .
As partner to a travel agency , Magic Mountain company offers the reader the ability to click on any of those destinations or hotels and arrange a trip .
Magic Mountain gets a commission from all transactions .
Some may argue that this is not an e-book at all but a Web business .
Co-founder of Mountain , Christoph Hargreaves-Allen , disagrees .
" Make no mistake , The Magic Mountain is an e-book -- it 's content produced in digital format to be read on a computer or on special electronic reading devices , " Hargreaves-Allen said .
" It is essentially a guide to the best-of-the-best ski resorts in the Alps .
But there 's more to an e-book than this open definition .
The real issue lies not in what an e-book is , but how it differs from another book . "
Hargreaves-Allen said that while many see the e-book revolution as a new chance for authors , it 's also a new chance for books as objects .
" This is not just about getting published .
It 's about changing traditional media constructs , experimenting with form and content , developing new bundles of information , " he said .
The Magic Mountain , which bills itself as a media company , was founded in the UK in January 2000 .
It 's backed by a private group of investors including Roger Horchow , producer of hit musicals Crazy For You and Kiss Me Kate .
----
MP3-style cliff notes : From Paradise Lost to Pilgrim 's Progress , those thirsting to know it all without having to read a word of it have a new option .
Just listen to MP3 versions of the World 's 100 Greatest Books Audio Collection , which will be released later this month from the InteliQuest Media Corporation .
Previously , the 45-minute audio summaries of the great tomes of world civilization came on 100 CDs or 50 tapes and cost $ 350 .
But now the whole package will go for only $ 50 .
Discussed are the book 's themes , an analysis of the characters , a detailed recreation of the story with descriptive passages from the book , and a concise yet full discussion of the book 's relevance .
The concept behind InteliQuest comes from Steven A. DeVore , founder and former president of SyberVision Systems , and Bonneville International Corporation .
At one point he set a goal to read the great books collection he had purchased from Encyclopaedia Britannica .
But he could n't even get through the first book he cracked on Aristotle 's writings .
What would happen , he thought , if he was able to contract with experts on the great books and have them explain in detail what the books were about .
He could apply that information to a learning system that would not only enable people to understand the works , but remember what they learned .
From that insight , The World 's 100 Greatest Books Audiocassette Collection was born .
Do n't be surprised to see Frankenstein and Moby Dick creeping up the Napster charts .




Music Streams Get Interactive

There 's a new streaming music service in town and this time , it 's legal .
On Monday , Emusic.com signed the first licensing agreement for an interactive music service with the National Music Publishers Association .
EMUS
Emusic CEO Gene Hoffman said the streaming service will be integrated into the existing download service by mid-year 2001 .
In July , the company rolled out its subscription service , which offers consumers unlimited downloads for a monthly fee ranging from $ 9.99 to $ 19.99 .
But requiring users to download , manage and store their own music can be seen as a drawback .
" You could build this into a business , but I do n't think that people willing to pay $ 10 if this was just a streaming service , " Hoffman said .
would be
The streaming component , where users have the ability to determine how they want to listen to their music , will be added by the second quarter of next year , Hoffman said .
While other services also offer streaming , the flexible licensing agreement will allow Emusic to create a more user-friendly service .
" We have a new and additional right to do fully interactive streaming , so what users will have is the ability to listen to anything they see on the site in whatever order they choose , " Hoffman said .
High-profile companies like Farmclub.com and MP3.com rolled out streaming services for the public despite potential conflicts with copyright laws .
Emusic.com took the direct route and negotiated licensing agreements with publishers and musicians to insulate the company from lawsuits .
" The advantages of having negotiated good licenses , not having to work within the constraints of the DMCA compulsory , would let them develop interactive streaming services that are much more compelling than the run-of-the-mill webcaster can , " Forrester analyst Eric Scheirer wrote in an e-mail .
" Right now , I think Emusic offers the most compelling subscription , because it 's about new content .
As long as your music interests are in a content niche they cover well -- jazz , punk rock , classical . "
Other companies have n't fared so well in obtaining the licensing agreements .
The Universal Music Group , which owns Farmclub.com , was sued by the National Music Publishers ' Association on Dec. 8 for copyright infringement .
The Internet music label created the streaming subscription service without signing a licensing agreement with the publishers .
The suit asks for $ 150,000 in damages for each violation -- the same amount that Universal sued for in its case against MP3.com
In April , MP3.com was found guilty of copyright infringement in a federal court for the creation of its streaming locker service .
MPPP
The Universal Music Group refused to settle its case , and eventually secured at $ 53 million judgment .
Representatives from Farmclub.com declined to comment .




Ireland Links to Net 's Future

DUBLIN , Ireland -- Ireland , sometimes jokingly described as America 's 51st state , will gain the research equivalent of statehood .
It 's getting a direct link to , and membership in , the cutting edge Next Generation Internet and Internet 2 research networks in the United States .
The special initiative was announced by the Irish Taoiseach Bertie Ahern in a speech honoring President Clinton during his visit to Dublin Tuesday .
.
" Taoiseach " is Gaelic for Prime Minister
Ireland will link directly to these two state-of-the-art Internet research networks in the United States , using a segment of the fiber optic telecommunications network the Irish government acquired through an unusual partnership deal with telecommunications company Global Crossing .
Within the next 18 months , Irish universities and research institutions will be able to use the network to collaborate with the 170 institutions in the United States involved in NGI and I2 projects .
" Broadband links are set to increase over 20 times between Irish and U.S. research institutions , " said Ahern , during a speech at Dublin 's Guinness brewery . "
That will mean closer cooperation in Internet 2 and Next Generation initiatives between our higher institutes of learning . "
Ahern also said that the area surrounding the Guinness site -- once among the more rundown areas of Dublin 's inner city -- was to be transformed into a multimillion-dollar digital business district , in one of the largest city regeneration projects of the decade .
At the heart of the digital zone will be the Massachusetts Institute of Technology 's Media Lab Europe , launched last summer by MIT Media Lab and MLE director Nicholas Negroponte .
MLE is located in a former Guinness grain warehouse off a cobbled street in an area known as The Liberties , a neighborhood well known to 18th century Irish writer Jonathan Swift , who was the dean of nearby St Patrick 's Cathedral .
MLE and businesses in the digital district will link directly to the NGI and I2 networks .




3 Dfx Fall Good Voodoo for NVidia

Having gone from hero to zero in less than four years , 3 Dfx will join Diamond Multimedia and S3 in the graphics industry bone yard .
After failing to find enough financing to keep it afloat , the company that propelled the 3-D gaming revolution into the stratosphere in 1996 with its radical chipset and graphics library has gone bust .
3 Dfx 's core assets and technology were sold off to nVidia , one of its major rivals in the 3-D graphics market , for $ 70 million cash and one million nVidia shares .
NVidia also loaned 3 Dfx $ 15 million to keep it solvent , and the two companies have settled their patent-infringement lawsuits .
Both companies had filed suits against each other .
It 's an intellectual property bonanza for nVidia .
The company gains seven patents plus another 40 pending patents ; ends the litigation ; and picks up approximately 100 engineers from 3 Dfx .
" We all know how hard it is to hire people here in the Valley , " said Derek Perez , a spokesman for nVidia . "
Combining their people with our assets makes for a really good company . "
It also gives nVidia the Voodoo brand name , which is widely recognized in the market as a top brand name among video graphics products .
PC Data lists five Voodoo products in its top 10 best-selling graphics boards .
Picking up 3 Dfx also means nVidia can get into incremental markets that it has n't previously played in , such as TV video and set-top boxes , an area where 3 Dfx has experience and nVidia does not .
The deal came down very quickly , and nVidia has n't fully decided what to do with 3 Dfx 's inventory , which it got as part of the deal .
3 Dfx had a video board business after purchasing STB Systems in May of 1999 .
NVidia 's strategy is to make chips and sell them to board makers like Creative Labs , Hercules and ELSA Graphics .
More importantly , nVidia is Microsoft 's partner in developing a high-performance chipset for the upcoming X-Box console , a deal 3 Dfx came very close to securing .
NVidia did not buy the 3 Dfx board manufacturing business and has no plans to go into retail .
Instead , it wants its licensees to take advantage of Voodoo products exiting the market .
" I call it a vacuum effect in retail , " said Perez . "
With them being gone , people will want to buy something , so I think our current retail partners can make a big dent in the market . "
NVidia has the right to do what it wants with the Voodoo brand name , whether it sits on it , sells it , or lets its partners release boards with the Voodoo name but an nVidia chipset , " said Perez .




Greens Push GM Agreement

BRUSSELS , Belgium -- The European Parliament and Council of Ministers have agreed on revisions to the European Union law on deliberate release of genetically modified organisms into the environment after what have been described as heated conciliation talks .
GMOs
The deal comes over three years after proposals for the revision emerged from the European Commission .
Green Members of the European Parliament are claiming a significant victory , having won a new requirement for national authorities to publicize the locations not only of genetically modified crops planted for testing but also the locations of commercially grown crops .
MEPs
This was the key remaining point of friction after the bulk of disagreements were cleared up last month .
In an unusual twist , the final deal appears to have been driven by an alliance of Green politicians in both the Parliament and the Council .
Parliamentary Greens today specifically complimented Green French Environment Minister Dominique Voynet , who led the Council delegation to the talks .
Earlier on in the process , Green MEPs exchanged harsh words with the Parliament 's Socialist rapporteur on the directive .
Though governments have agreed to Parliament 's demand on public registers , the final text suggests that the Greens ' victory may be less than complete .
Member states will have to establish registers for both experimental and commercial releases of GMOs , but will have significant leeway to decide exactly how to make this information public .
Another key outcome of the conciliation talks is agreement on a new requirement for an already agreed ten year limit on GMO marketing approvals .
This will be applied also to further renewals .
Biotechnology interests had campaigned strongly against such an outcome .
For genetically modified crops and forestry reproductive material , the rule is to be slightly softened .
Ten-year approval periods will start when varieties of plant are placed on national seed catalogues rather than when genetically modified " events " are approved under the deliberate release directive .
The Parliament has also won a concession from European Union governments on establishing links between the directive and the United Nations Cartagena Protocol on Biosafety .
The Commission is to be invited to propose ways of implementing the protocol by July 2001 .
First passed in 1990 , the deliberate release law became the focus of intense political debate as public fears about genetically modified crops spread through Europe in the late 1990s .
European Union governments imposed a quasi-moratorium on new approvals of genetically modified organisms in the summer of 1999 , which remains in place , and the European Commission has been forced to make supplementary proposals for strengthened labeling and traceability of genetically modified products .
A resolution adopted by the European Federation of Green Parties at a November 26 meeting in Stockholm declares , " The Green Parties of Europe acknowledge there are scientifically justified concerns about the safety of all foods produced through recombinant DNA technologies and that these genetically modified foods pose unique hazards to the health of both the consumer and the environment . "
The Green parties listed these hazards as , " the potential for generating new toxins , carcinogens and allergens . "
Besides unique risks to humans , the Greens said , GM foods pose unique risks to the environment : creation of super weeds and super viruses , destruction of biodiversity and pollution of soil .
