Palm Building Handier Tool

SANTA CLARA -- Palm Computing unveiled its next generation of operating system that the company hopes will accelerate the transformation of Palm devices from simple organizers into a multi-purpose handheld computers .
Version 4.0 of the Palm OS , previewed on Tuesday morning at the PalmSource developers conference , adds support for removable storage devices , wireless telephony and data transfers , and support for the Bluetooth standard .
A beta copy of the new OS was made available to software developers at the conference .
No date was given as to when the new operating system would be released , although executives said most Palm-branded handhelds would be able to upgrade to the system thanks to their flash memory , an advantage over competitor Handspring 's Visors , which are not software upgradeable .
The new OS will be able to read common file formats used by storage devices such as memory cards and will be able to automatically load applications stored on them .
Version 4.0 will also communicate with cell phones and wireless modems , and includes wider support for different wireless networks as well as expanded Web clipping , Palm 's proprietary method of trimming down Web sites for viewing on a handheld device .
The software will be " almost " ready for Bluetooth , a short-range wireless communications technology , when it starts to appear next year , executives said .
To communicate with other Bluetooth devices , Palm handhelds will still need extra hardware and software .
" It will be ready when Bluetooth modules are ready to ship , " said Palm executive David Fedor .
It will not , however , be ready for the new ARM processor chips Palm said it will be migrating to .
Earlier this year , Palm said it will move from Motorola 's Dragonball chip to much faster chips from ARM , a UK-based chip design firm .
The new OS will feature a handful of interface enhancements , including 16-bit color and an Attention Manager that tells the user when a paged message or e-mail has come in that requires their attention .
the Palm OS is currently 8-bit
However , the new OS will not support bigger displays .
The changes reflect Palm 's intention to continue the transformation from a basic information manager to a general-purpose handheld computer .
Palm execs believe the biggest market for this kind of device is the corporate market , which means expanding the range of applications , security and reliability .




Scour : Going , Going , Gone

The assets of Scour Inc. , the bankrupt online search engine and file-sharing company , were auctioned off Tuesday in federal bankruptcy court .
CenterSpan Communications walked off with the prize on its winning bid of $ 9 million .
CenterSpan beat out rivals Liquid Audio and privately held Listen.com with their bid consisting of $ 5.5 million in cash and stock worth $ 3.5 million .
CSCC
LQID
Listen.com chose to offer no more than $ 8.5 million . "
More than any other company , Listen.com thoroughly researched the value of Scour 's assets , " CEO Rob Reid said in a statement . "
With this information , we knew exactly what Scour was worth to us .
We saw absolutely no benefit in spending more than this amount . "
Included among the assets won by CenterSpan was Scour 's valued file-sharing technology , which allows users to swap digital music and video files over a peer-to-peer network , sidestepping the need for a central server .
Scour , which had millions of loyal registered users , had struggled recently to secure additional rounds of financial backing .
Scour 's financial troubles began on July 20 , when the Recording Industry Association of America , the National Music Publishers Association and the Motion Picture Association of America filed copyright infringement suits against Scour .
These lawsuits , along with lawsuits against similar services Napster and MP3.com , scared off prospective investors and set off a chain of events that led to the eventual closing of Scour 's file-exchange service .
In order to fight the lawsuits , Scour was forced to devote a large portion of its financing to legal battles .
This , in turn , diverted money away from developing new licensing agreements and investing in new technologies .
In early September , facing mounting legal expenses , Scour was forced to lay off 52 of its 70 employees after failing to obtain a new round of financing .
In November , Scour shut down its file-exchange service in order to hasten the decision in the pending lawsuit and the sale of its remaining assets .
CenterSpan will now be able to take advantage of Scour 's technology .
However , it will also be faced with the challenge of using this technology in a manner that avoids the legal challenges that haunted Scour .




Celera Maps Out Alternate Route

Celera Genomics is shaking the halls of academic science once again .
Celera researchers say they will publish the human genome map in Science magazine under a special arrangement that would allow the company to monitor access to its database of gene information by hosting it on the company website .
The agreement is unusual because gene researchers in the past have typically submitted their data to GenBank , a free , government-funded database .
Some scientists are worried that a precedent could be set that would limit scientific progress .
" Someone is supposed to be able to reproduce your experiment , that 's part of the scientific process , " said John McPherson , co-director of the Genome Sequencing Center at Washington University in St. Louis , Missouri . "
People take it and expand upon it and this is what drives science .
This is a departure from that . "
Company officials say they 're simply protecting their multibillion-dollar investment in the research .
" If there is anything unprecedented it is the amount of info that we are making available to the world researchers , " said Heather Kowalski , a spokeswoman for Celera . "
We believe this fits into our business plan because folks will see the quality of the data and get a taste for the tools that are available and want to subscribe . "
But critics say that 's not OK .
They understand that the company wants to protect its investment and intellectual property , but if they do n't want to share all their data , they shouldnt publish any of it .
" If there are huge restrictions , the publication becomes an infomercial , " said McPherson . "
Like AOL sticks a CD-ROM in your mailbox but you can n't really use it unless you sign up -- do they just want to hook people in and then sell the database ? "
Academic researchers will have open access to the database according to the agreement , but researchers from for-profit companies will be required to sign a technology transfer agreement saying they will n't commercialize their results or redistribute the sequence .
Otherwise , they must pay a subscriber fee , which can be more than a million dollars a year , or license the technology .
In June , rival teams from Celera and the Human Genome Project surprised the scientific community by ending an ongoing race to finish the maps , and announcing together that they each had completed a " working draft . "




The Other Dots Are Still Prized

When Network Solutions announced it was accepting requests for the new dot-info and dot-biz top-level domains last week , its site was deluged with visitors .
There was so much interest , a representative said , that some people were shut out .
Consequently , customers were sent an e-mail asking them to try again if they 'd encountered problems .
The overwhelming interest in these new top-level domain names was particularly surprising because Network Solutions was n't even offering people the chance to actually purchase a dot-biz or dot-info domain .
That can n't happen until the Commerce Department green-lights the new TLDs .
The company was merely allowing consumers to " request " a domain , so that when it became available , they 'd be notified .
But despite the meager offer , domain-name gurus flocked to the site -- an indication that , notwithstanding the Internet industry downturn , domain names are still a hot item and grabbing a good one is still seen as one of the best ways to start an Internet business .
The story of the dot-tv domain name -- the former country code of the Pacific Island nation of Tuvalu , which is now being marketed as an alternative to dot-com -- lends credence to this theory .
In October , dot-tv announced that 100,000 people had registered dot-tv addresses .
The company called this a record , saying it had taken dot-com six years to get 100,000 domains , and it only took dot-tv six months .
Of course , that dot-com figure is pretty misleading .
When dot-com was unveiled in the early 1990s , there were far fewer people using the Web , let alone snapping up domain names .
And by comparison , in the same period that dot-tv registered 100,000 names , dot-com registrations numbered in the millions , according to Network Solutions and other domain registries -- so it does n't look like dot-tv is hurting dot-com .
Still , dot-tv 's 100,000 registrations in six months are n't chump change .
Other " repurposed " country codes , like dot-am and dot-fm , have n't yet reached the 100,000 mark , though they 've been around for two years or more .
Moreover , there are indications that dot-tv 's advertising campaign -- which , weirdly , is presently only on the radio -- is causing registrations to accelerate .
Rob Kostich , dot-tv 's senior vice president of marketing , said that since October , the company has been able to sign up roughly another 100,000 users , " and we have a plan that calls for such consistent growth , " he said .
But if dot-tv 's registrations are doing well , what does that say about dot-tv 's customers -- are they being well served by their funky new addresses ?
More specifically , do Web users want to go to dot-tv sites ?




Palm Inventor : Yes It Can

Fact or Fiction ? : Sony showed some incredible video of prototype handhelds it is working on , but if or when we 'll ever see the real things is uncertain .
Keiji Kimura , president of Sony 's Personal Information Technology Network division , showed a picture of a digital still camera based on the company 's MemoryStick technology .
The camera was tiny , about the size of a stick of gum and not much thicker , with a lens at one end and an LCD screen on the back .
Kimura also showed a memory stick cell phone that recently went on sale in Japan .
The phone can download and store music over a cell phone network , but thanks to a protection scheme , can n't copy or redistribute tracks .
Kimura also showed a promotional video featuring a color handheld computer that used the memory stick slot as an expansion port for a range of add-on devices , including a GPS unit , a video camera and a module that identified the user from their fingerprint .
Perhaps the most striking thing about the handheld was the user interface , which clearly was n't the Palm OS .
Instead , users navigated the device via large , glowing touch-screen buttons and virtual dials .
" You definitely will be able to see them soon , " Kimura said .
Size matters : Jet-setting journalist Ben Hammersley , a technology reporter with the venerable Times of London , said he has almost completely dispensed with his laptop in favor of a Handspring Visor and a foldout keyboard .
" I leave the UK every three weeks and a laptop is a pain in the arse because it 's so big , " Hammersley said . "
Even the charger is bigger than a Palm . "
Hammersley has used his Visor , which has a slot for a 56K modem , to file stories from destinations as far flung as Morocco , Thailand and Burma .
He had to smuggle the setup into Burma for an interview with activist and Nobel Peace Prizewinner Aung San Suu Kyi .
" It 's illegal to be a journalist in Burma , " Hammersley explained . "
If you 're caught carrying a laptop through customs they deport you or imprison you .
But it 's quite easy to smuggle a Palm through in the pockets of your cargo trousers . "
Hammersley said his colleagues are so impressed with his lightweight setup , the Times -- a conservative organ that frowns on fads -- is talking about similarly equipping all its journalists .
" Compare a $ 300 Palm to a $ 3,000 laptop , " Hammersley said . "
Not only is it lighter , it 's much easier and less expensive to replace a lost Palm or a keyboard . "
But the miniature setup has its downside .
" It 's impossible to get any work done for the first five minutes because someone always says , ' What 's that ?
' "
President who ? : Typical of nerds , there was little talk at PalmSource of the incredible twists and turns in the presidential election , but the engrossing Palm-vs.-Pocket PC debate rages on .
Michael Mace , Palm 's chief competitive officer , said Microsoft has been aggressively feeding Palm-vs.-Pocket-PC stories to the press in an effort to position the company as the leading challenger , when in fact , they are n't .
The strategy is to make Microsoft look like Palm 's major competitor , instead of Symbian and Research in Motion , which runs the Blackberry pager .
" They are trying to make themselves number two when they are number three and fading , " Mace said .




Palm Inventor : Yes It Can

SANTA CLARA -- Jeff Hawkins , the father of handheld computing , used his characteristic tongue-in-cheek humor to respond to problems that Palm 's competitors say could cripple the platform .
In a lighthearted talk at the PalmSource developers conference , Hawkins , who co-invented the Palm and now heads Handspring , took on some of the " myths " spread by Palm 's competitors that portray the Palm operating system as doomed by insoluble problems .
Palm is the most popular handheld computing platform .
With more than 10 million devices sold to date , it commands three quarters of the worldwide market for handheld computers .
But Palm faces stiff competition from Microsoft 's Pocket PC , which commands about a quarter of the market , and wireless devices running Symbian 's Epoch software .
According to Hawkins , Palm 's competitors are using a fear , uncertainty and doubt campaign to malign the Palm OS 's ability to support the rapid evolution of handheld devices .
Palm 's competitors say the operating system can n't handle multimedia and it will n't perform more than one task at a time , Hawkins said .
Palm devices also have limited processing power and memory , and are no good for wireless communications .
Hawkins took each myth in turn .
To demonstrate that the Palm can handle multimedia , he used a Handspring Prism handheld to play a snowboarding video and play a pop song .
To show it could handle wireless communications , he plugged a cell phone module into the Prism 's expansion slot and tried to phone Colly Myers , Symbian 's CEO , in London .
Getting only voicemail , Hawkins started a three-way conference call and then sent a Short Messaging Service message .
Hawkins admitted the Palm OS suffered from some problems with multitasking , and limited memory and processor speed .
the ability to do more than one thing at a time
But he said they were irritations , not crippling limitations .
" All these things you can work around , " he said . "
The bottom line is none of this gets in our way of building user-friendly products .
They are annoyances at best . "
" We do n't see any products on the horizon that we can n't build using the Palm OS , " he added .
Tackling " further tales from the dark side , " Hawkins turned to a Magic Eight Ball application running on the Handspring Prism for answers .
He asked whether most Palm applications were trivial shareware , as competitors have alleged .
The Magic Eight Ball program replied with a " nag screen " announcing it was unregistered shareware , and that Hawkins should send in his shareware fee .
Hawkins then asked whether Handspring had hired away all the best talent from Palm .
The Eight Ball said no -- in fact he had hired all of their best talent and even more .




Video Games in the Crosshairs

WASHINGTON -- Computer games endorsed by gunmakers are " marketing tools to attract new customers for the gun industry , " a gun control group contended Thursday .
A study prepared by the Violence Policy Center , a Washington-based gun control group , examined several computer games endorsed by the Remington Arms Company and Colt Manufacturing Company , as well as Guns & Ammo magazine .
Several games , which feature the guns sold by the manufacturers , also contained digital and print gun catalogs .
They also had no age rating designed like television and movie ratings to warn parents about objectionable content , the study said .
The study 's authors also objected to the games ' content .
One game , Remington Top Shot , features human targets for the player to shoot at .
The game calls them " interactive targets . "
Colt 's Wild West Shootout instructs the player that " you 're the law and you carry the firepower to back it up . "
It includes a shootout in a church .
" These games , marketed as children 's toys and sold through channels such as eToys.com are , in fact , marketing tools to attract new customers for the gun industry , " said Marty Langley , the study 's author and an analyst at the Violence Policy Center .
Representatives from Remington and Colt did not immediately return telephone calls Thursday .
" You 're looking at just another half-baked report from people who will n't stop until all firearms are illegal , " National Rifle Association spokesman Bill Powers said .
Congress and federal regulators in September threatened that if entertainment companies failed to police themselves and stop advertising violent content to children , the government would step in.
Rep. Ed Markey said Thursday the games could contribute to more gun violence by youngsters .
D-Massachusetts
" When violent video games are used as the vehicle for making the sales pitch , you have ... a combination designed to train the child to accept handgun use as a reasonable way to settle a score and to educate the child about the virtues of a particular brand that he might want to use to do the deed and where to find it , " he said .
The computer game industry has exploded in recent years and is expected to soon outpace the motion picture industry in total revenue .
Retail sales of computer and video games reached $ 6.1 billion in 1999 , and 60 percent of all Americans over the age of five play the games , according to a survey by Hart Research Associates .
Gun control advocates say they are especially incensed because the games appeal to a younger and broader audience .
About 40 percent of video game players are under 18 , younger than the minimum age required to purchase a firearm .




Safer Calls , or Selling Fear ?

To the dismay of the cellular phone industry , a company recently introduced a device that it says would shield the human body from the " biological effects " from cell phones .
EMX Corporation , a developer of technology that mitigates the effects of exposure to electromagnetic fields , unveiled this week a microchip that -- inserted in a cell phone 's battery -- protects the caller 's body cells from the electromagnetic fields emitted by the cell phone .
The introduction of this new product underscores the ongoing question as to whether radiation emitted from cell phones is a health hazard .
The cellular phone industry -- backed by the opinions of researchers who do n't believe it 's so -- maintains that no evidence has been provided to conclude that cell phone use has deleterious effects .
Similar to the " scrambling of a television signal , " the EMF BioChip emits a random electrical impulse or " noise " to overpower the electromagnetic signal emitted by the cell phone and reduce the effect on the caller 's body .
EMX Corporation will n't go so far as to say unequivocally that signals emitted by cell phones could harm the body , but it touts research from European and North American universities backing its technology .
Researchers from Catholic University of America , University of Western Ontario , Columbia University , Aalborg University in Denmark and the University of Washington in Seattle found that cell phone EMF signals " bring the cells of the brain or other parts of the body ... into a state of stress or shock , " according to EMX Corporation founder and CEO Dr. Thomas Magnussen .
" You could see cells changing its metabolism and release stress proteins , which is a protective mechanism , " Dr. Magnussen said . "
sic
So the cells are truly bothered by this electromagnetic radiation from cell phones . "
However , members of the cellular phone industry and other scientists are incredulous , saying the amount of radioactive frequency signals emitted by cell phones is too weak to have any effect on the body .
" No reputable physician -- with nothing to gain one way or another and if they do n't own stock in the company -- will tell you radiation at those wavelengths can cause a biological response at all , " said Dr. Richard Freeman , chairman of the applied sciences department at the University of California at Davis . "
Any of these studies that get reported , I would be willing without knowing about the study , to say it 's just fog . "




Hotmail : You Get What You Pay For

If you 're a Hotmail user experiencing the free service 's latest shortcomings , you 're just going to have to tough it out .
That 's pretty much Microsoft 's advice to the 68 million folks using its free Hotmail e-mail service .
The software behemoth says there 's no customer support phone line because of " security reasons " and users that e-mail for help receive a generic message asking them to log on later .
There have been a number of problems , from not being able to get onto the Hotmail homepage to not being able to log in once you 're there .
And if you are lucky enough to get into your account , it 's taken some customers up to a minute to perform even the simplest task .
" I tried e-mailing them , and they sent back an auto response , with a list of e-mail addresses that I should contact , " said Geoff Haisty , a frustrated Hotmail user from Chapel Hill , North Carolina .
From there , it only became more frustrating .
" I e-mailed two of those , which also sent back auto responses , " said Haisty , a special projects team leader for GoTo.com . "
They both contained a URL to a support form that supposedly submits to a live human .
I tried the URL , but the first time I submitted , the request returned an error , so I had to try again .
The second time it got through , but I have no response yet . "
Haisty is part of a cluster of users plagued with Hotmail 's latest headaches .
Since Sunday , an undisclosed number of users have not been able to get to their Hotmail home pages or log onto their accounts .
Users who successfully log in must wait 30 seconds to a minute for any task to be completed .
Hotmail representatives did n't have a novel reason for the email meltdown .
Once again , the servers hosting the e-mail accounts are being repaired .




Solving China 's Dot-Com Puzzle

HONG KONG -- Entrepreneurs who thought creating a dot-com in the United States was a risky proposition are cautiously viewing China 's labyrinth of business rules , cultural subtleties and government censorship .
A new book hopes to give foreign companies a fighting chance of surviving in the largest potential market of Internet users .
Graham Earnshaw , born in England and a former Beijing journalist-turned-Internet entrepreneur , penned The Life and Death of A Dot-com in China to give advice and spread his optimism about the region 's potential .
Earnshaw 's 330-page book pulls together practical information from professionals that includes chapters on foreign investment in ISPs , real estate issues , licensing agreements and intellectual property .
since software and content piracy is a well-documented problem
Earnshaw 's book , published by Hong Kong publisher Asia Law & Practice , aspires to be a survival kit for businesses , investors , venture capitalists and dot-com wannabes looking to do business in China .
Earnshaw worked with more than 25 lawyers , accountants , consultants and business people .
" I am full of confidence in the future of the Internet in China , it 's messy and frustrating , but it 's faster than any other place on the planet , " said Earnshaw , who is also a director of the Shanghai lifestyle content site Chinanow.com . "
China is a very volatile , but highly entrepreneurial place , and the Internet will be at least as important to China as it is in the U.S. "
Recent Internet censorship regulations that the government passed have perplexed investors and industry players wanting to build markets there .
Under the code , any online content that violates the state or is anti-government is subject to heavy fines and even imprisonment .
Consequently , ISPs and content players have been put under immense pressure to curtail their content .
However , this has n't stopped investors from looking into China since it is expected to be a business hotbed once the country enters the World Trade Organization .
China 's attempt at entry into the WTO , which has been languishing for more than 14 years , is currently stalled over a wealth of concerns about the details of its entry requirements .
As a whole , China has agreed to open most sectors to more foreign investors and businesses .
For example , Wu Jichuan , the minister of Industry Information , told an audience at the ITU Telecom Asia 2000 conference in Hong Kong this week that China is committed to opening up its telecom industry and allowing more foreign investment and ownership in local companies .
However , certain groups such as the European Union are looking for further clarification on China 's commitments to opening up its insurance and distribution sectors , and Washington politicians are voicing concern over China 's human rights record as well .
Earnshaw said businesses in China must interpret statements from government officials that are often hard to define .
Foreigners who have turned away from investing in the Internet in the PRC because they have been frightened off by the rules do n't really understand the environment , Earnshaw said .
People 's Republic of China
" It 's not a crackdown , it 's a lot of regulations .
The government understands that information on the Internet is not controllable , but they 're trying to change the pace of change , " he said . "
The basic principle in China is you can say it , it 's just how you say it -- it 's a Confucian situation . "
where people agree to comply while finding workarounds
Earnshaw said he is worried about the regulations on an Internet community that is in many ways just beginning .
The Internet has had a much greater impact on establishing communications between ordinary people and businesses in China than it has in the West where free speech has been permitted .
E-mail , chat rooms and bulletin boards have given the society an important outlet to express ideas and information , since traditionally the government has kept a tight rein on the media .




MIT Entrants Go to Head of Class

Nobody 's getting rich on the money won in the MIT Entrepreneurial Competition .
The $ 30,000 first prize barely covers the cost of tuition at the university , let alone providing enough seed money to launch a successful business .
But a decade after MIT began bestowing honors for startups with smart business plans , it 's clear that winning , or even just entering , the competition , offers a leg up in the tech business world .
Let 's face it , people -- and more importantly , venture capitalists and media giants -- come calling when they hear you 've just been named best and brightest by the prestigious Massachusetts Institute of Technology .
" The competition gives you exposure .
The finals were on Wednesday , and by Thursday we were already on CNN , " said Zoran Zdraveski , one of the founders of Genigma -- the company , then known as Eyegen , which won the most recent award .
Genigma produces EyeGenRed , a dye that makes DNA visible to the naked eye .
" After the competition we were approached by every large in our area , " said Zdraveski .
venture capital firm
" We would not have been so successful &#91;if we had n't entered&#93 ; .
...
We were approached by people who wanted to be a part of our team because we won .
This would have been harder to attract with no track record -- this applies to the investors as well , " said Zdraveski .
Historically , even the losers have done well .
Just entering the competition helps tech companies get their business plans into action .
Lexicus Longhand , a 1991 entrant , is a good example .
" Losers actually do quite well .
Going through the process of the competition is the important thing , " said Ronjon Nag , founder of Lexicus -- which originally produced handwriting-recognition technology for bank checks , then evolved to do the same for PDAs .
" I tell other entrants that it 's the entering that matters -- the experience it affords you , " Nag said . "
The competition helped us sort out what ideas would work and what would n't , so that when we got the company going proper we did so on a much better footing . "
Once the company was up and running the press came running , too . "
We got a lot of coverage -- I was on the cover of Fortune magazine , " said Nag .
The company did so well that Motorola snapped it up in November of 1993 .
Lexicus still exists as a division of Motorola .
MOT
Lexicus Longhand 's story was representative of many contacted for this story .
Here 's the skinny on some of the other entrants .
A finalist in the 1994 competition was Banta Integrated Media .
They entered the competition as New Frontiers Information Corp.
The company was acquired by Banta Corporation at the end of 1995 .
BN
Banta Integrated Media currently provides software and e-business solutions for digital content management , e-commerce , and Internet-based cross-media publishing .
Its parent , Banta Corporation , had a net income , in 1999 , of $ 16 million , showing a one-year net income growth of 69.8 percent .




Mega-Corps Fawn Over Linux

A few years ago , a job at a giant computing company such as Hewlett Packard would have been a practically unthinkable career move for a die-hard Linux supporter like Bruce Perens .
Likewise , HP would n't have had many help-wanted ads for experts in the open-source movement .
" There was no business connection whatsoever , and frankly no one wanted to hear about it , " said Perens , a founder of the now-defunct incubator Linux Capital Group , who dates his involvement in the open-source platform back to 1994 .
Times change .
Last month , Perens scaled back his role as a startup entrepreneur -- dropping all but one company , open-source developer Progeny Linux , from his short-lived incubator business . "
It was an incubator that mostly used other peoples ' money , and we were n't getting it , " he explained .
So Perens opted for a day job , and agreed to become the Linux evangelist at Palo Alto , California-based Hewlett Packard .
HP
There , his job is to school HP 's 80,000-plus employees in the virtues of Linux , and , at the same time , to help pump up the company 's image as a supporter of all things open-source .
It 's a job description that Perens shares with open-source supporters at several large U.S. technology firms , including , on the opposite coast , IBM .
IBM
Big Blue 's unofficial evangelist is Linux guru Irving Wladawsky-Berger , who goes by the official title of vice president of technology and strategy .
Similar , though smaller , efforts are underway in Texas , as Compaq and Dell move to up their profile in the Linux community .
CPQ
DELL
Witness Compaq 's dedicated Linux website , which comes complete with a color photo of penguins frolicking on a distant beach .
Dell 's efforts include a partnership with Eazel , a Silicon Valley Linux startup , to develop desktop systems powered by the open-source platform .
Increasingly , open-source evangelism efforts are becoming backed up with cash .
A case in point this week was IBM .
Chairman Lou Gerstner announced , at a New York investment conference , that the company will invest $ 1 billion in its worldwide Linux operations in 2001 .
But the effect of Gerstner 's big investment plans on the scores of smaller Linux firms was unclear .
IBM 's announcement initially helped push up share prices for Linux competitors such as Red Hat and VA Linux .
But after two days , the rally proved short-lived .
The stocks dropped on Thursday , despite an earnings report from Red Hat that exceeded Wall Street expectations , and their prices were mixed on Friday .
Currently , the few Linux companies that launched stock offerings in the glitzy IPO market of 1999 and early 2000 are trading close to their all-time lows .
VA Linux , which set a new record for first-day gains in its debut last year , is currently selling for $ 12 a share , less than one-twentieth of its former high .
LNUX
Red Hat , at under $ 9 , is way off from its $ 148 high .
RHAT
Software developer Caldera , at $ 3 , is down from a 52-week high of $ 33 .
CALD
Regaining their stature as Wall Street darlings will be a difficult task .




Long Live the Fruit Fly

WASHINGTON -- Mutation of a gene whimsically named " I 'm not dead yet " can double the life span of fruit flies , a laboratory discovery that researchers said may lead to drugs to help people live longer and , perhaps , even lose weight .
Researchers at the University of Connecticut Health Center have found that the life span of fruit flies was extended from an average of 37 days to 70 days when a gene was modified on a single chromosome .
Some flies in the study lived 110 days .
The same long-life gene exists in humans , said Dr. Stephen L. Helfand , senior author of the study , and " offers a target for future drug therapies aimed at extending life . "
In human terms , a doubled life span would be about 150 years .
Helfand said the gene mutation appears to work by restricting calorie absorption on a cellular level -- in effect , putting the cells on a diet .
This raises the possibility , he said , of one day developing a pill that would both extend life and control weight .
" From what we know about this gene , that makes perfect sense , " he said .
Helfand said a key finding of the study , which was appearing Friday in the journal Science , is that not only did the fruit flies live longer , but they also seemed to maintain a high quality of life .
" It is not an empty or hollow increase in life span .
It prolongs active adult life , and I think , delays the onset of aging , " he said .
Some life-extension studies showed that animals tended to trade vigor and energy for a longer life , he said .
But the mutant flies " do well throughout their longer life , " Helfand said . "
By the time that 80 to 90 percent of normal flies are dead , these mutants are still doing just fine . "
Blanka Rogina , a co-author of the study , said female flies with the mutated genes were able to reproduce throughout life .
They had the energy for the fruit flies complex courtship ritual and could lay up to 2,000 eggs in their lifetime , compared with about 1,300 eggs normally , she said .
The long-life gene was named for a comical line -- " I 'm not dead yet " -- from a Monty Python movie , Helfand said .
The gene 's name was suggested by co-author Robert A. Reenan and has been shortened to " Indy . "
" In academic circles , " explained Helfand , " sophomoric humor , such as in Monty Python , is very common . "
There have been other studies that found long-life genes in fruit flies and nematodes .
There also have been experiments in mice that show calorie restriction -- a severe diet -- can extend life by up to 50 percent .
But Huber Warner , associate director for research into the biology of aging at the National Institute of Aging , said the Indy gene discovery is more significant because " it may be a different way to get the same effect that caloric restriction achieved in mice and other organisms . "
He said it may be possible to develop a drug that inhibits metabolism in the same way as the mutated Indy gene .
Such a drug would have to be tested extensively in animals to assure that it is safe , Warner said .
" If you wanted to slow metabolism in people , this research suggests that this could be a way to do it , " he said . "
It is strictly theoretical right now , but it is a possibility . "
Helfand and his colleagues discovered the livelong gene by chance .
He said they were screening a strain of fruit flies in another study and found that flies were living much longer than normal .
They isolated the Indy gene and then tested it in a number of different laboratory fruit fly strains .
In all cases , it extended life .
But Helfand said the researchers discovered that if the gene is mutated too much , it actually shortens life .
The normal gene is on two chromosomes of the fruit fly .
If one of these genes is altered , thus reducing the strength of the gene , then the flies enjoyed a long life .
If both genes were knocked out altogether , said Helfand , the flies actually died sooner , perhaps starving to death .
" If we restrict a little bit there is a big advantage , " said Helfand . "
the gene
But if we make an animal that has only the mutated gene , we find that the animal lives a shorter than normal . "




The Casino in the Sky

TOULOUSE , France -- Airbus gave final approval Tuesday to a plan to build the world 's largest passenger plane , a superjumbo jet that will hold 555 passengers and can come with bars and casinos .
Airbus hopes the new double-decker A380 will give it a competitive edge over its rival , Seattle-based Boeing Co.
" This decision heralds a new era in the history of flight , with the introduction into service of the world 's 21st century jetliner in early 2006 , " the company said in a statement , announcing that its supervisory board approved the plans Tuesday .
So far , Airbus has received 50 firm orders and 42 options for the superjumbo , which will have larger cabins , more floor space and staircases , and can be equipped with bars , casinos and lounges .
" We can not be more proud of the product we developed , " Manfred Bischoff , chairman of the Airbus supervisory board , said . "
We intend to once more set a standard for quality and efficiency . "
The board gave the green light for the $ 12 billion project at its headquarters in Toulouse in south-central France .
The board is made up of top executives from the two companies that are the sole shareholders in the consortium European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company , with an 80 percent holding , and Britain 's BAE Systems , with 20 percent .
The superjumbo will be a direct challenge to Boeing 's dominance of the long-haul , high-capacity market with its fleet of 747s , and it intensifies the rivalry between the two manufacturers , who are banking on conflicting forecasts for air travel in the 21st century .
Airbus says the demand for larger planes is set to grow .
It forecasts that the number of airliners in service with 400 seats or more will rise to 1,235 over the 20 years .
Boeing argues that airlines are more interested in smaller planes with the range to bypass major hubs on nonstop flights to mid-sized and smaller cities .
Boeing 's biggest jet at the moment is the 747-400 , which can carry 416 passengers .
" The announcement today is just another indication of how dynamic the commercial jet transport market is right now , " said John Dern , a Boeing Commercial Airplane Group spokesman in Seattle .
" Airbus is taking one strategic approach and Boeing is taking another , and time will tell , " he said . "
All we can do is what we hear the airlines are telling us and what the data is telling us about how new routes are developing .
Passenger preference is for direct nonstop service . "
In 2000 , Boeing committed to produce longer-range versions of its 767 and 777 jets , designed to make non-stop flights to smaller cities .
This year it received 117 orders for the 777 .
Boeing also has plans for a stretch version of its 747 jet to seat some 520 people .
It has not yet received any orders for the new jet , which it estimates will cost between $ 4 billion and $ 6 billion to develop .
Airbus officials had said they needed around 50 firm orders to make the A380 project economically viable , a target it met Friday when Virgin Atlantic Airways announced an order for six jets and options on six others in a deal worth more than $ 3.8 billion .
The biggest A380 order -- 12 planes -- came from Australia 's Qantas Airlines Ltd. , a Boeing client for more than 40 years .
Other firm orders have come from Singapore Airlines , Air France , Emirates Airlines , and the International Lease Finance Corp.
Germany 's Lufthansa AG and British Airways are in talks about buying the plane .
Airbus has been gradually closing the gap on Boeing since its creation in 1972 , and last year reported significantly more aircraft orders .




Gifts Online : Where to Find ' Em

Holiday gift guides are fine and dandy but most are fairly predictable .
Especially technology ones .
How many gift guides have you seen recommending a Handspring Visor , or a digital camera , or , God forbid , a scooter ?
And so , in an attempt to provide something useful , Wired News has dispensed with the traditional gift guide in favor of a guide to online gift guides .
Trouble is , these days good gift guides are few and far between .
Most are n't that original , or shill for their own e-commerce efforts .
What follows is far from a comprehensive list .
Instead , we 've tried to highlight gift guides that suggest less , well , predictable gifts .
Happy shopping .
Space.com has an unusual gift guide featuring Monolithic Domes , a Mach 5 Racer and a hovercraft .
You may not be able to afford these things , but it makes for interesting reading .
Surprise.com has an interesting gift guide created by its users .
The site -- which does n't actually sell the gifts , just links to them -- has a clever scheme for categorizing recipients : Lives in a Small Apartment ; Wants a Little Peace & Quiet ; Shops Garage Sales .
Gifts are suggested and rated by users , and can be sorted by popularity or price .
The site also keeps track of gifts you have browsed , making it easy to find them if you wander around a bit .
There are some fun ideas here , like the steak branding iron for barbecue cowboys .
PC Magazine 's John Dvorak lists his top 10 ideas for giving tech gifts .
The venerable tech columnist 's suggestions are n't all unique -- he recommends the Visor Prism for starters -- but he does suggest that parents forget about trying to find a Sony PlayStation II and go for a Sega Dreamcast instead .
Sage advice .
With characteristic humor , San Francisco Weekly has a well-rounded lineup of gift ideas .
Slashdot 's guide , commissioned by Wired Magazine , is n't as original as one might hope .
But there are some good ideas buried in the reader comments below the story , if you have the time and patience to go through them .
Worth has a guide to giving it away for those lucky enough to have enough to give away .
The AFL-CIO has some strong ideas about union-friendly holiday shopping , with links to resources for sweat-free shopping and WorkingFamilies.com , which sells only union-made merchandise .
ThinkGeek has some good geeky gift ideas .
We liked the Personal Desktop Refrigerator .
Stupid.com is full of the kind of crap geeks love , like Chokka Ca Ca , Singing Blenders and a Pregnant Woman keychain .
Memepool is an amazing resource for finding offbeat stuff on the Web .
Search the site for words like " gift " and you will be transported to places like Webundies , the " Internet 's largest collection of novelty boxer shorts " ; the Los Angeles County Coroner 's Office gift shop ; or Divine Interventions , a purveyor of blashphemous sex toys .
If you 're looking for what not to buy , there 's ShittyGift.com and Happy Christmas.com 's " Useless gift ideas . "
Spark.com has a mildly amusing Christmas Gift Test . "
Many , many years ago , Joseph and Mary were riding around on donkeys , " the site says . "
Today , Christmas rides our asses in a similar fashion . "
And when you 're thoroughly sick of Christmas shopping , restore a little sanity by exploring the links on Amalthys Consulting 's anti-consumerism page .




German Hate Law : No Denying It

BERLIN -- If this week 's border-transcending ruling by Germany 's highest court proves anything , it 's that an enormous distance remains between advocates of a free Internet and watchdogs against racism and hate-mongering .
The court , called the Bundesgerichtshof , issued a ruling on Tuesday that overturned a lower court ruling , and found that German law applies even to foreigners who post content on the Web in other countries -- so long as that content can be accessed by people inside of Germany .
Specifically , the court found Australian Holocaust-denier Frederick Tben guilty of spreading " Auschwitz lies . "
Tben , who was born in Germany , uses the website of his Australian-based Adelaide Institute to encourage people in the belief that the Holocaust has no historical basis .
International reaction to the ruling differed wildly .
Andy Mueller-Maguhn , a leader of Berlin 's famed Chaos Computer Club hacker collective and a new Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers board member , was blunt in questioning the legitimacy of the ruling .
ICANN
" This German court wants to judge over the whole world in effect , " he said . "
No one knows what it means .
We could easily agree that it seems likely to be a decision made by a judge who does not understand very much . "
Mueller-Maguhn , something of a celebrity in Germany as a technology visionary , plans to take immediate action .
He said he will contact Germany 's highest court on Monday morning and invite someone from the court for a debate before Germany 's legislature on the ruling - and how it should be applied in the future .
" The court decision of the Bundesgerichtshof seems to be the worst Internet-dependent court decision so far , " he said . "
If other countries would take this as an orientation and start to apply their laws on the citizens of other countries acting in their countries , the worldwide free flow of information could lead very fast to an unfree situation in the real world .
" Hopefully will take a minute to think about this . "
the Bundesgerichtshof
Tben himself made a similar argument .
" Germany is trying to rule the world again by saying that the people who access the Internet have no choice , " he told the Associated Press .
But Rabbi Abraham Cooper , Associate Dean of the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles , applauded the court action .
" We commend the German authorities for sticking to their commitment -- it 's their democracy , these are their laws , " he said by phone from California .
" In the first months of this year they had a thousand hate crimes in Germany .
We need to be sensitive to , and grateful to , to the democratic government of Germany when its says ' We have anti-Nazi laws in place and we still need those laws .
' "
" Maybe for those of us who live on the other side of the Atlantic , this seems remote or abstract .
If people are not outraged by the Adelaide website , how about mlking.org ?
That site is hosted by white supremacists .
You can n't outlaw that site .
But it is an early warning to us .
There 's no librarian online .
A kid goes to the Internet and plays Russian Roulette . "
Cooper urges Internet freedom advocates in the United States and elsewhere to keep an open mind on issues that have sprung up only recently with the widespread popularity of the Internet .
" We have to commend the Germans and the French for basically saying ' in our societies , this is how we deal with the problems of hate , racism and Holocaust denial .
You in America have your own laws , but at least respect our values .
' "
" It was their blood that was shed .
What 's theoretical for us is very real over there ... the Internet community is going to have to address these issues in a less contentious way . "
The German authorities arrested Tben in 1999 for distributing Holocaust-denying leaflets on a visit to Germany .
The lower court found Tben , 56 , guilty of offending the memory of the dead , but ruled that German law against inciting racial hatred could not be applied to content on a foreign website .
He was sentenced to 10 months in prison , and served seven months of that term before returning to Australia .
Germany 's Federal Court of Justice took a major interpretive step beyond the lower-court ruling this week , however .
It found that sweeping German legislation passed in the wake of World War II that banned the Nazi party and any glorification of it -- including denial of the Holocaust -- can be applied to Internet content that originates outside of the country 's borders .
Tben left Germany for Australia when he was 10 years old and went on to earn a Ph.D. in English and Philosophy from Melbourne University .
He told the Australian press this week that he believes he could spend up to five years in jail if he returns to Germany .
He said he 's willing to serve more time in German jails for his beliefs , but does not relish the thought of what might happen to him in such circumstances .
" I would not be safe in a German jail , " he told Australia 's ABC television . "
They would eliminate me and this gives me reason to think it would be foolish if I did go back . "
Although Tben could theoretically face extradition , so far Australia reports no extradition request from Germany .
He could face a more immediate legal challenge from within his own country .
Australia 's Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission issued an order in October instructing Tben to apologize to the Jewish community and remove at least some of the content from his website .
Tben refused .
The importance of the German court ruling may be in emboldening Australian authorities to make a more aggressive approach to what it considers offensive content .
Cooper of the Wiesenthal Center and others emphasize that a gradual and ongoing process of international consultation needs to occur to shape a new consensus on how to deal with such touchy issues of freedom and regulation .
" The basic approach to it , in our view , is not necessarily a whole ton of UNESCO- and UN-sponsored rules that would be more satisfactory to dictators than students , " Cooper said . "
It is to look for more creative leadership on the issue on the part of the collective Internet community .
" I think if we talk about the exchange of ideas , including the uncomfortable ones , we all know that at the end of the day , everyone can get up on the Internet .
You can n't keep them off .
They have to have a coherent policy , and that does n't exist yet . "
Germany , too , is arguing for more international coordination and in fact , the Wiesenthal Center hosted a conference on the topic of the Internet and hate speech last summer in Berlin , all part of an ongoing effort to encourage creative thinking .
" The best chance to fight against right-wing material on the Internet is on an international level , " Hans-Gertz Lange , a spokesman for Germany 's criminal investigative agency , told the IDG News Service .
" But when I think of the U.S. or Canada , it 's extremely unlikely that they 'll change their laws in accordance with ours .
Their concept of freedom of speech is tied up with their history ; our laws against incitement to racial hatred are tied up with ours . "
Michel Friedman , a leader of Germany 's Jewish community , also believes in inflexibility in responding to the power of the Internet to spread hate .
" is one of the communications basics number one in the far right scene , not only in Germany but in the whole of Europe and even America , " he said . "
The Net
It 's communication place number one for the exchange of neo-Nazi thinking in the world .
" This is very difficult to handle .
But I believe we have to be very creative next time on that issue .
Worldwide , we try to work on this issue .
We are just in the beginning . "




' Nature ' Snatches Genome Map ?

Rumors of where the Human Genome Project 's groundbreaking research paper will wind up are flying faster than RNA messages .
Earlier this week , the word on the street was the paper from the government-funded consortium would be submitted to the journal Science for simultaneous publication with research from Celera Genomics , a for-profit company that created its own human genome map .
Now HGP officials say that 's definitely not happening , and more than likely their paper will go to the journal Nature -- if only because the Human Genome Project leaders were miffed by a recent agreement between Celera and Science .
There are other scientific journals , but none with the cachet of the above-mentioned two .
" The issue does n't have anything to do with Celera , it has to do with Science and the fact that we just disagree with data restrictions , " said John McPherson , co-director of the genome sequencing center at Washington University in St. Louis , Missouri .
McPherson is the lead author on one of about 10 papers in total he confirmed have now been submitted to an unidentified journal based on the HGP research .
The special arrangement with Science would allow the company to monitor access to its database of gene information by hosting it on the Celera website .
The agreement is unusual because gene researchers in the past have typically submitted their data to GenBank , a free , government-funded database .
Some scientists are worried that the move could set a precedent that would limit scientific progress , because it 's a departure from providing unrestricted data for other scientists to use and replicate .
As a result , HGP researchers are choosing not to submit to Science what many think is the most important science since James Watson and Francis Crick described the structure of DNA in Nature in 1953 .
One source who asked not to be identified said that instead of Science the research will be submitted to Nature , but a spokeswoman at the National Human Genome Research Institute , the main organization overseeing the HGP , said the researchers would rather stick with custom and wait until publication to make any announcements .
" We will continue on the path of not disclosing where we 've submitted , because that 's good old tradition in scientific publishing , " said NHGRI spokeswoman Kathy Hudson .
Researchers traditionally wait until the publication date to disclose the specifics of when and where , the reason being that after submission , a paper must go through a rigorous peer-review process and publication is not guaranteed .
Celera officials dispensed with that tradition by announcing in a press release last week that they had submitted their paper to Science .
In June , the rival genome mapping teams surprised the scientific community by ending an ongoing race to finish the maps , and announcing together that they each had completed a " working draft . "
At the time they suggested a dual publication would happen by the end of the year .




Happy Holidays ...
You 're Fired

On the phone , Marc Sason sounds like a pretty nice guy .
He 's intelligent , articulate , and seems to have a good sense of humor .
Sason 's also got experience working on the Web .
So when he got laid off from his online content-producing job at SavvyHealth.com a month ago , one might have guessed that his hiatus would have been short-lived .
But it was n't .
Sason and the thousands of other Web workers who found themselves jobless in the past few months are realizing that it 's unlikely they 'll be snapped up by another online company before the holidays are out .
And stuck with high rents and bereft of salaries and stock options , they 're saying they do n't have much to celebrate in this new era of dried up dot-coms .
According to the outplacement firm Challenger , Gray & Christmas , 8,329 people were laid off from Internet businesses nationwide in November alone , more than in any other industry .
OK -- so worrying about the holiday-time hardships of online professionals probably is n't as noble as worrying about , say , homeless people .
But all nobility aside , this year has been one of the worst for online professionals , not only in the number of layoffs but also in the timing .
Sason , for instance , was laid off just a few days before Thanksgiving . "
I was working from home that day , " he described it . "
Then I got a telephone call from the CEO .
And he was very -- you know when you 're going to call a girl and ask her out ?
And you 're like , you keep putting the question off ?
That was what he was like with me . "
Sason and three others had to go , the CEO said , because SavvyHealth 's funding was ailing . "
They did n't tell me that when they hired me , though , " he said . "
They said things like , ' To the best of our knowledge , I do n't think we 'll run out of money ' -- using words that 'd pretty much save their ass either way . "
Now , Sason is looking for another job , but he says it is n't easy . "
I 've had a few interviews , but I hear that a lot of the companies are winding down their operations for the end of the year , " he said .
Sason suspects , consequently , that he 'll be jobless at least until the New Year , but he 's keeping his chin up : " What am I going to do ?
Cry ? " he asked with Alfred E. Neuman-like confidence when questioned about his thoughts on paying a high San Francisco rent .
Fortunately , Sason did his holiday shopping already , taking a loan from future earnings . "
All I can say is , thank God for credit cards , " he said .
Others among the recently pink-slipped also said that this holiday was looking down -- but some had plans for getting out of their slump .
" In true dot-com fashion , I 'm -- what else ?
-- starting up my own company , " said Steve Foerster , who was just laid off from his job at E-gold.com .




She 'll Go Down in History

The famous British tabloid press has tracked down a London woman whose lewd e-mail exchange with a boyfriend was circulated to millions around the world like a virus .
Claire Swire , whose explicit exchange in a private e-mail flooded into millions of inboxes around the world , is to be featured on British television Friday night and has reportedly sold her story to the Mail on Sunday .
The Londoner gained national notoriety this week when an e-mail exchange with her boyfriend about oral sex was forwarded by her boyfriend to some of his male friends .
Within minutes , the friends had forwarded it to their friends , and within hours the exchange had spread across the globe .
The Register , which picked up the story first , published details of the exchange but found it too hard to swallow and concluded it was a hoax .
But the episode made the front pages of many of Britains newspapers on Friday , including the Guardian , the Times and the BBC , and Claire Swire shot to fame .
Hoax or not , her boyfriend , Bradley Chiat , may be canned on Monday .
His employers , Norton Rose , a posh law firm , takes a dim view of obscene , non-work-related e-mail -- and presumably , the unwanted attention of the international press .




Indies File In Against MP3.com

Just when MP3.com thought it was safe to go back into the streams , Emusic.com filed a copyright infringement suit against the digital music company .
Filed in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York , the suit claims the my.mp3.com streaming audio service allows users to access music from Emusic 's collection without the proper licensing agreement .
" Although MP3.com has entered into settlement agreements with the five major record labels , they have chosen to ignore their infringing actions with respect to independent labels , " Emusic.com CEO Gene Hoffman said in a written statement . "
Emusic strongly supports the rights of music fans to have access to convenient , inexpensive digital music -- as well as the rights of all labels and artists to chose how and where their music is used . "
Six other label partners were party to the suit as well : Fearless Records , Fuel 2000 Records , Gig Records , Invisible Records , SpinART Records , and Victory Records .
Emusic has exclusive rights to 13,000 albums from 600 labels , although the company was unsure as to the number of albums MP3.com had made available to users .
The lawsuit comes just a month after MP3.com had negotiated its final settlement with the five major record labels and the music publishers over similar claims .
Users who sign up for the my.mp3.com service can stream music from MP3.com 's database to Internet-enabled devices .
But getting the service fully operational has proven to be difficult for MP3.com as the company has faced continued legal challenges from the independent label community .
In May , TVT Records filed a similar suit against the company , piggybacking on a New York district court 's finding that MP3.com violated the copyrights of the five major labels with the introduction of its streaming music service .
On November 17 -- one day after MP3.com settled its final copyright infringement suit with those major labels -- Santa Monica 's Engstrom , Lipscomb & Lack filed a class-action copyright infringement suit on behalf of the independent Unity Entertainment Corporation and other unnamed independent labels .
MP3.com had halted access to the my.mp3.com service on May 10 after legal action was taken by the major-label music industry .
The service re-launched in December after the company negotiated settlements with the major labels and publishers , prompting the latest lawsuit .
MP3.com and Emusic were unavailable for comment .




Appliances Work the Web

NEW YORK -- If there 's one word to characterize the emerging iAppliances category , it 's variety .
At the iAppliances conference this week , companies showed off a range of MP3 players , set-top boxes , WAP phones , pagers , handheld devices and Web terminals that will be gracing the well-connected home during early 2001 .
If you 've ever tried to view a Web page over a handheld device -- or , worse yet , a smart phone -- you were probably disappointed to see that you got nowhere near a full view of the page .
InViso , of Sunnyvale , California , takes care of that with its new display technology .
The company offers " a no-compromise view of the information you had on your desk , but it fits in your pocket , " said President and CEO Joy Weiss .
The eCase , for example , puts a postage-stamp-sized display into a handheld device that runs Windows CE .
Hold the device close to your eye , and that diminutive screen provides you with the equivalent of a 19-inch SVGA display .
The eCase can be used to read blueprints out in the field or to access Acrobat documents on the road , but is not recommended for prolonged use .
For longer reading periods , slip on inViso 's eShades .
They look like an oversized pair of wraparound sunglasses , but like the eCase , they provide you with a full view of Web pages , as well as DVD movies , games and other content .
InViso is also investigating the possibility of embedding its displays into digital cameras , handsets , and monocular and binocular headsets .
Trimble , also based in Sunnyvale , makes position-aware global positioning satellite applications that take advantage of GPS data .
The company currently concentrates on engineering/construction , agriculture and fleet management .
Trimble 's FirstGPS technology can give farmers a finer degree of information about water , fertilizer or chemical needs of their crops .
Where farmers had previously measured yields in bushels per acre , Trimble 's GPS technology lets them measure bushels per square meter , according to David M. Hall , senior vice president of marketing and development .
When managing fleets of ambulances , the GPS technology can have life-saving benefits , Hall said .
One hospital cut its time to dispatch ambulances from three minutes to 17 seconds , he claimed .
The company is also working on getting its navigation systems into cars , partnering with automotive electronics manufacturers that produce components for Mercedes-Benz , Volkswagen , Audi , Toyota , BMW , Porsche and other car makers .
Hall says Trimble 's technology cuts power use of GPS systems down from what had been one watt two years ago to only 30 milowatts .




Knowing When Vesuvius Will Erupt

SAN FRANCISCO -- A new generation of imaging satellites that measure changes in the Earth 's surface with millimeter accuracy will help scientists create an early-warning network for volcanic eruptions , scientist said on Friday .
A worldwide emergency network could be set up within a decade and save thousands of lives threatened by massively destructive eruptions , scientists told the annual meeting of the American Geophysical Union .
Scientists said volcanology is undergoing " a revolution " that -- in stark contrast to today -- will give people plenty of advance warning of volcanic eruptions .
" Volcanoes are something , we all believe , we will be able to predict in the future , " said Howard Zebker , a geophysicist at Stanford University .
Over the next 10 years , various space agencies , including NASA , the European Space Agency and the Japanese agency , will launch a constellation of extraordinarily sensitive satellites .
The satellites will allow scientists to measure millimeter deformations on the surface of the Earth 's 600 active volcanoes .
They will also be used for measuring the movement of ice flows , glaciers and tectonic plates .
The measurements will let scientists know when magma -- molten rock from the Earth 's core -- starts moving upwards toward the surface .
Deformations of the volcano 's surface that is caused by the magma may give months , possibly years , of advance warning of an eruption .
At present , the science of predicting volcanic eruptions is one of informed guesswork .
Volcanoes are so unpredictable , they often erupt without warning .
Currently , scientists are lucky if they can make a prediction weeks ahead of a major blow .
Early warning signs include a growing lava dome , and , naturally , a lot of smoke , ash and fire .
But eruptions frequently strike without warning and can be immensely destructive .
An eruption in Colombia in 1991 claimed 23,000 lives .
Chances are , Popocatepetl in Mexico City , Vesuvius in Italy , or Ranier outside Seattle will blow in the next decade , said John Fink , a geophysicist from Arizona State University .
" We really have no idea when volcanoes are going to erupt , " Fink said .
Volcanoes can also bring down airliners .
Volcanic ash easily clogs jet engines .
Many major airline routes pass over active volcanoes .
" We have had quite a few cases of near misses in the past decade , " Fink said . "
This can happen pretty much at any time . "
Many scientists hope the millimeter accuracy of the next generation of imaging satellites will also lead to better earthquake prediction .
But the movements of Earth 's tectonic plates are much more minute than the movements caused by huge plugs of rising magma .
" Plate motion is really subtle , " Zebker said . "
It 's at the same rate as fingernails grow .
It 's currently under our radar . "
As well as being cheaper and easier to monitor volcanoes from space , it 's also a lot safer .
Zebker said at least one volcanologist a year is killed while studying a volcano .
Advances in satellite technology will be married to other developments in volcanic monitoring -- including sensitive seismometers to measure earth tremors , strain gauges that can tell the stress on rocks , and a range of other instruments for detecting changes in temperature and atmospheric gas .
Scientists are even developing computer visualization and modeling techniques to predict which direction the volcano will blow , where the lava will run and how far out the blanket of dust might settle .
