Hooverville.com , a MUD for the new millennium : Thousands of unemployed Internet professionals go on a virtual bummer .
In a mass act of solidarity/desperation , 800,000 ex-Internet professionals in New York , San Francisco and Austin move their e-mail addresses and rsum sites to hooverville.com .
There , twenty-somethings swap war stories , review lines of code , recommend each other for jobs as the largest ad-hoc unemployment network in history .
For every 10 job referrals you make , you receive a virtual box to add to your cardboard domicile .
Each box is worth a 10 percent discount at BestBuy , Radio Shack and Kinko 's .
Hooverville.com is a registered trademark of the Republican Party .
Kevin Cooke , Wired Digital director of engineering , sorts it out : It will n't be at all about technology differentiation , but about making money .
With so much venture capital money chasing so few new tech ideas , most startups that differentiate themselves on technology , rather than on business models , will be just that much more dot-com detritus .
Those few new tech ideas that do stick -- a la Napster -- will be hailed as revolutionary by the techbiz media , ignorant as ever of history and lacking perspective .
The people who do n't care about the Internet as a medium will finally be scared off .
Geeks will rule the suits , finally .
No more X2X acronyms and marketspeak , dammit !
For those of us left in the industry : Our options may continue to be worthless , but we will still have interesting jobs , at least .
Doug Beeferman , Lycos research developer , on P2P : Most of the peer to peer activity on the Net today is the exchange of pirated music and porn .
It 's not surprising that the first few applications of this concept are illicit in some way .
Next year we will witness the growth of peer to peer as a search paradigm , not just for specific categories such as student term papers but also for general Web search .
Websites will opt-in to networks of actively indexed content .
It will gradually become possible for users to do an up-to-the-moment search of the Web , so that changes made to any page are instantaneously reflected in the results of the smartest search engines .
The need for these search engines to be scalable and accurate yet decentralized will motivate the study of algorithms that route requests to desired content in these networks .
Peer to peer sharing will bring new value to the Web but also a danger .
Increasingly , students will come to see the Internet as an exhaustive , infallible knowledge source , and they will do all of their research on the Web , overlooking the vastly larger amount of knowledge that is still undigitized or not digitizable .
Also , plagiarism will become rampant , and it will not find a countermeasure in technology alone .
On a happier note , we will come to realize that the " tech meltdown " of 2000 was only about dumb business models , not about the promise of the Internet .
The fundamental value of the Internet -- its utility for enlightening and connecting people -- will continue to grow .
Brad King , Wired News reporter , spins the future of music :
Shape up and sell out .
That 's the last , best business plan for those lucky digital music companies who survived the earth-scorching chaos of Chapter 11s that hit the industry this past year .
High-profile litigation from the recording industry against Napster and MP3.com scared off the venture capitalists , ensuring the flameouts of companies such as Riffage.com before they could get their business legs .
Now , the pending merger of America Online-Time Warner and the emergence of multinational corporations Vivendi and Bertelsmann in the digital space cast a long shadow over the future of music .
Look for a flurry of fire sales as the three giants try to buy their way into the infrastructure and distribution markets .
And look for digital music companies to continue to get squeezed out of existence .
And for those left without a home after the coming spending spree , well , there 's always the scrap heap .
Declan McCullagh , Wired News reporter , on a visible Washington :
One surprise in 2001 -- anonymity will suddenly become a hot topic of conversation .
Do we have the right to stay anonymous online and shield our privacy , or will law enforcement concerns prevail ?
The Feds will start talking about requiring ISPs and websites to keep detailed records about their customers , just in case a future investigation requires it .
The trend of failed B2C tech companies will extend to the privacy realm .
Zero Knowledge of Montreal could run out of cash by mid-2001 .
Second-tier firms will follow suit .
HavenCo , on Sealand , will n't get enough customers to stay afloat .
B2B privacy companies will have better luck .
But the market will finally learn that polls are unreliable : People do n't care that much about privacy , and are usually unwilling to pay more for it .




Gates Gives An Electric Intro

LAS VEGAS , Nevada -- The 2001 Consumer Electronics Show kicked off with the formal introduction of the Microsoft Xbox gaming console by none other than chairman Bill Gates himself .
CES
Gates offered very little new details on the console beyond the outside design of the unit .
Microsoft went through more than 100 designs , according to Gates , before settling on the form of choice , a black box with a large " X " shape in the plastic molding on the top .
It 's very large by console standards , almost as big as a desktop PC , and will come with built-in 100 Mbit Ethernet networking for broadband connections , support for high definition television and has four USB-based plugs on the front for game controllers .
HDTV
The game controllers are also upgradeable , with two PC Card-sized slots for expansion .
The controllers also have forced feedback , so the gamer will feel the vibrations of crashes and explosions .
Beyond that , there was n't a whole lot of detail .
The price was not disclosed and Gates would only give a ship date as " this fall . "
He did say the hardware was largely completed and the prototype that was shown is what would ship , both inside and out .
The only hardware still under development are the video controller chips , which are being done by graphics hotshot nVidia .
Gates said the 3-D chips in the Xbox would be three times faster than anything on the market and offer nearly unlimited graphical visuals . "
We 're approaching the level of detail seen in Toy Story 2 , " he said , referring to the computer-generated kids film from Disney/Pixar .
" Game developers will finally be able to develop games as they can visualize it in their minds , without having restrictions placed on them due to performance . "
During the demos , Gates repeatedly stressed that the current hardware and software were reflecting only one-fifth of the Xbox 's capabilities .
One of the first games on Xbox will be WWF Raw is War , and Gates decided rather than show one-fifth of a wrestler to have the full demo .
With that , in came World Wrestling Federation star Dwayne " The Rock " Johnson , who amused the audience by constantly talking about himself in the third person and putting Gates over with terms not usually associated with the turnbuckle-and-tights show he belongs to .
It looked like one of the few times , if ever , that the Microsoft boss looked intimidated .
What really drew a response from the audience , however , was a demonstration of the Pocket PC Plus , an enhanced handheld system with voice recognition .
The demo , run on a Compaq iPaq handheld , recognized full sentences dictated by voice in the auditorium , which was full of echoes , and even recognized commends to send e-mail and to schedule a meeting with an individual at a certain time .
Microsoft also demonstrated its forthcoming Whistler operating system , which will have a redesigned interface and a whole new infrastructure for data sharing .
One demo included taking pictures from a digital camera and sending them to a personal website and an electronic picture display mounted in the home , all in a few clicks .
The company also demonstrated a digital radio where the content , such as music or news , comes from the PC .
" The PC remains the place where you will store all of your information , but in the future , you will have more and more items connected to it , " said Gates . "
As they all come together , these pieces are about an overall digital lifestyle . "
The pieces are obviously selling well .
Before Gates spoke , Consumer Electronics Association president Gary Shapiro spoke , telling the crowd that consumer electronics sales rose 10 percent in 2000 , from $ 81 billion to a little over $ 90 billion , and that number is expected to reach $ 96 billion this year .
More than 625,000 HDTV units were sold for a total of $ 1.4 billion alone while DVD continues to enjoy the fastest acceptance of any consumer device , with 8.2 million units sold in 2000 alone .
Shapiro also announced a meeting next week among HDTV broadcasters and developers to set a single standard for HDTV transmissions , and that on March 6 there would be a meeting in Washington , D.C. between copyright holders and digital media companies to try and reach some agreements on how content can go digital while respecting copyrights .




MP3.com Looks Home for Harmony

The future of digital music entertainment runs through MP3.com .
MP3.com CEO Michael Robertson helped roll out new hardware and software applications designed to connect listeners with their music without using their computer .
Dubbed " The Next Generation of My.MP3 " after his controversial music-streaming service , the new service model seeks to connect listeners , retailers and labels .
" Today , the act of buying a CD , playing it on a stereo , and then putting that music in an online locker consists of three separate transactions , " Robertson said in a written statement . "
We expect to change that process by connecting a music retailer with a device manufacturer and an online locker service in a way that will make it one transaction . "
MP3.com is hanging its hat on the connectivity of home entertainment , something that some analysts believe might not be coming very soon .
Still , IDC analyst Malcolm Maclachlan said the company had no reason to hold back now that much of its legal troubles are behind it .
" The overall idea about music is right , " Maclachlan said . "
They 've already shelled out $ 180 million in lawsuits , so they have no incremental disadvantage to rolling out their innovations slowly .
Even if this does n't catch on right away , I do n't think they should shy away from being as far out at front as they can . "
Robertson , never one to shy away from anything , seemed to agree .
A key component to his vision is the Music Interoperating System , which is a fancy name for the new set of tools that MP3.com is making available to the industry .
" Before , the retail guys did stuff on their own , " Robertson said . "
The software guys did stuff on their own .
The hardware guys did stuff on their own .
We looked at the problems , and thought we needed to find a way to connect all these devices . "




Palm , Sprint Go After MS Vocally

Palm aficionados will soon have voice services on their handheld devices , or if they prefer , a smart phone running on the Palm operating system , according to Palm and Sprint PCS officials who unveiled a host of products to be released this year .
In a move analysts say will n't help Palm stave off competition by Microsoft 's Pocket PC team , Palm and Sprint PCS announced they would release products that would enable Palm users to access digital voice and data services over the Sprint PCS code-division multiple-access network .
PALM
PCS
" Customers will have a richer browsing experience than they have now , " Sprint PCS chief operating officer Charles Levine said .
The companies said they would co-brand and jointly release a kit that includes a data cable , a Palm handheld adapter , a CD-ROM and a guide telling Palm III and Palm V users how they can access content on Sprint 's wireless Web and Palm 's new portal .
Palm VII devices are already wirelessly enabled through BellSouth .
The Sprint PCS kit is expected to be in the Palm Store in early 2001 , according to company representatives .
By the middle of the year , Sprint PCS plans to release a smart phone with personal information management capabilities that run on the Palm OS .
The phone service carrier has also committed itself to release a CDMA wireless modem for Palm handhelds -- an indicator that Palm has done a poor job in locking up hardware manufacturers , analysts say .
The companies say they are targeting business users who want to access corporate e-mail and stock quotes and receive real-time news and other information .
Users will be charged a flat fee for airtime , whether they use it for making calls or accessing data .
Any airtime beyond that outlined by their plan will be charged on a minute-by-minute basis , no matter how it is used .
While both companies will benefit from reaching out to each other 's customers and increasing their traffic , the partnership does n't help Palm stave off competition from nemesis Microsoft , analysts say .
Both Microsoft and Palm are targeting business consumers .
But Microsoft has the advantage of dominance in the workplace with its Windows software installed on desktop computers .
As for offering CDMA voice services , analysts are expecting Microsoft to announce its own partnerships with phone service carriers this year .
" There are quite a few business users taking a hard look at Microsoft because of the migration of services , " Gartner Group analyst Phil Redman said .
Palm CEO Carl Yankowski , however , made it a point in a recent press conference to strike down the notion the company was losing its foothold in the business market .
Yankowski also said that since 30 percent of its revenues come from abroad , the company would soon announce partnerships with foreign phone service providers .
" Despite the media attention on Pocket PCs , Palm is already the handheld of choice in the enterprise , " Yankowski said .
Barely .
" It seems like Palm is everywhere but there are only 12 million devices , " Redman said . "
There 's no way a winner can be pronounced in this market .
" It 's just the beginning . "

Linux 2.4 Arrives

Perhaps the Wired News Vaporware List is a good motivator , because two weeks after winning a high spot on the list , the Linux 2.4 kernel has been released .
The announcement was made in a rather low-key way on the Linux Kernel Mailing List by Linux creator , Linus Torvalds , who sarcastically announced , " In a move unanimously hailed by the trade press and industry analysts as being a sure sign of incipient brain damage , Linus Torvalds decided that enough is enough , and that things do n't get better from having the same people test it over and over again .
also known as the ' father of Linux ' or , more commonly , as ' mush-for-brains '
In short , 2.4.0 is out there . "
The kernel is available on the main distribution site .
The kernel is more than a year late and has been delayed almost as often as operating systems from a certain Washington-based software company .
Torvalds had promised the 2.4 kernel for the fall of 1999 , and then pushed it off several more times .
However , Linux developers think it 's worth the wait and the delay was a good thing .
" I 'm glad he did n't put it out a year ago just because he promised to do so , " said Preston Brown , president of Linux OS engineering at Red Hat , the most widely used commercial Linux distribution on the market . "
There were a lot of major improvements made between then and now .
A lot of low-level stuff needed to be rewritten , like memory management and changes in the scheduler . "
The 2.4 kernel contains improvements for desktop users , but the emphasis is on the high end .
Most notable for desktop users is support for the Universal Serial Bus , which will give Linux users many more peripherals to choose from .
USB
On the server side , the changes include greatly improved support for symmetric multiprocessing , multi-threaded networking throughput , and SCSI and RAID disk support and throughput is also much faster .
SMP
The multi-threaded networking protocols means websites will be able to handle much more traffic , said Brown , while the improvements in SMP means it will scale up to a 16-processor machine .
The 2.2 kernel does have some SMP support , but performance levels out beyond four processors , he said .
The two-year gap between the 2.2 kernel and 2.4 is n't an issue for Linux developers , who see the APIs and interfaces around the kernel as far more important . "
Why would an individual need the 2.4 kernel ? " asked Mark Bolzern , founder of LinuxMall.com , a major online store for Linux products . "
The only thing it really applies to is people running it on the bleeding edge . "
" We were n't heavily hampered by not having a 2.4 kernel , " said Brown . "
The only thing that held us back were apps for the high end , like databases that need raw I/O access .
Certainly two years is right on track with other software vendors releases for new operating systems .
The rest of our OS has n't sat static while we waited for the kernel . "




Call Waiting : A Cell Phone ATM

Grabbing a burger is getting easier .
Soon you will just have to wave your cell phone as you pass McDonald 's drive-through .
Immediate gratification is always the best marketing tool .
Nokia is testing a new SmartCover for its 5100 Series phones that will act just like a debit card .
NOK
Tollbooth car tags and the ExxonMobile SpeedPass use the same technology and their users number in the millions .
To buy a Big Mac , the consumer pays a bill by holding a Nokia 5100 up to a scanner .
The scanner contacts a wireless network , and payment is deducted from a credit card or account .
The SmartCover Xpress-on contains a Texas Instruments chip that uses a short-range radio frequency transmission to send payment information to the scanner .
Expected to hit the stores before June , the snap-on cover works in conjunction with the 2 Scoot wireless network of Hudson Valley , New York .
The company specializes in cash-less transaction processing systems .
Currently the 2 Scoot technology is used to authorize and clear payments for credit cards and pay-at-the-pump gas stations .
The radio frequency identification chip is the size of a pencil eraser , said Rick Heimann , marketing strategist for Texas Instruments .
RFID
Acting as a passive transponder , the chip is activated when placed in the scanner 's radio frequency field .
The area of the field is usually 2 to 8 inches .
There is no dialing , no ATM , no fumbling for a wallet or dropped coins -- only radio-frequency burgers .
Nokia plans to market the RFID and SmartCover to retail , banking and other service industries that offer cash-less transactions and loyalty marketing programs .
" The RFID is also a personal identifier .
At the time of the transaction , the restaurant can send back to the users coupons or other information to their wireless device , " Heimann said .
Is this yet another invasion of privacy ?
More unwanted marketing ?
Or is it simply a version of an " electronic purse ? "
The RFID-equipped phone follows the trend of customized marketing that plagues Internet users and credit card owners .
But Nokia insists it will reduce the number of debits and " rewards " that SmartCards consumers must paw through when shopping .
Phone users will control which card is used or where the money for payment comes from .
" It is also a way to improve customer service , " said Michael Liard , a market researcher for Venture Development in Natick , Massachusetts .
The convenience of the transaction may soothe consumer reluctance , Liard said .
However , the real issues delaying the adoption of the RFID-equipped SmartCover are concerns over the transmission of banking information over the airwaves .




No Whiners at AOL

LAS VEGAS -- E-tailers may be crying over slow sales and eToys is circling the drain , but AOL had a boffo Christmas , according to Barry Schuler , president of the Interactive Services Group at America Online .
In his keynote speech here at the Consumer Electronics Show , Schuler said AOL subscribers spent $ 20 billion this year online , doubling last year 's $ 10 billion in online sales .
CES
" It 's interesting to note that this is the first year brick and mortar retail sales were flat and online purchases grew and grew , " he said .
He added that more than half of AOL 's subscribers do e-commerce and more than 60 percent of its subscriber base expects to have every room in their house wired in the near future .
AOL certainly has the traffic .
Schuler reported that AOL 's 26 million users send and receive 166 million e-mails per day and exchange more than 660 million instant messages daily .
AOL 's person-to-person messaging is now double the daily traffic of the US Post Office , Schuler said .

Turn Up the Volume , Hal : Electronics continue to get smarter .
Blaupunkt introduced a new car stereo that determines the best way to set up the sound inside your car .
The Digital Sound Adjustment listens to the acoustics of the car , including taking into account bodies being in the car and sound bouncing off them , and automatically adjusts the sound so it 's well centered for the listeners .
The DSA also automatically compensates for noises , such as tires or engine noise , and compensates at those noise levels to cover up the offending noises in the car .
The DSA comes in the Blaupunkt San Francisco CD70 player , which will cost $ 699 and is available this month .
- - -
But Where 's the Gas Station ? : Casio introduced a global positioning system on a watch , literally .
The Satellite Navi PAT-2GP watch has a satellite-based GPS tracking system built in to tell you your latitude and longitude anywhere in the world .
The PC link that comes with the watch helps you translate your position into something usable , like a location on a map .
The map also has a landmark tracker , allowing you to store up to 200 locations of your own choosing , and it even has an alarm to let you know when you are approaching your target .
Oh yeah , it 's also a watch that tells the time .
The price is $ 499 and it will be out at the end of the year .
- - -
One Less Item to Carry : You probably have a Palm Pilot and a cell phone .
Why not both in one unit ?
Kyocera Wireless introduced the Kyocera QCP 6035 Smartphone , which combines a Palm Pilot III with a cell phone that 's fully Internet-ready .
The phone is HTML- and WAP-enabled and supports Qualcomm 's Eudora e-mail client , so you can download and send mail from your cell phone .
The unit will have 4.5 hours of talk time or 110 hours of standby time .
It will be available this quarter , for between $ 449 to $ 549 .
- - -
Tax-free computers : Last year seven states declared one-week suspensions of the sales tax on computers as a way to encourage more households to get online .
The temporary moratorium works in bridging the digital divide and may soon be adopted in most states , according to government representatives and computer manufacturers who spoke on the subject of tax holidays at CES .
During tax-free weeks in Pennsylvania and South Carolina , sales of PCs at Radio Shack stores in the two states went up 400 and 600 percent respectively , according to Radio Shack 's Ron Parrish .
Pennsylvania Department of Revenue official Tom Armstrong agreed that the initiative was a success , saying retail computer sales across the state were up 60 percent during the tax-free week in August , which was promoted as a " back-to-school " initiative .
Panel members said that removing the 6 to 8 percent sales tax is much more effective in encouraging consumers to buy than even a 20 percent storewide sales .
But Why ?
Because people like to get something for free from the government more than from retailers , according to Mandy Rafool , who works for the non-profit National Conference of State Legislature , which advises states on policy issues .
But tax holidays currently only apply to computers and the software packaged with them .
States are considering broadening the tax-free status to include handheld computers , Internet appliances and peripherals in the future .




Digital VHS Takes On DVD

LAS VEGAS -- The DVD , which has plenty of problems already , could be dealt a further blow from a new format that comes in a package we 're all familiar with : VHS tape .
Now , with DVD bogged down in legal problems surrounding DeCSS and copy protection , and the failure of the industry to come to an agreement on a single standard for recording , JVC is hoping lightning will strike twice with its VHS format through a new Digital VHS , or D-VHS .
JVC introduced the new D-VHS tape at the Consumer Electronics Show along with a high definition television set that protects high definition content from being copied .
CES
HDTV
Video on D-VHS tapes is uncompressed , so it 's enormous .
A 75 GB hard disk would only hold around 30 minutes of the video , according to company officials , making the trading of HD content over the Internet impossible .
D-VHS can record and play back up to four hours of video in high definition mode -- up to 1,080 lines per screen width , or more than double the resolution of DVD , according to Allan Holland , national product specialist in the consumer video division at JVC .
It can also record at the standard VHS resolution of 240 lines per screen width .
JVC was originally the Victor Company , which developed the VHS format in the mid-1970s and was bought out by Japanese investors that renamed it Victor Company of Japan .
It won a format war in the early 1980s with Sony 's Betamax technology to become the de facto home video recording and playback standard .
With twice the resolution of DVD and a high definition recording option , D-VHS could give DVD a major run for its money , since the recordable standard for DVD still is n't set and now DVD discs are vulnerable to piracy .
D-VHS also has the benefit of full backwards compatibility with VHS tape . "
You could have one piece in your stereo for everything with D-VHS , " said Holland . "
Of course , as the developers of VHS , I 'd like to think we 're going give DVD some major competition . "
A new Macrovision copy protection system prevents the duplication of tapes by copying from one digital deck to another .
The content is encrypted with a High Definition Copy Protection system JVC developed that is similar in function to the Content Scrambling System on a DVD .
HDCP
CSS
The HDCP system can n't be broken , however , because only high definition sets will have the HDCP decoder , according to Dan McCarron , national product specialist in JVC 's color TV division .
JVC 's high definition television set uses the Digital Video Interface that Intel developed for PCs and high definition television sets .
DVI
DVI ports on PCs will not have the HDCP decoder , so PCs can n't be used to break HDCP like it did with CSS .
So , with the combination of massive video size and the fact that HDCP decoders are only in high definition sets , McCarron thinks it has the answer to Hollywood 's concerns over content protection .
" One of the reasons Hollywood studios support this is because the video is uncompressed , " McCarron said . "
By compressing it , it 's easier to transmit over the Internet because it 's smaller .
Because of its size when uncompressed , it 's harder to trade or copy . "
JVC is mustering Hollywood support .
Fox Home Video , Universal Pictures and New Line Cinema have already agreed to support D-VHS and JVC claims more are looking to jump on board .
But do n't declare your DVD player obsolete just yet .
The JVC D-VHS deck , which should be available around May , will sell for approximately $ 2,000 , while blank media will cost between $ 10 and $ 15 .
JVC 's only TV to support HDCP is the D'Ahlia system , which will sell for a whopping $ 10,000 when it ships this summer .




Squeeze Boxes : Music Gets Small

LAS VEGAS -- The Consumer Electronics Show is always full of eye-opening gadgets , many of which either never see the light of day , or take years to get off the ground .
Take Sony 's MiniDisc , for example .
First introduced in 1992 , MiniDisc has only recently started to make headway .
With some new momentum , Sony has upgraded the format without invalidating the media .
The electronics giant introduced a new MiniDisc format that uses the existing disc but stores up to five hours of music .
The higher capacity comes from a new compression routine that simply packs the music tighter on the disc .
The original MiniDiscs can be reused on the new MZR-700 portable player , which is only a little larger than the disc itself and will sell for $ 250 when it ships in March .
The MXD-D40 home stereo unit , which can record from a CD at 4x the playback speed , will sell for $ 300 when it ships in March or April , Sony says .
- - -
Size matters : On an even smaller scale , DataPlay introduced its DataPlay digital media , a multi-format media about the size of a quarter that can be used in a variety of devices , similar to Flash memory modules .
The DataPlay module can hold up to 500 MB of data , or around 11 hours of MP3 files , or 250 high resolution pictures .
DataPlay has the support of the Universal Music Group , Creative Labs , Samsung and Toshiba , which are all investors .
The discs will cost between $ 5 and $ 12 , depending on capacity .
- - -
Jukebox heroes : A pair of less-flashy MP3 player were on display at the Mutli Technology Equipment booth .
The players blurred the lines between PC and stereo equipment .
The Neo Jukebox 2100/2200 is a Gameboy-sized unit with 10 or 20 GB 3.5-inch hard disk that connects to a PC using a USB port .
You can make it your MP3 walkman , or if you want , plug it into the computer and use it as a hard disk .
The 10 GB version sells for $ 459 while the 20 GB version is $ 549 .
The Neo 35 operates under the same concept , playing MP3s off a standard hard disk , but it 's built into a mobile rack that mounts in either your car or in a 5.25-inch drive bay on the PC .
The 30 GB version is $ 479 .
- - -
Living in stereo : Do n't feel like using your computer to play MP3s ?
Spent a fortune on a stereo ?
Then play your MP3s right off the Internet on your stereo .
Panja introduced the BMP-100 , a set-top box that downloads MP3 files and plays them on a home stereo .
The company has a deal with MP3.com to allow customers to download and play all the MP3s they want .
All that 's needed is a broadband connection .
The price is $ 400 for the player plus $ 10 per month for the subscription to content on MP3.com .
- - -
Handy Linux PDA : Royal Electronics introduced a Linux-based PDA , called Linia that uses Intel StrongARM processor .
Like most PDAs , it uses a graphical interface and has the basic application suite , including a personal information manager , calendar , notebook , and phone book .
But unlike most handheld devices , it will run many Linux applications .
Its high refresh rate allows it to run many Linux graphical applications with minimal code tweaking required .
The Linia 's input mechanism is rather unique .
Rather than using a pen-like stylus , it comes with a plastic ring that is worn over the tip of the finger with a point on the end .
The Linia will come with 16 MB of memory and 8 MB of flash ROM for storing Linux and the applications .
It will have ports on the top and bottom of the unit for things like PC Card connectivity , an MP3 player or a modem .
It will sell for $ 300 when it ships in May .
- - -
DVD camcorder : Panasonic is moving away from the compact VHS-C media for camcorders with the introduction of the VDR-M10 , a recordable DVD camcorder .
The media holds 2.8 GB of video per side , which translates to 30 minutes of video per side if recorded in DVD-quality video or one hour per side if recorded in standard video quality .
In addition , the VDR-M10 can function as a 1.1 megapixel digital camera and hold thousands of pictures .
The DVD-RAM media can be read and then edited on any PC with a DVD-RAM drive , or the video can be played back in a DVD player that reads DVD-RAM discs , which Panasonic plans to introduce this summer .
Price for the camcorder has not been determined .




Hello Macworld , Hello Fast Macs

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
As expected , Apple CEO Steve Jobs introduced four fast new Macs at Macworld San Francisco on Tuesday , sporting G4 CPUs running at speeds from 466 MHz to 733 MHz .
The new Power Mac G4 line also features also features high-performance architecture with 133 MHz system and memory buses , five slots for increased expandability , and CD-RW drives in all models .
Jobs also unveiled Apple 's new SuperDrive , an all-in-one CD-RW/DVD-R drive that can read and write DVDs which can then be played in consumer DVD players .
burn
The Apple SuperDrive will come standard in the top Power Mac G4 model .
The new 466 and 533 MHz Power Mac G4s are available immediately and the 667 and 733 MHz Power Mac G4s will be available in February .
Only the new 533 MHz Mac will be offered in a dual chip model .
Also announced was the Titanium PowerBook G4 featuring PowerPC G4 processors with 500 MHz CPUs , 15.2-inch displays , slot-loading DVD drive , and a promised 5 hour battery life &mdash; packaged in a one-inch thick Titanium case weighing just 5.3 pounds .
diagonal
" The Titanium PowerBook G4 is the most revolutionary portable computer ever created , " Apple CEO Steve Jobs said . "
It 's a ' supercomputer to go ' in terms of performance , yet it 's thinner and sexier than the best sub-notebooks . "
Jobs said that Apple 's new motto would be " Power To Burn . "
He also stated that Apple 's new operating system , OS X , now has an official ship date of Saturday , March 24 and the system will be priced at $ 129 .
OS X will come pre-loaded on all new Macs beginning this July .
Four-hundred developers have announced support and 1,200 applications have been developed for OS X , Jobs said .
Jobs also announced " iTunes " a new application , which Jobs said is the " uber-music client " .
During that announcement , Jobs danced to the B52 's " Love Shack . "
ITunes allows users to manage their audio collections and rip songs from CDs , and transfer music to portable audio players by dragging and dropping files .




Bluetooth Shows Off at CES

LAS VEGAS , Nevada -- The Consumer Electronics Show is usually the grand coming out party for many new technologies , and this year 's show is no exception .
CES
A number of pavilions have been set up for some of the emerging technology concepts with multiple vendor support , one of them being the Bluetooth wireless standard .
Bluetooth is an intelligent wireless communication technology that overcomes several shortfalls of infrared -- namely , its lack of range and requirement of a line of sight .
Infrared works great with two Palm Pilots pointed at each other and three feet apart , but at a distance , or with anything between the two IR lenses , it does n't work well .
Infrared also requires manual transmission and can only transmit data , not instructions .
Bluetooth solves all that .
It has a range of up to 30 feet and works through walls .
You can send just data or instructions for the recipient machine on what to do with that data .
The 1.0 specification was only finalized last year , and developers are now working on products .
One thing that can be said , Bluetooth certainly has industry support .
More than 2,000 hardware and software companies are working on Bluetooth products , according to Mike Whitmire , product manager for new products at 3Com and a member of the Bluetooth Special Interest Group , which developed the spec .
SIG
The only real demo of useable Bluetooth technology was in the 3Com and Hewlett-Packard booths , where a 3Com Bluetooth PC Card sent data to an HP inkjet printer , no cable required . "
Bluetooth will be a cable replacement technology initially , but the market has much more use for it that is just a cable replacement , " said Whitmire .
As development ramps up , Bluetooth is expected to offer more advanced capabilities , such as eliminating the need to plug a PDA into a cradle to synchronize data with PCs .
Another potential use is a single phone that operates as a land line when used in the owner 's home , but then operates as a cell phone when the user is outside the home .
Whitmire said specific groups are working on advancing the printing , audio , imaging and handheld device capabilities .
3Com and TDK both were showing off PC Cards for laptops that allow the laptop to wirelessly send data to Bluetooth devices .
TDK and 3Com both displayed transmitters that plug into the USB port .
Both companies also showed off access points -- hub-like devices that increase the transmission range of a Bluetooth signal from the normal 30 feet to 200 feet , again through walls .
The 3Com Wireless Bluetooth PC Card will sell for $ 119 , while the 3Com Wireless Bluetooth USB Adapter will sell for $ 109 ; both products are expected to be available in late March .
The 3Com Wireless Access Point 1000 will sell for approximately $ 500 when it comes out in the summer .
The TDK PCMCIA Card will be out in April for $ 150 while the TDK USB Adapter will ship at the same time for $ 140 .
The Access Point device will run $ 250 and be available in July .
For software developers , Cambridge Silicon Radio is offering the CASIRA Bluetooth Development Kit and the BlueCore single chip implementation of Bluetooth technology .
The kit includes full documentation of the specification , tools for writing , testing and debugging code , and hardware modules for testing the transmission of the data .
The kit can be ordered from the CSR website .
Socket Communications introduced its Digital Phone Card Connection Kit , a flash card-sized adapter for any handheld device that enables it to transmit data to a Bluetooth recipient .
DPC
It can be used in GSM or CDMA digital phones or PDAs that use Microsoft Pocket PC operating system .
The cards will ship at the end of the first quarter or in early Q2 at an estimated price of between $ 149 and $ 179 .




Schools Get a Helping Handheld

Pencils , protractors , compasses , folders ... add handheld devices to the list of school supplies that some believe are essential for today 's classroom .
Instead of lugging a laptop to class or trooping to the computer lab , students at Consolidated High School District 230 in Orland Park , Ill. , are carrying their computer in the palms of their hand .
And after a semester of successfully incorporating the devices into class lessons , the school district plans to expand the program next year .
" This is going to be the dominant technology that students use at school , " said Darrell Walery , director of technology for the district .
The district 's three high schools rolled out 2,200 Palm IIIxe handhelds this fall in what is believed to be the largest experiment of its kind in public schools .
" A lot of technology-rich programs center around one grade level , one teacher or one ability , " Walery said . "
We have teachers from all different subject areas in the program . "
Andrew Lech , a freshman at Amos Alonzo Stagg High School , uses the Palm in nearly all of his courses .
Lech writes essays in English class on the handheld and skips the trip to the school media center .
He keeps track of his homework and instantly averages his grades on the device . "
I do n't like writing in my assignment notebook , " he said . " is more interactive .
The Palm
It 's a lot better . "
Instead of lugging around a dictionary for Spanish class , he uses a translation application for the Palm .
In his honors algebra class , he uses the device as a graphing calculator .
The sophomore biology classes taught by Laurie Ritchey at Carl Sandburg High School use the Palms to instantly graph data during lab experiments .
To measure dissolved oxygen in a pond , students plugged in a probe to the handhelds and dropped the probe in the water .
The Palm then recorded and graphed the data .
The portability of the device was essential . "
Normally you can n't be rolling a computer out to a pond , " Ritchey said .
In another project , students use the devices to predict and analyze their " ecological footprint , " a measure of the resources each person uses .
To do the experiment , students recorded " a massive amount of data " on the device including information about their homes , cars , food , recycling and the number of cotton clothes they wear .
A lesson on mitosis incorporated the Palm as well .
Students used a sketchpad program to draw the different stages of mitosis , which then became animated when the student finished .
Ritchey was one of 65 volunteer teachers who spent a week last summer learning to use the Palms .
She admitted that incorporating the device into the classroom has been time-consuming .
But the payoffs have been worth it , she said .
" You 're teaching the same things but it 's a more innovative way of teaching , " she said . "
The kids are more enthused . "
Walery said the district decided to introduce a large number of Palms all at once because otherwise , " it 's hard to tell how results transfer to different situations , " Walery said .

Net Earnings Off to Shaky Start

Yahoo got the Internet earnings season off to a less-than-optimal start Wednesday with a mixed message for investors about profits and future prospects .
The company , typically the first large Internet firm to report quarterly earnings , came forward with profit numbers that were largely in line with Wall Street expectations .
However , its stock got slammed in after-hours trading after executives warned of slowing growth in 2001 .
Yahoo 's stock fell 20 percent in after-hours trading following the earnings report , hitting a low for the year of $ 24.63 .
In a conference call with investors Wednesday afternoon , Yahoo executives talked up the company 's prospects for building up its global base of users and drawing more business from large corporate customers .
YHOO
But they also warned that in the short term , a global economic slowdown and the curtailment of dot-com spending would take their toll .
" 2001 will be a transition year , " said Susan Decker , Yahoo 's chief financial officer .
Over the next several quarters , she said , the company expects to make less money selling advertising to other Internet companies , and will concentrate on doing more business with larger , more established firms .
i.e. , companies that are n't on the verge of bankruptcy because no one wants to pay more than 50 cents for their stock
In the short term , the transition will n't do wonders for Yahoo 's bottom line .
The company said it expects to report revenue of $ 1.2 billion to $ 1.3 billion for the year 2001 .
That 's below the more-than $ 1.4 billion analysts had been predicting before the earnings report .
In the first three months of the year , the company also said that it expects sales of $ 220 million to $ 240 million , well below the $ 303.6 million expected by analysts surveyed by First Call .
Investors were n't too happy with the new outlook .
The 20 percent drop came despite the fact that Yahoo 's performance over the past three months turned out to be pretty much what investors had expected .
In the three-month period ending Dec. 31 , Yahoo said it earned $ 80.2 million , or 13 cents per diluted share , excluding certain one-time charges .
That was exactly in line with estimates from financial analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial .
The earnings did n't include a one-time charge of $ 163.2 million for equity investments in other firms and other items .
On the sales front , Yahoo reported fourth quarter revenue of $ 310.9 .
That was about $ 5 million short of expectations , but more or less on target .
Mostly , the projections for 2001 appeared to fuel the after-hours selling fever .
Some analysts who participated in the earnings conference questioned the rationale behind the scaled back earnings forecast .
Was Yahoo just being cautious , or was there real reason for fear ?
" We 're trying to figure out whether you 're just giving us worst-case scenario , " said David Readerman , an analyst at Thomas Weisel Partners .
He wondered why an increase in revenue from Fortune 500 companies would n't make up for the drop in dot-com spending .
Yahoo Chairman and CEO Tim Koogle hinted that the company opted to err on the side of caution .
" We 're trying to lay out a plan that 's very prudent , " he said . "
We try to lay out a plan and meet or exceed it every time . "
Koogle said he expects the effects of the tech stock market downturn to continue to affect Yahoo in the short term , However , he predicted ad spending will begin to accelerate in the second half of the year .
In the long run , Yahoo executives said they believed the dot-com downturn would actually strengthen their business .
To explain that logic , Decker fell back on the theory of evolution .
Back when markets were up and cash was easy to come by , she explained , even Internet companies with weak business models managed to survive for a while .
Now that the investment climate has grown considerably harsher , we 're seeing " an acceleration in economic Darwinism , " in which only the strongest companies will survive .




The Sound of One Hand Typing

If you use a Macintosh and spend a lot of time surfing the Net with one hand , the Matias Corporation may have the ideal product for you -- a one-handed keyboard .
At next week 's Macworld Expo in San Francisco , Matias will unveil the Mac version of its Half Keyboard .
Actually , the $ 99 Half Keyboard is intended for graphic artists , publishers , CAD designers and anyone else who constantly juggles a keyboard and an input device such as a graphics tablet or trackball .
After a little practice , the Half Keyboard is almost as efficient as a full keyboard for inputting text , and users can get a lot more work done if they are n't constantly shifting between input devices , the company claims .
" It makes you a lot more efficient if you are n't constantly alternating between the keyboard and the mouse or pen , " said Edgar Matias , the Half Keyboard 's inventor and president and CEO of Matias .
The Half Keyboard looks like the left half of a standard keyboard .
It has the same full-size keys and letter layout , but each key also doubles for its opposite right-hand key , which is activated when the space bar is held down .
Thus , the " G " key doubles for " H , " the " R " key for " U , " and so on .
It appears complicated , but Matias claims touch typists quickly learn to type with one hand instead of two .
The keyboard is based on the theory that the brain figures out which key to hit based on the finger used , rather than the spatial position of the key .
Because the right-hand keys are laid out in the mirror image of a standard keyboard , the same finger movements are made to type the appropriate keys .
So instead of hitting the " P " key with the right-hand little finger , it is hit with the left-hand little finger .
Matias invented the keyboard in the early 1990s as an undergraduate at the University of Toronto and tested it under the auspices of the school 's Input Research Group .
In a series of academic papers , Matias describes how -- after an hour of practice -- most touch-typists can get up to about 13 words a minute with 84 percent accuracy .
With 20 to 40 hours of practice , most typists are within 75 percent to 80 percent of their two-hand typing speeds .
Matias has spent the last four years bringing the one-hand keyboard to market .
His company sells a software version of the Half Keyboard for people who have lost the use of a hand through a repetitive stress injury or other disability .
It converts a standard keyboard into a one-handed one .




Seti : Is Anybody Out There ?

Seti@Home has clocked half-a-million years in computer time searching for ET on home PCs , but the real work is n't due to begin in earnest until January .
The Seti@Home project harnesses the spare computing cycles of millions of PCs across the globe to search for telltale signs of intelligent life in radio signals beamed from outer space .
Since its launch 18 months ago , 2.6 million people in 226 countries have downloaded Seti@Home's screensaver software , which scans radio data when their computers are n't otherwise in use .
The screensaver looks for strong signals among the white noise of the universe 's background radio transmissions .
But the process of figuring out which signals , if any , have come from alien civilizations will n't start operating at full swing until the end of January , when the project brings online all its back-end servers .
" We only recently started the back-end analysis , " said David Anderson , Seti@Home's director . "
We 've been doing bits and pieces here and there .
It will be turned on full blast next month . "
In the meantime , the Seti@Home project has become the largest computing problem ever undertaken .
It has clocked an astonishing 500,000 years in computing time , with another 1,000 years of processing time contributed every day .
Collectively , the 2.6 million Seti@Home machines are twice as powerful as the most powerful supercomputer on the planet , and a lot cheaper .
The U.S. Government 's ASCI White , housed at a California nuclear weapons research lab , is rated at 12 Teraflops and cost $ 110 million to build .
trillion operations a second
All day , every day , Seti@Home operates at around 25 Teraflops but cost only $ 500,000 , excluding the cost of the home PCs .
" It 's the biggest supercomputer on the planet by far , " said the project 's chief scientist , Dan Werthimer , an astronomer at the University of California at Berkeley 's Space Sciences Laboratory .
To date , the Seti@Home screensavers have identified 500 million strong radio signals from data gathered by the Arecibo radio telescope in Puerto Rico , the world 's largest radio telescope , which was built into a huge , bowl-shaped sink hole at the top of a mountain .
" In the screensaver , strong signals look like skyscrapers sticking up above the grass , " said Werthimer .
Using a variety of algorithms , the screensavers have whittled down the 500 million strong signals , or spikes , to about 125 million that look interesting .
All of these 125 million signals display a Gaussian , or bell curve , profile .
As the Aricebo telescope scans across the sky , the signal becomes progressively stronger and then weaker , just like a bell-shaped curve .
A signal displaying a Gaussian profile is less likely to be noise from terrestrial cell phones , airplanes or satellites , and probably originated from a single point in space -- maybe a planet orbiting a nearby star .
" That characteristic pattern gets us excited , " said Werthimer .
But to ensure the signal came from an alien civilization , it must be transmitted from the same part of the sky , at the same frequency , on two or more observations , which would indicate a persistent signal and not just a random burst of energy .
This " back-end " analysis was only recently begun , but already it has identified hundreds of signals that have been broadcast twice , three times , even four times , over an 18-month period .
A map on the project 's site shows the results : Red dots are signals picked up more twice .
Green dots are signals detected four or more times .




Microsoft Suite on OS X

SAN FRANCISCO -- Apple 's Mac OS X got a big boost on Wednesday when Microsoft said it will ship its Office productivity suite for the new operating system in the fall .
A working version of the productivity suite , which includes the Word , Excel , PowerPoint and Entourage applications , was demonstrated at a hotel near the Macworld conference .
" We 're trying to bring Office over to OS X , " said Kevin Browne , the head of Microsoft 's Macintosh software division . "
It 's going , but there 's a lot of code in 2001 to bring over . "
the current version of Office for Mac
Apple 's next-generation operating system , which is currently in beta testing , will be available at the end of March , Apple CEO Steve Job 's announced during a Macworld keynote speech on Tuesday .
AAPL
Microsoft 's Office is one of the most important applications for the Macintosh platform , ranking with Adobe 's Photoshop image editor , QuarkXpress publishing software and Macromedia 's Dreamweaver authoring tool .
But while other software companies have been quick to promise OS X versions of their software , Microsoft was dragging its feet .
Getting a version of the world 's best-selling office suite is one of the keys to OS X 's success .
Native versions of Photoshop , Quark Xpress and Dreamweaver will help persuade graphic designers and publishers to adopt Mac OS X , but without Office , many businesses would have little compelling reason to move to the new operating system .
Browne said the effort involves reworking 20 million lines of code .
The Office suite includes four complex applications , as well as dozens of optional components , add-ins and support libraries , he said .
Browne got a surprisingly friendly reception from the Mac crowd , which in the past has routinely booed Microsoft executives .
Browne said Microsoft started converting Office 2001 for OS X in October , but instead of doing a quick and dirty job , the company plans to rework the suite from the bottom up .
MSFT
" We see some awesome opportunities to bring great software to OS X , " Browne said . "
We 're working as hard as we can to deliver the best product we can as soon as we can . "
Browne said Microsoft programmers are delving into the software 's foundations to ensure it properly interacts with the underlying operating system .
The company is also rejigging the user interface , including redesigning more than 700 dialog boxes .
Browne showed the audience working versions of Word and Entourage , a personal information manager , which appeared to be fairly complete , although Word crashed just as Browne was warning the crowd that the software was still unstable .
Browne said the other two applications in the suite , PowerPoint and Excel , were n't as complete . "
Microsoft loves OS X , " he said .
Browne said he hopes to show a more complete version of Office for OS X at Macworld New York in July , which has been touted as the big coming out party for OS X software .
" It 'll knock your socks off , " Browne said .
Microsoft will offer Office for OS X for $ 149 , or about a 50 percent discount , to those who buy the current version .
Browne also announced a beta version of Outlook , which will allow Macs for the first time to connect to Microsoft 's Exchange Server , a group calendering and planning application .
The finished version is due this summer .
Throughout the presentation , Browne highlighted features of the software available first and only for the Mac platform .
Browne also repeatedly underlined Microsoft 's commitment to continue producing Macintosh software .
" This is a very strong business for Microsoft , " he said .

SAN FRANCISCO -- Five thousands seats at a Macworld keynote speech go very , very quickly .
The cavernous hall at San Francisco 's Moscone Center , venue of Apple CEO Steve Jobs ' Macworld keynote speech on Tuesday morning , filled within minutes .

By 6:30 a.m. , it was a full-fledged crowd .

There must have been 500 to 700 people .

Last year , he said he joined the line at 4:30 a.m. , but only managed to get into one of the large overflow rooms .
But this year , because of a mix-up with badges , hundreds of attendees who had pre-registered were standing in a separate , stationary line .
All were brandishing registration badges , but show management had neglected to include badge holders , which security was insisting were necessary before they let people into the hall .

" Never . "

I feel misled . "
