Gaming : Too Cool for School ?

Julia Child once pooh-poohed those who believe that a blowtorch does n't belong in the kitchen , as she eagerly fired up the flame and aimed it at a pot of creme brulee .
Like the renowned chef , Robert Nideffer , an assistant professor of studio art at the University of California at Irvine , is trying to bring a somewhat unconventional idea to a place where some feel it does not belong .
Nideffer has proposed that the school offer a minor in computer games and gaming , an initiative that has sparked heated debate .
" Computer games and gaming have been largely ignored by the academic community , " the proposal reads . "
A more comprehensive and theoretically informed approach to the artistic and technical production , dissemination and consumption of games and gaming needs to be taken if we wish to effectively engage the cultural institutions that inform our individual and collective identities , and engender new processes of communication and creativity . "
The proposal was already voted down once .
In December , a faculty committee rejected the proposal , with eight opposed , four in favor , and two abstaining , Nideffer said .
It will be re-submitted this year .
" As you can imagine , there 's still quite a bit of stigma associated with games and gaming , " Nideffer said . "
It gets into the whole ' high culture , low culture ' debate .
There is resistance . "
In a copy of a letter obtained by Wired News , Dean of the School of Social Sciences William Schonfeld expressed the following concerns :
" An academic program of study officially listed as focusing on gaming studies runs , I think , the strong risk of attracting people on the basis of prurient interest .
I do not think we should send forth messages of this type if we wish to be a research university of the highest level of distinction . "
When Schonfeld was contacted directly , he vehemently refused to comment on the proposal .
" Any discussion outside the university is inappropriate , " he said . "
It 's none of your business . "
Anne Friedberg , an associate professor of film studies and visual studies at UCI , is n't surprised such opposition exists .
" The academy has always been distrustful of the study of popular culture , " said Friedberg , a supporter of the initiative . "
It 's precisely why it is so important , because its cultural and aesthetic appeal is so pervasive . "
The interdisciplinary minor would bring together existing courses from the school of the arts , engineering , social sciences and humanities , and the department of information and computer science .
Students in the program will play games as part of their coursework .
But there is more to the proposal than just play time .
" Even though it sounds like a lot of fun , it 's also going to be extremely rigorous and demanding , " Nideffer said .




Who 's The Best Hacker of All ?

BOSTON -- Gentlemen , start your modems .
OpenHack III , a computer-hacking contest sponsored by eWeek magazine , will feature some stiff competition when it opens Monday .
In one corner is Savoy , Illinois ' Argus Systems Group , maker of a computer security product called PitBull that the company claims is virtually impenetrable .
In the other is an army of hackers who will try to break into a PitBull-protected system and win a $ 50,000 prize , supplied by Argus .
Hacking contests have been going on since the mid-1980s , but Argus has raised the stakes this time in an effort to validate a product it believes and many experts agree is the Fort Knox of computer security .
Hackers generally try to access computer operating systems by exploiting holes in the applications the systems run , and most security products try to plug those holes .
But PitBull protects the operating systems themselves , making it virtually impossible for a hacker to gain access .
In the contest , hackers will have two weeks to complete four tasks related to corrupting a website protected by PitBull .
There are prizes for being the first to complete each task , and a grand prize of $ 50,000 for being the first to complete all four .
Argus thought of giving a car away but realized from past hacking contests that participants are n't always old enough to drive .
In two previous eWeek contests involving other types of security , sites were successfully hacked .
In recent contests in Las Vegas and Munich , Germany , hackers failed to break into Argus-protected systems .
But hackers have always shown resilience in the face of attempts to defeat them .
Eric Lundquist , eWeek 's editor-in-chief , said no system is perfectly secure .
" I like that old rodeo saying : ' There 's never been a horse that can n't be rode , there 's never been a rider that can n't be throwed , ' " he said .
Most hacking competitions are lighthearted affairs , with hackers and security experts swapping tales and friendly advice .
But the contests have serious implications .
Big e-commerce companies like Yahoo and eBay have been hit by hackers , and some smaller companies are struggling to convince customers that their sites are safe places to make purchases .
Argus hopes the contest will prove the worth of its product .
But many in the computer security community think hacking competitions prove little because the cleverest , most dangerous hackers stay away or are reluctant to reveal their secrets a requirement to claim the prize .
" If you have the skills to break into a product that 's secure , are you going to announce it to the world , or are you going to keep those skills to yourself ? " said Jeff Moss , a hacker and security expert at Blackhat , a computer company based in Seattle .
Randy Sandone , the chief executive at Argus , acknowledges the test is imperfect .
" Even if we survive the two weeks without breaches , we 're not going to claim that our system is fundamentally impenetrable , " he said .
Nevertheless , the contest gives incentive to " some pretty serious people to give a good thrashing . "
the system




Lusting After a Landing on Eros

Take these ingredients :
A spinning rock about 21 miles in length and covered with small boulders and craters .
An automobile-sized craft that weighs 1,775 pounds .
No fuel .
A blindfold .
Johns Hopkins space jockeys .
A dash of adventure .
What do you have ?
Not the script to another bad space disaster movie , but an actual scientific endeavor that aims to land a vehicle on an asteroid .
" You got the picture .
We 're winging it , " said Dr. Robert Farquhar , NEAR Shoemaker mission director at Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory in Laurel , Maryland .
NEAR stands for Near Earth Asteroid Rendezvous .
Shoemaker is for the late Eugene " Super Gene " Shoemaker , a world-renowned geologist at the U.S. Geological Survey in Flagstaff , Arizona , and a close friend of Farquar .
The asteroid is named Asteroid 433 Eros , and the " rendezvous " originally meant to fly around the rock , take some pictures and then crash .
The mission was to last a year , then on Feb. 12 come to a rather abrupt end .
That mission has changed somewhat .
Now they 're actually trying to land the darn thing -- a challenge Farquhar says has about a 1 percent chance of success .
" It 'll end up on the surface one way or another , " Farquhar said . "
I like the description of landing on a moving aircraft carrier , if it 's spinning and the deck is coming up at you . "
Admittedly the landing is a piloting exercise for the John Hopkins University based team .
" This exercise in landing on small bodies like Eros is applicable .
I can see asteroids used as temporary quarters for traveling larger distances , " he said . "
We 'll slow the NEAR Shoemaker down and try the landing at about jogging speed . "
However , there is more to the landing than just derring-do .
" This is the first time we 've taken pictures this close of anything since the moon and a few small areas of Mars , " said Dr. Clark Chapman , a NEAR imaging team member and a geologist for the Southwest Research Institute in San Antonio , Texas .
The photos taken during the landing are expected to be 10 times better than those taken from orbit . "
We want to find out what it 's made of , " he said .
NEAR Shoemaker totes a range of scientific tools .
A magnetometer to check for magnetic materials like those found in meteorites .
An X-ray/Gamma-ray spectrometer for measuring silicon , magnesium , iron , uranium , thorium and potassium .
A near-infrared spectrometer to map the mineral composition of the surface by measuring the spectrum of sunlight reflected by the asteroid .
A multispectral camera and a laser rangefinder to measure the clog shoe-shaped EROS landforms and colors .
And the craft has performed experiments to evaluate the density of Eros .
" When we looked at the moon 's lunar surface we saw a few scattered boulders but mostly the moon was covered with small craters , but EROS is covered with small boulders and hills , he said .
" Asteroids are strange places from what little we know .
Eventually we will mine and take samples and deal with what they can tell us , " Dr. Chapman said . "
With this kind of imaging , it 's no different from taking a camera and going hiking , except we 're hiking into Wonderland .
We did n't know what to expect . "
The NEAR Shoemaker does n't have to land , but the activities of the space jockeys like Farquhar is all gravy , Chapman said .
The plans for landing were a surprise to many . "
I thought about doing this early on , but I did n't have the nerve to say anything , " Farquar said .
" He is mischievous and intriguing .
NASA is extremely risk-adverse ... and a bit straitlaced .
Farquhar is a breath of fresh air , " Chapman said .
Launched from Cape Canaveral Air Station in 1996 , NEAR 's arrival at Eros on Valentine 's Day of last year was no accident .
Eros is 1.3 astronomical units from the Sun , where Earth is 1 astronomical unit .
It is classified as a near-Earth asteroid , which means it travels within 121 million miles of the Sun .
Scientists theorize that these types of asteroids are from the main belt between Mars and Jupiter .
The NEAR Shoemaker adventure is not only about the adventurers who man our space programs , but about trying the impossible .
Farquhar , Chapman and the rest of the NEAR Shoemaker team engage in friendly competition with their NASA counterpart , the Jet Propulsion Laboratory .
But they all want the same thing .
Repeat after me : To boldly go ...




Big Four Back Down

Sixteen million dollars .
That 's the amount of money embattled Emusic.com expects to save this year after dumping 66 people , nearly 36 percent of its staff .
The company joins Listen.com -- two of the big four -- in the latest round of layoffs .
Only Napster and MP3.com have so far survived the extensive cutbacks , thanks in part to the major music labels .
But the story unfolding is n't necessarily one of doom and gloom , although the digital music sector is n't developing as everyone expected .
Both Emusic and Listen.com have enough money in the back to sustain themselves through next year , when they expect advertising revenues and sales to put them in the black .
With $ 16 million in the bank , EMusic is trying to bide its time while acquisition negotiations continue with two different companies , according to one analyst .
" We have taken today 's actions in order to withstand the combined effect of widespread illegal distribution of digital music and the significant market decline for Internet advertising , " stated Gene Hoffman , EMusic 's president and CEO in a written statement .
" In light of these challenges , we have reduced our expenses further with the objective of retaining sufficient cash to see us through to cash flow-positive operations . "
Listen.com reached a similar conclusion the week before , although the music directory company has a reported $ 60 million in the bank .
The two companies are trying to avoid the fate that befell Riffage.com , the online music label that did n't cut costs and barely missed securing the funding from major content companies that would have kept them in business .
So the power that tipped toward the technology industry , beginning in 1994 with the launch of the Internet Underground Music Archive , is now tipping back toward the music industry .
Napster has secured a deal with Bertelsmann that could leave the German media company owning up to 58 percent of the company -- maybe more if Napster burns through its entire $ 50 million loan .
MP3.com is reportedly being pursued by the giant as well .
Only Listen.com appears to be on its own these days .
Not exactly how the revolution was drawn up on the map .
---
Napster sell out:Let the buying begin .
That 's what the folks at Bertelsmann are hoping .
Napster community users can now purchase the music they downloaded from Napster by clicking on a link that takes them to CDNow .
The move comes as part of Napster 's continuing move to develop a service that the major music labels find an acceptable alternative to free file trading .
With record sales at an all-time high last year , the music industry continues to look for new ways to grow the sector without cannibalizing its CD sales .
By downloading the new beta version of the application , users have the ability to open a browser window that goes directly to CDNow.com .
This is the latest move from Napster to retain control of its company .
Bertelsmann gave the company $ 50 million to develop a secure version of its service in exchange for warrants giving it 58 percent of the company .
If Napster comes in under budget , the company could retain a majority stake .
---
No harm , no foul : Despite a rocky 2000 that saw the recording industry come under fire from the government for alleged price-fixing practices , bad marketing practices , and failure to move online , the two will come together to welcome George W. to office on January 18 .
PBS television show Austin City Limits will team up with the Recording Industry Association of America to put on a music show for the president-elect .
Other sponsors include Vivendi Universal , the Motion Picture Association of America , and Rock the Vote .




When in Rome , Travel Smart

ROME -- Italy ushered in a kinder , gentler era of public transportation last month with the introduction of smart-card technology to speed the fare collection process .
Thousands of smart cards have been issued to passengers in Rome and the surrounding Lazio regione since the program began on Dec. 28 .
Officials expect to have 350,000 cards in circulation by June and are hoping for 1 million users by the end of 2002 .
The card , developed jointly by Motorola and Australian technology company Erg , can be used on all of Rome 's 5,000 buses , its three light-rail lines and its 76 regional railway stations .
" With the introduction of the new system , we put the most advanced innovation at the disposal of the majority of Romans , " said Mario Di Carlo , president of the regional transit authority Atac .
And in the chaos that is Rome 's transit system , the need for simplicity is absolutely critical .
" I think that smart cards can really simplify public transport life in Rome , " said Francesca Lacroce , a student . "
Buses , trams and the subway are always so crowded , and you have to fight to stamp your ticket .
I think it is positive ... to have just one card to move in the city .
I hope the system will be working for every line and for everybody , and that we will n't need years to see this revolution . "
The Rome project is the largest of four contracts awarded to the Erg-Motorola alliance , which is also developing smart-card service for Berlin , San Francisco and Singapore .
The guts of the card is a microprocessor chip , which stores pertinent information , such as where and when the card was used .
Unlike most transit passes , which have to be replaced every month , a smart card is simply recharged by its owner at a sales outlet .
If the card is lost or stolen , it is easily replaced at one of Rome 's 19 help centers .
Probably the biggest benefit to passengers is ease of use .
The smart card only has to brush the machine in order to open the gate .
It 's no longer a case of feeding the card into a slot , right side up , while other passengers back up behind you .
Di Carlo says the card will eventually be available for non-transportation uses such as buying movie and museum tickets or paying a parking lot fee .
To support the card , the Roman system requires 9,700 validators , 4,000 sales outlets , 200 portable card readers , networked computers at depots and stations , a communications system , support services and maintenance .
The Erg-Motorola alliance , which continues to manage the project , holds everything together .
The companies will also be responsible for security , sales and data collection .
" The delivery schedule in Rome has been very short , and to implement such a large-scale system in 16 months is a great achievement , " said Peter Fogarty , Erg 's chief executive . "
We look forward to extending the system across other parts of Italy and in working with Atac to progressively extend and upgrade the public transport network in Rome and Lazio . "




Cache at the End of His Rainbow

Google 's search engine may be good for searches , but it 's useful in other ways , too .
Just ask Jake Savin , a San Francisco programmer who recently lost an entire website -- and three years ' hard work -- but found a copy of his entire site in Google 's online archive .
Savin had spent hundreds of hours working on his Weblog , a personal online journal documenting his life and interests .
Late last year , the hard drive on his laptop died .
No problem , because he had a backup on his server .
But two weeks later , his server 's drive also died .
He lost everything -- about 400 Web pages .
" It was upsetting , " he said with admirable understatement . "
I 'd put a lot of time and energy into it . "
But there was nothing he could do .
He chalked it up to experience .
Then late last week , Savin was searching for something on Google .
He followed a link to a page he was interested in , but got a " 404 error , " a common error message saying the requested Web page can n't be found .
Savin knew Google saved a copy of , or cached , all the Web pages in its index for just this kind of situation .
If a page someone is looking for is unavailable because a website is down or busy , it can instead be found in Google 's cache archive .
" That 's when the light bulb went off , " said Savin . "
I thought , wait a minute , they 've probably got my site . "
Although it had been six weeks since Savin lost his site , he found everything , all 400 pages , in Google 's cache .
" I 'm amazed they keep that much stuff around for that long , " Savin said . "
I was immediately elated but at the same time daunted by the amount of work it 's going to take to get it back into the database . "
Savin relocated everything except some pictures , which he intends to rescan .
" Google saved my ass ! " he wrote on his new Weblog .




Linux Plus Itanium Equals Whoosh

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Exploring big scientific mysteries requires big computing power .
Ed Seidel , researcher at the National Center for Supercomputing Applications and astrophysicist at the Max Planck Institute for Gravitational Physics , studies black holes and neutron stars in an attempt to understand the basic properties of space and time .
Seidel and the research team he works with use Linux and an open source program called Cactus they developed to aid them in their work .
And they are eagerly anticipating running those programs on one of the first supercomputers with Intel 's Itanium processor .
The National Center for Supercomputing Applications at University of Illinois at Champaign-Urbana announced on Tuesday that NCSA will install two IBM Linux clusters at NCSA , creating the world 's fastest Linux supercomputer in academia , and the fourth fastest supercomputer overall in the world .
NCSA
NCSA 's new clusters will have 2 teraflops of computing power and will be used by researchers to study some of the most fundamental questions of science , such as the nature of gravitational waves first predicted by Albert Einstein in his Theory of Relativity .
The fastest computer in the world is IBM 's ASCI White , with a computational capability of 12.3 teraflops .
capable of 12 trillion calculations per second
The ASCI White covers an area the size of two basketball courts and is used by the U.S. Department of Energy program to help ensure the safety and reliability of the nation 's nuclear weapons stockpile without real-world testing .
NCSA 's new supercomputer takes 4th place on the ASCI list of the world 's fastest computers , replacing the IBM ASCI Blue-Pacific , which runs at 1.2 Teraflops .
" We believe that Linux clusters will soon be the most widely used architecture for parallel computing , and that these two clusters from IBM are the best way to deliver terascale performance , " said Dan Reed , director of NCSA and the National Computational Science Alliance .
In June , Seidel , astrophysicist Wai-Mo Suen of Washington University in St. Louis , and their international research teams were given access to NCSA 's 256-processor Origin2000 .
By the time Suen and Seidel had finished their simulations , they had output nearly a terabyte of data and logged an astonishing 140,000 CPU-hours on the Origin2000 .
That 's equivalent to more than 16 years on a single-processor machine .
Suen credited the success of the June runs to " more than a dozen of us on both sides of the Atlantic cutting our daily allowance of sleep to less than five hours for two weeks . "
The runs were monitored nonstop in both Germany and the United States .
Whoever first noticed a problem took the initiative to kill , correct and restart the job .
" The explosion of the open source community , the maturity of clustering software , and the enthusiasm of the scientific community all tell us that Linux clusters are the future of high-performance computing , " Seidel said .
" It was very exciting we are limited by how much time we can get on such large machines .
but
I hope very much that NCSA will be able to continue to make such extraordinary high-end resources available in order to make this kind of science more routine , " Seidel added .
Harnessing the firepower of 600 IBM eServer xSeries servers , the new NCSA machine will process 2 trillion calculations per second .
It would take one person with a calculator more than 1.5 million years to tabulate the number of calculations that the new NCSA machine will handle in a single second .




A Major Day for Tech Earnings

The technology earnings season kicked into high gear Tuesday , led by a slightly better-than-expected quarterly report from Intel .
The Santa Clara , Calif. company , which has seen its stock beaten down in recent months following warnings of slower sales , reported earnings per share that came in a penny ahead of Wall Street estimates .
The firm is the first large chipmaker to report earnings for the quarter .
Following on the heels of Intel came mobile device developer Handspring and networking gearmaker Juniper Networks , both of which reported quarterly earnings ahead of analyst forecasts and saw their shares rise in after-hours trading .
Intel profits top forecasts : Intel provided meager relief for a jittery market when it reported quarterly profits that came in slighly ahead of analyst projections .
Intel 's fourth-quarter results just beat already lowered expectations as the world 's largest chipmaker suffered from flagging personal computer sales and forecast first quarter sales would fall about 15 percent from the fourth-quarter level .
Intel , which warned on Dec. 7 that fourth-quarter sales would not meet expectations , said that it had earnings excluding acquisition-related costs of $ 2.63 billion , or 38 cents a share , vs. $ 2.39 billion , or 34 cents a share .
INTC
On that basis , the results beat the consensus analyst forecast of 37 cents a share , as compiled by First Call/Thomson Financial .
Intel said its fourth-quarter sales rose 6 percent to $ 8.70 billion from $ 8.21 billion a year ago .
Investors hand it to Handspring : The mobile device maker reported quarterly earnings that came in ahead of analyst forecasts , and saw its shares get a boost in after-hours trading .
The Mountain View , Calif. company reported a net loss of $ 15.2 million , or 15 cents a share , in the three-month period ending Dec. 31 .
Analysts surveyed by First Call/Thomson Financial had expected the company to report a loss of 16 cents a share .
Revenue for the quarter came in at $ 115.6 million , an increase of 64 percent from the previous quarter and 600 percent from the same period last year .
Handspring attributed the rise in revenue to strong holiday season sales of its Visor line of handheld computers , expansion in Asia and growth in the number of U.S. retailers selling its products .
HAND
Following the release of the earnings report , shares of Handspring rose 4 percent to $ 46.50 in after-hours trading .
Juniper sales on the rise : Juniper Networks reported fourth-quarter earnings ahead of Wall Street forecasts as sales of its networking equipment jumped 47 percent from the previous quarter .
On Tuesday , the Sunnyvale , Calif. company reported pro forma earnings of $ 84.6 million , or 24 cents per share , compared with $ 3.1 million , or 2 cents per diluted share a year ago .
The numbers came in well ahead of forecasts from analysts , who had been predicting Juniper would report operating earnings of 18 cents per share , according to First Call/Thomson Financial .
JNPR
On a net basis , including amortization expenses , earnings were $ 62.2 million or 18 cents a share .
Shares of Juniper rose 2 percent to $ 130.38 in after-hours trading .




From Rejection to E-Lation

Whats right with Dorfman ?
The prestigious literary zine , January Magazine , recently chose What 's Wrong with Dorfman ? , by John Blumenthal , as one of the 50 best books of 2000 .
So , what 's so noteworthy about that ?
Well , it represents something of a milestone since the novel was self-published and only available for purchase online .
Blumenthal , whose credits include the screenplay Blue Streak and Ballantine Books Hollywood High : The History of America 's Most Famous Public School , kept the fact that Dorfman was self published secret because hed been warned the book would not get reviewed by the mainstream press if it was known .
Originally , Blumenthal and his agent hoped to get a traditional deal but the novel was rejected by over 30 publishers despite rave rejections .
" Hilarious , " said one New York house .
" Great characters , terrific plot .
Sorry , but we have to reject it , " said another .
It was the praise in these letters that convinced Blumenthal to proceed on his own .
Having had five books published by mainstream houses and knowing how much marketing issues play in deciding which books go to contract , Blumenthal chose to go it alone with his new novel .
" I figured I could n't possibly do worse than they do , " Blumenthal said . "
Publishing is an odd business -- Ive seen it first-hand .
Sometimes it almost seems like they are deliberately trying to not make money . "
Saying that he would not have self-published the book without the Net , Bluemthal praised the ease of selling via online bookstores and credited the people hes met in different listserves at Egroups.com in helping get out the word on Dorfman .
" People have been going out of their way to help this book be a success , " said Blumenthal , who has sold over 2000 copies in the past few months .
January 's editor , Linda Richards , was surprised to learn that Dorfman is self-published , but she was not astonished .
" Self-published should n't be either an accolade or a put-down .
It 's just what it is -- another book that has as much potential to transport you as books published in other ways , " Richards said . "
It 's the ideas that count . "
Richards recollects that she cried when she finished Losing Julia , was awed at the intricacy of The Blind Assassin and that What 's Wrong With Dorfman made her laugh out loud . "
Those are the things that are important to us at January , not the logo on the spine . "
Leonard writes but does n't e-read : Adding his name to the growing list of best-selling authors bypassing traditional publishers , Elmore Leonard will release Fire in the Hole as an e-book on Wednesday .
The 50-page novella will be published by Contentville and available at that site for $ 7 .
The book features U.S. Marshal Raylan Givens , the character who appeared in Leonards Pronto and its sequel , Riding the Rap .
" I do n't feel that writing an e-book is at all different than writing a story for publication , apart from the fact that I will n't be able to read it -- at least not in my home -- since I do n't own a computer , " Leonard said in a statement .
So who will read it ?
Katharine Weber , who teaches fiction writing at Yale University , is a fan of Leonard but wonders if $ 7 is n't too steep for 50 pages .
" I suppose I am one of those people who think of ' electronic text ' and ' free ' as synonyms , " said Weber , who wrote The Music Lesson .
Weber is n't alone , as the e-book continues to be a product in search of building a consumer base .
But the trend of authors bypassing publishers shows no sign of abating .
" In effect , name-brand authors are already their own publishers , " wrote Jason Epstein , formerly of Random House , in Book Business . "
While their nominal publishers are a vestigial , nonessential convenience , beneficiaries of inertia on the part of agents reluctant to forgo the security of a publisher 's guarantee . "
or victims
Plucked off the Net : It began as a self-published e-book , but this January , The Sharp Edge of Love , by Galen , will be released as an alternate selection of The Venus Book Club , a division of Book Span .
This is only the second time a major book club has plucked a self-published novel off the Net .
Without attempting to get a traditional deal first , Galen released the e-book in January 2000 and a print-on-demand version in July .
With the taboo nature of the erotic book , Galen believed he had a better chance launching it himself .
" I thought I would be in a stronger position to negotiate with a publisher after I could show them a sales track record and strong reviews , " he said .
Over the last few months , The Sharp Edge of Love has gotten serious online buzz and been reviewed by a number of influential critics and publications .
Nevertheless , Galen was flabbergasted when the Venus Book Club contacted him .
In addition to promoting the book on the back cover of the catalog , Venus is also running an author interview to go along with the listing . "
I felt validated that my point of view and writing talent met their standards , " Galen said .
Erika Tsang , editor at The Doubleday Book Club and The Venus Book Club , said she first became aware of the book from a review on noted sexpert Susie Bright 's website .
E-pubs in London : For two days preceding the prestigious London Book Fair , there will be an electronic publishing conference on March 22-23 .
Topics covered will range from e-publishing options for publishers to consumer e-publishing trends , understanding the e-tailer 's perspective , legal issues and fighting e-book piracy .
" The launch of ePubLondon adds an exciting dimension to the London Book Fair , " LBF Director Helen Shiers said . "
Aligned with such a major international publishing event , a forum of this kind provides an unrivaled opportunity for our customers to explore emerging business models and meet new publishing partners .
" By focusing on a case study approach with live demonstrations during breaks , the emphasis will be on real solutions and practical examples . "
M.J. Rose is the author of a new novel and a non-fiction book about e-publishing .




Calling Out for Quake Victims

SAN FRANCISCO -- As soon as she heard that El Salvador had been rocked by a 7.6-magnitude quake , Luisa Monge called the parish priest in La Libertad , a coastal town near the epicenter .
Monge , a labor union secretary in San Francisco , was desperate to communicate with her family , and she knew the priest had a cell phone .
" He is my only link , " said Monge , who learned her family was safe , but that their house had been destroyed along with 90 percent of the village . "
I 've been calling him every day for updates . "
Monge is one of thousands of Salvadoran immigrants who 've used cell phones and e-mail to contact loved ones after Saturday 's quake killed more than 600 people and left nearly 45,000 homeless .
Fixed-line phones are n't working in many parts of the country -- either because they were physically destroyed in the quake or because calls from anxious relatives have overloaded the system .
More modern communication methods have become lifelines .
One man who was trapped under the rubble has his cell phone to thank for saving his life , according to one media account .
The man was able to direct rescuers to his location using his mobile phone .
" It 's almost impossible to communicate by phone , " said Rhina M. Ramos , a grassroots coordinator for the SHARE Foundation , a nonprofit that is organizing relief efforts in San Francisco . "
fixed-line
The phone is down at our office there and our only communication has been by e-mail . "
Jos Santiago said that he consistently got a busy signal when he tried to call the government office in his hometown of Nueva San Salvador , a suburb of the capital city .
He was finally able to get a hold of the mayor 's cell phone number and ask him how things were going .
" He said the biggest problem they were having was putting the pieces of bodies back together so relatives could identify them , " Santiago , a social worker , said . "
He also said that they desperately needed money to buy clean water , food , tents , medicine and other provisions for the survivors . "




Cybersecurity Goes Cooperative

WASHINGTON -- Nineteen leading tech firms have created an information-sharing conglomerate aimed at countering the growing number of electronic attacks on U.S. companies .
The information technology sector on Tuesday became the third area of the economy to create its own " Information Sharing and Analysis Center " .
ISAC
This follows in the footsteps of similar centers for financial services and telecommunications that were created in the last few years .
The Information Technology Association of America will serve as the coordinator for the new body , whose founding members include AT&T , Cisco Systems , Hewlett Packard , IBM , and Intel .
ITAA
" These are the companies that make America work .
Without these companies , the economy would not work , " Richard Clark , national coordinator for infrastructure protection at the National Security Council , said at a Washington press conference .
The Clinton administration in May 1998 laid out its plans for critical infrastructure protection in Presidential Directive 63 .
" The IT-ISAC will enable the high-tech industry to take the lead in spotting potential threats to the Internet and information structures more quickly , sharing state-of-the-art Internet and information infrastructure security measures , and responding in a more coordinated way when incidents occur , " Commerce secretary Norman Mineta said .
Mineta designation as Transportation secretary-designate coincides with an ITAA statement that the transportation sector plans to meet in early February to discuss plans for their own ISAC .
The information-technology ISAC , which will be headquartered in Atlanta , was created to " report and exchange information among its industry members concerning electronic incidents , threats , attacks , vulnerabilities , solutions and countermeasures , best security practices and other protective measures , " according to a mission statement .
" Almost everything that we use today , from the water we drink to the power that we use , is carried by the networks of these companies here today in some way , " said Gregory Akers , vice president of IT for customer advocacy at Cisco .
The possibility of antitrust issues was dismissed by ISAC representatives , who said the organization was purely voluntary , openly encourages increased participation , and is doing nothing illegal .
Other members include Microsoft , IBM , and Oracle .
" We share common customers , but that 's not all we share , " said Mary Ann Davidson , director of security product management at Oracle . "
Every one of us here has or will be attacked via the Internet . "
The group 's creation comes on the heels of a new government-sponsored joint public-private sector critical infrastructure protection program called InfraGard , which aims at similar collaboration , but between government agencies and the private sector .
Members of the IT-ISAC say their organization is not the same thing .
" InfraGard and the National Infrastructure Protection Center address investigative , real-time enforcement issues , " said Ross Pinkus , vice president of business development and government relations at Computer Associates , an IT-ISAC member .
FBI 's
" We 're not an investigative body , we 're trying to share information among companies so as to help organizations like the NIPC and InfraGard do a better job , " Pinkus said .
The protocol for admitting foreign companies has yet to be decided by members of the IT-ISAC .
Because it is not a government organization , such protocol would be decided within the ISAC , said the NSC 's Clark .
He said that since companies and governments have been sharing information with one another for years , foreign corporations being admitted into the IT-ISAC " would hardly be breaking new ground anyway . "
The Bush Administration did not immediately return phone calls for comment , but " all the indications that we 've seen show that will continue to be a priority in the new administration , " said Howard Schmidt , Microsoft 's top security executive .
this info-sharing concept
" This is done regardless of party or corporate logo , " Schmidt said .

Of Mice and Men
Gene Altered

CANBERRA , Australia -- Australian scientists developing a biological contraceptive to halt mouse and rat plagues have unearthed a deadly new gene with profound implications for biological warfare .
Researchers made the discovery at the Cooperative Research Centre for the Biological Control of Pest Animals Canberra .
CRC
CRC scientists are experimenting with viruses to deliver an antigen to animals such as rodents , rabbits and foxes , all considered pests by the agricultural industry .
An antigen provokes the formation of an antibody when introduced into another organism .
In this particular experiment , scientists modified a mousepox virus to include the gene for a substance called interleukin-4 , which affects the immune system .
The aim was to boost the level of the animal 's immune response to block reproduction , a process known as immuno-contraception .
Ultimately , the goal was to suppress the plagues of mice and rats , which spread human diseases and destroy billions of dollars worth of grain .
Mouse plagues occur in Australia 's grain growing regions on average every three years , causing massive disruption to communities and losses to farmers .
Mouse plagues are increasing in frequency due to changes in farming practices .
The country 's Grains Research and Development Corporation estimates that between 100,000 and 500,000 hectares of grain crops are affected each year .
A plague in South Australia and Victoria in 1993 is estimated to have cost at least A$55 million in grain losses .
US$ 30.5 million
Scientists found that by introducing the extra gene , they suppressed part of the mouse 's immune system that deals with viruses -- the cell-mediated response .
As a result , lab mice normally resistant to the virus died .
Furthermore , the gene diminished the efficacy of vaccines used to protect mice by about half .
Mousepox virus does not infect humans or pose any threat to them , but the scientists are concerned that in the wrong hands , the technique could be used to strengthen biological weapons based on viruses that do affect humans .
They are calling for the global Biological Weapons Convention to be strengthened as a result of the discovery .
Formally known as the Biological and Toxin Weapons Convention , the agreement prohibits the development , production and stockpiling of biological and toxin weapons .
It entered into force in 1975 and has been signed by 162 countries .
" The concern is not so much about the modified mousepox virus , but about the implications of this research , said Dr. Annabelle Duncan , of the Commonwealth Scientific Industrial Research Organization .
CSIRO
Duncan is chief of CSIRO Molecular Science and former deputy head of a United Nations team that investigated the development of biowarfare agents in Iraq following the Gulf War .
" Could a similar experiment be conducted on a human disease-causing organism with similar results ?
If so , could this be exploited by an unscrupulous nation or a bioterrorist to develop biological weapons ?
" The answer to the first question is that we simply do not know .
There is no way of extrapolating from these results to another virus and another host animal .
All we can say is that it is theoretically possible .
" The important thing is to ensure they are used for good -- not for destructive purposes .
That is why we urge awareness and vigilance . "
CRC director Dr Bob Seamark stressed the experiments were undertaken with " completely humanitarian motives . "
" Our aim is to counter the enormous damage and human suffering which rodents cause by devouring a major part of the global grain harvest , especially in developing countries and in Australia , " said Seamark .
" In the course of science you sometimes make unexpected discoveries -- penicillin is one example .
" In this case , we 've found that certain changes to a mouse virus can render it more lethal and harder to immunize against .
" The best protection against any misuse of this technique was to issue a worldwide warning .
We also want researchers to use this new knowledge to help design better vaccines . "
A report on the discovery will be published in the Journal of Virology 's February issue .
For full text and graphics , visit : ENS .




And God Said : Let There Be Net

For thine is the kingdom , the power , and the glory of the Internet forever , Amen .
In the fast-paced digital age , some believers believe a basic church Web page is no longer enough .
That 's why the Fellowship Church in Grapevine , Texas , is changing its name to fellowshipchurch.com .
The church , one of the largest in the country , will launch a new website in February to mark the transition .
" We need to market the life-changing message of Jesus Christ to the world , " said Preston Mitchell , pastor of spiritual development for fellowshipchurch.com . "
God created the Internet -- he is the one who gave us the ability as human beings to do that .
We have a responsibility to use what God 's created to reach people . "
Not surprisingly , the site has raised the eyebrows of several pastors around the country .
When the site is unveiled on Feb. 15 , visitors will see " something along the lines of MSN or Yahoo , " including sports scores , stock quotes , weather , maps -- in addition to daily Bible devotionals and church news , Mitchell said .
There will also be an e-commerce portion to the website , where users can purchase religious books , transcripts of sermons , or pay the requisite fee to play on the church volleyball team .
" Anywhere the name is printed we 're going to add .com to the name , " Mitchell said , including the roof of the church .
Mitchell , who is one of six pastors on the church 's " management team , " explained that the church 's name is displayed on the roof because they are located in the flight pattern of the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport .
The 10-year-old contemporary Christian church is a member of the Southern Baptist Convention .
In its 10-year life , fellowshipchurch.com has grown from 150 to 13,000 regular attendees .
The church holds three services on the weekends , one on Saturday and two on Sunday .
News of the dot-com church did not shock one pastor .
" Number one : This was bound to happen .
Number two : This was bound to happen in Dallas , " said Bill Leonard , dean of Wake Forest University Divinity School , professor of church history and a native Texan himself . "
I would have bet half the ranch on that . "
" Dallas is a kind of case-study in religious communities that are constantly forming and re-forming in response to religious and cultural influences , " he said .
Megachurches , which sprout up and boast thousands of members , are well known for using blatant marketing techniques to attract the unchurched , he said .
" The method always impacts the message in spite of what the faithful may believe , " Leonard said .
" I see dangers in that , " he added .
For example , the local community and church traditions can become less relevant with the technology .
Another pastor , who preferred to remain anonymous , wondered if the church was focusing more on increasing its membership numbers than on the personal needs of its congregation .
" I hate the use of business terminology in the church because I think it sends the wrong message , " he said . "
Too often , using business terms people not as persons but as numbers or entities . "
