Gazoontite : Going , Going , Gone

SAN FRANCISCO -- From a distance , the trendy office suite , with its loft-style floor plan and bare brick walls , might have looked like the headquarters of any bustling new economy business .
Rows of neat workstations .
Bright , new Pentium computers .
Natural light filtering in through large-paned windows .
Upon closer inspection , the only thing to mar that tranquil picture was the fact that everything -- from the 19-inch monitors , to the tall , wooden book shelf , to the office TV set -- was neatly tagged for sale .
That , and the bellowing tones of an auctioneer echoing down from above .
" Everything sold today is sold as is , where is , " cautioned Adam Alexander , in rapid-fire auctioneer-speak from the second floor of the office suite .
Slumped in chairs and standing in the aisles before him were some 400-plus bargain hunters .
The sale would continue for the next seven hours or so , until all the remains of Gazoontite.com -- which sold health supplies for asthma and allergy sufferers -- were sold off to the highest bidder .
Swanky San Francisco offices aside , this auction was no new economy shindig .
This was the old economy , where people showed up in person to buy real products for cash and then lugged them home .
No one was buying any domain names here .
Just a PC and an extension cord , please .
As asset auctions go , the spoils at Gazoontite were nothing to sneeze at .
Pardon the cheesy pun .
These things happen when you name a company Gazoontite.com .
There were about 700 items in all , ranging from the obscure -- a Euroclean vacuum and a power drill -- to the mundane -- enough office chairs to seat a small army .
That 's not to mention the computers : Dell Dimension Pentium IIIs , Toshiba laptops , IBM Thinkpads and even a couple of Mac G4s .
And of course , there were monitors galore .
Overall , it was a mid-sized auction for a failed dot-com , said Don Cowan , partner at Cowan Alexander Equipment Group , the company that arranged the sale .
Cowan , who has arranged about 40 dot-com auctions in the last year , said it 's not unusual to see companies pull the plug just shortly after making massive purchases of computer equipment and office furniture .
" They spent their funds in anticipation of growth , " he said .
When that growth does n't happen , investors and creditors turn to auctioneers to get a return on their money .
Over the next three months , Cowan 's firm plans to arrange another four or five dot-com auctions .
The companies doing the sales either shut down or decided to scale back their businesses and sell off unneeded equipment as prospects for new investment dry up .
Gazoontite was in many ways a typical casualty of the dot-com massacre of 2000 .
The company raised close to $ 30 million in funding from a high-profile , line-up of venture capitalists in late 1999 .
Over the next few months , it used the money to build its website and opened four brick-and-mortar stores that sold health supplies .




TV Pirates Rule Spain 's Airwaves

MADRID , Spain -- Canal Satelite Digital , Spain 's leading satellite TV provider , fired targeted electronic impulses last weekend that disabled thousands of pirated decoder cards and froze systems all over the country .
News of the attacks spread like wildfire over cracker websites , and within hours cracked codes were whizzing through modems and onto the fried cards , giving them new life .
Anyone with a little computer savvy and a couple of pieces of $ 20 hardware was back to regularly scheduled programming .
So much for CSD 's big counter-offensive .
" It does n't take long now , hours , maybe a day at the most , " said a cracker called AAS .
to fend off the attacks
AAS is a self-described " experimenter " with satellite TV who until recently ran the most popular " educational " Spanish website about breaking satellite TV codes .
AAS no longer disseminates decoding software because , he says , it 's become too much of a business .
" When there were new attacks -- about once a month -- we got about 60,000 users on the site in a day , " he said . "
It has turned into a mafia with nothing to do with experimentation ; a few do the work and a lot take advantage . "
Last November , police busted a ring of illegal card traffickers in Barcelona , nabbing over 10,000 illegal cards .
And while exact numbers are hard to come by , AAS thinks there could be up to 500,000 cards on the market .
That 's just the hardware .
The lost revenue for all of Europe 's satellite providers was estimated to be around $ 180 million in 1999 , according to a study done by Europe 's anti piracy association , the Association Europeene pour la Protection des Ouvres et Services Cryptes .
AEPOC
This figure reflects its estimates that between 10 and 20 percent of Europe 's 35 million satellite subscribers were pirating .
" We have no idea how many people are viewing our services without paying , " said Soledad Alvarez Coto , spokeswoman for CSD , which began service to Spain in 1997 and has wired over a million homes .
Actually , most pirates are paying at least something .
To hack the premium services one has to pay about $ 35 per month for the basic service , which offers less than basic cable in the United States .
The premium services , however , are where the providers hope to make money .
" The losses are probably bigger than the official market , " said John Strand , the CEO of Strand Consult , which analyzes media sales and marketing processes .
It 's a Catch-22 .
High prices increase piracy , and piracy increases prices .
CSD recently upped the cost of its basic service by a third , which caused further uproar and inspired hackers .
Emili Prado , professor of audiovisual communications at the Autonomous University of Barcelona and director of Euromonitor , cites other reasons for the steep costs .
According to Prado , there 's not a developed habit for pay-per-view ; the economies of scale are n't sufficient to support the cost of programming ; there 's a heavy dependence on American products ; and there are few locally produced products .
The high cost of programming makes the providers reluctant to utilize better , more expensive methods of encryption .
" They 're already selling basic subscriptions at a loss , and more robust encryption would push the price even higher , " Strand said . "
The real money comes from premium , pay-per-view services such as soccer . "
However , there is some debate about the profitability of soccer .
In Spain , soccer was expected to be the killer app .
But according to Alvarez , the soccer clubs keep hiking their prices .
This has further eroded the profit margin and limited the appeal among consumers so much that CSD has pushed back its break-even date to later this year , instead of at the end of 2000 .
This , along with the basic service hike , has led to rumors among hackers and crackers that satellite providers are encouraging a certain amount of pirating to boost basic service subscribers .
This is a charge that providers firmly deny .
According to Alvarez , CSD is always taking measures to confound cracking , but the crackers remain unimpressed .
" The attacks they 've done to date are n't effective , " AAS said . "
There 's talk of them replacing the decoding box and changing the system of encryption , but those are just rumors . "
While the hackers seem to have no lack of will , Europe 's politicians do n't seem to have the stomach to enact tougher anti-piracy laws .
To be prosecuted for pirating TV in Spain , the police have to actually find an illegal card , in use or en masse .
" There are no votes in fighting cheap TV , " says Strand . "
You would be making things better for the company and not the end user . "
Despite the absence of tough laws , there is a growing ennui among crackers , many of whom are convinced they 've won the now repetitive game against CSD .
They are starting to turn their skills against CSD 's competitor , VIA Digital , which claims to have never been hacked .
owned by Telefonica
" VIA has more advanced encryption technology , and that 's more interesting , " says a cracker who did n't want his nickname used . "
Everyone has CSD . "




Long Day 's Journey Into Tights

EverQuest may be the most successful online game so far , drawing 300,000 players , 70,000 of whom are logged into the fantasy world at any time .
Although I 've learned a lot about people during my countless hours on EQ , fighting in dungeons or making clothes from animal skins , I received a most valuable lesson when I decided to walk a few virtual miles in slightly smaller shoes .
In the eight months since I began playing EverQuest , all of my characters have been males .
Although EQ 's wizards , gnomes , ogres , and trolls have different capabilities for intelligence and strength , gender does n't seem to affect player skills : Men and women of each race are more or less equal .
So until recently I had never felt the urge to have an online sex change .
Changing your gender when you enter the EQ realm is n't all that unique .
Experience had taught me that at least half of the female characters are actually males , and a lot of women take on male personas so the men do n't harass them .
I can usually tell the real-life gender of a player by their behavior : things like choice of words , attitude and other behaviors usually give them away after 20 seconds or so of interaction .
Still , I 'd noticed people just plain react differently to female characters , even if they do n't know who 's on the other end .
So after several months of playing a male High Elf Mage , I decided to see how the other half lives , and created a female Wood Elf Bard .
The female Wood Elf is easily the prettiest of female races in the game , and sans armor , the character is half-naked .
I was quickly reminded that Wood Elves attract a lot of attention .
Some time back , I escorted an unarmored female Wood Elf , played by a male , into unknown territory .
We stopped to chat with a trio of Dwarf characters , and all three players whistled at " her . "
I asked the guy using the female character how he felt , and well , he did n't like it .
Hopefully he 'll remember that in real life .
In creating the Wood Elf Bard , whose magic comes from songs , I got to experience first hand just how popular a woman -- especially an attractive one -- is in EverQuest .
The contrast in peoples ' response to me as a female instead of a male character was nothing short of remarkable .
First , whenever I was in a fight with one of the EQ monsters , other players who were observing would always offer their assistance if needed .
This almost never happened with my male character .
More than once the Mage would be in big trouble and I 'd be screaming at people nearby to help , and they just stood there and watched me die .
Not so as the curvaceous Bard .
In a few cases , I had three or four men offering their assistance as reinforcements .




Library of Congress Goes Digital

The Library of Congress has finally met its ambitious goal of putting 5 million historical items online by the year 2000 .
That 's no small feat considering the Internet was n't even around when the project began .
But even as the library completed this monumental task last week , some said its digital strategy still lags .
In addition , the project underscores the longstanding concern over whether the library should be geared more toward scholarly pursuits than mainstream interests .
The American Memory Project , which began as a pilot project to put images on CD-ROMs , has been woven into one of the largest digitized records of American history , with 90 collections of manuscripts , books , maps , films , sound recordings and photographs online .
Although the library has made great strides in meeting its five-year goal , 5 million represents a mere fraction of the more than 120 million items in its inventory .
That number represents an even smaller slice of the vast amount of digital material being created and published on the Web every day .
A report last summer by the National Research Council found that the library has made very slow progress in acquiring , preserving , cataloging and accessing digital material .
The fear is that the library continues to focus on archiving traditional print media instead of dealing with the proliferation of digital information .
" If the Library of Congress fails to make significant progress , it is in danger of becoming a book museum that houses a collection of priceless materials , " said James O'Donnell , vice provost for information systems and computing at the University of Pennsylvania and chairman of the committee that produced the report .
While American Memory has been a success , it is only a small step toward developing a larger digital strategy .
" American Memory was an excellent pilot for the library to undertake to learn how to digitize , " O'Donnell said . "
But it felt to us more like a demonstration project . "
Part of the problem is that the library 's role in the information age is unclear .
As a creation of Congress , the library 's mission is to serve both Congress and the public by building and maintaining comprehensive collections of historical and cultural records .
But while the library has focused on putting its historical collections online , it has neglected the growing number of electronic books , websites , electronic journals and other forms of electronic information that need to be stored .
So far , the library has n't developed a broad digital strategy and lacks the capacity necessary for accomplishing this arduous task .
" The Library of Congress is not a national library and it 's not at all clear that their mission is or should be to be the library for everybody , " O'Donnell said .
" Taking existing books and digitizing them is a small issue for the Library of Congress , " O'Donnell said . "
The real challenge is to collect and make available the stuff being published by the mass of publications and individuals . "
Instead of digitizing books or cataloging websites , the library has focused on putting its historical multimedia collections of original documents , photographs , video and audio recordings online .
" We have n't really concentrated on putting books online , " said Guy Lamolinara , spokesman for the Library of Congress . "
Our focus has been on unique and unusual items you would n't find in other libraries . "
Deciding what items to include in the American Memory Project was no easy task .
The project enlisted the help of a team of educators , librarians and historians to help with the selection .
Experts focused on items that were rare or unique , of educational and cultural value , and easily formatted for the Internet .
Copyright was another key consideration .
" Virtually everything on our site is not copyrighted or was once copyrighted and is now in the public domain , " Lamolinara said . "
Our focus is on historical collections . "
While most of the selected items were copyright-free , directors had to gain permission to digitize some copyrighted material .
" We were to some extent limited in what we could take , " said Marvin Kranz , an American history specialist who worked on the presidential inauguration collection .
Private donors also helped decide which items would get digitized first by funding individual projects from a list of curator-selected items .
AT&T funded the Alexander Graham Bell collection .
Reuters contributed $ 1 million to put the Washington and Jefferson presidential papers online .
" They saw it as a great way to jump-start the project online , " Lamolinara said .
But critics said that some items were overlooked in the project 's attempts to appeal to the mass public .




Privacy Battle Brews in England

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Clean up your hard drive and mind your manners if you live in or are traveling to the United Kingdom .
Police there may soon be able to copy and store the contents of computers , collect and warehouse samples of human DNA and fine people for misdemeanors without having to arrest them first .
The new Criminal Justice and Police Bill , which began what is expected to be its long journey through British legal and political channels on Friday , is being promoted as a defense against " yob culture . "
Yob is a British slang term for punks or hooligans , and the bill gives police extended powers to deal harshly with the drunk and disorderly .
But the bill covers more than quality-of-life crimes .
It also allows the police to expand their DNA database by permitting all legally acquired DNA samples to be stored indefinitely -- even if those samples belong to people who were later acquitted or not even charged with a crime .
Section 49 of the bill gives British police officers and customs guards the power to copy the disk of any computer device found during a legal search in order to be able to carefully examine the contents at a later time .
" They have to have a reasonable basis that the disk contains something relevant to what they are searching for , but it would seem to give them carte blanche to seize computers since it would almost always be reasonable to assume that a computer in a premises would or could contain information relevant to the search , " said Edward Hayes , a Manhattan attorney .
the bill
Hayes also pointed out that under the new bill , importing pornography would be considered , in the bill 's wording , a " serious arrestable offence , " and so any suspicion that porn lurks on a computer could provide a reason for a search of that computer by customs officers .
" The answer to whether they would take advantage of that to routinely copy the contents of computers would depend on your personal level of paranoia , " said Hayes . "
At this point in time I have no reason to think that they would or would n't . "
British customs guards have been checking the contents of travelers ' computers since the late '90s , an HM Customs and Excise spokesperson acknowledged , but until now they have n't been able to do more than a fast scan of the contents .
Her Majesty 's
" These checks were and continue to be performed in an effort to keep pornography out of England .
And suitcases and computers are the same to us , " the spokesperson said
" Travelers must be prepared and willing to have the contents of whatever they are bringing into our country checked . "
He declined to say what software was used for the scans , and said there were no current plans to make copies of the contents of hard drives .
" We will see what happens with the Police Bill .
Currently we are simply allowed to check hard drives for pornography .
Our current law does not entitle us or the police to seize material from one place in order to examine it elsewhere . "
" But since we are looking for pornography , not product plans or personal banking information , normal people should n't worry . "
Some corporate travelers , who are sensitive about the privileged company information stored on their computers , are still concerned about the new regulations , as are some journalists , who may have an odd assortment of research on their hard drives .
" A quick look through my files would shows information on hackers , viruses , antigovernment protests , espionage and drugs , " said Jeff Leydon , a Los Angeles freelance writer who contributes to computer and underground culture magazines , and often travels on assignment .




Bush Blocks Enviro Orders

President George W. Bush , less than 90 minutes after he took the oath of office on Saturday , ordered his chief of staff , Andrew Card , to distribute a memorandum directing the department heads to hold off on publishing any new or pending regulations in the Federal Register .
This act -- one of his first as the nation 's 43rd president -- effectively blocks a spate of Clinton 's executive orders intended , among other things , to create a number of new national monuments .
Clinton issued a flurry of environment-related executive orders during his final weeks in office , such as a measure designed to limit water pollution generated by factory farms .
Since the orders can not take effect until they have appeared in the Federal Register for a certain amount of time , however , the memo may mean those orders are never implemented .
The memo also directs the department heads to " temporarily postpone the effective date " of all regulations that have been published in the Federal Register , but which have not yet taken effect .
That provision , which will stretch over a period of 60 days , renders moot a host of environment-related measures , such as a recently unveiled U.S. Environmental Protection Agency rule that mandates a 95 percent reduction in harmful diesel emissions by 2006 .
Moreover , the memo calls on the nation 's independent regulatory agencies to " voluntarily " suspend all new and pending rule-making efforts until they can be reviewed by the Bush administration .
The memo declares that such a suspension would advance " the interest of sound regulatory practice , " and would help to stave off the onset of " costly , burdensome , or unnecessary " regulation .
The memo sets in motion the Bush administration 's long-held pledge to conduct a " vigorous review " of the myriad executive orders and other non-legislative federal regulations that were promulgated in the final weeks -- and even hours -- of the Clinton administration .
Four weeks before the November election , for example , the Clinton administration was placing an average of 210 pages of regulations per day in the Federal Register , one of the highest rates ever recorded .
A number of Republican lawmakers on Capitol Hill had been sharply critical of the Clinton administration 's regulatory actions , especially those that were put forth by agencies such as the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency .
EPA
Oklahoma Senator Jim Inhofe decried the Clinton administration EPA for trying to " cram through scores of rules and other regulatory decisions without proper disclosure , " a practice that Inhofe called " irresponsible and wrong . "
Other Congressional Republicans went further , vowing to roll back many of the environmental protections initiated by the Clinton administration .
Utah Congressman Jim Hansen has promised to undo the National Monuments that Clinton designated across several Western states , and to return the public lands to their former management status .
Hansen , the new chairman of the House Resource committee , last week announced that his Congressional panel will scrutinize the rules and regulations implemented by the Clinton administration " that may have violated federal law " or " circumvented established procedures . "
The directive put forth by President Bush on Saturday only elicited more apprehension among conservation advocacy groups , many of which have long feared that the former Texas governor will enact policies disastrous for the nation 's environment .
Frank O'Donnell , executive director of the Washington-based Clean Air Trust , worried that Bush 's memo was the first step toward undoing the EPA 's newly enacted diesel emissions rule .
" Given the massive health benefits of the diesel cleanup , it would be a terrible blunder for the new administration to weaken or delay these new standards , " O'Donnell said .
The EPA 's new diesel rule , which falls within procedural parameters of the regulatory suspension put forth by Bush on Saturday , would prevent some 8,300 premature deaths each year , according to EPA scientists .
The rule , by lowering emissions from heavy duty trucks and buses , would also stave off the onset of more than 20,000 cases of bronchitis and 360,000 asthma attacks annually , EPA scientists claim .
Those factors may or may not exempt the EPA 's diesel emissions measure from the reach of the Bush administration 's new regulatory suspension , which exempts any rules pertaining to " emergency or other urgent situations relating to health and safety . "
One EPA official , requesting anonymity , told ENS that the agency is " trying to figure out " which regulatory actions might be subject to the memo , and which measures might be exempted .
" We have not made any final decisions on a lot of pending regulations , and whether they 're subject to this or not .
At this point , nobody can say which rules might be pulled back , " the official said .
The White House could not be reached for comment on the Bush administration 's new regulatory review plan as of late Monday .
For full text and graphics visit : ENS .

Linux Lovers Launch Large Lab

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
The industry 's first independent , nonprofit lab for developers who are adding business-oriented capabilities to Linux and Linux-based software opens for business Wednesday .
Backed by the support of 19 sponsor companies and more than $ 24 million in funding , the Open Source Development Lab is an 11,000-square-foot computing center located in Beaverton , Oregon , a high-tech district west of Portland .
It will provide Linux and open-source developers with access to high-end enterprise hardware and an open forum where they can build and test software for powerful servers and business computing environments .
The lab will be managed by an independent board and officers , as well as a full-time director and staff .
Ross Mauri , vice president of eServer development at IBM , was chosen to serve as president of the OSDL , and will oversee the board and its directors .
The first projects to take advantage of the lab will include a scalability project designed to enhance the Linux operating system to support 16 64-bit processors .
The second project is being conducted by Jabber an open-source instant-messaging company , and is focused on increasing Linux TCP/IP concurrent connection support from the current 20,000 to greater than 64,000 .
Under the lab 's operating policies , first announced in August , the OSDL does not create projects but supports and accelerates existing or new projects developed by the open-source community .
Under the lab 's charter , all projects will adhere to the open-source development model .
The lab houses several servers that interface with high-speed Internet communications links , creating a virtual lab that can be accessed by developers around the world .
Future open-source development lab locations around the globe will also be linked together with OSDL to provide a unified virtual development environment .
Computer Associates , Fujitsu and Hitachi joined original lab sponsors Hewlett-Packard , Intel , IBM and NEC in supporting the lab .
Miracle Linux , Mitsubishi and Covalent joined original members Caldera , Dell , Linuxcare , LynuxWorks , Red Hat , SGI , SuSE , TurboLinux and VA Linux as additional contributors and sponsors .
" The Open Source Development Lab provides tremendous resources that enable collaborative development of enterprise-class capabilities in Linux , " said Dr. Larry M. Augustin , president and CEO of VA Linux Systems .
" Projects supported by the lab will further accelerate the acceptance of open-source solutions in large-scale business environments . "




Armor : The Things They 'll Carry

Battlefield armor is making a comeback .
While long out of style for soldiers , the sight of armor from any era or culture can fire even the most pacifist civilian 's inner Mongol warrior .
The stormtroopers in Star Wars clattered about convincingly , and Sigourney Weaver in her kickboxing forklift in Aliens continues to spark fantasies .
The Knights of the Round Table conjure images of epic battles in the Crusades .
Now the past and the future are ready to deliver a mechanical offspring to the present .
The Department of Defense 's primary research and development organization -- the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency -- is soliciting proposals for a $ 50 million project to develop an " exoskeleton " for battlefield soldiers .
DARPA expects the first trials by 2005 , according to its site .
If the trials are successful , it will be the first appearance of battlefield armor since the 17th century .
The exoskeleton itself is a frame that fits over the body .
Designed to be smart and strong -- and , as DARPA said on its website , to provide " increased unit survivability and lethality " -- it is supposed to help its wearers move faster and farther with heavier loads and larger weaponry .
For hundreds of years , European armor got bigger and bulkier until modern weaponry and warfare made it more of a liability than an advantage .
The fully armored knight , a formidable presence on a medieval battlefield , eventually became a sitting duck for archers equipped with an ever-evolving array of crossbows .
Later , the development of firearms rendered any kind of armor useless .
It was n't until World War I that the protective helmet was revived to provide some protection from weather , shrapnel and the occasional glancing bullet .
Since then , keeping soldiers light , dry and comfortable has been more vital than loading them up with bulky armor that usually does n't work .
More recently , studies have found that soldiers tend to dump heavy equipment before marching long distances .
Currently , soldiers carry about a third of their body weight , one of the main issues for the exoskeleton 's designers .
DARPA spokeswoman Jan Walker said the exoskeleton 's power plant not only must run for at least a 24-hour stretch , it also must be light , as must be the material that forms the exoskeleton itself .
According to John Knowles , publisher of the defense industry newsletter , The Knowles Report , weight is a deciding factor in whether the exoskeleton ever sees the heat of battle .
" How realistic is it to put this stuff on this guy ? "
Knowles said . "
In war games , soldiers are constantly pulling this stuff off . "
Retired Army Col. Daniel Smith , chief of research at the Center for Defense Information , calls attention to the Army 's recently-adopted motto , " An army of one . "
The idea of individual , super-armored soldiers " seems almost a parody of that , " he said , adding that large numbers of soldiers will always be more effective than a few heavily-armed ones .
" I can n't see that it would be a cost effective use of resources , " he said .
DARPA has put together an extensive standard equipment list for the exoskeletons .
It includes a visor that expands the field of vision , as well as devices to provide information about battlefield conditions , coordinate other soldiers and decrease friendly-fire casualties .
Other possibilities are systems to monitor a soldier 's health and wireless communications networks .
Helping soldiers march , lift and leap to extraordinary heights and distances will be among the exoskeleton 's main attributes .
Knowles and Walker agree that the exoskeleton would have to be physically intuitive , that is , to know when a soldier is walking or running , lifting or bending .
One of the " technological challenges " posed by DARPA 's proposal is the development of haptic interfaces , which would allow the exoskeleton to respond to touch .
" We do n't want &#91;soldiers&#93 ; to have to press buttons , " Walker said .
There 's even a chance that exoskeletons -- with their ability to increase carrying loads -- could help integrate women into combat situations .
Knowles said that in terms of marksmanship and other combat skills , " Women have proven themselves very equal . "
The prevailing argument against women in combat is that most can n't meet the job 's physical requirements .
Exoskeletons , said Knowles , could " radically equalize that , " thus enabling a 130-pound woman to lift , carry and be as effective as a 180-pound man .
The most challenging aspect for the project will be taking it from blueprint to reality .
" There are a lot of people in the U.S. Army that want to ditch this enhancement program , " Knowles said . "
Any fighter in the field is trained not to trust technology . "
That is to say , things break .
Visors can block gun sights ; the exoskeleton can run out of fuel or become damaged , rendering it little more than a heavy frame .
Knowles says that most battlefield technology must be something that the average high school graduate can operate and repair .
DARPA 's Walker said it 's possible that only a few soldiers , maybe those who are carrying the heaviest gear , will wear them .
The exoskeleton may be used primarily by special forces , at least at first , Knowles said .
While infantry soldiers go into battle with plenty of support , special forces operatives are often on their own and could use the performance boost that powered body armor would provide .
In the end , the multitude of technologies within the system must not only be rugged and dependable , but work together to assist and protect the human inside without pinning him or her down .
Walker said the exoskeleton 's designers must produce a wearable technology with the range of movement to match the human body .
" That 's a significant challenge . "




A Bad Day for Microsoft Sites

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Microsoft technicians struggled since early Wednesday morning to return service to the company 's main websites : Microsoft.com , MSN.com , MSNBC.com , WindowsMedia.com , Encarta.com and Carpoint.com .
By mid-afternoon Wednesday , service was slowly being restored to Microsoft 's main websites , and users on the East Coast reported that they were able to access their Hotmail accounts and the support sections at Microsoft.com .
EST
Users on the West Coast were still experiencing problems .
Microsoft spokesman Adam Sohn said he did not think Hotmail service , which provides free , Web-based e-mail to more than 74 million users worldwide , was affected by the outage .
But Hotmail service was unavailable to many users on Wednesday morning , and was finally restored late Wednesday afternoon .
The company 's U.S. websites appeared to be the victim of a problem with DNS routing , the database that translates the names of URLs to the actual number addresses of the servers where the Web pages are stored .
A company spokesman confirmed that " some " Microsoft websites were down due to problems with Microsoft 's own Domain Name System servers , and said the company was working as quickly as it could to solve the problem .
DNS
Contradicting earlier assurances , however , Sohn now says Microsoft is not ruling out the possibility that its problems may stem from a denial-of-service attack by crackers , something the company had vehemently denied earlier on Wednesday .
" We 're not ruling anything out at this point .
There 's not enough data at this point , but the guys are working as quick as they can to get it diagnosed , treated and cured . "
Sohn said
Although originally confined to the U.S. and U.K. sites , Microsoft also confirmed that it heard from customers in Europe and Australia who were having problems accessing the company 's various websites as well .
The company said the problem , which began late Tuesday night , was not due to anyone outside the company accessing its servers , but is solely an internal difficulty .
A Microsoft network administrator working on the problems said that Wednesday was " the worst day of my professional life . "
He requested that his name not be used .
" DNS servers have outages , it 's a fact of life .
I 've been through it before and I 'd bet so has every network administrator of a major business , " he said . "
You always have to scramble to fix them .
You work like crazy while people bellow ' Why are n't we up yet ?
' But knowing that the eyes of millions are upon you and wondering why you are n't up yet either adds a very special and sharp edge to what we 're going through here today .
" We are also getting a lot of visits from people who are checking our sites just out of curiosity , which is slowing access to the parts of the network that are up and running .
So yes , I 'd like to tell the world we 're down , we 'll be up as soon as possible , we are horribly sorry , please put yourself in our shoes and have a little patience . "
Access to Microsoft 's websites was still possible for some users , however , by bypassing the domain name server and using this URL : http://207.46.230.218/ms.htm .
Hotmail can also be reached by selecting MSN along the left-hand rail under Web Services , and then Hotmail from MSN 's front page .
Since Microsoft 's U.S. pages were accessible via this method , it would indicate that Microsoft was not suffering from a cracker attack such as a denial of service -- which would have made the sites totally inaccessible -- but instead had internal problems with its own DNS routing .
These access failures were only the latest in a string of problems and apparent attacks that have plagued Microsoft 's network of websites all over the world during the last several days .
Security experts affirm that the most recent problem did n't appear to be the work of crackers , but vandals have hit two of Microsoft 's sites this week .
Microsoft 's New Zealand and Australian sites were altered by crackers who left behind testy text messages .
Evan Whiting , a network administrator for New York State , said he believed the problem originates within Microsoft .




U.S. to Clone Brit Policy ?

Researchers in Britain are now allowed to clone human embryos .
But do n't expect that to be a sign of things to come in the United States .
The landmark decision , finalized on Tuesday by the House of Lords , is hailed by some scientists as a step forward in the fight against debilitating disease .
Researchers say cloned embryos could mean faster treatments for Parkinson 's disease , spinal cord injury , heart disease and any other condition involving the death of cells .
But not everyone applauds embryonic cloning , and it 's doubtful the Bush administration would ever approve of such a thing .
The prospect of cloning human embryos raises the dander of everyone from the religious right to scientists .
Many detractors see the procedure as essentially creating human beings , then killing them .
What 's clear is that Tuesday 's decision gives Britain a leg up in medical research .
But that may not be a persuasive argument to sway the new U.S. president .
" While one might argue that the U.K. has positioned itself to have a competitive edge in this research , I am not convinced that this would be sufficient for the Bush administration to take a position that would alienate so many of its own supporters and even some of the supporters of the Clinton administration and Gore-Lieberman ticket , " said Dr. R. Alta Charo , a professor of law and medical ethics at the University of Wisconsin in Madison , and member of the National Bioethics Advisory Committee .
Bush has already promised to re-evaluate Clinton 's decision last year to allow federally funded embryonic stem cell research , with the condition that government money is not used in the creation or destruction of the cells .
A glimmer of hope for stem cell research advocates is the fact that Bush has nominated Wisconsin Governor Tommy Thompson as director of the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services .
Thompson is anti-abortion , but praised the University of Wisconsin biologist who isolated the first embryonic stem cells in 1998 .
In fact , he held a party to celebrate it .
Stem cell research is a step before embryonic cloning .
There 's no indication it will be approved in the U.S. when basic stem cell research is still tenuous , and experts think U.S. scientists are missing out .
Mark Frankel , director of the program on scientific freedom , responsibility and law at the American Association for the Advancement of Science lamented that the U.S. will remain on the outskirts of the most exciting stem cell research .
" It puts the British in a position to make research gains in understanding because of a more permissive policy than in the U.S. , " he said .
Stem cells can grow , or differentiate , into every type of cell in the body , and many scientists say their powers of renewal are the only hope for people with certain debilitating diseases and injuries .
Stem cells taken from embryos have been shown to be the most powerful kind .
Embryonic stem cells are most often collected following in vitro fertilization , a technique that produces thousands of extra embryonic cells that are otherwise discarded .
A company called Geron in Menlo Park , California already has heart cells that beat in a petri dish .
GERN
They were grown from stem cells , and company researchers hope they can one day be injected into a damaged heart to repair it .
Taking the concept a step further , if scientists can first clone an embryo from someone with , say , heart disease , they can create a stem cell treatment that 's a perfect DNA match , with no worries of the patient rejecting the cells .
British parliament members came to the decision after a seven-hour debate .
The legislation includes a mandate that any clone will be allowed to live no longer than 14 days .
" Even though I do n't welcome the approval of embryonic cloning , I think they have blocked one of the worst consequences of it which is making cloned people , " said Stuart Newman , a professor of cell biology and anatomy at the New York Medical College in Valhalla , New York .
The 14-day mandate is no comfort at all , however , to anti-abortion activists like Father Howard , who believe that human life begins the moment an embryo is formed .
" It 's wrong for them to create the clone and then it 's wrong for them to kill a clone , " said Father Joseph Howard , director of the American Life League Bioethics Advisory Commission . "
It 's immoral .
Once it is created it should be protected to live , so killing it is an equally grave offense . "
Newman does worry , however , what precedent this sets for embryonic cloning in other countries that might not make the same stipulation .
It sets up the potential for bringing human clones to term , Newman said .
" That is potentially troublesome , " he said .
Then there 's the Human Cloning Foundation , which as the name suggests , advocates human cloning .
The group applauds any step that brings research closer to achieving human cloning .
" We are thrilled because what they 've passed is going to perfect the central technique of cloning , which is nuclear transfer , " said Randolfe Wicker , the founder of the Human Cloning Foundation as well as the Clone Rights United Front .
Nuclear transfer is taking the nucleus of a regular cell and placing it inside an egg from which the nucleus has been removed .
Dolly the cloned sheep was made that way , as are myriad cloned mammals like cows , mice , pigs and goats .
Wicker hopes the decision in Britain will temper Bush 's view , and the anti-abortionist ripple effect on stem cell research .
" These people could literally put America behind in medicine , " he said . "
Any scientist will say : ' You 're not even allowing us to play in the caboose and the British are in the engine !
' "




How , Why Microsoft Went Down

Microsoft 's websites were offline for up to 23 hours -- the most dramatic snafu to date on the Internet -- because of an equipment misconfiguration , the company says .
A series of problems centering around its collection of routers in Canyon Park , Wash. -- near the company 's headquarters -- is what the company blames for knocking out dozens of Microsoft properties including hotmail.com and msn.com , frustrating millions of users and providing acute embarrassment for a company that is offering the promise of unprecedented reliability in marketing its Internet products .
MSFT
" We screwed up .
night at around 6:30 p.m.
Tuesday
Pacific time we made a configuration change to the routers on the DNS network , " spokesman Adam Sohn said Wednesday evening .
The company said in a statement that it took nearly a day to determine what was wrong and undo the changes .
Microsoft 's sites -- including microsoft.com , slate.com , expedia.com and msnbc.com -- started to work properly again at about 4:30 p.m. , PST , Wednesday .
Media Metrix reports that the combined properties , not including news sites , received 54 million unique visitors in December .
Technical experts blame Microsoft 's design decisions for exacerbating its woes .
All the affected Microsoft sites rely on just four Windows servers , located in the company 's Canyon Park data center , to forward users to the right destination via the Domain Name System .
DNS
Because all four DNS servers -- which translate names like microsoft.com into its 207.46.230.218 numeric address -- share the same routers , all are vulnerable to hardware glitches or a technician 's error .
" Sure , small organizations have their DNS servers located together and there 's nothing wrong with that , " says Rich Kulawiec , a consultant with 20 years of networking experience . "
But national or global organizations should , as standard operating procedure , have their DNS servers on different networks served by different ISPs and running on different operating systems -- Solaris and FreeBSD , or Linux and HPUX -- so as to minimize the threats for DoS attacks , known OS vulnerabilities , and connectivity issues . "
Some companies already offer supra-reliable DNS to nervous customers worried about downtime .
Nominium , a Redwood City , Calif. startup , boasts it has many collections of DNS servers , each with at least two different hardware and OS platforms , and each connected to two different ISPs .
" If an entire site fails , the other sites around the world would continue to serve customers ' domain data , " the company 's white paper says .
Nominium
Ultradns.com offers a similar service .
" The problem that Microsoft is experiencing once again illustrates the fact that even if you are a technically competent organization , your business is at significant risk without a highly reliable DNS infrastructure , " said William Thomas , president and CEO of Nominum , Inc.
Making matters worse for Microsoft 's frantic technicians was that they were racing against time : For efficiency 's sake , ISPs , corporations and universities keep caches of the numeric IP addresses of frequently-visited sites .
But caches began to expire at different times across the Internet yesterday , which meant Microsoft 's properties began to fade , gradually , from public view .
" Anybody who knew anything about this and could be helpful dropped everything , " Microsoft 's Sohn said .
Sohn said : " We spent a lot of time diagnosing every single scenario we could think of : whether it was a denial of service attack , whether it was an .
equipment malfunction
We had little mini-teams off triaging all of this stuff and eliminating scenarios as fast as we could . "




Startups Not Out of Ideas

LA QUINTA , California -- Despite dot-coms dropping like flies , several brave entrepreneurs pitched their ideas for the " next big thing " to venture capitalists at Upside magazine 's Showcase 2001 .
In a reflection of the times , only one of the 82 companies exhibiting at the show had a name beginning with a lowercase ' e ' and ending with a ' .com , ' eWanted , a buy/sell service similar to eBay .
The show , designed to be a more intimate introduction of new products to the press and VCs than a trade show , featured a mixture of items for consumers and businesses . "
This show is all about launching new and interesting products that can n't get easily noticed at Comdex , " said Upside executive editor Jesse Berst , in his first year heading up the show .
Among the more interesting ideas was Uplister , a community for swapping user-made lists of MP3 files .
The idea behind Uplister is this : People make their mix list of MP3 songs for whatever moves them -- exercise , depression , romance or user-defined lists , like I Work for Satan .
Then people can share their lists , which are hyperlinked to more information on the artists as well as links to buy the CD .
Where you get the MP3s is between you and your conscience .
Napster may be sued into oblivion , " but Napster as an idea will n't go away , " said Rob Reid , CEO of online music site Listen.com .
For phone fanatics with home , business , mobile phones or pagers , SimulRing enables all lines to ring at once .
A user is assigned a single phone number , which will ring up to six of the customer 's pre-defined phone numbers at the same time -- figuring that he or she is liable to be at one of the numbers .
If the customer somehow manages to dodge six bullets , the call goes to the voice mail box of his or her choice .
The selling point is that users can put one number on their business cards , not six , and if they change cellular service or move , they simply make the change to the SimulRing service .
ArialPhone is offering a one-ounce ear piece phone that uses voice recognition technology to input phone numbers or dial by name .
The ArialPhone is inspired by the ear piece worn by Lieutenant Uhuru in Star Trek , and will cost $ 399 when it ships in May .
The whole phone is in the ear piece , which is approximately the size of Uhuru 's original prop .
Its logo looks similar to that of Star Trek 's Star Fleet , which may not go over well with Paramount Pictures .
During their demonstration , ArialPhone 's team called Berst 's SimulRing number , which to his annoyance was shown on the overhead screen to the audience .
AlphaGrip pitched a keyboard for the Nintendo generation which is accustomed to handheld controllers .
It looks like a fatter version of a Nintendo or PlayStation controller , but with a batch of buttons on both sides .
The company estimates people will be able to type at up to 50 words per minute , after a rather hefty learning curve .
AlphaGrip does n't have an OEM partner , but expects the unit will sell for under $ 100 when it hits the market .
Presenters varied from the cool and collected to the very nervous as they received feedback from the audience . "
Between the VCs and all the public relations people , have a lot of opportunities to get some advice , " said Amy Wohl , president of Wohl Associates , a market research and analysis firm in Narberth , Pennsylvania .
demonstrators
Wohl admits the first time she saw TiVo 's digital video recorder demonstrated she did n't get it , mostly due to the presentation .
But Wohl saw some future winners at Showcase . "
I see a lot of stuff that , with fine tuning , could be very successful . "




Microsoft 's Web Still Tangled

Reader 's advisory : Wired News has been unable to confirm some sources for a number of stories written by this author .
If you have any information about sources cited in this article , please send an e-mail to sourceinfo&#91;AT&#93;wired.com .
Just when Microsoft thought its Web server woes were resolved , they returned .
After Wednesday 's day-long failure that blocked users from its sites around the world , Microsoft released a statement indicating that it had fixed the problem .
But the software giant 's servers began once again to experience intermittent failures in the U.S. around midday Thursday , and shortly after failed completely for the second time , once again blocking access to Microsoft 's primary website .
Meanwhile , Microsoft 's UK website returned messages saying , " Server too busy -- The request can not be processed at this time .
The amount of traffic exceeds the Web site 's configured capacity , " before trying to redirect visitors to the company 's main site .
" If they had done their job right in the first place , it simply would not have mattered that if a router went down , because there would have been no single point of failure in their DNS setup , " said Greg Keefe , the owner and operator of DNS service provider HammerNode.com .
" But even the problem with their router is a sorry excuse for two days of DNS server problems .
They should have backup equipment ready to go at a moment 's notice for this type of emergency , " said Keefe .
Attempts to contact Microsoft 's servers by pinging them showed that they had again ceased to resolve Microsoft 's domain names , or the connection stalls and times out before information can be retrieved , another indicator of DNS routing problems .
Pinging is a network communication that allows remote verification of the status of a server .
" I work with DNS on a near constant basis , and I can say that Microsoft 's DNS configuration equals the membership dues for the sub-fifty IQ club .
They operate four DNS servers for their domain , which sounds good -- but when those servers are all within the same building , or on the same network , as it appears with Microsoft 's case , then the advantages disappear , " Keefe said .
" A move this dumb from a company touting reliability makes me wonder how they ever got to where they 're at . "
Adam Sohn , spokesman for Microsoft , said he was unaware of any new troubles Thursday with Microsoft sites .
Others speculated on the effect two days of failures would have on the companies " .net " software services initiative , the company 's newest pet project .
Microsoft is redesigning Windows software so that it can be delivered over networks on demand along with data instead of requiring it to be installed on computers .
" Can you imagine the problems this would cause if you were having your applications served up from a MS server as they are proposing in their.net plan .
It 's amazing the one single company 's inability to manage their own network could have such an effect on so many computer users , and this is without all their .net offers , " said one Wired News reader who wished to remain anonymous , via e-mail .
Microsoft said yesterday that its problems began when a set of four DNS servers operated by the company failed late Tuesday , leaving many Microsoft sites inaccessible to the public .
DNS servers are analogous to an Internet business phone book : They translate computer names into the numbers that are needed to actually access the computer .
Domain Name System
When DNS servers for a company become unavailable for any reason , it becomes difficult or impossible for most people to reach that company 's Web servers or other systems .
an attack or a system failure
This is what happened at Microsoft : A router problem made its DNS servers inaccessible .
The four DNS servers that Microsoft operates are listed as being on the same subnet , or within a grouping of IP addresses .
This usually means they are in close proximity on the network and often close physically as well .
sometimes in the same building
The servers are located in Canyon Park , Washington .
" This is not a robust design .
Whether the system was hacked or suffered a systemic failure , Microsoft will likely be reviewing its DNS architecture in the near future , " said Ric Steinberger , technical director for news website Security Portal .
Open source programmers , who are often critical of Microsoft , cheerfully noted that without the company 's insistence on strictly controlling information about its inner workings and products , problems like this would n't have as devastating an impact on users .
" I could n't even imagine this happening to Linux developer .
The sites we use to develop are mirrored in so many places that if one site is down , there are often so many mirrors to the site available that you have trouble selecting which one to use , " e-mailed another Wired News reader .
" Under the .net plan MS is developing , if the server supplying applications to a company was to go down , every single person in the company would be forced to stop using their computers while the problem was rectified . "




One Giant Leap for Reality TV

Proving that the space race did n't end with the Cold War , television production companies in the United States , Great Britain and Germany are scrambling to be the first to launch winning reality-TV contestants into orbit .
Indeed , next-generation reality TV is starting to look a bit like Star Trek : The Next Generation .
Networks are announcing new programs that promise to take the popular primetime format one step beyond .
Unfortunately , a few logistical details -- such as how , exactly , the contestants will be transported into space and where to put them when they get there -- may make these planned programs more fantasy than reality for now .
You 'll have to be satisfied with the likes of Temptation Island and The Mole for the time being .
But just maybe -- if you wish upon a star -- we 'll soon be blasting guys like Rich Hatch off our planet .
NBC has the first-mover advantage with this new twist on the genre .
It said in September it was teaming up with the producers of last year 's hit series Survivor to launch a civilian-in-space contest that would air in fall 2001 .
This new " reality adventure series " promised to stick with Survivor 's Darwinian process-of-elimination premise -- except this time , the stakes would be sky-high .
Destination Mir would follow 12 or 13 American civilians through several weeks of grueling physical and psychological trials at a Russian cosmonaut training camp near Moscow .
Each week , one unlucky contestant would be sent home .
The last remaining contestant would win a trip to space , traveling in style aboard a Soyuz spacecraft bound for the Mir Space Station .
NBC planned to cover the winner 's journey and space station visit , as well as his or her eventual return to Earth .
Of course , there 's a glitch .
While Destination Mir has all the makings of a millennial blockbuster , it 's lacking one critical element : a destination .
A month after NBC announced a call for contestants , the Russians said they might retire the nearly 14-year-old space station , which had become too expensive to maintain .
The Russian Aviation and Space Agency and Mir 's operator , RKK Energia , set March 6 , 2001 , as the day for administering a " killing pulse " to the trusty space pad , putting it out of orbit once and for all .
According to MSNBC , the producers of Destination Mir are now setting their sights on the International Space Station as an alternate landing strip .
But the ISS will n't be finished until at least 2006 , and NASA said it will n't consider having TV visitors until then .
Both NBC and the Mark Burnett Production company would n't comment on Destination Mir , saying that production of the series is not yet under way .
When announcing the show last September , however , NBCi president Edmond Sancti said , " We are excited to provide our members a unique chance to compete to take the ultimate trip to space and to offer TV viewers and Web users a compelling online destination to participate in this fascinating reality drama . "
The network launched an Internet portal to tie in with the planned series , where it continues to pre-register potential contestants .
Germany may not have been a strong contender in the last space race , but German TV does n't intend to be left behind in this one .
In December , the German television production company Brainpool TV announced it had already invested $ 7.5 million in a new series called Space Commander .
Seven winners , one from each season , will be rocketed to the International Space Station between 2002 and 2008 .

Sony said on Thursday its profits sagged in the last three months of 2000 , hit by production glitches on its flagship PlayStation 2 game console and lingering strength in the yen .
The results were slightly better than expectations , but are unlikely to lift a cloud cast over the firm 's prospects by a slowing U.S. economy and the doubtful health of a gaming division on which it has staked so much .
Its operating profit fell 11 percent to 146.47 billion yen in the crucial October-December period , which provides more than 50 percent of total profits , compared to expectations of a 15 to 27 percent fall .
$ 1.24 billion
" The profit decline came largely from the weak game sector , which will continue to be a drag for a while , " said Tsubasa Securities analyst Yukihiro Yoshida . "
I see more downward risk for the firm 's earnings for the full year and the game sector 's performance will continue to be the focus . "
Since the March launch of the latest version of the smash-hit PlayStation , Sony 's shares have fallen about 45 percent to trade around 8,700 yen , hitting a 16-month low of 7,510 yen on December 22 .
The stock closed down 0.82 percent at 8,510 yen on Thursday before the earnings release .
Sony says the PlayStation 's problems have now been ironed out , although analysts worry initial production delays mean it failed to maximize overseas sales during the crucial Christmas period , leaving it vulnerable to competition from rival consoles .

Europe 's data is showing : Despite tighter regulations , European websites are no better at protecting the privacy of visitors than their U.S. counterparts , according a study released on Thursday .
Two-thirds of websites in the United States and Europe surveyed by the advocacy group Consumers International collected personal data from visitors , but only a few of those gave visitors the option of limiting how that information was used .
Concerns about the use of personal data , such as names , birth dates and addresses for marketing purposes have increased in recent years with the growth of the Internet .
Unlike the United States , the European Union places tight restrictions on how businesses may use such data .
But the study found that the most popular U.S. websites were more likely to give users a choice about being added to their mailing list than leading European sites .
